headline: Coil Extends Bob Baffert’s Domination of the Haskell

He captured much of the sexually explicit action with his video camera.

headline: Drug Kingpin Wanted in U.S. Is Held in Mexico

headline: Becoming the Party of Freedom
text: Republicans began the Civil War as the party of Union, not the party of Freedom. They did not become the celebrated destroyers of slavery until almost two years into the war, with the Emancipation Proclamation, issued Jan. 1, 1863. But during the summer of 1861 the direction of change was unmistakable, as Republicans took the first, crucial steps in a mounting attack on the South’s “peculiar institution.” Long-held beliefs about the immorality of slavery combined with the challenges posed by an escalating conflict, explain the evolving outlook of the Republicans.

headline: It’s Getting Better
text: It has been a very good few weeks in the fight for gay equality. Last Tuesday, two days after same-sex couples began marrying in New York, the state’s attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, filed a brief in federal court challenging the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act, the odious law that bars federal recognition of same-sex unions. It was the latest in a welcome string of developments promoting fairness for gay men and lesbians.

headline: Retirees Say Players Shouldn’t Have Negotiated for Them

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Subway System
text: For two years, Jay Walder, an internationally known transportation expert, has been running the antiquated New York City mass-transit system with quiet efficiency. He has limited the failures dramatically, started new countdown clocks in subways and cut costs — $500 million last year, more than $600 million in 2011.

headline: About That Salmon
text: In 2007, a virus called infectious salmon anemia started killing millions of farm-raised salmon in Chile and devastated Chilean aquaculture. The virus was first detected in 1984 — long before salmon farming had spread around the globe — but what made it so lethal in 2007 was overcrowding in the offshore salmon pens and the fact that salmon were being raised in the midst of their own pollution. No one knew how the virus was transmitted, but a 2008 study at the University of Bergen determined it was carried in salmon eggs exported from Norway to Chile.

headline: Ohio: Man Kills 1 and Hurts 3 Near Outdoor Concert
text: A man fired several shots from a handgun in a fight near an outdoor concert in Cleveland that featured the funk artist George Clinton, killing a 16-year-old boy and wounding three other people, the police said Sunday. The fight erupted before 10 p.m. Saturday at an intersection near Luke Easter Park, where the eighth annual Unity in the Park festival was held. The police did not give a description of the gunman, and they said that no arrests had been made. It was unclear how long after Mr. Clinton or other musicians had performed that the shooting happened or what prompted it. The police said they did not know if those involved in the fight were among concertgoers leaving the area. The teenager died early Sunday of a gunshot wound to the head, the authorities said. The conditions of the three other three were not available. They were a 20-year-old woman shot in the neck, and a 14-year-old boy and 23-year-old man, each hospitalized with leg wounds. (AP)

headline: The Diminished President
text: By rights, Barack Obama should be emerging as the big political winner in the debt ceiling debate. For months, he’s positioned himself near the center of public opinion, leaving Republicans to occupy the rightward flank. Poll after poll suggests that Americans prefer the president’s call for a mix of spending cuts and tax increases to the Republican Party’s anti-tax approach. Poll after poll shows that House Republicans, not Obama, would take most of the blame if the debt ceiling weren’t raised.

headline: Heading Overseas in Name of Solidarity May Prove Divisive

headline: To Escape Chaos, a Terrible Deal
text: There is little to like about the tentative agreement between Congressional leaders and the White House except that it happened at all. The deal would avert a catastrophic government default, immediately and probably through the end of 2012. The rest of it is a nearly complete capitulation to the hostage-taking demands of Republican extremists. It will hurt programs for the middle class and poor, and hinder an economic recovery.

headline: Hopeful, but Wary at Money Markets

headline: How Far Will Republicans Go to Avoid Defense Cuts?

headline: Exciting New Sources of Contradictory Advice
text: I have always been a better reader than athlete, and as a teenager, I imagined that I could improve my golf game just from studying a book, “Five Lessons: The Modern Fundamentals of Golf,” by Ben Hogan. It took me years, during which I may have done myself permanent damage, before I realized that the Hogan swing, with its emphasis on pronation (whatever that is) and rapidly unwinding the hips, only makes sense if you’re Ben Hogan. If you’re me — and if you’re you, probably — the Hogan swing works about as well as a car engine that has thrown a rod.

headline: Madrid to Gather for Annual Religious Festivals
text: Despite the often oppressive temperatures, Madrileños take to the streets from Aug. 3 to 15 to honor the saints Cayetano and Lorenzo and the Virgin of Paloma in some of the most popular and traditional fairs of the year. Held in some of the city’s oldest neighborhoods — Lavapies, La Latina and las Vistillas — the spirited celebrations feature processions, plays, games, food, races and concerts, often with people dressing up in old-fashioned costumes. Films and magic shows entertain the children, while adults enjoy chess tournaments and art exhibitions.

headline: Japanese Lawmakers Denied Entry in South Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Airport immigration officials denied entry to three Japanese lawmakers on Monday, thwarting their plan to travel close to a set of tiny islands claimed by South Korea and Japan. The trio then refused for hours to board a return flight home in the confrontation, which has laid bare longstanding animosities between the two countries rooted in Japan’s colonialist past.

headline: Complaint Box | Water Wasters

headline: Why the Jets Picked Plaxico Burress Over Braylon Edwards
text: So the deed is done. The Jets made a big splash by signing wide receiver Plaxico Burress to play opposite Santonio Holmes. Edwards, a key player for the Jets in the last two seasons, will not be back. And the speculation? It’s that the Jets wanted Burress over Edwards primarily to grab attention in the New York market and get one-up on the Giants, their co-tenants at the New Meadowlands Stadium. The reasoning hints that Edwards wasn’t flashy enough for the “Hard Knocks” Jets. They even gave Burress the No. 17 worn by Edwards.

headline: The Hawks’ Dilemma
text: There’s plenty to be said about the details of the debt ceiling deal, but let’s start with the provision that’s making conservatives unhappiest: The use of broad defense cuts as part of the “trigger” mechanism that would automatically slash spending if the latest deficit commission’s recommendations can’t pass Congress. (See Rich Lowry, Bill Kristol, Yuval Levin, and others for expressions of concern and/or outright alarm.) In effect, defense cuts assumed the role that liberals wanted revenue increases to play in these negotiations, becoming the place where Republicans would give a little in order to get the deal they wanted done.

headline: Where’s My Relief Rally?
text: Weren’t we supposed to have a big rally in the stock market now that the threat of default was past and our deficit was on the way to being solved?

headline: Monday Motorsports: Back-to-Back McLaren Victories Put Red Bull on the Defensive
text: Sebastian Vettel may have finished first in qualifying for the Hungarian Grand Prix on Saturday, but as heavily favored teams in the National Football League can slip on any given Sunday, so, too, can dominant Formula One drivers, especially in the wet.

headline: One Supercongress to Rule Them All
text: John Quiggin on the “Mordor-inspired debt ceiling deal“, as analyzed by Gollum and Smeagol.

headline: A Broken Record
text: The record has fallen. As expected, “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” set an attendance record for a fashion exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art over the weekend. As of Sunday night, more than 582,000 people had seen the show, surpassing the previous record of 576,000 set by “Superheroes: Fashion and Fantasy” in 2008. And McQueen still has a week to go, with plans to keep the show open until midnight on its final two days, Aug. 6 and 7.

headline: For Him, Amateur Night at the Apollo Is Anything But
text: To someone stepping off a stifling hot 125th Street, the Apollo Theater — cool, dark and empty, as it was on a recent afternoon — felt like hallowed space. A tap-dancing man in a fedora beat out rhythms onstage, while a few musicians stood together collectively improvising a new song.

headline: A Bigger ‘Battle of the Buildings’
text: Imagine the TV show “The Biggest Loser,” only the contestants are big buildings, and instead of competing to shed unwanted pounds, it’s a race to reduce unnecessary energy consumption.

headline: Meanwhile, in the Global Economy
text: Bad news all over. In the US, Manufacturing growth hits lowest level in 2 years. In Europe, my favorite current indicator of the eurozone crisis, the Italy-Germany bond spread, has blown out again. And while part of this is due to falling German rates — which, like falling US rates, reflect growing pessimism about growth — the Italian bond rate is once again at 6 percent, a level that invites a self-fulfilling debt spiral.

headline: Giants Allow Umenyiora’s Agent to Seek a Trade
text: The Giants have given Osi Umenyiora’s agent permission to seek a trade.

headline: Small City, Big Debt Problems
text: Even as officials in Washington pledged to cut domestic spending, the city of Central Falls, R.I., landed in bankruptcy court on Monday, a stark reminder that some American cities have debts so overwhelming that no amount of belt tightening can set things right.

headline: N.C.A.A. Penalties Erase Wins but Not Memories
text: The University of Hawaii won a men’s volleyball championship in 2002. Or did it? Coach John Calipari earned his 500th college basketball victory last season. Or did he?

headline: The Ultimate Memento for Katharine Hepburn Fans
text: The Connecticut home where Katharine Hepburn retired and lived until her death in 2003 at age 96 is up for sale, according to The Associated Press. The estate, in Old Saybrook on Long Island Sound, is on the market for $28 million. The house — which the owners have by combining rooms created larger, more open spaces — can be purchased separately for $18 million. Seven years ago, the property sold for $6 million. Hepburn won four Oscars and received 12 nominations over her 60-year career.

headline: Westwood One and Dial Global to Merge
text: Westwood One, a radio network that distributes talk show hosts including Dennis Miller and call-in programs including “Loveline,” is merging with Dial Global, a radio syndication and advertising network, the two companies announced on Monday.

headline: American Airlines Hopes for a B.A. Merger
text: Could another big airline merger take off? The president of American Airlines‘ parent company hopes so.

headline: Israel Kills Two Palestinians as Raid in West Bank Refugee Camp Goes Awry
text: KALANDIA, West Bank — Israeli forces killed two Palestinians in a refugee camp here early Monday after raiding several houses and being set upon by stone-throwing Palestinians.

headline: If I Were In The House
text: I guess I have to be explicit at this point: yes, I would vote no.

headline: The Fine Print on the Debt Deal
text: If Democrats read the fine print on the debt deal struck by President Obama and Congressional leaders, they’ll find that it’s a little better than it appears at first glance.

headline: Leading Off: Two Sides of New York Football
text: It doesn’t take much deep thinking to divine the differences between New York’s two N.F.L. teams. One is a league stalwart, steered by a legendary football family, so buttoned down and traditional it refuses to employ cheerleaders. The other is the team of Broadway Joe, the all-you-can-eat bluster buffet that is Rex Ryan, a virtual halfway house of players with overflowing N.F.L rap sheets.

headline: Long Battle on Debt Ending as Senate Set for Final Vote
text: WASHINGTON — After months of partisan impasse, the House on Monday approved a budget agreement intended to head off a potential government default, pushing Congress a big step closer to the conclusion of a bitter fight that has left both parties bruised and exhausted.

headline: States and Cities Brace for Less Federal Money
text: LOS ANGELES — The deficit reduction deal reached in Washington produced some relief across the country on Monday, as the nation appeared to have avoided default. But it also produced a sharp wave of anxiety among governors and mayors worried about how the cuts might hurt already beleaguered states and cities, and it sowed anger and cynicism among many Americans about leaders in Washington.

headline: A race to the bottom of the ocean, an extinct marsupial comes to life and the psychology of addiction.
text: William J. Broad on plans by billionaires to explore the deepest parts of the ocean; molecular biologist Sean Carroll on signs of the existence of an extinct marsupial near Australia; and Denise Grady with Dr. Richard Friedman, psychiatrist at Weill Cornell Medical Center in New York, about the science of addiction.

headline: The Federal Debt: When Compound Interest Is Crushing
text: The showdown over increasing the federal debt limit got me thinking about the power of compound interest. It’s always been one of the most powerful forces in the financial universe. And in the case of the debt ceiling, it appears that compound interest has the potential to become a crushing enemy.

headline: Google Acquires Dealmap
text: Google may have failed in its takeover attempt of Groupon last year, but it’s not giving up on the social shopping market.

headline: Could This Deal Raise Budget Deficits?
text: It is virtually impossible to think of the impact of the debt deal as doing anything to help the economy. But give Mr. Kroszner credit for trying, in today’s front-page article by Binyamin Appelbaum and Catherine Rampell.

headline: Talbots Attracts a Private Equity Firm
text: Talbots, the struggling women’s retailer with a stuffy image, has fallen out of favor with shoppers. But it looks attractive to private equity.

headline: Look of the Moment | Emma Roberts
text: The Look: Lined up — wide white-on-white stripes add texture and intrigue to a clean, long-sleeve column dress.

headline: Packard Sells for $1.1 Million at Ex-Meadow Brook Concours
text: A custom-bodied Packard Twelve led sales at the auctions held by RM this past weekend at the Inn at St. John’s in Plymouth, Mich. The inn is the new site of the Concours d’Élégance of America, which relocated this summer after 32 years at Meadow Brook Hall.

headline: U.S. Military Claims Success Curbing Attacks in Iraq With Iranian Weapons
text: MOSUL, Iraq — Attacks by insurgents using what American analysts say are advanced Iranian weapons have dropped significantly over the last few weeks, senior American military officials said Monday, citing a two-track campaign of allied raids on Iranian-backed militants and official Iraqi protests to Tehran.

headline: Life Before and After a Child’s Diagnosis
text: For every parent of a child with a disability there is the moment they are given the news. And then there are the years spent responding to it.

headline: Hired to Fix U.S. Team, Klinsmann Says It’s Not Broken
text: After some of the recent performances by the men’s national soccer team, most notably in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa, in a friendly match against Spain and in the Gold Cup, many fans are convinced that the United States is an undeveloping soccer country, devolving instead of evolving.

headline: If It Ain’t Broke …
text: The recent results for the United States’ men’s national team have brought much gnashing of teeth among fans. But according to Juergen Klinsmann, the new coach, “there is nothing wrong with this team.” Klinsmann was introduced at a news conference Monday morning. Is Klinsmann correct, is this a case of fans’ impatience with a still maturing program, or is the coaching change just the first of several?

headline: Improve Your Backstroke While Staying Dry
text: Speedo has created a new interactive, online club for swimming enthusiasts that it hopes will help their training efforts and, more importantly, inspire them to buy merchandise.

headline: Interrupting Violence, on Screen and on the Streets
text: The men in orange and white Save Our Streets T-shirts were in a good mood.

headline: Buy This Apartment, and Get a Used Car Absolutely Free!
text: The offers crop up in listings and advertisements everywhere: Closing costs covered! A vintage car for the weekend! Money for summer camp!

headline: A Teachable Moment for Young Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — Crossing a generational divide in politics can be difficult, as former Gov.  Jon M. Huntsman Jr. of Utah, a candidate for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, made clear when he referred to “the Google” in a speech to kick off the annual convention of the College Republicans National Committee over the weekend.

headline: Oh Baby Answers Its Chicken-and-Egg Question
text: Last summer I wrote about Fran Free, founder of Oh Baby Foods. She faced the start-up’s classic chicken-egg dilemma. She wanted to land a large contract with a major retailer, but lacked the resources to fulfill it, partly because she worked out of a leased restaurant kitchen, where her maximum output was 300 cases of organic, locally sourced baby food a year. On the other hand, she couldn’t ramp up production without the promise of some much-needed business. Oh Baby’s 2010 monthly sales were about $2,000. While its customers are devoted, the company has not turned a profit.

headline: The Caucus | Politics of the Debt Deal
text: Aug. 1, 2011 - John Harwood and Jeff Zeleny on what the debt deal means for the 2012 election; and a sample of political reaction.

headline: In Middle East, a Restive First Day of Ramadan
text: Videos and messages posted online on Monday testified to a restive first day of Ramadan, the Muslim holy month, as a brutal crackdown continued in Syria, Egypt’s army destroyed a protest camp in Cairo’s central Tahrir Square and opposition fighters and government forces clashed in Yemen.

headline: Peak Performances’ Season Offers Eight Premieres
text: The Peak Performances series at Montclair State University in New Jersey will include eight world and American premieres starting Sept. 17. The season, which runs through May 5, will include premieres by, among others, Companhia Urbana de Dança|Sonia Destri of Brazil, Wayne McGregor|Random Dance and the Akram Khan Company from Britain, the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and Miguel Zenón from the United States.

headline: Hanna Segal, Who Popularized Play Therapy, Dies at 92
text: Hanna Segal, a British psychoanalyst who helped change child psychology in the United States by explaining and popularizing the play therapy techniques developed by her mentor, the seminal psychoanalytic thinker Melanie Klein, died on July 5 at her home in London. She was 92.

headline: Upper Half, Talking

headline: Braising Vegetables, a Turkish Delight
text: AMONG the culinary crimes committed by mid-20th-century American cooks, few were more heinous than the long, slow torture administered to boiled vegetables: green beans cooked to a gray mush, zucchini so squishy it was barely recognizable, tomatoes “stewed” into a formless mass.

headline: Help Wanted Ads Bode Ill for Jobs
text: If the debt deal passes on Monday in time to avert a federal default, all eyes will turn to the July jobs report coming Friday from the Labor Department. The last report, as you remember, was dismal: employers added just 18,000 net nonfarm payroll jobs in June.

headline: Winehouse Tops Album Chart in Britain
text: It is a sad truth, eloquently expressed by Joni Mitchell, that you don’t know what you’ve got until it’s gone. And judging by sales, the record-buying public seems to feel that way about Amy Winehouse, the troubled British soul singer found dead in her London home on July 23.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 1
text: A view of the day in sports, with fans showing up all over the world and N.F.L. training camps heating up.

headline: Battle of the Bands: Couples vs. Siblings
text: On paper, Mates of State have a few serious strikes against them. They’re a two-person band, which I’ve always found a little lame. They’re married. They live in the Connecticut suburbs. They’ve not only toured with their child; they’ve also written an online diary about it called — oh, no — “Band on the Diaper Run.” I mean, c’mon: what more could they possibly do to desecrate the spirit of rock?

headline: A Worker With No ID and Great Medical Need
text: In San Francisco, where bicycle commuters often wear full-body spandex suits, my patient Carlos could easily be spotted: the Mexican man in mustard-colored work boots and painter’s overalls stained with gear grease, furiously pedaling an adolescent’s red Huffy.

headline: Bradshaw Reaches Deal With Giants
text: The Giants signed running back Ahmad Bradshaw on Monday afternoon, solving one of their major problems on offense. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: In Iraqi Village, a Raid Sows Distrust of Americans
text: AL RUFAIT, Iraq — The American and Iraqi soldiers came to this village of grape farmers and tribal traditions in the dark in search of a suspected insurgent, and left in the morning sunlight.

headline: A Son’s Demons
text: Today’s guest posts are focusing on how different families respond to a diagnosis of something life-altering but not life-threatening in their children. Anon in the Midwest is a regular in the comments here on Motherlode. She often gives advice when others ask. In this essay she is not looking for answers, just some understanding and support. She asked that I send people who are interested in learning more to two Web sites, BipolarKids.org and the National Alliance on Mental Illness.

headline: Mission Motors R: an E.V. Bike That Runs With the Fastest Gas Burners
text: Electric-power road-racing motorcycles have been competing against each other on the world stage since 2009, when they first took to the track at the Isle of Man TT. But they have, for the most part, been seen as a silent, slower sideshow to gas-powered racebikes.

headline: Wall Street Continues to Spend Big on Lobbying
text: As the Dodd-Frank Act reaches its one-year anniversary, Wall Street’s army of lobbyists continue its aggressive campaign to tame the financial regulatory law.

headline: PBS’s ‘Masterpiece’ Picks Up a New Sponsor

headline: Fruit Smoothies for Summer
text: When I go to a farmers’ market in summer, I can’t resist buying more fruit than I need. I blame those cut fruit samples — one taste, and I’m filling my bag.

headline: Drawing Dance: Cunningham at Home in the West Village
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the seventh in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from the Cunningham Studio at Westbeth.

headline: Student Reading Contest Winner | China, Norway and Orwell
text: This is it: our fourth and final winner in our monthlong New York Times Summer Reading Contest. This week, Shannon Doyne and Amanda Christy Brown helped me judge, and their help and insights were invaluable – it was hard to choose from among the more than 100 thoughtful entries on topics that included healthy food, math camp, e-books and the attacks in Norway.

headline: The Airport Experience Now Includes Shopping for the Family
text: After visits to malls plummeted during the recession — and have yet to bounce back — many mass-market retailers stepped up their search for other locations to lure shoppers.

headline: We’re on Hiatus This Week
text: We hate to be a reminder that summer is ending, but we’re taking a break this week so that we can get our blog ready for academic year 2011-12. We’ll be back with regular daily posts on Aug. 8.

headline: Chávez, Battling Cancer, Appears With Shaved Head
text: The Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez, appeared on national television on Monday for the first time with a shaved head, a stark visual reminder of the treatment he is currently receiving for an unspecified cancer.

headline: Ancient Moves for Orthopedic Problems
text: With the costs of medical care spiraling out of control and an ever-growing shortage of doctors to treat an aging population, it pays to know about methods of prevention and treatment for orthopedic problems that are low-cost and rely almost entirely on self-care. As certain methods of alternative medicine are shown to have real value, some mainstream doctors who “think outside the box” have begun to incorporate them into their practices.

headline: App Smart Extra: Sheet Music for Your Smartphone
text: The latest App Smart column rounds up the top classical music apps – at least for listeners. For creators of classical music, there are fewer choices, especially for those on Android, where music software developers have yet to tread in large numbers.

headline: Legal Fees Keep Surging in Lehman Class-Action Suit
text: Patrick Andrade for The New York TimesLehman Brothers former headquarters in 2008.

headline: The Doctor Will See You ... Eventually
text: “How much of human life is lost in waiting!” Ralph Waldo Emerson lamented in his 1841 essay “Prudence.”

headline: Eugene McDaniels, Singer-Songwriter of Soul and Blues, Dies at 76
text: Eugene McDaniels, whose mellifluous voice brought him high onto the Billboard charts several times in the early 1960s, and who wrote “Feel Like Makin’ Love,” which Roberta Flack took to the top of the charts in 1974, died on Friday at his home in Kittery Point, Me. He was 76.

headline: Delta Says It Will Refund Airfare Tax
text: 6:30 p.m. | Updated with I.R.S. statement.

headline: Insurance Coverage for Contraception Is Required
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration issued new standards on Monday that require health insurance plans to cover all government-approved contraceptives for women, without co-payments or other charges.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Creamy Rice Casserole
text: This rice casserole, studded with fresh corn kernels, peas and poblano chiles, and made creamy with sour cream and cheddar cheese, is Mexican comfort food. “People love it because it’s creamy, crunchy and cheesy,” said Zarela Martinez, a cookbook author and until this year, owner of Zarela’s, the pioneering Mexican restaurant on Second Avenue. “It’s Mexican baby food. Like rice and beans.” She said her 3-year-old granddaughter, Violeta, eats it.

headline: Harry Reid Misses His Pomegranates
text: How much do the stressed-our, bleary-eyed lawmakers on Capitol Hill want to go home?

headline: Why Climate Scientists Are So Perturbed
text: Climate scientists have long called for steps to limit the buildup of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, and they are growing more and more worried about the slow pace of action. Yet their sense of urgency has not permeated society at large, and it certainly does not seem to be influencing the course of events in Washington, where climate legislation stalled last year.

headline: Pairings: Nectarines and Berries in Wine Sauce
text: I have kept a box of white wine in my refrigerator and red in the pantry almost since these easily dispensed wines first became available. Need a half-cup, a cup or more for a recipe? It’s at hand, ready to go into the pot, and there’s also some always ready to go into the cook.

headline: Thinking Inside the Box
text: IT’S the epitome of déclassé, the vinous equivalent of trailer trash, the wine snob’s worst nightmare. No, I don’t mean the screw cap. I’m talking about boxed wine.

headline: Reconsidering Boxed Wine
text: It’s taken a long time, but discerning American wine drinkers are slowly getting used to the idea of drinking wine from a box. No doubt, that is partly because the quality of boxed wines is improving, as the wine panel found.

headline: The Chelsea Guest Who Wouldn’t Leave
text: When guests at the Chelsea Hotel learned that it was abruptly shutting down, they reacted with anger, sadness and disappointment — but ultimately with resignation. One by one, they dutifully checked out of the storied hotel on 23rd Street by midday Sunday.

headline: The Pink and the Blue
text: Q. What influences the color of hydrangea blossoms? If it is soil acidity, why can a single bush have different-colored flowers?

headline: Numberplay: The Keys to Freedom
text: Mathematical folklore is rife with legends of imprisoned people who won their freedom or escaped death by solving a mathematical problem. We’ve featured a number of such problems here including the Josephus Problem, which, according to legend, allowed the 1st-century Jewish historian Flavius Josephus to save himself from death. (In our version, it was a firing game featuring Donald Trump and Ryan Seacrest.) We’ve also featured the Prisoners and Light Bulb problem and the Prisoners and the File Drawers problem, in both of which prison authorities give their detainees a mathematical problem to solve to gain their freedom. Today’s puzzle features a similar scenario. It concerns a medieval king who, in a rare fit of potential mercy, promises to free 5 of his prisoners on condition that they solve a problem. This problem is based on a submission by the prolific Numberplay contributor Ravi Kumar Meduri, from Hyderabad, India.

headline: A Good Night for CBS in the Ratings
text: CBS scored another ratings victory on Sunday night, beating out the other broadcast networks in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. “Big Brother” is particularly starting to look like a ratings juggernaut on Sundays, doubling every other show on the broadcast schedule in the 18-to-49 group except for a repeat of “Family Guy” on Fox. It also accumulated more than 8 million total viewers, up from 6.9 million last week. “60 minutes” did its part as well for CBS, as it was once again the most-watched program of the night with 8.8 million viewers. Meanwhile, “The Bachelorette: The Men Tell All Special” won the 9 p.m. time slot for ABC in total viewers with 5.1 million but was down considerably compared with last season’s edition, which drew 8.9 million. Still, it gave ABC its best summer Sunday rating with entertainment programming in five years (the 2010 special appeared on a Monday).

headline: Into the Abyss
text: Several new craft are being developed to reach Challenger Deep, the deepest part of the Mariana Trench.

headline: Who Falls to Addiction, and Who Is Unscathed?
text: Shortly after the singer Amy Winehouse, 27, was found dead in her London home, the airwaves were ringing with her popular hit “Rehab,” a song about her refusal to be treated for drug addiction.

headline: A Birthday Celebration for Philip Glass at Park Avenue Armory
text: The Park Avenue Armory will present a mini-festival dedicated to Philip Glass, putting on four performances of his music and of works by artists who have inspired him, on Feb. 23-26, the armory said on Monday. Those performing include Patti Smith and her band, as well as the jazz guitarist Bill Frisell.

headline: Ambitions as Deep as Their Pockets
text: A new generation of daredevils is seeking to plunge through nearly seven miles of seawater to the bottom of a rocky chasm in the western Pacific that is veiled in perpetual darkness. It is the ocean’s deepest spot. The forbidding place, known as the Challenger Deep, is so far removed from the warming rays of the sun that its temperature hovers near freezing.

headline: Dyslexia May Be a Hearing Problem Too
text: New research suggests dyslexia may be more than just a reading problem, but also an issue of how the brain processes spoken language.

headline: Study Sheds Light on Auditory Role in Dyslexia
text: Many people consider dyslexia simply a reading problem in which children mix up letters and misconstrue written words. But increasingly scientists have come to believe that the reading difficulties of dyslexia are part of a larger puzzle: a problem with how the brain processes speech and puts together words from smaller units of sound.

text: About 15 people in the visitors gallery overlooking the House floor were arrested Monday afternoon after disrupting a debate on the debt-limit proposal by chanting, “Boehner, get off it; it’s time to tax corporate profit.”

headline: The Belle of the Concours, and Her Car, Turn Heads in Michigan
text: For an innocent little country gal, as she described herself, Margaret Dunning was a rock star at Sunday’s Concours d’Élégance of America, where the 101-year-old showed the Packard she has owned for six decades.

headline: Screening: Mammograms Seen Ineffective in Europe
text: An analysis of data from six European countries suggests that mammography screening has had no effect on breast cancer mortality.

text: Updated, 5:30 p.m. | Long Island train commuters may face a difficult trip home on Monday after an apparent lightning strike crippled a swath of Long Island Rail Road track east of the city, officials said.

headline: Eurofile | Poland by the Sea
text: “Sopot is one of the sweetest places I’ve ever been,” Charlotte said as the Baltic seaside light began shading to sepia and tinting the waves amber. We were heading back to the wonderful Sofitel Grand Sopot Hotel, after lunch at Tomo Sushi, strolling along Europe’s longest wooden pleasure pier. As we walked and ate some of the world’s best strawberry lody (ice cream) — made with fresh, ivory-colored cream and wild berries — we were stopped regularly to snap photos of bashfully beaming families who wanted proof of their summer sojourns as warming souvenirs during Poland’s long winter.

headline: Breaking Bread Everywhere, Plentifully or Pitifully

headline: Particle Accelerators Full of Spin and Fury, Signifying Something
text: In the sidewalk con game known as three-card monte, you have to try to follow one of three cards (the red ace, say) as a dealer shuffles them back and forth face down. It’s easy until you actually put down money, and suddenly all your guesses are wrong.

headline: The 3 Women of Mountain Man, in Perfect Harmony
text: There were a few moments of truth during Mountain Man’s austere, engrossing performance at the Mercury Lounge on Thursday night. One came after midnight, just before the encore, as the three young women in the group — Molly Erin Sarle, Alexandra Sauser-Monnig and Amelia Randall Meath — gathered at the lip of the stage.

headline: How Can It Feel This Wrong?
text: I got nobody on my side, and surely that ain’t right.

headline: 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers'
text: A. O. Scott looks back at the 1956 paranoid fantasy.

headline: In This Video Game, You Can Make Real Cash Through Virtual Trading
text: How much would you pay for a magic sword that leached the life force from your enemies? Or an eldritch staff that let you unleash tempests of lightning? Or enchanted slippers that made you invisible to all but the sharpest senses?

headline: Birdlike Dinosaur Fossil May Shake Up the Avian Family Tree
text: In the 150 years since its discovery in Germany, Archaeopteryx has perched high on the avian family tree as the earliest and most primitive bird, somewhere near the evolutionary moment when some dinosaurs gave rise to birds. But recent fossil finds cast doubt on this interpretation: Archaeopteryx may be only a birdlike dinosaur rather than a dinosaurlike true bird.

headline: Sign of Advancing Society? An Organized War Effort
text: Some archaeologists have painted primitive societies as relatively peaceful, implying that war is a reprehensible modern deviation. Others have seen war as the midwife of the first states that arose as human population increased and more complex social structures emerged to coordinate activities.

headline: After Horror Stories, Airbnb Unveils New Policies
text: Airbnb, a service that lets people rent out their spare bedrooms to adventurous travelers, is on the rise, having recently raised $112 million in financing. But over the last few days, the company has run into trouble.

headline: LuPone and Patinkin Coming to Broadway
text: A mere 32 years after she played Eva Perón to his Che Guevara in “Evita,” Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin will reunite on Broadway for 63 performances of a theater concert, beginning Nov. 16. The production, “An Evening With Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin,” at the Barrymore Theater, is directed by Mr. Patinkin and includes musical staging consulting by his fellow Broadway veteran Ann Reinking. The Broadway premiere follows appearances across the United States and in Canada, Australia and New Zealand. “Evita” has not been revived on Broadway since the production that earned Ms. LuPone and Mr. Patinkin Tony Awards, but a version starring Elena Roger and Ricky Martin is to open next year.

headline: Call of the Thylacine: Protect the Wild
text: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK, Australia — Eleven thousand miles from my home in Wisconsin, this national park is one of my favorite places on the planet — a vast area of wetlands, woodlands and rock formations that is home to a fantastic array of wildlife.

headline: Taxi-Industry Battle Continues, With Echoes of 1971
text: This yellow-streaked city is no stranger to bitterly fought wars within its taxi industry, a saga that at times can resemble a daytime soap opera. Call it “As the Taxi Turns.”

headline: A Bare Market Lasts One Morning

Before most of the blue-shirted financiers descended, there came an army of helpers: the custodians and coffee fetchers, personal trainers and headsetted assistants who make the money street run smoothly. They marched along the sidewalks, in a hurry to start their workweek.

headline: Criss to Succeed Radcliffe In ‘How to Succeed’
text: January is often the cruelest month for Broadway box offices, as holiday tourists head home, students go back to school and New Yorkers hibernate from the cold and snow. Last winter the lead producers of the Broadway revival of “Promises, Promises” closed the show on Jan. 2 rather than gamble money on recasting their two stars, Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth, and risk a slide in ticket sales. Those same producers are now behind another Broadway revival, “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” but they have opted to replace their star, Daniel Radcliffe, who finishes his run as the scheming executive J. Pierrepont Finch on New Year’s Day. Confirming rumors that have been circulating for a couple of weeks, the producers announced on Monday that Mr. Radcliffe (of “Harry Potter” fame) will be succeeded by a lesser-known actor, Darren Criss, who has become popular recently on the Fox series “Glee” playing a gay high school student and show choir member who exudes charisma and self-confidence. In casting Mr. Criss the producers are seeking to appeal to at least some of the teenagers, women and gay men who often mob Mr. Radcliffe at the stage door after performances. Mr. Criss is scheduled for only a three-week engagement, Jan. 3 through 22. In their statement announcing Mr. Criss the producers did not say if they plan to cast another actor after him, close the $8.5 million production after he departs, or try to extend his run. A spokesman for the musical said the producers had not made decisions about the future of the show after the Criss run.

headline: Upheaval and Hope in a Land of Turmoil
text: When the longtime Middle East reporter Robin Wright’s last book, “Dreams and Shadows,” was published in 2008, her assessment — that “a budding culture of change” and empowerment had begun to permeate the region — was greeted as wildly optimistic. Three years later, given the wave of uprisings that began within the past year in Tunisia and Egypt and that has continued to roll through the Middle East, her views now seem extremely prescient.

headline: Gulf ‘Dead Zone’ Is Smaller Than Feared
text: A recent mapping expedition by scientists has shown that a zone of low oxygen in the Gulf of Mexico is above average but not as vast as many had anticipated, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Monday. Flooding in the Midwest had stirred fears that vast amounts of farm chemicals and waste traveling down the Mississippi would create the largest “dead zone” ever. NOAA said the zone measured 6,765 square miles, which is not a record. But scientists warned that the data could be misleading because a tropical storm had roiled and mixed gulf waters. They said that levels of the chemicals that deplete oxygen were rising year to year, weakening the gulf’s resistance to pollution.

headline: California: Crystal Cathedral Not for Sale
text: The Crystal Cathedral Ministries board has decided not to sell the campus of the landmark Orange County church, as the ministry works to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings. Potential buyers, including the Diocese of Orange, had offered up to $50 million for the campus, which would have allowed Crystal Cathedral to pay its creditors in full. Instead, the church will try to raise the money through donations, its lawyer told a bankruptcy court on Monday. The church may have only about four months to do so while the creditors committee proceeds with its own plan for a sale of the church.

headline: When the Numbers Outweigh the Message
text: Can public relations alone rescue a struggling deal? Validus shareholders have so far scorned the idea. The trouble is, messaging doesn’t win deals, numbers do. On that score, Validus isn’t far enough ahead.

headline: Guggenheim Outpost as a Pop-Up Urban Lab

headline: Does Philosophy Matter?
text: In a  recent essay about moral relativism in The Times’s philosophy series The Stone, Paul Boghossian cites a 2001 op-ed of mine as an example of the contradictions relativists fall into. At one moment, he says, I declare the unavailability of “independent standards” for deciding between rival accounts of a matter, and in the next moment  I am offering counsel that is “perfectly consistent with the endorsement of moral absolutes.”   I don’t  regard that as a contradiction, and I would say that to think of it as one is to fail to distinguish between relativism as a philosophical position — respectable, if controversial — and relativism as a way of life, something no one recommends and no one  practices.

headline: Up in the Air
text: The first manned balloon flight took place in France during the early 1780s and, not surprisingly, people began thinking of how to turn the balloon into an implement of war. Within a few years, the French army was using observation balloons in battle, and Benjamin Franklin even suggested that balloons might actually be used to convey soldiers into the fray. In 1849 the Austrian high command sent some 200 unmanned balloons, laden with timed explosives, over Venice. Unfortunately, the wind shifted, carrying them back over the hapless Austrians.

Mating in the spring, they need to lay their eggs on land, so in June and July they migrate to the sandy dunes of Jamaica Bay. The shortest route leads straight across the tarmac at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Versus Renamed Again

The name change was prompted by Comcast’s gaining control of NBC Universal earlier this year and the continuing efforts to make Versus the cable arm of NBC Sports. NBC’s efforts to rebrand Versus have been seen in the production of N.H.L. broadcasts and in the addition of horse racing and Notre Dame football.

headline: Cruel Isolation

headline: Fantasy Focus: Trade-Deadline Fallout
text: The Blue Jays somehow converted some middling prospects into Colby Rasmus, a center fielder who thrived in the major leagues a year ago at age 23. Next year Toronto could feature an outfield of Jose Bautista, Rasmus and Travis Snider/Eric Thames, and an infield with Adam Lind, Brett Lawrie and Yunel Escobar, to go along with a power-hitting catcher in J.P. Arencibia. With Ricky Romero and Brandon Morrow developing and Brett Cecil recently building on a solid rookie year, the Jays could crash the Yanks-Sox-Rays triumvirate as early as 2012.The Indians coughed up some top pitching prospects (Drew Pomeranz and Alex White) for Ubaldo Jimenez, and it makes you wonder why the Yankees didn’t offer a similar package (including Dellin Betances and Manny Banuelos), or, if they did, why the Rockies didn’t want it. Jimenez has a good contract and is under team control through 2014, so unless Colorado suspected there was something wrong with him, this seems like a good price. It’s not entirely true that there’s no such thing as a pitching prospect, especially when you’re talking about players who blew away the high minors like Tim Lincecum and Tommy Hanson or mega-talents like David Price or Stephen Strasburg. But for the next tier down, which is how I view both the Indians’ and Yankees’ duos, the failure rate is awfully high. It’ll be interesting to see how Jimenez fares with all his starts at sea level, albeit in the American League.

headline: Fighter-Jet Cockpit Canopies Tested for Formula One Racecars

headline: Waiting for a Recovery

It says “Keep Calm and Carry On,” and it has become quite popular all over the world. I think it’s good advice for dealing with fear, especially for small-business owners.

headline: After a Botched Raid in Iraq, Competing Facts and Unified Blame
text: BAGHDAD – The narrative of American officialdom here, civilian and military alike, is that United States muscle is used merely in service of supporting Iraq’s fledgling democracy. Iraq’s leaders and soldiers are the ones responsible, and seek American support only as needed. That may be literally true, but the reaction to a botched weekend raid in a village north of the capital that left three men dead, none the targeted insurgent, laid bare another truth: In Iraq, where grievances run deep, America will still bear the brunt of the blame when things go wrong, even if the facts don’t completely align.

headline: Latest Arrest Highlights a Tabloid’s Cash Payments

When reporters needed cash to pursue articles, they simply filled out a green form and, after getting authorization from the managing editor, exchanged it at the window for up to tens of thousands of pounds, said several journalists who worked there.

headline: Can’t a Restaurant Owner Drink at His Own Bar?
text: The chef deemed it unprofessional. The server was embarrassed. The bartender was afraid of legal ramifications. Huh? I was just sitting at the bar, minding my own business — and everyone else’s — sipping a glass of Paumonak Chardonnay. Innocent enough, I thought, until the prolonged dust up from my own people.

headline: All the Pie in Portland
text: Trying to locate this year’s fifth annual Pie Off in Laurelhurst Park in Portland, Ore., was like a sketch from the TV show “Portlandia”: first you had to pass by what was billed (in chalk on the asphalt path) as an “organic free-range wedding,” then a free performance of Shakespeare’s “Much Ado About Nothing.” Finally, in the northeast corner of the park — marked by a bluegrass band and pennant banners made from recycled fabric, strung between the linden trees — were four tables spilling with pies. There was everything from the classic (Grandma Jane’s apple pie, berry with a lattice crust) to the quintessentially Portland (a gluten-free “Rawvocado-chocolate” — avocado, chocolate, raw macadamias, dates and shredded coconut). Hopeful eaters of all ages clustered around the tables, compostable forks and paper plates at the ready, waiting for four judges to sample all 60 pies that had been entered in one of four categories: savory, sweet non-fruit, sweet fruit and “creative.”

headline: Debt Compromise Is Just ‘First Step,’ Obama Says

headline: Extraordinary Precautions Taken for Mubarak Trial
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim military government took strong preventive steps on Tuesday to secure the trial location where Hosni Mubarak, the deposed president, was scheduled to face charges of corruption and the killings of Egyptians during the tumultuous 18 days of revolution that led to his forced resignation nearly six months ago.

headline: Baruj Benacerraf, Nobel Winner in Medicine, Dies at 90
text: Dr. Baruj Benacerraf, a Venezuelan-born immunologist who received a Nobel Prize for his groundbreaking work in exploring why diseases like multiple sclerosis affect some people but not others, died on Tuesday at his home in the Jamaica Plain section of Boston. He was 90.

headline: A Sneak Preview of the Times Magazine Photo Book
text: We just received our first bound copies of  the book Aperture will publish this fall featuring three decades of photography in The New York Times Magazine. We can’t wait for readers to hold this wonderful, heavy book in their hands. Five years in the making, it spans more than 1,700 issues of the magazine, including photographs by 140 key image makers of our time across all genres of the medium: documentary, portraiture, fine art, photo illustration, style and conceptual photography. In the issue of the magazine that comes out on Sunday, Aug. 21, we’ll be republishing some of the pictures from the book, alongside new, updated photographs of the same subjects. Keep your eye out for both the issue and the book.

headline: Outside Pressure Builds on Syria

headline: Afghanistan Seeks to Disband Some Armed Militias
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Government officials seeking to break up hundreds of small independent militias in the volatile northern province of Kunduz have ordered more than 4,000 members to surrender their weapons within 20 days or face a military crackdown, threatening more violence in a region where security has steadily eroded over the last two years.

headline: All Consuming | The Céline Bag
text: Oftentimes, the Internet solves all. Sites like net-a-porter.com, luisaviaroma.com and mytheresa.com have made the act of shopping in person almost obsolete. Still, there are labels that refuse to enter the online arena, and Céline — why, Céline?! — is one of them. I learned this in the winter of 2009 when my need to acquire the king-size Luggage tote escalated to a level bordering on obsession. I loved everything about it — the elegant scrolls, the embossed gold lettering, the rigid structure. But I couldn’t find it anywhere.

headline: No Need for a Mountain
text: VINGSAND, Norway — Two large black mattresses bounced along the coastline, pausing every so often in front of large rocks and the glimmering sea view. The mattresses — or crash pads, as some call them — were strapped to the backs of two American rock climbers who are among a growing group of people who in the last decade have practiced and promoted a form of climbing that relies on mattresses, rather than ropes, to catch their falls.

headline: When You’ve Got Those First-24-Hour Blues
text: A traveler arrives in London, jet-lagged, throws his bags down in the hotel in Islington and sets out to meet a friend at Kings College, which Google Maps says is a 30-minute walk away. A half-hour later he’s lost and caught in pouring rain. Forty-five minutes later he’s wandering Fleet Street with a cheap umbrella in hand. An hour and a Tube ride later, this soaked and stressed shadow of his former self gives his impatient friend a hug.

headline: Mets Specialize in Drama, With a Touch of Futility

headline: El Museo del Barrio Names New Director
text: El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan has appointed Margarita Aguilar, a vice president and specialist in Latin American art at Christie’s, as its new director, the museum announced on Tuesday. Ms. Aguilar, 54, was a curator at El Museo from 1998 to 2006 before going to Christie’s. “It’s a very good homecoming for me,” she said in a telephone interview. She said that the museum’s annual attendance had doubled since she left, to roughly 250,000 visitors, and added that she would like to see it increase still further. “We want to be sure that we reach all of our constituents, including New Yorkers, Latinos and Latin Americans,” she said.

headline: The Leopard at des Artistes
text: HIGH summer in New York City and the Upper West Side is quiet at twilight, vast swaths of the neighborhood lost to the Hamptons, the Vineyard, the Cape, the Shore. headline: ABC Successfully Woos Viewers With ‘Bachelorette’ Bash

According to Nielsen data, the show gained viewers as the night progressed, beginning with 8.9 million in the first half hour at 8 p.m., where it seemed that Ashley’s sister would derail the proceedings entirely with her strong dislike of one of the suitors, and finishing with 10.6 million viewers tuning in to see whose proposal Ashley would ultimately accept by 9:30 p.m.

Of the more than 2,500 events scheduled through Aug. 29, when the festival ends, almost 800 involve the theater. From “Shakespeare for Breakfast” to “Hotel Medea,” an interpretation of that Greek tragedy that runs from midnight till dawn, the opportunities to live, eat and breathe theater appear unlimited.

headline: The New Hama Rules
text: What a difference three decades make. In April 1982, I was assigned to be the Beirut correspondent for The Times. Before I arrived, word had filtered back to Lebanon about an uprising in February in the Syrian town of Hama — famed for its water wheels on the Orontes River. Rumor had it that then President Hafez al-Assad had put down a Sunni Muslim rebellion in Hama by shelling the neighborhoods where the revolt was centered, then dynamiting buildings, some with residents still inside, and then steamrolling them flat, like a parking lot. It was hard to believe and even harder to check. No one had cellphones back then, and foreign media were not allowed access.

headline: Hiding Behind the Budget Act
text: The Budget Control Act of 2011, which President Obama signed on Tuesday after Congress passed it by wide margins, is as contrived as the artificial crisis that spawned it. The bill, like a tired opera production, is full of clumsy staging and failed gimmicks left over from previous decades. It is not only bad policy in its goals of cutting spending too much, but it is bad procedure. It allows members of Congress to avoid responsibility for their actions through a cutout committee, a spending limit and the pretense that this Congress can tell the next one what to do.

headline: Norway: War Games and Toys Pulled From Shelves

headline: Italy: Panel Approves Measure Banning Face Coverings
text: An Italian parliamentary commission passed a draft law on Tuesday to ban women from wearing clothing that covers their faces in public. The draft would prohibit women from wearing any garment, including the burqa and niqab, that covers the face and makes it hard to recognize them in public. Under the proposed legislation, anyone forcing women to cover their faces would be fined and face up to 12 months in jail.

headline: Islanders’ Future Blurred by Rejection of Plan to Pay for a New Arena
text: Charles Wang, the owner of the Islanders, said last week there was “no Plan B” if Nassau County, N.Y., voters rejected a plan to borrow $400 million to pay for a new arena for his team, a minor league ballpark and new convention space.

headline: China: Party Newspaper Warns the Philippines
text: China’s main Communist Party newspaper sharply warned neighboring nations on Tuesday against asserting their claims to territory in the South China Sea, responding to a news report that the Philippines was building shelter for troops on one of the disputed Spratly Islands, which the Chinese call the Nansha Islands. The commentary accused the Philippines of “a little trick” by building the shelter shortly after the Association of Southeast Asian Nations called for restraint in actions that might inflame territorial disputes.

headline: Keep the Windows and Sunroofs Closed in Bearizona
text: Black bears are in abundance in Arizona, but they are not easy to spot. They scavenge for food over vast distances and generally keep to themselves. For a guaranteed glimpse of them, though, there is a place called Bearizona.

headline: Giants’ Umenyiora Still Searching for New Contract, With Any Team
text: There was no resolution to the standoff between the Giants and the All-Pro defensive end Osi Umenyiora, but his agent, Tony Agnone, said Tuesday that “quite a few teams” have shown interest in Umenyiora, and he expected the situation to be sorted out quickly.

headline: TimesCast | Mubarak To Stand Trial
text: August 2, 2011 - Egypt's ousted president Hosni Mubarak goes on trial Wednesday.

headline: Greeting the Unthinkable: Mubarak on Trial
text: CAIRO — The headlines of newspapers on sale in a subway station once called Mubarak, and now renamed Martyrs', captured the moment Tuesday that could prove one of the most remarkable in modern Arab history: “The pharaoh in the cage of the accused.”

headline: Record Numbers Are Receiving Food Stamps
text: The number of Americans receiving food stamps rose to a record 45.753 million in May, up 2.5 percent from the previous month, the Department of Agriculture said. Recipients of Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program subsidies for food purchases were 12 percent higher than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday in a statement on its Web site.

headline: Harsh Report on Monitoring of Rapist
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Videos taken by the wife of the convicted rapist Phillip Garrido were released Tuesday by the El Dorado County District Attorney’s Office, part of a scathing report on the failings of the criminal justice system in handling Mr. Garrido over the years.

headline: How Chocolate Can Help Your Workout
text: For those who worry that fitness requires nutritional denial, there is good news, with caveats. Auspicious new science suggests that chocolate can have a surprisingly large effect on the body’s response to exercise, although not in the ways that many of us might expect, and certainly not at the dosages most might hope for.

headline: Needing to Show Something, Hughes Gives Yankees Six Scoreless Innings
text: CHICAGO — With two outs in the bottom of the first inning Tuesday night, Phil Hughes took a breath, steadied himself and peered in against White Sox designated hitter Carlos Quentin, a slugger who has hit 20 home runs this season.

headline: Swing and a Mess
text: Until this season, Adam Dunn had fairly consistent numbers in the major leagues, including plenty of homers and runs batted in. But now he seems completely lost with a bat in his hand.

headline: U.S. Stocks Manage to Eke Out a Gain
text: After seven days of losing ground, the stock market made some back on Wednesday.

headline: Disabled Man Is Found Dead in Van
text: A 48-year-old disabled man was found dead Tuesday in the rear seat of a van where he was left for six hours, the police said.

headline: TimesCast | Photographing Somalia
text: August 2, 2011 - In Somalia 500,000 children are on the brink of starvation because of a devastating drought. Tyler Hicks, the Times photographer, describes documenting their ordeal.

headline: At Mubarak Trial, Stark Image of Humbled Power
text: CAIRO — An ailing Hosni Mubarak, who had served longer than any other ruler of modern Egypt until a revolution toppled him in February, was rolled into a courtroom in a hospital bed on Wednesday to face charges of corruption and complicity in the killing of protesters, offering an indelible lesson for Egypt and the Arab world in the humbling of power.

headline: When Rome Shuts Down in August, Where to Eat
text: Roman businesses generally shut down in August, as locals shutter their homes and shops and head to the sea for a few weeks, or even the whole month. But because of an increase in summer tourism, and especially the recent rise in “staycations,” a number of prominent restaurants have elected to stay open during the summer holiday season. This year, a handful of worthwhile culinary destinations will be open for the entire month of August. Here is a selection.

text: Today’s Times

headline: More Evidence That Supply Matters
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: For a Second Time, Honda Civic Misses Recommendation From Consumer Reports
text: Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, sends out a news release each month summarizing the automotive evaluations of the coming month’s issue. Rarely does the release generate significant attention, let alone a media scrum, but on Monday a preview of the magazine’s September issue contained a bombshell: the 2012 Honda Civic LX sedan scored so poorly during testing that the car did not make the magazine’s Recommended list.

headline: Who Made Those NASA Logos?
text: The return of the space shuttle Atlantis to the Earth’s atmosphere two weeks ago marked the close of NASA’s 30-year space shuttle program. Retirement of this popular and very visible shuttle program further strains the already diminished agency. “Space experts say the best and brightest often head for the doors when rocket lines get marked for extinction, dampening morale and creating hidden threats,” according to The Times. This is not the first time in NASA’s history when the agency faced publicity troubles. Back in 1974, after the success of the Mercury and Apollo programs, but before the initiation of the Shuttle Program, NASA was convinced by the National Endowment for the Arts to participate in its “Federal Graphics Improvement Program,” and do what many companies these days do to revive their image: undergo a redesign.Up until that point, NASA had been primarily using an insignia adapted by James Modarelli, the head of NASA’s Lewis Research Center Reports Division. This logo, created in 1959 and affectionately dubbed “The Meatball,” relied heavily on multiple visual metaphors. According to NASA’s Web site, “the sphere represents a planet, the stars represent space, the red chevron is a wing representing aeronautics (the latest design in hypersonic wings at the time the logo was developed), and then there is an orbiting spacecraft going around the wing.” Although charming in its quirkiness, the meatball proved difficult to reproduce given the printing technology available at the time and the variety of applications it would need to adorn.

headline: Security Firm Sees Global Cyberspying
text: SHANGHAI — An American cybersecurity company issued a report on Wednesday saying that it had identified a single perpetrator of cyberattacks that lasted up to five years on a wide range of governments, American corporations and even United Nations groups, and that the pattern of targets suggested the attacker was a “state actor.”

headline: Video From the Trial of Hosni Mubarak
text: 12:15 p.m. | Updated The former president of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, was wheeled into an Egyptian court on Wednesday to face charges of corruption and murder in the deaths of protesters. A conviction could carry the death penalty.

headline: Officials Sent to Prison in Shanghai Tower Fire
text: SHANGHAI — A Shanghai court has sentenced nearly two dozen government officials, construction workers and contractors to jail for their role in a high-rise fire here that killed 58 people and injured 71 last November.

headline: Japan Passes Law Supporting Stricken Nuclear Plant’s Operator
text: TOKYO — Japan’s Parliament passed a law on Wednesday that will allow the use of public funds to shore up the company operating the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, and help it pay what is expected to amount to billions of dollars in compensation claims.

headline: Can the Debt Ceiling Genie Be Put Back in the Bottle?
text: If there was any doubt that Washington’s acrimonious debt fight created a new political reality, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky dashed it on Tuesday.

text: Société Générale, the second-largest French bank after BNP Paribas, on Wednesday reported that income fell 31 percent in the second quarter compared with the period a year earlier, driven by a write-down on Greek sovereign debt.

headline: Teaching Kids How to Break Up Nicely
text: Late last month, 200 teenagers from Boston-area schools gathered to discuss the minutia of Facebook breakup etiquette. Should you delete pictures of your ex after splitting up? Is it O.K. to unfriend your last girlfriend if you can’t stop looking at her profile? And is it ever ethically defensible to change your relationship status to single without first notifying the person whose heart you’re crushing?

headline: The Words We Live By
text: Among the many things to marvel over in “Talk to Me,” a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art about how people and objects communicate, is a device called the “communication prosthesis.” It’s a rigid mouthpiece that stretches the lips wide, exposing the wearer’s teeth and gums. It forces timid people to look as aggressive and unhinged as Heath Ledger’s Joker in “The Dark Knight.”

text: It’s been more than two weeks now since anyone has reported seeing Violet the red-tailed Hawk Cam hawk, mother of Pip, mate of Bobby.

headline: Casting Aside World Criticism, Syria Invades Town
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ignoring mounting condemnations, the Syrian military sent tanks, armored vehicles and snipers on Wednesday into the symbolic center of Hama, a rebellious city that has emerged as a linchpin of the nearly five-month uprising, in what appeared a decisive step by President Bashar al-Assad to crush opposition to his rule.

text: After hitting various bumps in the road, the design for the new Westinghouse AP-1000 reactor is approaching approval by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

headline: Congratulations to John Quiggin
text: The author of Zombie Economics has received a full sliming from the Murdoch empire. That’s a badge of honor. But if I were John, I’d be careful; the zombies will eat his brain if they can.

text: 9:22 a.m. | Updated The Canadian consortium seeking to acquire the parent of the Toronto stock exchange said on Wednesday that it would extend its offer of 3.8 billion Canadian dollars to Sept. 30.

text: Crimes by and against immigrants in Greece are on the rise while right-wing groups clamor for the expulsion of all illegal immigrants.

headline: A Place in the Shade
text: Summer’s heat wave has many of us running for cover. Here, cool portable cotton “Sombrillas” from the Australian company Hollie and Harrie are a delightful alternative to unwieldy stick-in-the-sand umbrellas. Designed by Skye Hollingsworth and Claire Harris, longtime friends, the cheerful beach tents fold up to roughly the size of a yoga mat and come with a clever matching carrying case. Clean lines, 95 percent UV protection and three pitch-perfect summer colors — Moroccan blue, French stripe and a sunny yellow — ensure that our last days of summer will be stylish and sunburn free.

text: As President Obama heads back home to Chicago to celebrate his 50th birthday (and raise a bit of campaign cash), Mr. Romney released a not so nice internet video as a present.

headline: British Arrest 6 and Seize 2,600 Pounds of Cocaine
text: LONDON — British authorities said on Wednesday that they had seized the largest shipment of illicit hard drugs in the country’s history, and that the seizure had led to the arrests of six people suspected of working with an international narcotics ring.

headline: Glaad Report Likes ABC Family Values
text: An annual report by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation commended the ABC Family cable channel for its representation of gay, lesbian and bisexual characters in its programming and for the racial diversity of those characters. In its fifth annual Network Responsibility Index, which Glaad issued on Wednesday, the organization gave a rating of “Excellent” to ABC Family, whose shows include “Pretty Little Liars,” “The Secret Life of the American Teenager,” “Greek” and “Switched at Birth,” and said that 55 percent of that channel’s 103 hours of original programming from June 2010 through May 2011 included “LGBT-inclusive images.” Herndon Graddick, the senior director of programs at Glaad, said in a statement, “Viewers expect to see television environments that accurately reflect what it’s like to be a young adult, and today that includes young adults who happen to be gay.”

headline: Wednesday Reading: Obama Promises Action on Jobs
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Motion Picture Academy to Honor Oprah Winfrey and James Earl Jones
text: LOS ANGELES — Oprah Winfrey will receive the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award and the actor James Earl Jones and the makeup artist Dick Smith will receive honorary Oscars for lifetime achievement this year from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the academy said late Tuesday. The awards will be presented at a Governors Awards banquet, to be held in the Hollywood district of Los Angeles on Nov. 12. The academy’s governors, who give up to four special awards each year, did not grant an Irving Thalberg award for lifetime achievement by a film producer this year.

headline: Australia Gripped by Story of ‘Collar Bomb’
text: 2:08 p.m. | Updated As images of the former Egyptian president in a courtroom cage transfixed much of the world on Wednesday, Australian television and online media were consumed by a bizarre and slowly unfolding drama in a suburban Sydney home.

text: Proposed fuel economy standards for 2017-25 model-year vehicles, announced last week by President Obama, should reduce greenhouse gas emissions at a pace consistent with targets set by the California Air Resources Board, according to agency representatives.

headline: Art Odyssey
text: A bit magically unpretentious, a bit Disney in its polished quaintness, Hydra, a car-free Greek island, has long been home to Athenian nobility and far-flung laureates alike: Leonard Cohen emigrated in the 1960s; Brice Marden has kept residences here since the ’70s. But as of late, the island is perhaps best known to the art world as the site of the annual events of the über-collector Dakis Joannou’s Deste Foundation, which were inaugurated three years ago with an epic performance collaboration between Matthew Barney and Elizabeth Peyton. This June, Deste hosted more than 300 international guests for Doug Aitken’s video-enhanced stage show set on a repurposed freight ship, Black Mirror, starring Chloe Sevigny.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Former Directors of Failed Firms Have Little to Fear | A look at how onetime Enron directors have fared in recent years suggests that directors of institutions that collapsed during the financial crisis have little to fear. In fact, the Enron example indicates that the former directors of Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers will likely continue their prominent careers.

headline: A Tainted Water Well, and Concern There May Be More
text: For decades, oil and gas industry executives as well as regulators have maintained that a drilling technique known as hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, that is used for most natural gas wells has never contaminated underground drinking water.

headline: How to Beat the High Costs of Dialing Abroad
text: IT’S hard not to feel ripped off when you get hit with unexpected roaming charges while traveling abroad — whether they come from making phone calls or checking e-mail. Take it from Jeff Gardner, who received an $11,000 bill from Verizon after spending four days in Jamaica. Before the trip, Mr. Gardner, who runs a fly-fishing business in Grayling, Mich., said he called Verizon to find out what it would cost to use his cellphone for calls and his wireless air card to check e-mail on his laptop while in the Caribbean. He said he was told that calls would be about $2 a minute and that there would be no extra charges for data as he was on an unlimited plan. The latter part turned out to be wrong.

headline: A Picture Book About Surviving Katrina
text: Can the enormity of a large-scale tragedy like 9/11, the Japanese tsunami or Hurricane Katrina be conveyed to school-age children without frightening them? How to describe the emotional toll without imposing a burden? It’s a difficult balance.
