headline: Basics of Accounting Are Vital to Survival for Entrepreneurs
text: Few people start a business because they are good with numbers. In fact, the terms “accounting” and “financial analysis” tend to put business owners to sleep or send them screaming from the room. But to run a business effectively, most owners need to have some understanding of their finances.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Nightmare and the Cat
text: It’s unusual for an opening act to outshine the headliner, but for Nightmare and the Cat it’s becoming par for the course. Led by the barely legal frontman Django James and his brother Samuel Stewart, the Los Angeles group is a rock ‘n’ roll force to be reckoned with. With moves not seen since Elvis Presley last took the stage, James and his cohorts are utterly captivating to watch and bring an energy to their live show that is increasingly rare. Nightmare performed at Mercury Lounge recently, celebrating the release of their self-titled EP, and held a dancing crowd under their spell from start to finish. Their showmanship is a testament to the brothers’ rightful position in the royal court of pop music as the children of the Eurythmics’ Dave Stewart and Bananarama’s Siobhan Fahey.

headline: Mubarak Trial Rivets Egyptians
text: Egypt’s ousted president, Hosni Mubarak, was wheeled into a courtroom cage in a hospital bed on Wednesday, in an image few Egyptians thought they would ever see.

headline: Do You Know Enough About Accounting?
text: In a small-business guide to accounting that we’ve just published, Darren Dahl writes about Bart Justice, who started a document-destruction business, Secure Destruction Service, in 2004. The business, based in Huntsville, Ala., grew from $70,000 in annual revenue its first year to $500,000 four years later. To finance his growth, Mr. Justice kept borrowing money from the bank, not realizing that the more he grew, the more he needed to borrow because his revenue was not covering his expenses. The loans meant he had money in his accounts — but it was borrowed money. “I knew how to print a financial statement from QuickBooks, but I couldn’t tell you what it meant,” he said. It took the intervention of business owners in a peer group Mr. Justice joined to convince him that if he didn’t master his finances he was going to lose his business.

headline: Germany Investigating Facebook Tagging Feature
text: BERLIN — A German regulator said Wednesday that he had asked Facebook to disable its new photo-tagging software, saying he was concerned that its facial recognition feature amounted to the unauthorized collection of data on individuals.

headline: Supervisor Held in Death of Autistic Man in S.I. Center
text: Updated, 1:49 p.m. | A supervisor at a state-run psychiatric center on Staten Island surrendered to the police on Wednesday to face homicide charges in the death of a 27-year-old man who was asphyxiated while being restrained last December, the authorities said.

headline: Playing on a Bigger Court: ‘Lysistrata Jones’ Taking Its Game to Broadway
text: “Lysistrata Jones,” a musical comedy about sex and college basketball that had a well-received production Off Broadway in the spring, will transfer to Broadway and begin performances on Nov. 12 and open on Dec. 14 at the Walter Kerr Theater, the show’s producers said on Wednesday. The music and lyrics are by Lewis Flinn and the book is by the playwright Douglas Carter Beane, a three-time Tony Award contender who most recently shared a nomination in June for the book of the musical “Sister Act.”

headline: Good Earnings and Perhaps Higher Prices From Sirius XM
text: Sirius XM Radio may raise its subscription fees next year, following the expiration of a federal rule that restricted its pricing, according to comments made by Mel Karmazin, the company’s chief executive.

headline: French Union Halts Help Into Inquiry in Jet Crash
text: PARIS — Air France’s largest pilots’ union suspended cooperation on Wednesday with investigators seeking to identify the causes of a fatal 2009 crash of a Rio de Janeiro-to-Paris flight, in protest of what it said was a decision by investigators to play down the role of the plane’s stall-warning system in an interim report last week.

headline: Cherchez la Femme
text: Like corpses in a bad horror movie, the women in the D.S.K. scandal pile up behind every door and under every bed. But the woman behind the man,  Anne Sinclair, has remained a somewhat shadowy figure. Vanessa Grigoriadis’s piece in New York magazine, borrowing heavily from interviews in Le Monde, Le Nouvel Observateur and the biography Madame DSK, which is currently available only in French, is filled with details of the marriage (both left spouses for each other; she prefers Paris, he their riad in Marrakesh; she broke off a friendship when her friend suggested D.S.K.’s affairs were too numerous to be forgivable even by a Frenchwoman). It also reminds us of Sinclair’s striking readiness, past and present, to stand behind and by her man, despite having a prominent career as a TV host and holding the purse strings.For those of you hankering for more of the “other woman,” it’s worth reading the account of one Marie-Victorine M. in the Daily Beast, who claims to have found D.S.K. irresistibly magnetic (their eyes met across a room and for four months they had a torrid affair), and yet who believes the account of the Sofitel maid is true. What convinced her?  “When I read the first articles in the American press containing for example the detail that he was supposed to have taken his presumed victim from behind, that encouraged me to believe this woman.”

headline: State Panel to Review Pay of Leaders at Nonprofits
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Wednesday the creation of a task force to investigate executive compensation at nonprofit organizations that receive taxpayer subsidies from the state.

headline: The Global Food Crisis, Mapped
text: Oxfam, the antihunger group, has been running a campaign to call attention to the global food crisis, its consequences and its potential solutions. The Times outlined the challenge of future food security on a warming planet in this article several weeks ago, and this week my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman described the appalling famine unfolding in Somalia. The Somalia situation has a drought component, although the causes of the suffering seem to be primarily political.

headline: N.R.A. Sues Over Bulk Gun Sales Rule
text: WASHINGTON — The National Rifle Association filed a lawsuit on Wednesday challenging a new federal regulation requiring gun merchants along the border with Mexico to report bulk sales of certain semiautomatic rifles, contending that the Obama administration exceeded its powers by imposing the rule last month without Congressional permission.

headline: Lauren Ambrose Will Be Fanny Brice in ‘Funny Girl’
text: The actress Lauren Ambrose, best known as the rebellious Claire Fisher in the HBO series “Six Feet Under,” was not an obvious first choice for the Barbra Streisand role in the Broadway-bound revival of the musical “Funny Girl.” But a combination of acting skill, comic timing, singing talent — including the high belt that is critical for well-known numbers like “Don’t Rain on My Parade” — and a “quirky, surprising fearlessness” (in the words of the director Bartlett Sher) helped win Ms. Ambrose the role, the revival’s producers said on Wednesday.

headline: Graphic Content | Typonine
text: Type specimen books are the plumbing-parts catalogs of graphic design. They show graphic designers the ways in which different sizes and weights of letters sit together as typeset words, and how they showcase typographic form and style. A specimen book enables a designer to visualize the mix and match new and old typefaces. Although digital type foundries now sell their fonts online, most still issue the occasional specimen books and booklets, as a nod to tradition.

headline: New H.I.V. Cases Steady Despite Better Treatment
text: Despite years of great progress in treating AIDS, the number of new infections with the virus that causes it has remained stubbornly around 50,000 a year in the United States for a decade, according to new figures released on Wednesday by federal officials.

headline: Panetta Issues Warning on Pentagon Cuts
text: Only a month into the job of defense secretary, Leon E. Panetta warned that “a round of dangerous across-the-board defense cuts” could compromise the country’s security if a Congressional panel does not reach consensus on ways to cut the deficit.

headline: The Caucus | The President's Next Steps
text: Mark Landler discusses how President Obama is, again, turning his focus to jobs, and Jeff Zeleny looks at the votes of the debt deal.

headline: Caucus Video: Obama’s Focus on Jobs, and a Closer Look at Some Debt Votes
text: Mark Landler on how President Obama is, again, turning his focus to jobs. Also, Jeff Zeleny takes a closer look at the some votes on the just-passed debt deal. Some provide clues about the 2012 election.

headline: More Talk of a Formula One Race in New York
text: The U.S. Grand Prix in Austin feels years away, but will run next year. The race in Indianapolis from 2000 to 2007 never took off. Now, before Austin has even happened, let alone proved itself, there is again talk of another Grand Prix in the United States — in New York.

headline: More Talk of a Formula One Race in New York
text: The U.S. Grand Prix in Austin feels years away, but will run next year. The race in Indianapolis from 2000 to 2007 never took off. Now, before Austin has even happened, let alone proved itself, there is again talk of another Grand Prix in the United States — in New York.

headline: Kutcher to Play a Billionaire on ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: This much CBS will say about the revised version of its hit comedy “Two and a Half Men”: Ashton Kutcher plays an “Internet billionaire with a broken heart.” And his character’s name is Walden Schmidt.

headline: Q. and A.: What’s So Funny in Brazil?
text: The Brazilian comedian Rafinha Bastos, recently named the most influential person in the Twitter universe, is spearheading a comedy explosion in his home country. He is part of “a new generation of humorists out there who are acid, vibrant and clever,” said Álvaro Paes de Barros, the general manager for Viacom in Brazil, who is supervising the opening of Comedy Central there.

headline: Russia Becomes a Magnet for U.S. Fast-Food Chains
text: MOSCOW — Earlier in his career, Christopher Wynne put his Russian expertise to work researching arms proliferation for the American government. Now he’s engaged in geopolitics of another sort: deploying American fast food for the emerging Russian middle class.

headline: Climate Change an Extra Burden for Native Americans, Study Says
text: Because tribal lands are particularly prone to drought, flooding, wildfires and other weather extremes, American Indian tribes suffer disproportionately from the impacts of climate change, a new study from the National Wildlife Federation and other groups reported Wednesday.

headline: Private Donors, Including Mayor, Save January Regents
text: Over the last several weeks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made a series of unusual fund-raising calls to a handful of wealthy New Yorkers. Would they be willing, he asked, to chip in $250,000 each to save some standardized tests?

headline: Your Very Own Cookie-Baking Robot
text: For some time I’ve been trying to justify owning a robot without coming across as “that weirdo with the robot.” Now, I think I finally found my cover: A robot that bakes cookies!

headline: Video From Syria Shows Tanks in Hama

headline: ‘The Friend Should Be Euthanized; the Dog Should Pay the Vet Bills’
text: Yesterday the 6th Floor played host to a four-hour public discussion about ethics. The question up for debate was this: If while walking a friend’s dog as a favor, someone neglects to take the agreed-upon precautions – and if as a result the dog breaks free and mauls another dog – who is responsible for the damage? The dog walker or the dog owner?

headline: Still Playing Catch-Up, Across the Economy
text: Given that the downturn began nearly four years ago, and that the population has grown significantly since then, the economy should instead be bigger than it was before the financial crisis. But Calculated Risk, a finance blog, makes a good observation: On most major measures of economic health, the economy is still worse today than it was before the recession began.

headline: The Art of Being a Character
text: THE art-fashion crowd struck a cool pose at the opening party for “On Shuffle,” an indie rock-themed show at the Lehmann Maupin Gallery in Chelsea. Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth nonchalantly stepped around her installation, a circle of glitter on the floor. Cecilia Dean, a founder of the avant-garde fashion bible Visionaire, sailed in wearing a black Margiela jersey.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: ARCH ANGELS Blink, the chain of walk-in brow-threading bars found in British stores like Selfridges, Harvey Nichols and Space NK, has opened its first branch in the United States, at Henri Bendel. With two cream-colored nappa leather chairs for clients, the small salon also sells Blink products like a soothing pure rose gel ($45) and eyebrow pencils in five shades ($26). Eyebrow shaping costs $32, eyelash perming is $90 and a threading of the entire face is $110. Dread the thread? Consider Chella Brow Tool Kit, which comes with scissors, tweezers, a razor, brush and comb tool and a shaping guide ($40 at chella.com).

headline: The Salahis Still Want In
text: SPOTTING Michaele Salahi at a recent polo match in Greenwich, Conn., was no easy task. In that crowd, a waifish striking blonde of a certain age — even one who stood at 5 foot 11 before slipping into her Louboutin heels — was not exactly an anomaly.

headline: Giants Sign Another Andrews for Offensive Line
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants were not without the services of one of the N.F.L.’s Andrews brothers for long.

headline: Channeling Inner Peace, With Air-Conditioning
text: RUSSELL SIMMONS sat cross-legged, yogi style, in his wood-shingled portico, watching as the first guests strutted for the cameras. He was a lone beacon of Zen, as some 700 partygoers swarmed his estate in East Hampton, N.Y., last Saturday for the annual Art of Life Benefit.

headline: PH-D
text: FOR those who have spent years absorbing life lessons from “Entourage,” PH-D is Xanadu: a glittering room of celebrities, beautiful women and cresting credit-card bills. The nightclub, which opened in June on the roof of the Dream Downtown hotel, is the latest endeavor from the impresarios behind Marquee, Tao and other successful playgrounds for the well heeled.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Philips Wins Energy Department’s Lighting Prize
text: Philips, the Netherlands-based consumer electronics giant, is now $10 million richer, having just won the L Prize, awarded by the federal Department of Energy in a contest to invent the next generation of solid-state lighting.

headline: Feuds: Hugh Hefner and Crystal Harris
text: THE breakup between Hugh Hefner and Crystal Harris quickly turned from amicable to ugly when Ms. Harris ended a round of press interviews by going on Howard Stern’s radio show and telling him that she never saw her ex-fiancé in the nude and that sex between them “lasted like two seconds.” As with many modern-day spats, the disintegration of the relationship was largely played out on Twitter.

headline: Mubarak Spectacle Captivates the Middle East
text: Hosni Mubarak’s televised trial transformed Egypt and much of the Middle East into a vast living room on Wednesday, with millions of viewers, from the shops of Amman and Jerusalem to the hovels of impoverished Yemen, mesmerized by the live broadcasts of a once-unthinkable spectacle beamed from a Cairo court.

headline: Crispy Fried Chicken
text: Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to make succulent, delectable fried chicken.

headline: Good Technique Means Great Fried Chicken
text: You don’t need a recipe to make crunchy, juicy, excellent fried chicken. It’s not about adding the right amount of this and a tiny pinch of that, or tossing in some secret ingredient (though a chicken is, of course, de rigueur). Great fried chicken depends above all on good technique.

headline: Scene City: Russell Simmons and the Art of Giving
text: The hip-hop impresario holds his annual Art for Life benefit in the Hamptons.

headline: Libya Allying With Islamists, Qaddafi Son Says
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — After six months battling a rebellion that his family portrayed as an Islamist conspiracy, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s son and one-time heir apparent said Wednesday that he was reversing course to forge a behind-the-scenes alliance with radical Islamist elements among the Libyan rebels to drive out their more liberal-minded confederates.

headline: Hulu to Host Its First Original Series
text: For the first time, the online video Web site Hulu is going to be the exclusive home for a television-style series.

headline: To Split or Not to Split
text: It felt to me like a whole new level of bungling was needed before I met my standard of a new entry for the Beekeeper’s Journal.  Yes, I had lost both hives during an exceedingly cold snap in the preceding winter.  Yes, I had gone through the process of ordering packaged bees from Georgia and had even managed the workaround of securing two northward-trucked hives when the Georgia apiaries delayed shipment because of a devastating southern winter.  Yes, I had somehow installed the queens and hives, which involved the usual banging and subsequent pouring of nearly 3,000 bees into their new home, even though I was sure I had broken my hand earlier that day (a gangly kid on “Nature Walk” at school got tangled in my feet and dropped me to the pavement).  Yes, I watched in June as a cluster of 10,000 bees swarmed from one hive and coagulated on a tree branch sixty feet above the ground.  None of these events taken alone seemed to merit an instructive tale.  It was the swarm, however, that lay the groundwork for my recent mid-Summer bungle.

While gay couples in New York are now treated like any other married couple under the state tax law, things get more complicated when filing federal taxes. She writes:

text: The calls come at least once a week these days, with growing urgency: friends of the Republican presidential candidates, aides to the candidates, and often the candidates themselves, wondering if Al Hoffman Jr. might be ready to lend a hand.

headline: A Double Game Swing Missed, a Title Won
text: Two major titles were decided on Sunday, the last day of the Summer North American Championships in Toronto.

headline: A Study of Time, Love and Decay in Genoa
text: “The places we walk through are an excavation of memory — forbidden remembrances of a lost world,” muses the unseen occasional narrator of Pietro Marcello’s impressionistic, extravagantly poetic documentary “The Mouth of the Wolf.”

headline: For a Harlem Theater, Hope Amid the Hurdles
text: The “Henry V” that begins this Friday in the newly renovated amphitheater at Mount Morris Park is quintessential Classical Theater of Harlem: a gritty, hyperactive production of a Shakespearean drama, featuring a mostly black cast. Not as apparent are the lofty ambitions this play (and the company’s other plans) represent, or the daunting hurdles it faces.

headline: Everybody Wants Her, Whoever She May Be
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — “Femme Fatale.” “Temptress.” “Sexy Assassin.” Those were the verbal self-descriptions Britney Spears projected onstage at Nassau Coliseum here on Tuesday night.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: iPads for Pilots
text: Airlines are starting to see the iPad as a helpful tool for pilots. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein chats with Alaska Airlines’ director of flight standards, Jim Freeman, about how its pilots are using the iPad in the cockpit. Mr. Freeman, who also flies for the airline, says that the device can serve as an electronic flight bag, allowing pilots to ditch many pounds of paper they have to carry — manuals, charts and other documents that must be on board the aircraft. He said pilots keep the devices on “airplane mode” during takeoff and landing.

headline: Nature Paints Backdrop for City Ballet’s Stars
text: VAIL, Colo. — The only scenery for much of New York City Ballet’s repertory is a plain blue backdrop suggesting the sky. At the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater here, however, there’s no backdrop. Visible behind the stage is a small rock garden and the steep pine-clad slopes of the Rockies. The auditorium and stage have side walls and a canopy, but what you remember are the gaps through which you see the mountaintops. The balletgoer who thinks he knows Jerome Robbins’s “Dances at a Gathering” or George Balanchine’s “Duo Concertant” finds that he sees them anew in such a setting.

headline: NYCB MOVES
text: Images of the dancers in the new company taken by fellow dancers in Vail, Colo.

headline: Hey Kids! Robots!
text: New from Radica, a division of Mattel: Fijit Friends ($50 each, fijitfriends.com, for girls 6-9), a set of four chatty robots that can dance to music, detect voice prompts and hear “sonic chirp” codes embedded in videos or sites.

headline: Mom and Dad and the Two Kids They Damage
text: The little boy and girl sing plaintively for a crowd. In front of them an open guitar case bears a handwritten note reading: “Our dog needs an operation. Please help us save him.” The audience members show sympathy for these two sad kids until, out of the blue, a man starts heckling. “You’re terrible!” he shouts. Suddenly, the scene turns contentious, split between cries of “Keep playing, children” and “Don’t quit your day job.”

headline: Where to Get the World’s Best Service
text: International travelers weigh in on the level of service they experienced in 24 countries.

text: Louis Langrée conducts the festival orchestra, with Christian Tetzlaff, violin, and Antoine Tamestit, viola, performing "Sinfonia concertante in E-flat major for violin and viola."

headline: Judge Explains Letting a Reporter Protect His Source
text: A federal court on Wednesday unsealed a judge’s opinion from last week explaining why she had issued an order on July 29 largely quashing a subpoena to the writer of a book on the Central Intelligence Agency. The ruling protected the writer –- James Risen, who is also a reporter for The New York Times –- from testifying in the trial of a former C.I.A. official who is accused of leaking information to Mr. Risen about the agency’s effort to sabotage Iranian nuclear research a decade ago.

headline: Showcasing the Viola in Updated Mozart
text: The Mostly Mozart Festival opened on Tuesday night with its music director, Louis Langrée, conducting the festival orchestra in a Mozart program amid the trappings that have re-energized this popular summer offering in recent seasons.

headline: A Veteran Sideman Takes the Lead
text: Rufus Reid took the lead on just one tune in his early set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night, but he made it count. Arms wrapped around his upright bass, he played “If You Could See Me Now,” the jazz ballad by Tadd Dameron, with a slow, sumptuous ease, applying a wide vibrato to most of his notes. His tone was hearty and resounding, and his technique nimble enough to seem utterly natural.

headline: Where to Get the World’s Best Service
text: International travelers weigh in on the level of service they experienced in 24 countries.

headline: Three Receivers Are Seeking a Second Opportunity With the Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants will give a wide receiver a second chance this season. It just won’t be the one many fans wanted.

headline: Sending Your Tunes Around the Home
text: It’s a question as old as the hills: How do I move music off of my computer or smartphone and into the speakers in my house?

headline: Summer at Camp Couture
text: COLOR wars at camp are a common American pastime, but the one that took place in a small building on East 53rd Street in Manhattan on a recent Tuesday was of a different stripe.

headline: Fashion Camp
text: Young women forgo fresh air and campfires to create their own designs at Fashion Camp.

headline: A Dashboard for Your Body
text: ONE recent morning, I woke up at 6:45, spent about 20 minutes preparing for the day (mainly this involves my persnickety multistep coffee-making process), and then strolled down the hall to my home office.

headline: Security Council Rebuke of Syria Ends Prolonged Deadlock
text: UNITED NATIONS — The Security Council on Wednesday broke its protracted impasse over responding to the bloody repression of the protest movement in Syria, issuing its first denunciation of the violence there since the uprising began five months ago and putting the onus on President Bashar al-Assad’s regime.

headline: ‘The Tenant’
text: Photos of a rehearsal of the latest site-specific work from the Woodshed Collective.

headline: No Space Too Dilapidated for a Show
text: FOR about three years the West-Park Presbyterian Church, at the corner of 86th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, sat abandoned as architects, congregants and preservationists squabbled over a plan to build condominiums above the rosy, Romanesque Revival structure. When landmark designation last year quashed development plans, worshipers returned to a building much in need of repairs. In the parish house that abuts the chapel, paint peels, damp patches spread, and musty odors rise from the basement.

headline: A Desert House That Soaks Up the View
text: A 1,200-square-foot house in Nevada looks out on an almost limitless landscape.

headline: In the High Nevada Desert, Sleeping in Star-Surround
text: SCOTTY’S JUNCTION, Nev.

headline: KO, OK
text: On Keith Olbermann tonight.

headline: At Mia Hamm’s Celebrity Challenge, the Hero Wore Cargo Shorts
text: WASHINGTON — A young man in a yellow polo shirt stood in the middle of the futsal court, surrounded by his family, and even with his sunglasses on, you could tell that he was crying.

headline: The Truth About Fundamentals
text: Herewith I offer a fundamental law about fundamentals:

headline: Hope Is Not A Plan
text: Nor is it good politics. So what the heck are they thinking?

headline: Star Departs Roundabout’s ‘Death Takes a Holiday’
text: The British actor Julian Ovenden, whose powerful tenor and leading-man looks positioned him as a star attraction in the new Off Broadway musical “Death Takes a Holiday,” has departed the Roundabout Theater Company production and will be replaced by an understudy, a Roundabout spokesman announced on Wednesday night.

headline: Airline pilots using iPads; Cowon's Plenue D3 and C2 media players; Photo stitching; news
text: The iPad as the new best friend of pilots? Bettina Edelstein chats with Alaska Airlines's director of flight standards, Jim Freeman, about pilots using the iPad as an electronic flight bag. Yes, you can recapture that big wide view from your vacation trip. J.D. Biersdorfer explains how to make photo panoramas. Pedro Rafael Rosado, who can't stay away from portable media players, checks out two new ones from Cowon: the Plenue D3 and the smaller C2. The news roundup includes Adobe's preview of an alternative to Flash for Web designers; Android malware that can intercept phone calls; Verizon Wireless phones turning into digital wallets; iTunes movies and shows streaming on Apple TV; more on the Windows XP deathwatch. J.D.'s tip of the week: how to use search engine settings to filter unsavory query results.

headline: 100 or So Danish Modernist Classics, on View
text: The prolific Danish furniture designer Hans Wegner created some of the best modernist design of the 20th century. And his collaboration with the master cabinetmaker Johannes Hansen, which began in the 1940s, resulted in a number of significant pieces. Now, about 100 are on display at Wyeth, in Wainscott, N.Y., an exhibition curated by John Birch, who owns this showroom and the Wyeth store in SoHo.

headline: Sales at Angela Adams, Aero and Others
text: Angela Adams is offering 30 percent off one-of-a-kind prototype rugs, through Saturday, and 20 percent off every item online, with the checkout code “SUMMERSALE,” through Monday (the Canopy Indigo 8-by-10-foot hand-tufted wool rug, originally $1,800, is $1,260, pictured); information: (800) 255-9454 or angelaadams.com.

headline: Michele Oka Doner’s ‘Microscopic’ Wallpaper
text: When Michele Oka Doner was a teenager, her favorite book was “Microbe Hunters” by Paul de Kruif. “I loved the microscope,” said Ms. Doner, a Manhattan artist known for sculpture, furniture and home accessories that celebrate nature. “My heroine was Madame Marie Curie.”

headline: Plastic Sharks in the Fountain: The Next Chapter in Greg Lynn’s Toy Story
text: Toys abound in the 1904 Craftsman-style home in the Venice district of Los Angeles that the architect Greg Lynn shares with his wife, Sylvia Lavin, and their two children. Vinyl Japanese action figures and vintage Godzillas crowd the shelves, and even the furniture, some of which Mr. Lynn designed, is playful, charged with color and much of it made of plastic.

headline: Paper, Pleated and Clipped for Shelter
text: Molo, a Canadian company that makes furniture, lighting and a flexible partition system called Softwall, has created an indoor emergency housing system called Softshelter. The pleated paper partitions stand 6 feet high and expand as wide as 15 feet, connecting with other partitions to create a room that sleeps four. No tools are required for assembly, which takes about five minutes.

headline: Finding the Potential in Vacant Lots
text: CLEVELAND

headline: A Luggage Valet, Toughened With Steel
text: Jim Zivic, a furniture designer known for masculine pieces like tables carved out of chunks of coal and rugs with thick leather links, has turned his attention to the lowly luggage valet.

headline: Looking for Rationality in Bond Markets
text: Demand for U.S. bonds has been strong, leading to ever lower yields. Graham Bowley speaks to Ajay Rajadhyaksha about why U.S. treasuries are still an appealing safe haven.

headline: Cargill Recalls Ground Turkey Linked to Outbreak
text: Cargill, a major United States meat processor, said Wednesday that it was recalling about 36 million pounds of ground turkey produced at an Arkansas plant after it was linked to a nationwide outbreak of salmonella sickness. It appeared to be one of the largest meat recalls ever.

headline: Photos Taken by the Cameras
text: New cameras from Sony and Olympus offer professional results despite their tiny size.

headline: Christie Hefner’s Husband Is Accused of Insider Trading
text: The son-in-law of Hugh Hefner, the founder of Playboy Enterprises, was accused on Wednesday of trading in the shares of the magazine publisher with insider information.

headline: Shopping for Magazine Racks With Carrier and Company
text: The interior designers Jesse Carrier and Mara Miller shopped for racks that can double as accent pieces.

headline: Magazine Racks
text: TO keep abreast of design trends and new products, Jesse Carrier and Mara Miller, the husband-and-wife team behind the New York interior design firm Carrier and Company, read a lot of magazines. “We have 12 or 13 subscriptions and try to page through everything,” said Ms. Miller, 39.

headline: A Scene From 'American Boy'
text: A scene from Martin Scorsese's "American Boy," featuring Steven Prince. (Martin Scorsese Collection)

headline: Large Banks in Europe Struggle With Weak Bonds
text: LONDON — Ever since the European debt crisis began, the risk of contagion — of problems spreading from smaller countries to bigger ones, like Italy and Spain — has worried government officials and investors.

headline: How Democrats Can Win Back Voters
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rory McIlroy Feels America’s Balmier Weather Calling
text: AKRON, Ohio — Rory McIlroy was not kidding after the British Open when he said he did not care much for the weather there and liked playing American-style golf courses better than Britain’s seaside links.

headline: Hughes Takes Lead in Rotation Competition
text: CHICAGO — Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had been evasive for days, refusing to commit to any sort of a plan for his two young starters, Phil Hughes and Ivan Nova, beyond the starts that each was scheduled to make this week. With six starters currently on the roster, Girardi had said he wanted to see each pitcher one more time before deciding which one would remain in the team’s rotation.

headline: Shark Feast for Viewers on Discovery
text: It’s that magical time of year again. Sunday marked the beginning of the 24th annual “Shark Week” on Discovery Channel with the comedian Andy Samberg presiding over the festivities. “Great White Invasion” kicked things off for 3.3 million viewers, followed by “Jaws Comes Home” with 3 million, which was also good enough to make it the No. 2 program in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic on cable, trailing only HBO’s “True Blood.”

headline: Medical Device Approval
text: To the Editor:

headline: Skewering Afghan Officials by Holding Up a Mirror
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the decrepit buildings that house Afghanistan’s ministries, one office is always new: the minister’s. It is also often where corrupt deals are done, incompetence often reigns and favoritism is the primary currency.

headline: Brands Now Direct Their Followers to Social Media
text: MARKETERS promoting their products online have followed a fairly standard arc historically, first buying digital ads and building their own Web sites in the early years of the Internet, and more recently amassing followers on social networks like Facebook and Twitter.

headline: For Disabled Man Left in Van, Cause of Death Is Unclear
text: The dark Ford Econoline van sat on a busy avenue in East Harlem through a warm morning and well into a hot afternoon on Tuesday, with Alonzo Eason, a developmentally disabled man, slumping in the rear seat, according to police and state officials.

headline: Pentagon Sounds Alarm on Threat of Budget Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon pushed back aggressively on Wednesday against what senior officials warned was the prospect of $1 trillion in military budget cuts and thousands of layoffs, furloughs and reductions in military programs over the next decade.

headline: Taliban Hint at Interest in Negotiated Settlement
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have begun to send signals that they are interested in a negotiated settlement, potentially offering an opening for the West and the Afghan government, several Western officials said.

headline: Building in Flood Zones
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giants Pull Their Unhappy Defensive End Off the Market, for Now
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The trade window for the disgruntled defensive end Osi Umenyiora has closed.

headline: Bluegrass Archetypes, With Gentle Voices of Ardor and Melancholy
text: Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, just before “Bonita and Bill Butler,” the dobro player Jerry Douglas tapped Alison Krauss’s shoulder and whispered something in her ear. She laughed a bit, then stepped ever so slightly away from center stage, so that Dan Tyminski, the guitar and mandolin virtuoso in her band Union Station, could take on lead singing duties for the song.

headline: TimesCast | Qaddafi's Son Speaks
text: August 3, 2011 - In a rare interview, the son of Libya's Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi, Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, remains defiant.

headline: Improving Maternal Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: TimesCast | Syrian Tanks Storm Hama
text: August 3, 2011 - Syrian president Bashar al-Assad sends tanks into Hama to crush the opposition.

headline: Actress Says She Can’t Be Evicted Because She Moved Out
text: The day after court records revealed that Faye Dunaway would be joining the masses of New Yorkers braving housing court for a landlord-tenant showdown, it was time for the Oscar-winning actress to share her side of the story.

headline: Conduct and Drug Policies Remain as Final Hurdles
text: The N.F.L. players union remained confident Wednesday afternoon that players would be able to vote to ratify a new collective bargaining agreement Thursday.

headline: Bloggingheads: Where's the Fed?
text: Brad DeLong, left, of the University of California, Berkeley, and Brink Lindsey of the Kauffman Foundation debate the Federal Reserve and the bad economy.

headline: Woman Says Her Uncle Was a Famous Hijacker
text: SEATTLE — Marla Cooper stepped forward Wednesday to claim that her uncle Lynn Doyle Cooper was the famed “D. B. Cooper” who mesmerized the world by hijacking a plane almost 40 years ago and bailing out somewhere over the rugged terrain of southwest Washington. His body was never found.

headline: Daily Deal Web Sites Become Players in Their Own Deals
text: One maxim rings true in the burgeoning world of online coupons: Everybody wants a deal.

headline: TimesCast | Mubarak's Trial Begins
text: Aug. 3, 2011 — Hosni Mubarak, the ousted Egyptian president, in court on a hospital bed.

headline: Immigrant Identities, Preserved in Vinegar?
text: TENSIONS over immigration in Europe are flaring this summer, along with questions about what — whether language, dress or diet — makes a foreigner a citizen. Of course, these questions also have a long history in America.

headline: Worry Grows Over Delays in F.A.A. Pay
text: WASHINGTON — Airport operators said Wednesday that a prolonged delay in restoring federal funds for airport construction projects would eventually endanger airport safety and lead to more passenger delays.

headline: Bloomberg to Use Own Funds in Plan to Aid Minority Youth
text: The administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in a blunt acknowledgment that thousands of young black and Latino men are cut off from New York’s civic, educational and economic life, plans to spend nearly $130 million on far-reaching measures to improve their circumstances.

headline: Bill Bergen’s Awesome Record of Baseball Futility
text: Today’s lesson, gleaned from baseball history, is that if you are going to be bad at something, be spectacularly bad. And if you are spectacularly bad enough, people might be talking about you 100 years after you retire.

headline: In Israel, the Rent Is Too Damn High
text: Tel Aviv

headline: Battling Longer Odds, but Still Courting Fans
text: AKRON, Ohio — When Phil Mickelson pulled into a tie for the lead by playing the front nine at Royal St. George’s Golf Club in five under par three Sundays ago, he looked very much as if he was about to win his first British Open.

headline: Iraq to Open Talks With U.S. on Troop Presence Past 2011
text: BAGHDAD — American officials said Wednesday that an announcement by the Iraqi government that it was ready to open formal discussions with the United States about keeping some troops in Iraq after the end of the year was a positive first step toward resolving the question about the American military’s future presence here.

headline: With Rally, Christian Group Asserts Its Presence in ’12 Race
text: TUPELO, Miss. — To its admirers on the religious right, the American Family Association is a stalwart leader in a last-ditch fight to save America’s Christian culture and the values of traditional families. To its liberal critics, it is a shrill, even hateful voice of intolerance, out to censor the arts, declare Muslims unfit for public office and deny equality to gay men and lesbians because they engage in sinful “aberrant sexual behavior.”

headline: New Breed of Leaders Helped Guide Fuel Standards, Chrysler Says
text: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich. — New leadership from outside Detroit was a deciding factor in the Big Three automakers’ acceptance of strict new fuel-economy standards, the chief executive of Chrysler said Wednesday.

headline: Alex Rodriguez to Be Asked About Poker Games
text: Once again, officials for Major League Baseball want to meet with Alex Rodriguez. This time, though, it is not about performance-enhancing drugs. In the coming weeks, baseball officials plan to question Rodriguez about reports of his participation in illegal poker games.

headline: Celebrating the Girls of Summer
text: As the millions of readers who made “The Help” a publishing phenomenon know, the novel explores the poignantly modest aspirations and profound humiliations of black maids in Mississippi in the 1960s. It’s a story of racial injustice, reconciliation and sweet, overdue revenge.

headline: Bubba Smith, N.F.L. Star and Actor, Dies at 66
text: When hearing tales of Bubba Smith, you wonder, is he man or myth?— Ogden Nash

headline: Scoring Outside the Lines
text: I.

headline: For High-End Goods, a Recovery
text: Apparel stores are struggling to get customers to spend, even with sales and coupons. But luxury retailers are beginning to raise prices to pre-recession levels.

headline: Who Will Help the Syrians?
text: As many as 1,600 courageous Syrians have been slaughtered since pro-democracy demonstrations began in March. On Wednesday, after three days of shelling, President Bashar al-Assad ordered his military to storm Hama, the city where his father killed up to 20,000 people three decades ago.

headline: Corrections: August 4
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: New Jockeying in Congress for Next Phase in Budget Fight
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans and Democrats maneuvered for advantage on Wednesday in the next battle over federal spending, trying to influence the choice of members and frame the agenda for a powerful “supercommittee” that is supposed to recommend at least $1.5 trillion of additional deficit reduction measures.

headline: Rainout Means Mets Don’t Lose
text: The Mets did not end their four-game losing streak Wednesday night, but not because of any bullpen meltdowns or fielding gaffes: their scheduled game against the Florida Marlins at Citi Field was rained out.

headline: Even Marked Up, Luxury Goods Fly Off Shelves
text: Nordstrom has a waiting list for a Chanel sequined tweed coat with a $9,010 price. Neiman Marcus has sold out in almost every size of Christian Louboutin “Bianca” platform pumps, at $775 a pair. Mercedes-Benz said it sold more cars last month in the United States than it had in any July in five years.

headline: Why Do Russians Hate Ice?
text: A Russian acquaintance of mine who grew up in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, recently told me that her father microwaved his orange juice. Her grandmother also used to heat her ice cream in a saucepan on the stove. She remembers once asking her grandmother why it was even called “ice” cream, when by all rights it should be called warm cream, or maybe hot cream. “Things have all kinds of crazy names,” her grandmother snapped back. “How should I know?”

headline: Seeking Balance on the Mideast
text: Congress periodically showcases the warts of democracy, occasionally even the deformities and disfigurements, and it might seem difficult to top the latest debt ceiling horrors. But there’s one area where Congress has been even more obstructionist: the Middle East.

headline: The Down Side of Corzine’s Promise
text: Jon Corzine makes no secret of the fact that politics is his passion. Now buyers of debt in MF Global, the firm he runs, are set to get a boost if the former Democratic politico and Goldman Sachs chief should leave the broker-dealer to decamp to Washington.

headline: To Fight Radical Islam, U.S. Wants Muslim Allies
text: WASHINGTON — Rolling out a new strategy for combating radicalization, White House officials on Wednesday warned that casting broad suspicion on Muslim Americans is counterproductive and could backfire by alienating a religious minority and fueling extremism.

headline: Time Warner Reports 10% Revenue Increase and Raises Its Outlook
text: Time Warner, the owner of Warner Brothers, Turner Broadcasting and Time Inc., on Wednesday reported a 10 percent rise in revenue for the quarter that ended in June — its highest growth rate since 2007 — and slightly revised upward its earnings guidance for the year.

headline: Obama, on Verge of 50, Returns to Fund-Raising
text: CHICAGO — For many men, turning 50 can be a day of reckoning, marked by graying hair, a slowing step and the wistful recognition that you are probably never going to make it to the corner office. What could be better, at such a melancholy moment, than to celebrate at home, among old friends?

headline: Lottery Numbers
NBCUniversal Helps Lift Comcast’s Quarterly Results
text: It has been six months since Comcast gained control of NBCUniversal from General Electric, and the Comcast chief executive Brian L. Roberts says he continues to believe that “our timing was just right.”

headline: The Woods Watch Turns Into Rubbernecking
text: Ending a three-month layoff, Tiger Woods will return to competitive golf Thursday, beginning the latest in a series of long-shot comebacks since 2009, a time in which his golfing empire has been battered by scandal, his loyal entourage purged and his once-exemplary physique betrayed by serious injury.

headline: Medtronic Giving Yale Grant to Review Bone Growth Data
text: Facing intensifying scrutiny over one of its bone growth products, Medtronic announced Wednesday that it was giving a $2.5 million grant to Yale to oversee a complete review of the study data that examined the product’s safety and effectiveness.

headline: Thursday: Beginning to Knock
text: Administrivial Out of Town Alert! Did you know that when you send your kids to sleep away camp, they actually make you take them back?? Neither did I, but that’s where I’m headed this weekend, and comments will be temporarily moderated by some lucky, lucky staffers at The New York Times. Please be patient with them, and I will see you all Sunday evening for the Monday post.

headline: To Relieve Tension, Mind the Spine but Do Not Relax
text: Michael Ostrow was studying Buddhism at the San Francisco Zen Center, searching for a career that dovetailed with his philosophy degree from Brandeis University, when he began to experience severe back pain during meditation sessions. A fellow student told him about the rejuvenating properties of the Alexander Technique, and after several lessons, he switched from Zen to studying the technique and ultimately trained to teach it. Mr. Ostrow, 55, and his wife, Laurie Kline, 54, a dancer turned Alexander instructor, have run the New York Center for the Alexander Technique near Union Square since 1990. They live in North Bergen, N.J.

headline: The F.A.A., After the Republicans
text: Here is what has happened since the Federal Aviation Administration lost its authorization on July 23, courtesy of House Republicans. The agency has not collected more than $300 million in taxes (money the airlines have mostly pocketed). It has had to furlough some 4,000 workers and halt construction projects worth $11 billion in 241 airports, putting 70,000 more people out of work.

headline: A Precedent for Press Freedom
text: Faced with prosecutorial demands to know journalists’ confidential sources, judges bow too often to the government’s wishes without considering carefully enough whether a need for the information to make the government’s case outweighs the needs and rights of reporters and an informed public.

headline: New York and the Eighth-Month Lull
text: Where is the August of yesteryear? It seems almost mythical now, that leisurely month when Manhattan emptied out like a scene from “The Seven Year Itch.” In those days, the weekend annexed Mondays and Fridays, and the business cycle pulled over to the curb and lowered its kickstand. Book publishing shut down almost entirely, and the city’s psychiatrists trooped away from their couches for the month. The days were torpid, and, at night, a martini moon hung in a seersucker sky.

headline: Indian Point May Enlist Giuliani as Defender
text: This has been a tough year for the long-beleaguered Indian Point nuclear plant. In January, a longtime critic, Andrew M. Cuomo, was sworn in as governor, and proceeded to push for the facility to be shuttered because of its proximity to New York City and its susceptibility to earthquakes and terrorist attacks. Then, in March, a tsunami precipitated a reactor meltdown in Japan, stoking new fears about the safety of nuclear power plants, especially those near population centers.

headline: Pfizer Is Said to Pursue Nonprescription Lipitor
text: Pfizer hopes to introduce an over-the-counter version of Lipitor, the world’s best-selling drug, after it loses patent protection in November, a person close to the situation said Wednesday.

headline: Pressured by White House, Treasury Secretary Is Expected to Stay at Post
text: WASHINGTON — Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary and dean of President Obama’s economic team, is expected to stay through the president’s term after intense White House pressure, according to officials familiar with the discussions.

headline: The Mets’ Latest Problem: Finding a Position in the Field for Murphy
text: The steady, unexpected resurgence of Daniel Murphy, in which an extraneous player has transformed himself into an essential one, has provided the Mets with a welcome story line in a season in which they are battling to stay relevant.

headline: Network That Preyed on Children Is Broken
text: WASHINGTON — Federal investigators announced on Wednesday that they had dismantled a sophisticated global network of pedophiles who traded pornographic videos and images of children as young as infants over the Internet, using encryption and proxy servers to evade detection.

headline: Swedish Nationalists in Struggling City See Rival Parties Steal Their Thunder
text: LANDSKRONA, Sweden — The Ahlgren family in this struggling industrial city offers one lens to view both the festering anger that has fueled the rise of anti-immigrant parties in Europe, including Scandinavia, and the potential for a backlash.

headline: Obama Takes Steps to Help Avert Atrocities
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, looking for ways to strengthen the American response to genocide and other mass atrocities, on Thursday will announce a ban on visas for people who the State Department finds have been involved in human rights violations, White House officials said.

headline: Battle for Libya | August 3, 2011
text: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said Wednesday that he was reversing course to forge a secret alliance with radical Islamist elements among the Libyan rebels.

headline: France: Noriega Extradition Approved
text: France approved the extradition of the former dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega to his native Panama, an official at the prime minister’s office said Wednesday. According to his lawyer, Yves Leberquier, Mr. Noriega will not be extradited before September. Last year, Mr. Noriega, left, who ruled Panama from 1983 to 1989, was sentenced by a French judge to seven years in prison for laundering $3 million in Colombian drug money through international banks and into French accounts. He had previously been jailed in Miami on charges that included cocaine trafficking. The government of Panama has requested that Mr. Noriega be extradited from France in order to serve three 20-year prison terms for human rights abuses and involvement in the disappearance of political opponents.

headline: Japan Buys Dollars to Weaken the Surging Yen
text: TOKYO — Japan said Thursday that it had intervened in the foreign exchange market, selling yen and buying dollars in a bid to reverse a punishing spike in the value of the Japanese currency.

headline: Death of Homeless Man After Beating by Police Stirs Outrage
text: LOS ANGELES — In one video, the sound of a Taser going off is followed by a man screaming in pain. In another, footage from a security camera on a public bus, riders describe police officers beating a man to death in graphic terms. “They beat him up, and then all the cops came and they hogtied him, and he was like, ‘Please God, please Dad!,’ ” one said.

headline: Gay Candidate Drops Out of Irish Presidential Race
text: David Norris, a frontrunner for Ireland's presidency who is openly gay, dropped out of the race on Tuesday, after it was revealed that he once appealed for clemency for a former partner who had been convicted of the statutory rape of a 15-year-old boy.

headline: A Do-It-Yourself ‘Green’ Home
text: Jerome Johnson’s house in Flatbush, Brooklyn, is an artifact of do-it-yourself green architecture. However, he is about to lose it to foreclosure.

headline: ‘Collar Bomb’ Was a Fake, Australian Police Say
text: After the police in Sydney, Australia, spent 10 hours trying to free an 18-year-old from what she had been told was a bomb chained to her neck, as we wrote here on Wednesday, officials said the device contained no explosives. The Associated Press reports that tests revealed the “bomb” was a fake, according to Mark Murdoch, the assistant commissioner of the New South Wales police.

headline: Yankees Rise Above Burnett’s Shortcomings to Rout White Sox
text: CHICAGO — Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had been evasive for days, refusing to commit to any sort of a plan for his two young starters, Phil Hughes and Ivan Nova, beyond the starts that each was scheduled to make this week.

headline: White House Names a New Chief of Information Technology
text: Steven VanRoekel, a former Microsoft executive, will become the next chief information officer for the federal government — a bigger, more policy-oriented technology job than any he held at the software giant.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 08/04/11
text: NYT: Front Page for 08/04/11

headline: Senator to Block a Confirmation
text: Senator David Vitter, a Louisiana Republican, said Wednesday that he would block the confirmation of an Interior Department official until the government extended leases for oil exploration in the Gulf of Mexico. Mr. Vitter’s spokesman said he wanted a blanket extension of all leases that expire this year to compensate for delays from last year’s oil spill; until then, the senator will block confirmation of Rebecca Wodder as assistant secretary for fish and wildlife and parks. The Interior Department has issued instructions on seeking more time on the leases; a spokeswoman said the administration had not declined requests for extensions so far.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,672 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Double Dip or Not, Economy Is Falling Further Behind
text: While Washington was busy debating whether or not to sabotage the recovery by failing to raise the federal debt ceiling, the economy seemed to be doing everything in its power to demonstrate that it’s in feeble health to begin with.

headline: Joining Switzerland, Japan Acts to Ease Currency’s Strength
text: TOKYO — As global investors flee the dollar and euro for refuge in stronger currencies, those havens have started to send out a message: enough.

headline: Japan’s Prime Minister Fires Three Nuclear Energy Officials
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Naoto Kan removed three top officials in charge of Japanese nuclear energy policy on Thursday, taking aim at the cozy ties between regulators and the power industry that were exposed after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant accident.

headline: ‘Where Children Sleep’
text: If your computer permits you to view these photographs in full-screen mode, we recommend it.

headline: Gay Pride Festival Comes to Prague
text: Starting Aug. 10, Prague will hold its inaugural gay pride festival with a tag line that nicely sets the tone: “Drink Beer, Be Queer!”

headline: Moving China Up the Value Chain
text: SHANGHAI — In “Run of the Red Queen,” a new book about China’s innovation drive, Dan Breznitz and Michael Murphree lay out a contrarian view of this country’s path. They argue that China should worry less about coming up with breakthrough technologies and focus more on what it already does best: making incremental innovations in everything from manufacturing to logistics.

headline: The Early Word: Moves
text: In Today’s Times:With the United States clear of imminent fiscal crisis, the markets are watching Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner. Jackie Calmes reminds us that Mr. Geither has said he would decide whether to stay with the Obama administration after the White House and Congress reached a deal to raise the debt ceiling. Ms. Calmes says President Obama wants Mr. Geithner to stay through 2012, and the secretary is expected to oblige. Just in case that changes, she looks at potential replacements if he leaves.

headline: Kraft to Split Its Snacks and Grocery Businesses
text: 7:39 a.m. | Updated Kraft Foods said on Thursday that it would spin off its North American grocery business from its global snacks group, a decision that comes 18 months after it bought Cadbury, the European candy maker.

headline: Remembering Bubba Smith, the Football Player
text: A few thoughts about Bubba Smith, who died yesterday at 66. He may be best remembered today as an actor and television pitchman. But he made his name on the football field, first at Michigan State, then as a Baltimore Colt. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down.

headline: BMW Guggenheim Lab: A Showcase for Urban Culture, and Carbon Fiber, Takes Shape in New York
text: Wednesday was the first public day for a novel building tucked between older structures on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. But the BMW Guggenheim Lab, a pavilion of video screens and gathering spaces aimed at investigations of urban life, barely looks like a building at all.

headline: This, I Believe, Says It All
text: Spotted on 95th and Amsterdam.

headline: Can IndieReader.com Muster Enough Traffic to Sustain a Business?
text: Last week, I asked you to take a look at Indiereader.com, a site dedicated to fans of independently published books and the authors who produce them.

headline: A Single Voice, a Single Face, a Single Story
text: ON screen just as on the stage the monologue lets us zero in on one character’s psychology and worldview. But the technique is usually selectively applied, temporarily isolating one player from the larger context of other actors and the production as a whole. Rarer is the film that, start to finish, is a one-person show: an extended aria, trading a scene-to-scene narrative for solitary storytelling and eschewing landscapes and sets for the power of one face and body.

headline: River Sand in Bedrock
text: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

headline: G.M.’s Profit Jumps 89% as U.S. Sales Grow Quickly
text: DETROIT — General Motors built surprisingly strong second-quarter results on the most basic automotive arithmetic — higher prices plus lower incentives.

headline: Debt Talk Over, Republicans Head to Iowa
text: After weeks of the all-consuming debt debate in Washington, the political conversation is about to take a sharp turn back to the 2012 presidential election as Republicans gather in Iowa for the first real test of momentum and organization.

headline: Pacific Islands Band Together on a Shark Sanctuary
text: As Americans tune in to TV programs like “Top 5 Eaten Alive” and “Jaws Comes Home” as part of Discovery Channel’s Shark Week, leaders in the western Pacific have taken a big step toward nurturing the predator: deciding jointly to create the largest shark sanctuary in the world.

headline: Skepticism Over India’s Anticorruption Bill
text: NEW DELHI — After a four-decade battle, Indian lawmakers took the first formal step toward creating an independent anticorruption agency on Thursday, introducing a bill in Parliament that would appoint a powerful ombudsman, or Lokpal, to investigate wrongdoing by government officials.

headline: A Brazilian’s Comic Mania: Social Media
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil -- When an Internet research group recently released a study concluding that the most influential person in the Twitter universe was Rafinha Bastos, a Brazilian comedian who came in well ahead of President Obama, Conan O’Brien and Kim Kardashian, the English-speaking world was predictably baffled. “Who is @RafinhaBastos?” Wired magazine asked.

headline: Supplying Brazil’s Laugh Track
text: var mmVideoPlayerOptions = {autoPlay : false,controlsBelow: true,fullScreen: false,skin: "light"};var mmVideoPlayer = new NYTMM.VideoPlayer($("embed365"),480,270,null,mmVideoPlayerOptions);mmVideoPlayer.setSources(['100000000981079','']);mmVideoPlayer.setPoster('http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2011/08/03/arts/bastos/bastos-blog480.jpg'); SWFObject.dispatchEventToSWF('nytmm_flashVideoPlayer0',{type:'setcaptions',url:'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/arts/20110803-artsbeat-movie-captions/movie2srt.xml'});Rafinha Bastos is a ringleader of sorts for a diverse group of Brazilian comedians who are irreverent and fearless. “They’re not afraid to do social criticism and commentary,” said Álvaro Paes de Barros, the general manager for Viacom in Brazil, who is supervising the start of Comedy Central there. “Really, they are quite gutsy.”

headline: Dear FloFab: My Friends Dump Their Stuff on My Counters
text: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Earnings at Fortress Drop 37%
text: The Fortress Investment Group, the publicly traded alternative asset manager run by Daniel H. Mudd, reported that earnings declined nearly 37 percent in the second quarter, as some hedge funds were hit hard by a volatile global trading environment.

headline: I.M.F. Chief to Face French Investigation
text: PARIS — A French court on Thursday ordered an investigation into charges that the International Monetary Fund’s new managing director, Christine Lagarde, had abused her authority in a 2007 dispute involving a multimillion-dollar payout to a French tycoon while she was the finance minister of France.

headline: Wrong And Right
text: Bruce Bartlett and others send me to this eloquent David Frum piece, which concludes:

headline: Why People Say “Eeh!” When They Learn About the ECB, Redux
text: ECB to halt rate hike cycle, pressured on bond buys.

headline: Sonia Gandhi in the U.S. for Operation
text: NEW DELHI — India’s most powerful politician, Sonia Gandhi, has flown to the United States for surgery, said a spokesman for the governing Congress Party, which Mrs. Gandhi leads.

headline: New York’s Ultimate Clock Watcher (and Painter)
A Better Way to Keep Patients Safe
text: Not long ago, a few colleagues and I were discussing the challenges of improving health care quality and patient safety. We debated the merits of clinical benchmarks that payers and regulatory groups now require, crude proxies of quality care like giving antibiotics at certain times, ordering specific tests at set intervals or permitting our results to be reported publicly.

headline: Nicholson Baker: The Mad Scientist of Smut
text: Nicholson Baker does not look like a dirty-book writer. His color is good. His gaze is direct, with none of the sidelong furtiveness of the compulsive masturbator. He wears round, owlish glasses­, and in early book-jacket photographs, when his beard was darker and more closely trimmed than it is now, he reminds you of one of those earnest Russian intellectuals of the 19th century. Nowadays, with the beard grown out and nearly white, he could easily get seasonal work as a shopping-mall Santa.

headline: A Movable Feast: Danny Meyer on a Roll
text: Danny Meyer scaled the subway stairs two at a time, emerged on Lexington and 77th, lengthened his stride and called over his shoulder: “Have I told you about the Meyer Street-Crossing Method? Meyscrom.” He scanned traffic. “Cut off every possible angle without being killed.”

headline: The Weight
text: Since their debut record, “North Hills,” came out two years ago, the Los Angeles-based folk-rock band Dawes has been eliciting breathless comparisons to some pretty illustrious names — Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, the Eagles, the Band. Partly it has to do with their origin myth: they recorded the album at the renowned producer Jonathan Wilson’s studio in Laurel Canyon after playing a run of small hootenannies there. But mostly it has to do with their sound, which has a warm, stripped-down Americana feel frequently described as “vintage.” Recently, the group got about as big a nod as four guys playing folk rock could hope for: Robbie Robertson, the somewhat reclusive songwriter from the Band, asked them to back him in a series of rare performances. Now in the middle of an East Coast tour to promote their follow-up record, “Nothing Is Wrong,” which was released this summer, Dawes seems both honored and amused to have been credited with leading a revival of the Laurel Canyon sound.

text: For more local news from The Times, including Mayor Michael R. headline: Concrete Tests Faked Again, Officials Charge
text: In 2008, a company hired to test the strength of the concrete used at major public works projects in New York, including the Second Avenue subway and the new Yankee Stadium, falsified results, prosecutors concluded, and construction executives scrambled to find a replacement.

headline: Cleaning Up After the Storms
text: In Alabama and Missouri, residents and government agencies face the daunting task of removing the debris from this year’s tragic abundance of tornadoes.

headline: The Cleanup Grinds On for Months After Disasters
text: Mother Nature is not like typical moms who tell their kids to clean up their messes. Mother Nature makes messes, and big ones.

headline: The Alternate Lives of Lauren Ambrose
text: Scientific theory and philosophy suggest that an infinite number of alternate realities may be possible, and that a new universe is created at every decision-making juncture in our lives, no matter how small or significant. And the above video suggests that in at least one such universe, the onetime “Star Search” contestant Lauren Ambrose grew up not to be the dark, complicated soul we know from the HBO series “Six Feet Under” but instead some sort of latter-day answer to Shirley Temple. (What was it that steered Ms. Ambrose as we know her off this trajectory? Was it being stuck in a bathroom with Seth Green in “Can’t Hardly Wait”?)

headline: Stocks Plunge on Fears of Global Turmoil
text: What began as a weak day in the stock markets ended in the worst rout in more than two years, as investors dumped stocks amid anxiety that both Europe and the United States were failing to fix deepening economic problems.

headline: What Does Buffett Think?
text: Warren E. Buffett lodged plenty of complaints last year when Kraft moved to buy Cadbury. But the billionaire investor told CNBC that he had no problem with the company’s decision to split in two.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Kraft Foods to Spin Off Grocery Business | A year and a half after buying Cadbury, Kraft Foods said on Thursday that it would split into two companies by spinning off its North American grocery business from its global snacks enterprise. The separation is expected to take at least 12 months, and be completed before the end of 2012.

headline: A Family Risk for Macular Degeneration
text: Does macular degeneration run in families? Several readers of the Consults blog had questions about the genetics of macular degeneration. Stephen Rose, chief research officer of the Foundation Fighting Blindness, responds.

text: The Blackstone Group agreed on Thursday to buy Emdeon, a medical data services provider, for about $3 billion, including debt, in the latest takeover within the health care services industry.

headline: Thursday Reading: Calculating the Real Age of Your Dog
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

text: In a long profile in The Times, Sean Wilsey trails Danny Meyer around Manhattan and Miami, attempting to distill the restaurateur’s philosophy. There is an explication of the Danny Meyer Street Crossing Method (“Meyerscrom”), an observation of a brainstorming session with Floyd Cardoz over the menu for their forthcoming restaurant in Battery Park City (“What if vegetables were the main course?”, and a three-part rationale for his refusal to clone one of his fine-dining restaurants in Las Vegas:

headline: Morgan Stanley C.E.O. Buys $2 Million of Firm’s Stock
text: It is no secret that James P. Gorman is one of Morgan Stanley’s biggest supporters. Now the Morgan Stanley chief executive is putting his money where his mouth is, buying 100,000 shares on Thursday, a purchase valued at roughly $2 million.

headline: James Ford Seale, Imprisoned Klansman, Dies at 76
text: James Ford Seale, a former Ku Klux Klansman who was convicted on federal kidnapping charges more than 40 years after the abduction, torture and drowning of two black teenagers near the Mississippi-Louisiana border in 1964, died Tuesday at the federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind. He was 76.

headline: Looking Apocalypse in the Eye
text: “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” an amusingly cheerful film about the end of humanity that’s PETA and critic approved — no animals were harmed in its making, and neither was James Franco’s career — is precisely the kind of summer diversion that the studios have such a hard time making now. It’s good, canny-dumb fun. Employing bleeding-edge technologies in the service of old-fashioned entertainment, it insists on the emotional truth of its absurd story, its tongue in cheek (and in check), while offering self-aware asides, like the ritual bow to Charlton Heston, the lockjaw hero of the original 1968 “Planet of the Apes.”

headline: ‘My So-Called Adulthood’
text: Long before we had much life to look back on, North Americans my age knew that nostalgia was a sickness. It’s not that we were aware the term was coined to describe the crippling melancholia that overcame many 17th-century Swiss soldiers when war took them away from the bucolic mountain landscapes of home. It was that, being in our teens and 20s in the early 1990s, we had grown up in the penumbra of the great eclipsing nostalgia of the baby boomers, with their 1950s “Happy Days”; their 1960s (the Greatest Decade Ever Told); and their serial losses of innocence, via the Kennedys’ assassinations, Vietnam, Watergate, etc. — a record of revirginization to rival any evangelical chastity-pledge campaign.

headline: Seeing Things | Size Matters
text: The New York architecture firm Lewis.Tsurumaki.Lewis (LTL) is taking up residence on Hollywood’s Walk of Fame with “4 Projects: 4 Scales,” a new exhibition at Woodbury University’s Hollywood outpost, at 6518 Hollywood Boulevard. Riffing on Rem Koolhaas’s iconic 1990s book “S, M, L, XL,” the exhibition focuses on projects that range in size from the micro to the massive, in a mix of built and speculative work. For the site-specific installation, LTL inserted a three-sided container with etched and printed surfaces into a long, narrow gallery space. Visitors entering the container make their way through the exhibition from the largest of the four projects on view to the smallest, walking on a white-painted wood floor that is laser-etched with the plans of each project. Canted walls of backlit panels provide photographs, architectural drawings and descriptive text. “Water Proving Ground,” at 69 million square feet, is LTL’s extra-large project. This visionary master plan for the northwest corner of New York Harbor was conceived as part of MoMA/P.S. 1’s recent “Rising Currents” initiative, which studied the impact of anticipated sea-level change on the city. The other projects in the show are all built works: Arthouse, a contemporary art center in Austin, Tex.; the Sullivan Family Student Center at the University of Wyoming in Laramie; and Lobby Wall, a site-specific sculpture for the lobby of Memorial Sloan-Kettering’s new Manhattan building, which is the smallest of the projects at 108 square feet.

headline: Civilian Toll Is Mounting in Assault on Syrian City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian human rights activists said Thursday that Syrian government forces had killed more than 100 people in the rebellious city of Hama in the first 24 hours since seizing control of its central square with armored columns and snipers.

headline: Mexican pop singer Ximena Sariñana; a visit from the band we dare not name; and a Song of the Week.
text: This week’s Popcast: three killer new albums, miles between styles. headline: Republicans Set Sights on Balanced Budget Amendment
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans, feeling they have scored significant fiscal victories, are moving on to an even bigger challenge: persuading voters, state legislatures and Democrats to alter the Constitution with a balanced budget amendment.

headline: Trans-Atlantic Inspiration: Adele Says Next Album Will Have a Country Flavor
text: If you detected an Appalachian twang in the opening verse of Adele’s smash hit “Rolling in the Deep,” you may have gotten a taste of the British singer’s future work. She told the Sun newspaper in Britain this week that she became hooked on American country music and bluegrass while touring in the United States earlier this year and that she wants to write the songs on her next album in that vein.

headline: BRD: Another West Coast Start-Up Takes Fight to Gas-Engined Dirt and Street Bikes
text: A San Francisco start-up is looking to muscle in on the West Coast boomlet of electric motorcycle manufacturers. Like the outwardly similar S and DS from Zero Motorcycles, built in the Bay Area, and the Brammo Engage series from Oregon, the BRD Redshift MX and Redshift SM are designed around the sit-up architecture of traditional dirt bikes, with the knobby-tired MX version designed for track and off-road riding and the smooth-tired SM intended for general short-range street use.

headline: New York Film Festival Prefers ‘My Week With Marilyn’ for Centerpiece Gala
text: Marilyn Monroe will make an unexpected appearance at the New York Film Festival in the form of Michelle Williams, who portrays the cinematic bombshell in “My Week With Marilyn,” a biographical feature that will be presented as the festival’s Centerpiece Gala selection, its organizers said on Thursday.

headline: Labor’s Decline and Wage Inequality
text: The decline in organized labor’s power and membership has played a larger role in fostering increased wage inequality in the United States than is generally thought, according to a study published in the American Sociological Review this month.

headline: Arthur Murray, Test Pilot, Is Dead at 92
text: “I begin to feel weightless, and I’m flying so fast my instruments can’t keep up — they show what happened two miles ago. I’m climbing so steeply I can’t see the ground, and I feel confused. I have a sense of falling and I want to grab something for support.”

headline: For Chicago Actress, a Broadway Debut Opposite Connick in ‘On a Clear Day’

Ms. Peck was in an apartment in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, with four other New York-based professional dancers who had gathered for a viewing of that Fox reality show.

headline: Will the Debt Deal Force Higher Taxes on the Rich?
text: During the 2008 campaign, President Obama and his rivals for the nomination used to talk a lot about how they were going to rid the world of both Osama bin Laden and the Bush administration’s tax cuts for the wealthy. Turns out that, of the two, Bin Laden was a whole lot easier to kill.

headline: Magic Trip
text: The Times's Ed Marks describes rare footage of the author Ken Kesey, whose 1964 cross-country, LSD-fueled road trip has recently been salvaged, and turned into a documentary.

headline: Gen X Golden Oldies
text: Once upon a time, making a personal mixtape was the purest expression of kinship. Or maybe that’s just my age showing. In my teens and early 20s, nothing seemed more important. I slaved over mixes for girls and best friends. Bad choices still haunt me. I cringe recalling a couple of Das Damen songs I dumped on a mix for a friend, especially considering he had made me a tape that included “Which Way to Go,” by the Big Boys, and “Best Friends,” by the Outlets, two all-time keepers.

headline: Levi Aron Called Fit for Trial in Leiby Kletzky Murder
text: Levi Aron, the man accused of kidnapping, murdering and dismembering an 8-year-old boy from Borough Park, Brooklyn, in a case that traumatized the Hasidic population, is competent to stand trial, according to the results of a psychological exam requested by his defense team that were revealed in court on Thursday.

headline: When They Won’t Spend the Money
text: My friend Cynthia, who works as an independent home care aide in Northern California, told me about her latest client, a 93-year-old widow who broke a hip in a fall and underwent replacement surgery. After two months in a hospital and in rehab, she returned home with instructions to hire home care four hours a day, seven days a week — a reasonable-sounding compromise between safety and independence.
