headline: The (Pipe) Dream of Opening Our Own Retail Stores
text: Since the inception of TerraCycle, I have dreamed of having our own chain of retail stores. Instead, we have always relied on stores like Wal-Mart and Whole Foods to sell our products. In the last decade, even as we shifted from selling home-and-garden products to selling a wide range of consumer products, and even as we shifted from manufacturing all our products to licensing them to assorted manufacturers, we’ve continued to sell most of our stuff through big-box retailers.

headline: Mixed Ruling in Title IX Case
text: A federal judge ruled that the University of California, Davis, which was sued by a group of female wrestlers charging sex discrimination, failed to offer enough athletic opportunities to women.

headline: Stoned Archive: Wild Ride Of the Merry Pranksters
text: If you have ever agreed to baby-sit for a friend who needed a sympathetic watchdog while experimenting with psychedelics, you know how boring it can be to observe someone else in the throes of an acid trip. Unless, heaven forbid, the friend freaks out and has to be carted off to a psych ward, there is nothing interesting about it, not even the addled oh-wow remarks of the person under the influence. Meaningful communication is possible only if you’ve also ingested hallucinogens and are flying side by side. Then you might share the clammy fantasy of crawling around inside each other’s heads.

headline: New Site to Buy and Sell Remodeling Supplies
text: You know they’re out there, in your garage: Boxes of tiles, left over from that bathroom remodeling project; old doors; maybe even an odd chandelier that doesn’t fit your current décor. You keep thinking you’ll have a yard sale and get rid of all that stuff but never get around to it.

headline: The Power of Dress
text: Today on “Morning Joe,” Mika Brzezinski lamented how buyers of $1,500 shoes were “shameless.” She pointed to the front-page article in The New York Times about buoyant luxury-goods spending in a weak economy. Before the co-host Joe Scarborough teased her off the soapbox, Ms. Brzezinski unloaded some indignation. Her aim was off, though. Sensible people might agree that it’s shameful to spend that kind of money (and more) for shoes or an article of clothing, but the wealthy and young people with decent enough jobs have been doing that for months, as retail numbers indicate.

text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s civilian leadership appointed four new commanders on Thursday, decisively strengthening its control over its armed forces less than a week after the military leadership abruptly resigned in frustration over the continuing prosecution of officers accused of plotting to overthrow the government.

headline: Mile After Mile of Tornado Debris
text: People might think that a disaster is no time to be thinking about recycling. But as my article on the enormous challenges involved in removing this year’s tornado debris reflects, the Environmental Protection Agency and state environmental officials take seriously the goal of cleaning up disasters in a responsible way. That means burning less of the debris than communities might have in the past and putting it in safe landfills.

headline: Deal Ratified by N.F.L. Players
text: N.F.L. players ratified the new 10-year collective bargaining agreement Thursday, which includes blood testing for human growth hormone, making the N.F.L. the first major American sports league to start such testing with the consent of its players union. According to the league, the goal is to begin testing by the first week of the regular season, which starts Sept. 8, and players will be tested annually and randomly.

headline: In Kraft Split, a Boon for 3 Banks
text: Kraft Foods’ plan to break itself into two pieces isn’t just good news to shareholders. It is also a win for the three banks that are advising the food giant.

headline: Teenager Arrested in Wheelchair Purse-Snatching
text: The teenager wanted in a purse-snatching from a 78-year-old woman in a wheelchair in Brooklyn was arrested on Thursday, the police say. The teenager, Cody Santiago, 18, of Bushwick, was charged with grand larceny. On July 20, the police have said, Mr. Santiago was caught on video grabbing the handbag off the woman’s lap as she rode along the sidewalk in Bushwick. The purse contained $15 and medication.

headline: Five (and Then Some) Tech Tips for Travel
text: In the big airports, you sometimes see three different lanes for the X-ray machines. They’re marked by a black diamond (expert travelers who know the routine and have their laptops out and shoes off), blue square (casual travelers) and green circle (families and people who need extra help).

headline: No Mush, Please
text: The other day I lugged home the summer issue of Acne Paper, occupying my office in-box like a hibernating bear. I’ve been on vacation. Yippee! Anyhow, there was Acne Paper, and suddenly, it flopped open to a piece called “My Own Private Hollywood,” with a photograph on the opposite page of a cute young man standing on the steps of a pool. The caption said “by Montgomery Clift.” I’d just finished reading Manny Farber’s analysis of why Clift was at his best in Howard Hawks’s “Red River” and not in, say, “From Here to Eternity.” Mr. Farber wrote: “One feels that this is the first and last hard, clamped-down, imaginative job Clift does in Hollywood — his one nonmush performance. Afterward, he goes to work for Zinnemann, Stevens, Hitchcock.”

headline: Miu Miu’s Super-Sparkle Sneakers
text: The glitter-coated pumps on Miu Miu’s fall runway weren’t the only stars in Miuccia Prada’s sky. Five lace-up low-tops bedecked in crystal appliqués, metal studs, little bits of lamé and layer upon layer of gold glitter are shining complements to this season’s dressier selection of shoes. Rubber soles and leather insoles mean happy, trek-friendly trails. And bread crumbs? Please. We’re leaving dazzling tracks of silver speckles in our wakes. Walk on!

headline: Poetry for Tough Guys
text: Bruce Smith’s new poems move fast and travel far, from Newtonian physics to the “fiery . . . riderless horse” of Christian apocalypse, “from the jet engine / as it gins the clouds” to “the hand-iron press and the sewing machine.” Most of those poems, though, begin in one place: a notion of blue-collar manhood, full of rough edges, frustration, defiance and pride. Smith’s Vietnam-era draftees, present-day stevedores, touring musicians and Iraq war veterans, along with their “black, white, sallow, olive, red, black kids,” inspire grand flights, tumultuous catalogs, as in a poem about drought: “Wherever there was water — the upended lid of a mayonnaise jar / in the gutter, the gutter, the sober silver puddle, the frenzied lake, / the tear ducts, the dew, the beveled rain — we drank.” When Smith is not speeding through such cascades of nouns, he revs up other repetitions: “They come like rats. . . . They want to save you. They want to slap you silly. They pet / the kitty. They bring gossip. . . . They’ve got questions for further study.” The plural noun to which each “They” refers is an obscenity most poets would not use.

headline: Digging Around for Snails
text: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

headline: Three Pakistan Naval Officers to Be Court Martialed Over Base Attack
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Three officers of the Pakistan Navy are facing a court martial on charges of negligence in connection with the audacious May 22 attack by small band of Islamist insurgents on a naval base in the southern port city of Karachi, a senior naval official said Thursday.

headline: Another Chance to Get 9/11 Memorial Passes
text: People locked out of reserving tickets to visit the 9/11 Memorial during its opening week are getting another opportunity to secure passes. The memorial released ­­­­­­­­­­more tickets on Thursday morning for dates that were previously unavailable, including the first weekend.

headline: Summer Lows for TV Networks
text: Your average channel surfer obviously found better things to do with leisure time on Wednesday night, as many shows on the broadcast networks posted summer lows in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic.

headline: 36 Hours in San Sebastián, Spain
text: TO visit San Sebastián, on Spain’s northern coast, is to fall in love. The first sight of the shimmering scallop-shaped bay, replete with crescents of golden sand and turquoise waves, will sweep you off your feet. Pairing this natural beauty with the unrivaled local cuisine — from decadent Michelin-starred feasts to delectable bite-sized pintxos (Basque-style tapas) — may leave your head spinning. A spruced-up seaside promenade, a renovated museum and a forthcoming culinary school all add to the city’s allure. But this love affair doesn’t have to be a fling. In June, the city secured a coveted designation as a 2016 European Capital of Culture, ensuring that it will put its best foot forward for years to come.

headline: In Its Final Quarter, Warner Music Reports a Loss
text: In its final full quarter as a public company, the Warner Music Group reported increased revenue yet a loss of $46 million.

headline: Some Advice for Democrats
text: The narrative that Republicans behaved like “terrorists” during the debt ceiling negotiations has become pretty well entrenched among Democratic partisans, and I doubt that any counter-arguments will dislodge it. Before we turn the page on this particular episode, I just want to highlight a few points, all from left-of-center writers, that suggest a slightly healthier way that liberals might look at recent events.

headline: ‘The Small Boys Came Early to the Hanging’
text: I was out of the country last week and therefore unable to do my usual sentence harvesting. In my absence, the 6th Floor blog asked Times readers to step in and propose their own favorite sentences of the week. headline: Spare Times for Aug. 5-11
text: Museum of the City of New York: ‘Whose Park is It? Financing and Administering New York’s New Parks’ (Tuesday) Creating and maintaining green spaces during a budget crunch is not exactly a walk in the park. An urban oasis designed today is very different from one designed in the days of Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux; you need only look at the High Line on the West Side of Manhattan, or Brooklyn Bridge Park, above, at the water’s edge in Brooklyn. A planned expansion there is expected to include several buildings of private housing — along with tennis courts, a swimming pool and other amenities — with payments from the buildings used to support the park’s operating expenses. On Tuesday at 6:30 p.m. Adrian Benepe, the New York parks commissioner, will discuss the history of the city’s parks and some issues surrounding park creation with Alexander D. Garvin, of the Yale School of Architecture, and Catherine Nagel, the executive director of the City Parks Alliance, an advocacy group based in Washington. Among the questions: Where will the money come from? What makes a park successful? The talk is part of an Urban Forum series at the museum (Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street) on the city’s infrastructure. It costs $12 ($8 for 65+ and students and $6 for members) and requires reservations: (917) 492-3395. Seating will be provided, so there’s no need for blankets or lawn chairs, and please, no picnics. For events at Brooklyn Bridge Park: brooklynbridgeparknyc.org. (Anne Mancuso)

headline: Kesey’s Kool Trip

headline: When Friends Drift
text: Last year, a close friend confided that he had joined Alcoholics Anonymous. He never seemed alcoholic, but I supported him because it was important to him. We grew even closer. Then he began pushing me away for A.A. friends, who exclude me because I’m not part of the program. I don’t want a dramatic showdown, but I can’t pretend we’re still close. We’ll probably keep drifting. What should I say to friends who ask about us and may try to mend fences?

headline: Demonstrating How a Special Choreographer Made Men Special
text: Beaver Creek, Colo. — When the choreographer George Balanchine was running New York City Ballet, there were two sides to being one of his male dancers. Sometimes, when teaching, he was so focused on exclusively female exercises that he omitted to give the men anything to do until they reminded him of their presence.

headline: A Souped-Up Romance Turns Demolition Derby
text: That American pastime of chopping cars is just one of the many true details that distinguish the seductive, grubby-beautiful, low-budget movie “Bellflower” from the usual indie chaff. The basic story sounds as dire as a quick read through a Sundance Film Festival catalog: Sensitive boy meets sexy girl. Happy and sad follow amid tears and beer, mumbled dialogue and openhearted sincerity, except that here they add up to an authentic slice of life, though one hopped up with an exuberant visual style and lurid excesses. Blood flows, fire belches, a devil car roars into the frame, and a couple meet cute over mouthfuls of live crickets.

headline: Saddled Up for Serious Strumming
text: The air was getting thick downstairs at Union Hall in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, and the members of the Band of Heathens were making themselves at home. Ed Jurdi, seated at a keyboard, was belting a Southern soul number called “The Other Broadway,” in his high, tremulous rasp. Colin Brooks, at the other end of the stage, attacked his electric guitar, uncoiling blues licks in a coarsened tone. Between them was Gordy Quist, blithely strumming a rhythm-guitar riff. The band played the song and then extended it, pushing an ecstatic four-bar vamp, louder and wilder with each turnaround but without ceding any control.

headline: Saving Scrapbooks From the Scrapheap
text: Woody Guthrie saved paperwork documenting his peripatetic life, from utility bills for New York apartments to fliers protesting shanty demolitions in Seattle and lyrics for folk songs performed at a Los Angeles radio station. He and his family put some of the artifacts in scrapbooks, but that did not fend off damage over the years.

headline: Following a Painter’s Options Beyond the Canvas
text: The German painter Blinky Palermo got his art training from Joseph Beuys and his pseudonym from an American gangster — a pair of tough guys, in other words. But intimidation wasn’t his style, to judge from a two-part survey of his work on view in upstate New York.

headline: A Songwriter, Still on the Line
text: Jimmy Webb may have been performing his greatest hits for decades, but you could never call his show at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Wednesday evening an example of phoning it in. A more accurate description of his treatment of “By the Time I Get to Phoenix,” “Wichita Lineman,” “MacArthur Park” and “All I Know” would be impassioned deconstruction. There were many moments when Mr. Webb, who turns 65 on Aug. 15, suggested the singer-songwriter equivalent of a famished wolf howling in the wilderness. Instead of embracing the niceties of a polished pop crooner, he eviscerated his own songs, laying out their raw emotions — mostly a young man’s desperate romanticism — with such intensity that I wondered how anyone could feel so much.

headline: It’s Not Just the Degree, but What You Study
text: Readers of Economix are familiar with the case for why a college education is worth it in the labor market. Quite simply, if you have a college degree, you will probably earn more than someone who doesn’t.

headline: Testing the Waters of Abstraction
text: The art of John Marin is easy to respect and hard to love. Compared with his vanguard associates of the between-the-wars era — Georgia O’Keeffe, Arthur Dove, Charles Demuth and Marsden Hartley — he was a flinty pragmatist. In the watercolors for which he was, and remains, most renowned, there is a hectic, sometimes luminously beautiful but often murky struggle between Cubist order and dynamic flux. Applied similarly to Manhattan cityscapes and Maine land- and seascapes, his touch is brusque, and his colors range from garish to drab. The invariably modest scale feels claustrophobic, despite the expansive subjects. Emotion is muted. An astringent pantheism is often suggested, but he was no visionary, and eros, whether carnal or mystical, is almost wholly absent.

headline: The Art and Heart of the Dealer
text: Summer is the time when New York’s commercial galleries break away in large numbers from the monthly grind of one- and two-artist exhibitions, almost as if let out of school. Art dealers of every stripe embrace the group show, whose wonderfully elastic format accommodates all manner of ambition and desire, curatorial and otherwise, serious and not.

headline: Vita and Violet: The Greatest Bloomsbury Love Story
text: “Heaven preserve us from all the sleek and dowdy virtues, such as punctuality, conscientiousness, fidelity and smugness!” So wrote Violet Keppel in her unruly call to arms to the great ruling passion of her life, Vita Sackville-West. “What great man was ever constant? What great queen was ever faithful? Novelty is the very essence of genius and always will be. If I were to die tomorrow, think how I should have lived!” And indeed, how this woman, this “unexploded bomb,” as Vita called her, “lived!”

headline: A Portuguese Tale of Time, the Revealer
text: A masterly tale about lives and stories and the art of their telling, “Mysteries of Lisbon” is also an elegiac meditation on love lost and rediscovered through misted memory. Directed by the Chilean filmmaker Raúl Ruiz and set mainly in Portugal, with detours to other European corners, it is a period picture based on a work by the prolific Camilo Castelo Branco (1825-90), who was born in Lisbon, illegitimate and orphaned, and flirted with the priesthood before finding his calling in writing, running off with a married woman, landing in prison and finally committing suicide. Mr. Ruiz’s “Mysteries” are just as outlandish, gloriously so.

text: ANYONE who has stepped into the often-stressful real estate market in New Jersey lately can hardly help being aware that it is an increasingly rude arena.

headline: Woman Is Accused of Murder After Breast-Fed Son Is Found to Have Meth in His System
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A Northern California woman has been accused of knowingly killing her infant son by breast-feeding him shortly after ingesting large amounts of methamphetamine, which rendered her milk toxic.

headline: Russian Village’s Self-Defense Underlines Failures of Police
text: SAGRA, Russia — When Sergei the Gypsy wanted to show who was boss in this tiny settlement on the edge of the Ural Mountains, he gathered a posse of armed men and drove down a narrow road through the night, illuminating the forest with his headlights.

headline: Mike Kirby
text: Mr. Kirby, 50, is a founder and the chairman of Green Street Advisors, an independent research and consulting firm that tracks the commercial real estate industry, with an emphasis on real estate investment trusts, or REITs, public companies that disburse most of their income as dividends. Mr. Kirby, who started the company in 1985, also serves as its research director.

headline: Afghans Who Risked Lives for U.S. Are Left in Dark on Visas
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Thousands of Afghans who have worked with American troops and diplomats here, often at great risk, have become stranded for years in a murky wait to emigrate to the United States, despite government efforts to speed them from potential threats in Afghanistan.

headline: Deutsche Bank Executive Puts Up a Fight
text: At first glance, Richard J. Byrne, the chief executive of Deutsche Bank Securities, doesn’t look much like a warrior.

headline: Habitats
text: Thanks to inherited family treasures, extensive travels and two excellent pairs of eyes, a couple’s SoHo loft has evolved into a veritable primer on craftsmanship.

headline: A Loft That Waited for Its Muse
text: BACK in the mid-’70s, when Sigrid Burton was a young artist living in a rented loft on Walker Street in what was coming to be called TriBeCa, she used to pore over the real estate ads in The Village Voice with almost religious fervor. Ms. Burton did this despite the fact that she was living so modestly, she used to ask taxi drivers taking her home late at night to drop her at the corner, to save the cost of circling around the block to her front door.

headline: With Floodwaters Ebbing, Long Haul of Sandbags Awaits
text: MANDAN, N.D. — Homes alongside the Missouri River here have been guarded for months by millions of sandbags, assembled in an urgent and cooperative effort last spring by the National Guard, local governments, residents and other volunteers. And now, as the floodwaters slowly recede, comes the unglamorous and expensive aftermath of cleaning up after another disaster, but here with a back-breaking twist.

headline: Questions About Urging Interim Mayor to Run
text: From the bustling alleys of Chinatown to the sleepy neighborhood of West Portal, dozens of youthful volunteers in bright yellow “Run Ed Run” T-shirts fanned out across San Francisco this summer to gather signatures as part of a campaign to entice the interim mayor, Edwin M. Lee, to join the mayor’s race.

headline: Living In | Hyde Park, N.Y.
text: It is the unscathed, understated beauty of this 37-square-mile river town that has been a draw for many people.

headline: The Exurbs, Too, Appreciate an Oasis
text: An analytical computer tool developed by Jordan Baris realty -- which it unveiled to the National Association of Realtors, and recently sold for use to a Long Island agency (but says it will keep proprietary in New Jersey).

headline: Ailing Father and Son Behind NFL Films Find Strength in Hall Journey
text: Few father-and-son acts have endured longer than Ed and Steve Sabol’s. Ed founded NFL Films in 1962, and Steve perpetuated it with a creative buoyancy that matched his father’s entrepreneurial zeal.

headline: Off the Train, and Onto a Wave
text: MANY New Yorkers may not think of surfing as a way to spend a summer day. After all, riding the waves typically means a flight to someplace exotic or at least a jitney ride to the Hamptons. But the only ticket you really need is a MetroCard: Rockaway Beach in Queens is an A-train ride away from prime surfing.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: You may not own New York City, but walking up the middle of Park Avenue can make you feel as if you did.

text: LAS VEGAS — The Web site of ManTech International, a $2.6 billion computer security company that won a major F.B.I. contract, sells its services this way:

headline: Governing New York by Writing a Check
text: It began years ago as a toss-off laugh line in City Hall’s marble halls: Hizzoner, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, might consider solving his most intractable problems with a quick tap-tap-tap on his personal savings account.

headline: Officials in China Seized Infants for Black Market
text: At least 16 babies were seized by family planning officials from 1999 to 2006 in a Hunan Province county; parents say the babies were used as a source of revenue.

headline: Chinese Officials Seized and Sold Babies, Parents Say
text: LONGHUI COUNTY, China — Many parents and grandparents in this mountainous region of terraced rice and sweet potato fields have long known to grab their babies and find the nearest hiding place whenever family planning officials show up. Too many infants, they say, have been snatched by officials, never to be seen again.

headline: A Mets All-Star Makes a Foray Into Music
text: On the field, Jose Reyes has been a revelation this season, taking his already respected skills as a hitter to a significantly higher level. The All-Star shortstop leads the National League in batting (.339 average), hits (142), runs (79) and triples (16) and will be the recipient of an enormous new contract, from the Mets or someone else, at some point in the off-season.

headline: Time to Say It: Double Dip Recession May Be Happening
text: Double dip may be back.

headline: Among Those It Would Help, Doubts That a Plan Can Tame Inequality in New York
text: The problems that face young black and Latino men in New York City are deep-seated and diverse, officials who work in minority neighborhoods say. They vary not only from neighborhood to neighborhood, but also from family to family and man to man.

headline: With Rodriguez Out, Lineup Hardly Lacks Punch
text: CHICAGO — While the Yankees prepared to conclude their series with the Chicago White Sox on Thursday, their cleanup hitter, Alex Rodriguez, was in Tampa, Fla., beginning his on-field rehabilitation from knee surgery amid another round of controversial headlines.

headline: Classical Music Moves From Concert Halls to Cafes
text: Ever since Classical Revolution, a loose collective of top-notch, classically trained musicians, started playing chamber music at the Revolution Cafe a few years ago, this Mission District bar has been packed on Mondays — not generally a big party night in town.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,673 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Egyptians See Signs of a Reckoning in Mubarak Trial
text: MIT KENANA, Egypt — In this town of unfinished brick buildings, along parcels of corn and rice watered by the Nile, the elation, suspicion and introspection of a country played out along one street a day after residents witnessed the unthinkable: former President Hosni Mubarak put on trial.

headline: Panetta Pleads for No More Cuts in Defense Spending
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta effectively told Congress on Thursday to raise taxes and cut Social Security and Medicare before taking another swipe at the Pentagon budget beyond defense cuts already called for in the debt-ceiling deal.

headline: In His Own Hand, a Suspect’s Account of a Grisly Crime
text: “My name is Levi Aron,” the writer began.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ciao, Jersey; Hello, Italy: No Culture Shock Here
text: The road signs point to Florence but they should read “Welcome to the Jersey Shoro.”

headline: Time For A Little Self-Indulgent Calm
text: At the end of a very scary day.

headline: Major Libyan Rebel Group Seeks Shake-Up in Ranks
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Rebel leaders, still reeling from the assassination of their top military commander last week, braced for a reshuffling in their ranks on Thursday, while law enforcement officials said a full-fledged investigation into the murder of the rebel general had gotten under way.

headline: ‘The Lion of the Day’
text: On Aug. 3, 1861, Harper’s Weekly published the astounding account of William Tillman, a 27-year old African-American sailor born a free man in Delaware. Tillman had been on the crew of the Yankee merchantman the S. J. Waring. On July 6 the 300-ton schooner, manned by a crew of eight under the command of Captain Francis Smith, had left New York bound for Montevideo, Uruguay, with a cargo of foodstuffs and a single passenger. Three days into its voyage, the ship was captured by a Confederate privateer, the Jefferson Davis.

headline: Nervous Investors Chase Low-Risk Assets
text: It was a frantic flight to safety.

headline: Brett Ratner Takes Producing Role at the Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES — If those who give the Oscars are looking for laughs, action and the occasional outrage from their annual awards show, they are on the right track. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Thursday said Brett Ratner, a filmmaker known for directing the raucous “Rush Hour” series and for producing “Horrible Bosses,” will join Don Mischer in producing the next Oscar show, which is set to air Feb. 26 on ABC. Last year’s broadcast, produced by Mr. Mischer and Bruce Cohen, had soft ratings and was widely criticized for a lackluster performance by one of its hosts, James Franco. If energy is the issue, Mr. Ratner should be able to provide a fix. He is known as a film aficionado and an ambitious filmmaker whose is currently making a Snow White project for Relativity Media, and has dozens of projects in development. Recently, Mr. Ratner directed “Tower Heist.” That action picture, due Nov. 4 from Universal Pictures, has uncertain Oscar prospects, but counts Ben Stiller, Eddie Murphy, Matthew Broderick and Gabourey Sidibe among its stars.

headline: Calls for CNN Host to Testify in Hacking Scandal
text: LONDON — Piers Morgan, the CNN talk show host and a former editor of the British tabloid The Daily Mirror, faced calls on Thursday from prominent British lawmakers to appear before a parliamentary committee investigating the illegal hacking of cellphone messages.

headline: Kraft Foods, in Split, Is Keeping Oreos but Not Velveeta
text: After years of mergers and takeovers, Kraft Foods is undertaking its biggest deal yet: breaking itself apart.

headline: For NASA, Return Trip to Jupiter in Search of Clues to Solar System’s Origins
text: The last time we saw Jupiter up close, it was 16 years ago, when a probe from NASA’s Galileo spacecraft took a death plunge through the cloud tops and radioed back tantalizing data that all but screamed, “To be continued...”

headline: Before a Walk Across Niagara Falls, a Balancing Act
text: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario — Nik Wallenda is a seventh-generation circus performer, scion of the famed Flying Wallendas. He set the world record for farthest distance traveled by bicycle on a high wire. And now he has set his sights on a new deed of daredevilry — walking the 1,800 feet across the gorge of Niagara Falls while balancing on a two-inch-diameter steel cable.

headline: Poland Fires Military Officials Over 2010 Crash
text: The prime minister of Poland dismissed more than a dozen top air force officers and Defense Ministry officials on Thursday after an Interior Ministry report on a devastating plane crash said that poor crew training, lax safety regulations and unprofessionalism were to blame.

headline: For Playoff Spice, Add a Pair of Wild Cards
text: Bud Selig has a plan but needs to act on it fast. He is dying to add another wild-card team to the playoffs in both leagues and to spare us the charade of making games like this weekend’s at Fenway Park between the Yankees and the Red Sox out to be much bigger than they are.

headline: The Right Way to Trim
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: In a Pageant, a Borough’s New Face
text: Inside a karaoke bar in Midtown Manhattan the other night, Tolulope Ibrahim, 17, and Olayinka Idowu, 17, both daughters of Nigerian parents who live on Staten Island, were wearing green shirts emblazoned with “Miss Africa New York” and singing hip-hop songs at high volume. In the glittering lights of a rotating disco ball, they leaned over to chat with Ama Kwakye, 19, the daughter of parents from Ghana who also lives on Staten Island, about the pageant in which they were all competing.

headline: The Wrong Worries
text: In case you had any doubts, Thursday’s more than 500-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average and the drop in interest rates to near-record lows confirmed it: The economy isn’t recovering, and Washington has been worrying about the wrong things.

headline: End the Debt Limit
text: It has long been clear that the federal debt limit is far too dangerous and unstable for lawmakers to use as a political weapon. Allowing that to happen in the last few traumatic weeks created an artificial national crisis that put the economy and the savings of Americans at risk and helped produce a loss of confidence that lingered as a cause of Thursday’s stock-market plunge.

headline: Friday: What Might Send Rover Right Over
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — By the time we solvers get to Friday, we’re ready to sink our writing implements into some toothsome, long entries and wrestle with some clues that really make us think. That’s the kind of puzzle Barry Silk offers us today, along with some Scrabbly consonant mashups to help slow you down a bit.

headline: Results From Markets
text: Closing levels of three exchanges.

headline: In Need of Deficit Plan, Congress Opts for Several
text: WASHINGTON — Congress says it has a plan for addressing the government’s deficit problems. But it does not. Instead, it merely has a plan for a plan for a plan, effectively commanding Congress to continue fighting over budget priorities through the 2012 elections.

headline: Matt Dodge Hoping to Move Past Inconsistency and a Blunder
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Punters, for better or worse, enjoy a blanket of anonymity on the field. They may shank a kick or miss a tackle on a return, but rarely do their mistakes — or successes — become the story, unlike their place-kicking brethren.

headline: Isolated, Vulnerable And Broke
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Johan Santana’s Recovery Hits a Setback
text: The optimistic hopes that the Mets’ ace, Johan Santana, could return this season were put into further doubt after it was determined Thursday afternoon that he had fatigue in his surgically repaired left shoulder.

headline: S.E.C. Needs More Clout, Not Less
text: At least one lawmaker seems to want the Securities and Exchange Commission to become irrelevant. The regulator has had its problems. But a Republican bid to reshape it seems meant to hinder, not help. There’s room for improvement, but with its duties growing, the watchdog needs more staff, more money and a buffer against Congress.

headline: Stocks Tumble Amid Global Worry
text: Investors dumped stocks amid anxiety that the United States and Europe were failing to fix deepening economic problems.

headline: Bloomberg Deputy Hired With Much Fanfare Steps Down
text: Stephen Goldsmith, a high-profile deputy to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg who came under fire for the city’s poor response to a crippling blizzard in December, announced on Thursday that he would leave his position after just 14 months in office.

headline: Familiar (Winning) Formula for Braves
text: Heading into the stretch run of baseball’s regular season, the Atlanta Braves are playing like their playoff teams of the 1990s, with the National League’s second-best record and the postseason in sight. Nowhere to be found, though, are legendary players like Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine, John Smoltz, Andruw Jones and Javy Lopez. The only leftover from the Braves’ playoff run from 1991 to 2005 is Chipper Jones, their likely Hall-of-Fame third baseman.

headline: How Safe Are Medical Devices?
text: A prestigious medical group is concerned that most medical devices are cleared for sale without evidence that they are safe and effective. That should give everyone pause. A panel of experts assembled by the Institute of Medicine found the current regulatory approach so flawed that it called for it to be scrapped and replaced with a system better designed to protect the public’s health.

headline: The Voters’ Need to Know
text: Just before President Obama hit the trail for a birthday binge of campaign fund-raising, 62 House Democrats sent him a pointed reminder that he has not yet signed the proposed executive order requiring federal contractors to disclose donations to the stealth campaign machines now undermining national politics.

headline: Some Carriages Should Not Be Horseless
text: The horses and carriages were missing from Central Park South on Monday, midafternoon. “Too hot,” explained a salesman trying to lure disappointed tourists into pedicabs instead. “Over 90, they go.”

headline: Battle for Libya | August 4, 2011
text: A spokesman for NATO said Thursday that it was looking into accusations that its planes had hit a civilian home, killing a mother and two children, in an early morning airstrike on the town of Zlitan, Libya.

headline: A Country Haven for Brooklynites
text: The Hudson River Valley is becoming home to refugees of New York City seeking a quieter life, but one that is still rich in culture.

headline: This Astronomical Recession
text: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

headline: Volatile Wall Street Ends the Day Mixed
text: Like a battered boxer, stocks were knocked down and kept dragging themselves up through trading Friday, closing flat in the end, but capping the worst weekly decline since November 2008.

headline: Are You Reading This? That Is So Cool.
text: WHAT’S up, Times readers? Normally right now you’d be nodding off over a very thoughtful prescription for offering Qaddafi an honorable exile at a plastic surgery teaching hospital. But not today, people! Because I deleted that snoozer when I hacked my way in here.

headline: Xiong Chao at Play
text: Xiong Chao, who was dropped from a second story balcony as an infant during a struggle between his mother and officials, plays with friends at his house. He is mentally handicapped from the fall.

headline: Salvaging Medical Cast-Offs to Save Lives
text: When Dr. Bruce Charash arrived in Cotonou, Benin, in May 2007, he went from the airport to Hubert Maga Hospital.  Charash is the founder of a Brooklyn-based organization called Doc2Dock, which collects surplus medical equipment from hospitals in the United States and ships it to hospitals in poor countries.  As Charash’s plane was landing, a container of medical equipment and supplies had docked, destined for Hubert Maga.

headline: Raw Food Co-op Is Raided in California
text: LOS ANGELES — Raw food enthusiasts fit right in here, in the earthy, health-conscious beach communities of Venice and Santa Monica, along with the farmers’ markets, health food stores and vegan restaurants.

headline: Juergen Klinsmann Names U.S. Roster
text: Juergen Klinsmann checked off the first item on his to-do list as United States national team coach by releasing the roster he has selected for an exhibition game against Mexico in Philadelphia on Wednesday.

headline: Student Protests in Chile
text: Students across Chile have taken an unusually confrontational stance toward the government and business elite, demanding wholesale changes in education, transportation and energy policy, sometimes violently.

headline: With Kiss-Ins and Dances, Young Chileans Push for Reform
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — A blanket stretched over their legs, Johanna Choapa and Maura Roque, both 17, sat in front of the stage in a chilly school auditorium last week as more than 300 parents and teachers debated whether to continue supporting their hunger strike aimed at pressuring the Chilean government to reform the country’s education system.

headline: An Opinion by Judge on Spy Law Creates a Stir
text: WASHINGTON — Proponents of press freedom have praised a ruling last week by a federal judge who protected a writer from being forced to testify in court about his sources for a book on the Central Intelligence Agency. But her opinion included a little-noticed passage: a suggestion that many journalists could be charged with a felony.

headline: Seoul Warns of Latest North Korean Threat: An Army of Online Gaming Hackers
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean leader Kim Jong-il has found a novel way of raising badly needed cash, according to the South Korean authorities: unleashing young hackers on South Korea’s immensely popular online gaming sites to find ways to rack up points convertible to cash.

headline: A Painter’s Unfinished Tribute to the Many Clocks of New York
text: Amir Wahib quit his job to look at clocks.

headline: Striking Change in Bedford-Stuyvesant as the White Population Soars
text: Mark Dunlea and his wife, Judith A. Enck, moved to Brooklyn from upstate New York two years ago. Last March, they breached the blurry Clinton Hill border to buy an apartment in a four-story condominium that had replaced an abandoned warehouse in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

headline: So Hopeful in April, So Glum in August
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Corrections: August 5
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Aldermen in Upsets Face Decision on Ward Post
text: The once-mighty 36th Ward Regular Democratic Organization, rocked by losing the alderman’s seat in an April run-off election upset, will soon undergo its first leadership change in 30 years.

headline: One Nation, One Chicago Strives for Interfaith Understanding
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Fighting Crime and Pressuring the Mayor, via Shoe Leather
text: By day, Palmer Park in Roseland hums with life: children splashing in the pool, teenagers shooting baskets and politicians holding news conferences with television crews in tow.

headline: Helping a Few to Vote, With Unintended Effects
text: Ross Ramsey, managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Drought Effects Extend Far Beyond Water Restrictions
text: When a wildfire chewed through power lines at a field of water wells in late June, Lubbock lost nine million gallons of water a day during the nearly two weeks it took to finish repairs.

headline: Students Pressure Chile to Reform Education System
text: In the more than two months since education protests began in Chile, students have organized rallies drawing up to 100,000 people.

headline: In Front of the Stove at 7 and Loving Every Minute
text: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Thomas McNaughton, chef at Flour + Water restaurant, addressed a room full of attentive grade-school-age children.

headline: Jail Time Yields a Clash on Vegetarian Meals
text: What started as the dubious drug bust of a beloved, elderly Mill Valley merchant — a case that rattled many in this bucolic burb — is morphing into a clash about vegetarian rights. Dave McDonald, 70, of Mill Valley, has been a vegetarian for 42 years. But when he was jailed recently for 99 days on drug-related charges (most of which were later dropped), Mr. McDonald was denied vegetarian meals.

headline: Recipes: The Proper Ways to Treat an Heirloom
text: A fresh tomato is a beautiful thing — which is all the more reason to slice it, mash it, crush it, or stuff it.

headline: The Proper Way to Treat an Heirloom
text: From the less-is-more department: A perfectly ripe, local summer tomato eaten with a drizzle of olive oil, a sprinkle of salt or nothing at all has become a bit of a culinary cliché. Your superior appreciation of the superior tomato relies on a distinct lack of meddling.

headline: ‘Family Guy’ Creator Part of ‘Cosmos’ Update
text: “Cosmos,” the 1980 documentary mini-series that encouraged a generation of viewers to contemplate the origins of the universe and their place in it, and made an unlikely television personality out of the astronomer Carl Sagan, is poised to return to terrestrial airwaves. Only this time the starship is being steered by a pilot whose identity you might not surmise even if you had billions and billions of guesses.

headline: Pepsi Takes Active Role in ‘X Factor’
text: SIMON COWELL has not just switched television shows; he has switched soft drinks.

headline: Resource at Risk
text: With Gabon’s oil reserves depleting, the country’s vast rain forests are facing new perils.

headline: Family Planning Officials Seized Infants in China
text: Many parents in Longhui County, China, say too many infants have been snatched by officials, never to be seen again.

headline: M.J. Perry Jr., Legal Pioneer, Dies at 89
text: Matthew J. Perry Jr., who as a young lawyer had to wait in the balcony of his segregated local courthouse before a judge would hear his case, then went on to win hundreds of civil rights legal battles and to become the first black federal judge from the Deep South, died on July 29 at his home in Columbia, S.C. He was 89.

headline: Campers’ Wounds Weren’t Caused by Bear
text: For the two boys who were awakened when a bear poked around their tents while on a camping trip on Wednesday in New Jersey, the ordeal must have been scary.

headline: NYT Front Page for 08/05/11
text: NYT Front Page for 08/05/11

headline: Yingluck Shinawatra Is Elected Thai Prime Minister by Parliament
text: BANGKOK — Thailand’s Parliament on Friday elected Yingluck Shinawatra the country’s first female prime minister, a month after her party won a landslide victory over a coalition backed by the nation’s military and traditional elites.

headline: Havens — Genoa, Nev.
text: This town in Nevada’s Carson Valley prides itself on its Old West heritage.

headline: $2.3 Billion Loss Posted by Royal Bank of Scotland
text: 7:44 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Art of Tea
text: A show at the Yale University Art Gallery aims to evoke the look and spirit of an intricately choreographed social convention in Japan.

headline: Outsize Roles
text: Photos from “Mabou Mines DollHouse” at St. Ann’s Warehouse.

headline: A Preview of the New Alice Tully Hall
text: A look inside the renovated concert hall at Lincoln Center, which will reopen in less than a month, as musicians test the acoustics.

headline: Picasso, Images and Language
text: A dense and busy show on Picasso at Yale University investigates the importance of words — written, painted, printed, spoken — in Picasso’s art.

headline: Through Plexiglas Barriers, a Noirish New York
text: Michael Kirby Smith, 31, is a New York-based freelance photographer. Since late in March, Mr. Smith, who grew up in Dallas, has been exploring the notion of barriers in New York — their role in the city’s past and present, as well as the human interactions they inspire.

headline: Cabinet Shuffle in Cyprus Seeks Backing for Austerity
text: ATHENS — The president of Cyprus, Demetris Christofias, shuffled his cabinet on Friday, but he failed to attract members of the opposition whose support is needed to impose crucial austerity measures.

headline: Tip of the Week: Filtering Search for Children
text: Search engines bring all kinds of results back in response to queries — including some that may not be suitable for children. While no software filter replaces parental supervision, most of the major search sites (Google, Yahoo and Bing) include the filters for safer searching that can help screen out pages with adult content from results.

headline: Pod Cars, Moving Silently at Heathrow’s Terminal 5
text: LONDON — Travelers passing through Heathrow Airport have an opportunity to experience the not-so-distant future of airport transportation systems in Terminal 5, where a curious row of pod cars connects the terminal’s two business parking lots.

headline: Night Life and More Along Rome’s Tiber River
text: Every night this summer, the banks of Rome’s Tiber River come to life for the 10th edition of “Lungo il Tevere” (“Along the Tiber”). The city-sponsored event, which runs through Aug. 28, features hundreds of venues, with theaters, cinemas, musical events, artisans, bars and restaurants offering the summer’s largest nighttime attraction to locals and travelers alike.

headline: The Early Word: Dissatisfaction
text: Today’s Times:

headline: 2011 Atlanta Falcons Season Preview
text: The Falcons told us everything about their intentions for 2011 on April 28. That night General Manager Thomas Dimitroff traded a king’s ransom to Cleveland  to move up and draft Alabama wide receiver Julio Jones with the sixth overall pick. Dimitroff initially carved out a name for himself during a five-year run as the director of college scouting for the New England Patriots; at his core, trading two first-round draft picks, a second-rounder and a pair of fourth-rounders just to move up 21 spots had to feel almost like trading a piece of his soul.

headline: Long Story Shortlist, Growling Stomach Edition
text: “Bad Food? Tax It, and Subsidize Vegetables,”by Mark Bittman (July 23, 2011)What will it take to get Americans to change our eating habits? The need is indisputable, because heart disease, diabetes and cancer are all, in large part, caused by the Standard American Diet. (Yes, it’s SAD.) Read more »

headline: I.C.B.C. to Buy Controlling Stake in Argentine Bank
text: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China said Friday that it had agreed to pay the South African lender Standard Bank $600 million for control of three financial units in Argentina.

headline: Further Thoughts on the Very Picky Customer
text: I’d like to thank everyone who took the time to write a response to my post “The Very Picky Customer.” The points raised by commenters were interesting, and I’d like to add a little more information and some further thoughts.

headline: Broadcasting Hama Ruins, Syria Says It Has Ended Revolt
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s state news media broadcast stark images of the destruction in the besieged city of Hama for the first time on Friday, showing burned buildings, makeshift barricades and deserted streets strewn with rubble in footage that appeared designed to show that government forces had put down a rebellion in the city.

headline: He’s a Soulful Survivor With New Music to Make
text: In a career that spans nearly 50 years Booker T. Jones has worn many hats: leader of the celebrated 1960s soul group Booker T. & the MG’s, a writer of hit songs like “Green Onions” and “Born Under a Bad Sign,” sideman, producer and arranger. Until very recently, though, he had neglected the one facet that many musicians value above all others, that of the solo artist.

headline: Fresh Ricotta, a Fleeting Pleasure
text: FRESH artisanal ricotta cheese — the real thing, not the supermarket version, which is not a reasonable facsimile — can be a delight. Sweet and creamy on the tongue, yet light, it is one of life’s simple luxurious pleasures.

headline: Live Blog: The Markets
text: Will the rout continue? Global stocks tanked on Thursday on pessimism over the state of economic affairs in both the United States and Europe. Recession-weary investors are losing hope for a recovery, and big European countries have still not wrestled their debt problems to the ground. The Lede blog is tracking developments in the markets Friday looking for clues to the near-term direction of stocks and bonds.

headline: Ricotta Worth Hunting For
text: Fresh ricotta is the subject of this week’s City Kitchen column. When I think about fresh ricotta, I think of Sicily. It was there that I learned how delicious it could be on nearly everything — added to a pasta with eggplant and tomatoes, spread on toasted semolina bread and drizzled with oil, or eaten just plain with a spoon.

headline: Poll Shows Negative View of Tea Party on the Rise
text: Little more than a year ago, most Americans did not know enough about the Tea Party to have an opinion. Now, more people have opinions, and they are hardly positive.

headline: DST Denies Activist Investor’s Board Bid
text: DST Systems, a data processor, said on Friday that its board had decided to deny a request by Russell D. Glass, an activist investor in the company, that he and two others be appointed to the company’s board.

headline: In Market Slide, Obama Loses an Economic Asset
text: For more than a year, there has been one economic indicator that President Obama could always count on as a good-news salve to the festering sore of grim unemployment and jobs data.

headline: U.S. Posts Stronger Job Growth in July
text: The United States economy continues on a wobbly course, but there was a momentary sigh of relief on Friday as the government reported that employers added 117,000 jobs last month, slightly more than expected.

headline: Liquidity Trapped
text: Some readers may recall that back in 2008, when I began writing about the dangers of a liquidity trap and all that implied, I got a lot of angry pushback from the usual suspects. The liquidity trap is nonsense, they said; printing money is always inflationary; someone, I think Alan Reynolds, referred to “liquidity claptrap.”

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: As Markets Tumble, What to Do?  |  As stock markets tumble, Graham Bowley, a business reporter at The New York Times, takes a look at what options are on the table to ease investor fears. Will the turmoil in the American financial markets lead to another round of quantitative easing, and if so, will it have the intended effect?DealBook

headline: Friendly Workplace Linked to Longer Life
text: Getting along with your colleagues at work may do more than boost your productivity. It may also be a boon to your health.

headline: Euro Zone | London Alfresco
text: By this time next year, London will be choked with Olympic tourists. So now’s the time to make the most of this year’s quiet London summer, when the weather is mild and the population manageable.

headline: Friday Reading: When the Elderly Can Afford to Pay, but Won’t
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Pulling Rank
text: John Quiggin has some fun with an economist named Stephen Williamson who attacks his work from a position of robust ignorance; Noah Smith has even more fun.

headline: Vandaag Loses Its Chef
text: The chef Phillip Kirschen-Clark, whose Dutch-influenced cooking helped Vandaag in the East Village earn two stars from Sam Sifton last September, has left. Mr. Kirschen-Clark said that Vandaag’s management had “different views on the direction they wanted the restaurant to take. They wanted a more neighborhood approach but I prefer doing more elaborate food.” He is exploring his next move, he said.

headline: A Homemade Drone Snoops on Wireless Networks
text: It flies. It spies. It is the color of sunshine, and it has googly eyes.

headline: Giants Sign Amukamara
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — With all eyes on Osi Umenyiora at Giants camp this week, it was easy to overlook a quieter drama: the absence of the first-round pick Prince Amukamara. That smaller mystery has been solved: Amukamara became the final first-round pick of the 2011 draft to agree to a contract.

headline: Seasonal Joys in the Jobs Report?
text: The job numbers on Friday were better than expected, at least if you look at the seasonally adjusted figures. They still were not very good, but any good news is welcome.

headline: Pilfered Peppers in City Gardens; Tomatoes, Too
text: AT the 700 community gardens sprinkled through the city like little Edens, the first commandment should be obvious: Thou shalt not covet, much less steal, thy neighbor’s tomatoes, cucumbers or peppers. But people do.

headline: Bridgewater Fights Back in Dartmouth Flap
text: 3:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: Has Someone Taken Your Tomatoes?
text: It’s harvest season in the city’s community gardens, which means it is high season for garden theft, too, as Robin Finn writes in this week’s Metropolitan section. At the West Side Community Garden on 89th Street between Broadway and Amsterdam, Linda Cardona’s cucumbers disappeared two weeks ago. Now all that’s left on her vines are shrimp-size cukes that will not mature until mid-August — if they make it that long. She said she planned to eat them sooner than that, just in case.

headline: Private Sector Up, Government Down
text: As weak as the economy has been in recent months, the private sector has still been adding jobs at a faster rate than the adult population has been growing. Over the last 12 months, the private-sector employment has grown by 1.7 percent, while the adult population has grown about 1 percent, according to Haver, a research firm, and the Bureau of Labor Statistics:

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Fruit Smoothies Without the Dairy
text: Depending on how you make it, a smoothie can end up with more milk and yogurt than fruit. This week, Martha Rose Shulman eliminates the dairy and creates five smoothie recipes that are all about the fruit.

headline: TimesCast | Economy Adds Jobs in July
text: August 5, 2011 - The job growth figure, reported by the Labor Department, was the strongest since April, but may still not be high enough to relieve fears of a renewed recession.

headline: On the Shark Beat
text: Juliet Eilperin, a Washington Post reporter who shifted in 2004 from covering Congress and politics to writing on the environment, has written “Demon Fish“, a captivating, world-spanning (and much praised) exploration of the difficult human relationship with sharks. I recently had an e-mail exchange with Eilperin* about the book and her reporting adventures. With Shark Week nearing an end (I still think what’s needed is Human Week), this seemed an appropriate time to post our Q&A. Here it is, with some shorthand cleaned up:

headline: Honda Recalls 1.5 Million Accords, CR-Vs and Elements to Reprogram Transmission Software
text: Honda is recalling about 1.5 million vehicles to make a software change to reduce the chance of automatic transmissions being damaged, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Hotels Take Fitness Into Guest Rooms
text: For regular exercisers, keeping up isn’t always easy when traveling. Some hotels don’t have facilities, and those that do often have inconvenient hours or gyms that are small and dark.

headline: It Ain’t Necessarily ‘Porgy’
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: In Syria, Live Fire and Dueling Narratives
text: After seeking to impose a communications blackout on the besieged city of Hama, Syrian state television aired its own footage of rubble-strewn and deserted streets as evidence, it said, of a campaign to restore “normal life.”

headline: Where to Get the World’s Best Service
text: The guidebooks tell you never to tip in Japan. But when my partner and I traveled there last December, and our 90-pound bellhop insisted on carrying our overstuffed suitcases to our room, we thought a few hundred yen was more than appropriate. She politely refused our money. And over the course of the next week, so did the hotel clerks who equipped us with umbrellas at the first sign of drizzle, the concierges who booked us tables at mind-blowing sushi restaurants too off the grid to be listed on the Internet and the restaurant owners who presented us with a souvenir menu — in English — to commemorate all the delicious food we had just eaten. No tipping meant no tipping, period.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Painful Season
text: It’s against my interest as a professional Supreme Court obsessive to say this, but the last term was straight-up dull. There were some weighty outcomes — for example, in a pair of cases about workplace discrimination and consumer rights, the court gave corporate defendants a road map for evading class-action lawsuits. On the whole, though, the term lacked drama: no news-cycle-eating cases or base-enflaming confirmation battles to be found.

headline: Speaking Ill
text: A person in our company recently committed suicide. Of course, it was shocking. But now colleagues are recalling harsh words that were exchanged between the employee and a supervisor, and they are blaming management. What the colleagues don’t know is that the employee’s work had been subpar for years and that much of it had to be redone (by management). Setting the record straight would help people make sense of what happened. It may seem unkind, but would it be unethical? NAME WITHHELD

headline: The Phantom Menace of Sleep-Deprived Doctors
text: Last month something extraordinary happened at teaching hospitals around the country: Young interns worked for 16 hours straight — and then they went home to sleep. After decades of debate and over the opposition of nearly every major medical organization and 79 percent of residency-program directors, new rules went into effect that abolished 30-hour overnight shifts for first-year residents. Sanity, it seemed to people who had long been fighting for a change, had finally won out.

headline: The Trivialities and Transcendence of Kickstarter
text: We had this idea, some friends and I, for a small public art project in New Orleans last year. The problem was, it involved some professional printing that would cost a few thousand dollars, which none of us had. Usually that’s where such conversations end: it would be cool if we could do X, but we’re not going to get a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, even if we knew how to pursue such a thing. So let’s get another round of beers.

headline: Hello, Lauren! A Former Fanny Brice on the New ‘Funny Girl’ in Town
text: In June the singer and comedian Marilyn Michaels wrote a guest Theater Talkback post for ArtsBeat about the challenges of casting the role of Fanny Brice in the musical “Funny Girl.” (Barbra Streisand originated the part when the show opened on Broadway in 1964; Ms. Michaels played it in the original national touring company.) On Wednesday it was announced that Lauren Ambrose would play the role in the Ahmanson Theater revival in Los Angeles, which is expected to end up on Broadway. That left Ms. Michaels wondering: Has the right Fanny been found?

headline: Multiple Fears Weigh on Markets
text: Aug. 5, 2011 - Concerns about Europe's sovereign debt crisis and fears of a double-dip recession in the U.S. are weighing heavily on markets.

headline: Preconceptions
text: A few years ago, when I knew I was heading toward becoming a parent, I began to think about what sort of parent I wanted to be. And I began to weigh whether or not I should spank. I grew up in the ’70s and was spanked — quite a bit. I think the vast majority of black children of my generation were spanked, and nearly all the black kids in my parents’ generation were. Spanking seemed like a black cultural imperative: black people tell one another, “Spare the rod, spoil the child.”

headline: Atheist Event to Be Held at Fort Bragg
text: Fort Bragg in North Carolina has reached a truce of sorts with a group of Army atheists that opens the door for an event called Rock Beyond Belief on post next spring featuring music and speeches by noted secular humanists, including the writer Richard Dawkins .

headline: Questions for Cornel West
text: Cornel West flunks Race Relations 101. I have admired West for many years; I am dismayed, however, at his statements about “smart white brothers” and “smart Jewish brothers.” Judaism is a religion, not a race. West wouldn’t refer to smart Catholic brothers or smart Mormon brothers or smart Protestant brothers, so why does he do so in reference to Jewish brothers? This racial/religious reference perplexes and offends me and displays ignorance.

headline: You Are Making Your Biscuits Wrong
text: You have solved a 65-year family mystery! I have tried to replicate my Tennessee mother-in-law’s fabulous biscuits. I thought it was because she made them every single day. Now I know it was just the flour she used.

headline: Ladies, We Have a Problem
text: Rebecca Traister misses an essential point in her recent, compelling article on women’s sexuality and power, “Ladies, We Have a Problem.” Namely, there’s a growing worldwide movement to prosecute rape, child pornography and gender violence as crimes against humanity. Under the Rome Statute of 1998, the International Criminal Court defines crimes against humanity to include “rape, sexual slavery, enforced prostitution, forced pregnancy, enforced sterilization or any other form of sexual violence of comparable gravity.” Forget the Toronto policeman; ladies, we have a growing worldwide movement behind us.

headline: Yemen on the Brink
text: In the 1980s, when the U.S. helped overthrow the government of South Yemen and then installedSaleh, the “president” of North Yemen, as our proxy dictator in a united Yemen, we sowed the seeds ofour own defeat in a Middle Eastern country — again.

headline: ‘Magically Resistant to the Ego-Bloating Properties of Hollywood Life’
text: Heather Havrilesky in her recent Riff has it backward: puerile “vicarious celebrity thrills” and “pursuit of [sexual] pleasure” is indeed the coin of the realm on “Entourage.”

headline: Ex-Leader of Ukraine Is Held for Contempt; Activists See Purge in Progress
text: KIEV, Ukraine — The former prime minister of Ukraine was arrested in a courtroom here on Friday for contempt, during her trial on what rights advocates say is a trumped up charge that centers on whether a document was stamped correctly.

headline: Lübeck’s Spires, a Quick Hop From Hamburg
text: WITH its soaring spires, ubiquitous crow-step gables and dozens of courtyards lined with centuries-old houses, it’s easy to see why Unesco placed a large swath of the northern German city of Lübeck on its list of World Heritage Sites.

headline: Woods Sputters in Second Round, Can’t Threaten Leaders
text: AKRON, Ohio — On a still Friday, hot, humid and ideally suited to having a go at a soft Firestone Country Club, many players did. Tiger Woods did not, but again saw positives about his golf game not visible to the untrained eye.

headline: Strategies for Acing the Open House
text: WITH the help of the Internet, prospective buyers can gather a heap of details about properties before stepping near any one of them.

headline: Challenges Ahead on Arctic Drilling
text: As John Broder and I report in The New York Times, Shell won a big victory by gaining conditional approval from the Interior Department for its plan to drill for oil in the Beaufort Sea off the North Slope of Alaska. The decision takes the company a giant step closer to drilling oil wells in the Arctic after five years of trying to break through court and regulatory hurdles. But the battle is not over, and environmentalists will surely redouble their efforts.

headline: Length of Unemployment Continues to Break Records
text: The average worker who is unemployed has been searching for a job for 40.4 weeks, or more than nine months, according to new Labor Department figures.

headline: Resisting the Urge to Run Away From Home
text: In market moments like these, it’s always tempting do something really big and bold with our investments.

headline: When the National Pastime Imitates the Country’s Politicians
text: What a spectacle of undignified behavior, of hypocrisy, of extremism, of civility abandoned, of epic brattiness. Could a disgraced city possibly have proved itself more worthy of its reputation?

headline: The State of Zombie Literature: An Autopsy
text: Zombies, traditionally, do not move with great speed or agility. As the sheriff in George A. Romero's classic 1968 movie, "Night of the Living Dead," astutely observes, “They’re dead, they’re all messed up.” But they’re also mighty persistent, and, apparently through sheer doggedness, the reanimated deceased have managed to occupy increasingly large areas of the popular imagination in the past few years. They don’t, of course, reproduce in the usual way. The Romero-type zombie, very much the dominant form these days, multiplies by contagion, like a virus: it feeds on flesh, and its bite is lethal, so even those semi-­fortunate humans who aren’t wholly devoured, but merely gnawed upon, die and come back as shuffling, hollow-­eyed flesh-­eaters themselves.

headline: In Brooklyn, Blurring the Wealth Boundary
text: WHEN the developers of Atlantic Terrace, an 80-unit co-op in Fort Greene, began planning, they envisioned occupants reflecting the populace on the sidewalks of Brooklyn — that is, diverse in all ways, but especially economically.

headline: ‘Reservation Road,’ Revisited
text: John Burnham Schwartz’s 1998 novel, “Reservation Road,” was acclaimed by critics and readers alike, translated into many languages and, almost a decade later, turned into a well-­regarded movie of the same name. Ricocheting in brief, staccato chapters among the perspectives of its main characters, Schwartz’s narrative depicted the shattering consequences of a hit-and-run accident on two Connecticut families. It ended with Dwight, the driver who killed a 10-year-old boy, about to confess to the police and go off to jail. But it also hinted that the families’ two surviving children — Dwight’s son, Sam, and the dead boy’s sister, Emma — would suffer the true emotional fallout of this tragedy.

headline: A Writer Investigates Madness, His Own and Others’
text: I write this knowing from experience that when you publish a memoir, the reviews tend to be not of your writing ability, but of your personality. In “The Rules of the Tunnel,” Ned Zeman — who chronicles his attempts to control clinical depression through myriad doctors, hospitals, psychiatric meds and finally electro­convulsive therapy, all while juggling a high-profile career as an editor for Vanity Fair — shows that he is a gifted writer, capable of the kind of cut-glass prose to be carried into sunlight and admired from all angles:

headline: Lenience for Some Off-Season Violations
text: N.F.L. players got some good and bad news about their off-field conduct during the lockout.

headline: Tracking Somali Pirates to Their Lair
text: On April 8, 2009, the Maersk Alabama, a 17,000-ton United States cargo vessel, was hijacked by four Somali pirates several hundred miles east of Mogadishu. Bobbing in a lifeboat with the skipper, 53-year-old Richard Phillips, they began negotiating with the ship’s owners via cellphone for a multimillion-dollar ransom. For five days, the pirates and their hostage drifted in the Indian Ocean, shadowed by the U.S.S. Bainbridge, a destroyer that arrived at the scene not long after the hijacking. At dusk on April 12, Navy snipers killed three of the Somalis, and Phillips was rescued unharmed. The surviving pirate was seized and taken to the United States, where he pleaded guilty in a Manhattan courtroom to a host of charges and was sentenced to 33 years and nine months in a federal prison.

headline: ‘The Pirates of Somalia’
text: Prologue

headline: A Novel of Jazz, Soul and Civil Rights
text: Clyde Edgerton’s slim, charming 10th novel is set in the rural South, as the spring of 1963 turns into summer. It is a fraught moment in American history, but in the town of Starke, N.C., the rhetoric and rupture of the civil rights movement are still felt only as distant tremors. Change may be blowing in the wind, as the idiom of the day had it, but it still has to travel across the ground.

headline: Up Front: Adam Mansbach
text: If you know anything about Adam Mansbach, you probably know that his daughter’s bedtime routine makes him entertainingly cranky. Mansbach is famous these days for his best-selling “children’s” book, “Go the _ to Sleep,” but before he was a father he was a novelist (his playful, complicated novels about race include “Angry Black White Boy” and “The End of the Jews”), and before he was a novelist he dreamed, 25 years ago, of becoming a hip-hop star.

headline: ‘The Night Train’
text: PART I

headline: The Mathematics of Changing Your Mind
text: Sharon Bertsch McGrayne introduces Bayes’s theorem in her new book with a remark by John Maynard Keynes: “When the facts change, I change my opinion. What do you do, sir?”

headline: Which Way to the Garden of Eden?
text: Most people probably think the search for a “real” Garden of Eden was abandoned centuries ago. With so many modern scientific advances, the discovery of fossil evidence from early ages and, of course, the advance of Darwin’s theory of evolution, surely no one would be so mad as to look for an actual Eden. Brook Wilensky-­Lanford’s first book, “Paradise Lust,” suggests just the opposite.

headline: Our Spy War with China
text: In May 2004, the F.B.I. special agent James J. Smith found himself in an uncomfortable spot: he had to tell a federal judge about an affair he’d had with an informer, Katrina Leung, a San Marino, Calif., businesswoman with “jet-black hair,” while his wife and son were sitting in the courtroom. “Argh!” he later wrote to friends.

text: Subjects include foraging in New York City parks, a rare seagull in Coney Island, and a stuntman who wants to walk a tightrope over Niagara Falls.

headline: Too Greedy to Fail
text: If reality exists only in each individual’s warped consciousness, then there is no such thing as objective truth. That’s how some artists see it, anyway — and also, apparently, some bankers. The title of Justin Cartwright’s acerbic and entertaining new novel, “Other People’s Money,” comes from the gleeful shout heard in dealing rooms — “O.P.M.!” — as bankers lose bad bets on behalf of their clients. Cartwright illustrates the folly, showing how the recent financial collapse resulted from speculative fantasies and from an attitude that none of the risks were quite real.

headline: Grimm Lessons
text: Those blood-lusty Jacobean dramatists could have picked up a few pointers about betrayal and revenge from Reginald Hill, who turns a contemporary crime of greed into a timeless morality tale in THE WOODCUTTER (Harper/HarperCollins, $25.99). For all its elaborate narrative artifices, there’s a fairy-tale simplicity to this story of a Cumbrian woodcutter’s son who accomplishes three difficult tasks (“Get elocution lessons, get educated, get rich”) and is granted his “heart’s desire” — the hand of the “beautiful princess glimpsed dancing on the castle lawn.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THIS BEAUTIFUL LIFE,  by Helen Schulman (Harper/HarperCollins, $24.99.) In this timely novel, a family’s Manhattan life comes crashing down when their 15-year-old forwards a sexually explicit video made for him, unsolicited, by a girl two years younger.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE SHALLOWS: What the Internet Is Doing to Our Brains,  by Nicholas Carr (Norton, $15.95.) In 2008, Carr, a technology writer, published an article in The Atlantic titled “Is Google Making Us Stupid?” “The Shallows” expands on that article, arguing that we are trading away the seriousness of sustained attention for the Web’s frantic superficiality.

headline: Mobilizing Help for People Accused of Hacking
text: When Senator Joseph R. McCarthy held hearings in the 1950s to question witnesses about their supposed ties to communism, critics accused him of fomenting a Red Scare hysteria.

headline: An Ex Blogs. Is it O.K. to Watch?
text: I HAVE a good friend who, like countless others, is addicted to Googling ex-boyfriends. Instead of coffee breaks, she goes on periodic search sprees where she looks up old lovers, passing fancies and mere crushes.

headline: Boss Reaches Deal With Raiders
text: The free-agent tight end Kevin Boss agreed to a four-year deal with the Oakland Raiders on Friday morning. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Outdoor Pools: Sun. Splash. Repeat.
text: LIKE iced tea, perhaps, or casual Fridays, outdoor pools are in many minds forever linked with summer. After all, the sensation of sun on wet skin after a few dips in the deep end just about sums up the season.

headline: Inside the List
text: WONDERFUL TOWN: Amor Towles, whose first novel, “Rules of Civility,” hits the hardcover fiction list at No. 16, arrived in New York in 1989 with diplomas from Yale and Stanford and dreams of becoming a writer. But he quickly noticed that all his friends who were waiting tables and pursuing art on the side looked just as tired as the office drones they were serving. So he joined an investment firm instead and took seven years off from writing. Towles, today a principal in a money management concern, says the novel’s success, though wonderful, has been less important than simply finishing something he thought was good. “I would’ve sold it for a penny, just to be able to say ‘O.K., I did it,’ ” he said in a telephone interview. “I always thought I was a writer on the inside, but after a few years of not writing you can’t make that claim anymore.”

headline: A Boss Worthy of the Name Muscles Its Way Into the Family

text: REVIEWS of BMW’s new luxury-class touring motorcycle, the 2012 K1600, tend to be in agreement: this bike handles well. Yet the evaluations often seem to harbor the same implied asterisk: it handles well for a big bike.

headline: Closets Even for the Kayaks

headline: You Don’t Want to Be an American Idiot
text: As I note in this weekend’s Your Money column, it’s times like these that tempt us to send a message to governmental leaders who won’t make hard choices and take our stock market money to countries that seem safer.

headline: Counting the Ways to Cook an Eggplant
text: FOR the last few summers, I’ve been in an eggplant rut. No matter how many times I stand over the pile of the multi-hued beauties at the farmers’ market, swearing I’ll try something new, I always fall back on my standby recipe: toss eggplant cubes with good olive oil and roast until they turn golden at the edges and meltingly soft inside.

headline: As Humans Draw Nearer, Leopards Attack in India
text: Several rural villages in India have suffered leopard attacks in recent months, most recently on Saturday in the northeastern state of Assam. In July alone, nearly 16 people were mauled in four different attacks across the country. The most serious was in the eastern state of West Bengal, where a leopard wandered into a village and injured 11 people.

headline: Sanity Is Next Issue in Brooklyn Boy’s Killing
text: Now that Levi Aron has been found competent to stand trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the next step for his lawyers is to determine whether he was sane at the time of the crime he is accused of committing: kidnapping, killing and dismembering an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy, Leiby Kletzky.

headline: The search for the Garden of Eden; "A Book of Secrets" by Michael Holroyd; and bestseller news.
text: This week, author Brook Wilensky-Lanford talks about the search for the Garden of Eden in her new book, "Paradise Lust"; Toni Bentley reviews "A Book of Secrets" by Michael Holroyd; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has bestseller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Pagani Huayra Makes Landfall in Southern California
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Horacio Pagani, the Argentine maker of exotic Italian sports cars, officially unveiled his newest creation, the $1.2 million Huayra, to a North American audience of journalists and prospective customers here Thursday evening.

headline: The Jam | Prince Language
text: Since house music is all the rage these days, Sean Hanratty chose New York’s coveted D.J. and producer Prince Language for this week’s playlist. “D.J. Prince Language has been spinning house music for a really long time,” says Hanratty of the D.J. whose remix work for acclaimed artists like LCD Soundsystem, the Rapture and MGMT put him on the map as one of New York City’s most in-demand remixers in dance music. “His is a near-encyclopedic knowledge of both hip-hop and house.” Language, who hails from Chicago and now calls Manhattan’s Alphabet City home, worked on Twin Shadow‘s debut album, “Forget,” and is currently at bat on a remix for Light Asylum, as well as his own record. If you missed his performance at P.S. 1 last weekend, which he headlined with legendary hip-hop D.J. Stretch Armstrong, he’ll be at Le Bain on Saturday for Swimming With Sharks.

headline: Weekend Fare
