A general admission ticket, $60, gets you samples from all the chefs and two drinks.

headline: Baseball Embraces Dry, as in Wit
text: Somewhere along the line, Stephen Colbert figured out that comedy and sports make rather natural bedfellows. Actually, most days, sports produces enough of its own absurdity that contributions from comedians are hardly necessary. But Colbert has not been shy about contributing to the mix. Before the Winter Olympics last year, he not only sponsored the United States speedskating team, he also climbed into a spandex suit and rode with the men’s bobsled team.

headline: Banks Face Obstacles With Volcker Rule, Report Finds

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Spider-Man No. 666
text: Volume two of “I Am Here,” by Ema Toyama, enters our manga list at No. 10 this week. The series, published by Kodansha Comics, is about an eighth grader named Hikage Sumino who lacks self-esteem. According to the publisher’s blurb, “her only friends are the visitors to her Internet blog.” In volume two, her two worlds merge when it seems as if an online friend may very well be someone from her real life.

headline: Slovenian Rhapsody
text: EVENING was fast approaching in the Slovenian town of Piran when the chimes of the Chiesa di San Giorgio reminded me that the piano concerto was about to begin. As the sun slanted across the Adriatic, I hurried toward the vast Tartini Square — named for Giuseppe Tartini, the Baroque-era Italian violinist and composer — past outdoor cafes, where boisterous groups of Slovenians were devouring Balkan sausages and toasting one another — “Na zdravje!” (“To your health!”) — with local Lasko beer.

headline: Where Alaskan Adventurers Lay Their Heads
text: WHEN hiking alone in Alaska, I’d been told, make noise. The last thing you want is to surprise a bear. And so I was doing my best to fill the woods with song, belting out Broadway tunes as I trekked the Denver Glacier Trail, when an enemy stepped right onto my path. This was no bear, however, but the beady-eyed state bird of Alaska, the ptarmigan.

headline: Slovenia: A Bicultural Mash-Up

headline: Discovering Laura Ingalls Wilder

headline: In North Michigan, Cherries Are Just the Beginning
text: Traverse City, best known for its cherry products and wines, has a growing culinary and arts scene that shows there’s more to the region than orchards and vines.

headline: Samurai Shopper | If the Gloss Sticks …
text: This week Andy Warhol would have been 83 years old. As an artist who immortalized mass-produced commercial products, Warhol ruffled the feathers of the fine art establishment with his cheerfully banal connoisseurship. Gore Vidal once said Warhol was a genius with the IQ of a moron. In that, Warhol reminds me of the reclusive simpleton Chauncey Gardener, the character in Jerzy Kosinski’s “Being There” lauded for uttering Zen-like nuggets of wisdom when, in fact, like the quotable Warhol, he was a mere precursor to Forrest Gump.

headline: Cabin-Hopping in Alaska
text: The public-use cabins in Alaska are scenically located along lakes, atop mountains or on coastal islands.

headline: Coheed and Cambria Parts Ways With Its Bassist After His Arrest
text: The progressive rock band Coheed and Cambria announced on Friday that it had parted ways with its bassist, Mike Todd, three weeks after he was arrested on charges of robbing a pharmacy in Massachusetts to obtain prescription painkillers.

headline: Robert Ryan’s Quiet Furies
text: BORN to play beautifully tortured, angry souls, the actor Robert Ryan was a familiar movie face for more than two decades in Hollywood’s classical years, his studio ups and downs, independent detours and outlier adventures paralleling the arc of American cinema as it went from a national pastime to near collapse. A little prettier and he might have been one of the golden boys of the golden age. But there could be something a touch menacing about his face (something open and sweet too), which bunched as tight as a fist, and his towering height (he stood 6 foot 4) at times loomed like a threat. The rage boiled up in him so quickly. It made him seem dangerous.

headline: Officers Guilty of Shooting Six in New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — In a verdict that brought a decisive close to a case that has haunted this city since most of it lay underwater nearly six years ago, five current and former New Orleans police officers were found guilty on all counts by a federal jury on Friday for shooting six citizens, two of whom died, and orchestrating a wide-ranging cover-up in the hours, weeks and years that followed.

headline: Port Authority Seeks Big Toll Increase
text: The cost of crossing the bridges and tunnels that span the Hudson River to New York City could rise by 50 percent for many drivers under a steep series of toll increases to be proposed on Friday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, according to two people familiar with the plans.

headline: Complaints That Rent Is Illegally High Often Languish
text: Relations between Maria de los Santos and the landlord of her railroad apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, soured after she filed a complaint in 2007 over lack of heat. But they worsened, she said, after she discovered she had been overcharged in rent and appealed to the state housing agency for help.

headline: When Parents Fight
text: What is the role of fighting in a marriage? Julie Kennon wonders about that in a guest post today. Join in. But let’s try to make it a clean, fair fight …

text: We spent the day on a family outing, and left before they replaced the exhausted hamsters that power the BLS website. So, some belated commentary on the jobs report and related.

headline: Anti-stimulus Politics
text: Via FT Alphaville, Cullen Roche likes what I said in today’s column except that it’s “too political”, and then asks why I don’t call for a temporary cut in payroll taxes, which Republicans, who love tax cuts, would support.

headline: Debt Deal Could Be a Job-Killer For Incumbents
text: Initial public reaction to the deficit-reducing deal reached by President Obama and Congress is fairly poor. Although there is some variance from survey to survey, on average approval of the deal registers at 38 percent against 49 percent disapproval across four national polls conducted on it so far.

headline: Facebook Groups Made Easy
text: Have you ever e-mailed a bunch of photos to your family? Or written an e-mail to all of your best friends trying to plan a trip? Or have you done the same thing on Facebook, trying to carry on a discussion in a message to a dozen recipients? Facebook has a fix for that – Facebook Groups – explicitly designed to let a small set of people communicate with one another either in public, or in private. Groups are meant to replace mailing lists for people planning weddings, parties or team events.

headline: The World Trade Center Ship, From Stern to Stem
text: After finding the stern of an 18th-century sailing vessel in landfill where the new World Trade Center is being constructed, what could be better? Finding the bow — or at least enough to gain a clearer picture of the length of the vessel and how it was constructed; all of which might help solve the mystery of what it was doing anchored off Lower Manhattan in the first place.

headline: Tesla-Powered Toyota RAV4 E.V. to Be Built in Canada, Not California
text: When Toyota and Tesla Motors announced an agreement last year to collaborate on electric versions of the RAV4 compact S.U.V., there was much speculation that the battery car would be built at the 5.5-million-square-foot Nummi plant in California that Tesla bought in 2010. The plant, based in the Bay Area community of Fremont, had been jointly operated by Toyota and General Motors, and had sufficient capacity to accommodate production of other vehicles alongside the Model S sedan, expected to begin deliveries in mid-2012.

headline: Cycling in Wheat Country (Horse Country, Too)
text: CHENEY, Wash. — A beautiful, difficult three-day ride through the Palouse region of eastern Washington has left me leg-weary and sun-baked, and reminded of how bicycle touring lets you experience the country in intensely felt geographical segments. I made it here, a college town (Eastern Washington University) just south of Spokane, and it feels like a pivot; next I head east, toward Idaho, Montana and the Rockies.

headline: Salmonella: What Will It Take?
text: You’re not going to find a better summary of what’s happening with the 36 million-pound recall of salmonella-tainted ground turkey than this post by Maryn McKenna at Superbug. She discusses not only the awesome size of the thing, but the problems with antibiotic resistance and (probably of paramount importance) the fact that it’s not illegal to sell food with salmonella, even though a policy like that could be enacted.

headline: The Risks You Can Control
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes that a stock market dive or the debt debate in Washington are events you have no control over. But he says there may be risks in your portfolio that you can control.

headline: Postcard From Edinburgh: Getting in Early to a Fringe Favorite
text: EDINBURGH –The Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the largest multi-arts festival in the world, began on Friday, but the city was in full Fringe mode well ahead of schedule. On just about every corner — and between them, too — advertisements for Fringe productions adorned fences, lampposts and various other surfaces. And humans, of course.

headline: No Prints? Evidence Points to Mutated Gene
text: Fingerprints are used as identity markers. No two are alike. But there are people with a rare condition called adermatoglyphia who have no fingerprints at all. Now, Dr. Eli Sprecher, a geneticist and dermatologist at the Tel Aviv Sourasky Medical Center in Israel, and his colleagues have identified the gene mutation that causes the disease.

headline: Euro Builder Ends His Career on a Bitter Note
text: FRANKFURT — Jean-Claude Trichet, the president of the European Central Bank, has spent much of his career building and defending the euro. But now, in a bitter twist, it looks as if his career may well end with the common currency in shambles.

headline: That Was The Inflation Scare That Was
text: A little while back many people made a big deal over the fact that measures of core inflation, if you took monthly data at an annual rate, were running above 3 percent. Some of us tried to make the case that this wasn’t really reflecting a big rise in underlying inflation, that it was mainly “contamination” of the core by transitory effects of commodity prices; but this brought much jeering.

headline: Heat Sensor Helps Vampire Bat Find Meals
text: Vampire bats need a blood meal every day or two to survive. And an ability to detect infrared radiation with their noses aids them in their search for sustenance by allowing them to pinpoint areas where blood flows near the surface in their prey.

headline: Daughter Leads, Mom Follows in Fashion Sync

headline: Making Waves, With No Apology
text: HAVING curly hair makes me taller, more literary and better in bed. Perhaps not everyone agrees with me, like, say, my husband and the 500 men I dated before him who dumped me. But forget that. I know it’s true. Or at least it’s the story I tell myself every time I have a bout of Straight Hair Envy, when I ponder the possibilities of the Brazilian Blowout (surely formaldehyde seeping into the scalp can’t be that bad?) or wistfully cruise the aisles of Ricky’s jonesing for Fekkai Silky Straight Ironless, Redken Align 12 Ultra-Straight Balm and John Frieda Frizz-Ease Straight Fixation Smoothing Crème.

headline: July’s Political Best Sellers
text: “A World On Fire” by Amanda Foreman makes its debut at No. 10. Ms. Foreman, the acclaimed historian, sheds light on the vast involvement that Britain had in the American Civil War; the fruits of her research shocked her: finding that countless British writers, students, actors and others sympathized with the feudal South. “The Storm Of War” by Andrew Roberts debuts at No. 13. A British historian, Roberts ponders that if the Axis had strategized and made better decisions, they possibly could have won World War II. And the final debut is “The Triple Agent” by Joby Warrick at No. 14. This is the first comprehensive account of the C.I.A. blunder that allowed a Qaeda mole, Humam al-Balawi, a Jordanian pediatrician turned spy, to detonate a custom-made vest of explosives that took the lives of nine intelligence operatives at a C.I.A. base in Afghanistan.

headline: By One Survey, Fewer Jobs Than 2 Years Ago
text: The job numbers every month come from two different surveys, which sometimes point in different directions. The establishment survey questions employers, and produces one headline number. This month it concluded that, seasonally adjusted, the economy added 117,000 jobs in July. The household survey asks people if they are working, and is used to calculate the unemployment rate.

headline: Adding Glitter to Eyeglass Frames
text: IN April, Paula Deen, the television cooking personality, introduced a line of prescription eyeglasses, retailing for about $30 each in Wal-Mart stores nationwide, a few aisles away from her popular casserole dishes. There are a dozen pairs in the collection, each the kind of acetate rectangle that’s become ubiquitous.

headline: Ethics Panel Takes Action in 3 Cases

headline: Now Watching | ‘LightHouse’ by NewVillager
text: Headed by the Brooklyn-based visual artists/musicians Ross Simonini and Ben Bromley, NewVillager approaches concerts as “integrated events”; D.J. sets are “lectures” and weeklong, multiroom gallery installations, like “Temporary Culture,” their recent show at Human Resources in Los Angeles which was “designed for living, sleeping, performing and going through stages of culture,” are formal opportunities to shed light on the group’s dense, and at times baffling mythology. To put it in layman’s terms, NewVillager is a pop band that plays art galleries. Its debut album comes out Aug. 16 on IAMSOUND Records.

headline: What Complements a Pink Taco Truck? An Iridescent El Camino, of Course

headline: Book Review Podcast: Michael Holroyd’s ‘Book of Secrets’

headline: Home Entertainment Spending Continues To Slide
text: LOS ANGELES — Home entertainment revenue slowed its decline in the second quarter, as total spending in the United States on DVDs, downloads and other formats fell 3.55 percent to about $3.99 billion, down from $4.14 billion in the second quarter of 2010, according to the Digital Entertainment Group. First quarter sales had fallen by about 6.41 percent from the year-earlier period.

headline: A Mother’s Familiar Optimism, Without the Familiar Letdown

Now here she is as Amanda Wingfield, Tennessee Williams’s faded belle and overbearing mother from “The Glass Menagerie.”

headline: CBS Invites Viewers to Help Fill ‘Big Brother’ Vacancies
text: “Big Brother” on CBS claimed the top spot for total viewers in prime time among programs on the broadcast networks Thursday night, and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, with 7.3 million viewers tuning in according to Nielsen. After the contestants voted to evict another member of the “Big Brother” household, it was announced that a new twist would be added to the shows’ long-in-the-tooth format.  Fans can now go to CBS.com and vote for a previously evicted resident, and the person with the most votes will get the chance to return to the show. The reality program carried CBS to an overall ratings victory as well, averaging around 6.3 million total viewers for the night. ABC came in second, averaging just under 5.5 million viewers thanks to its reality competitions, “Wipeout” (6.6 million viewers) and “Expedition Impossible.” (4.8 million).

text: Andrea Lynn Jepsen and Brett Lee Turner were married Saturday. Cassandra J. Netzke, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the home of the bridegroom in St. Paul.

headline: Talia Javid, Christopher Dardis
text: Talia Lynn Javid and Dr. Christopher John Patrick Dardis were married Saturday evening. Jamie A. Ross, ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary in Manhattan, officiated at Croton Point Park in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

headline: Kristine Berzins, Michael Birnbaum
text: Kristine Berzins and Michael Birnbaum were married Saturday at the Elizabeth F. Cheney Mansion, an event space in Oak Park, Ill. Anne Fadiman, a former teacher of the bridegroom’s who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Vanessa Zahorian, Davit Karapetyan
text: Vanessa Andrea Zahorian and Davit Karapetyan were married Monday at City Hall in San Francisco by Andrea Goldman, a deputy marriage commissioner. On June 11, the couple had a religious ceremony at St. Grigory the Illuminator Cathedral in Yerevan, Armenia, where Zenon Barseghyan, an Armenian Apostolic Orthodox priest, officiated.

headline: Angela Lanzafama and Kyle Sweeney
text: Angela Lanzafama and Kyle Michael Sweeney were married Saturday evening at the Mallard Island Yacht Club in Manahawkin, N.J. The Rev. Kevin W. Wildes, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

headline: Happy Birthday to the Income Tax
text: Happy birthday to the federal personal income tax, which turns 150 today.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 5
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include foraging in New York City parks, a rare seagull in Coney Island, and a stuntman who wants to walk a tightrope over Niagara Falls.

headline: The Woman Behind Lucy’s Laughs
text: HAD you met her casually with no clue as to her identity, you would never associate Madelyn Pugh Davis with the outlandish behavior and outrageous situations personified by Lucille Ball in her madcap heyday.

headline: Looking for a Date as China Looks On
text: CHANGSHA, China

headline: Psychedelia of Many Colors, Doo-Wop in Bluesy Shades
text: Jesse Sykes and the Sweet Hereafter

headline: This Sunday: No Financial Gloom Here (Or Not Much Anyway)
text: Nothing makes the arrival of the weekend sweeter than a few days of madness in the stock market. And you may be pleased to learn that this week’s issue aims for pleasurable diversion. I couldn’t be prouder of our cover stories from the last two weeks — Andrew Rice’s exploration of El Paso and Juárez, and Robert Worth in Yemen — but this time, we offer pure treats.

headline: Ads and Fees Lift Viacom to a 37% Increase in Profit
text: Viacom, the owner of MTV and Paramount Pictures, on Friday reported a 37 percent increase in profits for the quarter that ended in June.

headline: Chalky Chorus of Specters Who Dance and Crush
text: The Mostly Mozart Festival is billing its presentation of Mozart’s opera “Don Giovanni,” featuring the conductor Ivan Fischer, the excellent Budapest Festival Orchestra and an admirable cast, as just a “staged concert.” While festival organizers deserve respect for their honesty in not inflating the scope of this venture, the “Don Giovanni” that opened at the Rose Theater of Jazz at Lincoln Center on Thursday night, which was also directed by Mr. Fischer, is more involving, imaginative and theatrically daring than many full productions I have seen.

headline: Markets Activity
text: Daily changes in U.S. markets.

headline: The Week That Was, in Verse
text: Thought it was safe to go back into the markets after the debt ceiling was finally raised? Wrong! On that note, we run down the top DealBook stories from the week, in poetic form:

headline: Where Hip-Hop Meets the Martial Arts
text: What do you get when you mix the formality of martial arts with the brashness of hip-hop? In “Hip Hop Kung Fu,” at Asia Society on Wednesday night, it was an amateurish display that shed only a superficial light on the relationship between hip-hop and Asian cultures. (It is a worthy topic.) As part of Hip Hop Generation Next: From the South Bronx to East Asia, a festival organized by Dancing in the Streets and Casita Maria Center for Arts and Education, this evening-length show, also presented by Asia Society, sampled a range of styles from both sides of the world.

headline: Before Bach Arrived, Others Led the Way
text: The 4x4 Baroque Music Festival has developed a yearly tradition of including a program that puts the career of Johann Sebastian Bach — who for many is still Baroque music entire — into context with the work of his predecessors.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, August 5
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures: August 5
text: More Photographs

headline: A Last-Round Win in Toronto Secures the Title for a Team
text: On the last day of the Summer Nationals in Toronto last Sunday, there was a close finish to the Roth Open Swiss Teams. Aaron Silverstein, Chris Willenken, Andrew Rosenthal and Bjorn Fallenius of New York; Michael Rosenberg of Cupertino, Calif.; and Peter Fredin from Sweden were leading, with one match to be played.

headline: Bike Vacations Offer Freedom and Frugality
text: LIKE many New Yorkers, Alan Tansey is planning an escape this summer — in his case, a 370-mile journey north through New York State, over the Canadian border and into the heart of Montreal.

headline: Theory’s Designer Shapes a New Future
text: IT was the business equivalent of a blind date.

headline: Olivier Theyskens’s Past Work
text: The former artistic director for Rochas and Nina Ricci, Olivier Theyskens is trying again with Theyskens’ Theory.

headline: Back to the Simple Life, With Needle and Thread
text: WALK into the modest railroad-style brownstone apartment and it feels less like Brooklyn and more like stepping off the steam train into “Little House on the Park Slope Prairie.”

headline: Without This Ring: Losing a Wedding Band
text: ABOUT a week into Jill Stoll’s marriage, a colleague grabbed her hand and exclaimed, “Let’s see the ring,” recalled Ms. Stoll, who was teaching photography at the Dalton School. Only then did Ms. Stoll notice that both her wedding band and engagement ring were gone.

headline: ‘Law & Order,’ and Riverside Walks
text: Robin Roberts has not made peace with her 3:45 a.m. wake-up time, but as co-host of “Good Morning America” alongside George Stephanopoulos, she morphs into an early bird on weekdays in full makeup, heels and no-repeat designer outfits. She is one of the all-time leading scorers for the women’s basketball team at Southeastern Louisiana University, and she was elected this year to the Women’s Basketball Hall of Fame. A breast cancer survivor, she is the author of “From the Heart: 7 Rules to Live By”; a revised paperback version with eight rules describes her experience with the disease. Ms. Roberts, 50, lives on the Upper West Side with her wire-haired Jack Russell terrier, K.J.; she also has a home in Farmington, Conn.

headline: Obama's Undoing?
text: Glenn Loury, left, of Brown University and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate the relationship between Obama and Congress.

headline: The Ups and Downs of Attraction
text: THERE has always been something erotically charged about elevators. The tightness of the space, the evocative enclosure, the tension arising from keeping one’s gaze from meeting another’s — all contribute to the frisson that can sometimes accompany a ride, even from the ground floor to the mezzanine. The following poems about elevators — and other modes of up-and-down conveyance, like stairs and escalators (which work on a different erotic principle) — were found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.

headline: A.I.G. Unit at Center of Financial Crisis Is Wound Down
text: More than two years ago, fury over the financial crisis appeared to find a single target: an unassuming red-brick building in a suburban Connecticut office park.

headline: Sharing Oysters, Wine and New Ideas
text: Along the western edge of Hell’s Kitchen, nestled amid the many car dealerships is Print, an elegant farm-to-table restaurant in the lobby of Ink48, a Kimpton hotel in a former printing plant. The spot, at 48th Street and 11th Avenue, makes its own butter and limoncello and employs a full-time “forager” who travels the region and beyond to find fare like 3 Corner Field Farm lamb and Battenkill Valley Creamery milk. A rarity in the neighborhood, it has become something of a go-to place for people who work at Kenneth Cole, Prada, Coach and Ogilvy & Mather, all of which have offices nearby. On Tuesday evening, the crowd included two business associates catching up.

headline: Plane Is Evacuated in Philadelphia
text: A US Airways flight from Philadelphia to Anchorage was evacuated at Philadelphia International Airport on Friday afternoon after a threatening note was received saying there was a bomb onboard, officials said. Slightly more than three hours later, the plane was cleared.

headline: Group of 7 Will Meet to Address Debt Issue
text: PARIS — As European leaders on Friday tried to calm fears that the region’s sovereign debt problems were spinning beyond politicians’ control, Italy’s prime minister said finance ministers from the Group of 7 industrial nations would meet “within days” to discuss the volatile financial crisis.

headline: N.F.L. Falls Short of a Leap on H.G.H.
text: The drug-testing programs of major American professional sports leagues have long attracted more attention for their gaping loopholes than for any bold advances that make cheating especially difficult.

headline: Searching for a Rock Star, and Coming Up Empty
text: “Wanna see my picture on the cover / Wanna buy five copies for my mother / Wanna see my smiling face on the cover of the Rolling Stone ...” sang the band Dr. Hook and the Medicine Show in the 1973 hit “The Cover of the Rolling Stone,” on just how hard it was to get the top spot in the magazine.

headline: Fox News Site Calls Obama Party a ‘Hip-Hop BBQ’
text: To most news Web sites, what happened at the White House on Thursday night was a private 50th birthday party for President Obama. To an editor at Fox News, it was something a little different.

headline: Elisabeth Murdoch Won’t Be Nominated to Board This Year
text: In a change to her father’s plans, Elisabeth Murdoch will not be nominated this year to the board of the News Corporation, a member of the board said Friday.

headline: Broadway Ticket Booths, Palm-Size
text: APP tkts

headline: A Light Fantastic Could Illuminate New York
text: Summer. A long stretch of temperatures in the 80s and 90s. Feels as if we’re due for a blackout.

headline: Jets May Ask Mason to Take Less Money
text: With their options for finding a No. 3 receiver dwindling, the Jets on Friday continued their pursuit of Derrick Mason, the 14-year veteran who played the last six seasons with the Baltimore Ravens.

headline: A Murdoch’s Missed Opportunity
text: When the News Corporation announced it would stop paying the legal fees for Glenn Mulcaire, the private investigator at the center of Britain’s tabloid phone hacking scandal, the consequences were swift. Mr. Mulcaire could obviously shed light on who at the News Corporation knew about the phone hacking and efforts to conceal it.

headline: Vanessa & Davit
text: Davit Karapetyan and Vanessa Zahorian danced as Romeo and Juliet with the San Francisco Ballet. After the curtain call, Davit proposed to Vanessa.

headline: Prison Term for Crimes Against Cuba Is Upheld
text: MEXICO CITY — Cuba’s highest court on Friday upheld a 15-year prison sentence for Alan Gross, an American contractor charged with crimes against the Cuban state for distributing satellite telephone equipment to Jewish groups in Havana.

headline: Monitoring Progress of Wollman Rink in Prospect Park
text: Prospect Park Progress

headline: Relief Group Stops Work in Bahrain After Raid
text: Bahrain, the tiny but strategically important Persian Gulf monarchy that has sought for months to suppress an Arab Spring-inspired uprising, is engaged in a heated dispute with one of the world’s foremost medical relief organizations, which has stopped working there after accusing Bahraini security forces of raiding its premises last week.

headline: Rangers’ Sean Avery Is Arrested
text: Rangers forward Sean Avery was arrested in Los Angeles around 1 a.m. on Friday on a misdemeanor charge of battery on a police officer, the Los Angeles Police Department said. According to a report on the Web site TMZ, Avery is accused of shoving a police officer who was responding to a complaint about noise from a house party in the Hollywood Hills.

headline: Podcast: Double-Dip Fears and Grab-and-Go Food
text: August is off to a rocky start.

headline: Texas Rally Renews Debate Over the Boundaries of Perry’s Faith
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — In April, as Texas reeled from wildfires and a drought, Gov. Rick Perry sought assistance from the federal government, but also from a higher power. He asked the state to pray for rain, issuing an official proclamation that “I, Rick Perry, Governor of Texas, under the authority vested in me by the Constitution and Statutes of the State of Texas, do hereby proclaim the three-day period from Friday, April 22, 2011, to Sunday, April 24, 2011, as Days of Prayer for Rain in the State of Texas.”

headline: Russian President Says U.S. Had Role in Georgian Conflict
text: MOSCOW — In an interview Friday that was timed to the third anniversary of Russia’s war with Georgia, President Dmitri A. Medvedev said top United States officials played a key role in events that touched off the war, and offered a withering assessment of a recent Senate resolution on Georgia’s behalf, which he said reflected “the personal tastes of certain elderly members of the Senate.”

headline: On the Street | Dream Maker
text: Holly Golightly, as portrayed by Audrey Hepburn, and her imagery are having their moment with a new generation this summer.

headline: Bringing In Diners With Offerings Not on the Menu
text: TEMPERATURES soared outside the Division Street Grill in Peekskill on a recent Saturday night. But inside, the unflappable guitarist Bucky Pizzarelli and his longtime bassist, Jerry Bruno, were playing it cool with well-worn standards like “Satin Doll” and “Tangerine.” And their subtle, sly treatment struck a chord with the 40 or so diners, who applauded faithfully between bites of pan-seared tuna and penne Bolognese.

headline: Terms of Loan From Baseball Ease Dodgers’ Fear of Seizure
text: Under the terms of a $150 million loan agreement submitted to federal bankruptcy court on Friday, Major League Baseball cannot seize control of the Los Angeles Dodgers if the team defaults.

headline: Battle for Libya | August 5, 2011
text: A religious leader and hundreds of Benghazi residents prayed over the body of a rebel fighter killed at the front on Thursday.

headline: S.& P. Downgrades Debt Rating of U.S. for the First Time
text: WASHINGTON — Standard & Poor’s removed the United States government from its list of risk-free borrowers for the first time on Friday night, a downgrade that is freighted with symbolic significance but carries few clear financial implications.

headline: Deep in Slop, Trying to Stop Bigger Disaster in the Hudson
text: All around Stephen Askew was raw sewage, eight feet deep, flooding a crippled waste-treatment plant in Harlem. But Mr. Askew never had a choice; he had to go in.

headline: Wedding Etiquette
text: Name That In-Law

headline: Spanning the Globe, and Melding Cultures
text: The Olympics of contemporary art is happening this summer as nations around the world send artists to represent them at the Venice Biennale. But work that has a biennial flavor — in other words, it addresses a global audience, but with a local accent — can be seen closer to home in two shows at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford: “Shaun Gladwell: Matrix 162” and “Connections Gallery: Iona Rozeal Brown.” One of the artists is even biennial-certified: Mr. Gladwell, along with three others, represented Australia at the 2009 Venice Biennale.

headline: Many Questions About Money Remain After Financing Is Restored for F.A.A.
text: WASHINGTON — It took the Senate all of about 30 seconds on Friday to approve a bill that will put 4,000 employees of the Federal Aviation Administration back to work on Monday. Calculating the cost of the 14-day standoff will take much longer.

headline: For a Standout College Essay, Applicants Fill Their Summers
text: Josh Isackson, an 18-year-old graduate of Tenafly High School in New Jersey, spent the summer after his sophomore year studying Mandarin in Nanjing, China. The next year he was an intern at a market research firm in Shanghai. When it came time to write a personal statement for his college applications, those summers offered a lot of inspiration.

headline: Draft Brews to Go
text: Growlers, the reusable glass jugs designed to hold draft beers, are not regularly found in retail outlets. But a new shop in Croton-on-Hudson is now offering a constantly changing lineup of brews in growlers; most of them are not even available in traditional bottles.

headline: Tapas and Much More in a Warm Setting
text: LA CAMELIA celebrates its 27th anniversary this year, and may this lovely hilltop restaurant live to be 100. Styled as a European country inn, it is one of the homiest, most inviting restaurants in the county. The cozy dining rooms feature fireplaces (glowing in season), Iberian pottery, votive candlelight, a few modern Spanish prints and lovely views of the surrounding garden.

headline: Red Sox Waiting for a Glimpse of the Prized Free Agent They Signed
text: BOSTON

headline: Off-Center Fair Forgoes the 4-H for High Heels
text: At the Denver County Fair, the black stiletto pumps in the “shoes and accessories” category of competition were in trouble. Leslie Armagost, a judge, was feeling critical about the red jewel on the heel, which was a bit off-center, she thought.

headline: Bold, With a Long Finish
text: If August heat discourages cooking in favor of spicy Thai takeout, local gewürztraminer would be a fitting partner. Generally this bold, spicy white wine delivers a rose-petal aroma, grapefruit- and litchi-like flavors and a pleasingly bitter finish.

headline: Alvin Ailey’s Mission Inspires Dance Camp
text: NEWARK

headline: A Rustic Seafood Spot With a Hometown Chef
text: IT is easy to miss T R Restaurant and Bar in Hampton Bays — it shares a building with Tully’s Seafood Market and cannot be seen from the road. But motorists whizzing by on Foster Avenue, on their way to the Ponquogue Bridge and ocean beaches, can see a blue sign for it. Those initials, T R, stand for Tom Rutyna.

headline: Is Less Defense the Best Offense?
text: “Disastrous.” “Unacceptable.” “Doomsday.” “This is the Pentagon’s worst nightmare.” What is it? Another 9/11? North Korea nuking Seoul? Nope — try budget cuts.

headline: S&P and the USA
text: OK, so Standard and Poors has gone ahead with the threatened downgrade. It’s a strange situation.

headline: ‘Free-Spirited’ Music With a Tamer Name
text: Richard Rivkin, 55, of Greenlawn, likes to organize musical events and, when possible, to give them catchy names. For example: Elwoodstock, the jam-band festival he started in 2001 in Elwood Park. “The event had sort of a throwback-to-Woodstock vibe,” he said. “I couldn’t resist the play on words.”

headline: They Had a Barn, So They Decided to Put on a Show
text: East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: S.&P.’s Rationale for Downgrading the U.S.
text: After weeks of of speculation, Standard & Poor’s downgraded on Friday the credit rating of the United States by one notch, to AA+ from AAA. The agency’s outlook on the country’s short- and long-term ratings was also negative, meaning that a further downgrade to AA was possible.

headline: The Campaign to Ban Islamic Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fairer Share of Tax Burden
text: To the Editor:

headline: No New Pledges
text: To the Editor:

headline: Of Bikes, Bread and the Dutch Way of Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: With 1% Growth and Staggering Debt, Italy Might Have to Cut Its Vacation Short
text: ROME — Italians may have headed to the beach for their sacrosanct summer holidays, but a storm may be brewing offshore. High debt, rising interest rates and low growth are fast eroding Italy’s solvency at a time when Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s government is weaker and less popular than ever before.

headline: The Do-Everything Congress
text: Last week New York magazine, in a list of the worst Congresses in history, highlighted “The Inarguably Awful 37th,” which ran between 1861 and 1863: “The very least that can be said for the other congressional classes on this list is that they did not oversee the eruption of a catastrophic civil war.” And that’s pretty much all the 37th Congress is remembered for — which is a shame, because it was actually one of the most productive and momentous in American history.

headline: A Cafe With a Social Scene
text: The definition of the Portuguese word bolo — “sweet baked food” — is written in large letters on the wall of Bolo Bakery and Café. But the words hardly do justice to a family-run business that is a social hub at breakfast and lunch as well as a bakery offering a variety of breads and pastries.

headline: Where the River Meets the Salty Sound
text: IT would be hard to find a bad table at Fresh Salt, the new restaurant that replaced Terra Mar in May at the Saybrook Point Inn and Spa. Because the dining room overlooks the mouth of the Connecticut River, the view, through a wall of windows, is reliably fantastic from most vantage points and in every season. Food and service are less consistent.

headline: The 111th Congress and the Lobby
text: Though only five former legislators are registered lobbyists now, a significant share will likely register as lobbyists after the one-year ban on lobbying expires.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Wild Market Quiets the Buzz for I.P.O.’s
text: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg NewsOfferings by well-known brands like Zynga, a maker of online games, might perform well for a time while the rest of the market struggles.

headline: I’ll Borrow Your Farm, You Keep My Bees
text: MILFORD, N.J.

headline: Protesters Yearn for an Israel That Does More to Help Its People
text: JERUSALEM — The tent protest movement dominating Israel for three weeks focuses on the cost of living but is really about something deeper — the nature of the country’s social contract. Many Israelis feel that their sacrifices are not being repaid.

headline: C.C. vs. A.J.
text: After the Yankees missed the playoffs in 2008, they invested $243.5 million in C.C. Sabathia and A.J. Burnett, the top two starting pitchers available on the free-agent market.

headline: Steep Increases Proposed for PATH Fares and Tolls at Hudson Crossings
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey proposed its steepest toll increase in modern memory on Friday, unveiling a plan that would raise the cost of crossing the tunnels and bridges that span the Hudson River by 50 percent for most drivers and raise the price of a monthly PATH train pass by 65 percent.

headline: After Tunisia’s Revolution, Disenchantment
text: In the wake of widespread unemployment, promises from the government have raised expectations and then led to recriminations.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Saturday: Flibbertigibbety
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I didn’t get how funny this puzzle was until I had stared at it for what seemed like forever. At first, it just seemed like a very satisfying Saturday puzzle by Joe Krozel, with excellent 15s squaring off the grid.

headline: Mark Sanford Is Still in Love
text: In 2009 you told your family and staff that you were hiking the Appalachian Trail when in fact you were visiting Maria Belen Chapur in Argentina. You called her your “soul mate.” Is that still the case?  I would say that I have more than well described all of my emotions and feelings toward Maria. And out of fairness to my boys and to folks that I’ve hurt, I’m not going to say more than this: any of those seemingly goofy feelings that I described a couple years back have intensified, not dissipated, with time.

headline: In Tunisian Town of Arab Spring Martyr, Disillusionment Seeps In
text: SIDI BOUZID, Tunisia — It is hard to say for sure who took down the portrait of the revolution’s most famous martyr, Mohamed Bouazizi, from its perch atop a garish gold statue on the street where he set himself on fire, touching off a season of revolt across the Arab world. One man said unnamed counterrevolutionaries did it, and another man said it was damaged by rain.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: As Corporate Profits Rise, Workers’ Income Declines
text: THESE are the worst of times for workers, and the best of times for companies. At least that is one way to read the newly revised national economic statistics.

headline: Showing Little Fight, Mets Fall Against Braves
text: For once, the Mets did not lose a hair-raising game in their opponent’s final at-bat, as they had three times in a row this week.

headline: NATO Crew Failed to Aid Migrant Ship, Survivors Say
text: ROME — Italy demanded on Friday that NATO investigate reports that an alliance warship failed to come to the aid of a boat full of migrants fleeing violence in Libya.

headline: Bad Days and Weeks
text: Thursday was the worst day for the stock market in more than two years. Despite gains on Friday, the Dow Jones Industrial average ended the week down 5.75 percent, worse than 98 percent of the weeks in its history.

headline: Series Against Red Sox Has the Yankees Thinking Pitching, Including Nova
text: BOSTON — Fresh off a strong performance against the reeling Chicago White Sox on Thursday, Ivan Nova went through his normal day-after routine for a starting pitcher because, for now, that is what he remains. As Nova answered questions about his status before the Yankees’ game against the Boston Red Sox on Friday he wore a big smile on his face, if only because he was still with the team.

headline: Libya Rebuffs Qaddafi Son on Alliance With Radical Islamists
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi distanced itself on Friday from comments that his son Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi made the previous day, when he vowed in an interview to strike an alliance with a faction of radical Islamists among the rebels challenging his father’s rule.

headline: A Fast Trip Through Washington's Revolving Door
text: The documents provided here illustrate some of Earl Pomeroy’s lobbying efforts since leaving Congress.

headline: Rudolf Brazda, Who Survived Pink Triangle, Is Dead at 98
text: Rudolf Brazda, believed to be the last surviving man to wear the pink triangle — the emblem sewn onto the striped uniforms of the thousands of homosexuals sent to Nazi concentration camps, most of them to their deaths — died on Wednesday in Bantzenheim, in Alsace, France. He was 98.

headline: Andrzej Lepper, Polish Firebrand Wary of Europe, Dies at 57
text: Andrzej Lepper, a populist politician who rose from pig farmer to deputy prime minister of Poland but whose career was undone by scandal, was found dead on Friday in his office in Warsaw, the police said. He was 57.

headline: How to Respond to Rick Perry and ‘The Response’
text: Tuscaloosa, Ala.

headline: Mr. Mubarak on Trial
text: For anyone who saw Hosni Mubarak in all his glory — confident and in command during three decades as Egypt’s president — this week’s photographs were jarring. Hollow-eyed, lying in a hospital bed, surrounded by a cage at his trial in Cairo. The all-powerful modern pharaoh is now powerless and facing justice.

headline: Down to the Wire
text: More than 150 years ago, this newspaper took an editorial position on the question of tightrope walkers at Niagara Falls. We were opposed.

headline: The Madman Theory
text: I had breakfast this week with one of Hollywood’s most ferocious, self-confident and successful doers of deals. He was still steamed about what an unforgivably lousy negotiator his president had been on the debt ceiling agreement.

headline: Ex-Lawmaker Still a Friend of Hospitals
text: WASHINGTON — Earl Pomeroy figured that Plan A was his career in Congress, where, over nearly two decades, as a North Dakota congressman he became a powerful advocate for the hospital industry.

headline: Johan Santana Not Yet Ready to Give Up on Return
text: Manager Terry Collins conceded Friday that the Mets were running out of time to make up ground on the Atlanta Braves, whom they trailed by eight games in the National League wild card race at the start of the day.

headline: Elmer Staats, Comptroller General in 4 Administrations, Dies at 97
text: Elmer B. Staats, who as comptroller general of the United States during four presidential administrations transformed the role of the Congressional agency that oversees federal spending from keeping track of the dollars to evaluating the efficacy of government programs, died July 23 in Washington. He was 97.

headline: The Tea Party, Take Two
text: In the four months since I began writing an Op-Ed column, the thing that has most surprised me is how darned liberal I sound sometimes. I know that seems like a strange thing to say, so let me explain.

headline: The World This Week, Part 1
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Yankees’ Winning Streak Reaches Boston and Leads to First Place
text: BOSTON — For the first time since July 6, the Yankees seized sole possession of first place in the American League East, a reward for their gaudy success over the last several weeks.

headline: The World This Week, Part 2
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Political Roots in U.S. Economic Crisis
text: By nearly every recent measure — growth, consumer spending, manufacturing, house prices and stock prices — the American economy is struggling. The jobs report for July, released on Friday, was a bit better than expected, but still grim.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Photos
text: Pearls for everyone, bankruptcy in Rhode Island, American fast food in Russia, the surging sales of luxury goods, and more.

headline: No Better in Europe
text: We were hopeful last month that Europe’s leaders had bought themselves and the global economy time to address the fundamental economic problems eroding the finances and credibility of the 17-nation euro zone.

headline: Giants Sign Their Unexpected Draft Prize
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Prince Amukamara visited New York for the first time in April to attend the N.F.L. draft, he took advantage and did some exploring. Along the way, he checked a couple of items off his to-do list: riding the subway and attending a baseball game for the first time.

headline: The Decade of Lost Children
text: One of the greatest casualties of the great recession may well be a decade of lost children.

headline: A Wall to Remember an Era’s First Exiles
text: BAINBRIDGE ISLAND, Wash. — Frank Kitamoto was only 2 when he and his family — and more than 270 others of Japanese ancestry — were forcibly removed from this forested island and sent to an internment camp after Japan bombed Pearl Harbor in World War II. Mr. Kitamoto, now 72, said he spent many of his younger years in a severe identity crisis, ashamed of his Japanese heritage and wishing he were white. Other young men went so far as to have plastic surgery to disguise their Japanese features. Some committed suicide.

headline: Returning Home Again
text: A new memorial will reflect on an era when Japanese-Americans were exiled from their homes and incarcerated by the United States government because of their ethnicity.

headline: Polar Bear Kills British Teenager in Norway
text: A 17-year-old British boy was killed on a remote Norwegian island when a polar bear tore through his group’s campsite early Friday morning, according to officials and news reports. The bear injured four other people, two of them severely, before it was shot dead.

headline: Fannie Mae Seeks More Help as Its Loss Grows
text: Fannie Mae, the mortgage-finance company under government conservatorship, reported a $2.9 billion second-quarter loss on Friday and said it would seek $5.1 billion in Treasury Department aid to balance its books. Fannie Mae requested the money to eliminate a net worth deficit of $5.1 billion for the three-month period that ended June 30, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing by the company, which is based in Washington. The loss, which compares with a $1.2 billion loss a year earlier, was mostly a result of credit-related expenses on home loans made before the 2008 financial collapse. Fannie Mae also made a $2.3 billion payment to the Treasury in the second quarter. As of the second quarter, Fannie Mae has drawn $104.8 billion in Treasury aid and paid $14.7 billion in dividends, the company reported. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac together have drawn about $170 billion in taxpayer aid.

headline: Emerging Markets Lift Results at Procter & Gamble
text: The Procter & Gamble Company said Friday that its quarterly profit rose 15 percent as sales gained in emerging markets, and forecast annual revenue that topped some analysts’ estimates. Net income rose to $2.51 billion, or 84 cents a share, from $2.19 billion, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier, P.& G. said. The average estimate of 19 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg was for profit of 82 cents a share. Sales in the period, which ended June 30 and was the fourth quarter of Procter & Gamble’s fiscal year, rose 10 percent to $20.9 billion, exceeding the $20.6 billion forecast by analysts. Wood pulp, resin and other materials cost Procter & Gamble $1 billion more than expected this year and prompted price increases, the chief financial officer, Jon R. Moeller, said on a conference call. Procter & Gamble’s stock rose $1.01, to $60.59 a share.

text: Aug. 5, 2011 - A report by Manny Fernandez from Texas on the Texas Governor's upcoming prayer event and possible presidential run.

headline: Deal to Share Fingerprints Is Dropped, Not Program
text: Federal immigration officials announced Friday that they were terminating the joint agreements with state and local governments that have been at the center of a controversy surrounding a national fingerprint-sharing program, although they said they would continue setting up the program unilaterally.

headline: Army Deployments Will Be Shortened to Nine Months
text: Army deployments to overseas war zones will be reduced to nine months by April, easing stress on a ground combat force that has served for a year and even 15 months at a time in Iraq and Afghanistan. In a statement released Friday, John McHugh, the Army secretary, said some specialized units and individuals with particularly essential skills might still be deployed for a full year.

headline: Shabab Concede Control of Capital to Somalia Government
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Shabab Islamist rebel group abruptly pulled out of the bullet-ridden capital of Somalia on Saturday, leaving the entire city in the hands of the government for the first time in years and raising hopes that aid groups could now deliver aid to more famine victims unfettered.

headline: 2011 Tampa Bay Buccaneers Season Preview
text: We’re entering Year Three of what has been a top-to-bottom youth movement in Tampa Bay. So far, most would agree, it’s going better than planned. The team’s starting quarterback, running back, wide receivers, defensive ends, defensive tackles, middle linebacker and strong safety  enter the season with less than three years of league experience. Yet no eyes rolled when Raheem Morris – who, at 35 on opening day, will still be the youngest head coach in the league – declared this year’s goal to be to win the N.F.C. South.

headline: It’s Time to Go Long on Tomatoes
text: When the gang at Marketplace Money, the public radio show, called yesterday wanting to know what I was doing with my money amid the market meltdown, I suggested going long on a fleeting agricultural commodity: tomatoes.

headline: China Tells U.S. It Must ‘Cure Its Addiction to Debt’
text: SHANGHAI — China, the largest foreign holder of United States debt, said Saturday that Washington needed to “cure its addiction to debts” and “live within its means,” just hours after the rating agency Standard & Poor’s downgraded America’s long-term debt.

headline: Dozens Killed as NATO Helicopter Shot Down in Afghanistan
text: KABUL — Insurgents in eastern Afghanistan have shot down a NATO Chinook helicopter during an overnight operation in eastern Afghanistan, Ray Rivera and Alissa J. Rubin report in The Times. At least 37 people on board were killed, according to a coalition military official on Saturday.

headline: Syria Forces Extend Siege on Hama as Toll Rises

headline: Maine Moments
text: My wife has roots in the tiny Maine lobster port of Winter Harbor, which means I’m fortunate to be able to turn off the wider world for a short while each summer when we visit. On a short walk this week through a patch of beach rose* on the coast, we encountered a solitary cedar waxwing, one of my favorite birds, calling from the top of an eye-high conifer sapling.

headline: Barcelona Heats Up: Notes from the Circus
text: MIAMI — With an attractive style of skillful play and trophies backing up its philosophy of homegrown talent, F.C. Barcelona is the undisputed king of club soccer. With eight members of the World Cup champions Spain in its squad, and all three finalists of the world player of the year trophy, Barcelona will defend its Spanish La Liga and European Champions League title, along with the Club World Cup.

Quarterbacks and receivers must establish timing and rhythm. The whole offense must find its rhythm. Practices must fall into a predictable, up-tempo rhythm.

headline: As N.F.L. Stopped, Leonhard Didn’t
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On March 12, the N.F.L. awoke to grave uncertainty amid its first work stoppage in 22 years. headline: Atomic Bomb Survivors Join Nuclear Opposition

Still, like other survivors of the attacks here and in Hiroshima, he quietly accepted Japan’s postwar embrace of nuclear-generated power, believing government assurances that it was both safe and necessary for the nation’s economic rise.

headline: No Snooki Fatigue For MTV Audience
text: The first episode of “Jersey Shore” to be set far from any shore — in Florence, Italy — attracted 8.8 million viewers on Thursday night, making it the highest-rated season premiere in MTV’s history. The ratings showed that MTV viewers have not yet tired of Nicole Polizzi, a k a Snooki; Mike Sorrentino, a k a the Situation; or the other members of the cast. Their arrival in Florence was the beginning of the fourth season of the series. The third season began in early January with 8.45 million viewers, peaked later in the month with 8.9 million, and leveled off for the rest of the season, averaging 7.9 million for the 13 episodes. The test for “Jersey Shore” this season will be to entice the 8.8 million to keep watching.

headline: Strasburg on the Mend

headline: Twirler With a Curl

Lee has the most shutouts in a season since 2005, when Dontrelle Willis had five for Florida. No pitcher has recorded more shutouts in a season since Randy Johnson had six in 1998, two with Seattle and four with Houston.

That is because it confirmed what the markets, economists and most people already know: the United States has a debt problem and Washington is deeply divided over how to solve it.

headline: For Obama, a Record on Diversity but Delays on Judicial Confirmations
text: President Obama made history when he nominated Sonia Sotomayor, the first Hispanic justice on the Supreme Court. He did it again with his second nominee, Elena Kagan, raising the number of women on the nation’s highest court to three.

headline: A Thriving Growth Area in a Weak Economy: Hair
text: CAPITOL HEIGHTS, Md. — In low-slung suburban strip malls, nestled among fast-food restaurants and auto supply stores, hair salons are sprouting like mushrooms.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,678 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Candidates Give Obama an F for AA+ Rating
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa – The Republican presidential candidates on Saturday seized on the first-ever downgrade of the nation’s credit rating as a new line of criticism against President Obama, suggesting that ultimate responsibility rested in the Oval Office even though the rating agency, Standard & Poor’s, cited the overall political gridlock in Washington as a major cause for its decision.

headline: Picking Locks and Hacking Servers at Defcon
text: LAS VEGAS — They sat at tables along the perimeter of a ballroom in the Rio Hotel. Lights were low. Laptops burned like campfires. Men and women hunched over the machines, their backs curved like question marks. Their fingers clicked away furiously.

headline: A Month of Record Rain, a Number of Close Calls
text: A summer of endless rain, violent storms and plain, mean heat has left the Midwest doing what it is loath to do, especially in this season: whining about the weather. Then there is Roger Bossard, a man known as the Sodfather, whose livelihood depends on every centimeter of precipitation, every ray of sunshine.

headline: Living With Voices
text: Joe Holt, a computer consultant and entrepreneur who has a diagnosis of schizophrenia, describes how he's learned to manage the voices in his head.

headline: Learning to Cope With a Mind’s Taunting Voices
text: LEE’S SUMMIT, Mo. — The job was gone, the gun was loaded, and a voice was saying, “You’re a waste, give up now, do it now.”

headline: Advice for Perry in National Race: Watch Your Right

headline: One Man’s Story of Schizophrenia
text: In the latest installment of the Lives Restored series, about people coping with mental illness, Benedict Carey reports the story of Joe Holt, 50, a computer consultant and entrepreneur who has schizophrenia.

headline: Airstrike Reportedly Kills Civilians in Southern Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A woman and seven young children were killed in southern Afghanistan when a coalition patrol called in an airstrike against insurgents firing on them from a mud compound, Afghan officials said Saturday. NATO said it was investigating the attack.

headline: ‘Crazy Girl’ Takes Eli Young Band to a New Level
text: As the Aug. 16 release of their fourth studio album approaches, life on the road for Texas’ Eli Young Band is predictably routine: long bus rides and early wake-up calls are quickly followed by phone interviews, sound checks, more interviews, dinners with country radio programmers, and meet-and-greets with fans.

headline: Red Sox Batter Yankees’ C. C. Sabathia Again
text: BOSTON — C. C. Sabathia is the Yankees’ undisputed ace, a dominant force on the mound, and one of three pitchers considered the leading candidates for the American League Cy Young Award.

headline: On the Waterfront, a Pedicab Skirmish Erupts
text: On Tuesday afternoon, bicycle taxis lined up near the Ferry Building, waiting to take tourists for an open-air ride along the San Francisco waterfront.

headline: American Steel Studios
text: West Oakland’s post-industrial hinterland is home to many active and abandoned warehouses. A thriving arts community has taken root at one such space, American Steel Studios, a giant open warehouse and a smaller adjoining building used by creative types ranging from trapeze artists to soap makers.

headline: More Violence Reported in London Neighborhoods
text: 3:55 p.m. | Updated More violence rocked parts of of London Sunday night, a day after demonstrators looted shops and set fire to cars and buildings.

headline: A Neighborhood Is Shaken by a Violent Death
text: Last Tuesday, 20-year-old Michael Dawson sat at a computer and watched a young man die. After being shot twice — once by the police — the man, seen on a video, writhed face down in a pool of blood as officers tried to hold back a crowd of outraged bystanders.

headline: Protests Grow in Israel, With 250,000 Marching
text: JERUSALEM — At least 250,000 Israelis took to the streets on Saturday night to demonstrate against the high cost of living and lack of affordable housing, the largest in three weeks of protests aimed at forcing social and economic issues onto the government’s agenda.

headline: TIF Aided Public and Private Projects Almost Evenly, Analysis Shows
text: For years, former Mayor Richard M. Daley heard criticism that City Hall’s use of a particular economic development tool amounted to little more than a slush fund for him to subsidize corporate Chicago at the public’s expense.

text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: A Home Where ‘Strike Up the Band’ Is No Idle Order
text: Saxophonists are collectors; it’s an occupational hazard. They amass boxes of reeds to find one that works perfectly; their closets bulge with the secondary saxes, clarinets and flutes they are expected to play in bands and orchestras.

headline: A 6-Year-Old Finally Flashes His Speed at Saratoga
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The owner Bill Clifton and the trainer James Bond had been here before, in the paddock of one of the most beautiful racetracks in the world, readying a fast horse to run in one of the most important stakes in American racing: the $750,000 Grade I Whitney Invitational Handicap. They had done pretty well too — Will’s Way won in 1997 and Behrens finished second and third in 1999 and 2000.

headline: Battle for Libya | August 6, 2011
text: Rebel forces participate in live-fire exercises as the fighting in Libya continues.

headline: Citing Stalemate, Verizon Workers Strike
text: Two unions representing 45,000 workers at Verizon Communications announced early Sunday that they were calling an immediate strike because of a lack of progress in contract negotiations.

headline: Republican Candidates Converge on Iowa
text: Candidates seek to break from the pack in a debate and a straw poll.

headline: Anger Over Credit Rating Resurfaces in Washington
text: The frustration in the air was palpable. Officials from the credit ratings agency Standard & Poor’s were meeting with Congressional leaders on a stifling late day in late July to discuss the thorniest issue in Washington: the effort to cut the nation’s deficit and raise the borrowing limit to avert a default.

headline: Baseball Warns Players About Deer Antler Spray
text: BOSTON – Curtis Granderson tapped on his cellphone in the Yankees’ clubhouse Saturday after a 10-4 loss to the Boston Red Sox. He had received two text messages from old friends, asking if he knew that deer-antler spray was supposedly a form of human growth hormone.

headline: Amukamara, Giants’ Top Pick, Breaks Foot
text: Just two days after signing a four-year contract with the Giants, cornerback Prince Amukamara, the team’s first round pick in the N.F.L. draft, broke his left foot in practice Saturday night.

headline: Corrections: August 7

headline: U.S. Widens Role in Battle Against Mexican Drug Cartels
text: WASHINGTON — The United States is expanding its role in Mexico’s bloody fight against drug trafficking organizations, sending new C.I.A. operatives and retired military personnel to the country and considering plans to deploy private security contractors in hopes of  turning around a multibillion-dollar effort that so far has shown few results.

headline: For a Night, Mets Feel Comfortable in Their Own Home
text: The Mets have spent many days this summer pondering a frustrating fact of their recent existence: how can their home field be such a maddeningly inhospitable place?

headline: It Was Really No Contest at Two European Events
text: One lesson from the recent Biel Chess Festival in Switzerland and the Sparkassen Chess-Meeting in Germany is that the gap in skills between the world’s best players and those in the second tier is sometimes too big to overcome.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Vanishing Spray and the Future of Technology
text: Copa América, which was played in Argentina last month, marked the debut of the vanishing spray in an international tournament for national teams. This technological innovation consists of a can with white spray that allows referees to mark the place where the ball ,as well as the defensive wall,should be located on free kicks. Said marks vanish rapidly, leaving no trace on the field. In addition, the application of the vanishing spray is as easy as is its transportation.

headline: The Pageant Winner, Louisville, Ky.
text: Jewel Daily:  I’m from Montevallo, Ala., and I don’t mind telling you I’m 78. From a very young age I knew education was important, so in 1956 I received a Bachelor of Science degree from Alabama A&M College, which was one of the colleges that we were allowed to attend. The South was still segregated when I was growing up, but I didn’t really think too much about that. I have two daughters — one is a school principal, and the other is a reading specialist. My husband died in 2003.

headline: Riots in North London
text: Clusters of young men hurled bricks and aimed fireworks at riot police officers before a backdrop of burning cars and buildings.

headline: Syrian Military Mounts Assault on Another City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian military defied growing condemnation and initiated another assault on the country’s most restive locales on Sunday, deploying dozens of tanks and armored vehicles into parts of a city in eastern Syria that it had long feared provoking, activists and residents said. Dozens were killed, they said, and thousands had fled the city.

headline: 2011 New Orleans Saints Season Preview
text: Perhaps no higher compliment was paid to this organization than the collective silence that ensued after the Saints traded a 2012 first-round pick and a 2011 second-rounder to move up and draft Alabama running back Mark Ingram 28th over all. This was a move that seemed to make little sense. The Saints already had two good runners in Pierre Thomas and Chris Ivory. The former had just signed a four-year, $12 million contract and the latter was an undrafted second-year pro with a sub-$500,000 salary each of the next two years.

headline: In Paris, Classical Music in a Pastoral Setting
text: Parc Floral de Paris, a pastoral spot in the 12th Arrondissement, will host world-class classical musicians during this year’s Classique au Vert festival, held weekends from Aug. 6 to Sept. 25.

text: Oh, my. Treasury has a fact sheet explaining that $2 trillion error by S&P; it may sound technical, but to anyone who follows budget issues, it’s a doozy.

headline: Hugh Carey, Who Led Fiscal Rescue of New York City, Is Dead at 92
text: Hugh L. Carey, the governor who helped rescue New York from the brink of financial collapse in the 1970s and tamed a culture of ever-growing spending, died Sunday at his summer home on Shelter Island, N.Y. He was 92.

headline: Global Finance Leaders Pledge Bold Action to Calm Markets
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank signaled on Sunday that it would intervene more aggressively in bond markets to protect Spain and Italy, and leading finance ministers conferred about the mounting threats to the world’s economies, as policy makers sought to calm markets unnerved by deteriorating public finances and slow economic growth.

headline: Music to Know Festival Is Canceled
text: In the end, it was not the opposition of East Hampton, N.Y., locals worried about a Woodstock in their quiet seaside enclave but lackluster ticket sales that doomed the Music to Know Festival on Long Island next weekend.

text: WASHINGTON – Representatives of the Republican and Democratic parties went on television on Sunday morning to blame the other side for Standard & Poor’s unprecedented decision to downgrade the credit rating of the United States – a decision that was based largely on a lack of faith in the ability of the political system to forge agreements to reduce the debt.

text: BALTIMORE — Even now, 162 years after his death here, Edgar Allan Poe still seems to be suffering from the kind of bad luck that haunted his life.

headline: Stuck in the Muddle
text: You won’t be surprised to hear that I am very much in sympathy with Drew Westen’s lament about Obama’s unwillingness or inability to change the narrative. I went back to look at my own reactions to the inaugural speech; I’m sorry to say that my misgivings at the time have proved all too justified.

headline: High Hopes on a Dreary Day at the Newport Jazz Festival
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — The Newport Jazz Festival released its attendance figures for Saturday: 7,500. (The capacity is 10,000, and there will be fewer people on Sunday because it is raining.) I think I also neglected to mention that its main sponsors this year are the Boston-based Natixis Global Asset Management and Alex and Ani, the Rhode Island-based jewelry-maker whose mission statement tells us that “Alex and Ani’s artistry lies in drawing out the beauty that resides within.”

headline: Last Season for ‘Desperate Housewives’ on ABC
text: Paul Lee, the president of entertainment for ABC, confirmed at a news conference on Sunday that this would be the last season of that network’s longtime comedy-drama hit “Desperate Housewives.” Mr. Lee called it an “iconic show” that “put the network on the map.” He added that the network, in conjunction with the show’s creator, Marc Cherry, had decided to make the call before the season started to make sure the show “would have a victory lap.”Mr. Lee cited the success that ABC had had in making an early announcement that it would end its other hit drama that started around the same time, “Lost.”

headline: Red Bulls Debacle
text: The Red Bulls look like a team waiting around for something, anything, to happen.

headline: ‘Rise of the Planet of the Apes’ Leads at the Box Office
text: Computer-generated primates, yes. Extreme scatological humor? No. That sums up Hollywood’s weekend, as “Rise of the Planet of the Apes” took in about $54 million at North American theaters and “The Change-Up,” an ultra-crude comedy (it opens with a baby defecating in Jason Bateman’s mouth), landed with a $13.5 million thud.

headline: Lollapalooza Brand Is Heading to Brazil
text: Having successfully extended the Lollapalooza franchise to Chile this year, the founder of the influential alternative rock festival in Chicago has announced that he will start a second sister festival in Brazil next spring. The event, Lollapalooza Brazil, will be held April 7-8 at the Jockey Club de São Paulo, a large horse-racing track in one of Latin America’s largest cities, festival officials said.

headline: The Curtain Comes Down on ‘Rent’
text: The landmark musical, written by Jonathan Larson, ended its Broadway run after 12 years.

headline: Downsizing ‘Rent’ for a New Run
text: Gone is the two-tone scarf, the crewneck sweater, the eyeglasses: the signature costume for Mark Cohen, a lead character in the musical “Rent.” During the show’s 12 years on Broadway that character’s look was so familiar it inspired many Halloween costumes in New York. Now, in the new Off Broadway revival of “Rent,” Mark’s stylings are a cap atop his curly mop of hair (it’s still cold in the East Village) and a plaid shirt (referencing colors in his first overcoat).

headline: Giants’ Amukamara Faces Aftermath of Injury
text: Prince Amukamara had never broken a bone in his body until Saturday night. And he is not exactly sure how it happened.

headline: Yemeni President, Hurt in Bombing, Leaves Saudi Hospital
text: Yemen’s embattled and wounded president has been discharged from the hospital where he was being treated in Saudi Arabia and has moved into a government residence there, Yemen’s official SABA news agency reported Sunday.

headline: Friends in Seals Unit Are City’s Double Loss
text: WASHINGTON — They came from the same town, Shreveport, La. They were high school friends. Both men, Robert James Reeves and Jonas Kelsall, had overcome extreme tests and rigorous training to serve on the same elite Seal team. Both were assigned the same mission, and put in the same helicopter, only to perish together.

headline: Reyes Leaves Game With Stiff Hamstring
text: 5:52 p.m. | Updated The air was momentarily sucked from Citi Field Sunday afternoon when Willie Harris emerged from the Mets dugout in the bottom of the second inning to pinch-hit for Jose Reyes. An inning later, the Mets announced that Reyes was feeling stiffness in his left hamstring — yes, the same hamstring that landed him on the disabled list in July. Indeed, in the first inning, he had appeared to pull up gingerly while running out a soft ground ball to Braves’ third baseman Martin Prado. He played the field the next half-inning and appeared fine on the one ball hit to him, but did not return to bat in the second. Details will be updated here.

text: Hours before headlining her first show in Central Park, Swedish singer-songwriter Lykke Li meets up with Melena Ryzik in the tiny music shop where she started her career.

text: When assessing the downgrade, the question of track record comes up. As I understand it, countries that defaulted in the past were almost always downgraded well before the default happened; but in all such cases, the markets were already signalling big trouble before the rating agencies moved.
