headline: ‘Streetcar’ Casting News
text: Following in the footsteps of Vivien Leigh, Cate Blanchett and Marge Simpson, Nicole Ari Parker (“Soul Food”) has landed the role of Blanche DuBois in the coming Broadway production of Tennessee Williams’s classic drama “A Streetcar Named Desire,” the producers announced Sunday. It will be Ms. Parker’s Broadway debut; she previously performed in Off Broadway productions of “Chicago,” “House of Lear” and “Romeo and Juliet.” A graduate of the Tisch School for the Performing Arts, Ms. Parker described the news as “a childhood dream come true.” She added: “Blanche is the role of a lifetime. When I heard, I spun around in my kitchen like Diana Ross in ‘The Wiz.’ ” The production, which will feature a cast representative of the play’s New Orleans setting, is to open in the spring under the direction of Emily Mann (“Anna in the Tropics,” “Having Our Say”) and starring Blair Underwood (“The Event”). Mr. Underwood will also be making his Broadway debut, as Stanley Kowalski.

headline: Footnote
text: The Television Critics Association named “Friday Night Lights” its program of the year on Saturday night. Jon Hamm was named best actor in a drama for his role in “Mad Men,” which received the top drama award for a third year.

headline: London Sees Twin Perils Converging to Fuel Riot
text: LONDON — As London surveyed the damage on Sunday after a small anti-police demonstration spiraled into looting and violence that left 26 police officers injured and led to more than 160 arrests, many sought to cast the blame beyond the rioters themselves.

headline: A Self-Fulfilling Euro Crisis? (Wonkish)
text: There will probably be big action in the euro zone tomorrow; so, some quick analytical notes.

headline: Education Needs a Digital-Age Upgrade
text: If you have a child entering grade school this fall, file away just one number with all those back-to-school forms: 65 percent.

headline: Chekhov’s Slugfest, With Pratfalls
text: WASHINGTON — What blissfully irritating people they are. Cranks, I believe, is the word that keeps coming up to describe them. Under most circumstances I’d run a country mile to avoid being trapped in a room with the desperate characters now inhabiting the Sydney Theater Company’s production of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya” at the Kennedy Center here. Yet I consider the three hours I spent on Saturday night watching them complain about how bored they are among the happiest of my theatergoing life.

headline: A Family Reunited After a Rare Return From Deportation
text: A Polish woman will step off an airplane in Chicago on Monday afternoon with a legal visa in her hand, coming back to live in the United States four years after her deportation sundered her family, in a rare case of the return of an immigrant who was expelled.

headline: At Newport, Rain Rules the Day
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — Since the beginning of the Newport Jazz Festival on Sunday it has been raining, sometimes hard and loud and overwhelming, sometimes a thick harborside mist. The main stage, where there is no tent for the audience, has it the hardest. Maybe 150 hardy people are out there right now watching James Farm, the co-operative quartet with the saxophonist Joshua Redman, the pianist Aaron Parks, the bassist Matt Penman and the drummer Eric Harland. They’re playing way back from the lip of the stage to avoid getting wet, huddling closer than they would at a small club. They’re sounding good–strolling, right now, through a minor ballad.Hiromi is back for round two on a smaller stage with her trio, wowing them with amiable virtuosity. Earlier, John Hollenbeck’s 19-piece big band– including bass saxophone, vibraphone and two singers– played a great set, including songs by Ornette Coleman, Jimmy Webb and Imogen Heap and a version of the traditional “I’m a Man of Constant Sorrow,” with a solo by the tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby that came in chapters, getting destabilized and righting itself, using a few notes of the melody or, or of Hollenbeck’s strong arrangement, to start a new section. It takes at least a half-hour to start to understand this band’s range, from sci-fi to pastoral, loopy to dead serious. It’s come a long way over the last 10 years.

headline: Celebrating a Twisted, Elegant Versifier
text: Dan Zanes started “Shelebration!,” a concert tribute to Shel Silverstein on Saturday night at SummerStage, with “You’re Always Welcome at Our House.” It’s a smiley, bouncy song that could be a children’s ditty except that it’s about serial murder, with a new victim in each verse. It was a canny choice that pulled together some of the many strands of Silverstein’s career.

headline: An Exuberant Conductor and a Starry Violinist
text: It seems entirely likely that many in the large, enthusiastic audience that turned out for a performance by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night were drawn there by the starry soloist, Joshua Bell. A consistently excellent and broadly appealing violinist, Mr. Bell is one of the few reliable marquee names in classical music today.

headline: Like Ross, Rachel and Company, but With Faster Hook-Ups
text: Some television shows get buried. “Friends With Benefits” was shot in the back of the head, driven to the Meadowlands and dumped in a ditch.

headline: All Nooks, Crannies, Bedrooms and Trees Are Backdrops for Art
text: BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y. — Forgive the title, a shameless ploy for attention. “The 2011 Bridgehampton Biennial” is not actually a biennial; it’s just the second installment of an annual summer group show done under the auspices of a commercial gallery in a private home. But it’s a highly entertaining one, with a refreshingly casual attitude.

headline: In a Match of Quick Decisions, Deciding to Falsecard Early
text: If you find the regular pace of bridge play, 15 minutes for two deals, too slow, turn to fast pairs. Then you receive only 11 minutes and are speedily fined for finishing a round late.

headline: Monday: Terse Four-Star Review
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s a sailor’s life in Ian Livengood’s puzzle. From the outset we are asked to help him figure out where to find the endings of the theme entries, which are slangy terms for those who sail the HIGH SEAS.

headline: Geithner Will Stay for Now, the Treasury Department Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, has told President Obama that he will remain in his position for the time being, the department announced on Sunday, ending speculation that he might step down soon.

headline: Target Evokes a Touch of La Dolce Vita
text: CINEPHILES familiar with the Italian films of the 1960s will recall images of fashionably dressed women and men whirling by sidewalk cafes in tiny Fiats, racing along narrow cobblestone streets. Those vignettes are the inspiration for a new ad campaign highlighting the latest high fashion brand to market its line for a limited run at Target.

headline: Second Recession in U.S. Could Be Worse Than First
text: If the economy falls back into recession, as many economists are now warning, the bloodletting could be a lot more painful than the last time around.

text: From its 1,200-square-foot space overlooking 34th Street in Manhattan, Spy Shops offers customized surveillance installations with five-figure price tags for foreign princes, chart-topping rappers, business tycoons and paranoid husbands.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers on Lauren Ambrose, and Booing at the Theater
text: ArtsBeat was abuzz last week with two theater-related posts that sharply divided many readers. First, the decision to cast Lauren Ambrose (“Six Feet Under”) as Fanny Brice in the coming revival of “Funny Girl” had many people wondering if she has what it takes to step into the shoes of a character made famous by Barbra Streisand. Second, readers debated the etiquette and appropriateness of booing at the theater — the way they do at the opera — in response to a guest Talkback post. Following is a roundup of readers’ comments on these topics from ArtsBeat, Twitter and Facebook.

headline: Titans Grapple With Governance
text: Sumner Redstone should enjoy watching Rupert Murdoch squirm. There’s no love lost between Mr. Redstone, the 88-year-old chairman of Viacom and CBS, and Mr. Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation. Last year, Mr. Redstone even presciently ridiculed his competitor’s fondness for newspapers. But as Mr. Murdoch grapples with the misdeeds of one of his British tabloids, Mr. Redstone can delight only so much. He has his own costly governance problems, too.

headline: News Corp.’s Soft Power in the U.S.

text: For Long Island lobstermen, the good old days ended in 1999 when a great die-off in Long Island Sound rocked the local industry and stumped researchers.

text: Levi’s is adding a hue to its marketing efforts: Facebook blue. The purveyor of all things denim has teamed up with the social media giant on the next phase of its “Go Forth” campaign.

headline: Waiting Hours to See the McQueen Exhibit, in a Line Not Unlike a Runway
text: Even after midnight on a rainy Saturday, they waited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art: a line of about 1,500 people snaking through the Medieval Hall, past the Japanese ceramics and Mesopotamian artifacts displayed along the Great Hall balcony, past centuries of sculptures, paintings and other objects before they finally arrived, giddy from an hours-long wait.

text: To no one’s surprise, Maya Moore is having a standout rookie season in the W.N.B.A.

headline: On Idyllic Cape Cod, Growing Drug Problem Fuels a Rise in Property Crimes
text: DENNIS, Mass. — In late April, Mildred Duda, 77, woke up in the middle of the night to find three masked men in her bedroom, rifling through her possessions. The police believe that the men had information about when Ms. Duda refilled her prescription for what they wanted: narcotic painkillers.

headline: Where Monday Is Caddie Day
text: For decades, country clubs across America have closed on Mondays, largely for maintenance work. At Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y., that means the caddies are allowed to play the holes they walk all week.

headline: Ad Money Reliably Goes to Television
text: The economy is faltering and consumers are scared, but you wouldn’t know it by watching television, where advertisers are still pouring in money.

headline: The Last of the Lobstermen, Chasing a Vanishing Treasure
text: No matter his age, a Long Island lobsterman, thinking back to the good old days, will always describe the same years. That would be pretty much any of them before 1999.

headline: Rioting in Tottenham
text: A small anti-police demonstration in a north London neighborhood spiraled into looting and violent clashes that left 26 police officers injured and led to 55 arrests.

headline: Medical Journal Wins Business Reporting Honor
text: Most media organizations hunger for recognition for their work. But on Friday, a different kind of publication received an award for its coverage: a medical journal.

headline: Reviving a 79-Year-Old Barbarian
text: Back in 2001, Conan the Barbarian, the character that helped make Arnold Schwarzenegger a star, was tripping on his sword.

headline: With Prospect of U.S. Slowdown, Europe Fears a Worsening Debt Crisis
text: PARIS — European political leaders have garnered much of the blame for the continuing crisis of the euro, consistently failing to act with enough speed or severity to calm the markets. But the current panic has been partly produced by American politicians, whose noisy squabbling over the debt ceiling has combined with the prospect of another United States recession to undermine the potential for global growth.

headline: Death During Swim Renews Questions About Event’s Safety
text: A 64-year-old man died after having a heart attack during the swimming leg of Sunday’s New York City Triathlon, race officials said. A 40-year-old woman also had a heart attack during the 1,500-meter swim, according the New York Fire Department. She was in critical condition at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

headline: On Long Island, Disappearing Lobsters
text: Last fall, on a visit to his nearby Long Island fish shop, the New York Times staff photographer Barton Silverman placed an order for some lobster.

headline: Swallowed by a Shift
text: Mark Teixeira was sitting at his locker at Yankee Stadium late last month, trying to put into words how his season has gone at the plate.

headline: Where Cubans Can Meet the Beatles at Last
text: HAVANA — The hair and accents were wrong, but the audience cared about just one thing: the house band was singing the Beatles, here, in a new bar called the Yellow Submarine, in Cuba, where such an act might have led to arrests in the mid-1960s.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include second-quarter productivity (Tuesday); wholesale trade for June (Wednesday); the trade deficit for June and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and retail sales for July, the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for August, and business inventories for June (Friday).

headline: Treasury Auctions for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: In Sentencing, Just What Did the Judge Say: 3 Years, or 2?
text: Jerry Herrington spent about a year trying to convince anyone who would listen that the court system had made a terrible mistake: even though court records had him down for a three-year sentence, he was sure that the judge in Manhattan had given him only two years.

headline: S.&P. Downgrade Is Seen as Adding Urgency to Debt-Cutting Panel
text: WASHINGTON — The downgrade of the United States government’s credit rating by Standard & Poor’s is almost sure to increase pressure on a new Congressional “supercommittee” to mute ideological disagreements and recommend a package of deficit-reduction measures far exceeding its original goal of at least $1.5 trillion, lawmakers said Sunday.

headline: Athletes With a Rope to Hold, and Water to Stand On
text: SCOTIA, N.Y. — It was almost showtime along the banks of the Mohawk River. Young women in grass skirts and hot pink spandex braided one another’s hair. Men cinched black hats beneath their chins. The show’s director implored: “Big smiles!”

headline: For Scott and Caddie, a Victory to Savor
text: AKRON, Ohio — It happens in all sorts of ways, in business, politics and sports. A top guy fires a loyal lieutenant only to have the lieutenant come back to haunt the hallways, or, in the case at hand, the fairways.

headline: Racing Along, and Above, the Mohawk River
text: The United States Water Ski Show Team wows the crowd with an annual summer show on a river near Albany.

headline: Don’t Gut the S.E.C.
text: SOME of our Congressional leaders, especially in the Republican Party, seem to want the federal government to cease operations. After all, their brinkmanship over the raising of the debt ceiling suggests that they don’t really care whether anything ever gets done in Washington.

headline: Across Globe, Traders Brace for a Downturn
text: Traders and bankers are braced for another volatile week in global markets — and the wildest ride is likely to be in stocks, not the Treasury bonds that were downgraded by Standard & Poor’s on Friday.

headline: For Now, Posada Seems Out as Designated Hitter
text: BOSTON — Something about nationally televised night games against the Red Sox seems to evoke lineup issues surrounding Jorge Posada. On May 14, a Saturday night, Posada asked out of the starting lineup when he was written in to bat ninth by Yankees Manager Joe Girardi.

headline: Credibility, Chutzpah and Debt
text: To understand the furor over the decision by Standard & Poor’s, the rating agency, to downgrade U.S. government debt, you have to hold in your mind two seemingly (but not actually) contradictory ideas. The first is that America is indeed no longer the stable, reliable country it once was. The second is that S.& P. itself has even lower credibility; it’s the last place anyone should turn for judgments about our nation’s prospects.

headline: Waiting for a Landslide
text: In 1955, a political scientist named V. O. Key published an essay entitled “A Theory of Critical Elections.” He argued that realignments in American politics are usually punctuated by transformative elections, in which the old order suddenly gives way and a new majority emerges in its place.

headline: Palestinians and the U.N.
text: In little more than a month, the Palestinians are expected to ask the United Nations to recognize their state. We have sympathy for their yearning and their frustration. For years, they have been promised a negotiated solution — President Obama called for a peace deal by September — and they are still empty-handed. But the consequences could be profoundly damaging for all involved.

headline: Huntsman Runs on His Name, and His Father’s
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Jon M. Huntsman Jr. was 10 years old when his father packed up their growing family to move east in 1970, leaving behind his fledgling company to work for President Richard M. Nixon.

headline: How Congress Devastated Congo

headline: Escape to New York Festival Cancels Last Day
text: The final day of the Escape to New York music festival on Long Island was cancelled Sunday after overnight rains drenched the Shinnecock Indians meeting grounds where the main stage was erected, creating hazardous conditions, the organizers announced.

headline: Every Mistake Has a Caddie Who’s Seen It
text: SCARBOROUGH, N.Y. — Teaching professionals and well-traveled players see all kinds of golf swings, good and bad. But perhaps no one bears witness to more golfers’ mistakes than caddies at private clubs.

headline: Here’s an Easy $100 Billion Cut
text: If the Republicans are truly determined to slash the budget and end government waste, they will start with two obvious and long overdue cuts: ending the web of tax breaks enjoyed by the rolling-in-dough oil industry and terminating the ethanol subsidy. Together these cuts would save up to $100 billion over 10 years, without hurting the poor and middle class or slowing the economy.

headline: Ohio and the Death Penalty
text: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio postponed for a month the state’s next execution. The decision is an admission that Ohio’s management of the death penalty is broken and further proof that the machinery of death cannot be operated responsibly anywhere.

headline: When August Was Cold and Dark
text: A century ago this month, three wind-battered, frozen men quietly stepped into a hut on Cape Evans in the shadow of Antarctica’s Mount Erebus. They were Edward Wilson, Henry Bowers and Apsley Cherry-Garrard. Their sledge contained a precious cargo: three emperor penguin eggs, the first ever collected. To obtain them, these men — part of Robert Scott’s polar expedition — had walked 60 miles to Cape Crozier and back again, dragging a heavy sledge over impossible terrain in the Antarctic winter’s nearly complete darkness, howling winds and temperatures as low as 77 below zero.

headline: Sharp Rift in a Strike at Verizon
text: The decision by 45,000 workers at Verizon Communications businesses to go on strike Sunday over proposed benefit cuts reflects sharp battle lines. On one side is a highly profitable telecommunications company that is eager to trim costs in its declining businesses; on the other are unionized workers who fear that the many concessions demanded by their employer will force them to give up decades of hard-won gains.

After her students realize that the school year has begun and their grumbling subsides, she will ask the children, “Where did I go to college?” and “What are my interests?”

text: One month after Atlanta was rocked by revelations of a widespread school cheating scandal, teachers are bracing for difficult questions from students this year.

headline: Jane White, Actress and Singer Who Found Racial Attitudes to Be an Obstacle, Dies at 88
text: Jane White, an actress who made her reputation in the 1960s and ’70s in Shakespearean and classical Greek drama in New York but who felt hampered by the racial attitudes of casting directors toward light-skinned black performers like herself, died on July 24 at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 88.

text: Mark O. Hatfield, a liberal Republican who challenged his party’s positions on the Vietnam War and on a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution during his 30 years as a senator from Oregon, died on Sunday in Portland, Ore. He was 89.

headline: The Government’s Calling About a Table. Should I Take the Call?
text: The end of summer brings a surge in calls from government clients, mostly from the military, looking to spend remaining dollars in their budgets before the fiscal year ends on Oct. 1. This year is no exception. The surge has started and is most likely to peak at the end of August. Just last week we got calls from the State Department, the Army and the Marines. The person on the phone is generally a low-level officer, responding to a request from a superior for pricing on a large and fancy table. Our bid will be presented to the upper ranks as one of a number of ways to spend their remaining money. Consequently, we sell a much lower percentage of these inquiries than those from private clients. But August is usually a slower month for private business, so we take the time to write proposals anyway.

According to the event’s organizers, teens aren’t getting enough guidance when it comes to the etiquette of breaking up. What do you think about that? How have Facebook, other social media sites and texting played a role in breakups you have experienced or witnessed?

headline: Constructing a Portrait of Pakistan Through the Stories of Its People

By cultural capital, residents generally refer to the fading Mughal monuments and, to a lesser extent, the lively contemporary art scene at the National College of Arts.

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Fregola With Corn
text: Fregola are tiny, toothsome balls of pasta that marry happily with fresh corn, peas or asparagus. “Just keep everything small,” said Lee McGrath, the executive chef at Po in Manhattan. The end result is “kind of like macaroni and cheese,” he said. The pasta is cooked. The vegetables, along with scallions, simmer in a lively fashion for a few minutes, and everything is tossed together with a handful of Parmigiano-Reggiano.

headline: Rio and Mitsubishi Bid $1.6 Billion for Coal & Allied
text: Rio Tinto said on Monday that it was making a joint bid with the Mitsubishi Corporation for all the shares in the Australian mining company Coal & Allied they don’t already own for about $1.6 billion.

headline: Saudi Arabia Ramps Up Pressure on Syria
text: Syria came under new pressure on Monday from a widening clamor of criticism by Gulf Arab states over its brutal crackdown on a five-month-old antigovernment uprising, with Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Bahrain recalling their ambassadors and issuing statements calling on President Bashar al-Assad to change his ways.

headline: Monday Reading: Beat the High Cost of Dialing Abroad

headline: Morning Buzz
text: For more local news from The Times, including the story of a man who may have been wrongly held in prison for a year past his sentence, the scene at the line on the final Saturday of the popular Alexander McQueen exhibit at the Met, and how independent Brooklyn record stores are critical of a new Jay-Z distribution deal, see the N.Y./Region section.

headline: 2011 Dallas Cowboys Season Preview
text: The Dallas Cowboys got to their typical late-season meltdown much faster than usual last year. By the second week of November they were 1-7 and handing Coach Wade Phillips his walking papers. Though there were questionable tactical measures, the losing was primarily a consequence of sloppy execution. Many players simply lost their focus.

headline: The Red Shoes Are Coming
text: In trying to marry the prissiness of the Victorians with the sexual revolution of the 1960s, Tabitha Simmons has come out with an English heritage collection that is a hybrid hoot. “Like rockabilly shoes,” the English designer says of her inspirations, “but — more gothic.” The 49 styles are indeed evocative of the British Isles, with a smattering of high-heel brogues, evening sandals with chandelier trim and suede boots that look like they stepped out of “Bedknobs and Broomsticks.” Compared to previous collections, it is slightly more macabre, yet Simmons, now in her fifth season, continues to demonstrate an ability to imbue classic styles with a modern twist. For example, the Edna heel, a reimagined stiletto loafer, “is beetle-crusher when it’s in black and white,” she says, “and then we did a red and leopard version that has an element of Victoriana.” She’s certainly got a bead on the new monarchy. A pair of nude silk slippers looks fit for a duchess or a Park Avenue princess.

text: Commercial lender CIT Group has named Nelson J. Chai as its president, the firm announced on Monday. Mr. Chai, who formerly served as chief administrative officer and head of strategy, will keep his current responsibilities and lead the firm’s corporate finance and vendor finance businesses.

headline: ‘Gay Synagogue’ Finds a Home, Full of Ancient Assyrians
text: When King Pekah ruled the northern kingdom of Israel, the Assyrians invaded, occupied its cities and took its people “captive to Assyria.” (2 Kings 15:29.) Adding insult to grievous injury, the Assyrians later demanded of Hezekiah, ruler of the southern kingdom of Judah, a payment so large that he had to “cut off the gold from the doors” and doorposts of the first temple in Jerusalem. (2 Kings 18:16.)

headline: Postcard From Edinburgh: Spirits of Fringe Festivalgoers Remain Undampened
text: EDINBURGH — Was there some sort of biblical event this weekend? The Escape to New York music festival on Long Island canceled a slate of concerts on Sunday due to rain, and in Newport, R.I., rain pelted musicians and concertgoers at the Newport Jazz Festival. Here, too, it was awfully drizzly, making the opening weekend of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe a soggy one. Two days of relentless rain seemed to have little impact on the crowds though. All over town audience members huddled in line under umbrellas as they waited to enter some of the more than 250 locations playing host to festival performances.

headline: 10 Questions for Geithner

headline: Judge Keeps Ukraine Opposition Leader Jailed, Sparking Protest and Petitions

headline: McQueen: The Final Count

headline: Top Sun | Michael Bastian + Randolph Engineering
text: Randolph Engineering, purveyor of high-performance sunglasses, is getting a fashion boost from the 2011 CFDA Menswear Designer of the Year, Michael Bastian. Turning his prep-American flair on the United States military and air force’s longtime supplier of sunglasses by framing classic aviators in primary colors, Bastian says, “I’ve always loved what Randolph Engineering does. They’re pretty much the perfect, masculine sunglasses.” Available at Barneys New York and other select stores, the Michael Bastian for RE Signature Series sunglasses come in five different frame designs, all of which are variations of current and vintage models.

headline: By Helping a Girl Testify at a Rape Trial, a Dog Ignites a Legal Debate
text: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — Rosie, the first judicially approved courtroom dog in New York, was in the witness box here nuzzling a 15-year-old girl who was testifying that her father had raped and impregnated her. Rosie sat by the teenager’s feet. At particularly bad moments, she leaned in.

headline: Selena Gomez and Taylor Swift Are Teens’ Choices
text: Selena Gomez’s five wins at the Teen Choice Awards mean that she won one more than her boyfriend, Justin Bieber. The group was given the Choice single trophy for “Who Says” and the Choice award for love song for “Love You Like a Love Song,” which the 19-year-old Ms. Gomez performed at the Sunday ceremony.

headline: Weight Loss Improves Sex for Diabetic Men
text: Losing just a small amount of weight can improve the sex lives of men with diabetes, new research shows.

headline: Britain Urges Zimbabwe to Examine Diamond ‘Torture Camp’ Report
text: LONDON — Britain has urged the authorities in Zimbabwe to investigate a BBC report that its security forces are beating and raping prisoners at two camps in the Marange diamond fields in the east of the country. International monitors voted to allow exports from the fields to resume in June despite objections from the United States, Canada and the European Union.

headline: How Hated? Kanye West Likens Himself to Hitler
text: Kanye West, the multiplatinum-selling rapper, took his notorious self-pity and feelings of persecution to a new level during an onstage rant in England when he said he sometimes feels as hated as Adolf Hitler.

headline: After World Cup Thrills, Players Return to Unstable Women’s League
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Three weeks after losing in the final of the Women’s World Cup, the players on the United States national team have returned to their professional soccer league. They have been welcomed home as if they were champions, handed roses and plaques calling them “extraordinary heroes,” an embrace that they appreciate and find somewhat baffling.

headline: Match.com
text: It started when my very Parisian friend, staying at my New York apartment, hand-washed her lingerie and neatly hung the coordinating pairs along the shower rod. Bras and panties in tandem styles: frilly florals by Only Hearts, nude sheers from Eres and a hot pink number that could have only been from Agent Provocateur. So French, so chic. I squirmed in my mismatched red cotton briefs and orange satin bra. Why had it never dawned on me to match? “I only started buying sets when I got married,” says the author and Vogue contributing editor Plum Sykes, remembering a pistachio and cream lace combo she fell in love with on the Rue des Saints-Pères in Paris. “Young women today seem to be more aware of the trend for beautiful matching lingerie,” says Cynthia Gabay, Myla’s creative director. “Your underpinnings say as much about you as a person as your choice in clothing or accessories.” My early-20-something self now officially desires grown-up glamour — and one trip to Bergdorf’s later, taps and teddies are joined at the hip.

headline: It’s a Growth Scare
text: FTalphaville has been saying this all day, and it’s right. The action in the markets looks nothing like worries about US solvency; it looks exactly like what you expect to see when markets suddenly realize that the economy’s growth prospects look terrible.

headline: Never Too Old for Plastic Surgery
text: If you think you’re too old for a few nips and tucks, consider the story of 83-year-old Marie Kolstad.

headline: Stop! You’re Killing Me!
text: I hear on the grapevine that some people are shocked, shocked I tell you, that I compared S&P to a murderer. Um, no. That’s the funniest thing I’ve heard since Niall Ferguson accused me, somewhere or other, of dismissing confidence as a “mere fairy”.

headline: Traveling by Bike, Practically Speaking
text: SANDPOINT, Idaho — To judge from reader comments on this blog, tweets from those who are following me, e-mails to my New York Times address and inquiries from people I’ve been meeting along the way, the practical aspects of a cross-country bike trip are of real interest. People want solid facts. Not just where did you start and where are you going, but what’s your route, how many hours a day do you ride and when do you think you’ll be finished? How do you do your laundry, how many flat tires have you had, what sort of GPS are you carrying? Then there’s one I’ve been asked three or four times recently: What’s your favorite thing about the trip so far?

headline: McQueen Show Builds Met Membership
text: When all was said and done at the close of “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” on Sunday night, the final attendance count reached 661,509 visitors since the show opened on May 4, making it the eighth biggest show on record at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (Of course, some of us saw it five or six times, so that helped.)

headline: After Bad Luck Leaves, Miss Africa New York Emerges
text: “Bad luck has been following us today!” said Munah Manneh, one of the main organizers of the Miss Africa New York pageant, which was held Friday in St. Paul’s Elementary School on Staten Island.

headline: City Students Improve Slightly on Statewide Tests
text: City students posted modest gains on elementary and middle school statewide tests this year, showing more improvement than students in the state as a whole and in New York State’s other large cities, officials said Monday.

headline: Romney Is Back, With S.&P. Ratings on the Brain
text: CONCORD, N.H. — On his first day back on the campaign trail, Mitt Romney wasted no time in blaming President Obama for America’s recent credit downgrade.

headline: 3 Arab Countries Recall Ambassadors to Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Kuwait recalled their ambassadors from Damascus on Monday, joining a chorus of global criticism of Syria, as Syrian forces pressed ahead with President Bashar al-Assad’s brutal crackdown on the most restive areas.

headline: Private Messaging Network Is Said to Link London Rioters
text: The authorities in London arrested scores of people late Sunday and early Monday in hopes of heading off further violence after this weekend’s street riots, as evidence emerged suggesting that the unrest had been organized, at least in part, over private online messaging networks.

headline: Bernadine P. Healy, a Pioneer at National Institutes of Health, Dies at 67
text: Dr. Bernadine P. Healy, the first woman to lead the National Institutes of Health and the first physician to lead the American Red Cross until she was forced out in a storm of criticism over flawed responses to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, died on Saturday at her home in Gates Mills, Ohio. She was 67.

headline: The Caucus Click: Candidates and Reporters Make Iowa Push
text: Hundreds of members of the media will join the Republican presidential candidates in Iowa this week.

headline: David Bohrman Named President of Current TV
text: Signaling that it wants to compete directly with Fox News, MSNBC and CNN, Current TV on Monday hired a prominent CNN executive, David Bohrman, and put him in charge of all programming and production.

headline: Your Neglected Stock Market Backup Plan
text: The recent market decline, and the media (over)reaction that followed, reminded me that we still have not learned a very simple lesson: the time to prepare for a “crisis” is long before you find yourself in one. It’s not a good idea to figure out how a parachute works after you jump out of the plane.

headline: Bank of America Shares Fall to Lowest Point in 2 Years
text: 10:34 p.m. | Updated 8:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Announces 2012 Dates
text: The Tribeca Film Festival said on Monday that its 11th annual festival would be held April 18 – 29 in Manhattan. The festival has asked for submissions for narrative and documentary features as well as for short film entries. The Tribeca Film Institute, the year-round nonprofit arts organization, said it would take submissions starting on Monday for its Tribeca All Access program, TFI Documentary Fund, Latin America Media Arts Fund and the TFI Sloan Filmmaker Fund. Starting Sept. 19, submission forms and information regarding eligibility for the 2012 festival will be available on the Tribeca Web site. Submission forms and information regarding eligibility for the film institute programs are available at tribecafilminstitute.org.

headline: 75 Year Anniversary of City’s W.P.A Pools
text: In the summer of 1936 11 pools were built by the Works Progress Administration where opened in New York City.

headline: 3 More Deaths From Heat Bring City’s Toll to 7
text: Three people have died this month because of the heat, the medical examiner’s office said Monday, bringing this summer’s heat-related death toll to seven.

headline: Oil Sands to Raise Emissions, Canadian Report Says
text: The Canadian government has long fought efforts by politicians and environmentalists in other countries, including the United States, to characterize oil sands production as “dirty oil.” But an analysis quietly released late last month by its environmental agency indicates that the tar-like deposits will become an increasingly significant source of the country’s greenhouse gas emissions by the end of the decade.

headline: Andy Cohen of Bravo Plans a Memoir
text: Andy Cohen, the Bravo channel executive who doubles as a talk-show host for the network, will soon double — or is that triple? — as an author. Henry Holt and Company said on Monday that it would publish Mr. Cohen’s first book, a memoir about growing up with a love of pop culture and landing a job in the television business, which enabled him to meet many of the stars he admired. The as-yet untitled book will also detail how Mr. Cohen, who is gay, suppressed his sexuality as a boy. It is to be published next summer.

headline: David Krop on the U.S.S. Monitor
text: The conservation project manager for the U.S.S. Monitor talks about the restoration of a gun turret.

headline: Pawlenty Lures Straw Poll Voters With Politics and Food
text: AMES, Iowa — There is one objective for Republican candidates this week: getting their supporters to come to the straw poll here on Saturday.

headline: The Insider | Emerson Bethany Fry
text: If you’ve read an indie fashion blog lately, you’ve probably found yourself on the Web site of the studio EmersonMade, whose chief designer and model, Emerson Bethany Fry, seems to have inspired 1,000 girl crushes. First it was her fabric flower brooches; next the New Hampshire farm to which she and her husband, Ryan Fry, a photographer, had relocated from New York; and then the introduction of her clothing line, with the spring 2011 lineup of shift dresses and scalloped skirts causing particularly feverish obsession. Readers of Fry’s travel journal know that her continuous search for inspiration and textiles takes her to some far-flung places. Here, she shares a few of her favorite spots.

headline: Famine in Somalia
text: Nearly three million people are in urgent need of assistance as Somalia endures one of its worst droughts 60 years.

headline: A Campaign to Carry Pregnancies to Term
text: The March of Dimes opened a new campaign this summer to curb the large and growing number of otherwise healthy pregnancies that are deliberately ended early by induced labor or Caesarean delivery.

headline: Ben Younger, Director of ‘Boiler Room,’ Discusses Formula One Film Project
text: With the coming theatrical release of “Senna,” the documentary on Ayrton Senna, the three-time champion who died during the San Marino Grand Prix in 1994, Formula One has hit vogue status in Hollywood.

headline: The Caucus | Attention Turns to Iowa
text: Reports from the Hawkeye state ahead of a straw poll; Michael D. Shear's five things to watch for; Jeff Zeleny on Michele Bachmann's strategy.

headline: Caucus Video: On the Road in Iowa
text: Michael D. Shear outlines five things to watch leading up to the Ames Straw Poll on Saturday. Jeff Zeleny reports on Michele Bachmann. She’s drawing crowds, but can she turn them into straw poll votes?

headline: Assessing the Impact of a Downgrade
text: Fears about the potential economic impact of the sovereign debt crisis roil markets worldwide. The New York Times’s Graham Bowley assesses the impact of the latest blow to investor confidence.

headline: Morris Quickly Makes His Mark at Sony Music
text: One month into his new job as the chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment, Doug Morris has already begun to reorganize the company, shuffling label divisions and naming new lieutenants.

headline: A Brief Dry Spell for the U.S.S. Monitor
text: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. — Military secrecy was a bit lax during the Civil War, by today’s standards, but contractor deadlines were a lot tighter.

headline: Numberplay: Nim for (a) Change
text: We’ve previously had fun with the simple yet very interesting game of Nim in Gary Antonick’s Let’s Play 1-2-3 Nim. Today, we have a variant contributed by Patrick Vennebush, the author of the book Math Jokes 4 Mathy Folks and its extended online blog. Here’s the story of the game’s invention, in Patrick’s words:

headline: My House, Our Home
text: For some, having a live-in house guest who can also help is the perfect solution for aging at home.

headline: S.&P. ‘Negative’ on Berkshire Hathaway
text: Not long after Berkshire Hathaway uncharacteristically entered the takeover fray for Transatlantic Holdings, offering $3.25 billion, the credit ratings agency Standard & Poor’s had a surprise of its own: It lowered its outlook on Warren E. Buffett‘s company.

headline: Michael Cerveris to Play Juan Peron in ‘Evita’ Revival on Broadway
text: Michael Cerveris, the Tony Award-winning actor (“Assassins”), will star as Juan Peron in “Evita,” a revival of that Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber musical opening on Broadway in the spring of 2012, the show’s producers said on Monday. Mr. Cerveris joins a cast that includes the singer Ricky Martin as Che and the Olivier Award winner Elena Roger in her Broadway debut as Eva. Mr. Cerveris made his Broadway debut in 1993 as the title character in “The Who’s Tommy,” and his credits include playing John Wilkes Booth in “Assassins” and the title character in the 2005 revival “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.”

headline: Gun Query Off Limits for Doctors in Florida
text: As a primary care physician, I regularly ask patients questions that many people would consider rude, inappropriately nosy or just irrelevant in polite conversation.

headline: Jazz’s Present Gets Its Chance at Newport
text: NEWPORT, R.I. — Leaving the Newport Jazz Festival on Sunday evening, hearing Rudresh Mahanthappa and Bunky Green’s bright and brilliant alto saxophone sounds recede as you walked in the rain toward the water, you could feel a couple of contradictory things. One: The Newport Jazz Festival still matters. Two: That was pretty good for the Newport Jazz Festival.

headline: ‘Environment’ Poses a Knotty Challenge in Autism
text: Parents of children with autism often ask pediatricians like me about the cause of the condition, and parents-to-be often ask what they can do to reduce the risk. But although there is more research in this area than ever before, it sometimes feels as if it’s getting harder, not easier, to provide answers that do justice to the evidence and also offer practical guidance.

headline: A Lion With Buffalo Horns? Must Be the New BMW Campaign

text: The day in sports included badminton in London, cricket in Sri Lanka and preparations for the P.G.A. Championship in Georgia.

headline: One More Honor for Joe D: Finally, a Stamp
text: The Yankees may be one game behind the Boston Red Sox in the American League East standings, but the New York ball club has at least one thing to celebrate: a postage stamp.

headline: Picky Palates
text: Q. Why am I such a fussy eater? Does each person have a distinct set of taste buds, or is my fussiness just in my head?

headline: Nothing New in Obama Remarks
text: Presidential addresses on days of market panics seldom accomplish very much, but it is not really easy to see why the one President Obama gave this afternoon was scheduled. He got there later than promised. He announced nothing new. He had the same old suggestions for what the government should do — some of them quite reasonable — but gave no reason to hope that the Republicans would agree to any of them.

text: The Look: Glitterati — a tweed jacket with red piping gets that razzle-dazzle with embellished footwear.

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at Rest
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the eighth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from a week off in New York City.

headline: On Arctic Ice and Warmth, Past and Future
text: Aug. 9, 8:00 p.m. | Updated Here’s an update on Arctic ice trends, starting with a fast-motion video portrait of sea ice conditions near the North Pole, provided by one of two automated cameras deployed there in April (keeping in mind that the camera is on ice that’s drifted hundreds of miles since then):

headline: Groups Call for Scientists to Engage the Body Politic
text: When asked to name a scientist, Americans are stumped. In one recent survey, the top choice, at 47 percent, was Einstein, who has been dead since 1955, and the next, at 23 percent, was “I don’t know.” In another survey, only 4 percent of respondents could name a living scientist.

headline: Witness Feels Betrayed as U.S. Plans to Divide Family
text: WASHINGTON — About a decade ago, a federal prosecutor in Texas asked Edmond Demiraj to testify against an Albanian mobster charged with human smuggling.

headline: Fox Draws Teenagers and ‘Falling Skies’ Ends on a High
text: The Teen Choice Awards on Fox on Sunday night managed to ensnare its elusive target demographic thanks to squeal-inducing appearances by Taylor Swift, Robert Pattinson and Justin Bieber. The ceremony was the highest rated telecast of the summer for Fox among teenagers. Adults didn’t quite follow suit, flocking to somewhat older fare on CBS. “60 Minutes” garnered 8.7 million total viewers and “Big Brother” had 7.8 million, giving the station another Sunday win in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old segment.

headline: Citi and American Airlines to Offer an E.M.V. Card
text: Add another credit card to the list of those offering affluent customers the more-secure E.M.V. chip technology that’s becoming dominant in Europe.

headline: Frogs’ Songs Attract Females, and Predators
text: Male túngara frogs gather in shallow pools of water at night and let out long mating calls. Females visit these pools, listen to a few calls and then quickly pick mates. It’s a bit like speed dating.

headline: The Presider and the Fighter
text: The Daily Beast’s Leslie Bennetts has a story about prominent New York Democrats (all anonymous, of course) who wish that Hillary Clinton were president instead of the man they voted for three years ago:

headline: Rick Perry to Make Clear He Intends to Run
text: DES MOINES — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is preparing to make clear his intentions to join the Republican presidential race, two associates said, by visiting South Carolina and New Hampshire on Saturday — the same day several of his potential rivals are taking part in the Iowa Straw Poll.

headline: Catching Obesity From Friends May Not Be So Easy
text: Does obesity spread like a virus through networks of friends and friends of friends? Do smoking, loneliness, happiness, depression and illegal drug use also proliferate through social networks?

headline: The Director Formerly Known as Vincent Gallo
text: The man who gave us “Buffalo 66″ (when Cristina Ricci still had breasts) and “The Brown Bunny” (a must for those who like seeing Chloe Sevigny sink to her knees) has announced that his latest, “Promises Written in Water,” will never be screened again. “I do not want my new works to be generated in a market or audience of any kind,” he was quoted as saying in The Guardian. As The Guardian points out, he is in illustrious company. “Promises Written in Water” is  “to take its place in the same sealed vault many miles underground, housing that other movie locked away from prying eyes by its own obsessive mastermind, Jerry Lewis’s “The Day the Clown Cried.” Perhaps, like Lewis, Gallo will end up inducted into the Légion d’Honneur.

headline: House Leaders to End Page Program
text: WASHINGTON – There will be far fewer blue polyester jackets seen darting through Capitol Hill. John Boehner, the speaker of the House, and Nancy Pelosi, the minority leader, announced on Monday that they have decided to end the House page program. The decision, based on a cost analysis by an outside consulting firm, was largely driven by costs, and because advances in technology have rendered obsolete some of their tasks, such as taking phone messages.

headline: A Seasonal Thirst for a Good Read
text: BEACH reading doesn’t actually require a beach. You could just as easily be at the pool or on a breezy porch, or simply trying to stay cool on the couch, but if it’s summer, and you have a good book, in my mind it qualifies as beach reading. These four provocative wine books will no doubt inspire beachlike thirsts. It’s up to you to quench them.

headline: An Updated Sifty Fifty
text: Who’s in, who’s out? As summer comes to a close we’ve made some additions to my ever-evolving list of 50 favorite restaurants in New York City. Head over to The Scoop to download the free app. Or read it in your browser. Then get eating. Collect them all!

headline: The Newport Jazz Festival
text: The festival took place at Fort Adams State Park in Newport, R.I., where casual jazz and music fans made up the majority of the crowds.

headline: Focus on Insider Trading Becomes More Intense
text: The first week of August usually heralds the dog days of summer, but it also appeared to be “insider trading week,” as the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department unveiled three high-profile securities fraud cases, with the prospect for more. And another case, involving a former McKinsey & Company managing director, Rajat K. Gupta, took an interesting turn when the S.E.C. dismissed its administrative complaint and is likely to proceed in federal court in the near future.

headline: Cuomo Appoints Panel to Choose New Transit Chief
text: It may be the toughest job listing in state government: lead an underfinanced, underappreciated mass transit system that is a regular punching bag for politicians, an emblem of bureaucratic inertia, and, incidentally, crucial to the lives of the millions who depend on it each day.

headline: JPMorgan Hires Senior Insurance Banker From Bank of America
text: JPMorgan Chase has hired Paul Brown, a senior insurance deal-maker, from Bank of America Merrill Lynch, the firm announced in an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook on Monday.

headline: Sherman Takes Over at Recording Industry Group
text: The Recording Industry Association of America, the music industry’s biggest lobbying group, announced new leadership on Monday.

headline: Hospitality Boutiques
text: The hotel shop, with its practical mix of sundries, souvenirs and candy bars, has been a predictable if uninspired lobby fixture for years. But as hotels scramble to distinguish themselves, many are rethinking their shops, upgrading and expanding merchandise and fashioning shops as destinations for both guests and local residents, much as they did with restaurants a decade ago.

headline: Risks: Heart Risks May Hasten Mental Decline
text: Cardiovascular risk factors in middle age are associated with brain deterioration and a decline in mental function later in life, a new report has found.

headline: Chinese Fault Beijing Over Foreign Reserves
text: HONG KONG — It is not just many Americans who are upset about the Standard & Poor’s downgrade of United States debt. A lot of people in China are angry, too. But they are aiming their venom at the Chinese government.

headline: Sandwiches for Summer
text: Whenever I fly, I like to go armed with lunch, as the food in airports tends to be both appalling and expensive. Lately I’ve hitting the road with sandwiches that combine produce with canned fish, like sardines, herring, trout or smoked salmon — all of them high in omega-3 fatty acids, packed with protein and delicious.

headline: The People Who Should Sell Stocks Now
text: The temptation to do something, anything, is overwhelming when stock prices are falling. Watching the market decline while you’re just standing there feels overwhelmingly foolish.

headline: Longevity: Habits May Extend Life Only So Much
text: The eating, drinking and exercise habits of extremely old but healthy people differ little from those of the rest of us, a new study has found.

headline: Regimens: Soy Does Little for Menopause Symptoms
text: Fears about the risks of estrogen replacement therapy have led many women to turn to soy products to treat the symptoms of menopause. But a clinical trial published on Monday in Archives of Internal Medicine has found them no more effective than a placebo.

headline: TimesCast | August 8, 2011
text: President Obama addresses the downgrade of the United States' credit rating; Arab countries increase pressure on Syria; and rioting and looting continue in London for a third day.

headline: When the Wife Is a Lucky Charm, Don’t Leave Home Without Her
text: I HAVE to say that I love flying. There’s something very intimate about being on a plane. You never know who you’ll be seated next to and what their stories may be.

headline: Noose Hour
text: I’ll be on along with Ken Rogoff and someone from the investment world. We’ll be talking about sports statistics, or something. Unless, you know, something happened today.

headline: A P.G.A. Course Is Made to Take the Heat
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Clutching two golf balls, Ken Mangum hopped out of the cart and strolled onto the eighth green. He rolled an orange ball that briskly covered about 20 feet and stopped level with the hole. A white one, dropped straight down from knee high, bounced slightly, almost imperceptibly.

headline: Second Triathlon Swimmer Dies, Prompting Review of Race Protocol
text: A second competitor died Monday after apparently having had a heart attack during Sunday’s New York City Triathlon.

headline: Epidemics: AIDS Cases Increasing in Muslim Countries
text: AIDS is on the rise in many Muslim countries, driven by men having sex with other men in secret because of homophobia, religious intolerance and fear of being jailed or executed, according to a new study.

headline: Salad Bars in Pork City
text: Cincinnati isn’t the only town in the country that’s bringing salad bars to its public schools (there’s New Haven, and New Orleans), but it has the rare distinction of once being known as Porkopolis, from the time – the early-to-mid 19th century – when herds of hogs roamed its streets, and it was the biggest pork-packing center in the country.

headline: What Once Seemed Too Far Is Now Just Right
text: Many years ago, back when 96th Street was the bright-line border separating the upper reaches of the Upper East Side and East Harlem, Darin White, an executive at a major search firm, had a friend who lived in a nice prewar building on East 98th Street.

text: A look at developments in Libya.

Chen, a reporter and editor for Wired.com, is the author of a new book, “Always On: How the iPhone Unlocked the Anything-Anytime-Anywhere Future — and Locked Us In.” Mr. Chen discussed with me whether smartphones are good or bad for society and if we will all look like cyborgs in the near future.

headline: An Economist for Nature Calculates the Need for More Protection
text: COTO BRUS, Costa Rica — Dawn is breaking over this remote upland region, where neat rows of coffee plants cover many of the hillsides. The rising tropical sun saturates the landscape with color, revealing islandlike remnants of native forest scattered among the coffee plantations.

headline: An East Hampton Festival That Won’t Be
text: The promoters of the Music to Know Festival on Long Island had a magic number in mind last week: 5,500. That was how many tickets they would have to sell to break even on this two-day event in East Hampton.

headline: Chimpanzees Clear Some Doubt After Generosity Is Questioned

headline: Medicare Extends Experiment in Paying Doctors
text: After five years of testing the idea, Medicare officials said Monday that they believe that doctors who coordinate care and keep their patients out of the hospital can help reduce the nation’s health care costs.

headline: Scientists mixing it up in the political arena, facelifts and breast implants for the over-65 crowd, and do your friends make you fat redux.

headline: Hotel Housekeeper Sues Strauss-Kahn
text: The hotel housekeeper who has accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her in his 28th-floor suite sued him in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on Monday, seeking unspecified damages for a “violent and sadistic attack” that humiliated and degraded her and robbed her “of her dignity as a woman.”

headline: Demand Growing for Giving Birth at Home
text: When Kelly Brown gave birth three years ago, she labored for 22 hours, much of the time hooked up to an IV line that restricted her movement. Repeatedly offered pain medication she did not want, she narrowly avoided getting a Caesarean section.

headline: TimesCast | Condemning Syria
text: The Times's Anthony Shadid on Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Kuwait recalling their ambassadors from Damascus to protest the Syrian president's deadly crackdown on demonstrators.

headline: An Interior Design Deal-Maker Leaves His Mark
text: THE blond, brainy young decorator Celerie Kemble often seems to be everywhere on the Manhattan society circuit, but her name is not yet echoing outside its crown-molded corridors or emblazoned on bathmats in the Midwest.

headline: A Colorful Way to Watch Evolution in Nebraska’s Sand Dunes
text: VALENTINE, Neb. — The nearest ocean is a thousand miles away. Yet across central Nebraska, peeking out from rolling hills of prairie grass, is sand — beige and reminiscent of a Caribbean beach. Nebraska’s sandhills are the largest sand dunes in North America, spreading for more than 20,000 square miles, over more than a quarter of the state. The sand hails from the Rocky Mountains: tiny specks of eroded quartz that blew east and landed here, 8,000 years ago.

headline: Coup de Glass
text: For its fall collection of icicle-drop necklaces and pendants, Kora, the L.A.-based, African-made jewelry line, teamed up with glass makers in the Kenyan village of Kitengela. A mere two years old, Kora has dedicated itself to creating “trade not aid” jobs by designing and marketing hand-fashioned pieces made from recycled bone, aluminum, brass, horn and now glass. ”The colors of the glowing green glass are incredible; it’s so unlike animal horn,” says Kora’s co-founder Maxandra Short (above, left). Her partner, Amy Walker, adds, “Glass necklaces still have an organic feel, because every piece is different.” Indeed the latest offerings, like the necklace at right ($220; go to koradesigns.com), are a softer addition to the line’s usually more brawny designs, which in the past have included tribal-inspired manacles and industrial-looking chains. “I think we’re even going to be playing with color in bone,“ Walker says. “Color is our thing now.”

headline: 'Annie' Audition Tape: Caroline Ellis

headline: Fred Imus, Radio Personality and Songwriter, Dies at 69

headline: Austerity Plan Might Not Work for Spain and Italy
text: ONCE again Europe’s leadership has been forced to put up billions in cash to halt the spread of contagion to the Continent’s weaker economies, this time in the form of a potentially vast purchase of Italian and Spanish government bonds by the European Central Bank. And once again the condition for rescue is more austerity.

headline: An Easter Egg for Instagram Photos

headline: Footnote
text: The Tribeca Film Festival said on Monday that its 11th annual festival would be held April 18-29. The festival has asked for submissions for narrative and documentary features as well as for short film entries. Starting on Sept. 19, submission forms and information regarding eligibility for the festival will be at tribecafilm.com.

headline: Their Stock Portfolios May Be Bleeding, but Consumers Get a Break on Gas Prices
text: HOUSTON — The growing gloom about the economy has pushed down oil and gasoline prices, along with the prices of an array of other commodities. And while that could mean more spending power for consumers, perhaps tempering any possible downturn, the steep drop in energy prices reflects worries that economic activity is headed in the wrong direction.

headline: Recording Industry Chairman Named to Lead Automotive Trade Group

headline: Groups Advocating for the Arts Feel the Pinch
text: The Alliance for the Arts, which has served New York’s cultural world through research and advocacy for 35 years, is transferring its primary activities to the Municipal Art Society and to WNET, two deals in the process of being completed that illustrate how arts advocacy and service groups in New York are struggling to sustain themselves at a time of scarce resources.

That meant a merger with hip-hop for Blitz the Ambassador, originally from Ghana; a merger with dance-music electronics for Spoek Mathambo, of South Africa; and a merger with R&B for Iyadede, originally from Rwanda.

headline: Down Two Players, and Four Runs, Mets Rally to Win
text: In a season already best described as erratic, it seemed only fitting for the Mets to have a Monday like this one. They began their day by announcing the latest batch of grim injury news only to end it, hours later, with the exuberance of a victorious dog pile out near second base.

headline: Arizona: State Sues Marijuana Clubs
text: State Attorney General Tom Horne filed a civil suit Monday against four cannabis clubs in the Phoenix area that he said violated the state’s medical marijuana law, which voters approved in November. The state has not issued any licenses to marijuana dispensaries pending a federal court review. The result has been the creation of unlicensed cannabis clubs, which charge membership fees but give away marijuana to approved patients. “That type of deception and blatantly illegal activity must be stopped,” Mr. Horne said.

headline: El Salvador: Suspects in Killings of Priests Turn Themselves In
text: Nine former soldiers and officials have turned themselves in to a court in El Salvador after being indicted in Spain for the 1989 massacre of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter in San Salvador. The Supreme Court now has 45 days to decide whether to extradite the men to Spain. American officials and analysts, however, say an extradition is unlikely. The court is expected to rely on Salvadoran law, including a 1993 amnesty for crimes committed during its civil war.

headline: App Smart Extra: An App Aimed to Curb Distracted Driving

text: CAMP VICTORY, Iraq — If the combat zone in Iraq were not so completely dry, some soldier on the staff of the palatial J.V.B. would be ringing last call.

One memorable May afternoon, he pointed to a horse on the program by the name of Multiple Choice and declared: “He’s a quality animal. That’s the horse to bet.”

headline: Perry Signals Intent to Enter Race, Sending a Jolt to G.O.P. Candidates
text: DES MOINES — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas delivered a long-distance jolt to the Republican presidential campaign on Monday by signaling that he intends to join the race and visit South Carolina and New Hampshire on Saturday, the same day his rivals are battling for survival in the Iowa Straw Poll.

headline: Jets’ Sanchez Welcomes New Receivers, Again
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The free-agency frenzy dust has settled at Jets training camp, and what emerged in a matter of two weeks is the third wide receiver corps for Mark Sanchez in three years.

headline: Evolution’s Gold Standard
text: Feeling low? According to a new study in the Journal of Consumer Research, when people feel bad, their sense of touch quickens and they instinctively want to hug something or someone. Tykes cling to a teddy bear or blanket. It’s a mammal thing. If young mammals feel gloomy, it’s usually because they’re hurt, sick, cold, scared or lost. So their brain rewards them with a gust of pleasure if they scamper back to mom for a warm nuzzle and a meal. No need to think it over. All they know is that, when a negative mood hits, a cuddle just feels right; and if they’re upbeat and alert, then their eyes hunger for new sights and they’re itching to explore.

headline: In Afghanistan, a Village Is a Model of Dashed Hopes
text: ALICE-GHAN, Afghanistan — This tiny village rose from the rocky soil with great hopes and $10 million in foreign aid, a Levittown of identical mud-walled houses built to shelter some of the hundreds of thousands of Afghans set adrift by war and flight.

headline: Democrats Challenging Administration on Medicaid
text: WASHINGTON — In an unusual break with the White House, the Democratic leaders of Congress told the Supreme Court on Monday that President Obama was pursuing a misguided interpretation of federal Medicaid law that made it more difficult for low-income people to obtain health care.

headline: Past Time for a New Agenda
text: President Obama tried on Monday to restore the plunging confidence of investors, insisting the United States remains a triple-A country whatever Standard & Poor’s might think. It didn’t work with the stock markets, which sank again, and it did nothing to reassure the most important shareholders: ordinary Americans living from one paycheck to another, worried about their jobs or wondering how they will replace the one they lost.

headline: Virginia Goes to the Birds
text: In late July 1861, the noted lithographer John Bachmann published a captivating visual picture of Virginia, offering Northerners a powerful and intuitive way to follow the ongoing conflict. Of course, there were already lots of maps of the Old Dominion. What set this one apart? Perspective: looking westward with the Chesapeake Bay in the foreground, it offered a bird’s eye view, an intuitive but, for many, novel look at the unfolding conflict. His “wide angle lens” approach enabled viewers to follow not just the actual location of the battles, but the terrain of the conflict and a larger sense of the geography of the eastern theater.

headline: The Arab States and Syria
text: It took far too long, but the cruelty of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has finally registered with his Arab neighbors. They are speaking out against a reign of terror that has claimed the lives of as many as 1,600 courageous Syrians since pro-democracy protests began in March.

headline: Fire Dept. Reduced Bias Unit While Being Sued for Bias
text: The New York Fire Department office that handles discrimination complaints shrank during a period when the federal government was suing the agency on the grounds that its hiring tests were biased, an assistant fire commissioner testified in United States District Court on Monday.

headline: A Necessary Condition for Arctic Drilling
text: The Obama administration’s decision on Thursday to give “conditional approval” to Royal Dutch Shell’s plans to begin drilling four shallow-water wells in the Beaufort Sea off Alaska alarmed many environmentalists. Cleaning up an oil spill in the frigid, turbulent waters of the Arctic Ocean is likely to be far more complicated than it was in the comparatively benign waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: As Cheers Fade, Clock Ticks on W.P.S.
text: After thrilling fans at the Women’s World Cup, many of the world’s top players returned to their teams in Women’s Professional Soccer and resumed wondering how long the league would be there for them. Jeré Longman looks at the boost the World Cup brought the league, and at some of the serious challenges it still faces. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Perhaps It Was the Campaign Tooth Fairy
text: The secretive world of deep-pocket political giving does not get much murkier than the $1 million dropped on Mitt Romney’s presidential boosters by a company apparently created solely to make the gift then quickly dissolve.

headline: While the Markets Swoon ...
text: It’s hard not to feel a certain contempt for Standard & Poor’s in the wake of its downgrade of American debt. Its sole job as a credit-rating agency is to gauge the creditworthiness of bonds, yet like its competitors, Moody’s and Fitch, it has consistently fallen short. It downgraded Enron days before the company went bankrupt. Its willingness to slap a AAA rating on securitized subprime junk was the foundation upon which the entire financial crisis was built. And now, to show that it’s got some spine, S.& P. decided to downgrade the United States? From a purely economic standpoint, the likelihood of a U.S. default is nil. As my friend Daniel Alpert, a founding managing partner of Westwood Capital, put it: “The size of the U.S. economy, the wealth of its inhabitants and the assets of the sovereign entity itself are unquestionably more than adequate to repay, with interest, all of the $14 trillion or so of the nation’s debt.” He added, “Anyone with a rudimentary understanding of finance and economics can figure that out.” On Monday, with the market collapsing, where did investors rush to put their money? In the one security they still considered safe: U.S. Treasuries.

headline: Tuesday: Words to Swear By
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — When veteran constructors mentor new ones to publication, the veteran’s humor and creativity often takes a back seat to the neophyte’s, and that’s the way it should be, in my opinion. After all, the whole point of mentoring someone is not to foist your style on them, but to help them create their own.

headline: After Day of Tumult, Dow Closes Up 430 Points
text: In another wild day on Wall Street, stocks climbed, then dropped, then rocketed as traders did a double take on the Federal Reserve’s much-awaited statement on the economy Tuesday afternoon.

headline: In Boston, Rivera Revisits a Nemesis
text: Marco Scutaro may have ensured himself a spot on any Boston Red Sox postseason roster Sunday night when he foiled Mariano Rivera for the second time in his career.

headline: Identical Twins, One Charged in a Fatal Shooting, Create Confusion for the Police
text: CHANDLER, Ariz. — At first, the murder case against Orlando Nembhard seemed solid, as witness after witness came forward to say they saw someone that looked just like him brandish a pistol in February outside a crowded nightclub and fire on a young clubgoer, who later died.

headline: Marshall Grant, Bass Player With Johnny Cash, Dies at 83
text: Marshall Grant, a bass player who, as an original member of Johnny Cash’s band, the Tennessee Two, helped create the group’s pulsing “boom-chicka-boom” sound, died on Sunday in Jonesboro, Ark. He was 83.

headline: Video Intensifies Interest in a Mississippi Killing
text: ATLANTA — At first, the early-morning death of James C. Anderson, 49, appeared to be a hit-and-run accident.

headline: Libyan Berbers Re-emerge as a Political Force
text: A Berber city shows signs of a nascent sense of self-determination — a step, the people hope, toward full national and regional recognition.

headline: Libyan Street Art: Freedom, Defiance and Troubling Signs
text: Sitting in the ruins of a Libyan government building in Yafran that had been shattered by violence, Abdul Ghassem recalled his feeling within when he first began to paint murals expressing his disgust for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. That was in early June, soon after the Qaddafi military was driven out of his city. Abdul Ghassem’s paintbrushes moved along the interior walls. As a huge mural took shape, Libya’s longtime leader came to resemble a vampire watching over a world troubled by blood, suffering and fire.

headline: Bank of America Is Back in an Abyss
text: Bank of America is leading banks back into the mortgage abyss. The nation’s largest financial institution by assets shed over $16 billion of market value on Monday as its shares fell 20 percent after the downgrade of the United States credit rating, and a home loan lawsuit filed by the American International Group, the insurer. Other mortgage-heavy lenders were hit, too, but none as bad as Bank of America.

headline: Special Operations Veterans Rise in Hierarchy
text: WASHINGTON — A growing number of veteran commandos in Special Operations are rising to top positions in traditional military units and across the national security bureaucracy, reflecting the importance of their specialized training to fight unconventional wars that defined the past decade.

headline: Inflation Climbs in China on Higher Food Prices
text: HONG KONG — Inflation in China accelerated last month to its fastest pace in three years, with consumer prices up 6.5 percent from a year earlier mainly as a result of rising food prices.

headline: Amid a Berber Reawakening in Libya, Fears of Revenge
text: YAFRAN, Libya — In the evening, as the searing desert temperatures subside, the residents who have returned to this rebel-held city near the front lines appear on the streets. Some of them carry cans of paint, and begin to decorate murals with the characters of an ancient language that had been forbidden by the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Hopefuls Sing Out From Afar as Broadway Scouts Go Online
text: Julia Tan, a 10-year-old actress who dreams of belting like Barbra, auditioned for her first Broadway show last month — 2,500 miles away, in her family room in Kuna, Idaho. As her older sister fumbled with a video camera and her mother beamed nearby as a cue (keep smiling!), Julia performed “Born to Entertain” from the musical “Ruthless!” for one of the three-minute audition tapes that little girls worldwide are sending in to the online casting call for the 2012 revival of “Annie.”

headline: Mike Baxter, Batting 1.000 for His Hometown Team
text: Mike Baxter was 14 years old when the Mets reached the National League Championship Series in 1999. He was an infielder then, a Queens native who would star at Archbishop Molloy, and he admired the way Rey Ordonez played shortstop. A left-handed hitter, Baxter loved to watch John Olerud’s swing.

headline: Village for Afghanistan’s Displaced Is Largely Abandoned
text: Alice-Ghan was built with foreign aid to house Afghans set adrift by war and flight. But with few services or jobs within reach, hundreds of residents have moved away.

headline: Rosemary Harris and Carla Gugino to Star in Athol Fugard Play on Broadway

Gordon Edelstein is directing the production, which will begin previews on Dec. 16 and open on Jan. 17, 2012, on Broadway at the American Airlines Theater.

headline: Aug. 9, 1945 | U.S. Drops Atomic Bomb on Nagasaki, Japan
