headline: The Top Ten Reasons to Keep Going to Citi Field
text: Thanks to injuries and trades over the last 10 days, the Mets have gone from likable overachievers with some plucky young players on the fringe of the wild-card race to an undermanned bunch trying to keep Citi Field awake over the next two months (they did so Monday night, rallying to beat the Padres 9-8 in the ninth inning). Still, it’s summer and it’s baseball, so The Times asked online readers to act like “Late Show” writers and help us put together this list, and these were our favorites:

headline: Freezing the Fluid Emotions of Dance
text: “Some feelings and even some thoughts are too deep for words and have to be seen to be believed.”

headline: The Atlanta Testing Scandal
text: HOW many teachers and principals in Atlanta have admitted to tampering with standardized tests to raise students’ scores?

headline: Does Your School Value Students’ Digital Skills?
text: Do you think your school is “preparing students for a world that doesn’t exist” by ignoring the digital skills you and your peers already have in favor of asking you to do tasks more suited to the early 20th century? For instance, do you think you should be asked to create videos, write blog posts and contribute to Wikis at least as often as you’re asked to write research papers? Why or why not?

headline: Tokyo Electric Posts $7.4 Billion Loss
text: TOKYO — The operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, Tokyo Electric Power, said Tuesday that it lost 572 billion yen in the latest quarter, largely because of costs related to the cleanup after the nuclear disaster and the compensation of victims.

headline: Five European Teams to Keep an Eye On
text: Manchester United won the Community Shield on Sunday, but it’s always winning something. Here’s a look at five European clubs who may be in position to succeed, or surprise, this season.

headline: Has Sculpture Become Just Another Pretty Face?
text: We seem to prefer the multicolored distractions of illusionism on flat surfaces, whether filmed, digital or painted on canvas, to traditional European examples of sculpture.

headline: An Experiment in Austerity
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: Famed Berlin Club Now Hosts Restaurant
text: Berghain, the famed Berlin techno club, is housed in a cavernous former power station. Inside, you’ll find strobe lights, dark rooms, international D.J.’s, and people in line for the bathroom who will tell you, if you ask, that they haven’t left the club in days. Outside, right next to what was the power station’s pressure boiler, you’ll now find a European bistro-style restaurant.

headline: 2011 Giants Season Preview
text: Thus far, the story of the 2011 Giants has centered on Osi Umenyiora. He is looking for the new contract he says General Manager Jerry Reese had promised him. Umenyiora accused Reese of lying in a sworn affidavit during the lockout. After the lockout, he surprisingly showed up to training camp, with the Giants having given him permission to seek a trade. The  first-round price tag, however, was too steep for the rest of the league.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Setup Men to Pursue
text: The July nonwaiver trade deadline brought little movement on the closer front, as rumored-to-be-available guys like Leo Nunez, Andrew Bailey, Drew Storen and, most surprisingly, Heath Bell all stayed put. Owners who had stashed their probable replacements were left disappointed, but that doesn’t mean we won’t see current setup men become closers this season. Some almost certainly will.

headline: The Early Word: Blame Game
text: Today’s Times

headline: Circus to Take Over Prague Park
text: In a couple of weeks, a group of people with tents will move into a Prague park for two weeks, setting up their homes and offices. These people, though, are specialists in entertainment: From Aug. 21 to Sept. 9, Letni Letna, an annual festival of new circus and movement theater, ensconces itself in a corner of Letna Park.

headline: A Prepaid Phone So Fancy, Only Your Phone Company Will Know
text: Prepaid phones still suffer from an image problem. They are thought of as being cheap, unsophisticated and for people who can’t afford a contract plan.

headline: We’ll Show You Ours if You Show Us Yours
text: On the occasion of Charles McGrath’s profile of the novelist Nicholson Baker, we thought it would be fun to round up the favorite dirty books of some of our most illustrious literary critics at The Times. Below, their spicy replies.

headline: Viddy: Like Instagram, but for Videos
text: Most of the world’s video is now shot on smartphones, but hardly anyone shares their videos widely. That’s partly because it takes too many steps and results in too many error messages, but also because many people aren’t convinced their hand-shot clips are worthy of the Internet.

headline: Is God a Marketing Strategy?
text: Recently while searching online for a new refrigerator, I came across a Web site for a local appliance store that featured the Ichthus, or Christian fish symbol, in its logo. The personal side of me that grew up watching Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker tearfully separating people from their money on Sunday television hesitated. The marketer side of me wondered if companies that invoke religious symbols are simply sharing their values — or trading on the intrinsic values of the brand that is the Bible? Lots of businesses align themselves with religion (without going through any kind of certification process from a higher authority).

headline: From Koch, a Child’s Tale of Health and Self-Acceptance
text: As mayor, Edward I. Koch would often deflect insults by insisting that he was not, among other things, a “wacko,” a “dope” or a “punching bag.” But he now admits that the taunt that stung most was inflicted well before he acquired a politician’s thick skin.

headline: HSBC in Talks to Sell Credit Card Portfolio
text: HSBC Holdings said on Tuesday that it was in talks over the sale of its credit card business in the United States.

headline: Grim Headlines Hang Over Iowa Campaigning
text: AMES, Iowa — The Republican straw poll here is usually anything but a somber event.

headline: Morning Optimism
text: The great sell-off may be taking pause.

headline: Q&A: Skype Videochats With a Group
text: Q.

headline: Researching Safer Nuclear Energy
text: The nuclear power industry faces hard times, with tough competition from natural gas for meeting new electricity needs and a prevailing nervousness about nuclear safety after the Fukushima Daiichi accident in March. On Tuesday, the Energy Department, handing out research grants in all kinds of energy fields that are low in carbon dioxide emissions, is announcing that it will give $39 million to university programs around the country to try to solve various nuclear problems.

headline: Tim Pawlenty in Johnston, Iowa
text: Governor Pawlenty speaks on the challenges facing the United States at a coffee shop in Johnston, Iowa on Monday.

headline: Ralcorp to Buy a Sara Lee Unit for $545 Million
text: Sara Lee and Ralcorp are both food companies that have been busy trying to remake themselves this year. On Tuesday, they reached a deal toward that mutual end.

headline: Michele Bachmann in Des Moines
text: The Minnesota Congresswoman prays for military families at the end of a rally in Des Moines on Sunday.

headline: The Benefits of Exercise After Cancer
text: Many people who have had cancer may be inclined to rest and take it easy after treatment, but a new report by a leading British cancer charity is strongly urging some patients to increase, not reduce, their levels of physical activity.

headline: Vain Glorious | Create Your Own Spa Night at Moomah
text: Moomah, the downtown arts and crafts spot and cafe, has firmly established itself as the chic and relaxed place to go with a tot. (We love the coffee, Balthazar croissants and even the thoughtfully edited wine list). Many customers don’t even have kids — no, really. Now Moomah is introducing its own spa nights.

headline: Thinking Cap: Preventing Groupthink
text: “Irving Janis’ Groupthink and the Sanhedrin of Ancient Israel” by Eliezer Schnall, a psychologist at Yeshiva University, and his student, Michael Greenberg. Presented at the American Psychological Association’s Annual Convention in Washington on Aug. 7.

headline: Apollo’s 2nd-Quarter Profit Jumps
text: Apollo Global Management said on Tuesday that its second-quarter profit more than quintupled, as all its businesses showed marked improvement.

headline: Criticized Philippine Art Exhibit Is Closed
text: MANILA — Officials shut down a controversial art exhibition on Tuesday after a storm of public protest that included criticism from President Benigno S. Aquino III, who called the artwork offensive to the country’s Christian majority.

headline: Global Sell-Off Eases; U.S. Futures Slightly Up
text: After stocks in Asia continued a sell-off, European stocks rallied before turning mixed. Futures on United States stocks indicated they would rise when trading begins.

headline: Goldman Gives Details on Lackluster Quarter
text: Goldman Sachs lost money on 15 days in the second quarter, one of the worst trading performances the bank has posted in some time, according to a regulatory filing released on Tuesday.

headline: Morning Buzz
text: For more local news from The Times, including a legal debate about Rosie, New York’s first therapeutic courtroom dog, the growing use of video performances for young people to audition for Broadway roles and new rules and a one-year jail sentence for a former police officer, see the N.Y./Region section.

headline: Updates on Financial Market Upheaval
text: The Lede tracked the global financial markets on Tuesday.

headline: Fall Fashion Preview | Digital Media
text: Text or tweet in gloves that mix the lush textures of leather, pony, hair, wool and cashmere.

headline: Black-and-White Struggle With a Rosy Glow
text: THIS year I took Highway 80 from Montgomery to Selma, Ala., reversing the journey of activists in three separate civil rights marches in March 1965. My destination was the Edmund Pettus Bridge and the National Voting Rights Museum at its base. The infamous Bloody Sunday protest, March 7, 1965, in which several hundred marchers were beaten by state troopers at the bridge is commemorated at the museum, a long one-story building dedicated to “the foot soldiers of the movement,” the husbands and wives, schoolkids and churchgoers who overcame their fear to dramatize their desire for the unimpeded right to vote.

headline: Times Books to Publish Account of British Hacking Scandal
text: Times Books will publish the “definitive account” of the hacking scandal swirling around Rupert Murdoch and News International, the publisher said on Tuesday, written by Sarah Lyall and Don Van Natta Jr., longtime reporters for The New York Times.

headline: The Risks in Jarring a Complex System
text: Paul Fisher, a Dot Earth reader from New Jersey who recently expressed cogent concerns here about dealing with the risks in a complex engineered system — nuclear power plants — has offered similar observations about a complex biogeophysical system in a comment on my post on Arctic climate change, past and future.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Tummy Tucks and Face-Lifts in Your Golden Years
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘MASH’
text: Does America have a fascination with rebels? This week A. O. Scott looks into this idea by discussing Robert Altman‘s 1970 film “MASH,” about a group of Army doctors near the front lines during the Korean War. Mr. Scott sees the film as “a celebration, and perhaps a send-up, of the anti-authoritarian and sometimes antisocial tendencies of a certain type of American male.”

headline: Increased Scrutiny of Immigrants Returning to Mexico
text: U.S. Immigration agents have increased checks on immigrants trying to return to Mexico.

headline: Republicans Hold On to Wisconsin Senate After Recall Vote
text: SAYNER, Wis. — Two Republican state senators lost their seats in recall elections around Wisconsin on Tuesday, but Republicans maintained their control of the State Senate, ultimately handing a defeat to union groups and Democrats who had spent months and millions of dollars trying to wrestle away at least some of the state’s political power.

headline: Face Time | Katrina Bowden
text: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

headline: Mixing Drinks on Your Lap With No Spills
text: Now subway riders can use their iPads not just to catch up on the latest best seller, but to prepare for the cocktail hour that awaits them at home.

headline: Financial Stocks Hold On
text: 3:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: Man Quizzed in Groping Attacks on Upper East Side
text: Updated, 3:19 p.m. | This post has been updated with an interview with the man’s employer.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: What to Tell About an Absent Father
text: There are countless ways to create a family now: many planned, others less so. A reader, Kate, finds herself in one of the unexpected configurations, and is looking for advice. She writes:

headline: Southbound Border Checks
text: Marc Lacey looks at how new federal guidelines are snaring many illegal immigrants trying to go back home to Mexico.

headline: London Riots Widen
text: Riots spread to more affluent neighborhoods and outside London.

headline: Mexico-Bound Immigrants Face Scrutiny at Border
text: NOGALES, Ariz. — An American immigration agent bounded up the steps of a bus about to cross the United States-Mexico border recently and demanded to see the papers of all those aboard. “Papers!” he shouted, eyeing passengers warily as he walked up and down the aisle.

headline: Long-Term Investors Can Relax (a Little)
text: The short-term fluctuations in the stock market obviously can be maddening to anyone with more than a few pennies invested. In the time that I’ve been working on this article, futures prices on the Dow Jones Industrial Average have fluctuated greatly, showing everything from a 300-point loss to a 300-point gain to open Tuesday. The next few days and weeks, and possibly also the next couple months and years, are liable to be turbulent.

headline: Student-Athlete Equation Could Be a Win-Win
text: Joseph Agnew was once a Friday night superstar. A defensive back, he led his Texas high school football team to consecutive state titles in 2004 and 2005. He was also an A student.

headline: Fiscal Forecasting at S.&P.
text: In cutting the rating of the United States government, Standard & Poor’s complained that “the predictability” of American government actions is not what it used to be.

headline: International Paper Extends Temple-Inland Bid
text: International Paper said on Tuesday that it was extending its $3.3 billion hostile offer for Temple-Inland by a month, as it seeks control of the corrugated packaging maker.

headline: Ex-Youngstown Mayor Tackles the Work of Revitalizing Automotive Communities
text: Two years ago, when President Obama ordered the establishment of the Office of Recovery for Auto Communities and Workers, the nation’s automotive industry, like much of the economy, seemed headed into the nadir. General Motors and Chrysler were broke, new-vehicle sales had tanked and the prospect of hiring was improbable.

headline: An App Puts the Twin Towers Back in Sight
text: Brian August stood on the roof of a building on the Greenpoint, Brooklyn, waterfront on Thursday, facing Manhattan and squinting at his iPhone in the sun. As he swept the phone from south to north, the skyline across the East River showed up on its screen, with one difference. The whitish outline of two boxy skyscrapers rose from the spot where, until Sept. 11, 2001, the World Trade Center stood. The buildings towered above everything else in Manhattan, including the Freedom Tower directly to their north. One tower obscured the other slightly, and an antenna pushed far into the sky.

headline: LearnVest: A Money-Management Site for Women
text: Alexa von Tobel wants to change the way women handle their money.

headline: Turkish Minister and Other Envoys Press Syrian Leader
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria rebuffed an appeal from Turkey on Tuesday to end the Syrian crackdown that has emerged as one of the bloodiest chapters in the Arab uprising and has plunged his country into its deepest isolation in years.

headline: Magazine Sales Slipped at the Newsstand
text: Circulation trends for weekly magazines were largely flat over the last six months, with a few notable exceptions among the biggest brands in a business that has undergone considerable restructuring and downsizing in recent years.

headline: Yak Butter Tea and Tibetan Culture
text: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

headline: My House, Our Home
text: Faced with the usual options for senior housing and elder care, some older adults are inventing their own grassroots versions — do-it-yourself senior living that’s friendlier, more autonomous and less expensive. In the coming weeks, fellows in the News21 program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism will offer video reports on four of these: a shared housing arrangement in White Plains, a senior co-housing development in Virginia, an urban village in Chicago and an R.V. community in East Texas.

headline: Sewage Routinely Taints Hudson, Study Shows
text: Sewage routinely contaminates the Hudson River throughout the year, rendering the waterway unsuitable for swimming and other recreational activities for at least one and a half days a week,  a report based on four years of water testing shows.

headline: Cuba-to-Florida Quest Defeats Swimmer at 61
text: MIAMI — Three miles off Havana on Sunday evening, the Florida Straits were still glasslike when the 61-year-old marathon swimmer Diana Nyad felt her right shoulder seize up with pain. But she kept swimming.

headline: London Riots Widen
text: Continued rioting in England moved to more affluent neighborhoods and outside of London.

headline: News Corp.’s Independent Directors Have Strong Ties to Murdoch
text: When the News Corporation board convenes on the 20th Century Fox Studios lot Tuesday for its first meeting since a phone hacking scandal overseas plunged the company into turmoil, the participants will include many people with deep and personal ties to Rupert Murdoch.

headline: Q&A: A Side Trip to China From Hanoi?
text: My husband and I will be in Hanoi this fall, and we’re wondering if it’s feasible to make a side trip to China. We’ll have about five days (maybe a week), and we wonder if you could suggest someplace to visit, preferably in southern China. We enjoy train travel but would consider flying somewhere from Hanoi. We like outdoor activities (hiking, biking, boating) but wouldn’t mind a visit to a small city.

headline: Reviewing Uncle Zhou
text: A look inside the restaurant in Elmhurst, Queens, serving the cuisine of Henan province.

headline: Another Breakthrough for Oscar Pistorius
text: Several weeks ago, Eric Wilson wrote an article for Thursday Styles about the budding fashion career of Oscar Pistorius, the South African athlete who has become a world-class competitive runner despite being a double amputee. (He runs on J-shaped prosthetics made of black carbon fiber and has been dubbed the “Blade Runner.”) Mr. Pistorius, shown shirtless and running at full speed, has started appearing in ads for a new fragrance from Thierry Mugler. Now, Juliet Macur reports in today’s Sports section of The Times that Mr. Pistorius has achieved another milestone in his athletic career: He has been named to South Africa’s team for the track and field world championships, which will make him the first amputee to compete at the event. Ms. Macur reports that he will race in the 400 meters and 4 x 400 relay.

headline: July Was the Fourth-Warmest on Record
text: Results are in from the first stage of this summer’s heat wave, and it’s one for the record books. July was the fourth-warmest on record in the United States, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reports.

headline: Train Derailment Outside Penn Station Snarls Service
text: Update, 2:45 p.m. | Tuesday morning’s derailment just outside Penn Station is expected to cause delays on New Jersey Transit, Long Island Rail Road and Amtrak through the evening rush.

headline: The Caucus Click: Hook ‘Em Horns?
text: Supporters wearing “Americans for Rick Perry” T-shirts — in the classic Texas shade of burnt orange — are showing up across Iowa and urging people to write in his name at the Iowa Straw Poll.

headline: Adventureland
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#623", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: Weak Stocks, Weak Economy?
text: Amidst the sell-off on Monday and the calmer waters this morning, here’s a thought from Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at the High Frequency Economics research firm: a weak stock market is not always a sign of a weak economy.

headline: Ten Years Later, ‘The Guys’ Will Return to Commemorate 9/11
text: “The Guys,” one of the first dramatic responses to 9/11, will return for a series of performances to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks. Sigourney Weaver and Tom Wopat will star in the play, by Anne Nelson, which the Flea Theater will bring back to Lower Manhattan from Sept. 6 to 9.

headline: Riots in London and Paris: Plus Ça Change?
text: Seen from Paris, the images of charred cars and the silhouettes of urban young people battling with police in London called to mind the 2005 riots in France.

headline: The Fed to the Rescue?
text: Joe Gagnon has a widely-discussed proposal for dramatic Fed action. I’m for it — not because we know it would work, but because it might, and we desperately need to do something.

headline: Ppd., Real World Events
text: The sports news and chatter offer a classic choice today, a case of pure diversion versus its place in the real world. There isn’t anything right or wrong about which way your attention leans, but it might tell you something about your sports DNA. It’s sort of like your movie DNA, which either pushes you to gripping, real-life dramas or to “Cowboys and Aliens.”

headline: Six Questions for Brian Moynihan
text: Bank of America‘s chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, who has been under fire for his bank’s dismal performance, has agreed to field questions from investors on Wednesday.

headline: Record Labels Hit Hard as Fire Set by London Rioters Destroys Warehouse
text: Independent music labels were hit hard after rioters in London set fire to a 215,000-square-foot warehouse owned by the Sony Corporation on Monday night, destroying vast amounts of compact discs, vinyl albums and other stock, Reuters and the BBC reported.

headline: The Self-Justification Trap
text: Brad DeLong has an upsetting post about thinking within the Obama administration. I don’t know if it’s right, but it feels right. As Brad tells it,

headline: An Early Surge in an Injury the N.F.L. Wasn’t Expecting
text: When the N.F.L. lockout ended last month and players streamed into training camps on short notice after no supervised off-season workouts, many expected a series of nagging hamstring strains and quadriceps pulls to result, the normal early-season indicators of overexertion and uneven fitness.

headline: The Pawlenty Mystery
text: Matt Yglesias listens to Tim Pawlenty so the rest of us don’t have to.

headline: Response From the Mother of a ‘Son With Demons’
text: I received the following from Anon in the Midwest, who wrote so wrenchingly of her young son’s struggle with mental illness earlier this week. Motherlode readers responded with wisdom and compassion, and a lot of good advice. You also had many questions, and Anon has sent the following, which includes answers to many of those, along with her thanks.

headline: A Dramatic Entrance: Kelli O’Hara to Play Regan in ‘King Lear’
text: Kelli O’Hara, best known for sunny roles in musicals like “South Pacific” and “The Pajama Game,” is taking on Shakespeare — and a not-so-sunny role at that. Ms. O’Hara, a three-time Tony nominee, will play the betraying daughter Regan in a new production of “King Lear” at the Public Theater, with Sam Waterston (“Law and Order”) in the title role.

headline: Taking the Bait: Permits, Reservations, Drinking on the Job
text: Time to take stock. As always, many of the comments are more entertaining and insightful than the posts. Herein, we respond to the responders of the last month on scuffling for permits, canceling reservations, and drinking on the job.

headline: Live Nation Bounces Back With Strong Earnings
text: Live Nation Entertainment, the music and ticketing giant that includes Ticketmaster, reported strong results for its second quarter on Monday, with profits up on increased ticket sales and concert attendance.

headline: N.H.T.S.A. Opens Investigations of 40,000 Volkswagen Jettas and 120,000 BMW 7 Series Models
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened investigations into possible diesel fuel leaks on about 40,000 Volkswagen Jetta TDIs and reports of rollaways on 120,000 BMW 7 Series sedans because the automatic transmission may not secure the vehicle in Park.

headline: F1 Films on Your Holidays
text: Formula One news is scarce as the series is in the middle of its annual summer vacation, with four weeks between races to give the traveling teams a brief break. That means a break for fans too, of course, but the biggest fans, like the team members, never turn off. And this summer is a great time for the fans to look at Formula One in from different perspective.

headline: F1 Films on Your Holidays
text: Formula One news is scarce as the series is in the middle of its annual summer vacation, with four weeks between races to give the traveling teams a brief break. That means a break for fans too, of course, but the biggest fans, like the team members, never turn off. And this summer is a great time for the fans to look at Formula One in from different perspective.

headline: Elaine’s Table No. 1 and Artwork Will Be Auctioned
text: As City Room reports, table No. 1 from Elaine’s, the Upper East Side restaurant that closed in May, will be auctioned on Sept. 20, along with the posters and artwork that lined the restaurant and books and memorabilia from the nearby apartment of its longtime owner, Elaine Kaufman, who died last year.

headline: Lens: Dance Photography From the ’20s Through the ’90s
text: “Some feelings and even some thoughts are too deep for words and have to be seen to be believed.”

headline: On Selling Poison
text: Michele Simon has written a comprehensive and interesting piece about the law and salmonella. I’m going to do my best to post the salient points here for those who would like some kind of summary. (Apologies to Michele for oversimplifying but I think it’s important that people see at least this much.)

headline: Syfy, in Reversal, Pulls Plug on ‘Eureka’
text: Reversing what it had said just last week, Syfy now says it has canceled “Eureka,” a playful science-fiction series that the channel has broadcast since 2006.

headline: Obama Visits Dover to Honor Troops Killed in Crash
text: President Obama traveled to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware on Tuesday to pay his respects to the 30 American servicemen killed in a helicopter crash in eastern Afghanistan over the weekend.

headline: Has Sculpture Become Just Another Pretty Face?
text: BERLIN — Sometimes on a whim I stop into the Bode Museum here to commune with a tiny clay sculpture of John the Baptist.

headline: Gundlach and TCW Square Off in Court
text: Jessica Rinaldi/ReutersJeffrey Gundlach is in a legal fight with his former employer, TCW.

headline: Memoir by Obama’s Half-Sister to Be Published in U.S.
text: A memoir by Auma Obama, a half-sister of President Obama, will be published in the United States in May, St. Martin’s Press said on Tuesday. The book was released in Germany last fall with a title that translates as “Life Always Gets in the Way” or “Life Happens.”

headline: Heavy Trucks to Be Subject to New Rules for Mileage
text: WASHINGTON — Big tractor-trailer trucks will have to get 20 percent more miles per gallon by the 2018 model year under the first-ever fuel economy rules for heavy vehicles, announced Tuesday by President Obama.

headline: Good Behavior? Iraqis React to Release of Ringleader of Abu Ghraib Abuse
text: BAGHDAD — Seven years have passed since it was revealed that detainees at Abu Ghraib prison were abused by American soldiers.

headline: Perry to Visit Iowa for Sunday Speech
text: DES MOINES – The specter of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has been hanging over Iowa for weeks, but on Sunday afternoon he will pay his first visit to the state with a speech in Waterloo.

headline: Wheelies: The Overruled Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Fall Fashion Preview | Cozy Couture
text: A knitwear designer gets discovered. A post from our upcoming Fall Women’s issue.

headline: ‘Wire’ Actress, Caught on Wiretap, Pleads Guilty to Heroin Charge
text: What is that saying about truth being stranger than fiction? An actress who played a killer for a Baltimore drug gang in the HBO series “The Wire” pleaded guilty Monday to conspiring to distribute heroin. She was caught on a wiretap in a joint federal-state investigation of a suspected drug gang, The Associated Press reported.

headline: U.S. and North Korea May Discuss Recovering Remains of Americans
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States has proposed to meet with North Korea to discuss for the first time in six years bringing home the remains of any American soldiers buried there.

headline: London Police Use Flickr to Identify Looters
text: As rioting continues to roil the streets of London, local police forces are turning to the Web to help unmask those involved in the torching and looting.

headline: Its Forecast Dim, Fed Vows to Keep Rates Near Zero
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve made a rare promise on Tuesday to hold short-term interest rates near zero through at least the middle of 2013, in a sign that it has all but written off the chances of an expansion strong enough to drive up wages and prices.

headline: Apple Is the Most Valuable Company
text: 4:02 p.m. | Updated At the end of regular trading Tuesday, Exxon was again the most valuable company. Apple’s market cap was $346.74 billion vs. Exxon’s $348.32 billion.

headline: Nandan Nilekani, 56, Chairman of the Unique Identification Authority of India, talks about how Indians benefit from enrollment in the national identity database.
text: An interview with Nandan Nilekani

headline: Home Again, Home Again
text: It’s the return-from-travel trifecta: sleeping in your own bed, sharing pictures and stories from your trip and appreciating the wonderful place you call home.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 9
text: Temperatures in the mid-90s greeted P.G.A. Championship fans and golfers in Johns Creek, Ga., while rain, lots of it, greeted women’s tennis fans in Toronto for the Rogers Cup.

headline: Reviewing Boulud Sud
text: Daniel Boulud’s latest opening on the Upper West Side.

headline: Two Titans Share the Seat of Power
text: EVENTS in hip-hop feel smaller than they used to. This is the age of the regional hit, the no-budget viral video, the Twitter star. Hip-hop, so long the most vibrant force in pop music, could always be counted on for big spending, a boon to producers, directors, fashion stylists, car dealers and so on, to say nothing of the marketing specialists, brand synergists and secondary industries it fueled. But in recent years the center has been weakening, and the genre is readjusting to life built from the bottom up.

headline: Dissident Chinese Artist Speaks Out Using Twitter
text: HONG KONG — Ai Weiwei, the Chinese artist and dissident, on Tuesday broke his silence on political topics for the first time since he was released from detention in China nearly two months ago, denouncing in Twitter postings the treatment of business colleagues who had been detained with him and expressing support for two other incarcerated dissidents.

headline: Gavin DeGraw Attacked Outside His Club
text: 4:49 p.m. |Update: Details From Police

headline: A Lineup for the New York Comedy Festival
text: Louis C.K., Tracy Morgan, Sarah Silverman, Ricky Gervais, Bill Maher, Wanda Sykes, Russell Peters, Kathy Griffin and Norm Macdonald are among the stars who will go straight for the funny bone around New York City during the eighth annual New York Comedy Festival from Nov. 9 to 13, festival officials will announce Wednesday.

headline: Boulud Sud
text: TO the list of terrific Daniel Boulud restaurants in Manhattan, add this Lyonnais chef’s first significant gesture toward the sea that laps at the South of France and Spain to its west, then stretches across to Africa and east to the Levant. Boulud Sud is the Manhattan equivalent of a private yacht anchored off Monaco, serving the food of Sardinia, Greece, Tunisia, Gibraltar, Beirut. And you are invited along.

headline: Portugal Faces Challenges in Meeting Bailout Terms
text: LISBON — The smell of fresh paint wafted recently inside a mansion on the grounds of the São Bento Palace, the official residence of the Portuguese prime minister.

headline: ‘Bachelor Pad’ Rides ‘Bachelorette’ Coattails
text: The three-hour season premiere of “Bachelor Pad” on ABC – where previous contestants from the “Bachelor” compete for a second chance at love and $250,000 – averaged 6.9 million total viewers on Monday. It was enough to give ABC the most viewers for the night, but was a far cry from the audience numbers for the recently completed “Bachelorette” season, which frequently cracked the 8 million mark, according to an analysis of Nielsen ratings data by TV by the Numbers.

headline: Central Bank Props Up Spain and Italy, for Now
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank has succeeded at least temporarily in pushing down the effective interest rates on Spanish and Italian government debt. But analysts say the bank must still convince investors that it has the stamina to withstand what could be a long struggle against market turmoil.

headline: Swiss Near Tax Treaties With Germany and Britain
text: LONDON — Switzerland is close to signing sweeping tax treaties with Germany and Britain intended to ensure that assets belonging to citizens of those countries held in Swiss banks will no longer escape tax.

headline: The Fed Splits
text: There is more than meets the eye to the split at the Federal Reserve. There must be.

headline: After 7 Years, Wal-Mart Closes Its MP3 Store
text: 3:41 p.m. | Updated After more than seven years of selling digital music, Wal-Mart Stores will shut its MP3 store at the end of August, the company says.

headline: What Digital Maps Can Tell Us About the American Way
text: Life, liberty and the pursuit of … mappiness? That is the humorous rubric for a new series of digital maps created by the Scholars’ Lab, an office and Web site run by the University of Virginia Library about developments in the digital humanities.

headline: TimesCast | August 9, 2011
text: The Federal Reserve says it will hold interest rates; Britain deploys 10,000 more police officers as rioting widens; and Tim Pawlenty woos evangelical Christian voters in Iowa.

headline: The Caucus | Tim Pawlenty Woos Iowans
text: Aug. 9, 2011 - Former Minnesota Governor Tim Pawlenty looks for support from Evangelical Christians ahead of Saturday's straw poll in Iowa.

headline: Reviewing Uncle Zhou
text: This is not your father’s Hunan restaurant. Uncle Zhou (pronounced Uncle Joe) features the cuisine of Henan, breadbasket of China, especially the province’s well-known wheat noodles. Knife-shaved noodles are brusquely cut from a lump of dough, boiled until wonderfully chewy, and deposited in cool bowls dressed with tomato and egg. Thin, hand-pulled noodles swirl at the bottom of spicy soups; their ribbonlike cousins are great for swabbing the plate. Other are stretched to the fineness of angel hair, baked, then deposited as a crisp thatch atop a whole fish, swimming in a pool of sweet-and-sour sauce. Noodles and fish soak up the sauce; you and your friends soak up the lively atmosphere.

headline: Uncle Zhou
text: WHEN the summer air hangs on you like hot and sour soup, keep cool and listen to Uncle Zhou.

headline: The Fed States the Obvious
text: OK, count me unimpressed by the Fed statement — although for some reason markets went wild.

headline: ‘The Maids’ Now Have Their Say
text: There’s a scene in “The Help,” the new movie based on Kathryn Stockett’s novel, that cracks open the early-’60s world of strained smiles and gentility that rarely leaps out of this big, ole slab of honey-glazed hokum. It’s after hours, and Aibileen, a maid played with determined grace by Viola Davis, is going home. Suddenly the bus stops, and a white man orders the black passengers off, explaining that a black man has been shot — except that he doesn’t say black, Negro or colored. In a pool of dreadful night, Aibileen and a young man trade goodbyes and rush off. And then this sturdy, frightened woman starts running as if her life were in danger, because it’s Mississippi, and it is.

headline: Robert H. Lessin, Jefferies Vice Chairman, Dies at 56
text: Robert H. Lessin, a longtime Wall Street banker and technology angel investor, died on Monday evening. He was 56.

headline: Mormonism and Mitt Romney’s “Weirdness”
text: Thanks to the current spate of awful economic news, we pretty much know what kind of re-election campaign Barack Obama is going to wage: A relentlessly negative one, which, like George W. Bush’s re-election campaign against John Kerry, will focus almost exclusively on making the challenger seem unacceptable rather than defending the sitting president’s accomplishments. Thanks to Ben Smith at Politico, we also know roughly how the White House plans to “destroy Mitt Romney,” if he turns out to be that challenger: By “attacking him as inauthentic, unprincipled and, in a word used repeatedly by Obama’s advisers in about a dozen interviews, ‘weird.'”

headline: Good News From Europe
text: No, you didn’t misread that. Amid all the turmoil here, it’s worth noting that so far the ECB’s attempt to stop a self-fulfilling panic is going pretty well:

headline: Klinsmann Era Dawns for U.S.
text: Jurgen Klinsmann, the 35th coach in the history of the United States men’s national team, will coach his first match with his new team Wednesday night against Mexico in Philadelphia.

headline: Disney Profits Beat Wall Street Predictions
text: After two wild quarters — leaping in the first and missing big in the second — the Walt Disney Company returned to its calm and collected ways on Tuesday, reporting profit slightly above Wall Street’s predictions.

headline: Madmen In Authority
text: Just a reminder: back in the spring of last year conventional wisdom in Europe, although fortunately not at the Fed, was that it was time to start raising interest rates, with the OECD calling, I think, for 350 basis points by the end of 2010.

headline: The Office, L.E.S. Style
text: The slyly prescient gang of techno-corporate fetishists behind the website DIS Magazine are spending their summer in meet space: a real-life office on the Lower East Side! DIS HQ is occupying Invisible-Exports gallery for the month of August with a multiplatform workspace installation created by the artist Lizzie Fitch in her signature Ikea vernacular. One of the gallery’s walls has been repainted as a green screen for digital embellishments to the 24/7 surveillance the collective will stream to the Web. The office will also be open to corporeal visitors for performances, events and DIS’s day-to-day business, which includes casting sessions scouting for seniors to be made over as tweens, professional bodybuilders and pop-locking tribal belly dancers for the site’s end of summer Poprally event at MoMA PS1.

headline: Networks Step Up Coverage in Famine Zones
text: Television networks in the United States have stepped up their staffing in Somalia and Kenya in recent days amid what the United Nations calls a worsening humanitarian crisis there.

headline: TimesCast | Riots Spread in Britain
text: August 9, 2011 - After looting and riots spread beyond London, Prime Minister David Cameron deployed 10,000 additional police officers to quell unrest.

headline: Free Money!
text: Source.

headline: Fighting Cleavage Wrinkles
text: BACK when Lisa Barr wore a size 34B bra, she didn’t know from cleavage wrinkles. But soon after she got breast implants in 1999, augmenting her measurements to a 36C, she started waking up with thick lines on her chest where one breast had fallen against the other as she slept on her side.

headline: On New York’s Low Seas: Day 2
text: If the Statue of Liberty ferry passed right by Lady Liberty and took a five-minute detour farther to the west, the tourists – and even most seen-it-all New Yorkers – would get an eye-opening take on glamorous New York Harbor’s gritty, hard-working side.

headline: Stock Advice for These Uncertain Times
text: It may be a good time to start investing in baseball-bat manufacturers. According to Amazon U.K.,  sales of bats have climbed wildly. Billy clubs jumped an amazing 48,621 percent in Amazon’s sales ranks, to No. 14 from No. 6,821, as British citizens began taking the law into their own hands.

headline: TimesCast | Federal Reserve Holds Rates
text: The Federal Reserve announced interest rates will remain at "exceptionally low" levels for another two years.

headline: When Two Thumbs Down Are a Sign of Approval
text: HAND gestures can be vulgar, but recently a demure, loving one has risen to popularity. To make it, curl the index fingers on both hands with the thumbs pointing down and join them to make a heart shape. Two people can make it together: a human version of those best-friends-forever lockets that break apart to be shared.

headline: FRED Excels!
text: One of Issawi’s Laws, which I can’t seem to find online, explained the laws of progress or lack thereof. First, the total amount of good and evil in any system remains constant. Second, most things get steadily worse. In particular, people get worse as they grow older, because they become more like themselves. The second proposition does not contradict the first, because some things get much better.

headline: Fuel Economy: It’s Not Just for Cars Anymore
text: The Obama administration issued fuel economy standards on Tuesday for medium and heavy trucks, the first time the government has regulated vehicles over 8,500 pounds.

headline: Elaine’s Auction
text: Some of the items from Elaine Kaufman’s estate that are up for auction.

headline: Test Can Tell Fetal Sex at 7 Weeks, Study Says
text: A simple blood test that can determine a baby’s sex as early as seven weeks into pregnancy is highly accurate if used correctly, a finding that experts say is likely to lead to more widespread use by parents concerned about gender-linked diseases, those who are merely curious and people considering the more ethically controversial step of selecting the sex of their children.

headline: Boy or Girl? A Home Test Can Tell You
text: Many parents find out they are having a baby by using a home pregnancy test. Now, home tests can reliably determine a baby’s sex as early as seven weeks into the pregnancy.

headline: A Foreign Correspondent in Nazi Germany Who Interpreted It for the World
text: “It is impossible to realize,” Nora Ephron wrote in 1973, “how much of Ernest Hemingway still lives in the hearts of men until you spend time with the professional war correspondents.”

headline: In Court, the City’s Fire Commissioner Defends Efforts to Diversify the Ranks
text: Under firm, if generally polite, examination, New York City’s fire commissioner defended his efforts to recruit minority candidates in court on Tuesday, saying the Fire Department has measurably increased its number of black applicants while rebuilding its ranks a decade after the losses from 9/11.

headline: Trying to Live Forever
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: Rock Steady
text: As natural attractions go, Norway’s Pulpit Rock makes a jaw-dropping first impression on visitors.

headline: A Group Determinedly Finding a Spot Right in the Middle of Things
text: In 2007 Claire Chase, an accomplished flutist and an ambitious, industrious organizer, spelled out her hopes for the International Contemporary Ensemble, which she founded in 2001 with a group of fellow graduates of the Oberlin Conservatory in Ohio.

headline: Obama Forsakes Air Force One for Bus Tour
text: WASHINGTON — Who says presidents live the life of luxury?

headline: G.M. Sees Cost Cuts Continuing for Years in Effort to Sustain Long-Term Growth
text: DETROIT — General Motors, already much leaner and more efficient after going through bankruptcy and a painful reorganization, still has to undertake years of sharp cost cuts to ensure it remains profitable, its executives said Tuesday.

headline: Two Musicians at One With the Basics
text: Guitars and drum machines are very blunt instruments in the hands of the Kills, the two-member band that started a two-night stand at Terminal 5 on Monday night. Alison Mosshart, an American singer, and Jamie Hince, a British guitarist, write songs pared down to absolute basics: beat, riff and vocal.

headline: Reading the Wisconsin Recall Vote
text: Wisconsin residents on Tuesday voted on whether to recall six Republican state senators, whose backing of Gov. Scott Walker in the dispute over collective bargaining rights this year made them targets for Democratic-aligned groups. Two Democratic state senators face a recall vote next Tuesday. (A third Democratic senator, Dave Hansen, easily survived a recall election on July 19.) Democrats will need to win three of the six Republican seats — without losing either of their own next week — to take control of the state senate.

headline: Touring an Artist’s Pre-Apocalyptic Realm
text: The movie “Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow” is a portrait of the artist at work, though one that says as much about its British director, Sophie Fiennes, as about its stated subject, the German-born artist Anselm Kiefer. In 1993 Mr. Kiefer, perhaps the most celebrated and divisive artist of his generation — he was born in 1945 shortly before the end of World War II — moved to a swath of land outside Barjac, a town in the South of France. He and his assistants then began creating installations on the property that, at least to judge from this movie, are a monument to the human will to self-annihilation and a rehearsal for the apocalypse.

headline: Coaches’ New Friends
text: Norm Roberts took only one season off after coaching men’s basketball at St. John’s, but when he returned as an assistant at Florida in April, he entered a new era. Roberts could not believe how hard it had become to contact high school prospects by telephone.

headline: Productivity Falls for 2nd Quarter in a Row
text: The productivity of workers dropped from April through June for the second consecutive quarter, leading to an increase in labor costs that may restrain gains in profits.

headline: AOL Shares Fall on Report of Weak Gain in Ad Sales
text: Timothy M. Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, is trying to transform the onetime Internet service giant into an online media company, but the market seemed to lose patience Tuesday, driving the stock down by more than a quarter of its value, from $15.07 to close at $11.19.

headline: Soil Samples and Peanut Butter
text: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

headline: Boathouse Restaurant Workers Walk Off Job
text: A lunchtime walkout by workers at the Boathouse restaurant in Central Park on Tuesday caught managers and customers by surprise and forced the closing of the rowboat rental concession, which the restaurant runs.

headline: G.O.P. Phone Campaign Blames Democrats for Downgrade
text: Republicans and Democrats moved quickly to blame each other publicly for causing the S&P downgrade of the nation’s credit, and Republicans are now taking to the phone lines.

headline: Unarmed Officers on London’s Front Lines
text: Last Updated | Wednesday | 9:44 a.m. As British officials promised to end days of widespread riots with “more robust policing,” and 16,000 officers fanned out across London, American readers might be surprised to learn that most members of the force charged with ending the rioting remain unarmed.

headline: ‘Pass the Ketchup’ Could Bring Surprises
text: THE chef José Andrés says that it’s time for America to face a hard truth, one that all of Alice Waters’s goat cheese salads and Thomas Keller’s fried chicken cannot change.

headline: Green Radicchio in the Markets
text: The small, tight heads of what look like lettuce at the Paffenroth Gardens stand in the Union Square Greenmarket, pale green and white with an occasional streak of burgundy, are radicchio wearing a warm-weather wardrobe. “Radicchio needs cold to set the color, and the flavor also gets sharper and more bitter,” said Alex Paffenroth, the owner. The radicchio, grown from Italian seeds, should last into the fall.

headline: Portuguese Breads Sold at Alfama Restaurant
text: Unusual breads of Portugal are being sold at a kiosk at Alfama, the Portuguese restaurant that opened in Midtown in May, with Francisco Rosa, above, as its chef. Along with broa, made with cornmeal, there are pão de forma, a white loaf baked in a mold; ethereal pão de Deus buns with a coconut garnish; and small baguettes called pão de bico (“beaked bread”) for their pointy ends. And do not leave without the tiny custard tarts, pastéis de nata.

text: Name Your Treat

headline: Soda With a Jolt of Ginger
text: Following on the success of his Q Tonic, which has more bite than most tonic waters, Jordan Silbert has introduced Q Ginger. Clean, sharp and yet subtle, it makes an excellent refresher or mixer. Real ginger juice is bolstered with coriander, cardamom and cayenne, and the restrained sweetness comes from organic agave syrup.

text: Opening

headline: The New and the Newer; Hold the Preconceptions
text: LENOX, Mass. — The musicians who run the Tanglewood Music Center’s Festival of Contemporary Music tend to be less concerned with unifying themes, musical or extramusical, than with offering an overview of the composition world’s many competing styles.

headline: Riots Spread on Social Media, as Does the Cleanup
text: After three nights of riots and looting in a handful of London neighborhoods, volunteers used Twitter and Facebook to help mobilize hundreds of people today to clean up the mess.

headline: Johnson & Johnson to Settle Charge Over Drug’s Marketing
text: Johnson & Johnson reached an agreement in principle to settle a misdemeanor criminal charge related to the marketing of its antipsychotic drug Risperdal, the company said in a regulatory filing on Tuesday.

headline: Hazards of Borrowing Money From Hedge Funds
text: Harry Campbell

headline: 3 Senators Named to Deficit Panel
text: Senator Patty Murray of Washington will be co-chairwoman of a powerful new Congressional committee that is supposed to recommend at least $1.5 trillion of additional deficit-reduction measures, the Senate majority leader announced Tuesday.

headline: ‘Catch Me If You Can’ to Close on Sept. 4
text: Based on a Steven Spielberg movie and reuniting much of the creative team that won eight Tonys for “Hairspray,” “Catch Me If You Can” came to Broadway with everything going for it — except, as it turned out, audiences. The musical’s producers announced on Tuesday that it would close on Sept. 4, after 32 previews and 170 performances.

headline: Game-Day Tests Not Disruptive, N.F.L. Says
text: Adolpho Birch, who oversees the N.F.L.’s drug-testing program, said Tuesday that he was confident that game-day testing, which can take place before or after games, would not be disruptive to teams. That has long been a concern among players and coaches.

headline: The Contrapuntal Sounds of Gridlock
text: A red-white-and-blue sign at the corner of West Broadway and Watts Street in SoHo reads, “Don’t Honk — $350 Penalty.” It is, shall we say, not always heeded. This corner is a five-way crossing, where Broome Street forks into Watts, which leads to the Holland Tunnel, and crosses West Broadway, which has two-way traffic. The tunnel entrances themselves run smoothly, if slowly; traffic police officers are there. But the New Jersey exodus has to back up somewhere, and this corner is one of those places. Amid this gridlock is a whole lot of self-expression via car horns and the occasional, ah, verbal admonition.

headline: London Riots Put Spotlight on Troubled, Unemployed Youths in Britain
text: LONDON — “I came here to get my penny’s worth,” said a man who gave his name as Louis James, 19, a slightly built participant in the widening riots that have shaken London to its core. With a touch of guilt on Tuesday, Mr. James showed off what he described as a $195 designer sweater that he said he took during looting in Camden Town, a gentrified area of north London.

headline: Rodriguez Nears Return
text: Alex Rodriguez could play in a minor league rehabilitation game as soon as this weekend, which increases the likelihood that he will return to the Yankees during next week’s seven-game trip that begins Monday in Kansas City, then moves to Minnesota.

headline: Battle for Libya | Aug. 9, 2011
text: People sifted through the debris of a destroyed home that Libyan loyalists say was hit by a NATO bomb in the town of Majar, near Zlitan.

headline: Project Runway, on 4 Legs
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — J. J. Crupi is the horseflesh man. Eddie Rosen is the pedigree guy. Dr. Randy Brandon is the veterinarian who makes sure that the horse whose looks Crupi is enamored with, with the regal bloodlines Rosen vouches for, is, indeed, a healthy yearling worth the hundreds of thousands that Mike Repole might spend on him.

headline: Al Jazeera Changes Plan to Rerun Documentary
text: Al Jazeera English has quashed several planned rebroadcasts of “Shouting in the Dark,” an hourlong documentary about Bahrain’s crackdown on pro-democracy protesters that had its debut last week and brought complaints from Bahraini authorities.

headline: In an Enclave of Small Firms, Big Developers Knock
text: When Nancy Aber Goshow opened her architecture firm’s offices on 25th Street between Broadway and Sixth Avenue about 25 years ago, walking to work from her apartment on 16th Street was a lonely and at times even harrowing experience. Vacant properties and parking lots, she recalled, gave much of the area a desolate quality despite its location near the heart of the city.

headline: A Mass Grave, 70 Years Later
text: Khotyn, Ukraine

headline: Unanimous Yes Vote on Los Angeles Stadium
text: The Los Angeles City Council on Tuesday unanimously approved a tentative agreement with a private developer to build a $1.2 billion football stadium, in hopes of attracting an N.F.L. team back to downtown.

headline: The Revenge of the Rating Agencies
text: Washington

headline: In Siding With Leaders, Freshman Found a Voice
text: WASHINGTON — From her spot on a podium at a recent news conference on Capitol Hill, Representative Renee Ellmers, Republican of North Carolina, looked slightly nervous.

headline: Redefining the Hot Dog, a Cart at a Time
text: GET this: There are children in New York who have never eaten a hot dog.

headline: How Do You Want That Hot Dog?
text: “To say that I grew up eating those dirty-water dogs on the street is an understatement,” Alexandra Guarnaschelli told me when we got to talking about New York hot dogs for this week’s Dining article. “I have a very important memory of my father picking me up from school every day, and we would walk to the corner and we would eat a hot dog together.”

headline: Charges Against Ugandan Opposition Leader Are Dropped
text: A Ugandan court has dropped charges against an opposition politician, Kizza Besigye, who organized and led street protests against the government in the spring.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,685 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: California: Los Angeles Stadium Plan Is Approved
text: The Los Angeles City Council on Tuesday unanimously approved a tentative agreement with a private developer to build a $1.2 billion football stadium, in hopes of attracting an N.F.L. team back to downtown. The terms of the agreement with the developer, Anschutz Entertainment Group, allow for the demolition and relocation of part of the Los Angeles Convention Center to make room for the 72,000-seat stadium, which could open as soon as 2016. The city’s approval of the downtown stadium plan is a blow to a competing plan to build a N.F.L. stadium in the nearby City of Industry. Anschutz Entertainment Group has promised to finance the stadium and two parking lots without any cost to Los Angeles taxpayers. Over the next nine months, the City Council will negotiate terms and then vote on final approval.

headline: Returning Ground Zero to New Yorkers
text: If you have not laid eyes on the World Trade Center site for a while, the view now is nothing short of astonishing. It looks like a space for human beings. Much of the plaza has been set up; swamp oaks have been planted; fountains are running inside the two giant squares that were the footprints of the towers destroyed 10 years ago; the names of the dead are inscribed along the borders of the squares.

headline: London Rioting Prompts Fears Over Soccer and Olympics
text: Fearing for the safety of players and fans amid the rioting in London, soccer officials on Tuesday canceled two international matches and may postpone the opening weekend of the English Premier League, prompting questions about the city’s ability to secure high-profile events like soccer matches and next summer’s Olympics.

headline: New York on a Bun
text: The city’s hot dogs through the years, both the classic specimens and more newfangled inventions with fussier toppings and upgraded meat.

headline: In Tumult, New Hope for Palestinian Cause
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila, a corner of Beirut bearing the scars of massacres and an enduring despair, the words of a young barber hinted at an emerging optimism about what the Arab revolts could mean for a central issue of the last half century in the Middle East: the fate of Palestinians.

headline: A Caddie Speaks Out, and Some Players Say He’s Speaking Out of Turn
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.

headline: A Debate on Death Spirals and Arctic Resilience
text: Joe Romm has predictably assailed my rejection of his “death spiral” depiction of Arctic sea ice trends, straying into discussions of melting permafrost (which is an entirely different issue laden with its own questions — one being why the last big retreat of permafrost, in the Holocene’s warmest stretch, didn’t have a greenhouse-gas impact) and my refusal to proclaim a magically safe level of carbon dioxide (which I discuss here).

headline: Hardball Played as a Slow-Pitch Game
text: Baseball’s rule book says pitchers can take no more than 12 seconds between pitches with the bases empty.

headline: Half-Measures From the Fed
text: It came as no surprise on Tuesday when the Federal Reserve said that the economy was in a more precarious state than it had previously believed. It was refreshing that the Fed stopped blaming “transitory” factors like supply-chain disruptions from Japan and acknowledged, in effect, that this year’s rising joblessness and slowing growth are more than temporary setbacks.

headline: New York City Will Mandate Sex Education
text: For the first time in nearly two decades, students in New York City’s public middle and high schools will be required to take sex-education classes beginning this school year, using a curriculum that includes lessons on how to use a condom and the appropriate age for sexual activity.

headline: Serving Shareholders and Democracy
text: When the Supreme Court ruled that the government may not ban campaign spending by corporations in the landmark Citizens United decision last year, it argued that disclosure of contributions would protect American democracy from hidden corporate agendas.

headline: Timely Help for the Port Authority
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York have both expressed concern about the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey’s proposed 50 percent increase in bridge and tunnel tolls — from $8 to $12 as soon as next month, with another $2 jump in three years. Mr. Cuomo called the increase a “nonstarter” but promised to study it. Mr. Christie said his first reaction was: “You’re kidding, right?”

headline: Apple May Be Underpriced
text: Could Apple be worth $1 trillion? It’s conceivable. The $347 billion maker of iPhones and iPads became — if only briefly — the most valuable company in the United States when it overtook Exxon Mobil on Tuesday. Yet Apple’s sales have been surging 80 percent a year, and its profit faster. What’s more, it trades roughly in line with the growing stock market — and at less than half the price-to-earnings multiple it fetched in 2006, when revenue growth was much slower.

headline: No Plans for 2013, but an Actor Seems Focused on the Mayor’s Office
text: Alec Baldwin is not running for mayor of New York — yet.

headline: Kesey’s Trip, in Living Color
text: Ken Kesey’s cross-country bus trip with the Merry Pranksters in 1964 was supposed to be a movie. “The world’s first acid film,” as Tom Wolfe explained, “taken under conditions of total spontaneity barreling through the heartlands of America, recording all now, in the moment.” That’s why the bus was packed not just with LSD, speed and grass, but also speakers, mikes and wires.

headline: Cuomo Weighs Ending State Limits on Casino Gambling
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, suggesting it was time for the state to “come to grips” with the proliferation of gambling in New York and neighboring states, said Tuesday that he was weighing the legalization of commercial, non-Indian casinos in New York State.

headline: These Aren’t the Angels You Remember
text: The Philadelphia Phillies traded Bobby Abreu in 2006, and soon they won a championship. Then the Yankees let Abreu go, and they won, too. Fifteen years in the majors, a glittering résumé, and no World Series to show for it.

headline: The Day Our Leaders Got Unstuck
text: This is a scary economic moment. The response we need is not easy, but it is totally obvious. We need a Grand Bargain between America’s two parties — and we need it right now. Until you read the following news article, we’ll be stuck in a world of hurt.

headline: Pagan Looks for Better Results From Leadoff Spot
text: The loss of Jose Reyes, who was put on the disabled list this week with a strained left hamstring, is particularly painful for the Mets because they lack a natural replacement for him in the leadoff spot.

headline: Unusual Summer of Political Calm Is Enjoyed by a Disputed Region
text: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — By this time last summer, this beleaguered city was a war zone. Dozens of people had been killed in clashes between stone-throwing protesters and heavily armed security forces. Each death prompted a fresh set of angry demonstrations that prompted even tougher crackdowns, leading to more bloodshed.

headline: 10 Years and a Diagnosis Later, 9/11 Demons Haunt Thousands

headline: ‘We Bled in the Corn’

headline: Making Medical Donations Work
text: In Friday’s Fixes column I wrote about organizations that collect usable surplus equipment and supplies from hospitals in the United States and ship it to hospitals that need them in poor countries.   Readers were generally enthusiastic about the environmental and health benefits of this idea, but some offered important cautions. Homira from Wash, D.C. (15) wrote:  “There are a slew of complex issues that make donations of any kind aside from financial  really poor practice for trying to help developing countries. When it comes to medical equipment donations, the consumables necessary to operate many of these machines, such as x-ray film, reagents, etc,  are often not considered prior to the donations; nor is life-cycle costing and maintenance and operational costing and support figured in. Subsequently we see a lot of discarded medical equipment lying around clinics, hospitals and dump sites in low-income countries we work in.”

headline: Abundance of News, but Mixed Sales, for News Magazines

headline: China: Agency Reports 500,000 Cyberattacks in 2010
text: A government agency said Tuesday that Chinese computers were the targets of nearly 500,000 cyberattacks in 2010. Nearly half the attacks originated outside China, and the most common type employed so-called Trojan Horse malware, according to the agency, the National Computer Network Emergency Response Coordination Center of China. In a report, the agency said that the largest number, or 15 percent, of those malware attacks originated in the United States. Trojan Horse malware is software that appears to be a useful application but is actually malevolent.

headline: For Better Grades, Try Gym Class
text: If you want a young person to focus intently in school and perform well on tests, should you first send him or her to gym class? That question, which has particular relevance for school districts weighing whether to reduce or ax their physical education programs to save money, motivated a number of stimulating new examinations into the interplay of activity and attention. Some of the experiments studied children; others looked at laboratory rats bred to have an animal version of attention deficit disorder. For both groups, exercise significantly affected their ability to concentrate, although some activities seemed to be better than others at sharpening attention.

headline: High-End Hamam Opens in Historic Istanbul Location
text: For years the domed structure between the Aya Sofia (Hagia Sophia) and the Blue Mosque was used as a state-run carpet shop. Kilims and halis were strewn every which way across marble navel stones under huge domes that let shafts of light illuminate the structure built in 1556 by the famed architect Sinan to house the baths of Roxelana, known locally as Hurrem. (Hurrem was the slave who became the powerful wife of Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent.) Now, thanks to a $10 million restoration, the marble-clad space is once again a Turkish bath house, with separate facilities for men and women.

headline: Big Banks Shrinking as S.B.A. Lenders
text: The Small Business Administration’s guaranteed business loan program is back. Nudged by stimulus provisions that reduced fees and increased guarantees, American banks made a record amount of S.B.A.-backed loans in 2010 (measured in dollars), reversing a demoralizing four-year slide. But there’s something noteworthy about who was doing that lending: while banks as a whole loaned more government-backed money than ever, the biggest banks loaned less.

headline: The Two-Minus-One Pregnancy
text: As Jenny lay on the obstetrician’s examination table, she was grateful that the ultrasound tech had turned off the overhead screen. She didn’t want to see the two shadows floating inside her. Since making her decision, she had tried hard not to think about them, though she could often think of little else. She was 45 and pregnant after six years of fertility bills, ovulation injections, donor eggs and disappointment — and yet here she was, 14 weeks into her pregnancy, choosing to extinguish one of two healthy fetuses, almost as if having half an abortion. As the doctor inserted the needle into Jenny’s abdomen, aiming at one of the fetuses, Jenny tried not to flinch, caught between intense relief and intense guilt.

headline: Lost in a Daydream
text: Once there was this English showgirl and she used to take the stage right before Archie Rice came on, but now she is old and can barely get up from her rocking chair — but there is a trunkful of her tattered dance shoes up in the attic. And maybe she was your grandma and you just discovered them. Or maybe your granny (great-granny?) was a weathered-but-gorgeous sharecropper, a Dust Bowl refugee in frayed frock and battered boots, only — wait! — what if those boots were splattered with glitter?

headline: Got to Boogie on the Disco ‘Round: Studio 54 Radio on SiriusXM
text: 6:13 p.m. | Updated  Disco may have died, gone undercover or been lying in wait along with other 1970s fixtures like oil crises, economic malaise and wide-legged pants. In any case, it is being recalibrated for SiriusXM, the satellite radio broadcaster, which is starting a four-on-the-floor channel called Studio 54 on Aug. 15, the company will announce on Wednesday.

headline: Times Readers React to the London Riots
text: In response to the riots in Britain, NYTimes.com readers have largely divided into two camps. Many of our British readers view the riots as the sum of a materialistic culture and a welfare state that has spoiled its citizenry. Others, while refusing to support violent tactics, believe the rich have hoarded their nation’s wealth, and the resulting social unrest is inevitable. Here is a sampling of some of the nearly 700 comments we received on yesterday’s articles and blog posts.

headline: City Ballet Offers New Discount Program
text: Subscribers to New York City Ballet’s Fourth Ring Society will be offered a new discount program for the 2011-12 season starting on Aug. 29. The program, called Society NYCB, will be the same as it was last season for the Fourth Ring Society, which was discontinued. There will be a $20 annual membership fee, and tickets will cost $15 (plus a $2 facility fee). They can be purchased by phone or at the box office;  the standard ticket service fee of $7 will be waived and tickets will not be available online.

headline: Timely | Northern Lights
text: In indie rock, it’s not so much who you know as who knows you. And all the right people have come to know First Aid Kit, a Swedish folk duo made up of the sisters Johanna (left) and Klara Söderberg. They were discovered by Karin Dreijer Andersson (one half of the Swedish sibling duo the Knife), who released their first EP. They met Conor Oberst on the Monsters of Folk tour in Sweden; he introduced them to the producer of their next album. When First Aid Kit passed through Nashville on their American tour, Jack White invited them to record for his label. Part of a proud folk tradition — they “enjoy singing older songs,” Johanna says — they chose to rework Buffy Sainte-Marie’s “Universal Soldier,” a protest song from the ’60s, whose message “is unfortunately still very relevant today.”

headline: Suspect Charged in Groping Attacks
text: The man taken into custody Tuesday in connection with a string of groping attacks on the Upper East Side was charged late Tuesday night with burglary, sexual abuse and forcible touching in three of the encounters.

headline: How to Beat Roaming Fees While Traveling Abroad
text: LAST week’s column suggested ways to save when calling home from abroad. This week I’ll tackle data roaming fees, which wireless providers charge when customers use their phones outside their service area. With travelers using smartphones and other wireless devices abroad in the same way as they do back home (to check e-mail, to update Facebook and Twitter and to pull up online maps), the skyrocketing fees are taking many by surprise.

headline: MTV to Start Webcast Devoted to Emerging Bands
text: It has been two years since “New York Noise,” a beloved public television show devoted to the city’s underground rock bands, went off the air. Now an online subsidiary of MTV has hired the producer behind that show, Shirley Braha, to do a half-hour Webcast of indie videos in her humorous and playful style.

headline: Claude Laydu, French Actor, Dies at 84
text: Claude Laydu, a French actor best known for his screen debut in the lead role of Robert Bresson’s critically acclaimed early-1950s film “Diary of a Country Priest,” died on July 29 in Paris. He was 84.

headline: Putting the Cod Back in Cape Cod
text: I love fishing, which was one of the ways, growing up in Rhode Island, that I developed my broader passion for the wider living world outside of the human-built one. As a kid paddling around in a dinghy, I could “feel” the otherwise invisible seabed by bouncing my weighted hand line off the bottom. While waiting for a bite fishing for mackerel from a floating dock, I’d stick my head down close to the water and peer at the fascinating assemblage of small shrimp, sea squirts and other creatures growing on the immersed wood and floats.

headline: Francesco Quinn, Actor in ‘Platoon,’ Dies at 48
