headline: McIlroy Stays Mum Over Olympic Team Allegiance
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland, the 2011 United States Open champion, said Wednesday that he was looking forward to playing in the 2016 Summer Olympics golf tournament, although he did not indicate which nation he planned to represent. It has been a delicate subject for McIlroy, and his countryman Graeme McDowell, the 2010 United State Open champion. There have been veiled indications that they might represent Britain or Ireland in 2016, but recently each golfer seems eager to be vague on the subject.

headline: ‘Godspell’ Finds Its Jesus  in ‘Weeds’ Co-Star
text: Hunter Parrish has found religion — at least on  Broadway. Mr. Parrish, who stars as a hunky troubled teenager on the Showtime series “Weeds,” and played a hunky mopey teenager in “Spring Awakening,” will next take on the role of Jesus in a revival of “Godspell,” its producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: On CNN, a Son’s Photo Honors a Fallen Soldier
text: 4:05 p.m. | Updated Bryan Nichols, the father of Braydon Nichols, died in Afghanistan on Saturday when insurgents shot down a helicopter carrying 30 Americans and eight Afghans. Braydon, 10, noticed that television newscasts were showing photos of some of the service members, but not of his father. So he sent a picture to CNN.

headline: M.L.S. and NBC Sports Announce New TV Deal
text: Major League Soccer and NBC Sports on Thursday will announce a new three-year agreement to televise 45 league matches and 4 United States national team games on the main network and on the NBC Sports Network, which will be the new name of the current cable station Versus. The deal will end the league’s relationship with Fox Soccer, which recently signed a one-year deal to carry matches in 2011.

headline: Swapping Meat for Nuts to Lower Diabetes Risk
text: Eating red meat, and in particular processed red meat like bacon and hot dogs, raises the risk of Type 2 diabetes. But replacing just one serving a day with nuts or low-fat dairy can lower the risk, according to a study by Harvard researchers.

headline: Harri Holkeri, Northern Ireland Peace Negotiator, Is Dead at 74
text: Harri Holkeri, a former Finnish prime minister who helped shepherd talks that led to the historic 1998 peace agreement in Northern Ireland, died on Sunday in Helsinki. He was 74.

headline: Restored Monument Returns to St. Paul’s
text: The nation’s first official monument is back in place after three and a half months of 21st-century restoration on stone and marble that took 10 years to fabricate and deliver in the 18th century.

headline: Philadelphia Fights Violent Flash Mobs With Curfews
text: As British leaders struggle to contain spreading violence on their country’s streets, at least one commentator, writing in The Daily Telegraph, has suggested they look to Philadelphia for answers.

headline: Stephen Sondheim Takes Issue With Plan for Revamped ‘Porgy and Bess’
text: There’s a spanking new version of “Porgy and Bess” on the way, one that seeks to transform the classic 1935 opera into a commercial Broadway musical. To that end, the director Diane Paulus and the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks have added new scenes, punched up some dialogue, invented biographical details and — most radically — added a more upbeat ending. Such tinkering with the renowned  Gershwin work was bound to draw fire from some quarters, and indeed it has, following the publication of an Arts & Leisure article by Patrick Healy about the production, which stars Audra McDonald and Norm Lewis. It begins performances at the American Repertory Theater next Wednesday in Cambridge, Mass., with plans to transfer to Broadway next winter.

headline: 12th Suspect in Hacking Scandal Arrested in London
text: As the police in London questioned a 12th suspect in connection with Britain’s widening phone hacking scandal on Wednesday, Scotland Yard announced that Dick Fedorcio, its longtime director of public affairs, had been placed on extended leave until the criminal inquiries were concluded.

headline: All-Nighters for a Football Team During Ramadan
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — The clock reached midnight as Sunday ticked into Monday, and someone yelled, “It’s go time!” Football season could officially begin. New balls appeared, and players at Fordson High School prepared to do what had long been done in this hometown of Henry Ford: build something with assembly-line precision and reliability.

headline: Cards That Help Save on Airline Baggage Fees
text: If you’ve flown anywhere recently, you know that travelers are increasingly trying to cram more luggage into the overhead bins to avoid those pesky checked-baggage fees that generally start at $25 a bag. Some credit cards, though, can help reduce the fee burden — and maybe even reduce time wasted as attendants pry excess bags from the hands of desperate passengers and wheel them away to be checked.

headline: Paulson Fund Down 31% for the Year
text: The year keeps getting worse for the hedge fund titan John A. Paulson.

headline: Rockefeller Foundation Announces Cultural Grants for New York City Groups
text: The Rockefeller Foundation announced on Wednesday the recipients of its Cultural Innovation Fund grants, which will distribute nearly $3 million over two years to 16 New York City-based organizations.

headline: Rookie Hopes to Fill Holes, and Make Them
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Being a member of a vanishing breed has its advantages.

headline: Faith and Football Meet in Wee Hours
text: Two-a-day football practices at Fordson High School in Dearborn, Mich., whose enrollment is 90 percent Muslim, coincided this week with Ramadan, leading to an interesting scheduling solution.

headline: Ochocinco’s Next Move
text: In today’s bizarre news, Chad Ochocinco would like to move in with you. O.K., maybe not you exactly. You’d have to be a New England Patriots fan, living within a reasonable commute of Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Mass., and presumably in a home with indoor plumbing. Ochocinco also requests you own an Xbox.

headline: Woods, Upbeat and Smiling, Says Little About Williams’s Remarks
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — When Tiger Woods entered the room, stage right, for his Wednesday morning news conference at the Atlanta Athletic Club, he was greeted by the largest news media contingent of the week by a margin even wider than the smile he wore for the occasion.

headline: Six Republicans Named to Deficit Panel
text: The top Republicans in the House and the Senate appointed six more lawmakers on Wednesday to the bipartisan committee that is supposed to recommend steps to reduce federal budget deficits by at least $1.5 trillion over 10 years.

headline: Asked & Answered | Sean Patrick Maylone
text: With K-pop groups like the Wonder Girls on the ascent — and sitting front row at the Chloé show in Shanghai — it’s clear that Korean pop is having a moment. But is there a Korean underground? According to Sean Patrick Maylone, the answer is yes. His Seoul-based booking and promotion agency, SuperColorSuper, has helped to create a South Korean tour circuit for indie bands like Caribou, Das Racist and CocoRosie, blazing a trail not just to Seoul, but also to Busan and Daegu, places the 30-year-old native Californian knew nothing about when he arrived in Korea to teach English four years ago. Here, Maylone discusses South Korea’s burgeoning underground music scene.

headline: Who Needs Summer Homework?
text: Have you finished your homework?

headline: Growing Concern Over France’s Top Credit Rating Spreads Market Anxiety
text: PARIS — With the sense of economic crisis deepening in Europe after the United States debt downgrade, investors have played Who’s Next with the shrinking list of nations that still hold the top rating of AAA. And their sights have landed on France.

headline: Live Blog: Q.&A. With Bank of America’s Chief
text: Bank of America may not be your top pick – but it is a favorite of Fairholme Capital Management.

headline: The Caucus Click: Campaign 2012, Iowa Style
text: Eventually, the presidential candidates will have huge rallies in stadiums with thousands, or even tens of thousands, of loud, enthusiastic supporters. But not yet.

headline: Middle Class? At $9.5 Million, Actor’s Home Is Far From It
text: The actor Alec Baldwin has not yet begun running for mayor of New York, but he is already saying things that could alienate the great number of voters who cannot afford expensive neighborhoods.

headline: Karzai Annuls Afghan Court Reviewing 2010 Polls
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a startling reversal on Wednesday, President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan annulled a special court that he had set up to review the results of the 2010 parliamentary elections.

headline: Is the House G.O.P. Warming to Tax Increases?
text: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -– While last month’s Congressional tangle over the debt ceiling suggested permanent partisan gridlock, signs are emerging that some House Republicans are opening the door to potential revenue increases, as Congressional leaders continued to name their members of a bipartisan committee charged with finding ways to tame the deficit.

headline: To Swim or Not to Swim?
text: John Lipscomb, the captain of a boat that regularly plies the Hudson River for the environmental group Riverkeeper, says that on hot sunny days he sees “hundreds and hundreds of people” swimming in the river off official and unofficial beaches and off drifting boats.

headline: Adele Still No. 1, but Jay-Z and Kanye West are in Hot Pursuit
text: This week on the Billboard charts Adele continues her remarkable run with a 12th week at No. 1, but big competition from Jay-Z and Kanye West is right behind her.

headline: Nervously Watching as the Economy Churns
text: Wall Street, we know, is roiling. The extraordinary events of the last two weeks — the brinksmanship in Washington over raising the federal debt limit, the downgrade of the government’s credit rating by Standard & Poor’s, and the debt trouble across the Atlantic in Europe — have pummeled stocks and dizzied traders.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 10
text: Francesca Schiavone advanced at the Rogers Cup women’s tennis event in Toronto and golfers completed their final practice rounds ahead of the P.G.A. Championship in Johns Creek, Ga.

headline: Cooking Classes, Live on Google+
text: Google Hangouts, a feature of Google+, Google’s new social network, lets people video-chat, watch YouTube clips together and even take turns belting out rounds of karaoke.

headline: A Nurse, a Patient and a Television
text: Hospital patients watch a lot of television to pass the time. As a result, nurses often catch glimpses of news and entertainment programs while walking in and out of patient rooms.

headline: From Alpinestars, a Motorcycle Suit That Inflates to Protect the Rider
text: When Jorge Lorenzo, the Yamaha factory racer, was catapulted from his bike in a crash while practicing at Laguna Seca on July 22, sensors in his suit read that he hit the pavement with the force of 25.3 Gs. It’s the kind of impact that can shatter bones and careers, but Lorenzo not only walked away from the crash, he placed second at the track two days afterward in the Red Bull United States Grand Prix.

headline: Are You Prepared for a Double-Dip Recession?
text: We just published an article that surveyed small-business owners on the impact of recent financial news, and their coping strategies for a possible double-dip recession. “We’ve been through this before,” said Elizabeth Lunney, who is co-founder and chief executive of the language school ABC Language Exchange and who shared her experiences with daily deal Web sites in a previous post. Here’s what she had to say:

headline: Designer Named for Final Cunningham Performances
text: The final visual artist to collaborate with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company – a list that includes heavyweights like Jasper Johns, Robert Rauschenberg and Andy Warhol – will be Daniel Arsham. For his fourth collaboration with the company, Mr. Arsham, an artist who has designed sets, lighting and costumes for Merce Cunningham, will fill the Park Avenue Armory with “clouds” of colored spheres; the design will be used in the company’s final performances, on Dec. 29 to 31 at the armory.

headline: TBS Cancels ‘Lopez Tonight’
text: 3:50 p.m. | Updated TBS on Wednesday cancelled George Lopez’s late-night show, less than a year after the network moved “Lopez Tonight” from 11 p.m. to midnight to make room for Conan O’Brien.

headline: Hi Mark! It’s the F.T.C. Calling…
text: A couple of representatives of the Federal Trade Commission, evidently stung by my column last week (in which I called the agency “spineless”), scheduled a phone call to remind me that the F.T.C. doesn’t have the ability to pass legislation that determines how Big Food markets to children.

headline: The Caucus | Romney and Perry Face Off
text: Two men not competing in the Iowa Straw Poll this weekend are nonetheless garnering most of the attention. Also, the view from the political columnist at the Des Moines Register.

headline: Filing Challenge to Census, City Says 50,000 Weren’t Counted in 2 Boroughs
text: Invoking the Census Bureau’s own data and other evidence, New York City officials argued on Wednesday that the 2010 count had overlooked at least 50,000 residents of Brooklyn and Queens living in homes and apartments that the bureau incorrectly concluded were vacant.

headline: China Releases Dissident Blogger, With Conditions
text: BEIJING — One of China’s more prolific bloggers, whose introspective musings on democracy, human rights and fatherhood earned him tens of thousands of followers but also charges of inciting subversion, was unexpectedly released after nearly six months in police custody, his wife said Wednesday.

headline: As Markets Swing, HomeStreet and WageWorks Delay I.P.O.’s

headline: Caucus Video: Romney and Perry Prepare to Face Off; A Look at Straw Poll History
text: Jeff Zeleny reports from Iowa on two men who aren’t competing in the straw poll this weekend but are garnering most of the attention nonetheless. Also, Kathie Obradovich, the political columnist at The Des Moines Register, sits down for an interview about the field and lessons from Iowa political history.

headline: Children’s Museum of Manhattan Receives Grant for Muslim Exhibition
text: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan has received a $40,000 planning grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to develop a major exhibition on Muslim culture, the museum said on Wednesday. The exhibition, planned for 2014, will be called “Muslim Worlds” and will emphasize the diversity of Muslim culture.

headline: Slumping Goydos Waits for a Chance That May Not Come
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — The P.G.A. Tour pro Paul Goydos waited until his peers had cleared the Atlanta Athletic Club Highlands course Wednesday afternoon before squeezing in nine practice holes solo. Same routine Tuesday.

headline: Who Says Turtles Don’t Eat Pasta?

headline: Trains Back to Normal, Day After Derailment

headline: S.E.C. Sues Stifel Nicolaus Over Wisconsin School Investments
text: 4:12 p.m. | Updated The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Stifel, Nicolaus & Company on Wednesday, accusing the Midwestern brokerage firm of duping five Wisconsin school districts into buying $200 million in dubious investments.

headline: The War Memoirist’s Dilemma
text: In a detailed article last month, The Associated Press reported that a former Army captain, Luis Carlos Montalvan, distorted several of his Iraq war experiences in a memoir he co-authored. Ever since, I have been thinking a great deal about the dilemma of truth in war memoirs.

headline: Congressman Questions White House on Bin Laden Film

headline: Gen X Golden Oldies: Teenage Girl Edition
text: I was a teenager in the 1990s, and after reading Hugo’s “Gen X Golden Oldies” mix, I felt like I had to represent for the “Gen X” (ugh) girls. If there was ever a great musical moment to be an awkward, angst-ridden teenage girl, it was the early ’90s. So I made my own “I know ’90s nostalgia isn’t cool, but here are all my favorite ’90s songs anyway” mix. This is what the girls were listening to while the boys were off air-guitaring to the Grifters.

headline: Rock Steady
text: As natural attractions go, Norway’s Pulpit Rock makes a jaw-dropping first impression on visitors.

headline: 2nd Ex-Officer in Rape Case Is Sentenced for Misconduct
text: A former New York police officer who was convicted of official misconduct in a case in which his partner was accused of raping a drunken woman was sentenced on Wednesday to two months in jail.

headline: Wisc. Results Suggest Recall of Governor Would Be Close

headline: Beauty Spots
text: LET’S TWIST Known for sunglasses and flowing animal-printed maxi-dresses, Rachel Zoe, the stylist and reality-television star, is now promoting a new line of lipsticks and glosses, Exude, with a slanted applicator made of crystal. Users twist the case so that the product, which has a creamy gel-like consistency, is pushed up through a hole; anything extra is then sucked down into the tube for later use, avoiding the kind of crushing that can happen with traditional sticks. In nine creme colors including coral, nude and red, and five gloss shades, among them crimson and dusty pink. Both formulas are mint-scented and contain Vitamin E ($29 each at exudelipstick.com).

headline: A New York Poem by the New Poet Laureate
text: Philip Levine,  the new United States poet laureate, grew up in Detroit and lives in Fresno, Calif. As Dwight Garner writes in his appraisal, Mr. Levine is “known for his emphasis on the voice of the ordinary workingman and the industrial heartland.”

headline: Under an Economic Glare, the Italians Are Perplexed
text: ROME — Concerns about the stagnant Italian economy and its heavy public debt have buffeted global financial markets in recent weeks. But for ordinary Italians, the prevailing emotion is more bafflement than anxiety.

headline: Some in Germany Want Greece to Temporarily Exit the Euro Zone
text: FRANKFURT — If the European debt crisis were an old survival movie, there would be a scene in which the passengers in a lifeboat realize that they don’t have enough food and water for everyone and that someone needs to go over the side. We’re looking at you, Greece.

headline: Westway Club in the West Village
text: CONTRARY to earlier reports, you won’t find any stripper poles (or topless women) at Westway, the new club from Matt Kliegman and Carlos Quirarte, the masterminds behind the Smile and the Jane Ballroom parties.

headline: NBC Snags Most Viewers as Fox Lands Younger Ones
text: It was another split night among the broadcast networks on Tuesday as the cooking combo of “Hell’s Kitchen” and “MasterChef” helped Fox win the 18- to 49-year-old ratings category. Meanwhile, “America’s Got Talent” on NBC was the most watched program of the night with 11.2 million total viewers, boosting the overall average of viewers for NBC to 8.9 million.

headline: Bubba Remembers Bubba
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — If Bubba Watson wins his first major Sunday in the P.G.A. Championship at the Atlanta Athletic Club, he could dedicate it to the memory of his nickname-sake.

headline: An Ice Expert Muses on Greenhouse Heat
text: Ignatius G. Rigor, a ocean, ice and climate researcher at the University of Washington, has long been on my go-to list when grappling with studies of sea ice and climate. I sent him my post on new insights about Arctic ice retreats in the last big northern warm period — a 2,500-year “optimum,” ending around 6,000 years ago, when the region was several degrees warmer on average than today. He and I exchanged some thoughts about his scientific and personal reactions to the study and broader trends and I invited him to consolidate them in a “Your Dot” contribution:

headline: Designer Loses Bid to Protect Signature Shoes
text: The signature red soles on Christian Louboutin high heels, so famous they inspired a song by Jennifer Lopez and made countless cameos on “Sex and the City,” could one day show up on shoes sold at Payless.

text: Apple has a knack for turning friends into frenemies.

headline: Santa Fe Opera to Present Three New Works
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — Charles MacKay, the general director of the Santa Fe Opera, announced on Wednesday that at a time of economic hardship and cutbacks among many arts institutions, his company would present a new opera in three consecutive seasons, starting in the summer of 2013. These include the first commissioned works of Mr. MacKay’s tenure, which began in 2008.

headline: In U.S. Stress Tests, a Tool to Gauge Contagion in Europe

headline: Fans With Cellphones Welcomed at the P.G.A.

headline: In Iowa, Romney Is Comfortable at the Round Table

text: WATERLOO, Iowa — Ron Paul has none of the bravado of his Republican presidential rivals. At a town hall meeting here on Wednesday afternoon, he spoke for 35 minutes and then promptly apologized.

headline: Around the State, Exhibits Will Mark 9/11 Anniversary

headline: A Month of Roman Polanski Films
text: It looks like September will be Roman Polanski month. First the New York Film Festival announced its opening-night selection, on Sept. 30, would be the director’s latest project, “Carnage,” based on the play “God of Carnage.” Now comes news that the Museum of Modern Art is mounting what it is billing as “a complete retrospective” of the director’s work.

headline: On Trial, Gundlach Stands Defiant

headline: Irish Theater Festival to Offer Premieres and Vegetables
text: Premieres, imported and homegrown works, and at least one vegetable circus will be part of 1st Irish, the annual festival of Irish theater, its organizers announced. The fourth-annual program, which runs from Sept. 5 to Oct. 3, includes work by 16 contemporary Irish playwrights, panel discussions and a film screening.

headline: What Befits a Leader in Hard Times? An Intimate Knowledge of Insanity
text: The premise of Dr. Nassir Ghaemi’s book about leadership and mental illness is simple. It need not be reiterated as frequently as Dr. Ghaemi repeats it. But he begins “A First-Rate Madness” by writing, “This book argues that in at least one vitally important circumstance insanity produces good results and sanity is a problem.” To put it only a shade differently: “When our world is in tumult, mentally ill leaders function best.” Or: “In the storm of crisis, complete sanity can steer us astray, while some insanity brings us to port.”

headline: All the Editors That Are Fit to Spoof
text: IF you’re a newspaper editor on stage or screen, you are, as often as not, crusty, loud and easily exasperated.

headline: Common Sleep Problem Raises Dementia Risk
text: Sleep-disordered breathing, or sleep apnea, is a common condition characterized by repeated awakenings and pauses in breathing during the night. People with the disorder often snore and gasp during sleep, and it has been associated with hypertension, cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Now a new study suggests it may also be associated with mental decline and dementia.

headline: City’s Cable Deals Will Bring Wi-Fi to 32 Parks

headline: Literary Lions, by Their Cubs
text: IT can be a blessing and a burden to be the daughter of a literary luminary. Milton’s daughters secured a kind of immortality by transcribing their blind father’s lengthy masterpiece, “Paradise Lost” (of which the writer and critic Samuel Johnson wrote, “None ever wished it longer than it is”). Mary Shelley, the daughter of the political philosopher William Godwin (who encouraged her creativity), grew up to marry the poet Shelley, wrote the novel “Frankenstein” and transcribed her friend Lord Byron’s poems.

headline: Japan’s Tsunami Gave Birth to Faraway Icebergs
text: Japan’s 9.0-magnitude earthquake in March was so powerful that it shifted the island of Honshu eight feet to the east and caused the deaths of at least 15,600 people. The resulting tsunami also produced a wave that radiated throughout the rest of the world’s oceans.

headline: Eleanor M. Josaitis, Housewife-Turned-Urban Activist, Dies at 79
text: DETROIT — Eleanor M. Josaitis, a former suburban housewife who in 1968 moved her family into a city scarred by riots and helped create a highly regarded nonprofit organization to combat poverty and racism, died on Tuesday in Livonia, Mich. She was 79.

headline: At Nationals, a Bid Promises What a Hand Doesn’t Deliver
text: At the Summer Nationals the two-day Mixed Board-a-Match Teams was won by Judith Bianco and Win Allegaert of New York, Peggy Kaplan of Minnetonka, Minn., and Petra Hamman and Hemant Lall of Dallas. They finished three and a half points ahead of Lisa and David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Fla.; Josef Blass of Chapel Hill, N.C.; and Ewa Harasimowicz, Anna Sarniak and Marcin Lesniewski from Poland.

headline: Profit Slides on Soft Sales, but Cisco Stays Upbeat
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Cisco Systems managed to encourage investors Wednesday despite sliding quarterly profits and flat revenue growth, prompting a nearly 7 percent run-up in its shares during after-hours trading.

headline: A new app from the F.B.I.; the NYT’s new beta620 site for experimental software projects; tech news.
text: A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation introduces the agency’s very first smartphone app, Child ID, which is intended for parents to use in case a child goes missing. Several members of the team on beta620, the new site for experimental features at The Times, stop by to chat about the project’s goals and current offerings for Times readers. The weekly serving of technology news includes a look at social media’s role in the London riots and a new survey on mobile app security.

headline: Turning a Water Tower Into a Home
text: Patrick Mets and his partner, Valérie Lecherf, live with her two daughters in a nearly 100-foot-tall water tower that he converted into a home.

headline: Sleepless in Atlanta, Director Is Confident in His Course
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Ken Mangum slept two and a half hours Tuesday night, but not from tossing and turning over concerns about the P.G.A. Championship course that he shepherds.

headline: Waging War in Somalia, a Country in Chaos
text: As debate continues in the United States over how to help Somalia, a country whose government is in transition, fight back against Shabab militants, private security companies backed by Washington financing have stepped in to train the African recruits’ counterterrorism efforts.

headline: One Cruel King, by Way of Vivaldi
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — Vivaldi would surely find it frustrating, if not a little strange, that his achievement as a composer today is distorted by the cultlike popularity of “The Four Seasons.” He was indeed a master of Baroque instrumental music. Still, from his early days he was powerfully drawn to the theater and to the voice. He wrote nearly 50 operas. Yet productions are rare. The mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli brought overdue attention to Vivaldi’s operas with a successful album of arias in 1999 and a subsequent concert tour.

headline: One Night Heralds ‘One Day’
text: SUMMER’S flings may be on their last legs, but not for Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess. Their romance is just blossoming on the silver screen anyway. The attractive co-stars were promoting their romantic film, “One Day,” based on the best-selling novel of the same title by the English author David Nicholls, on Monday night.

headline: Scene City: Post-Premiere Party for ‘One Night’
text: The film leaves guests teary-eyed, but the after-party doesn’t.

headline: Portraits of Grief
text: Explore the “Portraits of Grief” archive — more than 2,500 impressionistic sketches of the lives lost in the Sept. 11 attacks. With videos by Matthew Orr of six families 10 years later.

headline: Waging War in Somalia, a Country in Chaos
text: As debate continues in the United States over how to help Somalia, private security companies backed by Washington financing have stepped in to train the African recruits’ counterterrorism efforts.

headline: Nurturing Weird Families in Tennessee
text: SEWANEE, Tenn. — When writing his first novel two years ago Kevin Wilson didn’t have to look far for inspiration. It was running back and forth above his study.

headline: A new comedy by Zach Braff, "All New People,” and "The Patsy" starring David Greenspan.
text: A new comedy by Zach Braff, "All New People,” and "The Patsy" starring David Greenspan.

headline: Palin Joins the Iowa State Fair Party
text: The Iowa State Fair just got its newest, late-breaking attraction — and it’s not even on a stick.

headline: A Young Music Executive Takes Over at Motown
text: The fate of Motown, the storied record label now owned by the Universal Music Group, has been the subject of music-industry gossip since May, when news reports surfaced that Sylvia Rhone, its president and one of the most powerful women in the industry, was stepping down. One of the label’s biggest stars, Erykah Badu, stirred further controversy when she wrote on Twitter that Motown had “folded.”

headline: The Facebook Scare That Wasn’t
text: This may have popped into your Facebook feed Wednesday:

headline: Chilling Video of Tanks in Hama, Where Syrian Protesters Rallied Before Crackdown
text: Updated | Friday, 3:12 p.m. As my colleagues Anthony Shadid and Steven Lee Myers report, the Syrian government announced on Wednesday that military forces were being withdrawn from the central city of Hama, apparently marking a pause in the offensive there.

headline: Mozart’s ‘Jupiter,’ Still Celestial but More Personal
text: New York classical music audiences are getting to know the Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer, and that, it turns out, is all to the good.

headline: On New York’s Low Seas: Day 3
text: On Wednesday morning, a 79-year-old, shirtless man basked in the sun at the water’s edge, reclining on a broad sloping rock at the very northern tip of Manhattan.

headline: Left the Volga, Kept the Vulgar
text: If the Soviet authorities had wanted to torture Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn beyond endurance, they would have forced him to watch “Russian Dolls.”

headline: Waging War in Somalia, a Country in Chaos
text: As debate continues in the United States over how to help Somalia, a country whose government is in transition, fight back against Shabab militants, private security companies backed by Washington financing have stepped in to train the African recruits’ counterterrorism efforts.

headline: Handbook on Elegance Takes Form and Flight
text: The San Francisco troupe ODC/Dance actually planted its roots at Oberlin College in Ohio in 1971. (The cryptic initials stand for Oberlin Dance Collective.) In 1976 the company relocated to the West Coast, establishing a strong presence in the Mission District of its home city: along with a theater there are studios, a school and a health clinic for dancers.

headline: U.S. Relies on Contractors in Somalia Conflict
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Richard Rouget,  a gun for hire over two decades of bloody African conflict, is the unlikely face of the American campaign against militants in Somalia.

headline: Lyricism With a Dash of Soft Rock
text: “Genius!” someone cried from the audience. She meant it; no fooling. “Genius!”

headline: Postcard From Edinburgh: In the Belly of the Beast
text: EDINBURGH — One very recognizable sight at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for the past several years is a giant purple cow lying on its back in Bristo Square on the grounds of Edinburgh University.

headline: All-Natural Terraces
text: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

headline: Moderate Democrats Ask to Cut Recess Short
text: Recess is usually a time for members of Congress to distance themselves from Washington, in every sense. So it’s remarkable, especially in this venomously anti-incumbent environment, that four of the House’s most precarious incumbents want to come back to Washington ASAP.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Aug. 11
text: Lisa Perry has designed a series of dresses using Roy Lichtenstein images; what the actress Krysten Ritter is wearing how and other items.

headline: Scouting Report
text: POP-UPS

headline: A Road Not Taken Leads Back to the P.G.A.
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Steve Stricker played at the University of Illinois in 1989 on a team captained by Mike Small. Their paths have diverged, even as each was lined with golf course grass, and they stayed close enough to serve as best man in each other’s wedding.

headline: When East Met West Under the Buddha’s Gaze
text: After what seemed like an endless run of geopolitical roadblocks, “The Buddhist Heritage of Pakistan: Art of Gandhara” has finally come, six months late, from Pakistan to Asia Society. Is the show worth all the diplomatic headaches it caused? With its images of bruiser bodhisattvas, polycultural goddesses and occasional flights into stratosphere splendor, it is.

headline: A Cottage Just Right for Frodo
text: TROUT CREEK, Mont.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: The F.B.I.’s App
text: This week’s episode of the Bits: Tech Talk podcast looks at a new smartphone app created by the Federal Bureau of Investigation can help panicky parents get personal details to the authorities. As an F.B.I. spokesman, Paul Bresson, explains on this week’s show, the agency’s very first iPhone app is called Child ID. The free app lets parents compile a miniature mobile database of photos and written descriptions of a child right on the phone — where the information can be quickly pulled up and shared with police should that child ever go missing.

headline: Art of Gandhara
text: Images from a new exhibit at the Asia Society in New York City.

headline: Almost Time to Change the Bulb
text: YOU may have heard that the federal government wants to limit your choice of light bulbs, starting in January.

headline: Two Charged in Missing iPhone Prototype Case
text: It has been over a year since a public spectacle unfolded surrounding a prototype iPhone 4 that was lost in a bar and ended up featured on Gizmodo, the technology blog.

headline: Life in a Belgian Water Tower
text: STEENOKKERZEEL, Belgium

headline: What Is Driving the Riots?
text: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen talks about the possible motivations of Britain's disgruntled youth.

headline: A Star of Animal Planet’s ‘Tanked’ on the Art of the Aquarium
text: Fish in the wild can make for compelling television, as evidenced by the Discovery Channel’s popular Shark Week programming, but how about the domesticated version? “Tanked,” a new reality show on Animal Planet, follows two high-end aquarium builders, Wayde King and Brett Raymer, who run a family business in Las Vegas called Acrylic Tank Manufacturing (Mr. King is married to Mr. Raymer’s sister, Heather, another employee). In the Aug. 19 premiere, the men are approached by a casino to build perhaps the world’s first “mob-themed” fish tank for a new gangland attraction; later, they transform a phone booth into a home aquarium for a married couple.

headline: Shopping for Hurricane Lamps With Deborah Ehrlich
text: The designer shops for both high- and low-end hurricane lamps, a staple of outdoor entertaining.

headline: Making Design Out of Rubbish
text: TRENTON

headline: In St. Petersburg, a New W Hotel
text: The W St. Petersburg, which opened in Russia this spring, “is like a Fabergé egg,” said Mike Tiedy, the senior vice president of global brand design and innovation for Starwood Hotels and Resorts, the company that owns the hotel. “It opens up to reveal itself. From the outside, it looks typical of the city, but inside, you see layers of warmth and of reflection.”

headline: Sales at ABC Carpet & Home and Others
text: Modani Furniture is taking $300 off all king-size beds in its Flatiron store through Aug. 21 (the black Cavali storage bed with hydraulic lift, originally $1,730, is $1,430); 40 East 19th Street; (212) 796-6926 or modani.com.

headline: Wood and Leather Pieces, the Old-Fashioned Way
text: Daniel Heer may be genetically predisposed to his line of work. More than 100 years ago, his grandfather Benedikt Heer founded a saddlery in Switzerland, where he also made horsehair mattresses and leather goods. Mr. Heer, 33, also makes horsehair mattresses, leather goods and furniture, albeit from a studio in Berlin. His latest collection to be introduced in the United States is a series of handwoven leather and wood pieces — a stool, a daybed and a table, above — called Keil, or “wedge.”

headline: Hurricane Lamps
text: HURRICANE lamps are a staple of outdoor entertaining, in part because the glass cylinder that surrounds the candle keeps it from burning down too fast, providing hours of flickering light.

headline: Animal Farm Chip Clips From David Weeks
text: Created by David Weeks, a designer known for high-end modern light fixtures, Animal Farm chip clips are intended to give one pause while grazing in the kitchen. “It came from a kind of humor,” Mr. Weeks said. “Is this chip clip judging me as I eat more and more potato chips?”

headline: Roy Mackey’s Hammer Art
text: A few years ago, Roy Mackey, a Canadian sculptor who works with sheet steel, began thinking about the hammer-and-nail relationship, and the way one is always driving the other — unfairly, he thought. So he created a Mastercraft hammer with a head impaled by a nail, calling it Revenge.

headline: Sample of NBC-Bloomingdale's Partnership
text: In an except from NBC's 2011 Fall Primetime Preview, the host goes on a shopping spree at Bloomingdale's, which has a marketing partnership with NBC this fall.

headline: Bloggingheads: American Riots
text: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Reihan Salam of Economics 21 debate the possibility of London-style riots in America.

headline: As the Sun Rises, Two Legends Murmur
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The horses look like shadows at dawn as they cross Union Avenue, stopping traffic to shuttle between the Saratoga Race Course on the west side of the street and a timeless oasis on its east side: the Oklahoma training track. Think of it as a Club Med for horsemen who prefer spending their working vacation with their own kind amid an oasis that evokes a bygone year.

headline: Waging War in Somalia, a Country in Chaos
text: As debate continues in the United States over how to help Somalia, a country whose government is in transition, fight back against Shabab militants, private security companies backed by Washington financing have stepped in to train the African recruits’ counterterrorism efforts.

headline: Setting Industry Guidelines for Marketing Junk Food
text: To the Editor:

headline: Middle-Class Families Face Evictions in Azerbaijan
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — Before the notices started to arrive, Eldostu Elman had a pretty clear idea how his life would unfold, at least as far as the living arrangements. He would live in the apartment where he was raised, along with his parents, his sons and, when they eventually marry, their families.

headline: Isringhausen Is on Verge of a Milestone
text: Jason Isringhausen recorded his first major league save on July 6, 1999. He was then a failed starter in his final weeks on the Mets’ roster. And he was about to bounce around to three teams in the 11 seasons that followed, making exactly zero starts.

headline: Yankees Looking Up, and Down
text: For the past several weeks, as the Red Sox and Yankees have jockeyed for top position in the American League East, the consensus projection has been that the loser would end up with a clear path to the playoffs through the wild card anyway.

headline: Members of the Bipartisan Deficit Panel
text: How the deficit panel members have voted on recent budget bills.

headline: Italy’s Government Grapples With Deficit, Its Will Still Uncertain
text: ROME — Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s government has kicked into high gear, working over the August holidays to find ways to eliminate Italy’s budget deficit by 2013 as it pledged to do last week after the country was caught in the crosshairs of the sovereign debt crisis.

headline: Coping With Swimmer’s Sudden Death
text: CRYSTAL LAKE, Ill. — Fred McCullough felt a father’s strongest fears, but he stopped short of panicking when he learned that his daughter, Amy McCullough Martich, had been pulled from the water unconscious and taken to a hospital during the swimming portion of the New York City Triathlon on Sunday.

headline: All the Town’s a Stage Where the Bard’s Works Inspire Street Names
text: OTHELLO, Wash. — Zounds! Who goes there? Why, it is Othello, the Moor of Venice. Unlikely as it seems, this is his town — his name is plastered all over this small agricultural community about three hours southeast of Seattle.

headline: U.S. Seeks Ideas on Renting Out Foreclosed Property
text: WASHINGTON — Uncle Sam wants you — to rent a house from Uncle Sam.

headline: Rachel’s Last Fund-Raiser
text: Perhaps every generation of geezers since Adam and Eve has whined about young people, and today is no different. Isn’t it clear that in contrast to our glorious selves, kids these days are self-absorbed Facebook junkies just a pixel deep?

headline: Priest for Women’s Ordination Fights His Dismissal
text: A Roman Catholic priest who is campaigning to open the priesthood to women says he will contest a move by his religious order to dismiss him for his dissent. The priest, the Rev. Roy Bourgeois, said he had retained the Rev. Thomas Doyle, a canon lawyer best known as a whistleblower in the priest sexual abuse scandal, to press the case with the Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers. Father Doyle said he would argue that Father Bourgeois had a right to follow his conscience, and that the prohibition on women’s ordination was not an infallible church teaching, despite Vatican declarations. A Maryknoll spokesman said its general council would decide the next step.

headline: Macy’s and Polo Ralph Lauren Deliver Strong Quarterly Results
text: So far, at least, the tumbling stock market has not hurt one of the country’s biggest department store companies nor one of its most popular specialty retailers.

headline: A Familiar Brand Promotes a New Line of Cheesy and Easy
text: IN a commercial for Velveeta Cheesy Skillets, a new line of just-add-meat pasta dinner kits by Kraft, a casually dressed woman in a suburban home says, “Let’s go, kids,” opens the front door and gasps.

headline: Stop Using Chimps as Guinea Pigs
text: Washington

headline: U.S. Charges Former Executive of Marvell With Fraud
text: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg NewsMarvell Technology headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif.

headline: In Auto Test in Europe, Meter Ticks Off Miles, and Fee to Driver
text: EINDHOVEN, the Netherlands — As Sander Van Dedem recalled watching the charges tick up every 10 seconds on the dashboard meter on the way to the airport, he resolved to try public transportation next time.  “Looking at the money makes you realize that a car isn’t always a good idea,” said Mr. Van Dedem, a commercial sales manager for I.B.M. here.

headline: Verizon Landline Unit at Heart of Strike
text: In the nation’s largest strike in four years, Verizon Communications and its unions are deeply divided over the company’s assertions that its traditional landline business is performing so badly that it needs large-scale concessions.

headline: How the Brixton Riot Unfolded
text: How the riot unfolded in the London neighborhood of Brixton.

headline: While Reporting Robust Profit, Murdoch Vows to Stay Head of News Corp.
text: While defending his company as it faces accusations of widespread phone hacking in Britain, Rupert Murdoch insisted on Wednesday that he had the backing of News Corporation’s board and would stay on as its chief executive for the foreseeable future. Meanwhile, his company reported a drop in fourth-quarter profit but a gain for the year.

headline: True Throwback: Rays and Royals Play in Under 2 Hours
text: Major League Baseball’s goal is to keep games from exceeding three hours.

headline: New York Archdiocese Criticizes Sex-Ed Mandate
text: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York called a new city requirement that sex education be taught at all public middle and high schools “troubling” on Wednesday, and some Catholic officials said they would advise Catholic parents not to let their children participate.

headline: Klinsmann Makes Debut as U.S. Coach
text: PHILADELPHIA — In and around Lincoln Financial Field on Wednesday night, the scent of lighter fluid, grilling meat and spilled beer mixed with something else in the air: curiosity.

headline: Hispanic Organizations Give Obama and Congress a C
text: Leaders of the nation’s major Hispanic organizations, issuing their first progress report on their priority issues, gave C grades on Wednesday to President Obama and to Congress for their performance over the last two years. But they warned that even the small gains Hispanics have seen are at risk of being erased in negotiations by the bipartisan committee that will recommend ways to reduce the federal deficit.

headline: Ray Anderson, Businessman Turned Environmentalist, Dies at 77
text: Ray C. Anderson was chairman and chief executive of the world’s largest carpet-tile manufacturer when he read a book that described people like him as thieves and plunderers of the planet. He saw the author’s point. He even wept. Then he set out to change things.

headline: U.S.-Mexico: The Lineups
text: PHILADELPHIA — The starting lineups for the United States’ exhibition game against Mexico on Wednesday night at Lincoln Financial Field.

headline: Cameron’s Broken Windows
text: OUR son lives next to a Turkish mosque on Kingsland Road in Hackney, where some of London’s worst mob violence has occurred. When looters rampaged through Hackney last weekend, there were few police officers to stop them and residents had to chase them off with butcher knives, truncheons and baseball bats. Vigilante action succeeded where normal policing failed.

headline: As Investors, Chinese Turn to New York
text: Chinese banks have poured more than $1 billion into real estate loans in New York City in the past year. Investors from China are snapping up luxury apartments and planning to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on commercial and residential projects like Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn. Chinese companies have signed major leases at the Empire State Building and at 1 World Trade Center, which is the centerpiece of the rebuilding at ground zero.

headline: Even Rivera Has to Face the Ultimate Closer: Time
text: Poke around the database at any newspaper office, and you can find obituaries of the living. For famous people who are old or in poor health, it only makes sense to prepare.

headline: A Fund and Its Former Star Clash in Their Legal Battle
text: LOS ANGELES — Jeffrey Gundlach, as the manager of highly successful fixed-income funds, first at Trust Company of the West and more recently at his own business, has been called “the king of bonds.”

headline: Heavily Chaperoned, Mainland Tourists Flock to Taiwan
text: Last year 1.6 million mainland Chinese citizens visited Taiwan, an increase of nearly 70 percent from 2009.

headline: As Chinese Visit Taiwan, the Cultural Influence Is Subdued
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — As two dozen anxious Chinese travelers began their maiden voyage across the Taiwan Strait, their tour guide called an impromptu meeting in the airport departure lounge.

headline: Board Orders a Repeat of a California Union Election
text: The National Labor Relations Board said Wednesday that it was ordering a rerun of an election by 43,000 Kaiser Permanente employees in California to decide which union should represent them.

headline: 6 Republicans Named to Deficit Reduction Panel
text: WASHINGTON — The top Republicans in the House and the Senate appointed six lawmakers on Wednesday to a powerful new Congressional committee that is supposed to find ways to reduce federal budget deficits by at least $1.5 trillion over 10 years.

headline: Where Will Growth Come From?
text: Never has the world economy depended so much on the success of developing nations. A misguided focus on budget cutting has plunged the European Union and the United States down paths that will prolong their economic stagnation and perhaps tip them into another recession. The International Monetary Fund was forecasting 2 percent growth in the euro zone before the financial crisis spread to Italy. The Japanese economy is shrinking. Some top economists put the odds of a double-dip recession in the United States at 1 in 2.

headline: Statue of Liberty Interior Will Close for a Year
text: After the 9/11 attacks, the federal government closed the Statue of Liberty National Monument, the symbol of a nation’s dreams and one of the city’s best-known and most-visited tourist attractions. Allowing people inside would be unsafe, the National Park Service said, because rescuers might not be able to get them out in an emergency.

headline: At the P.G.A. Championship, the Pros Play With the Pros
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — There are golf professionals, and there are professional golfers. The former teach lessons, run local tournaments and take cash for greens fees and other services at the pro shop counter. The latter travel the world on a pro tour, usually have a personal coach or two, and frequently cash some hefty competition checks.

headline: Wisconsin’s Warning to Union-Busters
text: Five months after Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin pushed through a law stripping public unions of their bargaining rights, the Republican Party has paid a price. Two of the state senators who backed the law were thrown out of office by voters on Tuesday and replaced with Democrats. Mr. Walker’s opponents did not succeed in turning over the Senate, but it was still an impressive response to the governor’s arrogant overreach.

headline: Bridge Repairs by a Company Tied to Beijing
text: It is, perhaps, an odd juxtaposition: the construction company in charge of the $407 million renovation of the Alexander Hamilton Bridge, named after a founding father and the nation’s first Treasury secretary, is controlled by the Chinese government.

headline: Plan to Deal With Seekers of Asylum Roils Australia
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Just how tough should Australia be in its campaign to dissuade asylum seekers from undertaking perilous voyages to its shores?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sex Education, Long Overdue
text: For nearly 20 years, New York City failed to require sex education in all public schools. Individual schools decided whether students were provided vital programs that could help them avoid disease and teenage pregnancy.

headline: A Governor
text: I’ve always liked bridges and been a bit phobic about tunnels, particularly those that run under water. So when I read late last year that the Queensboro Bridge was being named after New York’s former mayor, Edward I. Koch, and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel for Hugh L. Carey, I felt that the former governor was being cheated. After all, the Tappan Zee Bridge, still majestic in its sweep across the Hudson even in its current dilapidated state, was named after Malcolm Wilson, the man Carey defeated for governor in 1974. And Robert F. Kennedy got the Triborough Bridge.

headline: 1969-70 Sex Education Curriculum for New York City Schools
text: A New York City Board of Education publication from 1969-70 outlining the sex education curriculum.

headline: No Shortage of Intrigue at Last Major
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — The 93rd P.G.A. Championship begins Thursday on the 7,467-yard, par-70 Highlands Course at the Atlanta Athletic Club, where the pressure of competing in the season’s final major championship combined with temperatures in the 90s will create sizzling drama.

headline: The U.S. Dollar Is Still the Top Choice
text: It will take more than a debt downgrade and two years of ultra-low interest rates to knock the dollar from its perch as the world’s reserve currency. Despite multiple setbacks, the dollar remains the lingua franca of global commerce and the currency of choice for foreign central banks.

headline: Psychiatric Disorder Found in Defendant
text: The man charged in the murder of an 8-year-old Brooklyn boy has a psychiatric disorder that includes schizoid tendencies, doctors evaluating him found in a preliminary examination, according to one of the man’s lawyers, Pierre Bazile.

headline: Race-Day Medications Face a Ban
text: Race-day medications will be banned in graded 2-year-old stakes beginning in 2012, the American Graded Stakes Committee announced Wednesday.

headline: Hedge Funds Get Unfamiliar Taste of Losing
text: For hedge funds, just one week can change their entire year.

headline: Hugh L. Carey, Statesman, Wit and Cook
text: Signing legislation to save Yonkers from default in earlier hard times, Gov. Hugh Carey raised his voice in song: “Who cares what banks fail in Yonkers?” he trilled at his cabaret best. “Long as you’ve got a kiss that conquers?”

headline: Fugitive Florida Siblings Arrested After Colorado Crash
text: They were quickly dubbed “the Dougherty gang,” three gun-toting, fast-driving and allegedly bank-robbing siblings whose exploits invited media comparisons to Bonnie and Clyde.

headline: Thursday: Totally Baked
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the best things about writing Wordplay is the opportunity to meet some exceptionally interesting people. Sometimes I get to meet the readers, and sometimes I get to meet the constructors behind your daily brain twisters.

headline: Bellhop, There’s a Play in My Room
text: Sarah Lemp is ready for her close-up.

headline: Prepare to Kiss, a Bar Mitzvah Is Coming
text: After reading the bio of Ruby Rae Spiegel, a playwright in Series A of the annual new American play festival, this year titled “Summer Shorts 5,” I confess my first thought was that she must be the daughter of someone rich. How else could a teenager who just graduated from high school get her play produced alongside veterans like Neil LaBute and Christopher Durang at 59E59 Theaters?

headline: Mitt’s Vanishing Act
text: Pella, Iowa

headline: Living With Loss
text: Shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks, reporters at The New York Times began interviewing friends and relatives of the people whose lives had so suddenly been ended. The result was “Portraits of Grief,” a collection of brief sketches of the victims. These fresh visits with some of the families were written by Glenn Collins, Anthony DePalma, Robin Finn, Jan Hoffman, N. R. Kleinfield, Maria Newman and Janny Scott, all contributors to the original “Portraits of Grief” project in 2001.

headline: Giants Lose Prolific Receiver to Eagles
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In less than two weeks of training camp, the Giants have dealt with a high-profile contract dispute with one of their best players, a major injury to their first-round pick, the departure of their free-agent tight end and the sudden retirement of a player who spent a couple of days in a practice jersey.

headline: Banking Sector Punished Over European Debt
text: Fear is on the rise again that worsening problems at some of Europe’s biggest banks may wind up hurting financial institutions in the United States.

headline: Republicans Head to Iowa
text: Republican presidential hopefuls are descending on Iowa for their second major debate on Thursday in Ames.

headline: Granderson Home Runs Help Yanks End Skid
text: Had it not been for the terrific season he is having, Curtis Granderson might have received more severe criticism for being picked off first base Tuesday for the game-ending out.

headline: Financial Turmoil Evokes Comparison to 2008 Crisis
text: It feels eerily familiar: Stocks are plummeting. The economy is slowing. Politicians are scrambling to find solutions but are mired in disagreement.

headline: Portraits Redrawn: The Bailey Family
text: Judy and Kevin Bailey lost their son, Brett, on September 11th. In the decade since the tragedy they have created the Brett T. Bailey Foundation and Kevin has suffered numerous health issues.

headline: Republicans Head to Iowa
text: Republican presidential hopefuls are descending on Iowa for their second major debate on Thursday in Ames.

headline: The Stock Market Then ... and Now
text: Comparisons have been made between the financial crisis and stock market plunge in 2008 and the current downturn on Wall Street.

headline: Mets Dig Too Big a Hole to Climb Out of This Time
text: The Mets’ late-inning rallies this week had given Citi Field a strangely fuzzy feel. But the pitcher who had a charmed season last year was unable to reclaim that magic in his latest outing, and little else went right otherwise.

headline: With Return to Iowa, Romney Heeds Call of G.O.P. Strategists
text: PELLA, Iowa — Mitt Romney has kept a cautious distance from Iowa after Republicans here helped dash his presidential aspirations four years ago, but he stood before a lush soybean field on Wednesday and declared that his second White House bid depended on a path through this state.

headline: A Credential in Question
text: There has been market speculation over which of the remaining AAA-rated countries might be next in line for a downgrade.

headline: It Zigs, It Zags: U.S. Market Rises 4% After a Down Day
text: Continuing the wild swings from panicked selling to fevered buying and back, stocks soared on Thursday, leaving investors bewildered about what might come next.

headline: M.L.S. Moves to NBC
text: Major League Soccer and NBC Sports on Wednesday announced a three-year agreement to televise 45 league matches and four United States national team games on NBC and the NBC Sports Network, which will be the new name of the current cable channel Versus. The deal will end the league’s relationship with Fox Soccer, which had a one-year deal to carry matches in 2011.

headline: Battle for Libya | Aug. 10, 2011
text: Libyan rebel fighters prayed on the outskirts of the coastal oil town of Brega.

headline: HTC to Buy Majority Stake in Maker of Headphones
text: HTC, the Taiwanese maker of cellphones and tablets, is looking to pump up the volume on its smartphone offerings.

headline: M. Kenneth Oshman, Who Brought Fun to Silicon Valley, Dies at 71

headline: Aug. 11, 1965 | Riots in the Watts Section of Los Angeles
text: On Aug. 11, 1965, rioting broke out in the primarily black neighborhood of Watts in Los Angeles. The violence was sparked by false rumors of police brutality during a traffic stop, though the root causes were long simmering racial tension and anger over poor living conditions.

headline: In the Good Company of Siblings

Max Linsky, who helped found the Web site, writes: “What happens when the sibling bond is that strong? Incredible works of art. Tremendous professional success. And, at least occasionally, cold-blooded murder.” Well, the Hogan twins are only 4 years old, so give them a break. But check out their story and the other fascinating ones on this list.

headline: One Way to Close the Sale of a Business
text: I once worked with a man whose license plate read BCRE8VE (translation: Be Creative). It was the perfect mantra for a director of advertising — and equally fitting for business owners and deal makers navigating today’s business-for-sale marketplace. While there has been a slight uptick in business sales of late, getting a deal done with tight credit markets, depressed valuations and skittish investors continues to require as much art as science.

headline: Can Jeremy Grantham Profit From Ecological Mayhem?
text: Sitting in a Panera in Boston’s financial district in early July with Jeremy Grantham, I suddenly found myself considering how I might safeguard my children’s and notional grandchildren’s future by somehow engineering the U.S. annexation of Morocco. Grantham, the founder and chief strategist of the asset-management firm GMO, was reading aloud from a rough draft of his next quarterly letter to investors, in which he ranks some long-term crises of resource limitation along a scale from “merely serious” to “dangerous.”

headline: The September Issue
text: Like many women nowadays, I shop for my bikinis in the snow and boots in the blistering heat. You could say I’ve adapted. There is a despairing time lapse between when collections are shown (spring in September and fall in February) and when those pieces are sold. (Fall hits stores as early as July, and spring in February.) And thanks to instantaneous gratification sites like Moda Operandi and Gilt Groupe, avid customers can now begin preordering directly from their favorite designers. “I start planning the moment they walk down the runway,” says the designer Margherita Missoni. But some months, like September, linger in a sort of shopping purgatory. The idea of scouring the racks while waiting for sales and holiday items to hit the floor seems outdated. And tired. So while we dally in the off-season, how does one find (and love) things to buy now?

headline: Thelonious Monk Institute to Honor Aretha Franklin
text: Aretha Franklin will be honored at a gala concert in Washington to mark the 25th anniversary of the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz, the institute announced Thursday. The concert will be held Sept. 12 at the Kennedy Center.

headline: Stew in Africa: Colors and Collaborations That Won’t Fade

The two-week program provided East African artists with support and creative guidance, and was modeled on a similar program run by the Sundance Institute in North America.

headline: Stricker Leads, Woods Capsizes in P.G.A. First Round
text: The first round of the P.G.A. Championship gave few hints of drama when it started Thursday morning. But as the day got hotter and a little bit of chaos broke out, Steve Stricker was one of the few to steer completely clear of it. He not only came a stroke shy of setting a major championship record with a 63, he played Atlanta Country Club’s most diabolical holes without a hiccup.

headline: Time Ramps Up Synergy for 9/11 Anniversary Coverage

headline: China’s Chosen Lama Visits Monastery Town
text: BEIJING — A Chinese-designated Buddhist lama who Communist Party officials hope will become a spiritual leader for China’s five million Tibetans arrived in a monastery town in the northwestern province of Gansu on Thursday accompanied by a formidable police presence, and a skeptical crowd was forced to greet him with prayer flags and smiles, residents and exile groups said by telephone.

headline: Theater Talkback: Unforgettable Summer Kisses

Whether bestowed on the lips, the cheek, the hand or any other part of the anatomy, the simple application of the lips to someone else’s body can illuminate all sorts of different, and often contradictory, feelings.

headline: Listen Up | Foster the People
text: On stage, Foster the People could easily be mistaken for a hipster rock group from Brooklyn, except that the musicians are just a bit too muscular to qualify as Williamsburg hipsters. The band comprises the lead singer and songwriter Mark Foster, the drummer Mark Pontius and Cubbie Fink on bass, who came together in Los Angeles in 2009 when the trio began making music that Foster jokingly describes as “if Bryan Wilson and the Aphex Twin had a band baby that grew up in Motown.”

headline: Franc Thoughts on Long-Run Fiscal Issues
text: Regular readers of comments will notice a continual stream of criticism from MMT (modern monetary theory) types, who insist that deficits are never a problem as long as you have your own currency. I really don’t want to get into that fight right now, because for the time being the MMT people and yours truly are on the same side of the policy debate. Right now it really doesn’t matter at all whether the United States issues zero-interest short-term debt or simply prints zero-interest dollar bills, and concern about crowding out is just bad economics.

headline: Graffiti Exhibition Sets Attendance Records at Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles

The show, “Art in the Streets,” drew 201,352 visitors from April 17 through Aug. 8, the highest exhibition attendance in the museum’s history.

headline: Silver Lining
text: Dirk Schoenberger walks into the lobby of the Bowery Hotel wearing Prada’s infamous platform espadrille wingtips — an odd choice considering that Schoenberger is the creative director of the sports style division at Adidas, a company known for its footwear. What he likes about the Pradas, he explains, is “the mix of sharp tailoring and casual leisure.” Having held his post for little over a year, he has pushed Adidas to hybridize in a similar manner. “When I’m in Berlin and I see how the young guys and girls are dressing, none of them are wearing sneakers anymore. So you think, if these are the target consumers, and we are only selling sneakers, well, what are we going to do?” The answer may be found in Adidas SLVR. Priced somewhere between Originals and Y-3 (also under Schoenberger’s purview), the line has been reimagined for fall under his personal design stewardship. “It’s amazing for such a big company to be so open for discussions,” he says. With SLVR, it is a “new approach but still very much in the language of Adidas.”

headline: Met Cancels Plans to Loan Works to Moscow’s Kremlin Museum
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has officially canceled plans to loan works by the fashion designer Paul Poiret to Moscow’s Kremlin Museum, as part of the ongoing fallout from a legal dispute that has halted all loans from Russian to American museums. “It’s really a matter of fairness and equity,” the Met’s spokesman, Harold Holzer, said. As long as Russia’s “loan embargo is in place,” Mr. Holzer said, “this museum believes it can no longer lend to Russian museums.” The Met was to lend 35 Poiret works to the show, which is scheduled to open at the Moscow museum on September 6. The cancellation of the loans was first reported by the New York Observer.

headline: Letting Doctors Make the Tough Decisions
text: Soon after I finished my surgical training, I worked with a young doctor who was impressive not only for his clinical skills but also for his devotion to patients. He was large and powerfully built but never seemed to loom over his patients, miraculously shrinking down to their eye level whenever he spoke with them. He listened intently to every detail of their travails and always ended the visits by asking if they still had any unanswered questions.

headline: Now Playing | Plastique Ludique
text: At Les Arts Decoratifs in Paris, the summer crowds have gravitated to the Hussein Chalayan show and the exhibition of highlights from Ralph Lauren’s car collection. I was glad to see both on a recent trip, but I was also lucky to spot a sign for another, less-heralded exhibition at the museum. “Plastique Ludique” (“Playful Plastic”), which runs until Nov. 6, presents the work of the Czech toy designer Libuse Niklova (1934-1981), whose work with plastics, particularly in the 1960s and ’70s, changed the look — and the nature — of toys in her native country. Niklova believed that children should be able to play as creatively as possible, and the development of plastics after World War II offered a helpful tool. Her inflatable buffalo, giraffe and elephant, with their simplified, graphic silhouettes and bright, pop colors, could be used as chairs or pool toys for small children. (The three have been reissued in limited numbers and are for sale at the museum’s shop.) And Niklova’s ingenious use of pleated plastic piping produced animals with accordion-like midsections that squealed when squeezed. In contrast to the Chalayan and Lauren exhibitions, which are about the more expensive pleasures of the material world, “Plastique Ludique” offers a surprising, refreshing look at a more modest — yet no less inventive — endeavor.

headline: As Ecosystems, Cities Yield Some Surprises

In Fresno, researchers have discovered that backyard water use increases with wealth, as does backyard biodiversity. And in Los Angeles, ecologists studying the city’s “ecohydrology” have calculated that planting a million new trees, an idea with fairly universal appeal, would have the drawback of increasing water consumption by 5 percent.

headline: Really Now, What’s So Bad About Auto-Tune Pop?
text: One thing you learn when you spend a bunch of time on YouTube looking up songs that use the electronic pitch-correction algorithm known as Auto-Tune is that a lot of people really hate Auto-Tune. Which is weird. It’s just a sound — obnoxious in the hands of the untalented, occasionally amazing in the hands of the amazing. Hating it is like hating falsettos, or the accordion. And, O.K., given the current omnipresence of the sound in pop music, it’s like hating the accordion during some strange period of accordion-fascism during which everyone’s paying top dollar to sound like early Los Lobos or Weird Al. Rap and R&B may have run with Auto-Tune more than other genres, but these days you can’t get away from it, even by listening to metal, country or Moroccan music.

headline: 36 Hours in Marseille
text: FIRST the bad news: Marseille is not Paris. Unlike its culture-rich rival, France’s second-largest city has no world-class museums, must-see monuments or internationally renowned chefs. Now the good news: Marseille is not Paris. Kissed by the Mediterranean, Marseille can claim an un-Parisian combination of near-constant sun, miles of beaches and an ethnic mix — French, North African, Italian, Corsican, Armenian — that lends a flavor unlike anywhere else in the country. No wonder the rest of France calls it Planète Mars. And the news gets better: Named a European Capital of Culture for 2013, the historically gritty port is looking up, thanks to a waterfront renovation, a sleek new tram system, a first wave of design hotels, a generation of young restaurant and night-life impresarios and a homegrown fashion scene. More than ever, there is life on Mars.

In Concert,” the recent United States tour starring cast members of Ryan Murphy’s TV juggernaut. Directed by Kevin Tancharoen and filmed over two days at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J., it is a strenuous exercise in cheerleading for the “Glee” franchise. headline: A Russian Matriarch Gets Her Moment Onstage
text: On the first episode of “Russian Dolls,” Eva Levitis sits at the head of a table, prepping her pancake makeup for a beauty pageant. The pageant, for grandmothers only, is one she’ll handily win – no one else tries for a belly dance routine that includes an eggplant-colored brassiere, dripping with beads. But that hasn’t happened yet. She’s still at home, her hair a nest of blond curls, speaking longingly into a make-up mirror: “I always dreamed to be onstage. And people was looking at me.”

headline: Lumière | Île de Ré Idyll
text: One August morning years ago, there was a knock on the door of the small, 19th-century stone house in Ars-en-Ré that my husband, Andy, and I had rented for vacation. There, alongside a bicycle laced with rust, stood a silver-haired man, elegantly dressed in a faded rose-colored linen shirt and long khaki Bermuda shorts. He had come looking for the owners, who were his — and our — friends from Paris. His name was Hubert.

headline: Mickelson No Fan of Some Rees Jones Course Designs

But when the noted course toughener Rees Jones completed a configuration in 2001, Mickelson was no fan of the finished product. He seems to have never forgiven Jones, later disapproving of a makeover at another cherished greensward, Cog Hill’s Drubsdread in suburban Chicago.

It is surrounded by an invisible but impregnable wall and a moat full of sharks and crocodiles. Inside, successful artists work in spacious, light-filled studios and dally in sensual pleasures.

headline: Rediscovered at the Altar of Art
text: Any visual artist fated to be a one-hit wonder would be beyond lucky if that hit were as marvelous as “The Fulbright Triptych,” Simon Dinnerstein’s overlooked masterpiece of 1970s realism. This crackling, obsessive showboat of a painting, dreamed up during a decade when the medium supposedly teetered on the brink of death, is a three-panel autobiographical allegory of life, love and art that measures 14 feet across.
