headline: Out-Magritting Magritte, or at Least Coming Close
text: “La Carte d’Après Nature” at the Matthew Marks Gallery in Chelsea is the kind of magical, intuitive show that could only have been devised by an artist. Using the Belgian surrealist painter René Magritte as a kind of divining rod, it finds surrealism in some unlikely places.

headline: When Agents Play Two Roles
text: DO you know whom your broker is really working for? The natural assumption is that the agent is working for you, but the situation may not be that simple. There are seller’s agents, buyer’s agents, broker’s agents, dual agents and even dual agents with designated sales agents — which all sounds more like the cast of characters in a spy film than people involved in a real estate transaction.

headline: Shining New Light on a Modernist
text: MONTREAL — The architect Pierre Jeanneret spent his career in the large shadow of his famous cousin, Charles-Édouard Jeanneret, better known as Le Corbusier. These Swiss-born men set up a Paris office in the 1920s, and Jeanneret, whose archive is only now becoming publicly accessible, contributed to renowned Le Corbusier designs like tubular steel chairs and cubic villas on stilts.

headline: New Jersey Trains Hobbled by Derailment in Queens
text: Another evening commute, another schedule-snarling commuter train derailment.

headline: Goodyear Claims Breakthrough in Tire Self-Inflation Technology
text: Motorists who never experienced the delights of central tire inflation afforded by the Hummer H1, Arnold Schwarzenegger‘s favorite S.U.V., may yet have their opportunity.

headline: Newest New Yorkers at Play
text: THEY are young, talented and driven: artists who want to make their mark on the world. You see them in New York more than any other city in the country, and their New York is different from yours and mine. It’s hipper and faster paced, open to experience. If they want to see a folk-singing duo, and their iPhones tell them to cross two highway lanes on foot to get there, consider them crossed.

headline: A Spectacular Rise and Fall
text: Vroom. “Senna,” Asif Kapadia’s documentary biography of the Brazilian racecar driver Ayrton Senna, a three-time Formula One world champion, virtually puts you in the lap of its subject as he hurtles like a speeding bullet along the fastest tracks.

headline: Warren Edges Closer to Senate Run
text: BOSTON — Elizabeth Warren has enlisted two former aides to Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts to help her assess whether to run for the United States Senate and will make a decision after Labor Day, a Democrat familiar with her efforts said Thursday.

headline: Planet of the Hominids
text: 6:35 p.m. | Updated Last weekend, I took my two sons, 13 and 21, to see “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” which we thoroughly enjoyed on several levels. It’s a rousing slave revolt, an entertaining techno-thriller, a drama about a dysfunctional household (chimp included) dealing with disability and job-related stresses (in the conflicted genetic engineer played by James Franco). (Manohla Dargis liked it, too, as did my sons’ favorite critics, the team at Spill.com.

headline: Romney Heckled at Iowa State Fair
text: At the Iowa State Fair, a small group of angry hecklers called on Mitt Romney to support raising taxes on the wealthy to help fund social entitlement programs.

headline: Okra Stew
text: Mark Bittman makes a stew with pork that will appeal to okra lovers and haters alike.

headline: Borrowing in Retirement
text: HOUSEHOLDS headed by people 65 and older make up the largest segment of the population of homeowners in this country, and many of them will continue to make home purchases in or near retirement — in many cases, trading in a larger suburban house for a smaller apartment or town house in a more urban area.

headline: The Marilyn Catalog, Revisited Whimsically
text: Has any love goddess had more firsthand experience being a plaything coveted and discarded by spoiled male collectors of beauty than Marilyn Monroe? In 1920 Irving Berlin wrote “After You Get What You Want,” one of the best songs ever written about the heart of a fickle playboy, which Monroe sang 34 years later in the movie “There’s No Business Like Show Business.”

headline: TimesCast | East Jerusalem Housing
text: August 11, 2011 - Israel approves construction of a contentious 1,600-apartment complex in East Jerusalem, which could undercut efforts to salvage long-stalled Middle East peace talks.

headline: C.I.A. Is Disputed on Civilian Toll in Drone Strikes
text: WASHINGTON — On May 6, a Central Intelligence Agency drone fired a volley of missiles at a pickup truck carrying nine militants and bomb materials through a desolate stretch of Pakistan near the Afghan border. It killed all the militants — a clean strike with no civilian casualties, extending what is now a yearlong perfect record of avoiding collateral deaths.

headline: Q&A: Boosting the Speed of a Windows 7 PC
text: Q.

headline: Hints of a Bachmann-Perry Clash
text: AMES, Iowa — With news Thursday that Rick Perry is making his presidential campaign official, the coming clash between him and Michele Bachmann is quickly moving into the open.

headline: The Minimalist: Okra Stew
text: If you like okra, which is in season now, you’ll probably like this recipe for okra stew, because, well, it’s okra. If you hate okra, you’ll also probably like this recipe for okra stew, because the okra practically disappears.

headline: Perry Fund-Raising Team Goes on the Offensive
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas won’t officially announce his presidential campaign until Saturday. But his fund-raising team isn’t wasting any time.

headline: Latest Insider Trading Case Tied to Disney Deal
text: 8:57 p.m. | Updated

headline: Two Interpretations of New York, One Layered With Tart Observations
text: If classical music in its traditional forms is scarce at Lincoln Center Out of Doors, the series has always had a place for new music of the Downtown persuasion. Its principal offering from that world this summer was a double bill of idiosyncratic violinist-composers on Wednesday evening. Todd Reynolds opened the program, sharing the stage with Sxip Shirey, a composer and multi-instrumentalist, and Adam Matta, who makes percussion sounds vocally. Laurie Anderson closed the show with “The Real New York,” a work that she wrote in recent weeks.

headline: 'Crazy Sexy Cancer' Trailer
text: Kris Carr documented her battle with Stage 4 epithelioid hemangioendothelioma and her crazy, sexy life following the diagnosis. Video courtesy of Kris Carr.

headline: The No-Surprises Move
text: MOVING your worldly possessions to a new home is always fraught with potential complications, but in New York City, seemingly simple tasks like packing, parking and unloading are complicated by street-cleaning regulations, unexpectedly narrow doorways and rules about using the elevator.

headline: On New York’s Low Seas: Day 4
text: Bounding through the lively chop on the Long Island Sound on Thursday, the Manhattan skyline seemingly soaked by salty spray, it seemed a world of watery wonder. And then suddenly came an abrupt wake-up call.

headline: Caucus Video: Romney’s Authentic Moment; Iowa Debate Preview
text: Jeff Zeleny reports from Iowa on an unusual authentic moment for Mitt Romney when he responds to a question regarding social security. Also, a look at the stakes for the many Republican candidates at Thursday night’s debate.

headline: The Lonely I.P.O. of Carbonite
text: David Friend's business is built around preparing for the worst-case scenario. Perhaps that's why Carbonite was one of the few scheduled initial public offerings that went ahead this week.

headline: In Between the Terrorist Threats, Plenty of Time for Hanky-Panky
text: Cinemax — the network and the punch line — has always had a businesslike approach to original programming. Sex-businesslike, that is. “The Best Sex Ever,” “Sex Games Cancun,” “Zane’s Sex Chronicles”: its late-night offerings have made it the soft-core cathouse of premium cable.

headline: A Weekday Place for a Weekending Man
text: FIFTEEN years ago, when Warren Dakin was transferred to New York from Toronto, he and his wife, Jennifer, checked out a two-bedroom rental in a prewar building on East 86th Street. A friend from New York accompanied them, and told them that “we had to take it right away because it had a stackable washer and dryer,” Mrs. Dakin said.

headline: Late-Night Audience Splinters
text: With George Lopez becoming its latest casualty, the war for late-night ratings supremacy rages on without a clear victor.

headline: TV Cameras and Falling Rocks
text: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

headline: The Lonely I.P.O. of Carbonite
text: David Friend’s business is built around preparing for the worst-case scenario. Perhaps that’s why his company, Carbonite, was still willing to go public during an especially volatile week for stocks. Mr. Friend talks about Carbonite and its market debut.

headline: A Gay Oasis, With Beer and Barbecue
text: Walk past the low-ceilinged bar, the jukebox and the pool table. Keep going, beyond the stage where “Queeraoke” erupts every Tuesday, and right out the back door. Feel the sunshine on your face and inhale the relatively fresh air (this is New York, after all) that makes Metropolitan the most popular gay hangout in Brooklyn on summer Sunday afternoons.

headline: Victory, the Personal Kind
text: “I CUDDA been a contenduh” was how Marlon Brando once put it.

headline: In Future Math Whizzes, Signs of ‘Number Sense’
text: Children as young as 3 have a “number sense” that may be correlated with mathematical aptitude, according to a new study.

headline: Contrasting Reports of Drone Strikes
text: Obama administration officials say the Central Intelligence Agency’s drone program in Pakistan has killed about 600 militants and no civilians since May 2010. The Bureau of Investigative Journalism in London, a Web-based reporting project, counted at least 45 civilian deaths. Below are the contrasting accounts of four strikes. SCOTT SHANE

headline: Living Around | Gramercy Park
text: Though proximity isn’t the same as access, the privately owned park’s quiet presence in the neighborhood lends the surrounding blocks a certain hominess.

headline: In Southern Heat, Ishikawa Finds Water, but No Relief
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Ryo Ishikawa made quite a splash Thursday at the P.G.A. Championship. In fact, he made a half-dozen of them.

headline: Feel Free to Use the Name, at Least
text: PASSERS-BY peeking through the iron fence into the two-acre 19th-century gem known as Gramercy Park may find plenty to tantalize: statues ringed with landscaping, elaborate birdhouses and pathways invitingly empty of other New Yorkers. Polite-but-firm signs just inside the gates make clear what kind of rowdiness is not allowed: dog-walking and stepping on the grass, among other things.

headline: Brooklyn Library Branches Will Extend Hours
text: Despite a $1.1 million budget cut this year, Brooklyn Public Library branches are increasing, not cutting, their hours.

headline: Inside Nicholson Baker’s Sexual Utopia
text: There are many ways into the House of Holes, and they are all holes. Such is the logic that guides Nicholson Baker’s hilarious and extremely dirty “book of raunch,” “House of Holes,” and it’s more than enough. One woman enters this novel’s sex spa extraordinaire through an O-shape made by the fingers of a severed arm. Others fall through the hole in a golf green, or a pepper­mill. Somebody is funneled through a cocktail straw. Next thing, they all arrive at one of the loopier spots in literary memory — Plato’s Retreat by way of the Magic Mountain, or maybe the Oneida Community via Fantasy Island.

headline: Portraits and Stone
text: A look at the work of the photographer Mariana Cook.

headline: New Eyes at Play
text: Members of PigPen Theater find adventure on Governors Island.

headline: A TV Host Seeks Fluff, but Real Life Intrudes
text: Resetting “The Arabian Nights” in modern-day Cairo, “Scheherazade, Tell Me a Story” presents an environment of oppressive politics and repressed women.

headline: The Teenage Years in the Tumult of Afghanistan
text: In 2002 Phil Grabsky went to Afghanistan and made “The Boy Who Plays on the Buddhas of Bamiyan,” a documentary about a year in the life of Mir, an 8-year-old with boundless energy and a blinding smile. His family, dislocated by war, lived in grinding poverty in a cave near where the Taliban had destroyed centuries-old stone Buddhas; the family granted Mr. Grabsky an alarming degree of access, and the resulting film had a sharp focus, a fluid rhythm and a touch of strange beauty, abetted by the towering cliffs with their empty alcoves for statues.

headline: A Perp Walk on Twitter
text: Lifting a page from the hacker’s handbook, the Greater Manchester Police in Britain are naming and shaming rioters on their Twitter feed.

headline: Scenes From the Iowa State Fair
text: In the hours before they would offer rhetorical red meat during a debate on Thursday, several Republican presidential contenders encountered the other white meat at festivities in Des Moines.

headline: A Battle for India’s Soul
text: Nothing less than India’s soul is at stake in Prakash Jha’s “Aarakshan,” a Hindi movie about the battle — as intense as any gang war — between a righteous teacher and the hucksters who would make education a commodity available only to the privileged.

headline: One Last Bow for Violet and Bobby
text: They came back for a curtain call.

headline: Cellphone Market Share Shifting
text: Nokia is about to drop from its position as the leading cellphone maker in the world, according to the latest sales estimates made by the technology analysts at Gartner.

headline: A Brush With Internet Fame
text: It would be easy to be lulled into thinking that “Damn!,” a documentary about a fringe New York gubernatorial candidate, is just a mindless profile of a quirky guy. But by the end of this smart, subtle film by Aaron Fisher-Cohen, you realize that it’s actually a deft look at flash-in-the-pan fame and the emptiness at the heart of it.

headline: Postcrisis, New Investment Tactics to Lure the Ultra Wealthy
text: Funds of hedge funds are changing their ways.

headline: The Year the East Cried 'Freedom!'
text: A cascade of historic events climaxed in November with the fall of the Berlin Wall as East Europeans broke free of Communist rule.

headline: Recalling When a Wall Split a City Apart
text: BERLIN — Günter Schlusche stood in what was once the foundation of Bernauer Street 10A, right in front of the cinder blocks and mortar that remained, just as they had half a century earlier, when East German workers bricked up the house’s windows the day the Berlin Wall went up.

headline: Young Tourists Marooned in a California Town
text: A Japanese brother and sister, tourists in America, are momentarily stranded in a rural California town; the brother resumes their trip, but the sister, who speaks no English, stays on for a while, interested in the residents and flattered by their interest in her. That’s the premise of Mike Ott’s second feature, “Littlerock,” an out-of-pocket production shot on video and partly improvised, using mostly nonprofessional actors.

headline: Death Will Not Be Cheated
text: The fifth installment of the “Final Destination” series begins with the usual 10 minutes of fun. An elaborately choreographed disaster, in this case a bridge collapse, eliminates a group of teenagers in entertainingly disgusting ways before being revealed as a premonition. This allows some of the group to avoid death, so that they can be killed again — in slower, more stomach-churning fashion — over the rest of the film.

headline: Both Sides Promote Romney’s Heckling Response
text: AMES, Iowa — It took the Democratic National Committee only seven hours to turn comments by Mitt Romney at the Iowa State Fair into an attack video.

headline: The Gloves Come Off at Iowa Debate
text: AMES, Iowa — Fox News anchors are testing the microphones. Reporters have assembled in a cavernous room with hundreds of folding tables and chairs. Senior aides to the candidates are finishing up their efforts at pre-debate spin.

headline: Nigerians Receive First Payments for Children Who Died in 1996 Meningitis Drug Trial
text: The first payments were made Thursday to Nigerian families who lost children during a 1996 trial of an experimental meningitis drug, and Pfizer, which had tested the drug, a new antibiotic, said it was “pleased” that payments were finally being made under a settlement reached two years ago.

headline: Outsiders in Albuquerque
text: The first thing you notice about “Bad Posture” is that it’s unstudiedly cool: laid-back, observant and rather shady, it cares so little for your attention that you can’t stop watching.

headline: How to Make That College Essay Special
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Town Built for 30
text: The 30-odd residents of the tiny town of Darwin, Calif., prefer to keep themselves to themselves, as evidenced by the “No services ahead” sign they’ve erected to discourage visitors. We can only marvel, then, at their candor when faced with Nick Brandestini’s camera in “Darwin,” a droll and dusty portrait of a place where privacy is prized and boundaries respected.

headline: Send Us Your Tailgate Recipes
text: Last year, we asked readers to share images of their college tailgating experiences, and we got a sweeping look at the sometimes extravagant fun going on before games. This season, we thought we would zero in on what’s being served before kickoff on Saturdays and Sundays.

headline: Libya and the Legal Adviser: A State Dept. View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Metropolitan Bar
text: The lush backyard at Metropolitan Bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, makes it a popular gay summer hangout.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Downtown New York can be a revolving door for entertainers, all hoping to find an audience before their turn is over. Some move up. Others move out. Either way, it’s an excellent place to find the next great talent, and usually at little cost.

headline: ‘Corporations Are People,’ Romney Tells Iowa Hecklers Angry Over His Tax Policy
text: DES MOINES — Emerging on the campaign trail in Iowa after largely shunning the state, Mitt Romney was confronted on Thursday by hecklers on corporate tax policy and told one of them, “Corporations are people, my friend.”

headline: Republicans Debate in Iowa
text: Eight Republican presidential contenders gathered on a stage in Iowa Thursday night for a two-hour, high-stakes exchange just two days before the first real contest of the nominating process.

headline: The Bigger Tragedy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jets and Burress Are Taking Baby Steps
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets Coach Rex Ryan said Thursday that he planned to play receiver Plaxico Burress for a few snaps in Monday’s preseason opener against the Houston Texans, even though Burress continues to be limited in practice because of an ankle injury.

headline: The 30 Who Died Together
text: The faces of the 30 American military personnel killed when the Taliban shot down a Chinook helicopter in Afghanistan.

headline: Rick Perry’s Unanswered Prayers
text: A few months ago, with Texas aflame from more than 8,000 wildfires brought on by extreme drought, a man who hopes to be the next president took pen in hand and went to work:

headline: A Disservice to Theology
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Road, and Out of the Red
text: A nonprofit group has found that helping people get low-interest loans for more efficient cars can improve lives.

headline: House Tour: New Fairfield, Conn.
text: S. P. Wijegoonaratna and his wife, Michele, bought a 1920s house and transformed the property into a modern waterfront escape.

headline: House Tour: New Fairfield, Conn.
text: WHAT Two-bedroom house and a two-bedroom cottage on Ball Pond

headline: What the Ravens Wrought
text: WHEN Amanda Curtis was a little girl growing up in Kennebunkport, Me., she inhabited something of an enchanted world, albeit one tinged with sadness.

headline: Battle for Libya | Aug. 11, 2011
text: A Libyan rebel fighter lay in an ambulance at a field hospital near Bir al-Ghanem after being shot in the stomach during a firefight in western Libya.

headline: Syrian Security Forces Kill 12 People in Attack on a Western Town, Activists Say
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces killed 12 people on Thursday in an attack on a western town near the border with Lebanon and stormed another town in the northwest, human rights activists in Syria reported, and President Bashar al-Assad faced new pressure from Turkey and the United States to stop his harsh repression of the protest movement challenging his rule.

headline: Bloggingheads: Perry the Executioner
text: Tim Fernholz, left, of Good magazine and Kevin D. Williamson of National Review debate a controversial death-penalty case in Texas.

headline: Preparing for State Tests, to a Hip-Hop Beat
text: The team of six high school girls new to America sat frozen waiting for the next missing lyric, whiteboard and marker at the ready. They glanced toward their classmates, who sat nearby, in two competing teams.

headline: No Room in the P.G.A. Field
text: At a typical Grand Slam event, three to five players who are on site withdraw before Thursday’s opening round, most often citing injuries or personal issues.

headline: We Want Cake, Too
text: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

headline: Sometimes, Inflation Is Not Evil
text: Sometimes, you have to unlearn your lessons.

headline: Nordstrom and Kohl’s Expect Profit to Rise More
text: Despite this week’s stock market gyrations, two more retailers said on Thursday that not much had changed in their stores and that the rest of the year continued to look promising.

headline: The Hijacked Crisis
text: Has market turmoil left you feeling afraid? Well, it should. Clearly, the economic crisis that began in 2008 is by no means over.

headline: The Risk of Parking in Safe Havens
text: Financial lifeboats are starting to get crowded. Investors in droves have been seeking safety from sinking stocks. But some vessels of refuge have shown how quickly they can be rocked when too many investors pile in.

headline: Turning the Wrong Page
text: DURING the summer of 1995, just after my 17th birthday, I served as a page in the House of Representatives. It was a heady time to be in Washington: the country was reeling from the Oklahoma City bombing that spring, while Newt Gingrich, the newly elected speaker of the House, and his Republican Revolutionaries were promising to remake Capitol Hill.

headline: Lobster Salad, but a Key Ingredient Was Missing
text: Only the name has changed. The ingredients remain the same: wild freshwater crawfish, mayonnaise, celery, salt and sugar.

headline: Big Losses for Giants, and They Haven’t Played Yet
text: It was a few hours before Steve Smith defected to Philadelphia on Wednesday, setting off the latest deafening alarms surrounding the Giants, when Coach Tom Coughlin pondered the oddity of this season’s training camp.

headline: New York’s Urban Aloha
text: WHEN the world’s best surfers come to Long Beach, N.Y., next month to compete for a record million-dollar purse in the Quiksilver Pro New York, a new event on professional surfing’s world tour, they might be forgiven for using Google Earth to locate the place. Compared with Australia and California and Hawaii, where Quiksilver established its pre-eminence as a beachwear company, New York barely registers on the surfing atlas.

headline: Protests Force Israel to Confront Wealth Gap
text: TEL AVIV — They are mainstays of the society pages and glossy magazines. Some are praised for the hospital wings they have built, others are gossiped about for their quirks.

headline: How to Lose Allies and Alienate People
text: One of the more common misconceptions about the Civil War is that the world (meaning Europe and, in particular, Britain) favored a Southern victory because of its dependence on cotton. The economic data appears to provide incontrovertible evidence: the livelihood of one in five Britons was connected in some way to the textile trade.

headline: Positive Report Lifts Hopes for Umenyiora
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The two lingering issues hanging over Giants camp have been resolved, just in time for the team to travel to Charlotte, N.C., for its preseason opener.

headline: Trucks That Are Bigger and Badder, but Perhaps Not Better
text: HEAVY-DUTY pickup trucks are the supercars of the truck world. They have more power than drivers are likely ever to exploit, and bragging rights depend on statistics that are, in practical terms, theoretical.

headline: A Scalpel, Not an Ax, for Medicaid
text: Many states are struggling to balance their budgets by curbing spending on Medicaid, a joint state-federal program that provides health insurance for the poor and disabled. They have little choice because Medicaid is one of their biggest, fastest-growing expenses. The risk is that injudicious cuts could harm their most vulnerable citizens.

headline: A Retreat for Roosevelt in Georgia Burns Down
text: WARM SPRINGS, Ga. — It was the home where Franklin D. Roosevelt, ravaged by polio, learned to walk with a cane and leg braces.

headline: Starving in Somalia
text: The worst famine in 60 years is devastating the Horn of Africa. In Somalia, where the problem is most acute, 3.9 million people are at risk of starvation and as many as 12 million throughout the region. Some 29,000 Somali children are believed to have died in the last 90 days alone. The casualties will only grow without an urgent and generous international response.

headline: Politicians and Protesters Assail British Police
text: LONDON — Britain’s latest convulsion of rioting and looting began with a protest against the police handling of a killing in north London, but it soon turned into something much bigger — a challenge to state authority that shook the political elite, and, for the police itself, one more bleak entry in a catalog of crisis and condemnation.

headline: A Washington State Indian Tribe Approves Same-Sex Marriage
text: PORT MADISON INDIAN RESERVATION, Wash. — There were no protests and not much politics when the Suquamish Tribe quietly confronted one of the most tender social issues of the day.

headline: Stanley Bosworth, Iconoclastic Head of Brooklyn School, Dies at 83
text: Stanley Bosworth, a self-described “old wizard” who shaped his own Hogwarts in Brooklyn in the form of Saint Ann’s School, which rapidly gained national prominence for its free-form approach to education and its success in sending graduates to top colleges, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 83.

headline: For Some, Budget Pain Doesn’t Hurt
text: Summer is draining from the calendar, and across the city, school principals are swallowing hard and sending out notes to their staff. They go something like this: No yearbook. No dance team. No drama group. No basketball. No field trips.

headline: Investors Fret at Costs if Rescues Are Needed
text: LONDON — Ever since Lehman Brothers collapsed nearly three years ago, Europe’s leaders have repeatedly vowed to prevent any major European bank from failing.

headline: Taking a Gamble, McIlroy Is Forced to Play With Pain
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Apparently no major championship this year will be uneventful for Rory McIlroy. There was the spectacular collapse on the final day of the Masters. Then he stormed to victory at the United States Open, and last month he wobbled conspicuously out of contention at the British Open.

headline: The Salmon Deserve Better
text: Last week, for the third time in nearly a decade, Judge James Redden of the United States District Court in Portland, Ore., rejected as inadequate a federal plan claiming to save imperiled salmon species in the Columbia River basin. These fish have been listed as endangered or threatened under the Endangered Species Act since the early 1990s, their once-remarkable annual runs reduced to a trickle by habitat destruction and by the hydroelectric dams that impede their passage to the sea.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Judge Won’t Order Inquiry Over Psychologist’s Role in Guantánamo
text: New York State cannot be forced to investigate a psychologist accused by a human rights organization of overseeing coercive interrogation tactics at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a judge in Manhattan ruled on Thursday.

headline: In Court, Gundlach Denies Using Trade Secrets
text: Pool photo by CVNJeffrey Gundlach of DoubleLine Capital testified in a Los Angeles court.

headline: A Missed Chance for Accountability
text: In a disappointing ruling, a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan failed to hold the Central Intelligence Agency to account for a notorious attempt to cover up the torture and abuse of prisoners.

headline: Friday: Language With No Word for “Hello”
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — When most people sit down to solve a crossword puzzle, they are generally not thinking about how fresh the entries are (how many times that word or phrase has been used in a crossword) or how many cheater squares there are (how many “extra” black squares have been placed in the grid that do not affect the overall word count). Solving is an escape to some, a personal contest to others. But my guess is that most of you don’t spend a whole lot of time thinking about these things.

headline: That Ragtag Bohemian Army Returns
text: Maybe they should call it “Sublet.” The young ensemble members who inhabit the new production of Jonathan Larson’s “Rent,” which opened on Thursday night at New World Stages, never seem to feel truly at home. It is as if they had taken over the show for a couple of months of fun, as they might an older sibling’s house on Fire Island, and are now hesitant to treat it as their own.

headline: Father of Man Killed in Unrest Helps Calm Tense English City With Call for Peace
text: BIRMINGHAM, England — With one senseless act, the fragile peace this city had maintained while London was convulsed with violence was suddenly threatened.

headline: A Controversial Cancer Treatment, Step by Step
text: A cancer patient underwent the Hipec treatment, a controversial process that involves surgery to remove visible tumors in the abdomen, followed by the dousing of the abdominal cavity in a hot chemotherapy bath.

headline: Hot Chemotherapy Bath: Patients See Hope, Critics Hold Doubts
text: SAN DIEGO — This is cancer therapy at its most aggressive, a treatment patients liken to being filleted, disemboweled and then bathed in hot poison.

headline: Big Swing at the P.G.A.: 7 Under (Stricker) to 7 Over (Woods)
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — At one point on a hot Thursday morning in the first round of the P.G.A. Championship, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods were tied at the top, each at three under par and playing flawlessly. They had three birdies apiece after starting 30 minutes apart on the tough back nine of the Highlands Course at the Atlanta Athletic Club.

headline: Fact Check: The Republican Debate
text: Updated  As they tried to blame President Obama for the nation’s lowered credit rating, the Republican presidential candidates who squared off Thursday night in Iowa made several misleading, incomplete or simply false claims.

headline: Some Stealth Marketing by a ‘Hot Chemo’ Company
text: Dr. Jason M. Foster, a University of Nebraska surgeon, extolled the virtues of heated chemotherapy delivered directly into the abdominal cavity in a Web presentation in June. What he did not mention was that the Web site on which he appeared, HipecTreatment.com, is a marketing tool for ThermaSolutions, the leading manufacturer of equipment used for the controversial treatment.

headline: The Less Famous Faces of Housing Court
text: At first glance, the scene in Manhattan housing court was as casual as an August afternoon beach party.

headline: Massachusetts: Bulger’s Friend Charged
text: Catherine Greig, the girlfriend of the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger, was indicted by a federal grand jury for assisting Mr. Bulger during the couple’s 16 years on the run. Ms. Greig, 60, of Quincy, was charged with one count of conspiracy to harbor and conceal a fugitive, which carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The indictment replaces a criminal complaint that the authorities used to arrest Ms. Greig when they apprehended the couple in Santa Monica, Calif., in June. The indictment says that Ms. Greig, a former dental hygienist, posed as Mr. Bulger’s wife, used false identification and tried to prevent his “discovery and arrest.” Mr. Bulger is charged with 19 murders and other crimes.

headline: Citadel Chief Gives Up Dream for Investment Bank
text: It was to have been the summit of a spectacularly ambitious and rapid ascent in finance: turning what began as a $4.6 million hedge fund into an investment bank that could rival Goldman Sachs.

headline: For Mullin, Entering the Hall of Fame Means Saying Thanks
text: Three to five minutes, Chris Mullin was told, and this made him happy, a little bit relieved. He would not have to speak all that long, notwithstanding how far his oratory skills have come since the days when he mostly spoke a sign language of his own, with a ball or a beer.

headline: As Election Approaches, Sarkozy Faces Daunting To-Do List for French Economy
text: PARIS — President Nicolas Sarkozy faces an uncomfortable political predicament. He must satisfy an anxious market, preserve France’s AAA credit rating, defend French banks, cut the budget to fixed targets in a time of slowing growth and make it all palatable enough to win an election only nine months away.

headline: E.P.A. Bans Sale of Tree-Killing Herbicide

headline: As Dizzying Week Ends on Wall Street, Dangers Linger

headline: Horseflesh and High Society

They parted gamblers and picnickers and strode purposefully into one of the most venerable enclosures in American sports, the paddock at the Spa.

headline: Fight Harder, Voters Telling Congressmen

But in meetings with voters across the country this week, many members of Congress are seeing a mirror of the House floor.

headline: In Alabama, No Verdicts of Guilty in Graft Case
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — A sprawling federal investigation begun nearly two years ago into corruption at the highest levels of state politics concluded Thursday with acquittals or mistrials, ending, at least temporarily, a case that could have put sitting politicians and powerful campaign donors behind bars.

text: LONDON — When Prime Minister David Cameron faced an emergency session of the House of Commons on Thursday to account for his government’s handling of some of Britain’s darkest days since World War II, he was, in a sense, a man on trial.

headline: First Outdoor Ohio Game

The game, to be held Jan. 15, will be a home game for Ohio State, which has a devoted fan base in the Cleveland area. Michigan set an attendance record for a hockey game in December when it hosted Michigan State in the Big House.

headline: Delight and Unease Over Law on Student Vaccinations
text: Among the things 22-year old Jamie Schanbaum could not have anticipated three years ago was standing two inches taller, winning a national Paralympic gold medal in cycling and reveling in the Texas Legislature’s passage of two bills in her honor. Those gains, however, came after significant losses — most noticeably of both legs below the knee and much of each finger, the result of a bout with meningococcal septicemia in her sophomore year at the University of Texas.

Their deaths bring the number of American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations to 1,715.

headline: New Rules and Old Plants May Strain Summer Energy Supplies

headline: Who Are Your Favorite Movie Stars?

Can an actor be “too good” in a performance? Two New York Times film critics recently answered these reader questions. Which brings us to the question: Who are your favorite film and television actors and stars?

headline: Tip of the Week: Mobile Weather Options
text: From heat waves to hurricanes, August can be a month for dangerous weather. Smartphone owners have several custom app choices for getting a steady flow of weather-related information, but any phone with a Web browser and Internet connection can also get important storm alerts, forecasts and updates. For example, most of the major weather-focused Web sites offer streamlined versions for mobile users — just point the phone’s browser to sites like m.accuweather.com, m.weather.com or m.weatherbug.com for a quick look at the latest conditions. If you do not want to keep checking an app or site, you can also have the information find you when a storm is coming. Some commercial sites like Weather.com offer free e-mail or text-message alerts, as does the National Weather Service.

headline: Do Congress and the White House Deserve an AA+ Rating?

headline: Love-Letter to Auto-Tune, Part II
text: We’re singing the praises — in weird high-pitched computer voices, naturally — of Auto-Tune, the much-maligned and increasingly ubiquitous vocal-processing technology that’s become one of the defining sounds of 21st-century pop. Yesterday, we discussed the Auto-Tune pioneer Cher and the now-ex-Auto-Tune-superfan T-Pain, who brought the technology into diva-driven dance music and hip-hop, and Kanye West’s album “808s and Heartbreak,” on which a lovelorn millionaire used Auto-Tune to make people feel as sad for him as they did for Wall-E. Today, a few examples of how rappers, reggae singers, futuristic party-girls, D.J.’s and cartoon rodents have used and abused Auto-Tune in ways undreamt of by its creators. Plus: Ne-Yo gets cranky!

headline: Pakistani Soldier Sentenced to Death Over Fatal Shooting of Teen

headline: Aftershock to Economy Has a Precedent That Holds Lessons
text: Like earthquakes, financial crises seem to be accompanied by aftershocks, like the one we’ve been living through this week. They can feel every bit as bad as the crisis itself. But economic history and academic research suggest they can set the stage for a sustainable recovery — and eventual sharp stock market gains.

headline: Virtuosos Becoming a Dime a Dozen
text: THE latest young pianist from China to excite classical music audiences and earn raves from critics is the 24-year-old Yuja Wang, a distinctive artist with a comprehensive technique. That Ms. Wang is already a musician of consequence was made clear this year when Deutsche Grammophon released her first recording with an orchestra: performances of Rachmaninoff’s Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini and Second Piano Concerto with the Mahler Chamber Orchestra. The conductor is Claudio Abbado, no less, a towering maestro who is extremely discriminating in his choice of collaborators.

headline: Kris Carr: Crazy Sexy Entrepreneur
text: Please note that nearly every person at the vegan cafe in Woodstock, N.Y., was looking at Kris Carr. The waiter was trembling a little. This has been happening to her a lot lately. In New York City, in Denver, in San Francisco, in Portland, Ore., she can’t get a green drink at an organic juice bar or pick up goji berries at the Whole Foods Market and remain incognito. Somebody will see the giant, slightly googly green eyes and the hair whipped into a folded-over ponytail with a trademark streak of hot pink, and that’s enough for the tweeting about another Kris Carr sighting to begin.

headline: Compound Interest
text: In Los Angeles, everyone’s a hybrid. Caterer-dancer. Shop girl-singer. Bartender-drama student. Take Justin Kern: model, screenwriter and now fashion designer. Kern and his partner, Stephanie Danan, film producer and fashion designer, have founded Co, a collection of luxurious mega-basics: slip dresses, silk tanks and skirts, L.B.D.’s, skinny leather pants and the kind of big old fancy furs that Margot Tenenbaum would adore. The Royal Tenenbaum, in fact, is the personification of the Co customer — a woman who pictures herself in a variety of cinematic situations. To illuminate this idea, Kern and Danan (far right) collaborated with the actress Élodie Bouchez and the director Thomas Bangalter of Daft Punk on a four-minute film that they describe as a period piece with a sci-fi twist. (The film will have its premiere on T’s Web site during Fashion Week.) “We wanted to give the clothes an identity through the characters that we imagine inhabiting them,” Danan says. Margot, fictional character-muse, are you listening?

headline: Friday Reading: Are Tanning Beds Addictive?

text: The president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, appeared on state television this week looking healthy and walking confidently in the first such footage of the wounded leader since an early July speech in which he appeared dazed and disfigured.

headline: Spies to Brides: Fall Fashion Books
text: Two years ago, everybody seemed to be making a movie about the fashion world. Now, everybody is writing a book. Three new biographies of Coco Chanel are coming out, in case you’ve never heard of the lady from the Rue Cambon. There are also a number of designer monographs, quirky memoirs, style tomes and elegant surveys from magazine archives. It’s a huge season for fashion books — huge, as Diana Vreeland would have insisted, herself the subject of a new work.

headline: Latest Stop on the Art Circuit? Hydra, Greece
text: THE long communal table stretched out down a craggy path overlooking the Saronic Gulf. It had the cluttered look of a Renaissance painting, with remnants of grilled lamb, carafes of wine and abundant cutlery. But the overall effect was more minimalist; the sky was black save for a string of white party lights affixed to a telephone pole illuminating a barren hillside of rocks and prickly shrubs.

text: As part of his column this week, Bill Keller asked me if I could think of some poems that might be “helpful (inspirational, cautionary, exhortative, instructive) to a deadlocked, polarized and apparently lost Congress.” Here’s the somewhat hastily assembled list I sent to Bill, along with a couple of poems that occurred to me later.

headline: A Controversial Treatment, Step by Step
text: The following photographs show a cancer patient undergoing the Hipec treatment, a painful, invasive process that some patients believe represents their best chance of survival though it has not been clearly proven to work.

headline: ‘I Yield My Time to the Gentleman From Stratford-Upon-Avon’
text: Eleven summers ago I was sent to a management program at the Wharton School to be prepped for bigger things. Along with lectures on finance and entrepreneurship and the like, the program included a delightfully incongruous session with Al Filreis, an English professor at the University of Pennsylvania, on poetry.

headline: There’s Gold in That Scrap
text: It was 9 a.m. but already sweltering when Dave Petersen pulled his red pickup truck into S. D. Richman Sons Inc., a scrap-metal yard in Philadelphia’s industrial northeast. In the back of his truck were two old hot-water boilers, a rusty mattress frame and several lengths of outdated cast-iron pipe. “I’m a plumber, and the work is slow, so my plumber friends put me onto scrap,” Petersen said, his T-shirt soggy with sweat. “I brought a load yesterday and got $154. I expect to get about a deuce for this.”

headline: Life on the Line
text: Andrew Rice did a wonderful job in “Life on the Line” describing the misunderstood binational bubble that is El Paso, Tex., and Juárez, Mexico. His picture is incomplete, however. Virtually every one of the sources he quoted was someone who had more than enough money to pay for an investor’s visa or take other measures to flee the violence in Mexico and remake their lives on the U.S. side with very little disturbance to their family life. But what about the hundreds of thousands of poor Juarenses who escape with nothing more than the clothes on their backs and horrible stories haunting them? It’s not so easy. There are no visas to keep them safe, no work permits, and the U.S. government is reluctant to give them asylum, granting less than 2 percent of petitions from Mexican nationals.

headline: The Rollicking Life of Larry Hagman
text: I gather you’ve tried pretty much every drug, including mescaline, which you ate on an Indian reservation.  Well, I was in a hut with about 10 young Indian boys. I took this stuff and got real sick, but after a while that passed, and I looked down and I had bird’s claws, bird’s feet and fur instead of feathers. I thought, Well, golly, this is interesting. I flew around the hut, and then I flew through the wall and flew around the reservation and came back. It was a heavy-duty spiritual thing. I wouldn’t particularly want to do it again, but it was a wonderful experience.

headline: Watch Yourself
text: I believe that my name is on a Transportation Security Administration watch list. Often when I fly, the letters “SSSS” on my boarding pass alert gate agents to pull me aside for extra screening. But on a recent trip, a T.S.A. employee failed to notice the “SSSS.” I’m fairly certain that I am on the T.S.A. list because of my animal rights activism. I am not a threat to civil aviation. I was happy to avoid yet another bothersome search, but should I have spoken up? I wouldn’t want the guy to miss an actual threat. NICK A., FLORIDA

headline: The Regrets of a Semiprofessional Potterphile
text: Sometimes I feel as though I’ve written more words about Harry Potter than has J. K. Rowling herself. I reviewed installments in the movie series for two different newspapers. I assembled two separate Internet slide shows ranking all of the films. I led multiple book clubs about Harry Potter novels — one, discussing the sixth book, over e-mail with friends, and the other, about the seventh book, in an online magazine. I narrated a video critiquing Daniel Radcliffe’s acting. I penned blog posts on Good Snape versus Bad Snape. I mashed up Harry Potter with Tony Soprano. I created Ron Weasley’s Facebook page. I wrote an obituary for Hedwig the owl. I visited the Wizarding World of Harry Potter and whined publicly that it wasn’t magical enough. I wrote about Dumbledore coming out, Antonin Scalia’s resemblance to Snape and copyright-violating Asian knockoff books with titles like “Harry Potter and the Filler of Big.”

Confidential” style of heavy-handed policing, hostile relations with minorities and corruption. headline: The 80th Anniversary of Babar
text: This year marks the publication of an unusual number of new elephant books for children. But one literary elephant not only precedes them all but will also probably always tower over the rest: the intrepid, fair-minded, fatherly and eternally stylish Babar. Eighty years and 40-odd books after his debut, Babar continues to captivate young children.

A series of sultry black-and-white photos of Ms. Cobain, whom most of the world remembers as either an infant in her father’s arms or awkward adolescent, has been lighting up the Web after Hedi Slimane, the photographer and former Dior Homme designer, posted them just over a week ago. headline: A Writer’s Beginnings in Kenya
text: Harried reader, I’ll save you precious time: skip this review and head directly to the bookstore for Binyavanga Wainaina’s stand-up-and-cheer coming-of-age memoir, “One Day I Will Write About This Place.” Although written by an East African and set in East and Southern Africa, Wainaina’s book is not just for Afrophiles or lovers of post­colonial literature. This is a book for anyone who still finds the nourishment of a well-­written tale preferable to the empty-­calorie jolt of a celebrity confessional or Swedish mystery.

text: Chapter One

headline: Choosing to Stay in the City
text: Four older New York residents are among those deciding to retire in Manhattan.

headline: A Good Man Is Impossible to Find
text: From the opening sentences of Donald Ray Pollock’s violence-­soaked first novel, “The Devil All the Time,” it’s clear that blood will out. The West Virginia and southern Ohio landscapes of this book seem riven by one long, coal-smeared and hell-­harrowed gash in the earth, and the stories that vent from it file past in a crimson procession of evils so brutally creative, and so exactingly and lovingly detailed by Pollock, that over the course of the novel it becomes unclear whether they’ve been spawned for the purposes of plot or purely for atavistic pleasure.

headline: Charting Brain Growth in Humans and Chimps
text: Although baby humans and baby chimpanzees both start out with undeveloped forebrains, a new study reports that the human brain increases in volume much more rapidly early on.

headline: A Novel of Nigeria, Scotland and the Quest for Perfect Silence
text: There was once a time, centuries before Internet shopping, when buyers and sellers could honorably carry out their exchanges without ever meeting. In the gold-for-salt commerce of Saharan and Sahel tribes, for example, the Saharans would leave a salt pile by the banks of the Niger, then remove themselves so their clients could, in seclusion, deposit a sum of gold. At that point, the merchants would return, but if the payment was deemed insufficient, they would leave it with the salt and withdraw. The Sahel merchants would approach again, and this good-faith dance of advance and retreat would be repeated until both parties felt content with the deal.

headline: A Hacker Tells All
text: Considering the fact that Windows 95 hadn’t even been released when federal agents finally caught up with the computer hacker Kevin Mitnick, one might assume his new memoir would be full of stale old tech-and-­techniques that no one in 2011 could possibly care about. But as Mitnick makes clear here, don’t jump to conclusions.

headline: Dragons Ascendant: George R. R. Martin and the Rise of Fantasy
text: It’s a high time for high fantasy. Novels about wizards outsell (and often outshine) the most glittering literary fiction titles; the contemporary romantic hero generally sports a pair of fangs; and even now the five remaining earthlings who haven’t read “The Lord of the Rings” are being hunted down and put to the sword. Yet for all of fantasy’s successes, there remains a chip on the spaulder of the genre. As Michael Agger put it in 2009, reviewing Lev Grossman’s Harry Potter-­influenced novel “The Magicians”: “Perhaps a fantasy novel meant for adults can’t help being a strange mess of effects. . . . Sounds like fun, but aren’t we a little old for this?” And with that, hundreds of years of fantastical writing are reduced to 20-­sided dice, pencil nubs, half-filled Coke cans and the crushing realization that no, your elven rogue’s dagger is not going to be effective against green slime.

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: HALFWAY TO HOLLYWOOD  Diaries 1980-1988  By Michael Palin  Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s, $32.50.

headline: Up Front: Sam Lipsyte
text: Sam Lipsyte, who reviews Nicholson Baker’s “House of Holes” on our cover this week, knows something about sex writing: when his novel “The Ask” came out last year, Michael Dirda of The Washington Post wrote that its “rants become arias, and vulgarity sheer poetry.”

headline: Love, the Many-Splendored Emotion
text: The news about love — if anything can be said to be new when it comes to love — is that it affects us on more levels than we realized. Poets and artists have long viewed love as a prime mover, but by the beginning of the last century, scientists and philosophers were dismissing it as socially and scientifically irrelevant. Love was confined to private life, where only women and novelists and psychoanalysts were supposed to pay much attention to it. Then, a little more than half a century ago, biologists and economists and psychologists decided that love mattered after all, and began conducting experiments to determine how much.

headline: A Rough Rider Tackles a Rough Sport
text: Perhaps the National Football League executives who were heavily criticized by fans and players last season for trying to remove dangerous hits from the game can take solace: they have something in common with Theodore Roosevelt.

headline: The Curse of Musical Nostalgia
text: Five years ago, a young Scottish woman named Sandi Thom reached No. 1 on the British charts with her song “I Wish I Was a Punk Rocker (With Flowers in My Hair).” She delivered it with a voice of pleading and with a cappella sincerity, as if she were trying to sell you something. Perhaps that was why I found it irritating; or else it was the suggestion that punk rockers would break bread with someone who had flowers in her hair. Thanks to Simon Reynolds’s “Retromania,” I now understand that she “purposefully conflated 1967 and 1977 to speak to the vague nostalgia felt by many young people for a lost golden age when music had power and integrity.”

headline: Lethal Lessons in Misurata
text: C. J. Chivers provides analysis from Misurata, Libya, where rebels in a firefight with pro-Qaddafi forces demonstrate courage, but a serious lack of training.

headline: Explaining it All: How We Became the Center of the Universe
text: David Deutsch’s “Beginning of Infinity” is a brilliant and exhilarating and profoundly eccentric book. It’s about everything: art, science, philosophy, history, politics, evil, death, the future, infinity, bugs, thumbs, what have you. And the business of giving it anything like the attention it deserves, in the small space allotted here, is out of the question. But I will do what I can.

headline: O’Keeffe and Stieglitz: Intimacy at a Distance
text: Georgia O’Keeffe never seemed to mind having wrinkles. When we think of her, we are most likely to think of her later years, when she owned a ranch in Abiquiu, N.M., and roamed the red hills. She lived to be 98, and even after her hair went white, she was not shy about posing for photographs. As if to play up the pantheistic spirit of her art, she presented herself as an American natural, an exemplar of unbuttoned, un-­Botoxed ­authenticity.

headline: An African Chief in Cabby’s Clothing
text: BEFORE dawn, when most New Yorkers are fast asleep, Isaac and Elizabeth Osei have already been working for hours. On a recent morning, Mr. Osei drove his wife from New Jersey to the half-abandoned outer blocks of Midtown Manhattan to oversee the 4:30 a.m. transfer of their fleet of 50 taxis. With Ms. Osei leading the way and a sliver of moon still hanging in the sky, they scouted three square blocks to make sure all of their taxis had been picked up by drivers. Then, over the screeches emanating from auto-body shops and the smell of gasoline wafting from a Hess station crammed with cabs, they surveyed their troubled taxis just as sunlight faintly appeared over Manhattan.

headline: Race, Inheritance and Returning to the South
text: It takes less than a day to drive from Philadelphia to Beaufort County, S.C., but to Alonzo Rayne, the 30-year-old protagonist of “If Sons, Then Heirs,” the journey spans more than a hundred years. From the very start of Lorene Cary’s latest novel, when Rayne sets off to visit Nana Selma, the great-­grandmother who raised him, he’s enveloped by a sense of home. Taking along his girlfriend’s 7-year-old son, Rayne has high hopes for what the trip will give the boy: “How good it would be for him to have the experience of earlier generations, to spend time in a rural setting, to know from their own experience that black people . . . owned land and barns and silos, that they had rights to water from creeks and streams.”

headline: A Second Home for Affluent Chinese
text: WEALTHY buyers from mainland China, a rapidly expanding economy of 1.3 billion people, are increasingly turning to Manhattan for their luxury real estate purchases, brokers say.

headline: Byredo’s New Mister Is Simply Marvelous

headline: Romantic Mischief in 1930s Manhattan
text: The saying “May you live in interesting times” has undeniable resonance for the investment executive-turned-­novelist Amor Towles. In 1989, he was set to go to China for two years to teach. When the Tiananmen Square massacre put an abrupt end to that plan, he headed for Manhattan. On his first night in the city, he met two strangers. One would become his brother-in-law; through the other, he found the job in which he has worked for 20 years. What would have happened if he’d hit town a day later? This is the kind of improbable-but-true serendipity that plots the lives of people in their 20s — in whatever epoch — before they know the weight that decisions made in a moment might have.

headline: Paperback Row

Doerr’s brooding tales move gracefully back and forth between distant times and places — South Africa, Germany, Lithuania, China, the United States — and are linked by a preoccupation with the way memories are eroded by the depredations of time.

headline: Inside the List
text: REQUIRED READING: Can a peaceable literary vegetarian from Brooklyn bring together what a bloody Southern basketball rivalry has torn asunder? That was surely the hope of administrators at Duke and the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, when they chose Jonathan Safran Foer’s “Eating Animals” as the joint summer reading for this fall’s incoming freshmen. So far, the carnivore-unfriendly choice does not seem to have elicited any complaints from the local barbecue industry, though the state’s educators have courted controversy before. In 2002, conservative pundits and state legislators howled when U.N.C. assigned Michael Sells’s “Approaching the Qur’an,” calling it an insult to the memory of Sept. 11. In 2003, a student group called The Committee for a Better Carolina denounced that year’s choice, Barbara Ehrenreich’s “Nickel and Dimed,” as a “classic Marxist rant” and “intellectual pornography with no redeeming characteristics.”

headline: All Consuming | The Ann Demeulemeester Lace-Up Heel
text: Call them the ones that got away. Spring 2009: Ann Demeulemeester’s open-toe lace-up heels came down the runway and the quiet, almost suspicious stirring that precedes a full-blown frenzy began. Everyone wanted them. And, why wouldn’t they: hefty heel, combat-boot-like lacing that left just the right amount of skin showing, options in black or brown leather. But despite the hype — countless credits in fashion magazines, followed by colleagues professing how comfortable they were while wearing them with everything from jean shorts to Sunday dresses — I didn’t buy a pair. My reason (aside from the $965 price tag)? I wasn’t going to let myself fall for another of-the-moment shoe.

headline: How Crimes Have Changed
text: JUST as hemlines rise and fall, so do fashions in crime — or, at least, its fictional representation — evolve from decade to decade and even from year to year. Bracketing the 1950s a group of four crime films recently released by the Warner Archive Collection suggest just how radical those shifts can be. A pair of films from 1949, Richard O. Fleischer’s “Follow Me Quietly,” and “The Threat,” directed by Felix E. Feist, reflect an entirely different set of concerns from two movies produced at the end of the ’50s: “The Purple Gang” (1959), directed by Frank McDonald, and “The Rise and Fall of Legs Diamond” (1960) by Budd Boetticher.

headline: Letters: Planning a Vac(cin)ation
text: To the Editor: Re the Practical Traveler column (July 31): Having traveled abroad a number of times, I have sought methods to avoid incurring large expenses when getting vaccines. Many travel clinics charge more than $80 for a consult as their vaccine prices are often artificially inflated (Havrix for hepatitis A has a wholesale price of about $73, not $90). I typically read mdtravelhealth.com to find out what vaccines I need, ask my primary care doctor to call these into a good pharmacy that charges wholesale on vaccines (e.g. the Cure, 1025A Third Avenue, at 60th Street, Manhattan; thecureshop.com), then pick them up at the pharmacy and go to my physician who administers them for a normal insurance co-pay. David Pelavin

headline: Walking Martha’s Vineyard
text: DOWN a looping path deep in the Martha’s Vineyard woods, history keeps a muted vigil. It was here at Waskosim’s Rock, more than 300 years ago, that leaders of the native Wampanoag tribe met with the Mayhews (named after one of the area’s first settlers, Thomas Mayhew) to create a “Middle Line” division of property. Southwest of the boundary would remain in native control; north and east would be Mayhew territory. The great natural monument, lichen dappled and framed within a modest clearing, always surprises me when I approach it. There are no special signs along the trail. Nor will you find one of those historical markers, in cast iron, lettering raised, once you arrive. In fact, count yourself lucky to find the trailhead at all. Waskosim’s Rock, just off North Road in Chilmark, Mass., and the rest of the many splendid walking trails on Martha’s Vineyard, are a casually well-kept secret.

headline: In Halifax, an Old Market Gets a New Home
text: THE Halifax Seaport Farmers’ Market, in the Nova Scotian capital, is the oldest continuously running farmers’ market in North America, in operation since 1750. But it suddenly feels very modern in its new 56,000-square-foot harborside home. After spending time in 14 different locations, including church basements and a brewery, the market reopened last November in a specially constructed multilevel space that features every conceivable aspect of sustainable design, and highlights the local bounty of the region.

headline: British Reporters, Not Ad Men, in ’50s, Not ’60s
text: London -- ONE surprising notion that might strike you while watching “The Hour” — BBC America’s six-part series about a hard-hitting television news program in 1956 Britain and the men and women who work for it — is that Peggy Olson didn’t have it so bad. At least on “Mad Men,” the midcentury-period AMC drama, one gets the impression that Peggy — the peep-voiced, wide-eyed advertising copywriter struggling to establish herself in a man’s world — has a few equally ambitious girlfriends to gripe with about the boy’s club. On “The Hour,” however, the shoulder that the head producer Bel Rowley (Romola Garai) ends up crying on is that of Freddie (Ben Whishaw), a tenacious reporter who is also in love with her.

headline: Steinem’s Story, for a New Generation
text: SHEILA NEVINS, the longtime president of HBO’s documentary film division, calls Gloria Steinem “next to my mother, the most important woman I’ve ever met.” But when asked about Ms. Steinem, the most familiar face of the women’s movement, her staff had a different reaction. “We went up and down the halls of HBO and half the kids on the floor didn’t know who she was,” Ms. Nevins said.

headline: A Good Night For Obama

headline: On the Street | In Flower
text: Vincent van Gogh’s fascination with sunflowers is reflected in the many shades of yellow setting off summer tans.

headline: The Jam | Alain Levitt
text: Where there’s a solid restaurant, a solid playlist can most likely be found. For this week’s Jam, Sean Hanratty of Santos Party House has chosen Alain Levitt, whohelps run his wife’s Venetian restaurant, Bacaro, in Manhattan’s Chinatown district. “The music is always amazing in there, and the environment and décor is incredible,” saysHanratty, who is a regular at the intimate vento Italian restaurant on Division near Ludlow. “Alain is usually behind the bar smiling and just being wonderful.” Hanratty quickly learned Levitt recently started a “super-high-energy duo, which usually involved costumes” called Bubbles. (Already, Levitt’s synth-pop outfit with the vocalist Jason Grisell has opened up for Florence and the Machine at Central Park Summerstage and played on a boat with Gang Gang Dance.) The band, who says they “just want to make everyone dance,” is hard at work on a new release. “I knew Alain’s playlist would be a super-diverse set, with songs I personally have always gravitated towards,” says Hanratty of the beat maker who hails from California. Check out Bubbles in the basement of Santos tonight.

headline: N.F.L. Exhibitions Give Networks a Ratings Kick

headline: Nina Sankovitch, Allaying Grief Through Books
text: FOR three years after the death of her adored eldest sister, Anne-Marie, Nina Sankovitch mourned by staying relentlessly busy. She felt a guilt-strafed survivor’s obligation to live life enough for two.

headline: Good Fortune Brings Bad-Guy Roles
text: THE news that “Conan the Barbarian” was being screened for journalists in New York brought a mischievous grin from the ferocious warlord Khalar Zym, a k a Stephen Lang. “Do I own it?” he asked. “It’s an innocent question. I’d like to think I could do a romantic comedy, you know? But villains are a necessity. Without them, what’s your hero got?”

headline: A Wineglass Fills in for a Period Instrument
text: When ensembles that play mostly standard repertory take on contemporary works, they think of it as stretching, a broadening of their horizons. Perhaps it’s the same for a group like the International Contemporary Ensemble when it turns its attention to Mozart and, in the context of its usual wet-ink repertory, Schoenberg, as it did in a Mostly Mozart concert on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Or maybe not: however these players spend their time now, they lived and breathed the standard repertory during their student years, which were not long ago.

headline: In the Village, Nothing but Tiramisu
text: Nadia Tade, a tiramisu enthusiast from Italy, and her partner, Alessandro Radici, who is in the graduate business school at Columbia, hope to make tiramisu the next gelato. With Dolce Vizio Tiramisu, which opens Saturday, they will tap into what appears to be a growing trend in Italy, variations on tiramisu, the traditional Venetian dessert made with a type of lady fingers layered with a mascarpone custard and flavored with espresso and cocoa.

headline: Love Letter to Auto-Tune, Final Installment
text: In the first and second installments of our guide to Auto-Tune pop — check them out here and here — we’ve tried to make the case that, when it’s used creatively, Auto-Tune can be a tool for artists, rather than a crutch. But the biggest criticism Auto-Tune’s critics level against it is that it’s the sonic equivalent of plastic surgery or ‘roids, a digital fix that lets lousy singers skip over that whole learning-to-carry-a-tune thing (boring!) and cut straight to pop stardom’s V.I.P. room. And there’s some truth to that — while the listening public’s acceptance of Auto-Tune has undeniably opened up new avenues of expression for rappers and singers, it’s also enabled some of the world’s most annoying famous people to annoy us in new ways. (Note: We mean no disrespect by including Drake here — his Auto-Tune songs are actually pretty great. But he started out as an actor, so technically he belongs in this category. Hopefully the fact that he is a rich, beautiful man will soften the blow.)

headline: Intuitions Unsaid but Issued in Rhythms
text: The Rez Abbasi Acoustic Quartet began a new tune at Iridium on Thursday night with Mr. Abbasi alone on guitar, sketching a three-note pattern over a seven-beat cycle. Then, having set a groove in motion, he handed it like a spinning plate to the vibraphonist Bill Ware, who obligingly carried it onward. Bass and drums struck up a crosscurrent, clattering and oblique, as Mr. Abbasi introduced a flinty melody, darting through the stir.

headline: This Sunday: Three for Two
text: “I think we’re done with twins for a while,” a colleague told me as we were closing this week’s issue. She had a point. For the third time this year, we have a cover story that involves multiples. The first was Melanie Thernstrom’s story about the two surrogate children she had at the same time (she calls them “twiblings”); the second was Sue Dominus on little Krista and Tatiana Hogan, who are joined at the head; and now we have Ruth Padawer on parents who are expecting twins but decide to have only one.

headline: Market turmoil; riskier “risk free” investments; doing good by doing well, and economic lessons from World War II

headline: Plan C is Not All Play
text: Plan B, leaving the corporate world to work on your own, has its upsides, but it comes with pitfalls, too. The dream job is a job, not just a dream.

headline: Maybe It’s Time for Plan C
text: RONA ECONOMOU was a lawyer at a large Manhattan law firm, making a comfortable salary and enjoying nights on the town when she was laid off in 2009, another victim of the recession. At first, she cried. “Then it hit me,” said Ms. Economou, now 33. “This is my one chance” to pursue a dream.

headline: Chic in Review | A Model Lohan
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: G.O.P. House Majority at Risk
text: There has been various circumstantial evidence that the public’s dissatisfaction with the performance of Congress, particularly during the debt ceiling debate, could threaten the Republican majority in the House of Representatives. Disapproval ratings for the Congress are at record highs, as are disapproval ratings for the Republican Party. Other polls show record numbers of Americans saying that their representative should not be re-elected, that most members of Congress should not be re-elected, or both.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 12
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include water skiing, studying with the help of rap music, and a Russian grandmother turned television star.

headline: Invasion of the Pop-Ups: Time for a Smackdown
text: Somebody get me a large mallet.

headline: For Theater Lovers, a City Is the Stage, and a Purple Cow Is a Prop
text: EDINBURGH — Julian Sands stands alone onstage at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, dressed in an impeccably tailored suit that seems all the more natty in contrast to the tattered copy of “Various Voices,” a compilation of the writings of the playwright Harold Pinter, that he clutches. The book is bursting with Post-it notes. Mr. Sands spends about an hour there, recounting anecdotes about his personal experiences working with Pinter, the Nobel Laureate, who died in 2008.

headline: A Wild Ride in the Markets
text: Looking back at a week of confusion.

headline: Santa Fe Celebration Includes New York
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — For its 39th season this summer, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival is presenting 78 artists and ensembles performing more than 100 works in 42 programs over 5 weeks. But for a critic from New York and, I would guess, some vacationing New Yorkers in the audience, two recent programs made this important festival seem almost an outpost of the New York music scene.

headline: Where Feet, Beat and Joy All Soar Funkily
text: At the end of a day of perfect New York summer weather on Thursday, the mood established by the Lincoln Center Out of Doors two-part event of dance and live music at the Damrosch Park Bandshell was just right: generous, warm, high-spirited real entertainment for a big audience. But while the first half of the evening — featuring Debo Band with the special guests Fendika — was characterized by startling and thrilling particulars, the dance and music in the second half — David Dorfman Dance with the Family Stone — was little more than exercises in mood.

headline: The Week That Was, in Verse
text: Even on a week when the Dow industrials took a wild roller-coaster ride, there were other stories, here on DealBook, that piqued Wall Street’s interest. As always, we recount them in poetic form:

headline: Ushering City Opera Into a New Era
text: To paraphrase the conclusion of Camus’s essay “The Myth of Sisyphus”: one must imagine George Steel happy. And he is more than happy to play along.

headline: Riots, Good Credit and Stocks
text: After a week of wild swings, stock markets ended with relatively mild moves for the week, proving there was no need to come home from vacation just because there was a little volatility.

headline: Family Happiness and the Overbooked Child
text: I LIVE in an area where most parents would rather cut back on indulgences for themselves than stop paying for their children’s activities.

headline: Cadillac Converj May Go Forward, but Not With A123 Batteries
text: When Green Car Reports broke the news on Thursday that General Motors had decided to produce a version of its Cadillac Converj concept, the idea advanced quickly through the blogosphere.

headline: Podcast: Bonds, Markets, the Economy and History
text: The markets are being whipsawed. How severe has the volatility been? One statistic tells the story: for the first time in its history, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index moved up or down by at least 4 percent on four consecutive days.

headline: Reviewing the GMC Sierra Denali 2500HD, Ram Power Wagon and Ford F-350 Super Duty
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Ezra Dyer reviews three new pickup trucks intended to haul more than just a few planks of lumber and a toolbox. The heavy-duty GMC Sierra Denali 2500HD, Ram Power Wagon and Ford F-350 Super Duty are machines that can tow 20,000 pounds or more and command prices north of $50,000.

headline: Trying Hard to Stay in Line After a Wrong Turn
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — They were considered the top two quarterbacks in the high school class of 2005. Heavily recruited, they each decided to stay in-state and play for their local B.C.S. power. And both of them could be playing home games at New Meadowlands Stadium this season.

text: It’s a bank that hasn’t been much on Wall Street’s radar since the days of the A.I.G. bailout.

headline: After Trip, Piercy Makes a Splash
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Scott Piercy, the last of 156 players to earn entry to the P.G.A. Championship, had planned a vacation this week for his family of five that would begin with a Monday trek to SeaWorld in San Diego.

headline: Health Law Is Dealt Blow by a Court on Mandate
text: The provision in President Obama’s health care law requiring Americans to buy health insurance or face tax penalties was ruled unconstitutional on Friday by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta.

headline: What They Said, Exactly, About New York
text: THE novelist Anatole France once ingenuously offered this advice to fellow writers: “When a thing has been said and well said, have no scruple: take it and copy it.” A friend, the self-possessed journalist Doug Ireland, once described his own muse even more bluntly. “The world,” he declared, “is my Bartlett’s.”

headline: Puck Drops Again, Far From the Ice
text: IT may seem a bit odd to take a summer stroll down the boardwalk in Rockaway Beach, Queens, and suddenly come upon a squad of armored hockey players gliding around as if on some frozen pond.

headline: Bloggingheads: 'Weird' Mitt Romney
text: Ryan Lizza, left, of The New Yorker and Ramesh Ponnuru of National Review debate a possible line of attack against Mitt Romney.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Strikers Trade Barbs With Verizon
text: Ever since 45,000 workers began their strike against Verizon Communications on Sunday, their unions have repeatedly stressed one point: Verizon’s push for concessions would “destroy middle-class jobs” and “push workers out of the middle class.”

headline: Racetrack Education Leads to Law Career
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Drew Mollica has been around the racetrack for 30 years, and he looks the part — a mop of hair flecked with gray, a sparkle in his eye behind glasses the size of a windshield and quick with a name, a backslap, a story. Just two years ago, he was a jockey’s agent, a good one who over the years had put Hall of Famers like Angel Cordero Jr. and Jose Santos on horses.

text: To the Editor:

headline: After Youth Workshop, a Real Jazz Festival
text: LAST year’s inaugural Montclair Jazz Festival was organized mostly to celebrate the end of the summer workshop at Jazz House Kids, a nonprofit organization that promotes jazz education.

headline: Searching for Truth, Under Cover of Lies
text: If we had all been living in Italy in 1969, we might consider Dario Fo’s “Accidental Death of an Anarchist” a lot more shocking. That year, Giuseppe Pinelli, a railway worker accused of being involved in a bombing, died after falling, jumping or being pushed from a fourth-floor window in a police station in Milan. Could it really have been murder?

headline: Should New York Keep Its Carriage Horses?
text: To the Editor:

headline: China: Maker Recalls 54 Trains
text: One of China’s high-speed train manufacturers, the CNR Corporation, announced Friday that it was recalling 54 of its trains from the Beijing to Shanghai route to test sensors that may be causing the trains to stop unnecessarily, such as when a passenger lights a cigarette in a restroom. The Rail Ministry announced separately Thursday that the number of high-speed trains each day between Beijing and Shanghai would be reduced to 66 in each direction starting next Tuesday, from 88 in each direction now. The moves, coming after the government announced a safety review of high-speed rail on Wednesday, seemed to reflect heightened concern after a deadly high-speed rail crash last month.
