text: To the Editor:

headline: Foreigners Follow Money to Booming Brazil, Land of $35 Martini
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Pondering the financial storms lashing Europe and the United States, Seth Zalkin, a casually dressed American banker, sipped a demitasse and seemed content with his decision to move here in March with his wife and son.

headline: Boycott Campaign Donations!
text: Howard Schultz, the chairman and chief executive of Starbucks, has always been the kind of boss who wears his heart on his sleeve. So it came as no surprise to Starbucks employees when, on Monday, he sent out a long, passionate, companywide e-mail entitled “Leading Through Uncertain Times.”

headline: Iraqi Leader Backs Syria, With a Nudge From Iran
text: BAGHDAD — As leaders in the Arab world and other countries condemn President Bashar al-Assad’s violent crackdown on demonstrators in Syria, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq has struck a far friendlier tone, urging the protesters not to “sabotage” the state and hosting an official Syrian delegation.

headline: Scott LeDoux, Gritty Heavyweight Boxing Contender, Dies at 62
text: Scott LeDoux, the boxer known as the Fighting Frenchman, a contender for the heavyweight title in the mid-1970s and early ’80s, died Thursday at his home in Coon Rapids, Minn. He was 62.

headline: Herding Cats on a Runway at the Algonquin
text: It was moments before a fashion show, and Elvis, clad in a leather and leopard-print jumpsuit, was having a meltdown backstage. Blood was drawn and fur flew, so a therapist was called in to calm the divo with a combination of Reiki massage, soft music and a dash of catnip.

headline: Relaxing Under Liberty’s Shadow
text: David Luchsinger, 61, the superintendent of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, lives with his wife, Debbie, in a small brick house on Liberty Island, which is almost 15 acres. The closest thing they have to a neighbor, Lady Liberty, is obscured by trees on their plot of the island, as are the approximately 3.5 million tourists who visit the monument each year. (Mr. Luchsinger will remain on the island and on the job during the statue’s renovation, which starts in October.) Sunday is for taking the boat to church or to shop, and for relaxing on the island — under surveillance.

headline: F.T.C. Questions Bid to Spur Competition Between Drug Stores and Mail-Order Pharmacies
text: The Federal Trade Commission has issued an advisory opinion questioning a proposed New York State law intended to make it easier for neighborhood drug stores to compete with mail-order pharmacies.

headline: Portugal Praised for Progress on Financial Overhaul
text: MADRID — The new Portuguese government has made “a good start” to lowering its budget deficit and meeting the economic overhaul pledged in return for a bailout of 78 billion euros, or $111 billion, the country’s financial rescuers said Friday.

headline: Bay Area Officials Cut Cell Coverage to Thwart Protestors
text: To nip protest in the bud, authorities cut off a public communications system.

headline: Is London Burning?
text: A week that began as what many called Prime Minister David Cameron’s “Katrina Moment” ended as, well, what?

headline: For Boyhood Friends, an End to 17 Years of Holdups and Lockups
text: When the end came, it sounded like a door slamming shut.

headline: Magical Unrealism
text: There was nothing particularly surprising about the shrill skirmishing at the ideological edges of Thursday night’s Republican presidential debate in Iowa. What was shocking were the antics in the center.

headline: Qaeda Trying to Harness Toxin for Bombs, U.S. Officials Fear
text: WASHINGTON — American counterterrorism officials are increasingly concerned that the most dangerous regional arm of Al Qaeda is trying to produce the lethal poison ricin, to be packed around small explosives for attacks against the United States.

headline: ‘A Car Guy’ Prepares to Choose a Leader for a Troubled Mass-Transit Agency
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo proudly calls himself “a car guy, and a motorcycle guy, and a boat guy.” One thing he is not, however, is a subway guy.

headline: Britain Turns to Former New York and Los Angeles Police Official for Help
text: William J. Bratton, who was heralded as a crime-fighter after taming New York City’s rampant violence in the mid-1990s, has now been summoned to London to help salvage a British police force that has been bruised and maligned following days of rioting, deaths and arson fires.

headline: More Complex Picture Emerges in Rutgers Student’s Suicide
text: Court papers filed this week offer a more complex picture of the Rutgers freshman who jumped to his death from the George Washington Bridge in September and of his roommate, who used a webcam days earlier to spy on him in an intimate encounter with another man.

headline: Celebrating a Heritage and Its Music
text: WHEN the artist and sometime impresario Annie Pugsley hired the flutist Joseph FireCrow to appear at an art show and concert to raise money for a charity that helps Lakota Indians, she invited him to spend a day with her at Music Vale Farm, her property in Salem, Conn., where she will hold the event. The property, Ms. Pugsley said, has an “energy vortex,” and communing on it with Mr. FireCrow was a transcendent experience.

headline: Looking Lost, Woods Takes Nearest Exit
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Hole after hole Friday, the fans called to him, “Hang in there, Tiger.”

headline: We, Robot
text: “The Office” and “Parks and Recreation” and “30 Rock” were all repeats, so on Thursday night the most entertaining first-run comedy in prime time was on Fox News. And it was live!

headline: Enrollment Plunge for DeVry Sends Stock Lower
text: DeVry, the operator of DeVry University, said new undergraduate enrollment fell 26 percent, setting off a 17 percent loss in its share price. New summer enrollment dropped to 15,566, from 20,935 a year earlier, DeVry said. State and federal officials have been investigating profit-making colleges, and the Education Department has put new restrictions on financing for education companies. Adjusting to the regulations created distractions for employees, DeVry said Thursday. “Enrollment has been most impacted by the prolonged economic downturn and continued high unemployment, which has led some potential students to defer or refrain from making the commitment to enroll in college,” the company said. Stock in DeVry, which is based in Downers Grove, Ill., fell $8.90 to $44.49 a share.

headline: Carvings as Memorials to Alphabets in Peril
text: TIM BROOKES, who is exhibiting his work at the Sachem Public Library gallery, in Holbrook, has trouble thinking of himself as an artist.

headline: Faded Star Seeks Return to Glory (and Big Screen)
text: In the film and musical versions of “Sunset Boulevard,” the most poignant moment occurs when the half-forgotten silent-screen idol Norma Desmond returns to her former studio and is swarmed by the extra players who recognize her as the goddess she once was.

headline: Four Closing Holes Have Kick as Two Tie for the Lead
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — The final four holes at the Atlanta Athletic Club have a certain sinister beauty to them, a siren-song attraction that can lure unwary golfers at the P.G.A. Championship onto the rocks of ruined rounds and drowned chances.

headline: Along the Jersey Shore, a Struggle to Get to the Sand
text: SEA BRIGHT, N.J. — If you find the rare parking spot here, and climb one of the few public stairways over the seawall to a crowded patch of sand, you might notice a nearly empty expanse of beach nearby, beyond a “no trespassing” sign.

headline: Tearing Down Berlin’s Mental Wall
text: Berlin

headline: Johns Creek Gets on the Map
text: The dateline appearing on reports from the P.G.A. Championship is not just unfamiliar to readers around the country. Many residents of metro Atlanta would be unable to locate it on a map.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Photos
text: Chaotic markets after a downgrade of United States debt, a controversial cancer treatment and suffering crops.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For Egyptians, British Riots Are a Mix of Familiar and Peculiar
text: CAIRO — After decades of hearing the West bemoan the lawlessness of Arab societies, Egyptians watched this week with a mix of empathy, disgust and perhaps a measure of satisfaction as the British authorities struggled for four days to rein in arson and looting in London and other major cities.

headline: Genuflecting to the Tea Party
text: I must confess that every time Representative Michele Bachmann uttered the phrase “as president of the United States” during Thursday’s Republican presidential debate I blacked out a little bit, so I’m sure that I missed some things.

headline: Patient Ryan Postpones Burress’s Debut With the Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — As badly as he wanted to see wide receiver Plaxico Burress play in an actual game, Jets Coach Rex Ryan informed Burress on Friday morning that he would not accompany the team to Houston for its preseason opener Monday against the Texans.

headline: When Will You Retire?
text: Is this any way to plan for retirement? After a week of huge swings, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index, a broad gauge of the market, was modestly higher on Friday but still down for the week.

headline: A County in Alabama Puts Off Bankruptcy
text: Officials in troubled Jefferson County, Ala., rebuffed a settlement offer with creditors on Friday but refrained from declaring bankruptcy, saying they wanted to try to reach a better deal in face-to-face negotiations with their lenders.

headline: Don Chandler, Standout Kicker in N.F.L., Dies at 76
text: Don Chandler, who played on four N.F.L. championship teams with the Giants and the Green Bay Packers, becoming one of the leading punters and place-kickers of his era, died on Thursday in Tulsa, Okla. He was 76.

headline: A Century-Old Prison Prepares to Shut Down
text: As sentencing guidelines are revised, some states are finding an excess of prison cells. The Texas system, for example, finds it is operating so far under capacity that it is closing its 1,100-bed prison in Sugar Land.

headline: Trend to Lighten Harsh Sentences Catches On in Conservative States
text: WASHINGTON — Fanned by the financial crisis, a wave of sentencing and parole reforms is gaining force as it sweeps across the United States, reversing a trend of “tough on crime” policies that lasted for decades and drove the nation’s incarceration rate to the highest — and most costly — level in the developed world.

headline: In $32 Million Contract, State Lays Out Some Rules for Its Standardized Tests
text: Standardized tests in English and math taken by students in New York State are about to become slightly less tricky.

headline: Jani Lane, Heavy-Metal Lead Singer, Dies at 47
text: Jani Lane, the flaxen-haired former lead singer for the heavy metal band Warrant who wrote its 1990 hit “Cherry Pie" and other anthems, was found dead on Thursday in a hotel room near his home in Los Angeles. He was 47.

headline: Saturday: Celebrity Guest Blogger Daniel Okrent
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Before anyone accuses me of being a troublemaker, I would like to say that Daniel Okrent is appearing here today as our celebrity guest blogger of his own free will and because he simply loves solving crossword puzzles. His contribution has nothing, and I mean nothing* to do with the fact that TIME Magazine contributor Joel Stein, who appeared here in June (Across Lite, Solution, blog), accused him of being smug or perhaps even too smart for his own good. This is a blog about crossword puzzles, after all, and it would certainly not be appropriate to use this forum to stoke the fires of competitiveness or to provoke two renowned journalists into a public face-off, no matter how much fun I could have doing it.

headline: A Polarizing Polar Bear Investigation
text: A modest scientific observation about a few drowning polar bears has enmeshed a government wildlife biologist in an investigation into whether he is guilty of scientific misconduct. The investigation has taken on symbolic importance in the debate over global warming.

headline: Surprises Behind the Curtains
text: Not far down the road from Boscobel, where the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival is performing through the summer, Graze, a casual part-time restaurant edged into a corner of the Garrison Market, has added its own bit of drama to Route 9D.

headline: Progress on Fair Courts
text: At its recent annual meeting, the American Bar Association took overdue action to protect judicial fairness and impartiality in the face of skyrocketing special-interest spending in state judicial elections. By a unanimous vote, the A.B.A.’s House of Delegates approved a resolution calling for states to adopt clear new rules for recusal to cover instances when campaign spending by litigants or lawyers causes a judge’s impartiality to be questioned.

headline: A Variety of Influences on the Waterfront
text: DOLPHIN, a year-old addition to the Yonkers waterfront, has a little something for everyone: Vegas-style interior and patio dining in the sunshine, sexy, low-slung sofas and an affordable children’s menu. At the equal opportunity bar, you can catch the Mets game at one end, the Yankees game at the other, and sip a Budweiser or step up to a Blue Moon Belgian White.

headline: Cashman Defends High-Priced Burnett’s Pitching
text: General Manager Brian Cashman was engaging in some banter near the Yankees’ dugout before Friday night’s game against the Tampa Bay Rays when reporters approached him to ask about the team’s pending decision on the starting rotation.

headline: A Lunch Truck in Disguise
text: A mural of a vintage blue Ford pickup surrounded by grapevines rises, miragelike, from the gravel parking lot of the North Fork Table and Inn in Southold. Painted on wood by Rita Rooney, a local artist, it serves as a more appealing facade for the nondescript van that sits behind it, which actually functions as the Lunch Truck, a casual annex to the restaurant.

headline: In a Second-Floor Aerie, an Ambitious Debut
text: HUNTINGTON SOCIAL is a hidden gem. Even though the month-old newcomer is at the corner of Huntington’s busiest intersection, New York Avenue and Main Street, it is out of sight on the second floor; diners must look up to spot it. Over the years, the space has housed bars and clubs but never a serious restaurant.

headline: The World This Week, Part 1
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: The World This Week, Part 2
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: In a Strip Mall, a Lively Bar
text: The neoclassical facade of MiKro Craft Beer Bar is nearly identical to those of its neighbors in an otherwise nondescript nine-store strip mall in Hamden. Concealed behind its gauze curtains, however, is a hopping after-work destination and one of Connecticut’s more noteworthy beer bars.

headline: Contemporary Italian With a Vintage Look
text: TOSCANA TRATTORIA in downtown Greenwich has the darkly lighted look of an old-time Italian restaurant, with an inviting display of fresh ingredients, an extra-large, awkward-to-hold menu and a long stretch of banquettes.

headline: Touches of the Mediterranean
text: The tiny cafe Two Aprons, in Jersey City, draws a laid-back neighborhood crowd for breakfast and lunch. The croissants ($1.75 for plain), baked on the premises, are especially popular, and so are the Turkish cheese panini ($7), made with imported kashkaval cheese, a cured beef called pastirma, roasted pepper paste, onions and peppers, according to the owner, Vecdi Bilgin. But at dinnertime, the place can bustle a bit. Chalk that up to the chicken.

headline: Mother’s Recipes Inspire a Middle Eastern Menu
text: THE atmosphere at Marhaba (“welcome” in Arabic), which is tucked into a small shopping center opposite a playground in Lambertville, is one of low-key comfort, reminiscent of a friend’s kitchen.

headline: Daniel D. McCracken, Expert on Computers, Dies at 81
text: Daniel D. McCracken, the first best-selling author of books that taught people how to use computers, died on July 30 in New York. He was 81.

headline: Paul Meier, Statistician Who Revolutionized Medical Trials, Dies at 87
text: Paul Meier, a leading medical statistician who had a major influence on how the federal government assesses and makes decisions about new treatments that can affect the lives of millions, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: A Summer Idyll, and Then Three Bullets
text: IN the hour before sunset on June 30, Calvin Chu was with his wife, Melissa, and 15-month-old daughter, Emma, at the playground in Morningside Park, awaiting the long holiday weekend. Children splashed under graceful arcs of water from the sprinklers or clambered over a hanging wooden bridge.

headline: Market Swings Through the Decades
text: Volatility in this week’s stock market has made 2011 among the more turbulent years.

headline: Sabathia Falters, and the Yankees Fall to the Rays
text: General Manager Brian Cashman created a stir on Friday before the Yankees even took the field against the Tampa Bay Rays when he defended A. J. Burnett against suggestions that his struggles could warrant his removal from the team’s starting rotation.

headline: After a Scorching July, Mets’ Wright Cools Off in August
text: PHOENIX — When David Wright returned to the Mets in July after more than two months on the disabled list, he looked better at the plate than he did before the injury.

headline: Battle for Libya | Aug. 12, 2011
text: Libyans attended the funeral of five rebels killed in Brega, and rebels took control of Tuarga.

headline: Republicans Compete Before Iowa Straw Poll
text: A half-dozen Republican presidential hopefuls jockeyed for attention Friday on the eve of the Iowa straw poll.

headline: Mexico’s Drug War, Feminized. Photographs by Katie Orlinsky
text: The number of women incarcerated for federal crimes in Mexico has grown exponentially. Katie Orlinsky photographed women at El Cereso, a prison in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Jockey for Advantage in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — A half-dozen Republican presidential hopefuls jockeyed Friday for attention on the eve of the Iowa straw poll, a ritual that has taken on outsize meaning as candidates brace for a summertime shake-up in the party’s nominating fight.

headline: Scoring and Spending in England’s Premier League
text: The Premier League season opens on Saturday, but even before the first ball is kicked many believe the title race is open only to a limited field. Rob Hughes looks at where the money that runs the league comes from, and where the trophy will probably end up. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Redefining Art
text: The Museum of Modern Art offers an excellent retrospective of Martin Kippenberger’s messy and raucous works. Holland Cotter reviews.

headline: The Beginning of German Expressionism
text: The collective rawness of early 20th-century German art still startles, as seen in “Brücke,” at the Neue Galerie. Roberta Smith reviews.

headline: Resistance Widens to Obama Initiative on Criminal Immigrants
text: BOSTON — Mayor Thomas Menino, who often invokes his heritage as the grandson of an Italian immigrant, was one of the first local leaders in the country to embrace a federal program intended to improve community safety by deporting dangerous immigrant criminals.

headline: Faltering Rhode Island City Tests Vows to Pensioners
text: When the small, beleaguered city of Central Falls, R.I., filed for bankruptcy this month, it sought to cut the pension checks it has been sending its retired police officers, firefighters and other workers by as much as half. All the city promises now is that its retirees, many of whom do not get Social Security, will not have their benefits cut to less than $10,000 a year.

headline: Mexico’s Drug War, Feminized. Photographs by Katie Orlinsky
text: The number of women incarcerated for federal crimes in Mexico has grown exponentially. Katie Orlinsky photographed women at El Cereso, a prison in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.

headline: Mets Lose to Diamondbacks as Hopes for Late Run Dim
text: PHOENIX — Jason Bay was standing in the outfield Friday night, when a thought occurred to him: the Mets could very well be experiencing the beginning of the end.

headline: Deal in Place for Inspecting Foreign Drugs
text: More than 80 percent of the active ingredients for drugs sold in the United States are made abroad, mostly in a shadowy network of facilities in China and India that are rarely visited by government inspectors, who sometimes cannot even find the plants.

headline: A Public Rendez-Vous
text: Images from the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series.

headline: American Kidnapped by Gunmen in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A group of armed men broke into the home of an American development expert in Lahore on Saturday and abducted him, Pakistani and American officials said.

text: Today’s Times:

headline: Cashman Defends Giants’ Reese (Not a Good Sign)
text: Now you know things are getting bad.

headline: Collectible Car Auction Highlights
text: An overview of notable vehicles at the winter sales in Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Bus Overturns on Pennsylvania Turnpike
text: Law enforcement officials were investigating a bus accident Saturday on the Pennsylvania Turnpike that sent at least 21 people to area hospitals.

headline: Music for the Perry Campaign
text: Well, it could be this:

headline: Pain and Prejudice
text: So the claim is that Narayana Kocherlakota, and presumably the other Fed dissenters, are “sticking to economic facts“, basing their opposition to expansionary policies on falling unemployment and rising inflation. But as Mark Thoma rightly says, this is obviously not true.

headline: Urban Forager | Amaranth in Abundance
text: I recently stumbled upon a hardy patch of mature, leafy amaranth, flowering in a tree bed in Williamsburg. The tree had long been uprooted, but the amaranth was in full force — one of the few green plants on the block. I was lucky enough to find some younger, reddish-stemmed specimens later that week while walking to my office on Staten Island. The very next day, I spied more young amaranth, this time growing through the cracks in a Park Avenue sidewalk.

headline: Steele and Dufner Share Lead After P.G.A. Third Round

headline: The Making of a Debt Spiral
text: DEBT spirals: the term sounds ominous. As it should — these market vortexes are posing grave dangers to the global economy right now. A national debt crisis is a bank run writ large, says Kenneth Rogoff, an economics professor at Harvard and co-author with Carmen M. Reinhart of “This Time Is Different,” a history of financial crises. When a country like Greece goes deep into debt, bond investors start to worry they won’t get their money back. What can happen next is a debt spiral, a vicious circle of sinking confidence, rising borrowing costs and, ultimately, rising debt burdens. As investors lose confidence in a country, its bond prices drop, its bond yields rise and its government must pay higher interest rates to borrow. That, in turn, deepens the debt problem — and the whole thing starts over again. Debt spirals are dangerous, but they aren’t inevitable. “Country debt crises are essentially political,” Mr. Rogoff says. Governments can often stem the crisis by reducing spending, raising taxes or both. But such steps are particularly difficult — and politically unappetizing — when growth is slack, as it is now in much of the world. Tightening the belt slows growth even more, eroding tax revenue and — you guessed it — increasing the debt burden, at least in the short term. Of course, the best way to avoid a debt spiral is to avoid running up a lot of debt in the first place — when the economy is doing well. “If you walk outside without a raincoat and the sun is shining, you are fine,” Mr. Rogoff says. “But if it starts pouring, you are going to get wet.” — DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

headline: The General Theory of Anti-Mulliganism

One of his arguments was that since employment of teenagers continues to expand in the summer, when those teenagers are in fact able to work, supply must be the constraining factor. Another was that the growth in Texas employment similarly shows that demand can’t be the factor limiting national employment. The latter argument, of course, has new relevance now that Rick Perry is going to run on his alleged economic miracle.

text: GREENLAND, N.H. — Introduced as “the next president of the United States,” Gov. Rick Perry of Texas allowed himself a smile, stepping to a podium assembled hours earlier in a Greenland, N.H., backyard.

headline: Shell Tries to Control North Sea Oil Leak
text: Oil is seeping into the North Sea after a platform flow line in the seabed sprung a leak, dumping several hundred barrels of oil into the water, according to the British subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell and a Scottish official.

headline: White House Debates Fight on Economy
text: WASHINGTON — As the economy worsens, President Obama and his senior aides are considering whether to adopt a more combative approach on economic issues, seeking to highlight substantive differences with Republicans in Congress and on the campaign trail rather than continuing to pursue elusive compromises, advisers to the president say.

headline: The Caucus | Bachmann Wins Straw Poll
text: Aug. 13, 2011 - Michael D. Shear reports on the scene and Representative Michele Bachmann's win in the important Iowa straw poll this weekend.

headline: Caucus Video: The Scene From the Straw Poll
text: Michael D. Shear reports on the scene and Michele Bachmann’s win in the important Iowa Straw Poll this weekend.

headline: Loss and Healing in Norway
text: Scenes of grief and consolation played out in Norway as the nation attempted to recover from the scars of the massacre on July 22.

headline: Heat Keeps Atlanta Athletic Club Medical Team Busy
text: The weeklong oppressive weather at the Atlanta Athletic Club has kept the onsite medical team busy.

headline: Better Balance May Lead to More Options for Ryan and Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — For Rex Ryan’s first two seasons as the Jets’ coach, his philosophy was similar to what he saw as an assistant with the Baltimore Ravens: avoid mistakes on offense by running the football and rely on an elite defense to win games. That combination helped the Jets reach two straight A.F.C. championship games.

headline: For Dufner, It’s ‘Cool’ to Have Fans
text: In the late 1990s, the Auburn University golfer Jason Dufner and his buddies, fueled by beer, would fetch a few irons from their bags and hit balls late at night — from their front porch.

headline: McIlroy Has His Reasons to Bear Down
text: A four-over 74 freshly in the books, Rory McIlroy clickety-clacked past his manager, Chubby Chandler, en route to the scorer’s shed.

headline: U.S. Grand Slam Slump May Be Over
text: Forget “America the Beautiful.” It has been America the ordinary, bordering on the ugly, at recent Grand Slam events, with Europeans and South Africans hogging the last half-dozen.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Teeing Team Akin to Twins
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — Nobody scored better Saturday at the P.G.A. Championship than David Ben Toms-Crane.

headline: Jered Weaver’s Woes
text: As the manager of the Los Angeles Angels, Mike Scioscia is obviously biased toward his ace, Jered Weaver, as a contender for the American League Cy Young Award. But Scioscia made an interesting point last week about the stress of Weaver’s innings.

headline: You’ve Just Won the Ames Straw Poll; What Are You Going to Do Next?
text: This morning I introduced a formula that projects a candidate’s vote total in the Iowa caucuses based on their finish in the Ames Straw poll as well a couple of other factors. The straw poll historically does have some predictive power, particularly if you look at the share of the vote that each candidate finished with rather than simply who won and who lost.

headline: A Tumultuous Day for Pelfrey, and Another Loss by the Mets
text: PHOENIX — The stream of weirdness that flows generously from the Mets adheres to a certain ebb and flow.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 13
text: The day in sports, including images from the third round of the P.G.A. Championship and the World Badminton Championships in London.

headline: Cricket Team Attacked in Pakistan
text: The brazen attack on the Sri Lankan team by a dozen gunmen killed six police officers and two bystanders.

headline: Mets’ Bay Reflects on a Difficult Season
text: PHOENIX — Jason Bay knows that a stretch of decent games does not salvage a disappointing season. For now, he is just happy not to have an endless loop of insecurities running through his head whenever he steps to the plate.

headline: Rigging Falls at Indiana State Fair, Killing Four
text: At least four people were killed and 40 injured after whipping winds sent metal stage rigging crashing down onto the crowd at a concert at the Indiana State Fair on Saturday night, according to the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department.

headline: Nadia & David
text: In this homemade video, David Rawlinson recalls that upon proposing he took out newspaper ads in every city that Nadia Johnson had lived in.

headline: Youth Quake | Tokyo
text: What do you wear when protest and mayhem rock your world? Reports from three epicenters of street style: London, Cairo and Tokyo.

headline: Darwin’s Endless Forms
text: Images from the exhibition “Endless Forms: Charles Darwin, Natural Science and the Visual Arts” at the Yale Center for British Art.

headline: Corrections: August 14
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Amsterdam’s Urban Beaches
text: The Dutch summer weather might be a bit unpredictable, but even if the weather isn’t agreeable, Amsterdam’s urban beaches provide some worthwhile destinations. A bit more hidden than their Parisian counterparts, they have more to offer than chilling in the sand, even on a rainy day.

headline: 2011 Miami Dolphins Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. It’s Miami’s turn today, followed by the Jets and New England.

headline: Mr. Senna Goes to New York City
text: Formula One may not have made the foothold in the United States that it has in many other parts of the world, but you would not know that this weekend in New York City.

headline: Mr. Senna Goes to New York City
text: Formula One may not have made the foothold in the United States that it has in many other parts of the world, but you would not know that this weekend in New York City.

headline: Attack Is Latest to Jolt a Usually Quiet Afghan Area
text: CHARIKAR, Afghanistan — The governor of Parwan Province, Abdul Basir Salangi, convened a meeting Sunday morning with his top aides to find out why security had not been improved around his offices, 10 days after reports that a group of suicide bombers was planning an attack.

headline: Suspect in Norway Reconstructs Killings for Police
text: MOSCOW — Wearing a bulletproof vest and a leash held by a police guard, Anders Behring Breivik returned this weekend to the pristine Norwegian island where, he has admitted, he slaughtered 69 people last month, leading the police through a simulation of his actions, Oslo police officials said Sunday.

headline: Pawlenty Drops Out of Republican Race
text: DES MOINES  — Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, dropped his bid for the Republican nomination for president on Sunday morning, saying his disappointing performance in Iowa’s straw poll convinced him that his campaign had run its course.

headline: Loss and Healing in Norway
text: Scenes of grief and consolation played out in Norway as the nation attempted to recover from the scars of the massacre on July 22.

headline: Remembering Don Chandler, Former Giant and Packer
text: A few thoughts about Don Chandler, who began his career on the 1956 N.F.L. champion New York Giants and ended it on the 1967 Super Bowl champion Green Bay Packers. In between he was one of the best punters and place-kickers of his era. Chandler died Thursday in Tulsa, Okla., at age 76.

headline: Stage Rigging Falls at Indiana Fair; at Least 5 Dead
text: Just hours after lights and rigging on a concert stage at the state fair in Indianapolis toppled into a crowd, killing five people and injuring at least four dozen more, Indiana officials opened an investigation on Sunday to learn the cause of the calamity and what role the weather, including a wind gust that topped 60 miles per hour, may have played.

headline: Little or Nothing
text: Calculated Risk says it perfectly: this report in the Times on economic debate within the White House shows a fierce argument between those who want to do very little on jobs and those who want to do nothing at all.

headline: Missing Pawlenty
text: OK, I’m going to miss Tim Pawlenty, now that he’s dropped out of the Republican race. He was, after all, an econopundit’s dream.

headline: Bradley Grabs P.G.A. Championship
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — The final round of the P.G.A. Championship turned into a classic battle of the tortoise and the hare. In this case, the tortoise was the seemingly unflappable Jason Dufner who had played so steadily for most of the final two rounds, it appeared he had no nerves at all. The hare was 25-year-old rookie Keegan Bradley, who alternated spectacular birdies and an eagle with wild detours like a triple bogey on No. 15.

headline: Tax-Cap Tales
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had a remarkable legislative rookie season. He pushed through same-sex marriage, ethics reform and a 2 percent property tax cap. The cap got the least attention downstate (it does not apply in New York City) but could forever rework the face of town and city finances in the rest of the state.

headline: Setbacks May Push Europe Into a New Downturn
text: FRANKFURT — Economists may still be debating whether Europe is headed for a sharp slowdown or even a recession, but Steve Knott, who installs home heating systems in Barrow-in-Furness, a port town in northwest England once known for its iron mills, is convinced he already knows the answer.

headline: ‘The Help’ Impresses, but ‘Glee’ Does Not
text: A lavish marketing campaign and positive reviews powered “The Help” to better-than-expected results at the weekend box office, but moviegoers ignored a “Glee” concert movie, a troubling sign for that TV musical’s hopes of continued cultural dominance.

headline: Stand Clear of the Screaming Shakespeareans, Please
text: It takes a lot to rattle New York straphangers. They have seen and heard (and smelled) it all. And they mostly ignore it.

headline: Bachmann Faces Tough Questioning on Sunday Shows
text: DES MOINES — Michele Bachmann quickly became the target of fresh scrutiny Sunday morning as her victory in the Iowa straw poll propelled her into the top tier of a rapidly evolving Republican presidential contest.

headline: The Caucus Click: Perry Bus Makes Its Debut in Iowa
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas rolled out his new campaign bus in Des Moines Sunday.

headline: Perry’s Full-Court Press to Get Donations
text: Rick Perry, the Texas governor, has been in the presidential race for all of one day, but he is already promising his top donors perks for a Republican National Convention that will not be held for more than a year.

headline: Syrian Navy Joins Attack on Key Rebellious Port City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In yet another escalation of its crackdown on dissent, the Syrian government unleashed navy vessels, tanks and a mix of soldiers, security forces and paramilitary fighters against the port city of Latakia on Sunday, killing at least 25 people, including three children, activists and residents said.

headline: ‘The Lone Ranger’ Is Holstered, for Now
text: Disney’s high-profile remake of “The Lone Ranger” has ridden into the sunset, at least in its current configuration. That long-gestating movie project — starring Johnny Depp as Tonto, produced by Jerry Bruckheimer and directed by Gore Verbinski — was expected to start shooting in October in New Mexico. But Walt Disney Studios pulled the plug late Friday after reaching an impasse with the filmmakers over costs, according to an industry official briefed on the matter who asked for anonymity because the details of the shutdown were considered private.

headline: More Music for the Perry Campaign
text: Also, the things you’re liable to hear about Texas.

headline: ConAgra Presses $5.2 Billion Bid for Ralcorp
text: ConAgra confirmed on Sunday that it had offered nearly $5.2 billion for Ralcorp Holdings, days after Ralcorp rejected the bid.

headline: Will the ECB Change Course?
text: Just a quick note on the euro situation. The rescue operation to head off a self-fulfilling panic in Italy and Spain has succeeded, for now. But meanwhile the real economies continue to suffer; the latest is France, where growth has stalled.

headline: SEC Decides Against Adding Texas A&M
text: In a surprising decision that showcased how complex it would be for Texas A&M to leave the Big 12, a group of presidents of universities in the Southeastern Conference decided Sunday against taking immediate action on conference expansion.

headline: The Incredibly Shrinking Sixth Hole
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — It looked like a typographical error. The yardage sheet for the final round of the P.G.A. Championship listed the par-four sixth hole at a length of 289 yards, shortened substantially from the 431, 417 and 432 yards it played over the first three days.

headline: Rock Radio Station in New York Shifts to FM News Format
text: Listeners to 101.9 FM in New York, until recently a struggling alternative rock station, got a taste over the weekend of what its new owners hoped would be a successful new format: FM news.

headline: Jazz Fusion Heroes of the 1970s Resurrect Their Intricate Dynamics
text: Return to Forever IV showed off every which way on Friday night at the Beacon Theater. Otherwise the group wouldn’t have been doing its job. Jazz-rock fusion, as pioneered by previous lineups of Return to Forever in the 1970s, glorifies confrontational virtuosity. Composers show off by writing breakneck melodies, sudden meter shifts and quick-change structures; musicians show off by executing every whipsaw maneuver with pinpoint accuracy and improvising with a flourish. Done right, the music is a display of jet-fueled aerobatics; done wrong, it can be exhausting.

headline: Evoking Forbidden Love and Flying Ancient Armies
text: The Chinese composer Tan Dun first attracted attention with skillfully wrought concert works in which ancient Chinese folkloric instruments and techniques mingled in potent collusion with a Western avant-garde vocabulary. But it was as a composer of lavish scores for a series of prominent martial-arts films that Mr. Tan, who turns 54 on Thursday, became an international celebrity.

headline: Love Beats Science in a Spoof by Menotti
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — When Gian Carlo Menotti’s “Last Savage” had its American premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in early 1964, after its introduction at the Opéra Comique in Paris, its poor reception was explained by defenders as a case of bad timing. Just two months after the assassination of John F. Kennedy and with the civil-rights movement spawning both courageous demonstrations and brutal crackdowns, audiences were not disposed, it was thought, to an absurd comedy about the perky daughter of an American millionaire who, as a project for an anthropology degree, is determined to find a primitive man, the “last savage,” and take him to America for studies.

headline: In Toronto, an Artful Bid Helps to Secure a Trophy
text: At the Summer North American Championships in Toronto last month David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Fla., received the Fishbein Trophy for accruing the most master points.

headline: The Social Economics of a Facebook Birthday
text: Happy birthday!! With two exclamation points, as we do it on Facebook. It’s your birthday today, right? I send you many happy returns — and a wish that you are, if only for today, among the 750 million active Facebook users.

headline: When Cancer Steals the Joy of Food
text: Cancer steals much from the people it afflicts. For Anna Stoessinger, a gastronome, stomach cancer meant giving up a lifelong celebration of food.

headline: Affable Country Odes to Irresponsibility
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For about 15 minutes at the New Meadowlands Stadium here on Saturday night the Kenny Chesney who could be paid a visit to the Kenny Chesney who is.

headline: Yankees Have Unscheduled Day Off Before Road Trip
text: The Yankees concluded a stretch of eight games in nine days against some of the American League’s top teams Sunday by hanging around the clubhouse and packing for this week’s seven-game trip after their meeting with the Tampa Bay Rays was postponed.

headline: When the Bass Is Like a Conqueror, Crushing the Guitars and Words
text: Woofers and subwoofers weren’t the only part of the sound system Bassnectar brought to Governors Island on Saturday for Bass Island, a marathon of dance music and hip-hop. Bassnectar’s music, and sets by opening acts including the rapper Lupe Fiasco and the disc jockey Z-Trip, also used the midrange of vocals and the highs of synthesizer lines. But the attraction for the roughly 10,000 people who attended the event — in face paint and fluorescent clothes, wearing goofy hats and festooned with glowsticks, carrying tall poles with toys bobbing on top — was the promise of extended exposure to deep, body-shaking bass.

headline: Sporting Goods Chain Supports Concussion Testing in Schools
text: IN a new commercial for Dick’s Sporting Goods, Jerome Bettis, the former Pittsburgh Steelers star, strolls through one of the retailer’s stores, but Mr. Bettis never gets around to promoting equipment, clothing or footwear.

headline: With Big, Heavy Rocks, a Man Turns a Nuisance Into a Niche
text: Adam Distenfeld was driving by a construction pit on Nostrand Avenue in Brooklyn a few weeks ago and couldn’t resist. Mr. Distenfeld, 48, is a sculptor who prefers granite gneiss -– the banded metamorphic rock found beneath swaths of New York City -– and in the Nostrand pit he saw a boulder of it. He had never seen one larger. He needed it. But you try convincing your girlfriend that your studio –- which already looks like the Flintstones’ prop room — just needs one more boulder.

headline: Monday: Part to Play
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Thank goodness for Mondays. I solve these puzzles in bunches, and by the time I get through the two Sunday puzzles, my brain is fried. There’s nothing like a nice, smooth Monday grid to restore one’s self-esteem.

headline: Comedy Podcast Inside News Corp. Feasts on a Scandal
text: Sitting in a windowless London recording studio at the start of the phone hacking scandal that engulfed Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, Chris Skinner faced a dilemma.

headline: A Novel Updated, for E-Book
text: In his most recent thriller, “The Devil’s Light,” Richard North Patterson wrote a detailed plot in which Osama bin Laden tries to drop a nuclear bomb on the United States to coincide with the 10th anniversary of 9/11.

headline: Preparing Triathletes for the Chaos of Open Water
text: The deaths of two athletes stricken by cardiac arrest in the Hudson River during the New York City Triathlon on Aug. 7 have focused attention on the dangers of the open-water portion of such events.

headline: Gogol Bordello, "Immigraniada" (Bassnectar Remix)
text: Bassnectar's remix of Gogol Bordello's "Immigraniada."

headline: Nothing Special From Mickelson
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga. — An even-par P.G.A. Championship left Phil Mickelson even-tempered after a disquieting week at the Atlanta Athletic Club.

headline: As Networks Speed Up, Data Hits a Wall
text: The newest smartphones are intended to run on speedy 4G networks that allow people to effortlessly stream music, watch Netflix movies and tune in live to a Mets game, wherever they are.

headline: Who Is to Blame if Shares Continue Steep Declines?
text: It is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.

headline: Jockey Club Plans TV and Web Projects to Attract New Fans
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The Jockey Club, acknowledging that the audience for horse racing is in steep decline, announced Sunday a multimillion dollar campaign to increase television coverage and create a racing series to be accompanied by a free-to-play Web site for picking races as well as a social-network game.

headline: Reality Show Ricochets Through Brighton Beach
text: Russians are a gossipy bunch. In Soviet times the conspiratorial kitchen whisper — over a glass of tea or a bottle of vodka — was sometimes the only way to share information. Even now Chekhovian monologues, complete with meaningful sighs, spill forth in the confines of the sauna; “Have you heard?” is the greeting over a cigarette.

headline: A Future Wrapped in 1980s Culture
text: Ernest Cline’s “Ready Player One” is a book filled with references to video games, virtual reality, ’80s pop-culture trivia, geek heroes like E. Gary Gygax, and funny-sounding cult items like Frobozz and Raaka-Tu. Yet it works for people who like books without pictures too.

headline: Bass Notes
text: Photos from the Bass Island concert on Governors Island.

headline: Divining New York’s Fate Should a Double-Dip Recession Hit
text: New York City may have recovered from the Great Recession sooner and more strongly than the rest of the nation did, but it is no less likely to slip back into reverse, economists said.

headline: A Life Herding Yaks, Modernity on the Horizon
text: Locho and Yama, the Tibetan couple who are the focus of the enthralling documentary “Summer Pasture,” are nomadic herders pursuing a way of life that has changed little over 4,000 years. For all the hardship they endure, this intimate dual portrait, directed by Lynn True and Nelson Walker, with Tsering Perlo, suggests that their lives are neither more nor less fulfilled than those of any highly stressed upper-middle-class Americans.

headline: Finding Beethoven’s Moods Hidden Between the Lines
text: Just as you can put on a brave face to conceal your suffering, composers sometimes write works whose cheeriness belies a tortured state of mind. Beethoven began composing his vivacious Eighth Symphony in the summer of 1812, when he was enduring a painful affair of the heart with the woman he called “Immortal Beloved.”

headline: Hip-Hop, Folk and Karate Through a Strainer on a Hot Afternoon
text: What is there to do when a dance festival turns into an endurance test? When biting flies become so aggressive that your legs feel as if they have caught on fire? Clearly, opening day of the Downtown Dance Festival — three hours, no intermission — was a tester.

headline: Ex-Agent’s Charter School Is Set to Open
text: LOS ANGELES — When last seen in these pages, in late 2009, the Hollywood power agent Tom Strickler had forsaken fame, fortune and his position as a partner in the Endeavor talent agency — which was then merging with the William Morris Agency — to climb peaks in Peru’s Cordillera Huayhuash, and to start what he vaguely described as “a nonprofit organization in the field of education.”

headline: A Technique for Photos Real and Surreal
text: The eye can see a much wider range of light and dark than a camera. That’s why windows come out as a blurry masses of white in your daytime indoor shots but it doesn’t look that way to the naked eye.

headline: China Moves Swiftly to Close Chemical Plant After Protests
text: HONG KONG — Municipal leaders in a northeastern Chinese port city quickly announced plans to shut down a chemical plant on Sunday after thousands of protesters confronted riot police officers and demanded that it be closed because of safety concerns, state news media reported.

headline: Flash-Sale Site Shifts Its Model
text: On a recent day on Gilt.com, shoppers could buy 10 round-trip tickets on Virgin America for $3,585, three sessions of laser hair-removal for $352 or eight Alaskan king salmon fillets for $118.95.

headline: Urban Foraging in Atlanta
text: Kelly Callahan scours for fruits and vegetables in the yards of her neighborhood’s vacant properties.

headline: M.L.S. Nurturing Martin’s Interest in Soccer
text: Curtis Martin is closely associated with football American-style, but these days, he appears to be taking a crash course in soccer. It is too early to say whether Martin may someday seek to become a team owner in Major League Soccer, but his interest in the sport is clearly growing.

headline: Nepal’s Prime Minister Resigns, Citing a Stalemate
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Prime Minister Jhalanath Khanal resigned on Sunday, acknowledging that he had failed to advance a stagnant peace process or agree with the opposition on a new constitution, tasks he had promised to accomplish when he was elected to his post by a parliamentary vote in February.

headline: At Vacant Homes, Foraging for Fruit
text: ATLANTA — As she does every evening, Kelly Callahan walked her dogs through her East Atlanta neighborhood. As in many communities in a city with the 16th-highest foreclosure rate in the nation, there were plenty of empty, bank-owned properties for sale.

headline: The Mets Lose Their Fifth in a Row
text: Chris Capuano was once something of an unknown quantity for the Mets.

headline: The Limitations on Central Banks
text: If the first fear is global recession, the second is that central banks have run out of fixes. They do have means to respond, but only with radical and possibly dangerous policies whose efficacy is dubious. These nuclear monetary weapons might be better kept locked away.

headline: Britain Debates a Plan to Turn to U.S. ‘Supercop’
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron’s plan to bring in an American “supercop,” as the tabloid newspapers here have called him, became a political hot potato over the weekend, with the mayor of London and an array of British police officials publicly opposing the idea, often in blunt terms.

headline: Award for Ballet Dancers
text: Twenty-six former and current performers with the New York City Ballet who worked with the choreographer Jerome Robbins will share this year’s award for excellence in dance from his foundation. The Jerome Robbins Awards are to be presented by Chita Rivera, who collaborated with Robbins on the original production of “West Side Story.” Robbins, who died in 1998, established his foundation in 1970 to support all aspects of dance and theater. Past recipients have usually been individuals, including the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton, the director Robert Wilson and Mikhail Baryshnikov. The ceremony will be hosted by New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater on Sept. 30.

headline: Industry Tries to Streamline Privacy Policies for Mobile Users
text: For many Internet users, online privacy policies are long and difficult to read. Transfer those same policies to a mobile device, where users can find themselves clicking through multiple screens often with tiny type, and the policies can become almost useless to the average consumer.

headline: Indian Leader’s Illness Prompts Questions, but Also Restraint
text: NEW DELHI — It has been 11 days since the announcement of the disappearance of Sonia Gandhi, the most powerful political figure in India. From all corners of the country, people have offered prayers and good wishes, even her political enemies. Yet what is most intriguing is that so few people are demanding that she be found.

headline: Jails Chief Steps Down Amid Inquiry
text: Larry W. Davis Sr., the highest-ranking uniformed officer in the city’s Correction Department, resigned over the weekend amid mounting dissatisfaction about his leadership and a new inquiry into his relationships with subordinates.

headline: Time Warner Cable Is Said to Acquire Midwest Cable Operator
text: Time Warner Cable, the second biggest cable television company in the United States after Comcast, is near a deal to acquire Insight Communications, a large operator in the Midwest, for about $3 billion, a person with knowledge of the deal said on Sunday night.

headline: Obama Shifts Gears From Coaxing G.O.P. to Swaying the Public
text: CANNON FALLS, Minn. — House Speaker John A. Boehner once explained conservatives’ hard line on the debt limit this way: “A lot of them,” he told a radio host, believe “enough chaos” would make opponents yield.

headline: Divorce Tourists Go Abroad to Quickly Dissolve Their Italian Marriages
text: ROME — The Italian couple boarded a plane from their home in Bologna for Bucharest, Romania. They were met there by a consultant for an Italian company, who took them to an office where they signed papers applying for residency in the Romanian capital.

headline: Israeli Leader Vows Fiscal Reform but No Quick Fixes
text: BEERSHEBA, Israel — As Israel’s social protest movement spread beyond Tel Aviv and Jerusalem, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday tempered a promise to find “concrete solutions” to demonstrators’ concerns with a warning that the global financial crisis precluded quick change.

headline: California Scrutinizes Nonprofits, Sometimes Ending a Tax Exemption
text: A growing number of nonprofit groups in California are being denied exemption from property taxes because the state’s chief tax collector and assessors contend they do not do enough to benefit state residents, according to lawyers representing the groups.

headline: 49ers’ Harbaugh Is Happy Out of His Comfort Zone
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — It is so loud at the San Francisco 49ers’ training camp, it is hard to hear what the players think. On a recent afternoon, cornerback Carlos Rogers started to explain why he was happy to have joined the team as a free agent when he was drowned out by a plane, which had taken off from the airport in San Jose and was executing an out route overhead.

headline: Market Ills Give CNBC a Bounce
text: When Nik Deogun was running the financial coverage of The Wall Street Journal during the crisis in 2008, he kept a constant eye on CNBC as the events played out on television. “It was news being made, all the time, in real time,” he said.

headline: Time Warner Cable to Buy Insight for $3 Billion
text: 9:10 a.m. | Updated Time Warner Cable announced on Monday that it had agreed to buy Insight Communications, a large Midwestern cable television operator, for about $3 billion in cash.

headline: U.S. Aides Believe China Examined Stealth Copter
text: WASHINGTON — In the days after the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, Pakistan’s intelligence service probably allowed Chinese military engineers to examine the wreckage of a stealth American helicopter that crashed during the operation, according to American officials and others familiar with the classified intelligence assessments.

headline: Umenyiora Rejects Contract Incentives but Says He’ll Practice
text: After 11 practices, a preseason game and dozens of miles logged on a stationary bike, Giants defensive end Osi Umenyiora appears ready to end his holdout.

headline: Libya Rebels in Zawiyah Threaten Supply Line to Tripoli
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — After a period of political turmoil, fighters opposing Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi advanced on several fronts on Sunday, seizing ground in the strategic city of Zawiyah that placed them on Tripoli’s doorstep and threatening to cut off an important supply line for the colonel’s loyalists.

headline: Battle for Libya | August 14, 2011
text: Rebels took partial control of Zawiyah.

headline: Portraits Redrawn: Alissa Torres
text: To help deal with her grief, Alissa Torres wrote a graphic novel memoir about losing her husband on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Low Rates May Do Little to Entice Nervous Consumers
text: The Federal Reserve’s announcement last week that it intended to keep credit cheap for at least two more years was a clear invitation to Americans: Go out and borrow.

headline: Fish, Pushing Djokovic, Just Brings Out His Best
text: MONTREAL — Throughout this Rogers Cup, Novak Djokovic appeared unbeatable, each victory more dominant, more lopsided than the one before. By Sunday’s final, his latest title in this increasingly remarkable season seemed inevitable.

headline: Russia Arrests a Gadfly Over Some Simple Advice for Voters
text: MOSCOW — It seemed like a good way to make a point.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data this week will include housing starts, import prices and industrial production and capacity utilization for July (Tuesday); the Producer Price Index for July (Wednesday); and weekly jobless claims, the consumer price index, existing home sales and leading economic indicators for July, and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for August (Thursday).

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: With Post-Its and Checklists, Schools Cut Their Energy Bills
text: Simple yellow Post-it notes with the message “When not in use, turn off the juice,” pointedly left on classroom computers, printers and air-conditioners, have helped the Mount Sinai School District on Long Island save $350,000 annually on utility bills.

headline: Rookie Prevails in Playoff in 1st Major
text: JOHNS CREEK, Ga.  —  Keegan Bradley, who seemed to be out of chances, out of birdies and out of luck with three holes left in the P.G.A. Championship at the Atlanta Athletic Club on Sunday, came roaring back with two birdies to tie a faltering Jason Dufner and then prevailed in a three-hole playoff to become the first golfer in eight years, and just the third in history, to win a major championship in his first appearance.

headline: Will Low Rates Influence Your Behavior?

headline: Squeezing the South into Submission
text: Though the Union army was still getting its war footing, by August 1861 the Northern blockade of Southern ports and waterways was almost complete. That month federal ships closed the Mississippi River to commerce between loyal and secessionist states, while naval squadrons were in place off the coast of most Southern cities, from south Texas to the Chesapeake. President Lincoln had approved the blockade, known as the “Anaconda Plan,” in April. At first it was widely derided in the North and dismissed in the South—the American navy, people said, was in no shape to clamp down on thousands and thousands of miles of coastline. Nevertheless, this massive operation had an immediate impact on the Confederate economy and, as it tightened its grip on the Southern coastline, began to choke the South into submission.

headline: Hansen Ties for Low Round, but Comes Up Short

He tied for the day’s best round by shooting a four-under 66, but finished one stroke out of a playoff as the players ahead of him silenced questions about why Americans have been unable to win a major in recent years.

headline: A Jobs Agenda, Anyone?
text: In what can only be described as a triumph of bad policy and craven politics, Congress and the Obama administration have spent the year focused on budget cuts, as the economy has faltered and unemployment has worsened. Official unemployment is 9.1 percent, but it would be 16.1 percent, or 25.1 million people, if it included those who can only find part-time jobs and those who have given up looking for work. For the past two and a half years, there have been more than four unemployed workers for every job opening, a record high, by far. In a healthy market, the ratio would be about one to one.

headline: Chris Christie’s Cue

Thursday’s Republican debate reminded everyone why Mitt Romney is the front-runner, as his rivals left the former Massachusetts governor more or less untouched. Saturday’s Ames straw poll disposed of Tim Pawlenty, who not so long ago seemed positioned to give Romney a real challenge. Instead, that challenge will probably come from Rick Perry, whose entrance into the race promises to set up a Romney-Perry slugfest for the nomination, with Michele Bachmann playing spoiler.

headline: Adapting Patti Smith’s ‘Just Kids’ for the Big Screen
text: Patti Smith is variously known as a musician, poet, artist and memoirist. Now add feature film writer to that list. She confirmed Friday that she will be collaborating with the playwright and screenwriter John Logan on an adaptation of her best-selling book “Just Kids,” which chronicled her early years in New York, focusing on her relationship with the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. She said that she and Mr. Logan were friends and that she had particularly admired his script for “Coriolanus,” the coming film adaptation directed by a mutual friend of theirs, Ralph Fiennes. She also cited Mr. Logan’s Tony-winning play about Mark Rothko, “Red.” “It was a beautiful script and he’s very knowledgeable about art,” Ms. Smith said, speaking by phone, adding later, “He’s very knowledgeable about Robert and his work too.” There’s no director or financing set, though Ms. Smith’s literary agent, Betsy Lerner, said several producers and especially actresses have expressed interest since “Just Kids” was published last year.

headline: Record Industry Braces for Artists’ Battles Over Song Rights
text: Since their release in 1978, hit albums like Bruce Springsteen’s “Darkness on the Edge of Town,” Billy Joel’s “52nd Street,” the Doobie Brothers’ “Minute by Minute,” Kenny Rogers’s “Gambler” and Funkadelic’s “One Nation Under a Groove” have generated tens of millions of dollars for record companies. But thanks to a little-noted provision in United States copyright law, those artists — and thousands more — now have the right to reclaim ownership of their recordings, potentially leaving the labels out in the cold.

On the latter front, I and others have pointed out that the rise in core inflation in the first half of 2011 is looking very much like a temporary blip driven by commodity prices.

headline: For Coal Plants, a Game of Chicken
text: In an article in Friday’s paper, I described how some companies that operate dirty coal-fired power plants are playing chicken as they face a decision on whether to retire them or install expensive scrubbers and filters. They are waiting to see what their neighbors will do as new environmental rules take effect: as with two restaurants in a town that can support only one, if your neighbor goes out of business, more business comes to you, and prices may well rise.

Bush and Bob Dole, who tied for first with Phil Gramm in 1995).

headline: A Face From Japan’s Earthquake
text: The picture of the Japanese woman among the ruins of Natori appeared on the front page of this newspaper and in newspapers around the world after the earthquake and tsunami. She sits on a concrete foundation, sobbing, her red boots lined up neatly to her right. She wasn’t identified in the photo, but some information about Akane Ito, which turns out to be her name, later surfaced. The most complete version of her touching story is in this article in The Daily Mail from April. When the picture was taken, Ito later told the newspaper, she thought all 13 of her dogs had been lost. The Daily Mail update shows her reunited with two of them. (Sadly, since the article appeared, none of her remaining dogs have been found, according to news reports.)

headline: Cause Collab | Bean Pole and Kim Jones
text: When Kim Jones makes a move, the fashion world takes notice. The British designer, who was recently named menswear director at Louis Vuitton and previously lent his talents to Umbro and Dunhill, counts the stalwart Korean brand Bean Pole among his ever-growing list of collaborators, too. The full range of Bean Pole x Kim Jones men’s clothing, which includes shirting, outerwear, knits and pants, combines a traditional fit and palette with enough idiosyncratic details to keep fans feeling comfortably satisfied. Think reversible nylon jackets, classic chinos done over in a raccoon dog print and Ed Ruscha-inspired color blocked button-ups.

headline: A Vienna Festival Heads to New York
text: The Metropolitan Opera does not have a lock on outdoor, large-screen, high-definition opera transmissions. A popular summertime opera and classical music film festival has been operating for two decades in Vienna’s City Hall Square. Now a one-evening version, called the Vienna Music Film Festival NY, is heading to Brooklyn Bridge Park on Aug. 29 and will feature filmed excerpts of European opera productions. Austrian tourism and cultural authorities, along with the Vienna-based International Music + Media Center — a nonprofit association founded under the aegis of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization — and Czekaj Artistic Productions, are backing the show. The Met will present H.D. performances at Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5.

headline: Cancer’s Secrets Come Into Sharper Focus
text: For the last decade cancer research has been guided by a common vision of how a single cell, outcompeting its neighbors, evolves into a malignant tumor.

headline: Conquering the Divide
text: CUT BANK, Mont. — The most direct path through Glacier National Park is called, famously and aptly, Going-to-the-Sun Road. About 51 miles long, it begins in the town of West Glacier, proceeds pleasantly along the wooded southeastern shore of Lake McDonald, providing intermittent glimpses of soaring peaks, and then, as if a giant had stepped on the end of the road, mistaking it for a seesaw, begins ruthlessly, gorgeously climbing. It goes northeast for three miles or so, then makes a hairpin turn and heads southeast along a mountain precipice and up, up, up — endlessly up if you’re on a bicycle. From the turn it’s eight miles to Logan Pass. There, at 6,646 feet, the road crosses the Continental Divide.

headline: In Texas Jobs Boom, Crediting a Leader, or Luck
text: HOUSTON — Texas is home to at least one-third of the jobs created nationwide since the recession ended. The state’s economy is growing about twice as fast as the national rate. Home prices have remained stable even as much of the country has seen sharp declines.

headline: No Credit? No Problem
text: One of the most important questions for small businesses hovering through all of the tumult of the last three years is whether they’ve been able to get the credit they need. The question has been hotly debated — even becoming a partisan issue last year, when Congress wrestled with the small-business lending fund that ultimately became law in the small-business jobs act. Banks tell anyone who will listen that they are eager to lend to any creditworthy business they can find. Republicans tend to put it slightly differently: small businesses that deserve credit can get it, but many are too cautious to make investments right now. Many Democrats and some small-business advocates say a good loan is hard to find.
