headline: Monday Motorsports: Wet New Hampshire Speedway Brings IndyCar Crashes and Controversies
text: Wet racetracks have encouraged some of the most memorable overtaking maneuvers in motorsports history. They also have subjected race officials to pointed criticism for allowing competition to go on despite the heightened risk to drivers and crews. At New Hampshire Motor Speedway on Sunday, there was plenty of excitement and finger-pointing to go around.

headline: Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater Sign Up for ‘Seminar’ With Alan Rickman
text: An unconventional writing course taught by Alan Rickman in the coming Broadway comedy “Seminar” has snared its first two victims – er, students. Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater have joined the production of this Theresa Rebeck dark comedy, it was announced on Monday, playing aspiring novelists who pay $5,000 each for the privilege of working with Leonard, the internationally renowned literary figure played by Mr. Rickman.

headline: Original Model T’s | Adam Shecter
text: No. 4 in a series of original artworks.

headline: The Caucus | A Three-Way Race Emerges
text: Michael D. Shear on Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and the new dimensions of the Republican presidential race; John Harwood on President Obama's Midwest bus tour.

headline: MMT, Again
text: In a way, I really should not spend time debating the Modern Monetary Theory guys. They’re on my side in current policy debates, and it’s unlikely that they’ll ever have the kind of real — and really bad — influence that the Austrians have lately acquired. But I really don’t feel like getting right back to textbook revision, so here’s another shot.

headline: Why Pawlenty’s Candidacy Failed
text: There are a number of lessons one could take away from the surprisingly early implosion of Tim Pawlenty’s presidential aspirations, which not long ago seemed like something to be taken seriously.

headline: Caucus Video: Three-Way Republican Race Emerges; Obama’s Bus Tour
text: Michael D. Shear on Rick Perry and the new dimensions of the Republican presidential race. John Harwood on President Obama’s bus tour through the Midwest this week.

headline: Ice Cream Treats Without Ice Cream
text: One of the best things about making your own fancy ice cream desserts, like those I write about in “A Good Appetite,” is that you don’t actually have to use ice cream. There are so many frozen dessert alternatives out there that those who have to avoid ice cream can still partake.

headline: Growing Older in an Urban Village
text: Faced with the usual options for senior housing and elder care, some older adults are inventing their own grassroots versions — do-it-yourself senior living that’s friendlier, more autonomous and less expensive. Fellows in the News21 program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism are posting video reports on four of these: a shared housing arrangement in White Plains, a senior co-housing development in Virginia, an urban village in Chicago and an R.V. community in East Texas.

headline: Still More Rain for New York Area
text: On Day 2 of the midsummer deluge, they put away the rowboats. They pumped basements. And they looked at the steel-gray sky and said, That’s not good.

headline: Perry Jabs Romney in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — On his third day in the race, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas wasted little time drawing distinctions on Monday with Mitt Romney, highlighting his experience creating jobs at home.

headline: Summer Squash, With a Lighter Touch
text: Recently, I asked for recipe requests on the Recipes for Health Facebook page. There were many for squash, and no surprise: In August, home-delivered produce baskets are filled with pattypans, green and yellow zucchini, yellow crookneck squash and sturdy ronds de Nice.

headline: The Locavores
text: Three of Brooklyn’s greenest beauty queens share their favorite all-natural products, like fancy face creams and organic aphrodisiacs.

headline: Second Tibetan Monk Burns Himself to Death in Protest
text: A Tibetan Buddhist monk protesting Chinese policies immolated himself publicly in a Tibetan area of Sichuan Province in southwest China on Monday, an outside advocacy group reported. It was the second such act in the area in the past five months and appeared to reflect resistance to increased Chinese repression of loyalty to Tibet’s exiled spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama.

headline: Washington, Capital of Economic Optimism
text: In case you’re wondering why Congress spent so much time twisting itself in knots over the long-term deficit, instead of over the current jobs crisis, this might help explain things: Washington, D.C., is the most economically optimistic area in the nation, according to Gallup.

headline: Hugh Dancy Joins Broadway Cast of ‘Venus in Fur’
text: When Hugh Dancy made his Broadway debut in the 2007 revival of “Journey’s End,” it was as a British Army captain down in the trenches of World War I. When Mr. Dancy returns to Broadway this fall, he won’t be taking on the Central Powers – he’ll face off against Nina Arianda in Manhattan Theater Club’s coming production of “Venus in Fur,” the David Ives comedy-drama about an ever-shifting audition encounter between a director and an actress, the production’s press representatives said on Monday.

headline: Ex-Leader of Thailand Gets a Visa From Japan
text: Japan has granted a visa to Thaksin Shinawatra, the former prime minister of Thailand who was ousted from power by the Thai military in 2006 and who has lived in exile since a Thai court convicted him of corruption three years ago.

headline: Tunisian Protesters Watch Mubarak Trial With Envy
text: Seven months after protesters ousted the Tunisian president, Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali, the streets are still restless over the country’s judicial system.

headline: In Decline, Stillbirths Continue to Devastate
text: I had been in active labor for 12 hours when my obstetrician said he would have to do a Caesarean because Twin A was stuck and neither twin could emerge naturally. Terrified of losing either baby, I responded, “I don’t care if I cough them up, just get them out alive!”

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 15
text: Players in Hays, Kan., got an early start on the high school football season and Marcos Ambrose won the Nascar race at Watkins Glen, N.Y.

headline: Anonymous to BART: We Hack. We Organize, Too
text: Anonymous, the loosely affiliated group of computer hackers, is planning a flesh-and-blood demonstration Monday afternoon in San Francisco to protest the Bay Area Rapid Transit cutting off underground cellphone service to thwart protesters.

headline: As the Worm Turns
text: Q. Do earthworms have any sense of place or direction? When they are dug up in the garden and put back down someplace else, do they just return to work, or do they try to get back to their former location?

headline: Con Artists Claim Purchases Are Covered by eBay Motors, Crime Center Warns
text: Internet con artists are trying to sell vehicles they do not own, and to impart a look of legitimacy to their enterprise they are touting a fraudulent relationship with the e-commerce site eBay Motors, according to a statement issued Monday by the Internet Crime Complaint Center. The center is a partnership of the National White Collar Crime Center, the Bureau of Justice Assistance and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: These Apartments May as Well Already Have Monograms
text: Growing up on Long Island, Jeremy Noritz says, he was always interested in fine art, especially sculpture and painting. So, when he bought a loft in a converted warehouse on West 29th Street in 2006, he jumped at the chance to transform it.

headline: An Index for Ocean Health
text: What has been billed as the “Dow Jones of ocean health” is six months from release, and Ben Halpern is feeling the pressure. “We’re frantically wrapping up analyses,” Dr. Halpern, a research biologist at the University of California at Santa Barbara, said in a telephone interview.

headline: Refuse Collects Here, but Visitors and Wildlife Can Breathe Free
text: Waiting lists for selective colleges, fine restaurants and overbooked flights are familiar enough — but Singapore may have the only landfill with a four-month wait once you sign up to visit.

headline: Letting Charlie Bite the Finger Again
text: Gerber is using revamped versions of two wildly popular YouTube videos starring mischievous children to promote its products.

headline: Was There Insider Trading on S.&P.’s Downgrade?
text: Justin Lane/European Pressphoto Agency

headline: The New York Film Festival Employs ‘A Dangerous Method’
text: Carl Jung, Sigmund Freud and plastic surgery will all be part of this year’s New York Film Festival. The Film Society of Lincoln Center announced gala screenings of two new films from directors familiar to the festival scene. One is “A Dangerous Method,” the latest from David Cronenberg. It will be the Canadian filmmaker’s first film to screen at this festival, although his previous work has appeared at Cannes, Venice and Toronto. The other, “The Skin I Live In,” is a thriller from New York Film Festival veteran Pedro Almodóvar.

headline: Mistakes in Storage May Alter Medication
text: What does extreme heat do to medications? I found out while we were sweating out the recent heat wave in a lake cabin in New Hampshire and my 10-year-old son’s allergies kicked up.

headline: Barbera: I Knew It When
Ristretto | First Look at Sightglass Coffee Roasters
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#164", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: To Those Who Have Lost Faith in Investing
text: Part of the investor’s dilemma is that no matter how much data we have about the past, we have no data for the future. No matter what history says about the long-term, upward trend of the stock market, we still don’t know for sure what the future will bring.

headline: Perks of Cross-Training May End Before Finish Line
text: The question has occurred to many endurance athletes, and it seems so basic: Will cross-training — doing a second sport, or lifting weights on days when you aren’t running or cycling or swimming — improve your performance in your primary sport?

headline: Adolescent Health | General Well-Being and Safety
text: We’ve decided to declare this Adolescent Health Week on The Learning Network, because we know how important it is for students to be able to make safe and healthy lifestyle decisions, and because we have a lot of teaching materials to offer on the topic, partly because of the prevalence of teenager-related health topics in the news in the past few years.

headline: Turkey Warns Syria to Stop Crackdown
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Turkey’s foreign minister demanded Monday that the Syrian government end its crackdown on a five-month-old uprising “immediately and unconditionally,” warning that unspecified steps would be taken otherwise.

headline: Cuomo Opts to Vacation Close to Home
text: ALBANY — After an eventful first seven months in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has decided it is time for a vacation.

headline: Scaring, and Scarring, Parents-to-Be
text: I am back from two weeks spent hopscotching around the country, a mix of work and vacation. Among other things, I met scores of wonderful writers at BlogHer in San Diego — many of whom will become guest posters here over the next weeks and months. I also overdid the Mexican food in California, the stuffed pizza in Chicago and the lobster in Montauk.

headline: Shorelines, Sandy or Otherwise, That May Not Last
text: If you like a day at the beach — and who does not? — you can find lots of books that will enhance your experience by telling you about the birds, the fish, the plants and even the bugs you will encounter there.

headline: ‘Bring It On’ Screenwriter Alleges Musical Shenanigans
text: In “Bring It On,” the 2000 movie starring Kirsten Dunst, two cheerleading squads faced off amid accusations of stolen routines. Now that animosity has carried over to a new musical based on the movie.

headline: In Search of Customized Homes
text: This week, The Appraisal takes a look at two super-specific apartment renovations, one with a retro-yet-futuristic submarine sort of feel, the other that took the city and the four elements — imagine subway cars, metamorphic rock and a river running through it — as its inspiration. The second one managed to find a buyer after years and a few price cuts; the other has just come on the market.

headline: The New Prospectors
text: As gold prices climb, more people are joining the ranks of Australia’s modern gold hunters.

headline: This week: A disease with a mind of its own, looking for the oldest forms of life on Earth and is it a boy or a girl?
text: This week: A disease with a mind of its own, looking for the oldest forms of life on Earth and, is it a boy or a girl?

headline: Bookshelf
text: Coinciding with an exhibition at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris, “Hussein Chalayan” (Rizzoli, $85) explores the Cypriot-British designer’s provocative and pathbreaking signatures, including rotting silk dresses and nude models in chadors.

headline: Grizzlies Return, With Strings Attached
text: DUPUYER, Mont. — Russell Talmo, a bear management technician, greeted John and Leanne Hayne at their ranch on the windswept edge of this tiny town with a gift: a can of pepper spray to ward off grizzly bears.

headline: TimesCast | August 15, 2011
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's interior minister lands in Cairo with his family; Monday is the most violent day in Iraq this year; and a three-way race for the Republican nomination emerges.

headline: AMC and CBS Find Ratings Success
text: Just as viewers were easing into their couches on Sunday night to enjoy another tense hour of “Breaking Bad,” AMC announced that it had renewed the show for what would be its final run of episodes, filling those viewers with joy, followed by dread that the show would soon come to an end. According to Nielsen data, 1.8 million total viewers watched the episode — a 9 percent increase over the same point from last season. That continues an overall trend for the year that suggests a slowly growing audience. But how will viewers (and potential viewers) approach the show now that the end for Walter White is officially in sight?

headline: With Early Prep Time, Brunch Is a Breeze
text: A CHEERY weekend brunch provides a most civilized platform for outdoor eating, especially when the dishes can be prepared almost entirely ahead. When all you have to do before you wish to eat are simple assembly jobs, you are left to fill the role of laidback (dare I say glamorous?) brunch hostess.

headline: More Than Memories to Keep Spirit of Elaine’s Alive
text: Not all of the memorabilia from Elaine’s, the Upper East Side restaurant that closed a couple of months ago, will be up for sale at an auction planned for September: The restaurant’s yellow-and-black sign and one of the tables that celebrities and celebrity-watchers prized the most are being donated to the New-York Historical Society, according to Diane Becker, the restaurant’s longtime manager.

headline: Google Looks for Vertical Integration
text: Google’s acquisition of Motorola Mobility for $40 a share may mean the company thinks the best way to make money with mobile computing is by “owning” the device. DealBook’s editor, Andrew Ross Sorkin, speaks to Tavis McCourt, an analyst with Morgan Keegan, in a CNBC interview about what this might mean for competitors.

headline: Penguins Not Counting Crosby Out for Opener
text: Ray Shero, the Pittsburgh Penguins’ general manager, said Monday that Sidney Crosby was still experiencing symptoms from the concussion that sidelined him in early January.

headline: ‘Made in China,’ but Still Profiting Americans
text: 4:40 p.m. | Updated to correct the name of the organization that released the study.

headline: Looking Like A President
text: Steve Benen has a righteous rant about pundits who judge candidates on whether they “look like a president”. That immediately made me think of two things. First, I remember the Vietnam War — and I remember William Westmoreland, who came straight from central casting, but unfortunately was a pretty bad general. Second, I remember this, which seems especially appropriate for Governor Goodhair:

headline: Really? The Claim: To Prevent Migraines, Drink More Water
text: THE FACTS

headline: A Night Out for Fashionistas
text: If you’ve ever dreamed of meeting Oscar de la Renta or Michael Kors – and, really, who hasn’t? – then Fashion’s Night Out is the event you’ve been waiting for. The lineup for this year’s event, scheduled for Thursday, Sept. 8, has just been announced, and it includes appearances around New York by most of the fashion industry’s most notable figures.

headline: Bachmann’s ‘Don’t Ask’ Position a Legal Possibility
text: If elected president, Michele Bachmann said over the weekend, she would favor reinstating the ban on openly gay or lesbian people serving in the military, a policy known as “don’t ask, don’t tell.” Former Senator Rick Santorum has said similar things in the past.

headline: TimesCast | Libyan Minister in Cairo
text: Aug. 15, 2011 - Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi's interior minister, Nassr al-Mabrouk Abdullah, flew to Cairo with his family in an apparent defection.

headline: A.I.G. Names New Treasurer
text: The American International Group announced Monday that Brian T. Schreiber, its executive vice president for Treasury and capital markets, had been named to the additional role of the insurer’s treasurer.

headline: Stockholm Syndrome
text: I’m off to the European Finance Association meeting, combined with a family trip. No column Friday and next Monday; I might post a bit on the blog, but hopefully not too much.

headline: Protest Over Chemical Plant Shows Growing Pressure on China From Citizens
text: BEIJING — More than international prestige or even economic might, the top priority of China’s leadership is to maintain stability among this nation’s vast and varied population. President Hu Jintao explicitly reaffirmed that goal just last month, telling a Communist Party celebration that “without stability, nothing can be accomplished.”

headline: The End Comes for ‘Kate Plus Eight’
text: Kate Gosselin’s big family will no longer be followed by TLC’s cameras on a regular basis.

headline: Watch Your Step While Washing Up
text: The smallest room in the house can be a dangerous place.

headline: A Farewell to M. Wells
text: M. Wells, the celebrated little diner in Long Island City, Queens, that opened last summer and announced at the start of August that it would close at month’s end, has been throwing farewell dinners on Friday and Saturday nights. The first was an evening devoted to the fruits of the Fulton Fish Market in the Bronx. There was another devoted to the joys of melted cheese. On Saturday night, the theme was caviar and magic. Seats ran $200 a head.

headline: TimesCast | Widespread Attacks in Iraq
text: August 15, 2011 - Coordinated attacks across Iraq raise questions about the country's ability to maintain security.

headline: Regimens: Soothing Melodies for Cancer Patients
text: Listening to music may reduce anxiety and pain in cancer patients, new research suggests.

headline: Picture of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Egypt, Somalia and Afghanistan.

headline: Who Pays the Supercommittee?
text: The 12 members of the “supercommittee” that will try to develop yet another bipartisan fiscal policy proposal have now been named. What types of spending programs and tax breaks should we expect these members to care about most?

headline: Cross-Training by Lifting Weights
text: Many athletes try to spice up their workouts by cross-training in another sport. A runner might jump on a bicycle, for example, or a cyclist might go for a run.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Libya, Egypt and Somalia.

headline: The Most Dangerous Room in the House
text: What’s the most dangerous room in the house? While parents and caregivers for the elderly often worry about kitchen hazards like hot stoves and sharp knives, the riskiest room in the home is the bathroom.

headline: Rain, but Little Gloom, at Fiat 500 Movie Screenings in Times Square
text: Fiat turned Times Square into a drive-in of sorts last weekend, parking 36 examples of its 500 coupe and cabriolet to be used as seating for two nights of film screenings.

headline: Buffett Takes Stake in Dollar General
text: Warren E. Buffett noted in an op-ed article in The New York Times that “most Americans struggle to make ends meet.” So it probably makes investment sense that he has taken a stake in a retailer that draws in those very same Americans who are trying to find bargains wherever they can.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘I Light Up My Life’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on Artsbeat between now and the festival’s close on August 28. For more information, go to www.fringenyc.org.

headline: Hearing the Mystery in Sibelius
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — At one point here this weekend, the opening minutes of a documentary about Jean Sibelius were screened. The film’s score is the classic, almost unbearably emotional recording Sibelius made when he emerged from retirement to conduct his “Andante Festivo” over the radio in 1939.

headline: Early Plants Grew Wood as Plumbing, Study Says
text: Two small plants, both about 400 million years old, are the oldest known examples of wood, according to a new study. The older of the two plants predates other early examples of wood by at least 10 million years.

headline: The Caucus: Bachmann’s ‘Don’t Ask’ Position
text: Just in case you missed it, over on The Caucus, James Dao posts on whether Michele Bachmann, if elected president, could reinstate Don’t Ask Don’t Tell. (Spoiler Alert: Possibly.)

headline: Sentence of the Month, A Big Greasy Breakfast of Winners
text: It’s been awhile since we held a proper Sentence of the Week contest, which means we have a roiling abundance of sentences to deal with. Just look at them all:

headline: A Supergene Paints Wings for Surviving Biological War
text: The gaudy brown Brazilian butterfly known as Heliconius numata has long puzzled geneticists. It has seven different wing patterns, each of which mimics that of a different local species of Melinaea, another group of butterflies.

headline: So, Doctor, Isn’t There a Pill to Cure Middle-Aged Angst?
text: The title of Josh Koenigsberg’s dark new comedy, “Herman Kline’s Midlife Crisis,” at the Beckett Theater, is a little misleading. Sure, the lead character — Dr. Herman Kline, the 50-something head of the trauma bay at Mount Sinai Medical Center — is definitely feeling a crisis of confidence. But so is his wife, Liz, trapped as much by her station as a homemaker and doctor’s wife as by her age.

headline: The Right Architect With the Wrong Name
text: A decade after 9/11, Amy Waldman’s nervy and absorbing new novel, “The Submission,” tackles the aftermath of such a terrorist attack head-on. The result reads as if the author had embraced Tom Wolfe’s famous call for a new social realism — for fiction writers to use their reporting skills to depict “this wild, bizarre, unpredictable, Hog-stomping baroque country of ours” — and in doing so, has come up with a story that has more verisimilitude, more political resonance and way more heart than Mr. Wolfe’s own 1987 best seller, “The Bonfire of the Vanities.”

headline: Debt in Europe Fuels a Bond Debate
text: FRANKFURT — The Germans want to bury it. The French say it is a nonstarter. But the idea that the only way to contain the sovereign debt crisis is for Europe to issue bonds backed by all the nations of the euro zone will not go away.

headline: Youth Quake | London
text: What do you wear when protest and mayhem rock your world? Reports from three epicenters of street style: London, Cairo and Tokyo.

headline: Steve Jobs Biography Set for November Release
text: It is not often that technophiles get as excited about a new book as they do about a new gadget. The release of a biography of Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s co-founder, might be one of those rare moments.

headline: Hot Weather Takes Toll on Medication
text: The recent heat wave may have taken a toll on your medication. That’s what reporter Walecia Konrad learned after her son’s allergy medication stopped working after being exposed to high temperatures on a family vacation at the lake.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Dirty Harry'
text: A. O. Scott looks at the themes of justice and vengeance in the 1971 film starring Clint Eastwood.

headline: Briton Arrested for Plotting Water Fight by BlackBerry
text: In a demonstration of the kind of zero-tolerance policing of modern criminality that will no doubt impress Iran’s morals police as much as Egypt’s military rulers, officers outside London announced on Monday that they had arrested a man for sending text messages encouraging people to take part in a mass water fight.

headline: Closer to Her Fans and Further Away From Her Past
text: She is thunder, Beyoncé is. Fire and quake. A thing that can’t quite be contained. There is not any better advertisement for Beyoncé than Beyoncé herself, a hard worker who makes effort look like the most glamorous thing in the world.

headline: Girl Scout Cookies vs. City Zoning Laws
text: In Hazelwood, Mo., Carolyn Mills and her daughters, Abigail, 14, and Caitlin, 16, have sold Girl Scout cookies from their driveway for years. But after a neighbor complained that the cookie stand created too much traffic and was causing dogs to bark, city officials told the Millses that selling cookies there violated the city’s zoning code.

headline: Living With a Name That Evokes Pop Stardom, and Curious Glances
text: MY travel has increased quite a bit since I’ve become president of DKC. I’ve always traveled for business, but now it seems as if I’m in an airport all the time, which really doesn’t bother me. I like airports.

headline: A Feast of Food Links
text: A Harvard study links red meat, especially processed red meat, to an increased risk of Type 2 diabetes: “A daily 100-gram serving of unprocessed red meat may increase the risk of developing Type 2 diabetes by 19%, while just 50 grams of processed meat — for example one hot dog, a sausage, or two slices of bacon — is associated with 51% increased risk.” Wait for it, wait for it . . . the American Meat Institute says “nah.”

headline: Preserving Old-Time Cuisine and Values
text: “Family Restaurant” is the General Tso’s chicken of reality shows: deep fried and suspiciously sweet, concocted in North America to satisfy Western tastes. Which means it can be pretty satisfying, in half-hour portions, though the MSG (multi-stereotype glutamate) may leave you with a headache.

text: JEFF BRIDGES

headline: Gold Fever Gripping the Australian Outback
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Four years ago, Marco Nero was on top of the world. He was earning more than $1 million working as a film effects designer for some of the world’s most prestigious digital animation houses.

headline: Pathogens May Change, but the Fear Is the Same
text: In “House on Fire: The Fight to Eradicate Smallpox,” Dr. William H. Foege, one of the conquerors of the virus, describes a grotesque moment in the war: The last victim in Benin, in West Africa, is visited by several “fetisheurs” — witch doctors — seeking to harvest his scabs.

headline: T.S. Eliot Devotees Angered by Plans to Develop East Coker
text: “Houses rise and fall, crumble, are extended,/Are removed, destroyed, restored…” T.S. Eliot wrote in “East Coker,” a poem in his famed collection “Four Quartets.” Now a proposal to do the first — build a development with 3,750 houses and an industrial estate on the edge of East Coker, in Somerset — has prompted protests from Eliot devotees.

text: To the Editor:

headline: For Some in Menopause, Hormones May Be Only Option
text: For women hoping to combat the symptoms of menopause with nonprescription alternatives like soy and flaxseed supplements, recent studies have held one disappointment after another.

headline: Music, Memories and Regret
text: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — A piano is a dangerous thing in “Ten Cents a Dance,” John Doyle’s beautiful, brooding collage of the songs of Rodgers and Hart, now at the Williamstown Theater Festival here. A piano, you see, makes music. And music makes memories. And memories, well, as often as not they make regrets. So a piano can hurt a guy bad, especially in a place like the deserted gin palace where “Ten Cents a Dance” takes place.

headline: Phone Messages Improve Care, Study Finds
text: Using cellphones to broadcast text messages reminding health workers in Kenya how to treat children’s malaria increased the number of cases handled correctly, a new study has found.

headline: Romney’s Fire on Obama Not Turned on Perry
text: LITCHFIELD, N.H. — Hitting the campaign trail on Monday in New Hampshire, Mitt Romney compared President Obama to Jimmy Carter, said, “He’s in over his head when it comes to the economy,” and sent out a campaign release calling the president’s swing through Iowa this week a “Magical Misery bus tour.”

headline: Bloggingheads: G.O.P. Moderates D.O.A.?
text: Erica Grieder, left, of The Economist and Evan Smith of The Texas Tribune debate whether a moderate Republican can win the primary.

headline: New Jersey Superintendents Call State Agency Ineffective
text: Nearly three-quarters of New Jersey school superintendents said the state Education Department did not play an important role in helping districts raise students’ achievement or prepare graduates for college and careers, according to a survey the department released Monday.

headline: George C. Devol, Inventor of Robot Arm, Dies at 99
text: George C. Devol, a largely self-taught inventor who drew from science fiction to help develop Unimate, the revolutionary mechanical arm that became a prototype for robots now widely used on automobile assembly lines and in other industries, died on Thursday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 99.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,722 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Germany Is Flying Above the Economic Storm in Europe
text: BERLIN — There is no one whose thoughts European officials would rather read than Chancellor Angela Merkel, who meets Tuesday at the Élysée Palace with France’s president, Nicolas Sarkozy, as they struggle to find a lasting solution to the European debt crisis.

headline: Is Google Turning Into a Mobile Phone Company? No, It Says
text: Matthew Staver/Bloomberg NewsLarry Page, a Google co-founder, left, and Eric Schmidt, the former chief executive, in Sun Valley, Idaho, in 2009.

headline: Egypt Deploys Soldiers to North Sinai
text: CAIRO — Egyptian soldiers who were sent to crack down on lawlessness in the North Sinai Desert killed a man in a gunfight on Monday and captured a dozen others in a series of early morning raids, security officials said.

headline: For the Space Needle’s Birthday, a Trip to Space
text: SEATTLE — Already, a gender divide seems to be developing over the desirability of being launched into space, at least in the Bordian family, who were visiting the Space Needle here the other day, staring out at the cloudy cityscape and mulling the tower’s latest promotional contest — for a suborbital spaceflight, 62 miles above the earth.

headline: Giants Breathe Easier as Umenyiora Returns
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Ever since training camp began more than two weeks ago, the Giants had strenuously denied that the star defensive lineman Osi Umenyiora’s holdout was a distraction.

headline: Israel: Plans for New Housing Advance
text: Israel has recently advanced plans for the construction of 277 housing units in the Jewish settlement of Ariel, deep inside the West Bank, the defense minister’s office said on Monday. The move, the latest in a flurry of settlement activity, comes ahead of Palestinian plans to seek United Nations recognition as a member state in the fall. Last week Israel’s Interior Ministry announced approval for a contentious 1,600-apartment complex in East Jerusalem and said it would soon approve an additional 2,700 housing units there, prompting Palestinian fury and international criticism for undermining efforts to restart peace negotiations. Israel insists on keeping Ariel under any border agreement. The Palestinians claim that territory, conquered by Israel in the 1967 war, as part of a future state.

headline: Even Without a Course of Its Own, St. John’s Produced a Champion
text: St. John’s is perhaps best known for its basketball program, but it has a pretty good golf team, too — one that produced Keegan Bradley, the surprise winner of the P.G.A. Championship on Sunday.

headline: Sides in Verizon Strike Trade More Accusations
text: Verizon said on Monday that there had been 143 acts of sabotage to telephone facilities since 45,000 of its workers went on strike Aug. 7.

headline: With Hair Pat-Downs, Complaints of Racial Bias
text: TIMERY SHANTE NANCE is an African-American woman who has a thing about her hair. “I don’t use chemicals or straighteners,” she said. “It’s just my natural texture, and I wear it in a normal-looking puff.”

headline: A Gold Standard Is Unthinkable No More
text: Fiat money has worked well since Richard Nixon ended the dollar’s peg to gold 40 years ago this week, but this latest recession must gnaw at believers. If years of ultra-cheap cash give rise to serious inflation or an accelerated retreat of the American currency, the gold standard, however erratic and deflationary, could start to appeal again.

headline: Medicaid Pays Less Than Medicare for Many Prescription Drugs, U.S. Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Medicaid gets much deeper discounts on many prescription drugs than Medicare, in part because Medicaid discounts are set by law whereas Medicare prices are negotiated by private insurers and drug companies, federal investigators said Monday in a new report.

headline: Hedge Funds Disclose Positions
text: John A. Paulson, the hedge fund manager at the helm of the mighty Paulson & Company, has been bleeding money this summer in his Advantage Plus fund, which was down 31 percent at last count.

headline: Young Champions Ready to Move, With No Baggage

headline: City Selling Space in Brooklyn Building
text: It is unlikely that any visitors to the property assessor’s office in the stone monolith known as the Brooklyn Municipal Building ever looked around at the clerks poring over tax records and exclaimed, “It would be fun to spend my next paycheck here.” But the Laboz brothers think it could be just that sort of place.

headline: The Phantom Menace
text: Washington

headline: A Foot Care Company Shifts to Sell a New Line of Shoes
text: AH, the search for the perfect shoe — comfortable, stylish and able to help you leap tall buildings in a single bound or at least make the elevator in three.

headline: Losing Privacy in Route Plans
text: Imagine that every car had a global positioning device and that before every trip, drivers were required to let the traffic authorities know where they were going. And suppose the government released all that data to the public so anyone could follow a car’s movements online simply by entering a license plate number.

text: Turmoil in the stock market. A downgrade of the United States credit rating. The economic crisis in Europe.

headline: Emerald Cities
text: “Wastewater Treatment Plant” may not sound like a scenic destination. But some ecologically minded towns have been designing a new breed of wildlife preserve, one that gives recycling a lively twist. Instead of dumping treated water, they return it to nature as the essence of an ecosystem that offers food and habitat to animals. Migrating and native birds find a niche, entangled communities of plants and insects take up residence and a hodgepodge of wild animals bustles in.

headline: Virtual and Artificial, but 58,000 Want Course
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — A free online course at Stanford University on artificial intelligence, to be taught this fall by two leading experts from Silicon Valley, has attracted more than 58,000 students around the globe — a class nearly four times the size of Stanford’s entire student body.

headline: Catholic Clergy Protest Pope’s Visit, and Its Price Tag

headline: Nat Allbright, Voice of Dodgers Games He Did Not See, Dies at 87

headline: Sending the Police Before There’s a Crime

headline: What Is Business Waiting For?

headline: A Closer Look at Taxes on the Rich

headline: After Streak Ends, Braves’ Uggla Remains Focused
text: ATLANTA — Dan Uggla awoke Monday with a consecutive-games hit streak of zero. For the season’s first three months, that situation had greeted him nearly as often as the risen sun. His batting average scraped the National League floor, bottoming out at .170.

headline: On Wide Florida Roads, Running for Dear Life
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — As any pedestrian in Florida knows, walking in this car-obsessed state can be as tranquil as golfing in a lightning storm. Sidewalks are viewed as perks, not necessities. Crosswalks are disliked and dishonored. And many drivers maniacally speed up when they see someone crossing the street.

headline: Google’s Coup Shifts Mobile Alliances

headline: Albert Brown, Survivor of Bataan March, Dies at 105
text: Albert Brown, the oldest American survivor of the Bataan Death March, in which as many as 11,000 soldiers died at the hands of the Japanese in the Philippines in 1942, and perhaps the oldest American veteran of World War II, died Sunday in Nashville, Ill. He was 105 and lived in Pinckneyville, Ill.

headline: In the World of Wireless, It’s All About Patents
text: Google, in announcing a $12.5 billion deal for Motorola Mobility on Monday, saved its warmest words not for Motorola Mobility’s management or its products, but for one valuable asset: the company’s roughly 17,000 patents, as well as an additional 7,500 patents that are under government review.

headline: After Making Successful Return to Lineup, Posada Now Hopes He Can Stay
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — In his first game in a week last Saturday, Jorge Posada hit a grand slam and had six R.B.I., his most since 2006. It was an emotional day for him as the fans lavished him with ovations and a request for a curtain call.

headline: The Clear Case for the Gas Tax
text: Unless Congress extends it, the 18.4 cents-a-gallon federal gas tax will expire on Sept. 30. Allowing that to happen would be tremendously destructive. It would bankrupt the already stressed Highway Trust Fund, with devastating effects on the country’s highways, bridges, mass transit systems and the economy as a whole.

headline: N.C.A.A. Chief Suggests a Summit on Conference Expansion
text: Mark Emmert, the president of the N.C.A.A., reached out to several top college officials Monday, suggesting a meeting to discuss a less cannibalistic and more collegial way to approach conference expansion.

headline: The Union’s Spy Game
text: At the outset of the Civil War, neither the Union nor the Confederacy had a centralized military intelligence department — and yet the need for information on enemy troop movements, political developments and even simple things like geography was immediate. In the breach, they turned to a motley crew of amateur spies who were as untrained and untested as the soldiers who met on the early battlefields at Bull Run and Wilson’s Creek.

headline: A Confident Perry Lingers to Make Friends at the Fair

headline: A Race to Repudiate Government
text: At one level, it’s ridiculous that 17,000 people in a small Iowa town could cast a vote that ended the campaign of a major Republican presidential candidate, Tim Pawlenty. Given the nature of the Republican primary system — and the mood of its voters this year — it has its own grim logic. Why not let a handful of conservatives and libertarians winnow the field? It will toughen up the candidates for the extremist gauntlet to come.

headline: Miles and Miles of Drought
text: This year, Texas has received less than half its normal rainfall: 6.53 inches instead of 16.03. Climatologists say this dry spell is the worst one-year drought since Texas began keeping rainfall records in 1895, and they predict that the cause of the drought — the weather created by the Pacific current called La Niña — may well extend into next year. For farmers and ranchers, this is a disaster. Agricultural losses have already surpassed the record — $4.1 billion in 2006 — and could double.

But as the police investigate, some here already consider the incident one more example of the politics in this state veering toward the extreme.

headline: Getting Ready for Baseball’s ‘Week 17’
text: One of the hardest things about fantasy baseball is the sheer length of the season. It almost seems as though we’re in the stretch run, and that if you’re near the top of the standings, you’ve largely done your job, but it’s not so. There’s roughly 25 percent of the season left to play, plenty of time for the front-runners to fall apart or for those within reasonable striking distance to make up the necessary ground.

headline: App Smart Extra: More on Sleeping-Aid Apps
text: The most recent App Smart column, on apps that help you relax and sleep, earned a fair amount of circulation among insomniacs. People who suffer from poor sleep will happily pay a few dollars on an app, if it leads to a few hours of deep slumber. And they are not above trying multiple apps, gadgets or mind tricks to find sleep.

headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis Weakens Quarterly Growth
text: FRANKFURT — Europe’s sovereign debt crisis threatened to spill over into the broader economy after official figures released Tuesday showed that growth in the euro zone fell to its lowest rate in two years. Germany — the Continent’s powerhouse — slowed almost to a standstill.

headline: Britain Will Force Convicted Rioters to Clean Up

headline: Wanted: A Good Job and Some Understanding
text: My father and I don’t talk much about my time in the war. I’ve told him a little about my frustrations with the experience and about my contradictory feelings of pride and humbleness. During dinner one evening, when we were discussing my difficulties with juggling my civilian job and National Guard responsibilities, my father finished chewing his food and placed his fork down on the table.

headline: Court Sides With Trustee Over Madoff Payouts
text: A federal appeals court panel reviewing one of the fiercest legal disputes to arise from Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme ruled on Tuesday that the embattled trustee’s approach on how to calculate investor losses in the case is “legally sound” and fundamentally fair.

headline: First 5 Minutes: 'Jane Eyre'
text: The opening scene from the latest film adaptation of "Jane Eyre," directed by Cary Fukunaga and now on Blu-ray and DVD.

headline: Parliamentary Documents Released in Tabloid Hacking Case
text: Documents from the Home Affairs Committee’s investigation into phone hacking at the News of the World tabloid. The documents include a letter from former royal correspondent Clive Goodman, who claims the practice was “widely discussed”in daily meetings and approved by senior editors.

headline: A Town Beacon, With a Side of Soft Serve
text: Just outside of Reading, Pa., a proud owner has turned his Dairy Queen into a cornerstone of the community.

headline: Reeve Carney to Play Jeff Buckley in Biographical Film
text: “Anything You Can Do” is not a song associated with the catalog of Jeff Buckley, but it is one that seems to apply to the competitive zeal surrounding two rival film projects seeking to dramatize the life of that singer-songwriter.

headline: Good Will to All, With a Side of Soft-Serve
text: KENHORST, Pa.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Myla Dalbesio
text: The latest installment of Chelsea Art Walk was arguably hijacked by a rebellious performance piece by the budding artist Myla Dalbesio. Barely clothed in a hot pink bikini and stripper heels, and covered in slimy brown body paint, Dalbesio writhed on a dollar-bill-coated floor of the tiny back room at Ramis Barquet gallery, covering herself, the room and innocent bystanders with sticky, cheap Champagne.

headline: Edelbrock Highboy: A Slice of Land Speed History Heads to Pebble Beach
text: One of the cars present at the birth of hot-rodding, the Edelbrock Highboy Roadster, will be offered Friday at the RM Auctions event in Monterey, Calif. This memento from land speed racing’s roots carries a pre-auction estimate ranging from $350,000 to $450,000. That’s a price that would probably bring an ironic smile to any hot-rodder old enough to remember the humble beginnings of the typical “highboy.”

headline: Take One Dog, Add Water and Shake
text: On a beach outing recently, my friends and I watched a yellow Labrador frolic in the waves and dig with abandon in the sand. Then, to our horror, he bounded toward us and stopped. We all knew what was coming.

headline: ‘Watch the Throne’ Breaks iTunes Record
text: Jay-Z and Kanye West have broken a record set by Coldplay for the most iTunes downloads of an album during its first week of release, as their collaboration ‘Watch the Throne’ sold more than 290,000 digital copies on Apple’s music service, a publicist for Mr. West said. The album was released last Monday after months of hype and publicity, and it was exclusively avaible on iTunes for the first three days, doubtless boosting its sales on the service.

headline: China’s Troubled Railway Ministry Fires Spokesman
text: BEIJING — China’s railways ministry said Tuesday that it had dismissed its spokesman, whose statements after a high-speed train collision in eastern China last month became a target of public ridicule.

headline: Sarkozy and Merkel Vow Fiscal Unity for Euro Nations
text: PARIS — Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, and France’s president, Nicolas Sarkozy, on Tuesday called for closer coordination of economic policy among the 17 countries that share the euro currency and proposed that they enshrine in their constitutions an obligation to balance their national budgets.

headline: Michael Lewis’s Piece is a Luftnummer, and That’s not a Compliment
text: Editor’s note: Michael Lewis was for many years a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine, and we hold him in very high esteem. But his recent piece about German economics in Vanity Fair has caused some controversy (viz Felix Salmon of The Columbia Journalism Review and Kevin Drum of Mother Jones ), so we asked Stephan Seiler, an Arthur F. Burns Fellow in journalism from Hamburg, Germany, who is currently in residence at the Times Magazine, for his reaction to the piece. Here’s his take on it.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘The Day the Sky Turned Black’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festival’s close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: A Slitherer Makes a Comeback
text: The Lake Erie watersnake, a harmless critter that can grow to more than three feet in length, has been removed from the federal list of endangered and threatened wildlife after a successful decadelong effort to protect the snake and its habitat, the Interior Department announced this week.

headline: At This Library, Check Out the Tomatoes
text: Robert Cox walked into the public library on City Island in the Bronx the other day to read the daily papers and to grab a handful of cherry tomatoes from a bowl of fresh produce next to the checkout counter.

headline: A Nice Guy Hits No. 600
text: Chances are you didn’t see much more than a highlight of Jim Thome hitting his 600th home run Monday night. And until then, you might not have even been aware he was close to becoming the eighth player to reach that milestone. And even now, you might need to be reminded he plays for the Minnesota Twins. His monumental achievement received less media hype than Derek Jeter on a double date.

headline: The Case for Harbinger Group as the Next Berkshire
text: Someone loves Philip A. Falcone.

headline: Donating Breast Milk
text: The use of donor breast milk has grown significantly in recent years, according to The Houston Chronicle, which details a breast milk donor program at Texas Children’s Hospital.

headline: With Bank Failures Mounting, Some Complain of Harsh Exams
text: Financial regulators have taken a public thrashing for going easy on banks before the financial crisis hit, allowing institutions big and small to dole out dubious loans. Now, according to some community bankers, regulators have abandoned their light touch for a heavy hand at a time when the industry is struggling to recover.

headline: Edible Selby | Nordic Cuisine in Stockholm
text: Chefs Fredrik Andersson, Victor Fransson and Peter Goldberg bring a minimalist aesthetic and a whimsical, free-form approach to Swedish cooking. Audio and Photos: Fredrik Andersson on his restaurant, Mistral >>

headline: Yankees’ List of Draft Signings
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. – The Yankees have signed eight of their first nine 2011 draft picks and 19 of their 25. Their top pick, the high school third baseman Dante Bichette Jr., the 51st pick over all, signed on June 18.

headline: They’re Chess Pieces. They’re Old. O.K. They’re From Norway. Oh, Yeah?
text: Scholars have long thought that the Lewis Chessmen — eight-century-old chess pieces carved mostly out of walrus tusk that were found on the Isle of Lewis, in the Outer Hebrides, Scotland, in 1831 — were made in Trondheim, Norway.

headline: Lawyers for Defendant in Giffords Shooting Seem to Be Searching for Illness
text: PHOENIX — Jared L. Loughner’s grandparents and great-grandparents died years ago, but lawyers defending Mr. Loughner in connection with a Jan. 8 shooting spree outside Tucson are delving into their lives and those of numerous other Loughner ancestors in an apparent effort to show that mental illness runs in the family.

headline: Alan Richman, M. Wells and the State of Service in New York Restaurants
text: So Alan Richman has a barn-burner column in the new GQ about how he had a couple of good meals at M. Wells in Queens and then a horrible third one that led to a shocking exchange of e-mails between him and one of the restaurant’s owners, Sarah Obraitis, in which she accused him of giving a waitress “a hardy pat” on the backside. The crossfire led to much discussion on Twitter and Eater .

headline: Debit Overdraft Fees, While Voluntary, Are Still Steep
text: Even though banks now must get permission from their customers before charging overdraft fees on debit card purchases, the fees they charge are still hefty — and some big banks have increased the maximum number of overdraft fees customers can run up each day.

headline: Brooklyn Takes a Bow as a Town of Writers
text: “Brooklyn, Brooklyn, take me in,” the chorus of an improbably lovely song by the Avett Brothers implores. “Are you aware the shape I’m in?”

headline: Gay Malaysian Pastor’s Wedding Plans Stir Anger
text: Government officials in Malaysia have expressed outrage over the plans of a prominent gay Malaysian to marry in New York — and celebrate the wedding back in his home country.

headline: Books and Backpacks From Blackstone
text: Students will be clamoring over the hottest fall fashions as they head back to school this month. But thanks to the Blackstone Group, 150 New York students will be able to one-up classmates by showing off their private equity connections.

headline: Dollar Stores: Shelf by Shelf
text: The ubiquitous dollar store is the American dream writ small.

headline: Could Things Break Any Worse for AMC?
text: It was just this May that an article in New York magazine described AMC as “the ­fastest-­rising network in America” and wondered if that cable channel could “survive its own success.” Three months later that question seems more pressing and prophetic than ever. After rapidly building its brand of original programming around prestigious and much-lauded series like “Mad Men” and “Breaking Bad,” AMC has been roiled by behind-the-scenes disputes and controversies at every one of its signature shows – even the ones it hasn’t started broadcasting yet. Although the network received 29 Emmy Award nominations in July (including a fourth consecutive best drama nod for “Mad Men”), that moment was a rare bright spot amid months of developments that were often as gloomy as the art direction for “The Walking Dead.”

headline: A Happy 200th to The Times’s First Publisher, Whom Boss Tweed Couldn’t Buy or Kill
text: “I don’t think the devil will ever make a higher bid for me than that.”

headline: Trout Fishing in a Climate-Changed America
text: As difficult as it is to predict precisely how the planet will warm over the next century or so, it is even harder to refine predictions of how those changes will affect specific species. That’s because warmer temperatures alone are not the only driver of what happens to, say, four varieties of trout.

headline: Injury to Turner Leaves Jets Thin on Line
text: 6:46 p.m. | Updated

headline: Syrian Enclave of Palestinians Nearly Deserted After Assault
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — United Nations officials said Tuesday that as many as 10,000 residents of a Palestinian refugee neighborhood in the Syrian port city of Latakia had fled during a four-day assault, as security forces carried out more arrests and intimidation in what residents said was a government attempt to rebuild a wall of fear in one of Syria’s largest cities.

headline: Asked and Answered | Mary Wilson
text: A Supremes fanatic gets to quiz a musical idol.

headline: Soft Serve in a Small Town
text: A local Dairy Queen serves as a gathering place to beat the heat of summer.

headline: The Real San Marzanos
text: A can of San Marzano tomatoes is an icon for food lovers: with red, concentrated flesh, plum-shaped San Marzanos are often the only kind deemed acceptable by chefs and cookbooks.

headline: If Not Christie, Then Who?
text: Daniel Larison and Jonathan Chait, among others, are dismissive of my suggestion that the prospect of a Mitt Romney-Rick Perry showdown should inspire Chris Christie to take another look at the presidential race. Here’s Larison’s counterargument:

headline: Contractors Are Accused in Large-Scale Theft of Food Aid in Somalia
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Beyond freelance gunmen, Islamist militants, cholera, malaria, measles and the staggering needs of hundreds of thousands of starving children, aid agencies scrambling to address Somalia’s famine now may have another problem to reckon with: the wholesale theft of food aid.

headline: The Legend of Zhayi Zhaga
text: Amanda Schmidt, an assistant professor of geology at Oberlin College, writes from Sichuan Province, China. She is studying the relative natural hazards of some places where people choose to live.

headline: Thinking About a Double Dip
text: Watching the debt-ceiling talks and the stock market’s gyrations the last few weeks, along with the resulting fears that we may be entering another recession, has reminded me of something that happened many years ago.

headline: Israeli Air Strike Hits Gaza After Rocket Fire
text: GAZA — A Palestinian militant was killed early Tuesday in an Israeli airstrike on Gaza that was mounted in response to rocket fire from the enclave, which is controlled by Hamas, a militant Palestinian political group.

headline: Love Blessed by Lady Liberty Lives On
text: One question went unanswered last week when the National Park Service announced it would shut down the Statue of Liberty for renovations in October: What happened to the couple who got engaged in the crown when the statue reopened on July 4, 2009?

headline: Large Account Loss Leads to Layoffs at DraftFCB Agency
text: The loss of the giant SC Johnson & Son account is leading the DraftFCB advertising agency to lay off hundreds of employees.

headline: Ron Paul: He Who Shall Not Be Named
text: Is Ron Paul getting a raw deal? Jon Stewart, host of “The Daily Show,” thinks so.

headline: After Dropping PBS, Los Angeles Station Makes Deal of Its Own
text: KCET, the Los Angeles public television that quit carrying PBS shows Jan. 1 because it said the dues were too high, has found a new source of original programs that it will get free.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 16
text: The day in sports included cricket in Sri Lanka, rugby in France and the Palio of Siena horse race in Italy.

headline: LinkedIn Targets Mobile Users
text: LinkedIn hopes to capture some of the frenzy surrounding social networking on smartphones with a series of major updates announced Tuesday on the company’s Web site.

headline: Meal Plan
text: Ian Marber, the well-known London-based nutritionist and author (a k a the Food Doctor), helps his celebrity clientele stay slim and healthy using a revolutionary technique. “I don’t blind people with science,” he says. “I simply teach them how to eat.”

headline: What to Call a Half-Sibling?
text: What to call one another when forming a family? It used to be simple: wife took husband’s name; kids did, too. But it hasn’t been for a long time.

headline: Two Rick Perry Books Are on the Way
text: The entrance of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas into the Republican presidential race may be bad news for Mitt Romney and Michele Bachmann, but so far it seems to be good news for the book business. On Tuesday, two publishers announced forthcoming books on Mr. Perry, The Associated Press reported. Metropolitan Books will publish a work, with an unprintable title, by James C. Moore, the co-author of “Bush’s Brain,” and the Texas political consultant Jason Stanford in early 2012. The book, to be subtitled “Why Rick Perry Will Make America Miss George W. Bush,” will describe Mr. Perry as an “ideologue with scant interest or success in governing,” according to the publisher’s announcement. Crown, meanwhile, said it would publish “Rick Perry and his Eggheads,” by Sasha Issenberg, as an e-book next week. The e-book, about Mr. Perry’s successful 2006 re-election campaign, is based on Mr. Issenberg’s larger work, “The Victory Lab,” which is expected in the fall of 2012 and is to explore how social science and statistical analysis are changing political campaigning.

headline: Seeing Chicago Through a Theatrical Scrim
text: The Australian theater company One Step At a Time Like This has brought its introspective walking tour to Chicago from Melbourne this summer in “en route,” presented by Chicago Shakespeare Theater.

headline: Recipes for Ice Cream
text: Recipes for dinner-worthy desserts.

headline: Criticism Is Growing Over Shell’s Response to Oil Leak
text: LONDON — Pressure mounted on Royal Dutch Shell to explain how 1,300 barrels of oil could have leaked from a pipeline into the North Sea in a spill that has tarnished Britain’s reputation for avoiding such problems.

headline: Adolescent Health | Sex and Teenage Pregnancy
text: It’s never easy to talk about sex, but we’ve tried to make it as easy as possible with this collection of resources, our second installment in Adolescent Health Week.

headline: Mediterranean Dream Trip Higher-Lights
text: 4:55 p.m. | Updated

headline: ‘See You Soon,’ Yemen’s President Promises Supporters
text: Ali Abdullah Saleh, the embattled president of Yemen, looked remarkably healthy as he stared defiantly into the camera during his third television appearance in less than a week and promised his supporters on Tuesday that he would “see you soon in the capital, Sana.”

headline: In Vietnamese Village, Stitching the Wounds of Human Trafficking
text: HOP TIEN, Vietnam — Rare visitors to Hop Tien often catch a first glimpse of this sleepy village in a blur as they career, white-knuckled, around a hairpin turn high in the mountains above.

headline: Group of Robbers Sought in 3 Bronx Attacks
text: The police are looking for a group of young men who have been robbing and beating people in Fordham Heights in the Bronx. In a surveillance video released on Tuesday, a 64-year-old man is seen holding open the vestibule door at 2100 Creston Avenue on Aug. 8 for a youth who then grabs him by the neck, throws him to the ground and proceeds to beat and kick him with the help of two confederates.

headline: Paula Vogel Will Leave Early as Head of Yale’s Playwriting Program
text: The playwright Paula Vogel is leaving and staying. Ms. Vogel, the chairwoman of the playwriting department at the Yale School of Drama, has decided to step down at the end of the 2011-12 academic year, a year before her five-year term was scheduled to conclude. But she will remain a member of the faculty, which she joined in 2008, and will continue teaching at the school as she works on two projects.

headline: Poll Finds Bloomberg’s Approval Rating the Lowest in 6 Years
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s job approval rating among New Yorkers has hit its lowest point in six years, with residents conveying widespread anxieties about the city’s economic prospects, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: Off the Shelf | ‘The Wanderings of Odysseus’
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#71", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

headline: What’s Behind the Hefty Motorola Breakup Fee
text: Google proved itself willing to pay up for Motorola Mobility, agreeing to buy the cellphone maker for $12.5 billion, a 63.5 percent premium.

headline: Fox Wins Viewers With Food
text: The chef Gordon Ramsay led Fox to a ratings victory on Monday with new episodes of “Hell’s Kitchen” and “MasterChef,” both setting season highs for the night in total viewership, at 6.8 million (“Hell’s Kitchen”) and 6 million (“MasterChef”) viewers. It was Fox’s most-watched Monday with summer programming in more than three years. An absence of competition certainly helped, as “Bachelor Pad” on ABC was the only other show on the broadcast networks not in reruns. It averaged 6.3 million viewers over two hours, dropping 9 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic when compared with last week’s premiere.

headline: A Slow Start For Anderson Cooper At 8 P.M.
text: Anderson Cooper moved into the most important time slot on cable news, 8 p.m., last week. But he didn’t receive a very warm reception from viewers.

headline: The Industry With the Most Steadfast Retirement Savers
text: What is it about utility workers? They apparently are among the country’s most dedicated retirement savers, according to new research from Vanguard.

headline: No Cover for Perry From Bush Team
text: In this hyper-partisan age, there is typically a circle-the-wagons mentality when a politician says something as controversial as Rick Perry did when he called the actions of the chairman of the Federal Reserve “almost treasonous.”

headline: Reviewing Danji
text: Hooni Kim opened Danji, at 346 West 52nd Street, in December.

headline: Feel Free to Graze but Just Be Quick
text: DANJI is a wee little restaurant on West 52nd Street, done up in whitewashed brick and blond Ikea stylings, naked bulbs, extension cords and a lot of wooden spoons artfully displayed, as if by David Rockwell on a $200 budget. The crowds are fierce.

text: Harry Campbell

headline: TimesCast | August 16, 2011
text: Palestinian refugees flee Latakia, Syria during a four-day assault by government forces; France and Germany hold economic talks; and President Obama and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas campaign in Iowa.

headline: Big City Book Club | Coming Soon
text: From “Bartleby, the Scrivener” to “The Bonfire of the Vanities” New York has been a compelling character in American letters. The Big City Book Club aims to generate lively online discussion of works, classic and current, obvious and obscure, fictional and non, in which the city features centrally.

headline: For Fringe Festival Playwright, ‘Porgy’ Brouhaha Has a Familiar Ring
text: Even before Stephen Sondheim weighed in angrily on planned revisions to “Porgy and Bess,” the show, its permutations and how African-Americans are depicted in theater had been on the mind of the playwright Leah Maddrie.

headline: Tighter Qualifications for School Bus Drivers
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed legislation on Tuesday expanding the kinds of criminal convictions that bar people from driving school buses.

headline: Giants Re-Sign Grant for Depth at Safety
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Deon Grant lost a couple of things in his brief time away from the Giants. He lost his uniform number, which has been worn by the rookie safety Jarrard Tarrant for the first three weeks of camp. He lost his portable stereo, which he donated to charity at the end of last season.

headline: Ron Paul Rolls Out New Campaign Ad
text: Ron Paul’s supporters might be frustrated by the lack of news media coverage for his presidential campaign, but at least he can keep up with the competition in the world of paid media.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Somalia, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Yemen.

headline: Accounting Board to Seek Comments on Rotating Auditors
text: WASHINGTON — An accounting oversight board agreed on Tuesday to seek public comment on whether companies should be required to change their auditors every few years, a move that supporters say they believe would strengthen the independence and objectivity of accountants that inspect corporate ledgers for accuracy.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Somalia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Somalia, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Libya.

headline: Wheelies: The Sinking-Feeling Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: More Surgeries for James Levine
text: James Levine, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director, has received two previously undisclosed back operations since the spring, when he canceled a Met tour to Japan and his schedule at the Tanglewood Music Festival, his brother said on Tuesday. But now, without the excruciating pain that has plagued him over the last several years because of back problems, Mr. Levine is planning to begin rehearsing at the Met right after Labor Day and has not canceled any performances, said his brother, Tom Levine. “The surgeries have done what they’re supposed to do,” he added.

headline: In Vietnam, Healing a Village Wounded by Trafficking
text: A textile cooperative started for women rescued from the sex trade is thriving, lifting a small Vietnamese village near the border with China.

headline: Bank of America in Talks With Blackstone Over Merrill Real Estate
text: Bank of America is in talks to sell a major portion of Merrill Lynch‘s real estate portfolio to the Blackstone Group for up to $1 billion, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday, as the bank seeks to raise additional capital.

headline: A 17-Year-Old Beanstalk From a Wholesome ’70s Family Is Eager to Go Far Out
text: “The Talls,” by Anna Kerrigan, is the rare play about an American family in reasonable working order. True, mother is a little remote, and preoccupied with her best-friendship with a Roman Catholic nun. Perhaps father is distracted from the kids’ big games by his forthcoming campaign for comptroller of the city of Oakland, Calif. Still, by the standards of American drama of the last half-century, the Clarke family is positively wholesome, almost ready for a prime-time sitcom of the 1960s.

headline: Pete Pihos, Eagles Hall of Fame Receiver, Dies at 87
text: Pete Pihos could do just about anything on a football field. A member of both the College and Pro Football Halls of Fame, he was an outstanding pass-catcher, a powerful runner and a formidable blocker, helping to take the Philadelphia Eagles to two consecutive National Football League championships in the 1940s.

headline: A Camera Bag That Actually Looks Good
text: Camera bags usually get short shrift when it comes to design and fashion-forward thinking. While laptop bags often look like little purses complete with fancy buckles and handsome materials, most camera bags are one step up from a fanny pack in styling.

headline: BBC Radio 1 Returns (Sort of) to Satellite Radio
text: Less than a week after it replaced BBC Radio 1 with a channel devoted to the disco hits of the Studio 54 era, Sirius XM, the satellite radio broadcaster, announced that the British music channel will return to its regular lineup — but only online.

headline: Critic’s Notebook: Next, in Chicago
text: Now appearing: a restaurant in footlights.

text: CHICAGO

headline: Dell Posts Flat Sales but Its Profit Rises 63%
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Dell’s sales flattened in its latest quarter as government spending declined and the company pared low-margin sales, but its net income rose 63 percent.

headline: TimesCast | Leaders Meet About Euro Zone
text: As weak economic data hit Europe's two largest economies, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany announced proposals aimed at stabilizing the euro zone.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: A Magician Pulling Strings to Prove a Point: Love Stinks
text: Handel’s opera “Orlando” has had a peculiar life. It was little more than a footnote in Handel’s day. He composed it in 1732, to an anonymous libretto based on Ariosto’s “Orlando Furioso.” He performed it only 10 times in 1733, then dropped it entirely, never bothering to revive it. It languished until the 20th century, when conductors (mostly of the period-instrument persuasion) began to nudge it into the repertory alongside “Alcina” and “Ariodante,” Handel’s two other works based on Ariosto.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Starting Them Young

headline: The Cannibal Next Door? No Reason to Be Afraid
text: The owners of Resto, a Belgian-accented restaurant known for its whole-animal feasts and nose-to-tail specialties, needed more space for butchering. An adjacent storefront was just the ticket. By day, starting Friday, they will sell terrines and fresh sausages made by the chef, Michael Berardino, above, as well as sandwiches, ground beef from Pat LaFreida and other cuts of fresh meat. In the evening it will turn into a restaurant with small plates and whole animal feasts using pigs, lambs or goats. They have some 350 beers to quaff with food or to take out. The Cannibal was the nickname of a Belgian cyclist, Eddy Merckx, so the owners, Christian Pappanicholas and Bobby Hellen, will sell bicycling gear along with blood sausage.

headline: Dear Leader, I’ve Made a Friend in the South
text: What Chekhov said about the gun on the wall also applies to the cute white puppy in the street in Park Jungbum’s “Journals of Musan,” winner of the best new narrative director award at the Tribeca Film Festival this year. When we see it introduced early on as the only real friend of the miserable North Korean defector Seung-chul (played by Mr. Park), we can be pretty sure that it will be used to manipulate our emotions cruelly before the film is over.

headline: Choose a Tiramisù or Construct Your Own
text: Nadia Tade, a tiramisù enthusiast from Italy, and her partner, Alessandro Radici, who is in the graduate business school at Columbia, hope to make tiramisù the next gelato. With Dolce Vizio Tiramisù, which opened on Saturday, they have tapped into what appears to be a growing trend in Italy: variations on tiramisù, the traditional Venetian dessert made with a type of ladyfinger layered with a mascarpone custard and flavored with espresso and cocoa. “A tiramisù shop opened in Milan three weeks ago,” Ms. Tade said. “They beat us to it, but not by much.” Their airy shop sells tiramisù in six flavors, including lemon, berries and chocolate, with the option to assemble your own. Fabrizio Ferrari, a Michelin-starred chef from Bergamo, was in New York helping to fine-tune the recipes. Portions are sold to eat at tables, with a cup of espresso perhaps, or to take away in plastic containers.

headline: A Wild Maine Blueberry Unlike Its Cousins
text: Small, dark, tangy wild blueberries from Maine, below left, seem to bear little relation to the typically fleshy cultivated berries, right. They are terrific in pancakes, muffins and scones. Lynn Thurston, who is a kind of blueberry broker, gets berries that farmers gather from wild bushes on their land and distributes them in the Northeast through her company, Blue Sky Produce. “It gives the farmers an alternative to selling them for the frozen market,” she said. Dry pint containers hold about two and a half cups. “That’s anywhere from 800 to 1,200 berries,” she said. “I know because I once counted them.”

headline: Champagne by the Case
text: The bubbly flowed, the diamonds too. For one good-time girl in ’70s L.A., it seemed as if the party would never end. Adapted from “Loose Diamonds … and Other Things I’ve Lost (and Found) Along the Way,” to be published by William Morrow in September. Some names have been changed.

headline: Illustrious Local Compatriot Contributes to a Troupe’s New York Visit
text: The dancers of Cisne Negro, the Brazilian company appearing this week at the Joyce Theater, are so glowingly amiable, youthful, attractive, enthusiastic and musical that you wish the program’s choreography made them look better. The three pieces they are presenting here this week, however, tend to show their limitations, obscure their virtues and saddle them with clichés. At the end of each dance you don’t feel inclined to applaud much. Since these performers merit affection and deserve encouragement, it’s a frustrating experience.

headline: Excerpt: 'Olive and the Bitter Herbs'
text: From left, Dan Butler, Richard Masur and Marcia Jean Kurtz in a scene from Charles Busch's new play "Olive and the Bitter Herbs," at 59E59 Theaters. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: A Peek at Apple’s Plans for Grand Central Store
text: After putting up considerable resistance, Apple executives finally let the Metropolitan Transportation Authority release renderings Tuesday of the Apple store planned for Grand Central.

headline: A Village Person Tests the Copyright Law
text: The prefab, gaudily costumed 1970s group the Village People and its big hit “Y.M.C.A.” are enduring symbols of the disco era. But now this campy and eternally popular song has become the centerpiece of what could be a significant test of copyright law.

headline: A Diner’s Magic in a Vanishing Act
text: M. WELLS, the celebrated little diner in Long Island City, Queens, that opened last summer and announced at the start of August that it would close at month’s end, has been throwing farewell dinners on Friday and Saturday nights. The first was an evening devoted to the fruits of the Fulton Fish Market in the Bronx. There was another devoted to the joys of melted cheese. On Saturday night, the theme was caviar and magic. Seats ran $200 a head.

headline: A Victory in Court for the Author of ‘The Help’
text: It’s been a pretty good few days for Kathryn Stockett. The movie version of her mega-best-selling book, “The Help,” did well at the weekend box office and on Tuesday a lawsuit alleging that she had based a character in the book on a real person without permission was thrown out by a Mississippi judge.

headline: Williams Reaffirms $5.5 Billion Bid for Southern Union
text: For those who thought that the Williams Companies had walked away from the fight for the Southern Union company, think again.

headline: TimesCast | Refugees Attacked in Syria
text: August 16, 2011 - As Syria continues suppressing anti-government protests, a Palestinian refugee camp is caught in the crossfire.
