headline: Untitled
text: Untitled is the restaurateur Danny Meyer’s second foray into the art world.

headline: A Unified Berlin
text: To the Editor:

headline: Despite the Odds, a Jazz Label Finds a Way to Thrive
text: Steve Coleman and Five Elements were deep into one of their horizonless, hypnotic inventions at the Newport Jazz Festival this month, and the tent-sheltered crowd seemed duly absorbed. Mr. Coleman’s alto saxophone slashed through the air, often in off-kilter counterpoint with the vocalist Jen Shyu. The shifting rhythmic base was punctuated by the drummer Tyshawn Sorey, who called to mind an octopus, limbs moving in steady flow. It was all a vivid barometer reading from Mr. Coleman’s pressure system and, by extension, a reflection on Pi Recordings, his current label home.

headline: Children of Poverty
text: To the Editor:

headline: Silence, Please, for the Electric Camaro Drag Racer
text: Huge clouds of smoke rolled off the giant slicks of Ron Adamowicz’s 1981 Chevrolet Camaro as he prepared for a quarter-mile attempt earlier this month at New York’s Lebanon Valley Dragway. Nearby fans, aware of the powerful roar that accompanies the burnout ritual, raised hands to ears. That proved unnecessary, as the only sound to be heard was generated in the paddock by gassers awaiting their turn. On the track, all was silent but for the the hum of electric motors and spinning wheels.

headline: Cancer Drug Shortages: 2 Senators’ View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bachmann’s Elvis Tribute, Slightly Off
text: Before making her pitch for the Republican presidential nomination in Spartanburg, S.C., on Tuesday Representative Michele Bachmann paused to show some respect.

headline: Children With Autism
text: To the Editor:

headline: Charles P. Murray Jr., Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 89
text: Charles P. Murray Jr., who received the Medal of Honor for single-handedly preventing 200 German soldiers from attacking an American battalion while leading a scouting mission in France during World War II, died Aug. 12 at his home in Columbia, S.C. He was 89.

headline: The New York Times/CBS News Poll, August 2011
text: The results of a poll conducted in August, 2011.

headline: A Befuddling Sound, but Danceable Nonetheless
text: In what was his first live performance, Clams Casino was hunched over a minimal setup: an iPad connected to what appeared to be an iPhone with a cracked face. He didn’t look up much, if at all, maybe because he didn’t know what to make of the scene in front of him: the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, on a Saturday afternoon, teeming with people trying to make sense of the music he was playing, figuring out what it was supposed to do to their bodies.

headline: Panoramas: Expanding the Shortcut Between the Seas
text: In the first expansion in the 100-year history of the Panama Canal, crews are starting to build a new set of locks that will handle much larger ships.

headline: M.L.S. Tweaks Designated Player Rule
text: Major League Soccer on Tuesday announced a change to its designated player rule that is intended to entice its clubs to spend money on younger players with the potential to turn into international stars — instead of on aging players who have their best years behind them, as many currently do.

headline: Dinner and a Show
text: A seat at the chef’s-table at Aldea offers a front-row seat for the frenzied drama of high-end food preparation.

headline: Bits Pics: Anonymous Protests in San Francisco
text: More than a dozen masked members of the hacker group Anonymous disrupted service on the Bay Area Rapid Transit system on Monday to protest the killing of a 45-year-old man by police officers last month.

headline: Cigarette Companies File 2nd Suit Over Warnings
text: Five tobacco companies filed a lawsuit in federal court in Washington late Tuesday challenging the constitutionality of regulations and graphic warning labels under the 2009 law that imposed federal regulation on tobacco.

headline: Testimony Challenged in the Phone Hacking Scandal
text: Documents released recently appeared to contradict News Corporation executives’ statements in July and previous claims about the phone hacking at The News of the World. On Tuesday, a letter written in 2007 by a former reporter, Clive Goodman, challenging his dismissal was released, with redactions, by lawmakers.

headline: How the Bloomberg Poll Was Conducted
text: The New York Times/CBS News poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 9 through Aug. 15 in New York City with 1,027 adults. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.

headline: Mitt Romney, Political Surfer
text: BERLIN, N.H. — So, just what did Mitt Romney learn while he was running for president four years ago?

headline: Manchester United Nears Stock Sale on Asian Exchange
text: Manchester United, the English Premier League soccer power that is already the most valuable sports team in the world, is preparing to sell shares on the Singapore stock exchange that could raise about $1 billion, according to a person familiar with the plan who declined to be identified before the details of the sale were made public.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,723 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: Dr. Phil Lands Interview With Anthony Grandparents
text: The daytime television host Dr. Phil McGraw will conduct the first interview with Cindy and George Anthony since their daughter Casey was acquitted of killing her daughter Caylee, CBS said Tuesday.

headline: Jets’ Backup Plan on Offensive Line Needs a Backup
text: Jets Coach Rex Ryan has spoken throughout training camp about the importance of roster depth. After one preseason game, however, the depth of the offensive line could suddenly be a concern.

headline: Conflict Exacerbates Drought and Famine
text: Nearly 1 million Somalis have fled the country, while about 3.2 million of those who remain need immediate help, 2.8 million in the south.

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Voracious Outsider Grabs a Toehold, and That Means War
text: Like many of their old-timey contemporaries, the residents of Whiskeytown, a Gold Rush garrison in the mountains of Northern California, were a bit skeptical of outsiders. Filled with prospectors and the entrepreneurs who mined them, Whiskeytown had folks who looked after one another, but also looked long and hard at anyone intruding on their claims or their community.

headline: Yemen’s Leader Vows to Return Soon and Defies Calls for His Ouster
text: Ali Abdullah Saleh, the embattled president of Yemen, promised his supporters on Tuesday that he would “see you soon in the capital, Sana,” in his third television appearance in less than a week.

headline: More Unwed Parents Live Together, Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON — The number of Americans who have children and live together without marrying has increased twelvefold since 1970, according to a report released Tuesday. The report states that children now are more likely to have unmarried parents than divorced ones.

headline: Panama Adding a Wider Shortcut for Shipping
text: COCOLÍ, Panama — For now, the future of global shipping is little more than a hole in the ground here, just a short distance from the Pacific Ocean.

headline: There’s a Doctor in the Paddock
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Dr. Gerald Bortolazzo, or Doc, as he is known, has some story to tell about a horse, his new career as a horseman and how he, if he did not exactly cheat death, fooled it but good.

headline: Musing on the Prospects of a Microsoft Counterbid for Motorola
text: Ted S. Warren/Associated PressA Windows Phone 7 at a Microsoft store.

headline: A Battered Paterno Sees No Reason to Relax
text: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — Penn State Coach Joe Paterno was on campus Tuesday, after a blindside hit on Aug. 7 sent him to the hospital, and said he planned to be back on the sideline when the Nittany Lions open their season Sept. 3 against Indiana State.

headline: Romney View of Perry: Just Another Opponent
text: LITTLETON, N.H. — Gov. Rick Perry has plans to eat his way through Mitt Romney’s New Hampshire backyard this week — a politics and eggs breakfast in Bedford on Wednesday, a coffee meet-and-greet in Portsmouth and a lunch in Dover on Thursday, as well as two tours of local businesses. Yet to watch Mr. Romney, who on the campaign trail brushed off several opportunities to directly challenge Mr. Perry, the Texas governor could not be further from his mind.

headline: Attacks in Iraq Heighten Political Tensions
text: BAGHDAD — One day after insurgents unleashed the most lethal series of attacks in Iraq this year, political tensions flared as Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki appointed a member of his governing coalition as acting defense minister.

headline: Facing the Loss of a Little Building, Much More Than a Place for Stamps
text: NORTH HOOSICK, N.Y. — In the center of this hamlet sits a tiny building the color of the sky. It is a blue so bright and so rich, it seems more suited to a Caribbean beach bungalow than to the rural hills of upstate New York.

headline: BlackBerry Maker RIM Again Subject of Takeover Talk
text: OTTAWA — Ever since the introduction of its first BlackBerry more than a decade ago, Research in Motion has defied expectations that it would be gobbled up by a larger rival and has effectively created the market for smartphones.

headline: White Picket Fence? Not So Fast
text: THE United States spends more than $100 billion annually to subsidize homeowners. Renters get no breaks; homeowners get tons of them. Their mortgage rates are subsidized through the government-sponsored enterprises Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac; they get a big deduction on federal income taxes for mortgage interest payments and for state and local property taxes; and they even get favored treatment on capital gains from the sales of primary residences.

headline: H.P.-Palm Deal Looks Better With Time
text: Hewlett-Packard’s $1.2 billion acquisition of Palm last year suddenly looks smarter. Google’s $12.5 billion deal to buy Motorola Mobility this week, and the earlier frenzied bidding for Nortel’s patents, have revealed the riches in mobile computing intellectual property. And H.P. snatched one of the most important troves for a price that now looks cheap. Yet, it could be challenging for H.P. to cash in.

headline: Phillies’ Latest Ex-Astro Adds Big Bat to Winning Lineup
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: Gundlach Says 2009 Firing Had Roots In 2001
text: The bond fund manager Jeffrey E. Gundlach’s clash with his former employer, Trust Company of the West, began as early as 2001 and intensified in the months leading up to his firing, he testified on Tuesday.

headline: Perry Links Federal Reserve Policies and Treason
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry did not back down on Tuesday, but he did not repeat his suggestion that the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve were potentially “treasonous” and could warrant “ugly” treatment should the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, ever pay a visit to Texas.

headline: Making Low-Interest Auto Loans Work
text: A followup, with reader comments, to a column on affordable car loans.

headline: Player’s Death Follows Bouts of Depression
text: Rick Rypien, the scrappy 27-year-old Winnipeg Jets forward who was found dead Monday, was considered perhaps the best pound-for-pound fighter in the N.H.L. But for more than a decade he battled depression, a disorder that caused him to take two leaves of absence from the Vancouver Canucks.

headline: Before Voting, Russian Leaders Go to the Polls
text: MOSCOW — Every Thursday, a bearded, bespectacled man arrives at the Kremlin bearing a sheaf of data for Vladislav Y. Surkov, the government’s chief ideologist. There, a roomful of decision makers are gathered to hear the latest installment of What Russia Thinks.

headline: Crashing the Tea Party
text: GIVEN how much sway the Tea Party has among Republicans in Congress and those seeking the Republican presidential nomination, one might think the Tea Party is redefining mainstream American politics.

headline: A Farm Around the Corner
text: It is sweet corn and ripe tomato season, a time for freshly picked garlic, luminous carrots, crisp cucumbers and (as far as we’re concerned too much) zucchini.

headline: Madoff Decision Is Significant Setback for Owners of Mets
text: From the moment they were sued last year for $1 billion by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud, the owners of the Mets have fought every aspect of the enormous claim.

headline: Swiss Banks, Aiding and Abetting
text: Despite all of the I.R.S.’s efforts, wealthy American tax cheats are still able to hide their money because Swiss banks are still eager to help them.

headline: Serena Williams Adds Fitness to Her Game, and Wins Keep Coming
text: MASON, Ohio — The only upset in Serena Williams’s first-round match on Tuesday against Lucie Hradecka was registered in the stands, well above the court, when one female fan turned to another and said, “Serena’s legs look skinny.”

headline: Field of Dashed Dreams
text: PEOSTA, Iowa

headline: A Summer of Italy, Music and Pasta
text: WHEN Barilla, the pasta company formed in Italy in 1877, was first nationally advertised in the United States in 1996, it turned out to be less an introduction than an invasion. In just three years, Barilla bested familiar brands like Ronzoni and Mueller’s to become the top-selling dry pasta in the country. Even when the pasta category contracted at the height of the low-carbohydrate diet craze from 2002 to 2004, Barilla continued to boil over with year-over-year gains.

headline: In Albany, a Labor Pact Without Attacks on Unions
text: ALBANY — A day after the state’s largest public-workers union agreed to accept wage and benefits concessions, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and labor leaders said the vote demonstrated that fiscally troubled states could cut work-force costs without attacking collective bargaining.

headline: Midwest States Where Obama Faces New Challenges
text: A rattled economy and Republican gains in the House have changed the economic and political landscape of the Midwestern states that helped propel President Obama’s campaign in the 2008 election.

headline: Since Milestone Hit, Jeter Has Taken Off
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Derek Jeter’s teammates were not surprised at all to see him collect three hits and knock in three runs on Monday. Watching Jeter take command of the game with a couple of clutch hits, including a rocket to the right-center-field gap for a two-run triple, looked very familiar to them.

headline: Suffolk Seeks ‘Safety Zone’ Barring Gang Members
text: WYANDANCH, N.Y. — Fed up with unrelenting violence by two factions of the Bloods gang, Suffolk County officials have embraced a novel legal strategy that, if approved by a judge, would bar specific gang members from a two-square-mile “safety zone.”

headline: Quest for Patents Brings New Focus in Tech Deals
text: Wall Street bankers and technology executives have been busy with their calculators in the wake of Google’s $12.5 billion offer for Motorola Mobililty.

headline: Meteorologists Who Offer Not Forecasts but Testimony
text: After the last of the record-setting rain had fallen in the New York area, those in the business of delivering weather forecasts on television got back to their normal routines, calling for mostly sunny days or the like.

headline: Hurricane Players and Recruits Accused of N.C.A.A. Violations
text: At a time when the ideal of amateurism in college athletics appears shakier than ever, Yahoo Sports reported Tuesday that University of Miami players and recruits received thousands of benefits in violation of N.C.A.A. rules from a booster from 2002 through 2010.

headline: New Farmers Find Their Footing
text: North Haven, Me.

text: A funeral in Benghazi, and rebel forces face sniper fire in Zawiyah.

headline: Obama and Perry Tour Iowa
text: President Obama and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas campaigned simultaneously in the state.

headline: His Anger Is a Start
text: Faced with a divided Congress and an economy in desperate straits, President Obama tried bargaining with Republicans, he tried adopting some of their ideas and he pleaded with them for reasonable policies to help stave off disaster. For his efforts, he got nothing but a cold shoulder and the country got a credit downgrade.

headline: Highway Fight Widens Gulf Between State and Seneca Nation
text: IRVING, N.Y. — The westernmost spur of the New York State Thruway is a lonely four-lane road, lined by leafy sugar maple trees and little else.

headline: Obama Presses His Case in Crucial Iowa, but Perry Is Close on His Heels
text: PEOSTA, Iowa — President Obama pulled up to a bucolic community college here in his $1.1 million black armored bus on Tuesday and spent much of the day closeted in a conference with farmers and small-business owners, hoping to sell them on his message that he could revive the listless job market.

headline: A Bull Market in Tech Patents
text: Google was willing on Monday to pay $12.5 billion for Motorola Mobility in no small part because of its stockpile of 17,000 patents. The patent portfolio, some analysts estimate, could represent more than half of the value of the deal, or more than $400,000 a patent.

headline: Giants Sign Lloyd as Kicker Insurance
text: With Lawrence Tynes sidelined because of a bruised thigh, the Giants signed kicker Rhys Lloyd on Tuesday.

headline: 3 Charged in Plot to Aid Smuggling
text: Three people, including a Manhattan lawyer, have been charged with helping to smuggle hundreds of illegal immigrants into the country, the United States attorney in Manhattan said on Tuesday.

headline: Fight for a Jobs Agenda
text: Come September, President Obama’s aides say he will roll out more programs to put Americans back to work. What we are hearing so far doesn’t go nearly far enough.

headline: TimesCast | Obama Tours Midwest
text: August 16, 2011 - On his bus tour through the Midwest, President Obama visits must-win states for re-election next year.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Wednesday: Have a Hearty Laugh
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Hindsight is always 20/20, they say, and while it took me a while to understand where Michael Black was going with this tricky-for-a-Wednesday theme, I have to say that my post-solving reaction was along the lines of, “Of course. Why didn’t I see that going in?”

headline: Co-Op’s Old Crank Finds a Fresh Spirit
text: To live is to kvetch, to kvetch to live, for the cranky title character in “Olive and the Bitter Herbs,” the acidly funny but decidedly ramshackle new play by Charles Busch that opened on Tuesday night at the 59E59 Theaters in a Primary Stages production.

headline: Amazon Set to Publish Pop Author
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon moved aggressively Tuesday to fulfill its new ambition to publish books as well as sell them, announcing that it had signed Timothy Ferriss, the wildly popular self-help guru for young men.

headline: Ambitious Plans for a Building Where Sears Served Atlanta
text: ATLANTA — As large as 20 Wal-Mart stores, the cavernous former Sears building now known as City Hall East towers above a motley assortment of restaurants, underground dance halls and a strip club a few miles northeast of downtown. The building, which at 2.1 million square feet is the largest brick structure in the South, according to its owners, has been mostly vacant since Sears left in 1989.

headline: A Suburban Town Sees Housing Where Retail Rules
text: MORRISTOWN, N.J. — Jordan Eppolito has taken a liking to his new home here in the Morris County seat, about 30 miles west of New York City. Mr. Eppolito, a 28-year-old entrepreneur who plans to open a pizza shop this fall on South Street, lives in a new condominium overlooking the Morristown Green, the historic park at the center of town.

headline: Ralph Albertazzie, Nixon’s Pilot, Dies at 88
text: Ralph D. Albertazzie, the pilot of Air Force One during the Nixon administration, who flew  the president on a historic trip to China and flew the Nixon family home to California after his resignation, died on Monday at his home in Falling Waters, W.Va. He was 88.

headline: Disney Fires Three Over Resort Fees Fiasco
text: LOS ANGELES – The Walt Disney Company’s new resort in Hawaii, built at an estimated cost of $850 million, is off to a slower-than-expected start as a result of bungled time-share fees.

headline: Facing Flurry of Lawsuits, a Governor Loses a Round
text: MIAMI — Gov. Rick Scott, a Republican conservative, took office this year on a promise to shake things up. That he did, and now the aggrieved — teachers, prison workers, food stamp recipients, doctors — are plastering him with lawsuits.

headline: For Mets, Different Approach Pays Off
text: SAN DIEGO — After the Mets revamped their front office last fall, their approach to Major League Baseball’s draft this summer became one of the most discussed issues among the new general manager Sandy Alderson’s staff.

headline: Federal Policy Resulting in Wave of Deportations Draws Protests
text: A program that is central to President Obama’s immigration enforcement strategy has drawn protests by Latino and immigrant organizations in six cities in the last two days, as those groups stepped up their confrontation with the administration over the fast pace of deportations.

headline: Pledge for Euro Unity May Not Be Enough to Satisfy Markets
text: PARIS — The leaders of France and Germany on Tuesday promised to take concrete steps toward a closer political and economic union of the 17 countries that use the euro, but it was unclear whether their proposals would be sufficient, or come quickly enough, to satisfy markets anxious over Europe’s debts and listless economies.

headline: Rodriguez Could Rejoin Yankees on Thursday
text: MOOSIC, Pa. — In his gradual climb back to the major leagues after arthroscopic surgery to repair a torn meniscus in his right knee, Alex Rodriguez played six innings at third base for the Scranton/Wilkes-Barre Yankees of the International League on Tuesday night in a 2-0 loss to the Durham Bulls.

headline: Isringhausen’s Milestone Augurs Changes in the Mets’ Bullpen
text: SAN DIEGO — Mets Manager Terry Collins said Tuesday afternoon that he would begin experimenting with different combinations of relievers out of his bullpen, now that Jason Isringhausen has his 300th save.

headline: On Economy, Raw Data Gets a Grain of Salt
text: WASHINGTON — When the government announced in April that the economy had grown at a moderate annual pace of 1.8 percent in the first quarter, politicians and investors saw evidence that the nation was continuing its recovery from the depths of the financial crisis. The White House called the news “encouraging” and the stock market extended its bull run.

headline: Schools Restore Fresh Cooking to the Cafeteria
text: GREELEY, Colo. — The idea of making school lunches better and healthier has gathered steam in many parts of the nation in recent years, but not equally for every child. Schools with money and involved parents concerned about obesity and nutrition charged ahead, while poor and struggling districts, overwhelmed by hard times, mostly did not.

headline: China: Railroad Spokesman Fired
text: The Railways Ministry said Tuesday that it had dismissed its spokesman, Wang Yongping, making him the fourth ministry official to be fired since a high-speed train collision on July 23 near Wenzhou killed 40 people and injured 191. Mr. Wang’s performance in answering the news media’s questions about the crash had made him a target of public ridicule. Asked why workers had buried a train car at the site before an inquiry had begun, he said the wreckage had to be cleared for rescuers. “Whether you believe it or not, I believe it anyway,” he said.

headline: France: Lagarde Inquiry Opens
text: A court formally opened an investigation on Tuesday into charges that Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, abused her power as France’s finance minister in 2007 when she intervened in a legal conflict in which a prominent businessman was awarded hundreds of millions of dollars in state funds. Earlier, a court had thrown out the case brought by the businessman, Bernard Tapie, a friend of President Nicolas Sarkozy and himself a former minister, who accused a state-owned bank of defrauding him in a 1993 transaction. Ms. Lagarde ordered the case sent to an arbitration panel, which awarded Mr. Tapie a settlement of about $580 million.

headline: Corrections: August 17
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: New Limits on Bus Drivers for Schools
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed legislation on Tuesday expanding the kinds of criminal convictions that bar people from driving school buses.

headline: 2 Wisconsin Democrats Re-elected
text: Two Democrats kept their seats in the Wisconsin State Senate on Tuesday, drawing an end to an unprecedented series of recall elections that had distracted the state all summer.

headline: Detective Stole Cash and Cigarettes, Complaint Charges
text: Late last month, a longtime Bronx detective showed up at a home in Fordham Heights around midnight, wearing a New York Police Department jacket and flashing a badge and a piece of paper he said was a search warrant, according to a criminal complaint.

headline: Judge Rejects Groups’ Effort to Remove Bike Lane
text: A judge on Tuesday dismissed an effort by Brooklyn residents to remove a hotly contested bicycle lane installed by the city on Prospect Park West, in one of the most closely watched controversies over a signature policy of the Bloomberg administration.

headline: Yanks Pile Up Runs to Make Up for the Ones Nova Allows
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — All the fuss and concern over the Yankees’ six-man rotation, and who should eventually be lopped from it, have recently been rendered moot by two developments: a small cut on Freddy Garcia’s finger, and the large abrasions the Yankees’ hitters are inflicting on baseballs these days.

text: NYT: Front Page for 08/17/2011

headline: Are Crunches Worth the Effort?
text: For a study published this year, researchers at Indiana State University had a group of healthy, young adults squat, lunge, twist, crunch and hold a rigid plank position to measure the hardiness of their back, abdominal and side muscles, the area generally known as the core. The same volunteers then completed a battery of physical performance tests, including leaping off the ground while tossing a medicine ball backward over the head and sprinting through a short obstacle course.

headline: Remembering Horton Foote
text: A look at the career of the playwright and screenwriter, who died at age 92.

headline: Mets Succumb Meekly to Padres Rookie
text: SAN DIEGO — One of Terry Collins’s main objectives, as he endeavors to extract a dose of meaning from the remainder of the Mets’ season, will be to figure out if there is a pitcher somewhere in his bullpen with the mettle to be a major league closer.

headline: Should Rich People Have to Pay More Taxes?
text: Warren E. Buffett, an investor who is one of the wealthiest people in the world, wrote an Op-Ed article in The Times this week arguing that the “super-rich” should be required to contribute more to the United States economy in the form of taxes, and says that most wealthy people wouldn’t mind doing so. Do you agree or disagree?

headline: SABMiller Goes Hostile in Pursuit of Foster’s
text: 9:46 p.m. | Updated SABMiller, one of the world’s largest brewers, said on Wednesday that it would take its $10 billion bid for rival Foster’s Group directly to shareholders, two months after the board of the Australian beer maker rebuffed an initial offer.

text: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He starts his look at the A.F.C. South with the Jaguars.

headline: Exceptions to Keynesian Theory
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Throw Couplets at Bill
text: A happy consequence of Bill Keller’s latest column, which suggested that the logjammers in Washington start reading more poetry, is that people have been filling his inbox with reading suggestions. Some, like this one from R. Ford Reid, have directly addressed his political points:

headline: Cooling Off the Berlin Summer With Artisanal Ice Cream
text: When it came to creative ice cream options, there was a time when Germans might have had to settle for spaghetti-eis, thin strands of vanilla ice cream smothered in a (supposedly) fruit-based syrup. But Berliners’ palates have become more demanding, prompting many high-quality ice cream parlors to open around the city. For the traveler, this means that Berlin now offers some great new ways to cool off with cone or cup.

headline: Deal Would Free Indian Activist and Allow Protests
text: NEW DELHI — The protest leader Anna Hazare appeared to strike a deal with the police early Thursday morning that would enable him to leave a local jail and begin staging a hunger strike against corruption later in the day, according to a close aide and reports in the Indian news media.

headline: A Bad Night in August
text: “Thursday, Aug. 4, 2011. Remember this date, boss. Go home and drink a bottle of wine and circle this day on your calendar. You won’t see another one like it.”

headline: A Tribute to Ads That Made an Impression and Then Wouldn’t Leave
text: Remember the frothing pitchman for the now-defunct Crazy Eddie chain of electronics stores who screamed in television commercials that were inescapable in the 1970s and 1980s about prices that were insaaaaaane?

headline: Indictment in Hariri Assassination Is Published
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the assassination of a former Lebanese prime minister in 2005 released the full indictment on Wednesday against members of Hezbollah named in the killing, a move that could deepen tensions in a country polarized by the repercussions of the investigation.

headline: Do You Suffer From Decision Fatigue?
text: Editor’s note: As you navigate a world of choices, revisit this 2011 magazine story on the paralyzing effects of decision fatigue.

headline: Dinner Theater, Starring the Kitchen
text: When people say that a restaurant provides an evening of good theater, they are almost always referring to the high quotient of air kissing among a clientele with a high media profile. The people in the banquettes, not the dishes on the plates, are really the show at places like the Waverly Inn and the Monkey Bar and the Minetta Tavern.

headline: What Would Hillary Clinton Have Done?
text: In the worst of the Democratic primary campaign in 2008, the angry end of the thing, when I had become a devoted Hillary Clinton supporter and was engaged in bitter arguments with people with whom I often agreed, I used to harbor a secret fear, the twin of my political hope: I worried that Hillary Clinton would win her party’s nomination.

headline: Getting Noticed at the Fringe: ‘Fourteen Flights’
text: It can be tough to stand out among the almost 200 shows in this year’s New York International Fringe Festival, which runs through Aug. 28. (Ending the title of your show with the words “The Musical!” is so 10 years ago.) One way to stop passers-by in their tracks is to design eye-catching artwork — to be used online and in print — that says “Look at me. Come see the show. If it’s not good, keep me as a bookmark.”

headline: Pulse Points
text: NYTD.hotSpotsFactory.createMap("map2", 592, 750, false, chameleonData);

headline: Manchester United Plans to Raise $1 Billion
text: Manchester United, the Premier League power that is already the most valuable sports team in the world, is preparing to sell shares on the Singapore stock exchange that could raise about $1 billion. The deal would allow the Glazer family, which owns the team, to reduce the club’s debt and presumably free up more money for Alex Ferguson (and his successor, if he ever quits) to spend. Read Ken Belson’s article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Photo Turns U.S. Envoy Into a Lesson for Chinese
text: BEIJING — The word on the street these days, whether in Washington or Beijing, is that the United States is on the decline and China is on the ascent. But it has taken nothing more than a cup of coffee and a backpack to show that American officials can still evoke awe, respect and envy among Chinese, even if unwittingly.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Are Abdominal Crunches Worth It?
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Pledge of Euro Unity May Not Be Enough to Satisfy Markets
text: PARIS — The leaders of France and Germany on Tuesday promised to take concrete steps toward a closer political and economic union of the 17 countries that use the euro, but it was unclear whether their proposals would be sufficient, or come quickly enough, to satisfy markets anxious over Europe’s debts and listless economies.

headline: Wholesale Costs Increased More Than Expected in July
text: Wholesale costs in the United States rose more than forecast in July, led by higher prices for tobacco, trucks and pharmaceuticals, the Labor Department said Wednesday.

headline: Remembering Pete Pihos, Pioneering Tight End
text: A few thoughts about Pete Pihos, one of pro football’s first great pass-catching tight ends. After a long battle with Alzheimer’s disease, Pihos died Tuesday in a nursing home in Winston-Salem, N.C., at age 87.

headline: Morning Buzz
text: For more local news from The Times, including disappointing poll numbers for the mayor, a dispute between New York State and the Seneca Nation of Indians and a new approach to curbing gang violence in Suffolk County, see the N.Y./Region Section.

headline: Stocks Close Flat as Investors Parse Quarterly Results
text: The stock market wavered on Wednesday and ended mixed, weighed down by corporate results related to the technology and consumer sectors.

headline: Say Käse!
text: If you think Polaroid cameras are old school (and expensive), try the Imago 1:1.

headline: ‘Ground Force One,’ a Custom-Made Ride
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa – As President Obama sets off on the last day of his three-day road trip across the Midwest, his high-tech, black, armored bus has become a familiar presence on the highways and byways here – or at least, a less ominous presence than when it first pulled up next to Air Force One in Minneapolis.

headline: New York Moves to Crack Down on Abuse of Disabled
text: Moving to end the state’s lax oversight of the developmentally disabled, the Cuomo administration on Wednesday announced an agreement with the State Police to establish guidelines for reporting possible crimes against the disabled to law enforcement authorities.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Pondering Perry’s Electability
text: The speech by Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to announce his presidential candidacy on Saturday got generally favorable reviews, but it did not take long for some influential Republicans to become overtly skeptical about what Mr. Perry might do for the party in November.

headline: Open Secret | LN-CC Boutique
text: A hidden basement boutique in London’s Dalston district takes destination shopping to the next level. View interactive feature >>

headline: StumbleUpon Gets More Specific
text: StumbleUpon has long been one of the most powerful tools for those who revel in the Web’s randomness. A user chooses a few things he’s interested in — say, writing, American football and science — and the service pulls up a new Web site of interest every time he presses “Stumble!” So, perhaps, that user would find a site with a list of “30 Books to Read Before You’re 30,” followed by one with “10 Quirky Science Tricks for Parties,” followed by a page containing just a map of the United States made out of the football helmets of the local N.F.L. teams.

headline: Head of Net’s Address System to Leave
text: Rod Beckstrom, chief executive of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, which oversees the Internet address system, plans to leave the organization next July.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: A Gift From the Musical Gods
text: ON Friday, March 19, 1965, Maria Callas returned to the Metropolitan Opera after a seven-year absence. The work was Puccini’s “Tosca”; it was one of the most anticipated nights in Met history.

headline: Putin and Medvedev Go Fishing, and a Camera Tags Along
text: As my colleague Ellen Barry reports, Russia’s leaders are inordinately obsessed with how the public perceives them. Polling data have become an important part of government, which relies heavily on the personalities of the men at the top — Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin and President Dmitri A. Medvedev.

headline: Crowd-Sourcing for Travel Advice
text: LOOKING back at my favorite vacation spots, several have one vital thing in common: they were suggested by friends.

headline: Cameron Ends Bid to Hire Ex-New York Police Chief
text: LONDON — In the wake of Britain’s brief exploration of the possibility of appointing a former New York City police commissioner to the country’s top police post, the government settled Wednesday on a short list of four senior police commanders — all of them British nationals.

headline: The Sweet Side of Sibling Rivalry
text: “Cute” is probably the last word that comes to mind when we contemplate sibling rivalry, followed closely by “endearing,” “charming” and “sweet.” But those are just the words to describe two new picture books about warring siblings aimed at the youngest readers and rivals.

headline: A More Subdued Perry on the Trail in N.H.
text: BEDFORD, N.H. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas sounded like a sheepish schoolboy at the Granite State’s Politics & Eggs breakfast on Wednesday morning, when he told a bipartisan crowd of 200 that he’d gotten a real talking to the day before.

headline: Musical Couple Turn to Aviator and His Wife
text: TONIO and Consuelo, the wanderlusty aviator and the exotic widow at the center of the new musical “Saint-Ex,” give voice to their tempestuous relationship by singing, “Love is not a gaze that’s shared/But years spent gazing outward together.”

headline: Champions League: Fast Start for L.A. and Seattle
text: It may be only one game, but two teams in Major League Soccer — the Los Angeles Galaxy and the Seattle Sounders — got off to roaring starts Tuesday night as group play opened in the Concacaf Champions League.

headline: The Printing Press Mystery
text: John Plender at the FT seems mystified by something that has become obvious lately: bond vigilantes are only going after countries that no longer have their own currencies. He writes:

headline: LinkedIn’s Social-Ad Misstep
text: Move over Facebook. It’s time to pay attention to privacy on LinkedIn.

headline: Notre Dame’s Kelly Wants Season to Be About Football Again
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — The Notre Dame football coach, Brian Kelly, may be a devout Red Sox fan. But when he sat down with Yankees Manager Joe Girardi before the Irish played at Yankee Stadium last year, they bonded over the challenges inherent in overseeing an iconic brand in sports.

headline: Morgan Freeman and Anthony Edwards Will Appear in ‘8’ Reading on Broadway
text: A new play by Dustin Lance Black, about a trial to overturn California’s voter-approved ban on gay marriage, has found its first cast members for a one-time staged reading on Broadway. Morgan Freeman and Anthony Edwards will be among the actors performing in “8,” written by Mr. Black, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of “Milk,” and adapted from reporting and trial transcripts from the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger, in which a federal judge in San Francisco struck down California’s Proposition 8 in 2010. (The ruling is currently being appealed.)

headline: Smashing Bridges to Build Them
text: The metaphor of building bridges is often used to note a rite of passage or a step toward the future. But while many schools at this time of year are focused on building metaphorical bridges for their students, like helping them transition to high school, students at City Polytechnic High School of Engineering, Architecture, and Technology in Brooklyn were doing the opposite this week.

headline: SABMiller, From Local Brewer to Global Leader
text: SABMiller’s $10 billion hostile bid for the Foster’s Group may be the brewer’s largest. But it is only the latest in a history of global deal-making at the company.

headline: Obama Plans Jobs Speech After Labor Day
text: President Obama plans a major speech on jobs after Labor Day in which he will lay out new proposals for jump-starting the economy and specific plans for legislative efforts to cut spending, White House officials said.

headline: Leading Off: Jailed Booster Imperils Miami Sports Programs
text: The scandal now pummeling the University of Miami should be the last straw. With a Yahoo.com report detailing the Sherman’s March that a rogue booster did through the N.C.A.A. rule book in providing just about every immoral inducement to Miami athletes, it would seem to end college sports’ ability to drape itself in pompoms and pretend it is a worthwhile part of our educational system. Unless this entire story turns out to be a figment of the jailed booster’s imagination — and there is no early indication that is the case — is anybody going to pretend there is a single ethical leg for this whole enterprise to teeter on?

headline: If You Can Vacation Here …
text: It’s been more than a decade since I’ve spent an entire summer, straight through, in New York City. It’s a brutal prospect, what with the steaming pavements and bone-wilting humidity, but if it has to be done, it should be done right. So this summer, armed with my girlfriend and my Metrocard, I set out to design the perfect balance of work, play and sunshine. Herewith I give you my staycation story, a real New Yorker’s guide to not losing your mind between May Day and Labor Day weekend. Part 1: the Red Hook pool, the Bronx Zoo, Coney Island and Far Rockaway.

headline: Two Groups That Help Nonprofits in a Merger
text: GOOD, a fast-growing publishing and marketing business that promotes social causes, is acquiring Jumo, a social networking site that raises money and support for nonprofit groups.

headline: Loving the Hostile
text: Deal makers appear more willing to let slip the dogs of war these days.

headline: Philip Glass to Write Memoir
text: The composer Philip Glass, 74, a pioneer of the Minimalist style of composing, has signed a contract to write a memoir, according to the publisher W.W. Norton & Company. The book will be published by the Norton division Liveright & Company. The publishing date was not disclosed. The publisher said Mr. Glass would explore his youth and musical influences, including working in his father’s record store in Baltimore and collaborations with Ravi Shankar and Allen Ginsberg.

headline: Marshall Islands Denies Culpability in Gulf Spill
text: A report released on Wednesday by the Marshall Islands, the flag state for the drilling rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico last year, says that a review shows that a crew’s deviation from established protocol and its failure to react to signs of an imminent blowout were the main factors that led to the disaster.

headline: Joplin Defies Odds, Just by Opening Schools
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — When the schools here were reduced to red-brick rubble in the deadly tornado three months ago, abruptly ending classes just before final exams, district leaders made a promise that seemed like a long shot: the new school year would start on time.

headline: Amid Skepticism, Debt Panel Is Pressed for a Deal
text: WASHINGTON — There is a joke in this town that goes something like this: If you want to guarantee that a problem does not get solved, convene a committee to study it.

headline: ING Direct’s Paperless Account Now Offers Paper Checks
text: Even as payments become increasingly electronic, the need for paper checks persists. Just ask the folks at the online bank, ING Direct, which touts its Electric Orange checking account as “paperless” — but which just began offering its customers the option to use, well, paper.

headline: Kiss Booted From Michael Jackson Tribute Concert
text: Organizers of a tribute concert for Michael Jackson in Britain scratched the rock band Kiss from the lineup on Tuesday after fans complained that the band’s front man, Gene Simmons, had called Mr. Jackson a child molester, according to wire service reports.

headline: Insider Trading Defendant in Disney Case Fights Back
text: A California man accused of insider trading  is fighting back with his own batch of allegations and insults, issuing a stinging statement late Tuesday that called the Securities and Exchange Commission‘s lawyers “bumbling” and their case against him “riddled with omissions, distortions and inaccuracies.”

headline: ‘Wendy and the Lost Boys’
text: THE FAMILY WASSERSTEIN

headline: ‘The Descendants,’ With George Clooney, Will Close New York Film Festival
text: “The Descendants,” Alexander Payne‘s first feature since his 2004 film “Sideways,” will be the closing night selection of the New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced on Wednesday along with the roster of 27 films that will be presented in the festival’s main slate.

headline: And Now, Wendy Gets Her Chronicles
text: Wendy Wasserstein had a contract to write her memoir when she died, in 2006. The question she had asked herself, putting off the job, was: Could she “reach that kind of depth?” The more obvious question for those acquainted with this Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright: Was there anything left to tell?

headline: Resistance Transforms a Once Mute Syrian City
text: HOMS, Syria — The narrower the streets of this city, a caldron of revolt and resistance against four decades of rule by the Assad family, the blunter the graffiti becomes. It is scrawled on walls, garbage bins, phone booths, doors and even tree trunks, as a city that was long quiescent declares these days that it will no longer stay quiet.

headline: Asthma More Likely Among Children of Overweight Mothers
text: Women who are overweight or obese when they become pregnant may be more likely to have children who develop asthma as teenagers, new research shows.

headline: McGraw-Hill Explores Education Spinoff or Sale
text: 8:09 p.m. | Updated

headline: Notes From Homs: A Reporter’s Trip to One of Syria’s Most Rebellious Cities
text: For nearly five months, Syrian authorities have tried to crush a nationwide popular uprising, killing an estimated 2,000 demonstrators and jailing thousands more. They have also blocked foreign journalists from entering the country. Most of the reports emerging have been spread by local people relying on cellphones and social media networks.

headline: Ahead of Frankfurt, Jaguar Previews C-X16 Concept
text: Having coasted for a year on the strength of its C-X75 hybrid concept, which is headed into production as a supercar costing upwards of $1.5 million, Jaguar has its predatory eyes on a less rarefied market segment with the C-X16 concept, scheduled to have its debut at the Frankfurt auto show next month.

headline: Katy Perry Makes Some Billboard History
text: Katy Perry became the only second artist in the last 53 years to have five songs from a single album reach the top spot on Billboard’s Hot 100 chart, as her track “Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)” has reached No. 1, Billboard reported on Wednesday. The only other singer to pull off that feat was Michael Jackson, who had five songs from “Bad” go to the top of the charts in 1987 and 1988.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Le Gourmand, or Gluttony!’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festival’s close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Young Entrepreneur Sees Little Help In Washington
text: One day last month, Neil Blumenthal, who is a young entrepreneur, found himself in an ornate room on Capitol Hill listening to a parade of politicians — Senator Charles E. Schumer, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand and Senator John McCain, among others — talk about how important young entrepreneurs were to the economy. Mr. Blumenthal, 31, one of the founders of Warby Parker, an online eyewear company that sells designer frames for less than $100, was among 150 young chief executives invited to Washington by Our Time, a youth advocacy group, to help start Buy Young, an initiative that encourages consumers to support companies owned by members of the millennial generation.

headline: Are Young Entrepreneurs Getting Enough Help?
text: We’ve just published an interview with Neil Blumenthal, a young entrepreneur who recently went to Capitol Hill to talk about how important young entrepreneurs are to the economy. One of the founders of Warby Parker, an online eyewear company based in New York, Mr. Blumenthal and Hannah Seligson discussed, among other things, what politicians don’t understand about business, what he had to promise the Small Business Administration he wouldn’t do with his borrowed money, and what the Bloomberg administration is doing right. (You can read more small-business conversations here.)At one point, Mr. Blumenthal noted that his company had struggled to get a loan backed by the Small Business Administration because the company did not yet have two years of tax returns.

headline: Profile in Style | Erica Reid
text: Every fashion-loving gal has that one piece she just can’t part with. For Erica Reid, it’s a cozy old Joseph turtleneck: ‘‘I’ve had it for 14 years. It’s been with me through my girlfriend, fiancée, wife, pregnancy and mother stages.’’ (She’s married to the record executive L. A. Reid.) When Erica, a budding author, isn’t swaddled in her security sweater, she rocks fierce pieces from Alexander McQueen, Preen, Erdem and Norma Kamali (‘‘so old school’’) as well as a vintage collection that would make Kate Moss weep. She opts for high street style from the likes of H&M and Topshop when the mood strikes. ‘‘There’s no shame in my game,’’ she says. ‘‘I am not a slave to labels.’’

headline: The Caucus | Obama Bus Tour Wraps Up
text: The photographer Doug Mills reflects on President Obama's economic tour; Michael D. Shear on the candidates' transportation mode of choice, the bus.

headline: Debate Over Social Media Incitement as Flash Mobs Strike
text: Prime Minister David Cameron called it a “tough message,” but the harsh sentences being handed down by British courts in the wake of last week’s rioting have sparked an outcry, divided his governing coalition and raised questions about the proper response to incitement in the social media age.

headline: Pebble Beach Stars, Minus a Couple Zeroes
text: Given the presence of bespoke Testa Rossas, prewar Mercedes-Benz roadsters and custom-painted M1s, Pebble Beach this week may not seem like a place to go bargain hunting, particularly at the events produced by silk-stocking auction houses like Gooding, Bonhams and RM Auctions. Nevertheless, if savvy but budget-minded enthusiasts look hard enough, they’ll find some interesting cars with pre-auction estimates of under $50,000.

headline: Tech Moguls Find a Fashion Champion in Ashton Kutcher

text: It may not make for the best political strategy, but Newt Gingrich is laughing all the way to the beach.

headline: Rising Political Star in Germany Plummets After Affair With Teenager
text: BERLIN — German voters may be willing to tolerate a politician’s having an affair with a teenager, but not when that politician — a leading conservative, no less — met her on Facebook, where he also flaunted immodest details of his life.

headline: Discrimination Suit Against Bloomberg L.P. Is Rejected

headline: Jay-Z and Kanye West Top Billboard Chart
text: On the music charts this week, Jay-Z and Kanye West reached No. 1 with fewer album sales than expected, and Katy Perry tied Michael Jackson for the most No. 1 songs from one album.

headline: A Truck Dangled in Queens
text: A 15-ton salt-spreading truck burst through the wall of a sprawling Sanitation Department repair depot in Queens on Wednesday morning and hung precariously in the air — 30 feet above the ground — until rescuers could free its driver, the authorities said.

headline: An Epidemic of Rhino Poaching
text: As if a rhino’s life wasn’t already hard enough.

headline: Another View: Icahn Defends His Record
text: Carl C. Icahn is the chairman of Icahn Associates.

headline: Adolescent Health | Drugs, Alcohol and Tobacco
text: The third post in our series: a collection of teaching resources on drugs, alcohol and tobacco.

headline: Some Lesser Mediterranean Lights
text: If you read through the highlights of my Mediterranean summer trip, you might think I spent every waking moment on gorgeous Albanian beaches, taking in stunning Croatian vistas, listening to live Turkish folk music, hiking the picturesque Spanish coast and downing luscious Neapolitan pizzas. I wish. There was also the sleepless night on the ferry, the almost-sleepless night on the French Riviera and the scourge of tourist-clogged cities, to name just a few hiccups.

headline: Up and Down From Ground Zero
text: New office towers are rising at the World Trade Center, which also serves as a memorial and a transportation hub.

headline: A Tattered Theater Nears Return to Glory After Years of Delays
text: MOSCOW — Plácido Domingo climbed carefully up a shaky metal ladder onto the newly rebuilt stage of the Bolshoi Theater — white shirt, white pants, white shoes — and with a sweep of his arm broke into song, the first performer to test the acoustics of the grand and newly renovated theater.

headline: Getting Noticed at the Fringe: ‘Never Look in the Mirror When You’re Dancing’
text: Over the next two weeks ArtsBeat will take a look at some of the most clever, mysterious and strikingly designed postcards created to draw attention among the nearly 200 productions in this year’s New York International Fringe Festival.

headline: Turkey Vows Retaliation for Kurdish Ambush
text: ISTANBUL — Turkish warplanes bombed suspected Kurdish insurgent positions inside northern Iraq late Wednesday for the first time in a year, news services in Turkey reported, hours after an insurgent ambush on a military convoy in southeast Turkey left at least eight dead.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: This month murder and romance are on tap, sometimes in the same novel. And while there’s no shortage of heartache in this selection of fiction, these authors aren’t shy about unabashed happy endings.

headline: Homes for $435,000
text: An 1896 house in Salt Lake City; a contemporary in Houston; and a log house in Montana.

headline: Warning Raised on European Union Plan to Change Rules for Insurers’ Investments
text: LONDON — The world’s largest financial institutions warned Wednesday that proposed rule changes in the European Union could encourage insurance companies to invest in riskier assets like bank debt and sovereign bonds, and they called for reconsideration of the measure.
