headline: Abercrombie Wants Off ‘Jersey Shore’ (Wink-Wink)
text: Brands have pursued product placement for years, cutting deals to get sodas and sports cars in movies and on television. Some have even insisted on the opposite, having their logos and labels blurred by the camera when associated with the bad guy, for instance.

headline: Two Stars and Two Early Exits Before Open
text: MASON, Ohio — Two of the top contenders for the women’s singles title at the United States Open hit significant snags in their preparation Wednesday. Serena Williams, a three-time Open champion, withdrew from the Western & Southern Open, her final tuneup for the Open, shortly before her second-round match against the Australian Samantha Stosur. She said he had a toe injury on her surgically repaired right foot.

headline: TimesCast | August 17, 2011
text: More than 10,000 take to the streets of New Delhi to protest corruption; soaring gold prices mean brisk business for Manhattan jewelers; and the photographer Doug Mills on Obama's Midwest trip.

headline: Former ‘SpongeBob’ Artist Sued for Allegedly Arranging Attack on His Art Dealer
text: According to a lawsuit filed last week in Superior Court in Los Angeles, a former lead artist on the cartoon “SpongeBob SquarePants” hired accomplices to attack his art dealer and take over her gallery in order to gain control of the sale of his work — claims the artist denies.

headline: Can a New Form Make Health Insurance Decisions Easier?
text: The world of health insurance is complex and loaded with jargon. Pre-existing conditions! Family deductibles! Out-of-pocket maximums! Ugh. It’s no wonder people get confused when trying to compare plans.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Uganda, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Somalia.

headline: Gadgetwise: LinkedIn’s Social-Ad Misstep
text: Gadgetwise reports that LinkedIn users are not happy after the company quietly introduced a new site feature called “social ads.” The new form of advertising commandeers a users’ name and picture for product endorsements, but does so without asking users to opt-in to the new ads. Read the entire post here.

headline: Russia Is Better Prepared for a Possible Global Downturn
text: MOSCOW — During previous bouts of financial volatility, Russia could be reliably found on the edge of the violent extremes. In 2008, for example, the Russian stock market was the worst performing of any major stock exchange in the world. The ruble collapsed. And the rich industrialists known as the oligarchs suffered $230 billion in paper losses.

headline: New Commissioner for City’s Environmental Protection Agency
text: Carter H. Strickland Jr., who has helped lead the Bloomberg administration’s efforts on environmental sustainability, has been named commissioner of the city’s Department of Environmental Protection, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Wednesday.

headline: Liberty Considers Range of Options for Barnes & Noble
text: Liberty Media is considering a range of options for Barnes & Noble, which include taking a minority stake in the bookseller instead of buying it outright, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: The Failure of Liberal Bioethics
text: Here’s a telling passage from this Sunday’s Times Magazine story on “selective reduction” — the increasingly commonplace practice whereby twin pregnancies are “reduced” to single babies via abortion:

headline: Fox and NBC Battle in Tuesday Ratings
text: Jennifer Behm was declared the winner during the two-hour season finale of “MasterChef” on Tuesday on Fox. This competitive cook-off reached series highs in total viewers – with 7 million – and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. But it was enough to give Fox a victory in the 18-to-49 category for the night among the broadcast networks, according to Nielsen data. NBC claimed the top spot in total viewers despite another disappointing outing for “America’s Got Talent.” That show hit a summer low in the demographic and and was down in total viewers, as well, averaging 10 million over a two-hour period.

headline: A Big ‘Big Lebowski’ Cast Reunion
text: The “Big Lebowski” cast reunites for one night onstage? Dude!

headline: A Monumental Occasion
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art unveiled in its Great Hall a colossal statue of a pharaoh, on loan from the Egyptian Museum in Berlin for 10 years.

headline: Bladder Cancer a Growing Concern for Smokers
text: Smokers have much higher odds of developing bladder cancer than previously believed, and the changing makeup of cigarettes may be a factor, new research shows.

headline: Weather Alerts Are Imperiled, NOAA Warns
text: Without money to build a new satellite, the federal government will no longer be able to forecast severe weather events far enough in advance for communities to take life-saving action five years from now. That was the message that Jane Lubchenco, the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, delivered on Wednesday at a town-hall-style meeting in Denver.

headline: Caution: Women Playing
text: “I DON’T wear shorts in public!” shouted Sophie Franks Staub, a rangy 41-year-old stay-at-home mother, from her spot on a sand court on Pier 25 in Hudson River Park. Yet she was indeed wearing them, as were two dozen other women in their 30s and 40s, all barefoot as they learned to play beach volleyball on a buttery night in July.

headline: In Crisis, Reminders of Disputes in Euro’s Founding
text: LONDON

headline: Managing social-media overload; the Flame Index; augmented reality; tech news.
text: Stephanie Rosenbloom of The Times offers tips for wrangling personal time back from multiple social-media Web sites. John Jones of The Flame Index explains how the site ranks companies that are battling negative events in the news. The weekly discussion of technology news includes a look at Google’s deal for Motorola Mobility and a new blog about Windows 8.

headline: Tudou’s First-Day Fizzle
text: The Chinese video site Tudou managed to break into the public markets on Wednesday — but it wasn’t pretty.

headline: Was It Worth It? Theater Makers Who Showed Their Stuff in Edinburgh Add It Up
text: 4:57 p.m. | Updated  Getting noticed at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is a matter of numbers. Some 2,500 events make up the multi-arts extravaganza, which continues through Aug. 29, and according to a recent article in The Scotsman, 188 of them are American theatrical productions, many of which originated in New York. (That’s about the same number of shows, in total, playing at the New York International Fringe Festival, which finishes up this week.)

headline: Malpractice Anxiety
text: Amitabh Chandra, a Harvard economist, is a leading expert on medical malpractice, and his work does not fit neatly into either the American Medical Association’s camp or the trial lawyers association’s camp. Sometimes it comforts one side. Sometimes, it comforts the other. I used Mr. Chandra’s research extensively in writing an overview of malpractice in 2009.

headline: Scene City: Whispers at Guild Hall
text: High-minded artists and scandal-prone celebrities mix at Guild Hall’s summer gala.

headline: In East Hampton, the Art Elite Gather
text: GUILD HALL, the 80-year-old cultural pillar of East Hampton, usually stands above the fray in a town with its share of tabloid fodder. But last Friday night, during its summer gala, whiffs of scandal were in the air and on the gallery walls.

headline: Sample Sales | The Rules
text: “I’ve never been up this early in SoHo,” someone says. “I’m so tired; I can’t get my head around boots in summer, but when else will I find a pair at this price?”

headline: To Get to Cats, Common Parasite Hijacks Rats’ Arousal Circuitry
text: Sometimes it’s hard to tell the difference between danger and sex appeal, at least for rats infected with a parasite that twists ancient rat instincts to its own advantage.

headline: Harrison, Hewitt, Sock Among Open Wild Cards
text: Former United States Open champion Lleyton Hewitt and up-and-coming American teenagers Ryan Harrison and Jack Sock are among the eight men awarded wild card spots in the main draw by the United States Tennis Association on Wednesday.

headline: Citing a Lack of Usage, Costco Removes E.V. Chargers
text: Costco, the membership warehouse-club chain, was an early leader in offering electric-vehicle charging to its customers, setting an example followed by other retailers, including Best Buy and Walgreen. By 2006, Costco had installed 90 chargers at 64 stores, mostly in California but also some in Arizona, New York and Georgia. Even after General Motors crushed its EV1 battery cars, the Costco chargers stayed in place.

headline: Tablet Buyers Only Want the iPad, Report Says
text: According to a report issued on Wednesday, consumers who already own or plan to buy a new tablet are only interested in one thing: the Apple iPad.

headline: Shopping for Audio Equipment With Jonah Takagi
text: The designer went shopping for speakers, headphones and other equipment that looks as good as it sounds.

headline: Fast F.D.A. Approval of Melanoma Drug
text: Updated: The Food and Drug Administration approved an expensive new melanoma drug much faster than expected, giving a boost not only to that drug but also to other experimental products that may offer gene-based personalized medicine.

headline: Audio Equipment
text: JONAH TAKAGI, an up-and-coming furniture and lighting designer, has been attracting a lot of attention for his work for companies like Roll & Hill, MatterMade and Council. But before he was a full-time designer, he spent years playing bass in indie rock bands, touring with acts like Benjy Ferree.

headline: Council Members Call for Change to Marijuana Possession Law
text: Criticizing the Bloomberg administration’s aggressive pursuit of marijuana possession arrests as “racially biased” and costly, a group of City Council members gathered in front of City Hall on Wednesday to introduce a resolution aimed at curbing the practice.

headline: Charles Isherwood on Charles Busch's new Off-Broadway comedy, “Olive and the Bitter Herbs”.
text: Charles Isherwood on Charles Busch's new Off-Broadway comedy, “Olive and the Bitter Herbs”.

headline: TimesCast | New Delhi Protests
text: August 17, 2011 - More than 10,000 anticorruption demonstrators marched through New Delhi, a day after 2,600 protesters were detained, including the leader of the movement, Anna Hazare.

headline: Why You Need to Sleep On It
text: It may be a newly identified phenomenon among psychologists, but the symptoms seem familiar to some of the readers who have commented on my article on decision fatigue in this Sunday’s Times Magazine. They say they’ve learned not to make important decisions late in the day, which jibes with the advice of Roy F. Baumeister, a social psychologist at Florida State University, whose research is the subject of the article (and of a forthcoming book that he and I wrote together, “Willpower: Rediscovering the Greatest Human Strength”).

headline: Common, Bogusky’s New Venture, Says, ‘C’mon, Join Us’
text: Alex Bogusky, the one-time advertising wunderkind, is moving ahead with his ambitious plans for Common, an organization he helped start after his surprise departure from the agency business last year.

headline: Army Didn’t Properly Test Plates for Body Armor, Audit Finds
text: An audit by the Pentagon’s inspector general has found that the Army did a poor job of testing the ballistic plates used in body armor and therefore cannot be certain that the equipment is adequately protecting soldiers.

headline: As the Gavels Fell: 240 Years at Old Bailey
text: For 240 years the grand parade of human greed, love, cruelty, longing, and foolishness was captured in the Proceedings, the published record of trials that took place at the Old Bailey, the central criminal court, in London.

headline: App in One Hand, Wine Glass in the Other
text: Some people take a sip of wine and pick up hints of cherry, oak or coffee bean. Others immediately think of the dusty residue at the bottom of a box of Count Chocula cereal, or perhaps a flaming Snickers bar.

headline: A Kingdom for a Stage, Princes to Act ...and Maybe a Better Hall?
text: At the beginning of the Classical Theater of Harlem’s “Henry V” actors who have been milling around and chatting with audience members slowly start to leave the casual and the quotidian behind. Someone beats out time with sticks. A chant begins, an eerie invocation: “O, for a muse of fire” — the first words of this Shakespeare play.

headline: Shape Shifting Effortlessly in Brooklyn
text: Wearing a dress covered in purplish sequins, Yukimi Nagano was her own disco ball on Tuesday night. The lead singer of Little Dragon, the deeply able mimics from Gothenburg, Sweden, she was a grade-A shimmier onstage at Music Hall of Williamsburg. When the song called for slinkiness, she bent into undulating curves. When it demanded toughness, she adopted a no-guff-taking posture.

headline: A Workout for Winds and Brasses
text: The British conductor Jonathan Nott, who has been thriving as the principal conductor of the Bamberg Symphony Orchestra in Germany since 2000, and the gifted young Finnish pianist Juho Pohjonen, who has been steadily gaining intentional attention for his thoughtful artistry, both made their debuts with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall. The highlight of the program was their collaboration on Mozart’s Piano Concerto No. 23 in A, a gracious and elegant performance.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Social Network Burnout
text: Feeling overwhelmed with keeping up appearances on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Google+ and all the other social media sites you use? Stephanie Rosenbloom, a New York Times reporter, provides some tips on this week’s Bits: Tech Talk podcast for streamlining your online presence so you have more time for your offline life. (Also in the interest of saving time, the Tip of the Week segment looks at a way to speed up e-mail conversations by jumping to chat mode from a message.)

headline: Two Different Spins for a Noisy Room
text: Several songs into his show at Cake Shop on Tuesday night the drummer Mike Pride did something stubborn and contrary. He cued a ballad, “Lullaby for Charlie,” dedicated to his 8-month-old son. His four-piece band, From Bacteria to Boys, played it beautifully and quietly, in drifting waltz time. What made this feel counterintuitive, like an act of passive resistance, was the atmosphere in the room: beery and oblivious, a shouting din.

headline: Making It Seem Simple, With a Bonus
text: The Emerson String Quartet has undertaken so many big projects over the years — Beethoven, Bartok, Mendelssohn and Shostakovich cycles, most notably — that when it offers a conventional program, it can seem as if the ensemble is setting adventure and ambition aside and taking it easy. That’s silly of course: single, theme-free programs of mixed composers are the daily bread of all musicians, and they were once the norm for the Emerson too.

headline: Bits Pics: Inside Apple’s New Grand Central Store
text: The City Room blog reports that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority released renderings Tuesday of the Apple store that is scheduled to open in Grand Central Terminal soon.

headline: Web Page About the Met Closes at Opera’s Request
text: The tale sounded like Goliath raising his heel to crush a spunky David. The Metropolitan Opera, irked by regular disclosure of its programming, far into the future, on a Web site’s page, asked its operator to cease and desist.

headline: Yemeni Opposition Leaders Form National Council
text: Seven months after demonstrators first took to the streets in Yemen calling for democracy, opposition leaders formed a national council on Wednesday to act as a government-in-waiting, a provocative step the government condemned even before it was announced.

headline: When an Android Phone Becomes a GPS Device
text: LOS ANGELES — I was on my way to one of my favorite art house cinemas, about 15 minutes away by car. Even though I go there three to four times a year, I always forget which exit to take. Fortunately, I had not one but two GPS devices on my dashboard: a popular model made by Garmin and an Android smartphone.

headline: TimesCast | Gold Rush
text: Soaring gold prices mean brisk business for Manhattan jewelers.

headline: Black Eyed Peas’ Central Park Concert Is Back On
text: When the Black Eyed Peas canceled their June 9 concert on the Great Lawn in Central Park because of lightning, thousands of fans who were already in the park refused to leave, chanting “We Won’t Go.”

headline: Arts Journal in Cyberspace Finds a Home on the Ground
text: It was a steamy summer weeknight, and on a rooftop in Chelsea there was a skyline-lighted party.

headline: Bashing E.P.A. Is New Theme in G.O.P. Race
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency is emerging as a favorite target of the Republican presidential candidates, who portray it as the very symbol of a heavy-handed regulatory agenda imposed by the Obama administration that they say is strangling the economy.

headline: Excerpt: Mostly Mozart Festival
text: Jonathan Nott conducted the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, featuring pianist Juho Pohjonen in Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 23.

headline: Activist in India Agrees to 15-Day Fast
text: Two days after the government in India arrested an anticorruption activist, Anna Hazare, to keep him from starting an indefinite hunger strike, the authorities agreed to permit him to stage a 15-day fast in a park in the capital, New Delhi, the country’s NDTV reports.

headline: Never Mind a Tiger in Your Tank: How About An Alligator?
text: Researchers at the Lafayette campus of the University of Louisiana are looking for green substitutes for diesel fuel. The prime one now in use is soybeans, which are used to make biodiesel oil. But soybeans are also needed for human consumption and animal feed. The United States uses 45 billion gallons of diesel a year; making just one billion gallons from soybeans would use up 21 percent of the American crop, the scientists point out.

headline: Cree to Buy LED Outdoor Lighting Company
text: Cree, a maker of light-emitting diode, or LED, products, said on Wednesday that it would acquire Ruud Lighting for $583 million to expand in LED outdoor lighting.

headline: Winning a Title of Life Master but Not for Being 94 Years Old
text: Last Sunday, Lucy and Everett Jones of Vero Beach, Fla., celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary. Not that special, you might think, but for both this is their third marriage.

headline: Outside Santiago, a Crate for Living
text: A single-story, 1,900-square-foot house in central Chile is a giant wood box that opens to the landscape.

headline: In Chile, a Modern House Returns to Its Creator
text: WHEN the Chilean architect Mathias Klotz was designing Casa Raul — a house for a client with very specific needs — he never imagined one day owning the place himself. But that’s exactly what has happened.

headline: Bloggingheads: Anyone Else Running?
text: Ben Smith, left, of Politico and Byron York of The Washington Examiner debate the possibility of new entrants to the G.O.P. primary.

headline: Gundlach Denies Trying to Poach TCW Clients
text: Jeffrey Gundlach, a bond manager, testified on Wednesday that he never told investors at the Trust Company of the West to take their money out of the firm’s funds after he was fired.

headline: With the Television Built in, the Ultimate Recliner
text: If you are weary of your mate's abandoning you day and night for television, you might wish to consider the Shiane TV Chaise, wide enough at four feet for you to snuggle up close and serve him or her with divorce papers.

headline: The Concrete Wall Clock
text: The weighty 4th Dimension wall clock stands out, thanks to an unusual material: concrete. Created by the Taiwanese industrial design firm 22designstudio, which also makes sculptural concrete rings and photo frames, the three-pound clock resembles a circular staircase with each hour represented by a miniature triangular step.

headline: ‘Nano House’ Explores the Realm of the Tiny
text: “Nano House: Innovations for Small Dwellings” (Thames & Hudson, $29.95; to be published in the fall), by Phyllis Richardson, is an examination of small dwellings around the world — very small. The structures, which include full-time residences as well as vacation getaways, are all smaller than 800 square feet, with many less than 500 square feet.

headline: Leicht Unveils Its First U.S. Store
text: Leicht, one of Germany’s most popular kitchen cabinetry manufacturers, recently opened its first United States showroom, on the Upper West Side.

headline: Sales at Jonathan Adler, Home Remedy and Others
text: All in-stock and custom rugs are 20 percent off at Jonathan Adler through Sunday (a 6-by-9-foot orange herringbone rug, originally $1,550, is $1,240); for information and locations: (800) 963-0891 or jonathanadler.com.

headline: How to Make a Window Garden, With Crowd-Sourced Advice
text: Britta Riley grew up on a ranch in Texas, so after four years of living in a one-bedroom apartment overlooking an airshaft, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, she felt deprived of nature. She decided to try growing food indoors, and three years ago began reading about hydroponic systems. “I got to visit some hydroponic growers and nerd out with them, and figured out how to reverse-engineer it for the personal scale,” said Ms. Riley, 34.

headline: Ken Smith’s Pod Planters Land on a Midtown Terrace
text: SOME might think the blob-like fiberglass forms on Wendy Evans Joseph and Jeffrey Ravetch’s roof terrace look like Al Capp’s sweet-natured Shmoos. But for the couple and their landscape architect, Ken Smith, the voluptuous planters are whimsical abstractions of scholars’ rocks, the stones found in traditional Chinese gardens.

headline: The Retro Renovators
text: Devotees of vintage décor spurn the latest trends in favor of retiling their bathrooms in mosaics from the Eisenhower years.

headline: A Hobby Best Kept Small
text: FOR my seventh birthday, my parents gave me a plain, unfinished wooden dollhouse. It had six empty rooms, two floors, a staircase and a door that swung out onto a little front stoop. The windows opened, and the roof retracted on one side, revealing an attic.

headline: Restoring the Retro House
text: IN early 2008, Stephan Edwards bought an apartment in Palm Springs, Calif., and over the next four months he restored the bathroom, using fixtures dating to circa 1958, the year the building was constructed. When he finished, he sent photos to the one person he knew would truly appreciate his efforts: Pam Kueber at retrorenovation.com.

headline: The New Dandies: Prep Fashion With a Twist
text: The founders of the blog Street Etiquette started out as high school fashion rebels. Now, they are followed by a whole generation.

headline: Pushing the Boundaries of Black Style
text: THE best posts on the style blog Street Etiquette find its principals, Travis Gumbs and Joshua Kissi, in motion. As opposed to the fascistically frozen street-style snaps of The Sartorialist and others, these pictures are styled and plotted fictions but also affecting ones, depicting a pair of young black men taking ownership not just of the body and what goes on it, but also of the environment it moves in. No one ever smiles on Street Etiquette: there’s business to attend to.

headline: Cadillac Parade in Vermont Shatters Guinness Record
text: Slide over, Holland. The Vermont county that claims Henry Leland, the founder of Cadillac, as a native son now holds the Guinness World Record for the largest parade of Cadillacs.

headline: Bolshoi Theater to Reopen in October
text: The crown jewel of Russian arts has been restored after six years of work that was often delayed.

headline: As Perry Sets Out on the Campaign Trail
text: To the Editor:

headline: NBC Sports to Broadcast From Fall Meet at Keeneland
text: Horse racing will get much-needed television coverage this fall when the NBC Sports Group broadcasts live from Keeneland Race Course for two weekends beginning Oct. 7.

headline: YouTube and Music Publishers Reach Ad Accord
text: Ending a four-year legal dispute, YouTube has struck a deal with music publishers that will allow advertising to run alongside more videos on its site, and could result in significant new revenue for smaller publishers.

headline: The Death of Camus
text: To the Editor:

headline: Day After Fed Uproar, Perry Tones It Down
text: NASHUA, N.H. — When Gov. Rick Perry of Texas finished up a round-table discussion Wednesday at a manufacturing company here, one man was so impressed that he leapt from his seat, offering the governor high praise.

headline: Review of Job Placements
text: To the Editor:

headline: Burress Back on the Field, and ‘It Felt Great’
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — About 30 minutes after completing his first full practice of the season, Plaxico Burress arrived in the small interview room at the Jets’ training complex, stepped to the microphone and — when asked how the session had felt — offered a toothy smile.

headline: From Deborah Lipstadt: Hitler and the ’36 Olympics
text: To the Editor:

headline: Refugees Flee Libya Oil City as Qaddafi’s Forces Dig In
text: ZAWIYAH, Libya — Escaping sniper fire and a steady rain of artillery shells, hundreds of refugees fled from Zawiyah on Wednesday as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s loyalists fought to keep control of this strategic city — a half-hour drive from Tripoli, the capital — and its oil refinery.

headline: A Naval Base in South Korea (Continued)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Qualms on Medco May Be Premature
text: The market now seems to think that Express Scripts’ $29 billion agreement to buy Medco Health Solutions, another pharmacy benefits manager, has zero chance of success. Investors are right to take antitrust concerns about the industry seriously, but their doubts look overdone.

headline: Fritz Bach, Who Aided Transplant Survival, Dies at 77
text: Dr. Fritz H. Bach, a physician and medical researcher who helped develop techniques to improve people’s chances of surviving organ and bone marrow transplants, died Sunday at his home in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass. He was 77.

headline: Suicide Throws ‘Housewives’ Season Into Uncertainty
text: The suicide of Russell Armstrong, the husband of one of the leading characters in the Bravo series “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills,” has thrown the plans for the next edition of the series into uncertainty.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,727 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: No to Arctic Drilling
text: ABOUT 55,000 gallons of oil have escaped into the North Sea since last week from a leaky pipeline operated by Royal Dutch Shell, about 100 miles off Scotland.

headline: One Ball, Two Backs and Many, Many Options
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On the surface, Brandon Jacobs and Ahmed Bradshaw are the prototypical — and stereotypical — running back tandem.

headline: In Nigeria, an Islamist Insurgency Strengthens
text: A shadowy insurgency that has haunted northern Nigeria, surviving repeated, bloody efforts to eliminate it, appears to be branching out and collaborating with Al Qaeda’s affiliates.

headline: Islamist Group With Possible Qaeda Links Upends Nigeria
text: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — A shadowy Islamist insurgency that has haunted northern Nigeria — surviving repeated, bloody efforts to eliminate it — appears to be branching out and collaborating with Al Qaeda’s affiliates, alarming Western officials and analysts who had previously viewed the militants here as a largely isolated, if deadly, menace.

headline: Court Ruling Offers Path to Challenge Dodd-Frank
text: Alex Wong/Getty ImagesMary L. Schapiro, the S.E.C. chairwoman, said the agency spent 21,000 staff hours drafting the proxy rule over two years.

headline: S.E.C. Files Were Illegally Destroyed, Lawyer Says
text: WASHINGTON — An enforcement lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission says that the agency illegally destroyed files and documents related to thousands of early-stage investigations over the last 20 years, according to information released Wednesday by Congressional investigators.

headline: Transit Agency Study Finds Fares Up and Service Down
text: The fare for Atlanta’s trains and buses will jump to $2.50 in October, giving the city one of the more expensive transit systems in the country. In Salt Lake City, rides to Temple Square on the popular light-rail system rose a quarter in May to $2.25, and are scheduled to hit $2.50 in two years. Even San Francisco’s iconic cable cars went up a dollar last month, to $6.

headline: A Huge Scandal, but Probably Not the Harshest Penalties
text: As college sports officials confront yet another cheating scandal — this one involving Miami, the latest in a conga line of blue-chip programs that have recently stumbled into the crosshairs of N.C.A.A. investigators — speculation over the extent of the fallout intensified Wednesday. Questions were raised about the status of current players, former coaches and even administrators, including Donna Shalala, the university president.

headline: Wrong Answers in Britain
text: Nothing can justify or excuse the terrifying wave of violent lawlessness that swept through London and other British cities earlier this month. Hardworking people in struggling neighborhoods were its principal victims. Public support for racial and ethnic coexistence also suffered a damaging, and we fear lasting, blow.

headline: Rebels Fight for Zawiyah as Refugees Flee
text: Hundreds of refugees fled from Zawiyah on Wednesday as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s loyalists fought to keep control of this strategic city.

headline: Threadbare American Justice
text: It is an American article of faith that the path to justice runs through the courts. State courts, which handle a vast majority of civil and criminal cases, are in a state of crisis. Across the country, deep budget cuts and increased caseloads have created long delays and a denial of basic access to justice.

headline: Warburg Stays in the Fray, but Off the Public Market
text: Richard Perry/The New York TimesJoseph P. Landy, left, and Charles R. Kaye, co-presidents of Warburg, which has been careful not to depend too heavily on leveraged buyouts.

headline: A Deal to Get Cheaper and Safer Drugs
text: Federal regulators and the generic drug industry are putting the final touches on an agreement that would help speed the approval of generic drugs in this country and increase inspections at foreign plants that export generic drugs and drug ingredients to the United States.

headline: Israel Says It Won’t Apologize to Turkey for Deadly Flotilla Raid
text: JERUSALEM — Israel has decided not to apologize to Turkey for last year’s deadly raid on a Turkish protest flotilla bound for Gaza ahead of a United Nations report on the episode scheduled to be published early next week, according to a senior Israeli official.

headline: The Man Who Helped Stop Boss Tweed
text: In the 1860s and ’70s, William M. Tweed — the apotheosis of big-city corruption — appeared to be unstoppable. Gorging on duck, oysters and tenderloin, he reigned supreme over New York City’s patronage and politics. By one estimate, he and his Tammany Hall cronies purloined at least $1 billion and perhaps as much as $4 billion in today’s dollars, much of it from the public purse.

headline: New Grit, New Bullpen and Newfound Success in Arizona
text: PHILADELPHIA — With two out in the ninth inning Tuesday night, Gerardo Parra broke for second on a stolen-base attempt for the Arizona Diamondbacks. From his seat in the third-base dugout, Ian Kennedy distinctly heard Ryan Howard, the Philadelphia Phillies’ first baseman, shout, “Runner!” to alert the other fielders.

headline: Central Florida Facing an Inquiry
text: The University of Central Florida received a letter of inquiry from the N.C.A.A. on Wednesday alerting it to an investigation into its football and men’s basketball programs. The letter came after an article in The New York Times in April that detailed how Ken Caldwell, a convicted felon with ties to a sports agency, helped recruit players to the university.

headline: Heroes, Until They’ve Arrived
text: A little Rick Perry goes a very long way.

headline: Citing Debt and Benefits, Fitch Lowers Bond Rating for New Jersey
text: Despite its efforts to cut spending, New Jersey is a riskier investment, one of the leading ratings agencies said on Wednesday as it lowered the state’s credit rating, citing heavy debt and benefits obligations.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Short Life of a Rebel Privateer
text: Not long after setting sail from Massachusetts, the Cuba-bound merchant schooner Enchantress spied a square-rigged brig approaching, painted black, with dark sails and black mastheads and yards. As the vessel drew near the merchantman, a voice ordered the Enchantress to heave to. Shortly, a boat containing an officer and six men rowed alongside. Upon climbing over the gangway, the officer confronted the merchantman’s captain, demanding immediate surrender of his vessel. Facing the muzzles of the raider’s cannon, and with only a single musket on board, the schooner’s captain had no alternative but to submit. It was piracy, plain and simple — but piracy condoned and supported by the Confederacy.

headline: Selling My Mother’s Dresses
text: I moved from Chicago to Brooklyn in July of 2004, just in time to watch my mother die. That wasn’t why I moved back. She was supposed to be getting better; the chemo was working. I came because I’d rented an apartment with Jay, this cute guy I’d started dating, who was originally from New York too. But a week after pulling up in a U-Haul, I found myself cleaning out my childhood home with my siblings. Our parents were both gone now; anything that we couldn’t take with us had to fit in a 20-cubic-yard Dumpster.

headline: Sabathia Goes for a History Lesson
text: 10:12 p.m. | Updated

headline: Venezuela: Nationalizing Gold
text: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela said Wednesday that he planned to take control of the country’s gold industry to halt illegal mining and bolster reserves, adding to nationalizations in the oil, metals and cement businesses. Mr. Chávez, speaking on state television, said he was preparing a decree increasing government control to stop illegal miners from exploiting deposits of gold and coltan, an ore containing tantalum, used in cellphones and video game consoles.

headline: All My Old Haunts
text: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

headline: Creed C. Black, Newspaper Executive, Dies at 86
text: Creed Black, a peripatetic, pugnacious newspaper executive who enraged his native state by printing a series of articles exposing corruption on the University of Kentucky basketball team, died Tuesday in Miami. He was 86.

headline: Egypt: Military Exercises Canceled
text: The United States and Egypt have canceled joint military exercises planned for this year because the Egyptian military is preoccupied running the government since the ouster in February of President Hosni Mubarak. The semiannual exercises, known as “Bright Star,” have become one of the most significant bonds between the two allies since they were begun 30 years ago after Egypt signed the Camp David accords with Israel. The United States provides Egypt about $1.3 billion in military aid each year as a legacy of the Camp David accords. Military officials in both countries have said they expect to hold the joint military exercises again in 2013.

headline: No Cause for Marijuana Case, but Enough for Child Neglect
text: The police found about 10 grams of marijuana, or about a third of an ounce, when they searched Penelope Harris’s apartment in the Bronx last year. The amount was below the legal threshold for even a misdemeanor, and prosecutors declined to charge her. But Ms. Harris, a mother whose son and niece were home when she was briefly in custody, could hardly rest easy.

headline: A Block Abuzz With the Business of Gold
text: On Tuesday morning, Arnie and Laura Goldstein, a retired couple from Rego Park, Queens, took some gold jewelry they had been saving for years to the incredible trinket bazaar that is the diamond district in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Cuts in Health Care May Undermine Role in Labor Market
text: Even during months of stubborn unemployment, the health care industry has provided a solid underpinning, reliably adding jobs in an otherwise dismal environment.

headline: Peru: Some Anti-Coca Work Halted
text: The government of President Ollanta Humala said Wednesday that it was temporarily suspending coca eradication projects in the tropical valleys around Tingo María, one of Peru’s top sources of coca, the plant used to make cocaine. The move opened the possibility of a shift in antinarcotics strategy in Peru, which is close to surpassing Colombia as the world’s leading coca producer. The United States, which provides financing for Peru’s coca eradication projects, was taken by surprise. Ambassador Rose Likins said she had not received a full explanation of the decision.

headline: U.S. Inquiry Is Said to Focus on S.&P. Ratings
text: The Justice Department is investigating whether the nation’s largest credit ratings agency, Standard & Poor’s, improperly rated dozens of mortgage securities in the years leading up to the financial crisis, according to two people interviewed by the government and another briefed on such interviews.

headline: Thursday: Bless Us and Splash Us, My Precioussss!
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Have you ever calculated your Six Degrees of Separation from someone else? How about from Kevin Bacon? The Six Degrees of Separation is an unproven theory (originated by Hungarian author Frigyes Karinthy and later popularized in a play by John Guare) that says that all people on Earth are no more than six connections away from each other. These “chains” of connections were meant to show that the world, while growing in population, was actually smaller than ever.

headline: School Panel, Over Protests, Backs a Deal With Verizon
text: The Panel for Educational Policy on Wednesday approved a $120 million contract with a Verizon subsidiary to provide phone and Internet services for two years at city schools, despite calls for postponing the vote and boisterous protests over Verizon’s possible role in federal theft charges against an Education Department consultant.

headline: Washington’s Woes Follow Obama Across the Midwest
text: As the President Obama wrapped up his three-day bus tour, the mood was somber, with questions about lost jobs, collapsed housing prices and threats to Social Security following him.

headline: Lessons in Austerity: How City Principals Make Budgets Work
text: Five months after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg outlined a plan to give principals more autonomy to run their schools, the city imposed what would be the first of five consecutive cuts to the schools’ budgets. To make ends meet, principals have trimmed after-school programs, shrunk their support staffs and tightened their schools’ use of things like printing paper, markers and Post-it notes. They have dismissed coaches who used to help teachers prepare for their lessons, and teachers whose salaries they could no longer pay.

headline: Far From Capital, Obama Still Finds Its Woes
text: ATKINSON, Ill. — When President Obama called on Alex McAvoy, a sandy-haired boy who had just turned 11, he may have figured he would get a break from the drumbeat of questions about lost jobs, collapsed housing prices and threats to Social Security that flowed through his town-hall-style meeting on Wednesday at a seed-corn warehouse here.

headline: A Feminine Approach to Incontinence
text: A PRINT ad for Poise Hourglass, a new line of bladder protection products from Kimberly-Clark, features the bare back of a woman facing away from the camera, her supple torso assuming the shape of an apostrophe.

headline: Mets’ Gee Contributes Solid Effort, and Gets Help From Offense
text: SAN DIEGO — The dwindling effectiveness of Dillon Gee has been a vexing issue for the Mets.

headline: Obama to Press Committee on Jobs
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will deliver a major address soon after Labor Day seeking to pressure a special Congressional committee to propose new measures to promote job creation as well as larger long-term deficit cuts than mandated, aides said Wednesday.

headline: Court Rejects Publishers’ Deal With Writers
text: A federal appeals court on Wednesday vacated a multimillion-dollar settlement between freelance writers and some of the country’s largest publishers, saying the deal undercompensated most of the writers involved.

headline: Hewitt Gets Wild Card
text: The former United States Open champion Lleyton Hewitt was among the eight men awarded wild-card spots in the main draw by the United States Tennis Association on Wednesday. Hewitt, 30, is trying to rebound from hip surgery last year and is ranked 165th.

headline: Foreign Students in Work Visa Program Stage Walkout at Plant
text: PALMYRA, Pa. — Hundreds of foreign students, waving their fists and shouting defiantly in many languages, walked off their jobs on Wednesday at a plant here that packs Hershey’s chocolates, saying a summer program that was supposed to be a cultural exchange had instead turned them into underpaid labor.

headline: First Day of School, and the Whole City Cheers
text: Classes began on schedule but in makeshift spaces around Joplin, Mo., as the city continued to recover from the May 22 storm that killed 160.

headline: Offering Funds, U.S. Agency Dreams of Sending Humans to Stars
text: Alpha Centauri or bust.

headline: Proposal Would Aid Deciphering of Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration proposed new rules on Wednesday that would require health insurance companies and employers to provide information to policyholders and employees describing health benefits, coverage and costs in plain English.

headline: Ruling on Evidence in Russian’s Arms Case Favors Prosecutors
text: Prosecutors in the case against Viktor Bout, a Russian man accused of conspiring to sell arms to a terrorist organization, will be allowed to use evidence showing that the United Nations and the United States had placed economic sanctions against him within the last decade, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Frustrated Yanks Lose by One Run, and They’re Pretty Sure Which One
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When Royals designated hitter Billy Butler was awarded a home run in the third inning of Wednesday night’s game, the Yankees argued and complained but probably never imagined that the run he scored would prove so costly.

headline: Robert Breer, Pioneer of Avant-Garde Animation, Dies at 84
text: Robert Breer, an animator whose use of novel techniques to set lines and forms scrambling across the screen opened up a new language for film, died on Aug. 11 at his home in Tucson. He was 84.

headline: This Is Why Some People Don’t Like Real Madrid
text: Marcelo’s angry foul on Barcelona’s Cesc Fabregas, which marred the end of Wednesday’s Spanish Supercup final, was an unnecessary attack given it occurred moments before the whistle in a game his team was about to lose. But it was also the latest black mark on a Real Madrid team that, under Jose Mourinho, has become known more for its indefensible outbursts and its postgame complaining than it has for its sometimes unbeatable play.

headline: Baby’s Got Bass
text: The contrast between the Esperanza Spalding that you see onstage and the offstage Esperanza, jazz bassist and singer, was not immediately apparent at breakfast the day after her big sold-out show at the Montreal International Jazz Festival, the kickoff of her summer tour. Onstage she is luminous, a major chord of exuberance, swinging behind her stand-up bass, eyes closed, singing to the lights, an evangelist of joy in various cool time signatures. At breakfast, meanwhile, she was soft-spoken and contemplative, almost demure.

headline: What a Cow Taught Me About Running
text: What’s running rock bottom? For me, it was being passed by a cow in a half marathon. The cow was ambling beside a fence, and she outpaced me on only about 100 meters. Still, she did it.

headline: Word of the Day | effeminate
text: effeminate •\e-ˈfe-mə-nət\• adjective

headline: Cooperation Emphasized as Biden Visits China
text: BEIJING — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Chinese leaders emphasized on Thursday the need for economic cooperation at a time when the global economy is struggling with new crises. But a fistfight at an American-versus-Chinese good-will basketball game at night cast a shadow on the day’s diplomacy.

headline: Corrections: August 18

headline: McGraw-Hill Weighs a Spinoff of Its Education Unit
text: McGraw-Hill is now weighing what to do with one if its oldest businesses: education.

headline: I.B.M. Announces Brainy Computer Chip
text: Since the early days in the 1940s, computers have routinely been described as “brains” — giant brains or mathematical brains or electronic brains. Scientists and engineers often cringed at the distorting simplification, but the popular label stuck.

headline: Aug. 18, 1963 | James Meredith Graduates From Mississippi
text: On Aug. 18, 1963, James Meredith was awarded a bachelor’s degree by the University of Mississippi (Ole Miss), becoming the first black man to graduate from the school.

headline: News Quiz | Aug. 18, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Fishnet Markets Hypothesis
text: From the food hall in Ostermalm. Now to figure out how to incorporate into my presentation this afternoon on the state of financial economics.

headline: Hippie Punching
text: Via Greg Sargent, I learn that some people in the Obama campaign really, really dislike people like me, who complain when the president gives in to GOP blackmail.

headline: Libyan Rebels Gain Control of Oil Refinery as Qaddafi Forces Flee
text: ZAWIYAH, Libya — Rebel fighters claimed complete control of a sprawling oil refinery in this coastal town on Thursday, seizing one of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s most important assets after just three days of fighting and delivering the latest in a string of small victories that have suddenly put the rebels at Tripoli’s door.

headline: Lake Wobegon Economics
text: Dean Baker has a very good, succinct summary of what’s wrong with pretty much everything Casey Mulligan has written about employment. What I’d say, however, is that it’s much broader than Mulligan.

text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: In Classified Photos, the Art of Surveillance
text: Taken out of context, many of the images the photographer Simon Menner found in the archives of the Stasi, the former East German secret police, are comical. Others are merely banal. All of them reveal the pervasive surveillance habits of the repressive government agency.

headline: Insurgent Attacks Taking Toll on Afghan Civilians
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A series of attacks by insurgents in recent days killed numerous civilians, but for the most part failed against military targets.

headline: Do You Have a Hard Time Making Decisions?
text: A New York Times Magazine article explains the phenomenon of “decision fatigue,” the experience of being worn down by having to make decision after decision. Do you think you have experienced decision fatigue? Under what conditions do you tend to make good decisions?

headline: Indian Anticorruption Leader to Leave Jail
text: NEW DELHI — Having trumped a government effort to defuse his anticorruption movement, the protest leader Anna Hazare announced that he would leave a city jail on Friday and begin a mass demonstration and hunger strike at a public ground in the national capital.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 18, 2011
text: Today’s question was written by Shannon Doyne. Her question comes from the article “Ugly Details in Selling Newspapers.”

headline: On Eve of Frankfurt Auto Show, German Orchestra Builds a Tuner Special
text: In Mannheim, Germany, car horns and engines are among the noted soloists scheduled to perform a multimodal musical piece on Sept. 10.

headline: 2011 Tennessee Titans Season Preview
text: The relationship finally went stale. Jeff Fisher and the Tennessee Titans — over, after 16 years. Good run. Or long run, anyway.

headline: Folklore Festival Returns to Prague
text: One of Prague’s most endearing traits is its unwavering ability to tuck large-scale cultural events into unusual, out-of-the-way spots — for instance, the large courtyard (Ovocny trh) behind the Estates Theatre in the heart of Old Town. A working fruit market during the Middle Ages, this hidden corner of the city is the setting for the annual International Folklore Festival, a six-day bonanza of dance and music acts from around the world that starts Aug. 25.

headline: Back to School, and Back to Basics
text: WHY have some school districts been able to make school lunches “better and healthier” while others have not?

headline: The Early Word: In the Works
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: The View From on High
text: It looks like the great prow of the world, steering us into the void. Or if you prefer something more in keeping with the genius loki of the place (fjord, land of the Norsemen), a real-world version of Hlidskjalf, the seat in Asgard from which all-wise Odin was able to see everything.

headline: Wag the Dalek
text: OK, that’s by far the best thing I’ve heard about my remark that an imaginary threat from aliens, by leading to a burst of spending, would solve the unemployment problem. It’s in this comment thread.

headline: Q&A: Finding the Right Software for Windows Media Player
text: Q.

headline: A Republican Shout-Out for Wind Energy
text: In The New York Times on Thursday, John M. Broder writes about a blood sport that has become quite popular among the field of Republican presidential candidates: attacks on the Environmental Protection Agency. Yet the candidates recently found time to rally behind clean wind energy, a topic some voters identify with a somewhat more liberal agenda.

headline: Attacks Near Israeli Resort Heighten Tensions With Egypt and Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — Armed attackers, described by the authorities as Gazans who had crossed into Israel from Egypt, carried out multiple deadly attacks near the popular Red Sea resort of Eilat on Thursday, prompting a fierce Israeli bombing raid on Gaza and threatening to escalate tensions there.

headline: What Satisfying Picky Customers Can Mean to a Business
text: I have been reading Paul Downs’s recent posts about his Very Picky Customer with great interest. I think Paul handled the situation well, and I wouldn’t be surprised if the woman he wrote about ended up becoming a valued customer of his. While I can certainly identify with the trials and tribulations of dealing with picky customers, I was surprised by the many comments from business owners who concluded that this woman was too much trouble.

headline: When the Point Isn’t Just to Stay Dry
text: Sunday was one of the rainiest days in New York’s weather history, Monday was soggy and Tuesday was mostly gray. Thursday morning it is raining again. All over the city, umbrellas are being hawked for $4, as they always are at the first drop of rain.

headline: What’s the Scariest Film You Ever Saw?
text: The end of summer has become something of a bonanza for horror fans: this month alone has “Final Destination 5,” “Fright Night” and “Don’t Be Afraid of the Dark” coming to a theater near you. “Dark” is a remake of a 1973 haunted house tale that Guillermo Del Toro, a writer and producer of the new film, has called the scariest television movie he ever saw. In Arts & Leisure, Jason Zinoman, author of the horror history “Shock Value,” asks a diverse group of filmmakers — Ti West, John Landis, Marti Noxon, John Sayles and others — about the films that frightened them the most.

headline: Stocks Fall Anew on Debt Worries and the Economy
text: After just a few days of calm, stock markets heaved again on Thursday, sending major American indexes down as much as 5 percent on persistent worries about the economy and Europe’s debt problems.

headline: No Letup in Syrian Crackdown on Protesters, Activists Say
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian pro-democracy activists said Thursday that military operations against protesters seeking to oust President Bashar al-Assad had not stopped, a day after Mr. Assad told the United Nations secretary general that the crackdown had ended.

headline: Can Another Speech Really Help Obama?
text: For weeks, many of President Obama’s staunchest supporters have been urging him to gather his boldest ideas for job creation and present them, in a big way, to the American people as a way of putting Republicans back on their heels.

headline: Asahi to Buy New Zealand Liquor Company
text: Asahi Group Holdings on Thursday agreed to buy Flavoured Beverages Group Holdings, a liquor company based in New Zealand, for $1.3 billion from the private equity firms Pacific Equity Partners and Unitas Capital, in the latest deal in the consolidating industry.

headline: Protests Greet Visiting Pope as Austerity Grips Spain
text: MADRID — Pope Benedict XVI began a four-day visit to Spain on Thursday, bringing what he hoped would be a message of faith and optimism to young people in an overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country where church attendance has declined and many citizens are worried about severe economic austerity, indebtedness and unemployment.

headline: Classic Magazine Photographs, Then and Now
text: A new look at nine classic pictures from the magazine’s past.

headline: Clay Tarver’s Rock Remembrances
text: Clay Tarver, guitarist for indie band Chavez, has tried hard to keep his rock life a secret from his kids.

headline: Emma and Dex and July 15
text: “One Day” tracks the crisscrossing fates of two good-looking people from 1988, when they are newly fledged, happily drunken university graduates, to a point just short of the present, which is to say middle age for them. The movie’s conceit, embedded in the title, is that all of the depicted action takes place, from one year to the next, on a single date, July 15.

headline: Strangers on a Plate: Vitello Tonnato
text: “Vitello tonnato is simple,” Gherardo Guarducci was saying, talking over a mobile phone in his fast, Italian-flecked English from the dining room of Casa Lever, the elegant Manhattan restaurant of which he is an owner. The dish combines cold veal with a thick, creamy sauce flavored with canned or jarred tuna to make a meal of outrageous textural excellence, equally appropriate at summer business lunches and weekend dinners on the fire escape. “You make veal, you make a tuna sauce.”

headline: The Secret Life of a Rock Dad
text: “Your husband’s a guitarist, right? Does he want to play in the Dad Band for the Spring Faire?” That’s verbatim what a father from our preschool asked my wife. She and I shared a big, long laugh. Until I noticed she wasn’t laughing. In fact, she seemed hurt. “You wouldn’t even do that for your own kids,” she said, “would you?”

headline: Turkey Attacks Kurdish Targets in Northern Iraq After Ambush
text: ISTANBUL — Turkish warplanes attacked 60 targets in the mountains and border areas of northern Iraq early Thursday in pursuit of Kurdish separatist rebels suspected of responsibility a day earlier for a deadly quadruple bombing ambush on a military convoy in southeast Turkey, the army headquarters said.

headline: Thursday Reading: Obama’s Push for Job Creation Measures
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Strong Yen Is a Two-Edged Sword for Japan
text: TOKYO — In a bid to calm jittery markets, top Japanese finance officials discussed the country’s persistently strengthening currency at an emergency meeting Thursday, even as a beverage maker announced an overseas acquisition that took advantage of the soaring yen.

headline: Critic’s Choice

headline: Revisiting Climate and the Food Supply
text: When I was researching a June article on the threat that climate change poses to the food supply, scientists described numerous difficulties they have encountered in seeking to forecast food production. They cited uncertainty about whether crops would be hit harder by drought or heat.

headline: Longer Lives for Obese Mice, With Hope for Humans of All Sizes
text: Sustaining the flickering hope that human aging might somehow be decelerated, researchers have found they can substantially extend the average life span of obese mice with a specially designed drug.

headline: Morning Buzz
text: For more local news from The Times, including the  neglect investigations by child welfare agencies after parents’ minor marijuana offenses, new state guidelines for reporting abuse of the developmentally disabled (developed after a series of Times articles), and the rejection of the class-action discrimination lawsuit against Bloomberg L.P., see the N.Y./Region Section.

headline: U.S. and Allies Say Syria Leader Must Step Down
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and several of its major allies on Thursday called on Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, to give up power. The carefully choreographed announcements came after months of popular protests and increasingly deadly reprisals that the United Nations commissioner for human rights said amounted to crimes against humanity by the Syrian authorities.

headline: Judy Garland Drama Coming to Broadway
text: “End of the Rainbow,” Peter Quilter’s popular London drama-with-music about the final months of Judy Garland’s life, will come to Broadway next year, the show’s producers announced on Thursday. Performances are scheduled to begin March 19, 2012, at a Shubert theater to be announced, with opening night set for April 3. Tracie Bennett, a two-time Olivier Award winner who originated the role of Garland in London, will reprise her role on Broadway.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: President Obama’s Statement on Syria
text: The following is a statement released by the White House, announcing President Obama's call for Syria's president, Bashar al-Assad, to step down, and the administration's decision to impose additional sanctions on the Syrian government.

headline: Reporter Known for Scoops Is Held in Hacking Inquiry
text: LONDON — The British police arrested the Hollywood reporter for the defunct tabloid The News of the World on Thursday, according to a person close to the investigation. He is the 13th person to be arrested in the scandal over phone hacking.

headline: ‘The Snowy Day’ Celebrates 50 Years
text: A snowy date would be most refreshing during the dregs of August, which is why the publication today of the 50th anniversary edition of “The Snowy Day” by Ezra Jack Keats is such a welcome event.

headline: Former Met Is First Player to Test Positive for H.G.H.
text: Mike Jacobs, a first baseman in the Colorado Rockies’ organization who has played more than 500 games in the major leagues, including dozens with the Mets, is the first professional baseball player to test positive for human growth hormone, a banned performance-enhancing drug.

headline: New York Subpoenas Energy Firms
text: New York State’s attorney general has sent subpoenas to three large energy companies as part of a broad investigation into whether they have accurately described to investors the prospects for their natural gas wells, according to several sources familiar with the inquiry.

headline: Leading Off: Let the Hand-Wringing Begin
text: In the four stages of N.C.A.A. scandal reaction, we have now officially entered Stage 3, the hand-wringing stage. This comes after the first two stages — piqued prurient interest (Ponzi scheme artist providing strippers? Top-notch.) and watching the accused parties squirm — and before the fourth stage of everybody becoming bored because nothing ever changes in a system rotten to the core.

headline: A Festival in Red Square
text: For the third year running, the end of summer will be celebrated in Red Square in Moscow against the onion-domed backdrop of St. Basil’s Cathedral with the Spasskaya Tower Festival, named after one of the Kremlin’s main towers.

headline: Clip: 'Amigo'
text: A scene from "Amigo," the John Sayles film about America's occupation of the Philippines in the early 20th century.

headline: Financial Stocks Sink
text: Financial stocks tumbled in a global market rout on Thursday as fears re-emerged about stresses to banks amid fresh signs of economic weakness and a persistent European debt crisis.

headline: Forest Labs Defeats Icahn in Proxy Fight
text: Forest Laboratories defeated Carl C. Icahn in a closely watched proxy fight, as shareholders on Thursday elected all 10 of the drug maker’s board nominees.

headline: How German Is It?
text: Michael Lewis’s Vanity Fair article on why Germany now calls the shots in the Eurozone is delightfully, mischievously Swiftian. Lewis ties Germans’ relationship to money to, well, their relationship to excrement. As his source, he cites the work of a Berkeley anthropologist, Alan Dundes, whose book “Life Is Like a Chicken Coop Ladder” argues that German folklore is uncommonly obsessed with anality. To support the thesis that this obsession is at the root of Germany’s economic dominance (and its faulty risk-taking), Lewis uncovers myriad examples of fecal focus in German colloquialisms and proverbs.

headline: Back Again, Whether or Not He Was Away
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.

headline: Human Bacteria Killing Coral in Florida Keys
text: We’ve all heard about bird flu, swine flu, H.I.V., ebola — diseases that jump species with alarming agility and wreak havoc on humanity’s unprepared immune system. But have you ever stopped to consider the capacity of the human species to infect other life forms?

headline: 76 Cents Worth of Good News
text: In a slightly desperate hunt for good economic news, I’ve come up with this small consolation: Average premiums for Medicare Part D, the prescription drug benefit, will not rise in 2012. In fact, they will fall slightly.

headline: Perry Parries Hecklers in Portsmouth
text: 7:06 p.m. | Updated PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas took his popovers with a side of hecklers Thursday morning, when he stopped into Popovers on the Square in downtown Portsmouth to greet voters.

headline: U.S., European and U.N. Statements on Syria

headline: Davis Polk Hires Former Antitrust Regulator

text: On Thursday, FarmVille, Mafia Wars and Bejewelled are getting some new neighbors on Facebook: The Sims.

headline: Seeing Things | Iko Iko Goes West
text: Earlier this month, Iko Iko, a concept shop and gallery, pulled up stakes and moved to 931 North Fairfax Avenue in Hollywood. Its new space is lighter and airier than its former Echo Park location, and it gives Iko Iko’s proprietors, Kristin Dickson and Shin Okuda, more room to showcase the charming utilitarian goods that have garnered the shop something of a cult following in Los Angeles. Okuda is from Tsuruga, a seaport city in western Japan, and he and Dickson share a deep affection for the beauty and simplicity of Japanese craft and design.

headline: With Ames Over, Candidates Are Free to Move About the Country
text: Life has gotten a bit more complicated for the folks who work as travel managers for the Republican presidential candidates.

headline: Noble Energy Buys Consol Shale Stake for $3.4 Billion
text: Noble Energy has agreed to pay $3.4 billion for a 50 percent stake in Consol Energy’s venture in the huge Marcellus shale formation, reflecting the strong demand for natural gas assets.

headline: The ‘I’m Fine’ Shortstop Is Proving He Is

headline: The Dollar-Store Economy
text: Heather Mann writes a blog called Dollar Store Crafts, which evolved from her occasional trips to the extreme-discount dollar stores near her home in Salem, Ore. Her readers admire her gift for buying really cheap stuff and then making cool and beautiful things from the pile. Her knockoff “alien abduction lamp” is jury-rigged from a small light fixture, two plastic bowls (flying saucer), a clear acrylic tumbler (tractor beam) and a small plastic toy cow (abductee) — all purchased for about five bucks.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Strikes $11.7 Billion Deal; Plans to Spin Off P.C. Unit

headline: Bank of America Names Executive to Oversee Bad Loan Portfolio

headline: AT&T Plans to Offer Only an Unlimited Texting Plan
text: AT&T said Thursday that it is getting rid of its lower-tier texting plan that lets people pay $10 a month for 1,000 text messages. Instead, the company plans to offer new subscribers only one plan: unlimited texting for $20 a month. Those who don’t want to fork over $20 can choose to pay for each text, starting at 20 cents a message.

headline: Finding a Quality Doctor
text: “Quality.” It’s one of those words that used to mean something: actual quality you could trust. Nowadays in hospital hallways, quality is a charged word that is more corporate-speak than actual English, eliciting stomach churning and eye rolling in equal measures.

headline: Coloring Outside the Lines
text: FOR many of her 73 years, Audrey Heckler lived what she herself described as an unremarkable and sometimes unsatisfying life.

headline: 20 Years After Soviet Fall, Some Look Back Longingly
text: MOSCOW — Gennady Veretelny was shot and wounded when he stepped forward unarmed 20 years ago to help stop a column of armored vehicles in central Moscow, one of the few casualties of the last, failed attempt to preserve the Soviet Union.

headline: Colleagues Rally Around Shot Detective
text: After a veteran New York City police detective, Harold Thomas, was shot and seriously wounded while vacationing in Florida last month, the head of his union, Michael J. Palladino of the Detectives’ Endowment Association, was among the colleagues who traveled to Detective Thomas’s bedside.

headline: Fables
text: James Jean made his name painting covers for the comic book Fables.

headline: Poetry Pairing | Roads Not Taken
text: We’re doing something new with our Poetry Pairings starting today.

headline: Mortgage Rates Hit 50-Year Low
text: Back in June, in a post about adjustable-rate home loans, Bucks mused about how nice it would be to have a mortgage interest rate that began with a “3.” The way things are going, that time may not be far off for fixed-rates loans, as well.

headline: Stephen Malkmus and Beck's “Mirror Traffic”; War on Drugs on their new record; plus new releases by Jeff Bridges and others.
text: This week we hear about a slacker summit: Dave Itzkoff talks about “Mirror Traffic,” the new album collaboration by Stephen Malkmus and Beck; then the War on Drugs drops by to discuss both their new record, “Slave Ambient,” and bad Google results; and we listen to new releases by Jeff Bridges and others. Jeremy Egner is the host.

headline: ‘Big Brother’ Lifts CBS in Ratings
text: The lull before the fall television season is officially upon us, as the broadcast networks continue to wind down their summer programming with repeats and the required minimum of reality shows. On Wednesday night, CBS was the most-watched network, courtesy of “Big Brother,” which reached season highs in total viewers (just under 8 million) and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic.

headline: Ranking Google’s Hefty Motorola Breakup Fee
text: Google gave Motorola Mobility some sizable assurances that it was committed to buying the cellphone maker for $12.5 billion. As part of the deal, Google offered to pay a $2.5 billion reverse termination fee, according to a regulatory filing on Thursday.

headline: Foursquare Lets Users Check In to Events
text: Foursquare, the location-based social network that lets users tell their friends where they are, announced new features on Thursday that allow check-ins at events, like concerts or movies, instead of just the places where those events are happening.

headline: Paula & Randal
text: In this homemade video, Paula Derrow says she's glad that she waited until she was 48 to get married. Her fiancee Randal Chinnock says he's also glad that she waited.

headline: Rhapsody Strikes Deal with MetroPCS for Bundled Music
text: Rhapsody, the subscription digital music service, has struck a deal with the wireless phone carrier MetroPCS to offer its service as part of a monthly bundle plan.

headline: Deadly Attacks on Israelis Near Egypt
text: Attackers mounted at least three separate strikes near the Red Sea resort of Eilat on Thursday. The Israeli military said the attacks originated in Gaza.

headline: Stocks Tumble Amid Economic Worries
text: Graham Bowley discusses European bank funding.

headline: Ex-Lehman Banker May Avoid Drug Arrest Prosecution
text: Bradley H. Jack, a former investment banking chief at Lehman Brothers, received court approval on Thursday to enter a program that could allow him to avoid prosecution on charges that he forged a prescription for Oxycontin and Ritalin.

headline: Have Solar Panels, Will Travel
text: A thing of sheer beauty is berthed in Victoria Harbor in Hong Kong: the Tûranor PlanetSolar, a vessel that is circumnavigating the globe to prove that solar energy can power water transportation.

headline: If You Can Vacation Here … Part 2
text: It’s been more than a decade since I’ve spent an entire summer, straight through, in New York City. It’s a brutal prospect, what with the steaming pavements and bone-wilting humidity, but if it has to be done, it should be done right. So this summer, armed with my girlfriend and my Metrocard, I set out to design the perfect balance of work, play and sunshine. Herewith I give you my staycation story, a real New Yorker’s guide to not losing your mind between May Day and Labor Day Weekend. Part 2: The George Washington Bridge, Fire Island and Ocean Grove.

headline: Popcast: Stephen Malkmus, Beck and the War on Drugs
text: This week, Dave Itzkoff talks about “Mirror Traffic,” the new album by Stephen Malkmus and the Jicks. The record, Mr. Malkmus’s fifth since leaving Pavement, was produced by Beck Hansen. It’s the first collaboration by the indie elder statesmen, though they’ve been acquainted since the 1990s alt-rock heyday. Although the pairing would seem to jibe with the current strain of ’90s revivalism, listeners shouldn’t expect a Gen X nostalgia act, Mr. Itzkoff said.

headline: Wheelies: The $2 Per Gallon Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Art Books Elevate Picassos of Pulp
text: THE place of comic books at the cultural supper table has never been more secure. Summertime films have come to mean superhero movies. Comics-related museum shows and gallery exhibitions are a regular part of the art world palette. And the market for original comic-book art continues to be strong. Just this May a bold, full-page drawing of Batman and Robin by Frank Miller and Klaus Janson — from the groundbreaking 1986 series “Batman: The Dark Knight Returns” — sold at auction for an emphatic $448,125.

headline: Comics Canonization
text: A gallery of books aimed at serious fans of the comic book as art form.

headline: Teenagers Highlight U.S. Open Women’s Wild Cards
text: Lauren Davis, fresh off her victory in the United States Tennis Association’s Girls 18s national championships, was awarded one of eight wild cards into the women’s main draw of the United States Open.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Vegan Journey
text: After undergoing two separate heart procedures since leaving office a decade ago, former President Bill Clinton changed his diet to slow the progression of heart disease. But when a doctor told him that more “intensive changes” were needed for someone with his family history of heart disease, Mr. Clinton -– the man famous for his love of McDonald’s and junk food -– went vegan, or nearly so. “At Thanksgiving, I had one bite of turkey,” he told CNN’s chief medical correspondent, Dr. Sanjay Gupta.

headline: Road Back to Russia, Paved With a Play
text: I HAD vowed never to come back. But here Mother Russia was calling me to Moscow, my former stomping ground, for an extraordinary opportunity: to hear my Broadway-bound play “The Mountaintop” translated into Russian for a public reading last March as part of a prestigious theater festival. How could I turn it down?

headline: Dunkin’ Donuts Opens Shop in Sims’ Universe
text: The stimulative effects of coffee have long been celebrated in the popular culture, as evidenced by tunes like “The Coffee Song” and “Coffee Break” from the musical “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.” But how much can coffee energize people in a virtual world?

headline: In Montana, the Wind and the Wide Open Spaces
text: HAVRE, Mont. — Montana is so enormous it makes a cyclist feel as though he were standing still. I crossed the border from Idaho nine days ago, and I’ve been eating up reasonable chunks of daily mileage this week — except for the day off I took today — but I am only barely across the center line of the state. It’s still about 300 miles to the North Dakota line.

headline: Black Scientists Less Likely to Win Federal Research Grants, Study Reports
text: A research grant application from a black scientist to the National Institutes of Health is markedly less likely to win approval than one from a white scientist, a new study reported on Thursday.

headline: Dear FloFab: My (Brother/Boyfriend/Colleague) Eats Like an Animal
text: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 18
text: The day in sports included winter sports in New Zealand, LeBron James in China and Bolivian squirrel monkeys.

headline: Ridley Scott Will Take Another Run at ‘Blade Runner’
text: “It’s too bad she won’t live,” Edward James Olmos tells Harrison Ford in “Blade Runner.” “But then again, who does?” And then again, there are those movies that just live on forever: Ridley Scott, who directed that moody 1982 science-fiction film noir, will direct and produce a new feature that is being described as a “Blade Runner” follow-up for Alcon Entertainment, a Warner Brothers-based financing and production company, its press representatives said on Thursday.

headline: Connecticut Workers Approve Contract They Had Rejected
text: HARTFORD — Two months after Connecticut workers rejected an agreement meant to save $1.6 billion over two years, union leaders said on Thursday that they had accepted the same deal, bowing to the threat of layoffs in a year full of battles between unions and state governments.

headline: Warren Files to Test the Senate Waters
text: 3:50 p.m. | Updated Elizabeth Warren formed an exploratory committee on Thursday morning as she continues to consider a run for the Senate in Massachusetts, and her camp maintains that she is still doing just that: exploring. But given their gleeful reaction to this news, Bay State and some national Democrats seem primed for a painful letdown if Ms. Warren, a Harvard Law professor, ultimately decides against challenging Senator Scott Brown.

headline: 36 Seconds in Lower Manhattan
text: Although progress on the World Trade Center site has been slow, the surrounding neighborhoods did not wait to revive.

headline: 36 Hours in Lower Manhattan
text: With the exception of those seeking a night of club-hopping, travelers hardly need venture north of Canal Street for a complete New York weekend.

headline: 36 Hours in Downtown Manhattan
text: ONE WORLD TRADE CENTER is rising, and the 9/11 Memorial will open right below it next month on the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks. Although progress on the World Trade Center site has been slow, the surrounding neighborhoods did not wait to revive (and in some cases reinvent themselves) after all the emotional and economic devastation. The financial district is bustling, Chinatown is as quirky and enticing as ever, and TriBeCa is bursting with new restaurants, bars and hotels. With the exception of those seeking a night of relentless club-hopping, travelers hardly need venture north of Canal Street for a complete New York weekend.

headline: Medical Debt Cited More Often in Bankruptcies
text: Medical debt is increasingly a factor in personal bankruptcy filings, an analysis of data at a large credit-counseling agency finds.

headline: Before 9/11 Ceremony, Back-Room Maneuvers
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rebuffed concerns on Thursday that the 10th anniversary ceremony for 9/11 had grown excessively politicized, shrugging off reports of kerfuffles over the guest list and itinerary at the day’s memorial event.

headline: Only The Finest Kind
text: Maine, to the outsider’s view, seems as food-conscious right now as California. (The Winter/Spring issue of Maine Policy Review, devoted to food and with a very cool cover, is 250 pages, some of which are even worth reading.) Of course it’s all whom you talk to, but it sure was easy enough to meet people who wanted to talk food. (And that, as we know, is happening everywhere, increasingly. Good.)

headline: Euro-Style Anxiety Spreads
text: European banks are continuing to show signs of strain, making investors increasingly skittish about American financial institutions.

headline: Requests for Collateral Pose a Hurdle for Greek Bailout
text: LONDON — Greece’s international bailout hit a new obstacle Thursday when three euro zone countries indicated they were likely to seek collateral in exchange for their loan. Finland earlier reached a similar deal with the debt-laden government in Athens.

headline: Economic Miracle Eludes Germany’s Lowest-Paid

headline: Spokesman Fired After Chinese Train Crash Has New Job

headline: H.P. Weighs Spinning Off Its PC Unit
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In a sweeping change for Hewlett-Packard, Leo Apotheker, the technology giant’s chief executive, said Thursday that he was considering spinning off the company’s personal computer business into a separate company and spending $10 billion on Autonomy, a business software maker.

headline: Perry and Romney Assail Obama on Syria
text: PEMBROKE, N.H. — When Gov. Rick Perry of Texas left Popovers on the Square in Portsmouth, N.H., on Thursday morning, he ignored a television reporter who asked him if had a comment about the news that President Obama had called for Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, to step down. But by his third stop of the day, Mr. Perry had an answer ready.
