headline: A Novel of Grief, Memorials and a Muslim Architect in Post-9/11 America
text: When, in December 2009, The New York Times first reported plans for a Muslim community center in Lower Manhattan, there was little controversy. Only subsequently, as a result of protests organized by groups like the Freedom Defense Initiative and Stop Islamization of America, did the project become the subject of passionate debate. It was they who named the community center the “ground zero mosque.” In the months that followed, other vociferous opponents of the project emerged, among them not only conservative politicians like Newt Gingrich and some of the families of victims of 9/11, but also a number of Muslim leaders, who felt that the choice of site was insensitive and would complicate Muslim relations with the broader community. The controversy gave rise to a media frenzy that reached its height in the late summer of 2010. One imagines that the former New York Times journalist Amy Waldman heard these arguments with a combination of recognition and, perhaps, faint dismay: the general topic of her as yet unpublished first novel, “The Submission,” was proving disturbingly prescient. Her carefully imagined fiction was in the process of becoming fact.

headline: Last Lullaby for My Son
text: “I was afraid I’d hurt him. Before he was born, I was afraid that I would hurt my son,” Kelle Groom writes of her infant child in her memoir, “I Wore the Ocean in the Shape of a Girl.” For decades, Groom did not ask for details about Tommy, the son she’d had at age 19, whom she’d given up to her aunt and uncle to raise, and who died from leukemia at 14 months.

headline: Are All of Our Leaders Mad?
text: After examining the psychological histories of a few living leaders and a whole little power necropolis, Nassir Ghaemi, director of the Mood Disorders Program at Tufts University Medical Center, is ready to proclaim a link between madness and achievement that is usually reserved for poets, not prime ministers: “Depression makes leaders more realistic and empathic, and mania makes them more creative and resilient.” It may be fine to like Ike during periods of smooth sailing, but Lincoln and a little lunacy are the ticket when seas get rough: “For abnormal challenges,” Ghaemi insists, “abnormal leaders are needed.” The text makes only one reference to the current president, warning us that while “ ‘No drama’ Obama might be considered the epitome of mental health,” we must remember that “psychological moderation” is not the prescription for greatness.

headline: A Tale of a Highly Articulate Cuckold
text: Anyone reading William Giraldi’s first novel, “Busy Monsters,” will be struck by its narrative voice. So let’s start there, with some excerpts. Here’s the narrator on the fatigue of his labors: “So much to celebrate, and me standing there a spiritual syphilitic, mangled mental-wise from too much tumble.”

headline: Seeds, Germs and Slaves
text: “There’s a chain of events in this best of all possible worlds,” Dr. Pangloss says at the end of Voltaire’s “Candide.” “If you hadn’t been caught up in the Inquisition, or walked across America . . . you would not be here eating candied fruit and pistachio nuts.”

headline: Middle School Mischief
text: Wouldn’t it be nice if “Diary of a Sweet-Natured Kid” were the best-selling young adult book of the last couple of years? Instead, we’ve got this horrible little human being, Greg Heffley, protagonist of “Diary of a Wimpy Kid.” Not really wimpy, he’s better described as a deceitful, self-absorbed, scheming, arrogant, callous kid.

headline: Being the New Kid Isn’t Easy
text: Will you be my friend? With the possible exception of “Does this look infected?,” there is no more off-putting question. Friends are like handkerchiefs: everybody needs them, but the sight of someone asking for one is so mortifyingly vulnerable that you want to avert your eyes from the whole mess. As with handkerchiefs, it’s probably best not to look at friendship too closely, at least until you’ve had it around for a while. We stick with our friends for an entanglement of reasons, and three new picture books, while ostensibly feel-good tales about making friends, turn out to be much closer to the complicated and murky truth than one might guess from their cheery covers. Also, two of the books have splendid artwork.

headline: Middle School Angst
text: Over the course of his amazingly prolific and varied writing career, James Howe, perhaps best known for his “Bunnicula” vampire rabbit series, has established himself as a beloved and elegant voice in children’s literature. The first two of his “Misfits” books — 2001’s “The Misfits” and 2005’s “Totally Joe” — were masterworks of middle school angst, powerful in their ability to impart lessons about difference and empathy in highly readable stories that Disney-jaded preteens could both enjoy and relate to.

headline: Tales of a Fourth-Grade Something
text: At a certain point in our lives something terrific happens — the stops and starts of reading begin to flow and we are able to turn our complete attention to the text itself. For many children at this stage, the familiar rules: they take particular pleasure in reading about someone in a school with routines and structures not unlike their own and enjoy meeting, in a series, their beloved characters again and again. Unconventionally designed books appeal as well — say an ersatz journal filled with just the sorts of notes and sketches the young reader could imagine making herself. Back in 1995, Marissa Moss successfully used all three of these elements in “Amelia’s Notebook.” Now, 23 books later, as her title character makes her way through middle school, she has a series for younger readers, “Daphne’s Diary of Daily Disasters.”

headline: Divided by Date Rape
text: In the classic star-crossed romance, a crime forces a choice between youthful passion and family loyalty. For Romeo and Juliet, it’s the murder of Mercutio; for Tony and Maria, it’s the knife fight between Sharks and Jets. This is how tentative adolescent love turns into high drama. Parents don’t object to boyfriends or girlfriends for being taciturn or tattooed. They object because of a blood feud.

headline: Elephants in the Room
text: Few creatures can compete with elephants when it comes to being both magnificent and ungainly, but human children, if we’re being honest with ourselves, come close. This sense of distant kinship, plus the fact that trunks are the coolest appendages this side of opposable thumbs, may be why elephants have been a staple of children’s literature since the days of Rudyard Kipling and Jean de Brunhoff. True, they’re not quite so numerous on the bookshelf as bunnies, mice and ducklings, but they outnumber squids by a long shot, and, what with their tree-stump legs, bulky bodies, sail-like ears and those sinuous trunks, elephants are surely more fun for illustrators to draw than just about anything, aside from explosions. So elephants: bring ’em on!

headline: Shy, Bookish and Beastly Creatures
text: For young children, making that first friend bears all the weight and tension that wooing a potential sweetheart does for 17-year-olds. And if you’re shy, bookish or beastly, the task is all the more awkward, as three delightful picture book debuts make expressively and tenderly clear.

headline: Chanda Ouk and Matthew Wolf
text: LOWELL, Mass., represented two very different things to the teenagers Matthew Wolf and Chanda Ouk. But for both, it became a place for hope, and eventually love, to blossom.

headline: Children’s Bookshelf: Back to School
text: Picture books about school and imaginative play.

headline: Bookshelf: Back to School
text: KINDERGATORS: HANDS OFF, HARRY!  Written and illustrated by Rosemary Wells 40 pp. Katherine Tegen/HarperCollins. $14.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)

headline: Next Up: W.P.S. Championship Game
text: I’ve been part of an underdog team that’s defied the odds.

headline: Big Three Increase Their Financial Footprint on Woodward Dream Cruise
text: DETROIT — After a lengthy spell in the doldrums, and encouraged by improved sales, domestic carmakers are stepping up involvement in the Woodward Dream Cruise, suburban Detroit’s annual paean to all things automotive.

headline: Tweet Birds of Youth
text: “Tweets from Tahrir”The New York artist Michael Waugh’s T features, at a glance, three gorgeous, menacing eagles intertwined to form the rather gothic moniker of this magazine. What is less apparent is that every line, every feathery stroke of Waugh’s pen and ink drawing, contains words, and specifically the words that were tweeted from Tahrir Square last February, which preceded the fall of Hosni Mubarak and his government. Scroll across the work above and glimpse an account of a revolution in progress.

headline: Adolescent Health | Nutrition, Healthy Weight and Eating Disorders
text: To wrap up Adolescent Health Week, here is our collection of materials on nutrition, healthy weight and eating disorders, including coverage of Michelle Obama’s antichildhood obesity initiative and growing criticism of many school lunch programs.

headline: F.T.C. Says It Will Not Investigate Ashton Kutcher
text: It looks like Ashton Kutcher is in the clear.

headline: Tomato Water (Remember That?) Charms Once Again
text: IN the 1990s, chefs around the country seemed mesmerized by an intense translucent liquid, a nectar of the vegetable garden: tomato water. Brightly flavored yet almost invisible, it was the clear essence of summer in spoonable form.

headline: H.G.H. Testing in N.F.L. Not in Place, Union Says
text: Two weeks after the N.F.L. announced that, starting this season, every player would be tested for human growth hormone at least once a year, and possibly many more times, its players union says there may be no H.G.H. testing at all.

headline: An Inmate’s Letter Recalls a Certain Summer
text: “I was in London for a moment,” the letter began. “Just long enough to learn how to walk and talk and gather a few memories before leaving for Staten Island, where I grew up. Grew up too fast in some respects but not fast enough to outgrow the adolescent flaws and shortcomings of character to which I would steadily succumb in a bad way.”

headline: Confidence in Obama, and in the Economy, Declines
text: Markets “go up and down,” the White House press secretary Jay Carney noted this month. So do presidential approval ratings. But the trendline for President Obama has been poor.

headline: In Quiet End to Career, Drury Retires From N.H.L.
text: Chris Drury, the low-key and widely admired former captain of the Rangers, retired Friday, less than two months after agreeing to a buyout from the team, and one day before he turned 35.

headline: Benz’s Biturbo V-8s: Red-Hot and Greener
text: IN recent decades, luxury automakers in particular have been criticized — and in some cases, heavily fined — for obsessing over power at the expense of fuel economy.

headline: Beauty Contestants With Curves, Talent and German Accents
text: ONE carmaker after another is proposing an answer to a question: how do you show off lavish wheels without looking like, well, a show-off?

headline: Caucus Video: Perry on the Campaign Trail; Presidential Vacations
text: Jeff Zeleny on the opening week of Rick Perry’s campaign, and a report from Martha’s Vineyard on President Obama’s working vacation.

headline: The Caucus | Rick Perry's Up & Down Week
text: Aug. 19, 2011 - Jeff Zeleny on Rick Perry’s opening week of the campaign, and a report from Martha’s Vineyard on President Obama's working vacation.

headline: Another Luxury Hotel Perk: A Car at Your Disposal
text: Free chocolates on the pillow are nice, but some luxury hotels are upping the ante with fancy cars for guests to use at no charge. Misty Ewing, the director of public relations for Virtuoso, a luxury travel network, said it was “a huge convenience for guests” and “helps in building traveler loyalty.”

headline: Doctors, Tired and Well Rested, Weigh In
text: Many doctors wrote into the comments section for our article on doctor training hours.

headline: Why Not Ryan?
text: Earlier this week I promised a post explaining why I think Chris Christie would make a better late-entering challenger in the Republican field than Paul Ryan. Since then the chatter surrounding a Ryan run has increased, but at the same time a number of writers have highlighted obvious difficulties with his potential candidacy. (See Byron York, Philip Klein, Allahpundit, Daniel Larison, Jim Antle and Ed Kilgore, among others.) Rather than recapitulating all of their points, I just want to draw three Christie-Ryan contrasts.

headline: Husband Admits He Set Up Killing of Wife in Street, the Police Say
text: BOONTON, N.J. — After his wife had been shot to death on the street and he had been wounded, Kashif Parvaiz told the police here in her quiet hometown in New Jersey that three men had accosted them and, before opening fire, called them a name that is offensive to Muslims in America: “Terrorist.”

headline: A Paradise for Plant Diversity
text: Paola Pedraza, assistant curator of the Institute of Systematic Botany at the New York Botanical Garden, writes about her recent expedition to catalog the flora of Las Orquídeas National Park, Colombia.

headline: Bossy Pants
text: Whether two-tone, textured or regimentally striped, the new trouser dictates the look.

headline: A Prime-Time True-Crime Spree
text: MURDER is in retreat in the United States, down from a high of more than 24,000 killings in 1991 to just over 15,000 last year.

headline: A Confection of Pop, and Newport Chops
text: Sam Yahel

headline: It Happened One Night at the Cheetah
text: EARLY in the salsa documentary “Our Latin Thing (Nuestra Cosa),” a 40th anniversary version of which will be released Tuesday, the master percussionist Ray Barretto is asked what he wants the movie to accomplish. He responds that he hopes it will become a vehicle through which “our Latin music and culture goes out all over the world.”

headline: Chevrolet Small-Block V-8: the Little Engine That Still Can
text: Chevrolet, marking its 100th anniversary this week with its sponsorship of metro Detroit’s Woodward Dream Cruise, announced on Thursday that it would build the 100 millionth version of its small-block V-8 engine this year.

headline: Distracted at the Concert Hall
text: James Oestreich, a critic for The New York Times, set out last month to review a concert at Lincoln Center featuring the works of Mozart and Stravinsky. But Mr. Oestreich found himself more focused on the man seated directly behind him, who was connected to an oxygen cart or similar medical device that emitted what he called a steady — and apparently disruptive — ticking sound.

headline: The 30-Minute Interview | Andrew Barrocas
text: Mr. Barrocas, 32, is the chief executive of the brokerage firm MNS, formerly known as TDG/Tregny, after the 2009 merger of the Developers Group and the Real Estate Group New York. The company, which changed its name last spring, provides in-house marketing for its residential listings, including new developments like One Brooklyn Bridge Park and the Edge in Williamsburg .

headline: Q & A
text: A Co-op Neighbor Becomes Abusive

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 19
text: The day in sports included hot air ballooning in Poland, kayaking in Hungary and BMX racing in London.

headline: Trader in Insider Case Speaks Out Again
text: Most people accused of insider trading hunker down and let their lawyers do the talking.

headline: Copyright Lawsuit Against Ryan McGinley Dismissed
text: A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a copyright lawsuit filed against the photographer Ryan McGinley by another photographer who claimed that he relied too heavily on her work for his inspiration.

headline: Clip: 'Circumstance'
text: A scene from the film "Circumstance," about teenage women coming of age in Tehran.

headline: Green Respite for a Bustling Delhi Suburb
text: Amid the high-rise office buildings, towering apartment complexes and sprawling construction sites, green pockets are hard to find in Gurgaon, a New Delhi suburb that is home to the back-office operations of some of the world’s biggest companies. So the local government, private companies and citizens have banded together to plant a million trees.

headline: Questioning the Dogma of Tax Rates
text: Warren Buffett pays a lower tax rate than his secretary and the 19 other people who work in his office. He pays a much lower rate than I do, and, I suspect, lower than nearly everyone reading this column. So, no doubt, do a long list of American billionaires, including Stephen Schwarzman of Blackstone and the hedge fund king John Paulson.

headline: Inside the List
text: ODD COUPLES: Dog books have long been a staple of the best-seller list. But has the world ever seen as probing a work of zoological investigative reporting as “Unlikely Friendships: 47 Remarkable Stories From the Animal Kingdom”? Jennifer S. Holland’s irresistible volume, No. 7 in its sixth week on the paperback nonfiction list, features heartwarming stories of interspecies love and adorable photographs that are heart-stopping in more than one sense. Everything seems copacetic between the nearsighted deer and the black poodle shown canoodling on a bed in Canal Fulton, Ohio, but one wonders about the long-term stability of the relationship between the polar bear and the sled dog shown cavorting in the Canadian Arctic, not to mention the lioness and baby oryx shown strolling together in Kenya’s Samburu National Reserve.

headline: Living and Loving Underground in Iran
text: SHORTLY before she began shooting the film “Circumstance,” her first experience in front of a camera, the law student and soon-to-be actress Sarah Kazemy flew from her home in France to visit relatives in Iran. She anticipated that the movie, which focuses on the lesbian romance of two Tehran teenagers rebelling against a puritanical Islamic theocracy, would make it difficult for her to return there for the foreseeable future, and she wanted to say her farewells to people and a country that she loves.

headline: Banks Ease Stance on Short Sales
text: STANDING by while her mother was evicted from her home in Tinton Falls for the few thousand dollars she owed in mortgage payments in the 1990s had a big influence on Kim Hale and her career choices. A new nursing school graduate at the time, Ms. Hale said she had had no idea how to help her mother, who was “too embarrassed to reach out to anyone.”

headline: Reports: New Meadowlands Soon to Be MetLife Stadium
text: New Meadowlands Stadium will be renamed for MetLife, the insurance company, possibly as early as next week. The Jets and Giants, who have been without the income from a naming rights deal, would split $17 million to $20 million annually over 20 years, according to published reports.

headline: New Mini Coupe Contends With a $52,000 Distraction at Pebble Beach
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — A limited-edition Mini Cooper model, packed with luxury appointments usually reserved for Rolls-Royce cars, siphoned some of the excitement from the North American debut of the Mini Coupe.

headline: Market Boos for Hewlett Transformation
text: If Thursday was “Day 1 of the transformation” of Hewlett-Packard, Day 2 was something much less inspiring.

headline: Living In | Roseland, N.J.
text: A place that still feels a lot like a farm town, Roseland is affordable, especially for Essex County.

headline: Streaming Video’s Emerging Bounty
text: AT this point in its evolution streaming video can still feel like your neighborhood VHS rental shop, circa 1985.

headline: Where the Taxes Are Below Average
text: CLAUDIA REIS and her husband, Scott Gorman, loved the comforts and convenience of condo living in Springfield, in Union County. But that changed somewhat when the couple, lawyers who commute to Morristown (her) and Hackensack (him), had their first child three years ago. They decided they needed a house — and a town — in which a family could nestle.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Ghost Stories
text: The manga list has the only new arrival this week and it is a “three-in-one” edition of Bleach, a series about Ichigo Kurosaki, who sees dead people and must usher them safely into the afterlife. This reprint edition collects three volumes of the regular manga series and arrives at No. 7. In the latest twist, Mr. Kurosaki must cope with a reality show that features live exorcisms.

headline: Couch Potatoes
text: Siri Tollerød and Meghan Collison lounge around in a mix of two-tone, striped and textured trousers. A film by Julian De Zorzi.

headline: Ecclestone’s Bluesy Gift to His Daughter
text: It is no coincidence that Bernie Ecclestone has hired Eric Clapton and the Black Eyed Peas to perform at the marriage of his daughter, Petra. Formula One racing – and auto racing in general – goes together with music, especially rock music. And in recent years, the Formula One paddock has played host to a lot of musicians who are also fans.

headline: Ecclestone’s Bluesy Gift to His Daughter
text: It is no coincidence that Bernie Ecclestone has hired Eric Clapton and the Black Eyed Peas to perform at the marriage of his daughter, Petra. Formula One racing – and auto racing in general – goes together with music, especially rock music. And in recent years, the Formula One paddock has played host to a lot of musicians who are also fans.

headline: For Some Banks, Prices Are Below 2008
text: Which banks don’t you trust?

headline: Letters: Keeping Data Fees Low
text: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column (Aug. 14): I recommend the Amazon Kindle 3G’s free international service. Not only can I download books (very nice to avoid carting around a dozen travel guides), but I also can check e-mail while riding the Hong Kong subway and find directions to my hotel, like when a New Delhi cabbie got lost. I think the only country I visited where Amazon didn’t have coverage was Vietnam.

headline: Lost in the Odyssey
text: SING to me of the man, O Muse — that cleverest of men, most favored by the gods, most frustrated by them, too. Sing to me of endlessly lost Odysseus, whose 10-year journey home, from the scorched and blood-stained plains of Troy to the Ionian island of Ithaca, was a decade of disaster. Sing to me of the Cyclops, the Sirens, Calypso and Circe, Scylla and Charybdis, of challenges confronted and conquered, destiny delayed and at long last achieved.

headline: Design Ateliers Set Up Shop in Istanbul
text: ON an unseasonably warm day last winter the tap-tap of a jeweler’s hammer mingled with the clink of espresso cups in Istanbul’s Galata neighborhood. Just a few strides from the neo-bohemians idling at tables outside the cafe-cum-boutique Mavra, the jewelry designer Janset Bilgin hunched over a workbench in her tiny atelier fusing silver, gray labradorite and strips of silk into a bold, chunky necklace.

headline: Restaurant Report: Lou’s Food Bar in Denver
text: Denver residents who have been to one of the six restaurants and bars run by Frank Bonnano would most likely agree that the experience means good food and service to match. With Lou’s Food Bar, which opened late last year, the 43-year-old chef has broadened his repertory with an American rendition of a French bistro that has quickly helped to add more followers to his already loyal customer base.

headline: Letters: The High Cost of Dialing Abroad
text: To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column (Aug. 7): Whenever I go abroad, I take out my old, junky unlocked Motorola (which I got from a used-phone dealer in Queens) and buy a local SIM card for my destination, which is usually available via mail-order online (so that you have the phone number before you leave town). The result? Full use of a phone in Scotland for two weeks, including calls home: total price, around $30 ($20 for the card, plus a fill-up). The only time I ever had to buy a card at my destination was in Iceland, and there I got hooked up for around $45 total. If you need smartphone features, tote along a tablet that is Wi-Fi enabled and get your local instant maps and such that way.

headline: Bivouacking in Oregon’s Back of Beyond
text: ON a chilly afternoon in late June, we stood contemplating our options in an icy Oregon rain that pricked our skin like needles. The canyon’s 300-foot-high walls of chocolate rhyolite had corralled the river into a pool too deep to wade through, too cold to swim in. Turning back would mean a grueling two-day retreat upstream. If we pushed ahead we could be out in a day. The decision was painful but clear: time to strip and swim.

headline: Hotel Review: House Hotel Bosphorus, in Istanbul
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Step by Step, Hut by Hut in Colorado
text: DURING a recent trek along a mountain trail in the central Colorado Rockies, I found signs of those who had come before me. These weren’t fellow hikers, though, but soldiers. One patch near the trail was pitted with foxholes — scooped-out hollows, with one raised side, like a shield, the whole thing grown over with grass.

headline: For the Closets of Kuala Lumpur’s Style Obsessed
text: One of Kuala Lumpur’s oldest suburbs, Bangsar is bringing hip boutiques in stylish malls to the area.

headline: Oregon’s Outback
text: A four-day, 50-mile exploratory hike through Louse Canyon in southeastern Oregon.

headline: In Odysseus’ Footsteps
text: Matt Gross’s plan was to stumble in his footsteps and try to get a glimpse into his psyche as he tried and failed and tried again to reach Ithaca.

headline: This Is Not Their Lives. Really. It’s Not.
text: NED is a patsy, a goof, an innocent: a naïf in a striped tank top and red Crocs, trying to navigate a world populated by tricksters. He loves his dog (a grinning golden retriever named Willie Nelson), cultivating organic vegetables, taking the occasional toke and playing charades with his mom and sisters. He is often seen scratching a cascade of wavy brown hair or reading a book about aromatherapy. He spent time in jail for handing a baggie of weed to a uniformed cop, but only after the officer said he’d been having a hard week.

headline: A Year Full of Weather Disasters and an Economic Toll to Match
text: The weather this year has not only been lousy, it has been as destructive in terms of economic loss as any on record.

headline: In Rajasthan’s Push for Sterilization, Tata Nano Is Offered as an Incentive
text: The prospect of winning a Tata Nano city car is one of the incentives being used to attract Indians to a sterilization program in the Jhunjhunu district of Rajasthan, roughly 130 miles west of New Delhi.

headline: Sexy Beast
text: The photographer Danko Steiner and his wife, the stylist Ana Steiner, dress their femme fatale, a k a Hanaa Abdesslem, in fall’s wildest all-over and to-the-floor furs.

headline: From Convertibles to Rentals
text: Port Jefferson Station

headline: Steps-From-Work Housing
text: WINDSOR

headline: Raoul Ruiz — In Memoriam
text: The great filmmaker Raoul Ruiz, died this morning in Paris, at 70, from a lung infection. Just six short weeks ago, A.O. Scott interviewed him for this magazine, in anticipation of the release of his most recent film, “Mysteries of Lisbon,” which has been hailed by many critics as a masterpiece. Ruiz was in poor health for some time, following the discovery of a cancerous tumor in his liver. It is a testament to his spirit that he made time to sit and talk, ranging in his conversation across eras and disciplines, just as he does in his remarkable films. As Scott wrote:

headline: The Caucus | Presidential Downtime
text: Aug. 19, 2011 - Mark Landler reports from Martha's Vineyard on President Obama's working vacation.

headline: Lawyer Tied to Galleon Case Gets 3-Year Prison Term
text: The government’s vast insider trading investigation of Raj Rajaratnam, the now-convicted billionaire investor, has ensnared prominent management consultants, corporate executives and hedge fund managers.

headline: Nearing 1,000 Feet, 1 World Trade Center Joins the Skyline
text: From New Jersey especially, but even in mid-Manhattan’s canyons, 1 World Trade Center has asserted itself among the city’s skyscrapers.

headline: Adventure Beyond the South Pole
text: ON a stormy summer afternoon Ethan Stiefel sat in a noisy Mexican restaurant a few blocks south of Lincoln Center wearing a T-shirt with the words “Wisconsin. We conserve.”

headline: Ackman Moves to Raise His Stake in J.C. Penney
text: William A. Ackman likes a good sale.

headline: Sixth Death Is Reported in Indiana Stage Collapse
text: A 22-year-old Indiana woman died Friday of injuries sustained at the stage collapse at the Indiana State Fair last week, becoming the sixth person to die as a result of the accident.

headline: 'Our Latin Thing (Nuestra Cosa)'
text: The Larry Harlow orchestra and Johnny Pacheco performed "Lamento de un Guajiro" in "Our Latin Thing (Nuestra Cosa)." A 40th anniversary edition of the 1971 documentary is being released on DVD.

headline: Community Stands Strong to Block an Eviction
text: From inside Mary Lee Ward’s small and sparsely furnished living room in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, it sounded Friday as if a block party was in full swing in the street below. Cars and trucks honked their horns as they passed and almost 200 voices could be heard cheering and chanting.

headline: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 19
text: A look back at the week’s events in New York City and the region.

headline: Detective in Phone Hacking Inquiry Is Arrested
text: LONDON — A Scotland Yard detective has been arrested on suspicion of leaking details about the phone hacking case to the news media, the police said on Friday.

headline: Kin of Norway Victims Visit Scene of Shootings
text: OSLO — Relatives of victims killed on the Norwegian island of Utoya last month traveled to the site of the massacre for the first time on Friday, and with the aid of the police, clergy members and counselors, were able to walk through their loved ones’ last moments.

headline: Big Deal | A SoHo Pad That Screams ‘Bachelor’
text: Brokers have to be quite careful when choosing the language in real estate listings.

headline: A Smattering of This Week’s Food Links
text: Slow Food USA is issuing the “$5 Challenge” to “take back the value meal.” Want to participate? On Sept. 17, get together with family and friends and cook a “slow food meal” that costs no more than $5 per person. I’ve been saying it for years: cooking, even with great ingredients, can be soooo cheap.

headline: A Ratings Victory for Fox Football
text: Another nationally televised preseason National Football League game, another victory in the ratings. The nastiness caused by the owners’ lockout does not appear to have dimmed football fans’ ardor for the game, even for preseason games. The Fox telecast of the the Pittsburgh Steelers and Philadelphia Eagles exhibition game drew an estimated average of 8.7 million viewers in the 8 p.m. to 9 p.m. hour and 9.1 million during the the rest of prime time. The broadcast was up 45 percent compared to a game last year at this time, and helped Fox win a night when its stiffest competition was “Big Brother” on CBS (8 million total viewers) and both NBC and the CW were in repeats.

headline: From Philadelphia, Slowdown News
text: DID the American economy hit the brakes this summer?

headline: Aug. 21 — 27
text: Theater

headline: Troubled Markets; A Bidding War for Internet Analysts; Declining Productivity; A Silver Lining for Stocks
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Graham Bowley and Floyd Norris on the troubled markets, Susanne Craig on a bidding war for Internet analysts, Tyler Cowen on declining productivity, and Paul Lim on a silver lining for stocks.

headline: The Jam | Koudlam
text: The French symphonic composer Koudlam is known for his otherworldly electronic beats, pulled from classical music to tribal, creating a psychedelic something from the future, maybe even space. Here he offers up this week’s playlist, which ranges from David Bowie to the relatively unknown Japanese musical cult Geinoh Yamashirogumi, headed by the scientist Tsutomu Ohashi. Sean Hanratty was introduced to Koudlam, which is French slang for “knife stab,” through the very talented visual artist Cyprien Gaillard, with whom Koudlam regularly collaborates. (Gaillard’s “Fight Club”-esque film, “Desniansky Raion,” which Koudlam scored, was coveted at the 2007 Basel Art Fair.) “I have been a huge fan of Koudlam’s for so many years,” says Hanratty of Koudlam, who is constantly traveling around the world, a hobby that no doubt influences his music. “His music has this immediate sensibility that is beautiful and detached.”

headline: TimesCast | August 19, 2011
text: An anticorruption activist in India is released from jail; Syrian forces fire on protesters; and China's press plays down a brawl between American and Chinese basketball teams.

headline: Battle of the Swoopy Sedans
text: The Audi A7 and Mercedes-Benz CLS550 both deliver in terms of looks and performance. But one gives a little more.

headline: The North Dakota Miracle
text: Forget the Texas Miracle. Let’s instead take a look at North Dakota, which has the lowest unemployment rate and the fastest job growth rate in the country.

headline: Norilsk Offers Share Buyback to End Long Dispute
text: MOSCOW — The management of Russia’s largest mining operator, Norilsk Nickel, offered on Friday to buy most of the shares held by one of the company’s two feuding owners and thus resolve the dispute.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Aug. 19
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Deciding Whether to Have More Children
text: Melissa Fay Greene thought her family was complete. By 1994, she had four children, ranging in age from 2 to 13. She toyed with the idea of having a fifth, setting the arbitrary deadline of giving birth before she turned 43, which was 11 months away. Looking for answers, she spent some time in a therapist’s office, which she describes in this month’s Motherlode Book Club, “No Biking in the House Without a Helmet”:

headline: Infiniti JX Crossover Concept: a Plush People Mover at Pebble Beach
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — Never mind the distracting one-off Testa Rossa prototypes and Shelby Cobras. For visitors to the Monterey peninsula intent on glimpsing the latest in seven-passenger crossover technology from Japan, Infiniti has brought just the thing: the JX concept.

headline: Getting Noticed at the Fringe: ‘As the Boat Approaches’
text: ArtsBeat is taking a look at some of the most clever, mysterious and strikingly designed postcards created to draw attention among the nearly 200 productions in this year’s New York International Fringe Festival.

headline: Tomato Water: What to Do With the Rest of the Tomatoes
text: After making tomato water, you’ll be left with a colander full of ruddy tomato flesh that is just begging not to be thrown out. I made mine into a quick tomato sauce. I smashed a few garlic cloves, bronzed them in some oil, then added the tomato solids and let it all bubble for about 15 minutes. Spooned over pasta with a few blobs of ricotta and torn basil leaves, it made a fine dinner.

headline: Relationship Status: In a ‘Stayover’
text: THE GIST “Stayovers” are a new, low-commitment form of cohabitation among young adults.

headline: Armed With PowerPoint and ‘Monty Python’ Jokes, Saab Executive Addresses Owners Club

headline: Gunshots Ring Out in Videos From Syria

headline: A Dead Son’s Namesake, and the Road Not Taken
text: When Carmen Rivera bore a son 36 years ago and considered a name, she thought of a book she had recently read, “Run Baby Run.” It was the gangs-to-God story of Nicky Cruz, once a self-described “warlord” of a New York City gang who found religion in his early 20s and began evangelizing against crime.

headline: After a Suicide, Bravo Tries for On-Time Start of ‘Housewives’ Season
text: The Bravo network denied a report on Friday that it had decided to delay the start of the new season of “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” because of the recent suicide of a character in the show. Instead, the network said, it would re-edit the program in hopes of starting on schedule on Sept. 5.

headline: At Pebble Beach, Hennessey Venom GT Sets Bait for Bugatti Veyrons
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — Attendees at last June’s Goodwood Festival of Speed in England were treated to the formal introduction of the Venom GT from Hennessey Performance, the tuning shop based outside Houston. The first unit of the $950,000 vehicles that sold to an American customer was delivered at the McCall’s Motorworks Revival here on Wednesday.

headline: Payrolls Increased in 31 States in July, but Jobless Rate Rose in 28, New Data Shows
text: Payrolls climbed in 31 states in July, led by New York and Texas, while the jobless rate increased in 28, painting a mixed employment picture for last month.

headline: Where Hearing the Parts Whirl Is the Point
text: Bienestan, which made its live debut at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, is a group with a strong concept and a clear point of view, but that doesn’t mean that it lays itself out for comprehension. Early in its sold-out first set, an enveloping piece called “Human Feel” underscored that idea.

headline: On the Merits of Parks and Bluefish
text: I owe an apology to regular readers — and comment contributors — on having Dot Earth go silent for the past week without hanging out a “Gone Fishing” (and camping and swimming) sign.

headline: The Night Is Young
text: “WHERE is the school bus to pick up all of these kids?” a 27-year-old man was wondering aloud around 11:30 p.m., in a parking lot outside the nightclub SL East on Three Mile Harbor Road in East Hampton, N.Y. It was a hot Saturday night in July, and around him girls who appeared to be about 18 were huddled together, illuminated by a chandelier and the sickly hue of their smartphones.

headline: 'West Memphis Three' Speak Out
text: After three men convicted of killing three 8-year-old boys in a notorious 1993 murder case were freed from jail on Friday, they spoke to the press.

text: Wall Street’s bulls got mauled again, but there were other stories that may have brightened up the week for some. We recount a few in poetic form:

headline: Wedding Etiquette

headline: Now Online | T Women’s Fashion Fall 2011
text: The fall season begins on a high note with our cover star: the jazz singer Esperanza Spalding. It continues with a trend report on the fully lined, feline eye, a look at street style in London, Cairo and Japan, and a sartorial tutorial on how to wear novelty knits, maxi coats and retro dresses. Along the way, The Selby finds Nordic foragers in Stockholm, Amy Ephron recalls her 1970s party days and Alex Kuczynski sits down with the actor Demian Bichir. In “Nightie Aphrodites,” Solange Knowles and Corinne Bailey Rae, among others, show off how to pair Afros with evening gowns. And don’t forget to meet the model students in “Beautiful Minds” and the women who lost their hair for Hedi Slimane in “Boy Crazy.” Finally, to relax a bit — vicariously, at least — drop by the rustic retreat of the designers Isabel Marant and Jerome Dreyfuss in “Le Shack.” See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Finally, Fish Topples Nadal
text: MASON, Ohio — Mardy Fish extended his arms and then wrapped them around his body, as if trying to embrace the whole stadium. The fans at Center Court had thrown their full-throated support behind him, and Fish channeled their energy Friday into a 6-3, 6-4 victory against Rafael Nadal in the quarterfinals of the Western & Southern Open.

headline: All Deliberate Speed for Nuclear Reforms?
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is moving forward on recommendations made by an internal task force studying the Fukushima Daiichi triple meltdown. But it is not moving quite the way its chairman wanted.

headline: Long Story Shortlist: Mommy and Me
text: “Baby Makes Four, and Complications,”by N.R. Kleinfeld (June 19, 2011)At the apartment in Brooklyn where George Russell spends four nights each week, he checked the clock: 7:09 p.m. Wasn’t it 7:05 about 20 minutes ago? Never had time moved so slowly. Was the clock even working? Read more »

headline: Eight Is Probably Enough
text: Ryota Igarashi, who is in the final season of a two-year, $3 million contract, had another ineffective relief outing for the Mets on Wednesday, allowing a walk and two doubles in the ninth inning of a 7-3 victory over San Diego.

headline: This Sunday: Who Are Those Oily Guys?
text: The idea for the cover package this week seemed simple enough. Inspired by the gorgeous forthcoming book on three decades of the magazine’s photography, I thought it would be fun and possibly enlightening to pick a bunch of our favorite pictures and find out what happened to the people in them.

text: Participants in the Commonwealth Vintage Dances relish dressing in costumes from the 1850s, the Gilded Age and the ragtime years, and often make their own clothes.

headline: Very Busy Mom Faces a Bigger Mission
text: Give me back my Carla Gugino. That’s what I couldn’t help thinking every time Jessica Alba — lovely to look at, utterly ordinary to watch — appeared on screen in “Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D.” The fall-off in sexiness, soulfulness and wittiness from Ms. Gugino and Antonio Banderas, the parents in the first three “Spy Kids” films, to Ms. Alba and Joel McHale is whiplash steep.

headline: Beach-Ready, Even in Rain
text: Jayma Cardoso, 35, began her night life career as a part-time hostess while attending Fordham University. She now owns the Surf Lodge in Montauk, N.Y., and GoldBar in SoHo and is a partner in Lavo New York, a Midtown favorite. Ms. Cardoso is engaged to Scott Campbell, 38, a broker at Phoenix Partners Group, and is planning their wedding in her native Brazil for next February.  BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

headline: Chic in Review | Victoria Beckham’s Five Hands of Food
text: Abercrombie & FitchPays the “Jersey Shore” star Michael Sorrentino to stay away from its clothing brand. The aftermath — or the situation, if you will — is that its stock has now dropped by 8 percent!

headline: Vicky Tiel’s 40-Year Career in Fashion
text: IF you are famous for dressed-to-spill goddess gowns beloved by women like Joan Collins and Halle Berry — steel stays radiating pitilessly from the diaphragm — then deciding what to wear to pick up a reporter at a train station in upstate New York might pose a challenge.

headline: The High Price of Looking Like a Woman
text: ZAIRA QUISPE, 42, said she knew as a child that she was a girl, though she had been born male. She picked up a photo that she kept on the windowsill above her bed and held it out as proof. It’s a picture of herself as a smiling baby, naked and with legs crossed, concealing genitals. “Look,” she said, “even then I was trying to hide it.”

headline: Farewell to My Summer Tan
text: I GREW up in New Jersey in the 1980s. I wish I could buck the clichés and say that I spent my summers sneaking into seminars at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, but the truth is that I frittered away the days “laying out,” as it is ungrammatically termed, in my backyard on a deck chair. Wearing a Walkman and sipping a Capri Sun, I’d barbecue my skin with sheets of tinfoil carefully positioned on either side of my face.

headline: Love Blessed by Lady Liberty Lives On
text: ONE question went unanswered this month when the National Park Service announced it would shut down the Statue of Liberty for renovations in October: What happened to the couple who got engaged in the crown when the statue reopened on July 4, 2009?

headline: Scouting the City for Her Characters
text: A SUMMER afternoon in Chelsea, and Sarah Jones was on a recon mission, searching for ... she did not know what, exactly. An accent, for starters. An ethnic wild card. “Hybridity,” she said, using a word she uses often to describe her field of urban study.

headline: Cubs’ Chairman Says Time Ran Out on Hendry
text: CHICAGO — A late August Cubs-Cardinals series has been a high point in dozens of baseball seasons on the North Side. But the Cubs’ two-year slide into National League Central irrelevance has removed much of the juice from this weekend’s three-game set at Wrigley Field.

headline: Walking Her Cats and Playing Guitar
text: The landscape artist April Gornik has been devoting as much energy lately to her new acoustic guitar as to her work. On Sundays, the guitar wins out. Ms. Gornik, 58, has paintings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum; her next solo show is in October at Danese in Chelsea, which represents her. Though she and her husband, the artist Eric Fischl, 63, have a loft and studio space in New York City, they live most of the time on five secluded acres in North Haven on Long Island with their two Bengal cats, Hooper and Bebop. ROBIN FINN

text: For nearly five years, the accuracy of drunken driven tests administered with a breath testing device used by Minnesota law enforcement agencies has been in question.

headline: Until Labor Day, Dining With a View
text: As the city has worked to expand the dining options in its parks, Brooklyn Bridge Park, which is being developed along a stretch of piers on the East River, has become a lively food destination. Pier 6 at the south end, near Atlantic Avenue, has its own collection of spots — including Bark and Milk Truck, new this summer — and roof deck seating. Pier 1, at the end of Old Fulton Street, has an outpost of Ditch Plains, a cart from Calexico, Blue Marble ice cream and a wine bar. Open only through Labor Day, the concessions draw crowds of people looking to have a lobster roll, a chipotle pork taco or a glass of prosecco. Sweeping views of the harbor and the skyline are also part of the appeal. On Wednesday afternoon, the crowds included two friends discussing Ghana and microlending. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: Two Oklahoma Indian Tribes Contest State for Water Rights
text: The Choctaw and Chickasaw Indian tribes in Oklahoma have filed a federal lawsuit to protect water rights they say derived from long-ago treaties and to prevent exports of water from their traditional homelands without their permission.

headline: Straight Out of the East Bay, With Aspirations and Swag
text: In the 2011 hip-hop artifact time capsule, certainly the YouTube clip “Video Unacceptable This Chick Gets Loose With the N Word But She Spittin With the Hoodest Bars” gets prime placement. In it V-Nasty, a white female rapper from East Oakland, Calif., raps for about a minute, awkwardly but with attitude, and manages to use a certain epithet twice — not violently, but casually, as if it were any other word.

headline: Music, Activism and the Peruvian Cabinet
text: Success was a long time coming for Susana Baca, the Afro-Peruvian folk singer who was recently named minister of culture for the new populist government of President Ollanta Humala of Peru. She is the first black member of the Peruvian cabinet and the first musician to hold the position.

headline: Folk Art Museum Considers Closing
text: The financial picture has grown so bleak at the American Folk Art Museum that its trustees are considering whether to shut it down and donate its collections to another institution, said a person involved in the discussions, who requested anonymity because the talks are confidential.

headline: Raúl Ruiz, Prolific Director of Cryptic Films, Dies at 70
text: Raúl Ruiz, a Chilean director who presented a labyrinthine, cryptic picture of individual psychology and social relations in “Mysteries of Lisbon” and more than 100 other films, died on Friday in Paris. He was 70.

headline: Bloggingheads: Libya Politics
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Eli Lake of The New Republic debate how the Libyan intervention could play politically in 2012.

headline: A Romp Through the Barn
text: How many layers are there to human thought? Sometimes in art, just as in people’s conversations, we’re aware of only one at a time. On other occasions, though, we realize just how many layers can be in simultaneous action, and we’re given a sense of both revelation and mystery. When a choreographer responds to music — when one artist reacts in detail to another — the sensation of multilayering can affect us as an insight not just into dance but into the regions of the mind.

headline: Secrets of Survival: To Be Used When Summer Doldrums Fade
text: Things started to get weird last week when the following invitation from a public relations firm arrived in Nocturnalist’s in-box: “Last night while rioting ensued on the streets of London,” it began, the company’s client, a stylist, “caused a riot of his own” at a hip Manhattan bar, with the stylist’s fabulous fashion advice and adorable monogrammed pocket squares.

headline: What He Did (or Not) on His Australian Vacation
text: With his long, lean physique and thin, angular face, Steven Hauck seems destined to play Don Quixote someday. In the meantime, he’s making do with Louis de Rougemont, the somewhat quixotic memoirist who thrilled Victorian England with his ripping yarns and ended up in a sideshow as “The Greatest Liar on Earth.”

headline: U.S. Rejects Mayor’s Plan to Ban Use of Food Stamps to Buy Soda
text: Federal officials on Friday rejected Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to bar New York City’s food stamp users from buying soda and other sugary drinks with them.

headline: Regional Sports Networks Show the Money
text: In the 1970s, regional sports networks began to offer fans a new way to watch games on TV.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Questions on a Bank Merger
text: Representative Barney Frank, a Democrat of Massachusetts, got it exactly right this week when he asked the Federal Reserve to do more than just rubber-stamp the proposed purchase of the online bank, ING Direct, by the Capital One Financial Corporation.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Photos
text: Warning from the health care industry about jobs; anxiety over Europe roils markets; Nordstrom’s new effort in New York; and a summer camp introducing girls to manufacturing.

headline: Clemens Prosecutors Request a New Trial
text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors overseeing the Roger Clemens perjury case said Friday that they made an unintentional error when showing jurors inadmissible evidence that led to Clemens’s mistrial last month. The prosecutors asked a judge to allow a new trial.

headline: Podcast: Eurobonds, Star Analysts and Productivity
text: Financial markets have been showing more signs of stress. The daily swings of stock markets have been growing wider, and investments presumed to be safe, like Treasury bonds and gold bullion, have been rising sharply in price.

headline: Music Hall of Fame Gets Home of Its Own
text: THE Long Island Music Hall of Fame was organized seven years ago “to start trumpeting the fact that all these amazing people come from Long Island,” according to the chairman of its board of directors, James Faith, of Miller Place.

headline: But I Really Want to Act (Never Mind the Stage Fright)
text: In a play loaded with clever words, the funniest scene is one about not being able to get any out. That’s largely because Josh Grisetti, the appealing young star of “Enter Laughing, the Musical,” mimes stage fright so expertly that his struggle becomes as comical as a well-crafted line.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Flying? Increasingly for the Birds
text: “I’ll be passing the back of my hand over your buttocks and then come up the insides of your legs up toward the private parts. Is that O.K.?”

headline: No U.S. Trip for Students From Gaza, Hamas Says
text: GAZA — The Islamist group that governs Gaza barred a group of students this week from traveling to the United States for a year of study, officials of the group, Hamas, said.

headline: Staging a Classic, Retooled and Slimmed Down
text: When Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein II wrote “Show Boat,” they also rewrote the rules for musicals, adding serious themes and complex characters to a genre that had been all fluff. And just as our notion of serious themes and complex characters has evolved since 1927, when it opened, so has “Show Boat.”

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Judging a Paperback’s Cover by Its Painter
text: The Beatles immortalized the plight of an aspiring author in their 1966 song “Paperback Writer.” But what about the paperback painter? A comprehensive view of that lot can be found in “The Painting World of James Avati” at the Monmouth Museum in Lincroft, an intriguing show that surveys the life and work of America’s premier mid-20th-century paperback-cover artist.

headline: Innocent Parties
text: In the past few weeks I’ve hawk-proofed my chicken yard. It’s now covered by a net, as though a trapeze artist who missed his hold might come plummeting into it. I’ve also fox-proofed the yard with fencing, but I forgot about weasels because they’ve never given me any trouble. Last week, I walked out to the yard and there, in the chicken house, lay the bodies of 24 pullets. Instead of the early morning clatter of a chicken flock, silence greeted me. It was a characteristic weasel kill — all the birds dead but none removed or eaten.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Lawyer Sentenced in Insider Trading Case
text: A federal judge sentenced a personal-injury lawyer, Jason C. Goldfarb, to three years in prison for his role in an insider trading scheme that involved a hedge fund trader and two corporate lawyers. Mr. Goldfarb, who worked at Brecher Fishman Pasternack Walsh Tilker & Ziegler, pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme with Zvi Goffer, a former trader at the Galleon Group, the hedge fund run by Raj Rajaratnam. He admitted to receiving tips about impending corporate mergers from Arthur Cutillo and Brien Santarlas, two low-level associates at the law firm Ropes & Gray, and then passing them to Mr. Goffer. During an April court appearance, Mr. Goldfarb, who earned college and law degrees from Villanova, said that Mr. Goffer, a friend, approached him shortly after his law school graduation and asked if he knew any corporate lawyers. Mr. Goldfarb said he eventually introduced Mr. Goffer to Mr. Cutillo, his college roommate. Both Mr. Cutillo and Mr. Santarlas have pleaded guilty to leaking information about takeovers involving 3Com and Axcan Pharma. Mr. Goffer took his case to trial and was convicted by a jury in June.

headline: As PCs Wane, Companies Look to Tablets
text: Although the world is dependent on personal computers, making them has not been a great business for most American companies for almost a decade.

headline: Toward Immigration Sanity
text: The White House has just taken a large step toward a more sensible and lawful policy on illegal immigration. The administration said that it would stop deporting illegal immigrants who pose no threat to public safety or national security so that it can focus on catching and expelling criminals who do.

headline: Judge Hinting at Trial in Case of Mets Owners
text: A federal district judge on Friday raised the prospect that all or part of the $1 billion lawsuit brought against the owners of the Mets by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s epic fraud could wind up being decided in a public trial before a jury.

headline: A Study in Judicial Dysfunction
text: Harsh state judicial campaigns financed by ever larger amounts of special interest money are eating away at public faith in judicial impartiality. There are few places where the spectacle is more shameful than Wisconsin, where over-the-top campaigning, self-interested rulings, and a complete breakdown of courthouse collegiality and ethics is destroying trust in its Supreme Court.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Scrambling to Ease Shortage of Vital Medicine
text: WASHINGTON — Federal officials and lawmakers, along with the drug industry and doctors’ groups, are rushing to find remedies for critical shortages of drugs to treat a number of life-threatening illnesses, including bacterial infection and several forms of cancer.

headline: Rick, Rattle and Roll
text: Consider the Rick Perry paradox: in a G.O.P. field notably bereft of experience in elected office, he has won nine back-to-back elections and spent the last decade as governor of America’s second-most-populous state. And, though the Thread has yet to see him in person, he is apparently the Red State equivalent of Kal-El. Or so says this rapturous lede from Politico:

headline: Uncertainty in Courthouse Fogs the View at the Stadium
text: It is a sad state of affairs when the big events are being played in courtrooms rather than ballparks. But that is the plight of the Mets, who are trying to stay competitive on the field and solvent off the field.

headline: A ‘Close to the Cow’ Treat
text: With summer on the wane, anyone who has yet to achieve the perfect ice cream moment should plot a course for Lighthouse Ice Cream and Coffee, on the Tarrytown waterfront. With its jaunty nautical theme, this new venture honors the old-fashioned virtues of vanilla, chocolate and strawberry while delighting patrons with the likes of Meyer lemon, pomegranate and pineapple-basil sorbets.

headline: At Enduring Trattoria, Dessert Is High Point
text: NOW in its third year, TuttaBella Trattoria seems to have dispelled any notion that the building it occupies, on the corner of Route 22 and Wilmot Road, is somehow unlucky.

headline: If Phones Ring, Obama Is Here, With Cell Power
text: CHILMARK, Mass. — To the slamming screen door, happy vacation chatter and other noises at the Chilmark General Store, add a less expected one this month: ringing cellphones.

headline: For President at Play, Family Outings, Golf and Lots of Advisers
text: CHILMARK, Mass. — When President Obama boarded Air Force One this week for his vacation on Martha’s Vineyard, he was conspicuously accompanied by John O. Brennan, his chief counterterrorism adviser. Next week, a top economic adviser, Brian Deese, will arrive to prep Mr. Obama for his speech on the economy after Labor Day.

headline: Flavors of Australia
text: The winemaker Russell Hearn left his native Australia in 1985, but he hasn’t left Australia behind.

headline: Report Finds ‘Vast Improvement’ at the City’s Beaches
text: It may not be this summer’s most gripping beach read, but a civic organization’s new 27-page report should bring smiles to New York’s swimmers and sunbathers.

headline: Views of Peconic Bay, Tastes of Local Bounty
text: FOR around 15 years, until its closing in 2009, the Seafood Barge at the Port of Egypt Marina in Southold was one of the North Fork’s best restaurants. A Lure Chowder House and Oysteria, which opened in the Seafood Barge’s waterfront space in May, is a worthy successor.

headline: Principal to Resign Following Grade-Altering Inquiry
text: The principal of a Bronx high school who was found to have improperly changed student grades has agreed to resign from the school, but will continue to work for the Department of Education, possibly advising principals and teachers on curriculum and other matters, city officials said Friday.

headline: 9/11’s White Elephant
text: There is nothing wrong — and much that is right — with building a national monument to memorialize the nearly 3,000 people killed in the 9/11 attacks a decade ago. The awful events of that day traumatized the country — and changed it. The dead deserve to be remembered. Far be it from me to suggest otherwise.

headline: Qaddafi’s Hold in Tripoli in Doubt as Rebels Advance
text: CAIRO — Six months after the outbreak of the revolt against his 42 years in power, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hold on his Tripoli stronghold shows signs of slipping.

headline: Five Days of Market Volatility
text: A look at multiple indexes over the past five days.

headline: Falling Off the Bone
text: Little Mark’s Big BBQ in Vernon, a 60-seat restaurant that opened in 1990, occupies a pale blue freestanding building of the sort often favored by fast-food chains. But there is nothing quick about the way its meats are barbecued. Prolonged smoking at a low temperature — cooking times are from 6 to 12 hours — is the norm in Southern barbecue, which is offered here with a variety of sauces and rubs.

headline: Where Sushi Is Good, but Rarely Simple
text: WE listened agog as our waiter inventoried the elements in the lobster tempura sushi roll, a special that night at Feng Asian Bistro in Hartford. The list was lengthy, a daring amalgamation of lobster tempura, avocado, lettuce and mango, glazed with Parmesan cheese and finished with barbecue eel sauce and spicy mayonnaise. It was a surprise hit, the cheese providing a sharp, savory note that brightened the lobster and avocado.

headline: Our Politics Are Sick
text: We have a tendency to elect presidents who seem like the antitheses of their immediate predecessors — randy young Kennedy the un-Eisenhower, earnest truth-telling Carter the un-Nixon, charismatic Reagan the un-Carter, randy young Clinton the un-H.W. Bush, cool and cerebral Obama the un-W.

headline: Getting Ribs Right, Slowly
text: For Mike Cassidy, an owner of the pig-themed Hickory Hog restaurant in Point Pleasant, barbecue is an art and a science.

headline: Kosher Dishes, Straight From India
text: I WANTED to love Mysore Woodlands. It’s kosher, so I could bring the leftovers into my home. It’s Indian, so it would please my masala-loving wife, whose heart sank when a kosher-vegetarian South Indian place, Udupi Village, closed down two months after we moved to Montclair.

headline: Saturday: A Special Puzzle From Lollapuzzoola
text: Administrivial Notepad Alert! There will be a Notepad on the Sunday puzzle that reads: “When this puzzle is done, look for a name (hinted at by 37 Down) hidden 17 times in the grid, each reading forward, backward, down, up or diagonally, word search-style.”

headline: Reyes Makes an Appearance but Is Not Quite Ready to Return
text: Jose Reyes gave every indication on Friday afternoon that he was ready to rejoin the Mets. He stabbed ground balls, took batting practice and jogged across the grass at Citi Field before the team hosted the Milwaukee Brewers.

headline: Battle for Libya | August 19, 2011
text: Rebels continue to fight in Zawiyah as Qaddafi’s hold on Tripoli shows signs of slipping.

headline: In California, Victims’ Families Fight for the Dead
text: SAN DIEGO — The other day, at the sprawling state prison here, Linda and Alfred Tay sat in a cramped, windowless room, just feet from the man serving time for murdering their son.

headline: New York Police Officer Charged With Rape While Off Duty
text: An off-duty New York City police officer was arrested in Upper Manhattan on Friday after he grabbed a woman who was on her way to work, showed her he had a gun and raped her in the backyard of a nearby building, the police said.

headline: Corrections: August 20
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: New York City, in the Dawn’s Early Light
text: Librado Romero, a staff photographer for The New York Times, explores the city’s early morning hours.

headline: Obama in the Valley
text: In 1970, the Japanese roboticist Masahiro Mori coined the phrase “uncanny valley.” In the field of robotics, and increasingly in computer animation, it refers to the theory that people feel good about robots — up to a point. When they start to look almost real, but not quite, we experience an eerie and unsettling sense of revulsion.

headline: Turkey: Army Strikes Kurdish Rebels
text: The Turkish military carried out airstrikes in northern Iraq for a second day in pursuit of Kurdish separatist rebels suspected of attacking Turkey from bases in the mountainous border region. Warplanes hit 28 rebel locations, and artillery shelled 96 targets, the army said Friday. Meanwhile, the rebels — from the P.K.K., or Kurdistan Workers Party — struck two military posts in Siirt Province, in the southeast, killing two soldiers and wounding three civilians, the semiofficial Anatolian Agency reported. More than 40 people have been killed since separatist violence escalated in July, which led to this week’s intense military operations.

headline: Jones Listens to His Mother, Opens His Stance and Recovers His Stroke
text: MINNEAPOLIS — After a disappointing first half of the season in which he batted only .195, Andruw Jones received important advice from one of his personal batting coaches, and it seems to have had quite an impact on his second-half production.

headline: Is That Review a Fake?
text: Researchers at Cornell University have been analyzing Web reviews to detect fake ones.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Long Climbs to No. 1
text: Over the past two decades, there have been four books that spent 20 weeks or more on the list before reaching the top spot.

headline: Pennsylvania: Three Dead in Pittsburgh Flooding
text: Flash floods in Pittsburgh left three people dead and one person missing on Friday, city and county officials said. According to the Allegheny County medical examiner’s office, two of the dead were children.

headline: Twang and Job Title Might Be the Same, but Perry and Bush Keep Their Distance
text: Sharing a last name with George W. Bush has no doubt contributed to the decision by his younger brother Jeb to stay out of the Republican presidential fray. But can sharing a Texas twang with the last president hurt Gov. Rick Perry’s chances of becoming the next one?

headline: His Place in the Rotation Secure, Hughes Shows Why He Deserves It
text: MINNEAPOLIS — After weeks of uncertainty surrounding the Yankees’ starting pitching rotation, Friday’s game provided a night of clarity. In the span of a few hours the Yankees placed Freddy Garcia on the disabled list with an injury he said had healed, and then watched as Phil Hughes produced a dominating start.

headline: For Mets, More Waiting and Nothing to Show for It
text: The Mets’ return home Friday was defined by a tantalizing series of fits and starts. During batting practice, the injured Jose Reyes looked ready to rejoin the club, but he remains days away. Then rain delayed the start of the game for 2 hours 46 minutes.

headline: Nations Race to Defuse Crisis Between Egypt and Israel
text: CAIRO — Diplomats scrambled to avert a crisis in relations between Egypt and Israel on Saturday, and the Israeli government issued a rare statement of regret for the killing of three Egyptian security officers by an Israeli warplane.

headline: Fancy Theorists of the World Unite
text: A number of people have pointed me to this remarkable editorial by Stephen Moore in the WSJ. What’s remarkable isn’t the views; it’s the all-out embrace of anti-intellectualism. It actually denounces “fancy theories” and rejects them because they “defy common sense”.

headline: Spain’s Players Go on Strike
text: The Spanish League season will not start as scheduled this weekend after the players and team owners failed to reach an agreement on a new collective bargaining agreement. Raphael Minder of the I.H.T. laid out some more details on the black cloud over La Liga on Thursday. Read his article here, and come back to comment.

headline: Swede Talk, Swede Talk
text: A few random notes:

headline: Heavy Fighting Reported in Tripoli; Rebels Encircle City
text: ZAWIYAH, Libya — For the first time in months, witnesses in Tripoli reported heavy fighting across the capital late Saturday night, even as rebel forces claimed to have encircled the city by taking major towns to its east, west and south.
