text: Today’s Times

headline: Star Analysts Are Back (No Autographs, Please)
text: THEY are the new tastemakers of Web investing, the supposed seers of Bubble-Tech 2.0. And despite the stock market’s recent craziness, they are almost as hot as some of the stocks they cover.

headline: Leadership Doesn’t Rest on Your Title
text: This interview with  Terri Ludwig, president and chief executive of Enterprise Community Partners, a nonprofit housing finance organization, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Iran Sentences 2 Hikers to 8 Years in Jail
text: The Revolutionary Court in Iran sentenced two American hikers imprisoned since July 2009 to eight years in jail for espionage and entering the country illegally, Tehran’s prosecutor, Abbas Jafari Dolatabadi, told a news conference Sunday.

headline: Silicon Valley Entrepreneurs
text: Tech professionals are optimistic.

headline: In Silicon Valley, the Night Is Still Young
text: MENLO PARK, Calif.

headline: A Generous Gift
text: The Cleveland Indians were in Boston this month when Jack Hannahan, a reserve infielder, learned that his wife, Jenny, had gone into labor. She had been on bed rest since the 24th week of her pregnancy, and this was Week 28.

headline: Finger-Pointing in the Fog
text: UNEARTHING the story of the financial crisis is like conducting an archaeological dig. New shards keep emerging from the dust.

headline: Just Give Me the Right to Be Forgotten
text: THE marketing pitch came by e-mail: Would you like to make an appointment with your dentist to have your teeth cleaned? And while you’re at it, how about recommending him to a friend, or posting a review of your dental care?

headline: High-Tech Product, Low-Tech Pitch
text: ZERO percent financing on a new car. A mattress sale blowout. Storewide discounts at the local hardware. These are the types of pitches that people expect to hear on the radio. Not commercials for the Barracuda Load Balancer, which sounds vaguely automotive but is actually software related to managing Web site traffic.

headline: Of Management and Mosquito Nets
text: CORPORATE chieftains tend to have an overarching faith in the curative powers of modern management — goal-setting, incentivizing, metrics, accountability, the whole shebang. People like Ross Perot and Mitt Romney have sought to introduce this kind of thinking into government circles, with mixed results.

headline: Three Weeks Into Camp, Teams Are Starting to See Things
text: If you spend too much time in the August heat of training camp, you may start to experience football-related hallucinations.

headline: Is Manning One of Elite? Numbers Muddle Issue
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For a Super Bowl-winning quarterback in the country’s largest news media market, Eli Manning routinely tiptoes around the spotlight, rarely making headlines. It is not by accident. His public image is carefully managed, devoid of the irreverence and swagger that made his older brother, Peyton, one of the league’s most popular and marketable stars. Eli Manning’s interviews sound more like depositions: short, direct, lawyerly, with a hint of goofiness.

headline: The Sad Statistic That Trumps the Others
text: THERE’S been a lot of bad economic news lately, yet we may be overlooking the most disturbing development of all: our economic productivity has been weakening. This isn’t just a problem for the United States. Because America remains a leader in technology and innovation, it is also a matter of concern for the entire world.

headline: Who Says Companies Aren’t Spending?
text: CONVENTIONAL wisdom says the unwillingness of businesses to spend and employ more workers is holding back the economy and the stock market.

headline: The Boundaries of Marriage and Work
text: When husband and wife work next to each other, can they truly keep their home life outside the office? Lisa and Michael Pallen, executives at VerveLife, a music marketing agency in Chicago, say it’s working out so far.

headline: All the King’s Horses
text: A day in the life of North America’s top trainer: hot walking, hand holding and a heart-thumping victory.

headline: All the King’s Horses
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — He watched on the dusty television hanging from the ceiling of a cramped office that is always full of people and that perpetually smells of the horses that snort and whinny and shuffle in the adjacent stalls. It was 5:31 p.m. on a recent Saturday, and Todd Pletcher was back in the same barn where his day had begun 13 hours earlier, with him checking feed tubs and taking the temperatures of nearly 100 racehorses.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The Puns & Anagrams puzzles that we know and love in The New York Times go all the way back to Feb. 15, 1942. Underneath The Times’ first Sunday crossword was a Puns & Anagrams puzzle titled “Riddle Me This” by the maddeningly named Anna Gram. No one today knows for sure who the pseudonymous Anna Gram was, although Will Shortz tells me that he has always suspected Margaret Farrar. In fact, you can read a brief PandA history written by our puzzlemaster here.

headline: Pirates Rely on Draft
text: In the midst of their tumble from the top of the National League Central, the Pittsburgh Pirates made a significant investment in their future at Monday’s deadline to sign drafted players. The Pirates gave $13 million to two Scott Boras clients: $8 million for pitcher Gerrit Cole, the No. 1 overall pick, and $5 million for outfielder Josh Bell, the 61st.

headline: College Football’s Ugly Season, Facing Scandals of Every Stripe
text: College football is set to start its new season Sept. 1, but a kind of dispirited consensus has taken hold about a sport that has been played on American campuses since 1869: its reputation has never been more damaged.

headline: 50 Years Later, Maris’s 61-Homer Season Looks Even Better
text: Ever since people began to wonder what was happening during the Large Ball Cap Generation, Roger Maris has been having a terrific decade.

headline: Tracking the Flow of Money
text: An example of how state grants appear to be paying dividends for some major Perry contributors.

headline: Farewell, Aching Feet
text: WHEN I was 15, I moved from Taipei, Taiwan, where I was born, to live in the United States. Education was very important to my parents, so they sent my sister and brother and me to Wilmington, Del., to live with my grandparents and attend school there.

headline: Arsenal May Covet a Red Bull on the Rise
text: In the last month, Red Bulls defender Tim Ream has turned out for Major League Soccer’s All-Stars against Manchester United and helped lead his team to a surprise victory at the Emirates Cup in London.

headline: Iraq Militants Say Violence Is to Avenge Bin Laden
text: BAGHDAD — One of the most powerful insurgent groups in Iraq, Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, released a statement on Saturday, warning that it had launched a 100-attack campaign to exact revenge for the United States’ killing of Osama bin Laden.

headline: Verizon Workers Plan to End Strike, Agreeing to Revive Talks Toward a Contract
text: Leaders of the unions that have been on strike against Verizon Communications announced on Saturday that they were ending the walkout even though the two sides had not reached an overall settlement for a new contract.

headline: Thome’s Success Rooted in a Simple Suggestion
text: PHILADELPHIA — When Jim Thome and Ryan Howard come to the plate, they dig their spikes into the left-hander’s batter’s box, keeping the left foot closer to the plate than the right foot. They extend their right arm, pointing the bat menacingly to some distant spot beyond the center-field wall, like a samurai offering his sword to the pitcher.

headline: Economic Lessons From World War II
text: To the Editor:

headline: Concussion Suit Seeks Better Health Monitoring
text: As the attention paid to head injuries in the N.F.L. has increased in recent years, much of the emphasis has been on the plight of retired players, many of whom are now facing a number of serious ailments.

headline: To Your Right, the Frenzied Capital of Finance
text: Tourists have flocked to the Wall Street area to have their pictures taken outside the Exchange even as the markets continue their fluctuations inside.

headline: Sharing a Tournament, but Not a Culture
text: MASON, Ohio — Jelena Jankovic was struggling to fend off Francesca Schiavone on Thursday at the Western and Southern Open. She might as well have been trying to extricate a bulldog’s teeth from her leg.

headline: Two Teams Race to Forget the Past
text: Detroit

headline: With North Korea in Need, Kim Jong-il Goes to Russia
text: MOSCOW — North Korea’s reclusive leader, Kim Jong-il, rumbled across the border into Russia aboard an armored train early Saturday amid growing hopes for a resumption of talks over ending his country’s nuclear weapons program.

headline: In Labor Deal’s Minutiae, No X’s or O’s, but a Few Zzzzzs
text: The recently ratified N.F.L. collective bargaining agreement has all the makings of a literary masterpiece. It is much talked about, unquestionably important, somewhat controversial, epic in scope and thematically complex. And only the tiniest percentage of the population will ever read a word of it.

headline: With Klaus Obermeyer
text: At 91, Klaus Obermeyer remains the energetic patriarch of the family-owned skiwear company he founded in 1947. As an early ski instructor in Aspen, Colo., Obermeyer realized that his comforter stuffed with goose feathers, packed by his mother when he left Germany for North America, could provide the template for one of the first down parkas. Among Obermeyer’s other notable innovations are high-altitude sun lotion, double-paned goggles, the nylon windshirt and the dual-layer ski boot. Over the years, Sport Obermeyer has been in the forefront in developing ski gear that keeps skiers warmer, dryer, comfortable and safer on their skis. With winter inching closer, Obermeyer, an aeronautical engineer by training, is itching to get back on the slopes as he recovers from an accident last March that resulted in a broken femur in his right leg, his first serious injury in 88 years on skis. JACK BELL

headline: Lawyer for Strauss-Kahn’s Accuser Expects Charges to Be Dropped
text: Manhattan prosecutors will meet with the woman who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault on the eve of a court appearance in which they are expected to announce whether they will proceed with the case. The woman’s lawyer, who received a letter from the district attorney’s office requesting the Monday afternoon meeting, said he believed it to be a clear indication that prosecutors would seek to have a judge dismiss all or some of the charges at the court hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: After Cellphone Action, BART Faces Escalating Protests
text: Early last month, a BART police officer shot and killed a knife-wielding homeless man at the San Francisco Civic Center station. The incident provoked a series of small protests that drew little attention until Aug. 11, when the transit agency took the unusual step of shutting down cellphone service for several hours as activists prepared for another rally.

headline: Colliding, With Nuance
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — For those who have come to know John Conner beyond his controlled violence, it is not surprising that the most brutal hitter on the Jets — a man whose devastating blocks have been featured on “Hard Knocks” and immortalized on YouTube — also enjoys bowling and the occasional women’s soccer game.

headline: Casualties on Both Sides as Israel and Gaza Trade Fire
text: JERUSALEM — Palestinian militants from Gaza fired rockets at cities deep inside Israeli territory on Saturday, killing one person. And Israel struck a squad that was firing mortars from northern Gaza as violence continued in the wake of an attack on Thursday that killed eight Israelis, Israeli officials said.

headline: Keeping Score: Looking Past Mere Wins and Losses
text: Luck, or if you prefer a less loaded term, randomness, plays a significant role in any major league baseball game. A line drive caught by the third baseman might be rattling around the left-field corner if it had hit the bat just a few millimeters higher. A borderline strike three might be ball four with just a tiny change in the pitcher’s grip. Usually all of these events that could go one way or another balance out over 162 games and the season ends with the best teams at the top of the standings, but only usually.

headline: Nature Without the Nanny State
text: Teanaway Valley, Wash.

headline: Leopard Rider Fuglsang Leads Vuelta After Day 1
text: Jakob Fuglsang is the early leader of the Vuelta a España after his Leopard team won the opening-day team time trial Saturday.

headline: Immigrant Struggles to Stay in Britain and Honor a Sacrifice
text: In 2005, Antonio Bravo’s father committed suicide in a desperate attempt to avert his son’s deportation to Angola.

headline: In Father’s Memory, Fighting to Stay in Britain
text: CLAPHAM, England — The boy was 13 when a dawn immigration raid abruptly ended his father’s four-year quest for political asylum in Britain. By nightfall of that day in 2005, father and son were hundreds of miles from home, locked in the privately run Yarl’s Wood Immigration Removal Center here, scheduled for deportation to their native Angola in the morning.

headline: Atop a Training Empire, the Days Are Full
text: The daily routine of North America’s top horse trainer, Todd Pletcher, is a feat of choreography, in which high-tech wizardry is as necessary as plain old horse sense.

headline: The Grand Staircase, City Hall
text: The majestic stairs to the Ceremonial Rotunda and the Board of Supervisors Chambers were built with economic stimulus money after the previous City Hall was destroyed in the 1906 earthquake. Designed by graduates of the University of California, Berkeley, the building was constructed in three years — without power tools — opening in 1915.

headline: A Big Hollywood Movie Is Coming, and a Novelist Cries Foul
text: In 1998, Joe Quirk, a Bay Area novelist, wrote “Ultimate Rush,” a thriller about an adrenaline-fueled messenger who tears through the city on rollerblades as he tries to deliver a mysterious package. Mr. Quirk’s novel, his first to be published, sold well and was optioned by Warner Brothers. A screenplay was commissioned, and Mr. Quirk became a client of the powerful C.A.A. agency. But nothing ever came of it — or so Mr. Quirk thought.

headline: Ice Cream Pilgrimage, With Shopping and the Arts
text: If ice cream is your religion, then Brenham is mecca. On any given day, up to 2,000 people visit the Blue Bell Creamery (1101 South Blue Bell Road, 800-327-8135, bluebell.com), the birthplace of every true Texan’s favorite frozen treat. Cheerful guides spice up the tour with fun facts — Blue Bell is sold in 20 states, and most of the cookies and wafers are made in house — while ushering guests through elevated hallways overlooking mixing and packing rooms. The tour clocks in at a third of a mile with two flights of stairs, which means you shouldn’t feel guilty devouring the generous helping of ice cream served at the end.

headline: Suggesting A Few Extras For a Park With Loyalists
text: Dolores Park sprawls across 14 sloping acres between the Mission and Castro neighborhoods in San Francisco, with spectacular views of the Bay Bridge and beyond. On warm weekends, the park fills with families and nearly nude sunbathers, fitness fanatics and Chardonnay-sipping picnickers, plus a roving man selling pot truffles.

headline: Conservatives Eye Senate and Anticipate a Battle
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Perry and the Tea Party: Depends on Whom You Ask
text: WACO — He was Tea Party before Tea Party was cool, the darling of the ultra-conservative right wing. That is how many news analysts described Gov. Rick Perry as he leapt into the national spotlight announcing his bid for the presidency.

headline: As Governor, Perry Backed Wind, Gas and Coal
text: In the opening days of his presidential campaign, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has railed against a favorite target, the Environmental Protection Agency, and declared himself a “skeptic” on the subject of humans as the cause of global warming.

headline: Gary Lures Hollywood With a Bounty of Decay
text: Inside City Methodist Church in downtown Gary, Ind., mushrooms grew next to a pile of rubble and a wooden cross. Old theater seats were scattered about, the backs snapped from their cushioned seats as if a giant had smashed them in a fit of rage.

headline: Locust Soufflé, Anyone? It’s a Start
text: Grasshopper fajitas, mealworm fried rice, Bee-LT’s and similar delicacies will be on the menu for a public tasting buffet in October at the University of Chicago. The insect-dominated bill of fare is the idea of Matthew Krisiloff, a sophomore from California who last year founded Entom Foods, a start-up that seeks to make bugs a staple of the American diet.

headline: Briefly the New Frontier, Exurbs See a Bust After Boom
text: Far west suburban Yorkville scarcely looks as if it was once one of America’s hottest boomtowns. In some subdivisions, lots for big homes are patches of scrub grass and rocky soil. Weeds crawl up around some curbs. A mere handful of houses dot the barren landscape.

headline: Antigraft Activists in India Intensify Drive for Reform
text: NEW DELHI — With his hunger strike reaching a fifth day, the protest leader Anna Hazare maintained pressure on the government on Saturday as his advisers demanded that their version of legislation to create a national anticorruption agency be introduced in Parliament on Tuesday and passed by the end of the month.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 20
text: There were trips, slips, kicks and flips during a busy day in sports.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, August 21
text: Participants and spectators from both sides of the 2012 campaign will appear on the Sunday shows to talk strategy for either securing a second term or beginning a first. Three governors will also weigh in to discuss what the consecutive rabble-rousing in Washington means for state and local elections.

headline: If I Were President ...
text: We've heard from the media and from experts — incessantly. What if we entered a pundit-free zone?

headline: Surely They Can Read a Spreadsheet
text: When the federal government was on the brink of default and the economy hung in the balance, the nation’s business leaders had a chance to step forward and push for a long-term solution. They could have supported a grand bargain that cut spending and raised tax revenue. They could have warned House Republicans that it was far too risky to use the debt ceiling for political leverage.

headline: An Empty Regard
text: William Deresiewicz is an essayist and critic, and the author of “Solitude and Leadership,” an address delivered at West Point in 2009 and widely taught in the armed forces.

headline: The Debate on Fracturing
text: The argument over hydraulic fracturing — a technique used to extract natural gas from deep shale formations — has become increasingly polarized. Some environmental groups have demanded a nationwide moratorium because of complaints about polluted drinking water in wells. Meanwhile, industry officials and many politicians, including Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, extol fracturing and insist there is already more than enough regulation.

headline: Fairies, Witches and Supply and Demand
text: Motoko Rich is an economics reporter for The New York Times.

headline: As Farmers’ Markets Go Mainstream, Some Fear a Glut
text: FLORENCE, Mass. — John Spineti started selling plump tomatoes and shiny squash at farmers’ markets in the early 1970s and saw his profits boom as markets became more popular. But just as farmers’ markets have become mainstream, Mr. Spineti said business has gone bust.

headline: Google Goes Hardware Shopping
text: Steve Lohr is a technology reporter for The New York Times.

headline: Mr. Demiraj’s Nightmare
text: Edmond Demiraj is trapped. An Albanian gangster, Bill Bedini, wants to kill him and harm his family. The United States wants to deport Mr. Demiraj’s wife and teenage son from Texas to Albania, where they will no doubt be in great danger from Mr. Bedini. Mr. Demiraj keeps pleading with the federal authorities for help, and keeps losing.

headline: Will Health Care Reform Survive the Courts?
text: The legal battle over the constitutionality of the health care reform law will determine how far government can go in helping to improve people’s lives. Ultimately, the Supreme Court will have to decide this question. Until then, the pileup of lower federal court rulings — responding to some of the more than two dozen lawsuits filed against the law — is confusing and sharply divided, especially on the requirement that individuals buy or obtain health insurance or pay a penalty.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: The Tax When You Fill Up
text: With the federal gas tax due to expire on Sept. 30, readers debate whether to raise it, and the effects an increase would have.

headline: Migrants in United Arab Emirates Get Stuck in Web of Debt
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Before she arrived in this mecca of migrant labor at age 48, Evelyn Naces, a Filipino nurse, had never owned a credit card. Soon she had 14 of them — and like thousands of other foreign workers here, a trip to debtors’ prison.

headline: Summer Wins Again
text: Henry Alford writes for Vanity Fair and will publish a book about manners in January.

headline: Murray Stops Fish; Will Face Djokovic in Final
text: MASON, Ohio — Andy Murray’s forehand service return Saturday on his second match point against Mardy Fish appeared good. So much has gone right for Fish during this hard-court season, he challenged the linesman’s call, anyway, figuring he had nothing to lose but the match.

headline: Humble Service With a Side of Swag
text: I’d love to see Meryl Streep win another Oscar, I pray for the invention of fat-burning ice cream and I share many a pageant finalist’s dewy dream of world peace.

headline: Nuns, a ‘Dying Breed,’ Fade From Leadership Roles at Catholic Hospitals
text: ST. LOUIS — When Sister Mary Jean Ryan entered the convent as a young nurse in 1960, virtually every department of every Catholic hospital was run by a nun, from pediatrics to dietary to billing. After her retirement on July 31 as the chief executive of one of the country’s largest networks of Catholic hospitals, only 11 nuns remained among her company’s more than 22,000 employees, and none were administrators.

headline: Murray Is Not Checking His Phone
text: MASON, Ohio — The Scotsman Andy Murray makes an inviting target for the British tabloids, especially during the Wimbledon fortnight when his every move — from his cheese pizza delivery order to his stepping out to the London theater — is reported.

headline: Clair George, Spy and Iran-Contra Figure, Dies at 81
text: Clair E. George, a consummate spymaster who moved the chess pieces in the Central Intelligence Agency’s clandestine games of intrigue before being convicted of lying to Congress about the Iran-contra affair, died Aug. 11 in Bethesda, Md. He was 81.

headline: With Age Came Patience to Wait Out Passing Frenzy

headline: Battle Begins for the Libyan Capital
text: The Lede followed the first effort by Libyan rebels to capture the country’s capital, Tripoli, on Saturday.

headline: Mets Closers Past and Present Don’t Come Through

headline: Laser Advances in Nuclear Fuel Stir Terror Fear
text: Scientists have long sought easier ways to make the costly material known as enriched uranium — the fuel of nuclear reactors and bombs, now produced only in giant industrial plants.

headline: Joke’s on Sharapova as Djokovic Goes Blond
text: MASON, Ohio — With a match record of 57-1 this year, Novak Djokovic is doing a pretty fair imitation of Roger Federer five years ago when he finished with a record of 92-5. His impression of Maria Sharapova, on the other hand, could use some work.

headline: Perry Mines Texas System to Raise Cash for Campaigns
text: Two years ago, John McHale, an entrepreneur from Austin, Tex., who has given millions of dollars to Democratic candidates and causes, did something very unusual for him: he wrote a $50,000 check to a Republican candidate, Rick Perry, then seeking a third full term as governor of Texas. In September 2010, he did it again, catapulting himself into the top ranks of Mr. Perry’s donors.

headline: To Senior Players, Fifth Major Doesn’t Really Feel Like One
text: HARRISON, N.Y. — Fred Couples, the 1992 Masters champion, is one round from his second major professional title, the Champions Tour’s Senior Players Championship.

headline: A Hollywood Anachronism, Serving Stars but Never Gossip
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Jennifer Aniston is Table 24, a coveted perch with a view of the piano yet screened from prying eyes by a bank of Casablanca lilies. Anderson Cooper is Table 11, with its panoramic view across the dining room. Sean Penn is Table 20, except on those nights when a certain agent he’s at war with is in the house. A major studio executive who dines on successive nights with his daughter, wife and mistress is guided to cozy spots at Tables 21, 22 and 12.

headline: Young Generation’s Best Skip a World Title Event

headline: Alex Rodriguez Expected to Return on Sunday vs. Twins

headline: Burnett Leaves Early in Anger, and Girardi Heatedly Defends Him

text: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He wraps up the A.F.C. South today with a look at the Houston Texans. He wrote previously about the Colts,  the Titans and the Jaguars.

headline: London’s Notting Hill Carnival Still on Despite Recent Rioting
text: Because of the million or more people who attend it, the Notting Hill Carnival, an annual celebration of Caribbean culture, can feel overwhelming to say the least. Sprawling over roughly 20 miles of West London, the carnival is often cited as one of the largest street festivals in Europe. This year’s festival takes place on Aug. 28 and 29, from 9 a.m. to 7 p.m.

headline: California Court Weighs Proposition 8
text: A ballot initiative that outlawed gay marriage faces a legal test in the California Supreme Court. The hearing has drawn supporters and opponents of the measure.

headline: Taking Baby Photos You’ll Drool Over
text: Babies don’t take direction very well (if they did we should start by getting them to shush on airplanes), but Me Ra Koh has made a specialty of coaxing warm, memorable photos from infants,  newborns and children. She has had her work showcased on Oprah, written how-to books such as “Your Baby in Pictures,” and teaches women’s workshops.

headline: A Memorial to Colonial Life
text: The convent in southern France that will house a controversial memorial to the “pieds noirs.”

headline: Russia Trip Hints North Korea Is Ready to Do Business
text: SEOUL, South Korea — An armored train carried the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il to a hydroelectric plant in Siberia on Sunday, according to news reports and two South Korean officials, amid signs that Mr. Kim might be seeking a lucrative role in relaying Russian energy sources to South Korea and Japan.

headline: Pope Urges Pilgrims in Spain to Stay True to Their Beliefs
text: MADRID — Pope Benedict XVI closed the religious ceremonies of World Youth Day on Sunday with a giant Mass in which he told young people to “swim against the tide” and abide by the principles of the Catholic Church despite broader changes in society.

headline: Seeking a Functioning Parliament, Afghan Panel Upends Vote Results
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The beleaguered election commission here declared on Sunday, after months of intense political pressure, that it would change the results of the latest parliamentary elections.

headline: German Leaders Reiterate Opposition to Euro Bonds as a Way to Ease Crisis
text: FRANKFURT — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Sunday re-emphasized her opposition to issuing bonds backed by all the euro zone countries, a position that will be greeted enthusiastically by many of her fellow citizens but could unsettle investors at the beginning of what could be another difficult week in global financial markets.

headline: Huntsman Calls His Rivals ‘Unelectable’
text: WASHINGTON – Jon M. Huntsman Jr., the former Utah governor who has been stuck in the second tier of candidates for the Republican presidential nomination, took an aggressive new tone during a televised interview on Sunday, saying that recent remarks from two of his major rivals were “extreme” and “unrealistic.”

headline: Former Oasis Singer Sues His Brother
text: The battling Gallagher brothers are it again, and this time the feud is heading to court. Liam Gallagher, erstwhile singer of Oasis, is suing his brother and former bandmate, Noel, for saying last month that Liam’s hangover forced the band to cancel a concert two years ago.

headline: Show Goes on for Petkovic, Even in Defeat
text: 3:01 p.m. | Updated MASON, Ohio — The line tennis players straddle between entertaining their fans and their own best interests was illustrated poignantly Saturday night by Andrea Petkovic, who played her semifinal against Jelena Jankovic at the Western and Southern Open with a meniscus tear in her surgically-repaired right knee.

headline: Jubilant Rebels Control Much of Tripoli
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s grip on power dissolved with astonishing speed on Monday as rebels marched into the capital and arrested two of his sons, while residents raucously celebrated the prospective end of his four-decade-old rule.

headline: ‘Conan’ Proves Weaker Than He Looks
text: It was a weekend of carnage at the box office, but not in the way that “Conan the Barbarian” had hoped. That gory remake, financed by Nu Image for about $90 million and distributed by Lionsgate, took in an anemic $10 million in North American theaters. A variety of factors probably contributed, including a lack of interest by women in the subject matter, terrible reviews and a release date when consumers were distracted with vacations or back-to-school preparations. Two other new films also flopped. A $30 million remake of “Fright Night” (DreamWorks Studios) sold $8.3 million in tickets, while the $15 million drama “One Day” (Focus Features) took in $5 million.

headline: Fans Flock to Disney Expo in California
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Fans are by their nature hyper-enthusiastic. But throw red meat at them — as the Walt Disney Company did to devotees here over the weekend, previewing new movies and theme park rides — and the clamor can be downright daunting, especially for buttoned-up Disney executives.

headline: Team Claims It Has Found Oldest Fossils
text: A team of Australian and British geologists have discovered fossilized, single-cell organisms that are 3.4 billion years old and that the scientists say are the oldest known fossils on earth.

headline: John J. Kelley, Marathon Champion, Dies at 80
text: John J. Kelley, a former high school English teacher who won the 1957 Boston Marathon and eight consecutive national marathon championships, died Sunday in North Stonington, Conn. He was 80.

text: As rebels crept to within 10 miles of the Libyan capital, they vowed to combine forces with insurgents who have waged intense battles inside Tripoli.

headline: 1928 Coventry Eagle, Rival of the Brough Superior, Sells for $265,000 at Pebble Beach
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — One of the top sales over all on Thursday, and the highest-grossing motorcycle sold during the week of collector vehicle auctions around the 2011 Pebble Beach Concours d’Élégance, was a 1928 Coventry Eagle Flying-8. It went across the block at Bonhams for $265,000, including commission.

headline: Pixar Announces Two Original Films
text: Pixar Animation Studios, battered a bit by critics of late for its embrace of sequels like “Cars 2,” announced two new original films over the weekend, although details were spare and both are still untitled.

headline: A Conservative Beachhead in the Sunshine
text: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The mid-’90s were rough on Democrats, especially here in this beachhead of fabulously wealthy political donors. Their money wasn’t enough to keep the Democratic Party in control of Congress. The famous Kennedy estate on North Ocean Boulevard, known as the “Winter White House” during the administration of John F. Kennedy, was sold to a New York banker who now holds Republican fund-raisers there.

headline: Airstrike Kills 7 in Northern Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Seven Iraqis traveling in a pickup truck were killed in an airstrike on Sunday in Iraqi Kurdistan, the semiautonomous region in northern Iraq, according to local officials. Two of the victims were children, they added.

headline: Efforts Seek to Restore Calm Between Israel and Hamas

headline: The Struggles They Faced After That Day

headline: ‘A Charity Case’ Casting

The play, which Ms. Beckett will also direct, is to begin previews at the Clurman Theater on Oct. 28, with an opening night set for Nov. 1. Additional casting has yet to be announced. As described in a news release, Ms. Beckett’s play “examines the adoption triangle between a birth mother, the relinquishing mother and a 17-year-old daughter.”

headline: Childhood Images and Wilde’s Torments
text: As the summer comes to an end Bargemusic is increasing the new-music quotient at its concerts, in preparation for the four-day new-music celebration that has become the barge’s Labor Day weekend tradition in recent years. The pianist Doris Stevenson offered a teaser for these festivities on Thursday evening, when she played an energetic, bright-edged Here and Now recital.

headline: A Championship Is Up for Grabs in Croatia

headline: Hindu Mythology Comes to Life on the Streets of New York
text: The tourist in me looks forward each year to the Downtown Dance Festival’s open-air performances. Some of the dances the festival presents are considerably less equal than others, but every year I know I’m going to see companies new to me, often from other parts of the world, all playing against memorable settings in southernmost Manhattan.

headline: Girardi Discusses Burnett, Calmly
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Late Saturday night, after A.J. Burnett stormed off the mound with a three-word, double-profanity outburst, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi defended the struggling pitcher with a small outburst of his own during a postgame session with reporters.

text: The Times’s Kareem Fahim reports from Zawiyah, Libya, where rebels are advancing toward Tripoli.

headline: Stravinsky’s Catalog Yields Tasty Plums
text: The Mostly Mozart Festival’s secondary focus on Stravinsky this summer has been a hit, no doubt because the most frequently heard of his works — the three early ballets, the various incarnations of “L’Histoire du Soldat” and “Pulcinella” — have largely been bypassed in favor of worthy scores that are not programmed continuously through the season.

headline: How to Sleep on a Plane
text: More than two million travelers will board commercial airplanes today. Check-in kiosks. Sockfeet at security. Overhead storage.

headline: Font Pain and Poetry: So Much Depends on a Curve
text: Font wonks fight. They champion some typefaces and sneer at others. They go ballistic if a system of signage is altered, as when Ikea changed its designated corporate font from Futura to Verdana in 2009. And they show off tribal symbols. A T-shirt that is depicted in Simon Garfield’s “Just My Type: A Book About Fonts” is adorned with nothing but the ornate ampersand of the font Caslon. This graphic, Mr. Garfield remarks, is capable of “occasionally eliciting a nod from another aficionado, like smug fans of a cool pop band before it becomes famous.”

headline: Monday: Doughnuts, Topologically Speaking
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Milo Beckman made his debut in June with a sensational Friday grid (Across Lite, Solution, blog), and he’s back today. Fortunately, he’s going easy on us this time with a Monday grid that I enjoyed.

headline: A ‘Ninja Warrior’ Upgrade Into Network Prime Time
text: The American embrace of full-contact Japanese game shows — from reconditioned originals like the former “MXC” on Spike to clones like “Wipeout” on ABC — has to do with the appeal of bright colors, spectacular crashes and other people’s embarrassment and discomfort. And, of course, the pleasure of rooting for a winner: after all the carnage, someone is crowned champion.

headline: ‘Annie Hall’ Meets ‘Manhattan’ in Los Angeles
text: When AMC started a division to develop original Web series, it was reasonable to expect that the online shows would resemble the channel’s ballyhooed television dramas — “Breaking Bad,” “Mad Men,” “The Walking Dead,” “The Killing” — that traffic in pitch-black humor and grim horror and film noir. But the only thing darker than usual about “The Trivial Pursuits of Arthur Banks,” the first AMC Digital Studios production, is the black and white cinematography. The three-episode, 42-minute project, which goes live on Monday at amctv.com and Hulu, is a loving send-up of Woody Allen in his European art-house phase, complete with limited color palette, melancholy jazz score and Adam Goldberg standing in for Mr. Allen as the sex-and-maybe-love-obsessed male artist.

headline: It Takes a Headless Lady to Cause New Yorkers to Stop
text: An Upper West Sider is walking past Citarella when her head falls off. Two elegant couples celebrate New Year’s Eve at the Waldorf-Astoria with increasing venom. A gay man visits his dementia-isolated mother in Queens.

headline: Cantonese Erotic Fantasy: 3-D and One Lousy Lover
text: The Cantonese historical fantasy “3D Sex and Zen: Extreme Ecstasy” was banned in mainland China but is now rolling out in cities across the United States and Canada. The Chinese government has committed either an astute piece of film criticism, an insidious act of cultural terrorism or both.

headline: Dark but Danceable Visions of a Chilly Technological Future
text: Handsome Furs were every bit the manic electro party band when they performed at Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night. Dan Boeckner and Alexei Perry, a married couple from Montreal, each had a bank of keyboards and synthesizers synced to pumping drum-machine beats. The nasal, staccato riffs and responses harked back to 1980s synth-pop and its starker sibling, Krautrock: half-mechanized, insistent and catchy.

headline: Nova Extends a Streak on a Day of Good News
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Other than a botched play in the outfield that did not prove costly, there was much for the Yankees to admire and savor about Sunday’s 3-0 victory against the Minnesota Twins.

headline: Web Site Ranks Hacks and Bestows Bragging Rights
text: So you think you can hack?

headline: Sutra Dance Theater
text: Photos of a performance at One New York Plaza.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Mexican President Stars in New Tourism Pitch
text: President Felipe Calderón of Mexico has a new role in efforts to lift Mexico’s sagging tourism industry, according to The Associated Press. Mr. Calderón, 49, will appear as an adventure guide of sorts in 30-minute television programs to appear starting next month on public television stations in the United States. He wears an Indiana Jones-style hat and a harness and descends a rope into a cavern, accompanied by Peter Greenberg, host of the “The Royal Tour” series. The A.P. reports that Mr. Calderón also straps on scuba tanks to lead Mr. Greenberg into a sinkhole lake, known as a cenote, in the Yucatán and helps a Lacandon Indian paddle a boat down a jungle river. Mr. Calderón’s message is that Mexico is safe for tourists. Foreign tourism in 2010, not including border-area visitors, was down 6.3 percent from 2008 levels, and the first half of 2011 saw a 2 percent decline from the same period in 2010, according to the country’s central bank. The global economy and Mexico’s drug violence have been blamed, though foreign tourists have not been targets of the violence.

headline: Four Deutsche Bank Employees Are Charged in South Korea
text: Four Deutsche Bank employees and its South Korean brokerage house face a trial at a South Korean court after they were charged by prosecutors with causing a one-day rout in stocks in November that wiped out $27 billion in value, the company confirmed on Saturday.

headline: Skype Buys GroupMe, a Mobile Messaging Start-Up
text: Skype, the Internet calling service, said on Sunday that it was buying GroupMe, a year-old start-up in New York that offers a group-messaging service for cellphones.

headline: Comic’s PAC Is More Than a Gag
text: Let’s start with a spot political quiz. Which of the following are legitimate political action committees known as Super PACs, and which is fake?

headline: Carl Hanford, Kelso’s Trainer, Dies at 95
text: In the spring of 1960, as the nation’s leading 3-year-old thoroughbreds vied in the Triple Crown, Carl Hanford began training horses for Allaire du Pont at her Bohemia Stable in Maryland. One of his first projects was a 3-year-old who had been gelded by his previous trainer to help him gain weight and to calm an ornery disposition. His name was Kelso.

headline: Spend Now, Save Later, Bond Fund Leaders Say
text: WASHINGTON — Early in Bill Clinton’s presidency, his populist advisers saw their spending plans crash into resistance from Wall Street, which demanded deficit-cutting austerity.

headline: On Wall St., a Big Split on Outlook
text: Amid all the grim economic data and a chorus of warnings of a fresh recession, one group on Wall Street has remained remarkably optimistic despite the dangers that may lie ahead — the research analysts who track individual companies.

headline: F.B.I.’s Man on the Pirate Beat, Seeking Confessions
text: In the F.B.I.’s expansive offices in Lower Manhattan, a black-and-white banner on Special Agent Kevin P. Coughlin’s desk stands out amid the rows of cubicles. It is a Jolly Roger, skull above crossed swords, the pirate’s calling card.

headline: Tribal Clashes Raise Fears of Instability in South Sudan
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Tribal clashes in a region of newly independent South Sudan have killed at least 58 people in the past week, the United Nations says, raising fears of ethnic instability in the deeply impoverished country.

headline: Summer Diversions to Fill the ‘Mad Men’ Void
text: FOR the last four summers, Madison Avenue has been absorbed in “Mad Men,” the AMC series about the advertising industry in the 1960s. But a delay in production for the coming season means there are no new episodes until early next year.

headline: Five Steps to Solving Europe’s Debt Crisis
text: The crisis of 2008 is repeating itself in reverse. Three years ago, European governments stepped in to save the banking sector. Today, the euro zone’s indebted sovereigns are threatening to cause a full-scale bank panic and possibly even another credit crisis. Europe’s lenders must be insulated from their governments and vice versa. Five radical steps could break the bank-sovereign “doom loop.”

headline: To Enjoy Fall Scenery, Prepare for Uneven Lies
text: For a lot of golfers, the late summer and approaching fall is the best time to play. It’s less crowded and the air is crisper. A personal choice of mine is to head for the hills, where the foliage and scenery enhance every round. But if you play where there are elevation changes, you will find yourself with a lot of sidehill and downhill lies off the tee.

headline: N.Y. Still Pursues Case Against Whistle-Blower
text: ALBANY — The Cuomo administration is continuing to pursue a two-year-old disciplinary case against Jeffrey Monsour, a state employee at the Office for People With Developmental Disabilities who has been an outspoken critic of the agency’s management.

headline: Career-Worst Day For Indians’ Jimenez, the Ace Who Isn’t
text: DETROIT – There is no cheering in the press box, as the rule goes, but as far as I know, we’re allowed an occasional exclamation. At the end of the Tigers/Indians series on Sunday at Comerica Park, I let out a “Wow!” Couldn’t help it. Not often do you see a game end on a double play from center field to the plate.

headline: A Champion’s Putter Worth Its Weights
text: Most of the putter talk after Keegan Bradley’s Aug. 14 victory in the P.G.A. Championship was about how he became the first player to use a belly putter to win a men’s major. Bradley used an Odyssey White Hot XG Sabertooth that was nearly 47 inches long. I’m a golf traditionalist, but I’m also tired of the debate. Long putters will never be banned at this point and they no doubt help some people keep playing golf. Let’s get used to them.

headline: How to Take Lessons in the Winter (or in Secret)
text: The overwhelming majority of recreational golfers do not take lessons. It is another one of those quizzical, only-in-golf mysteries. Most of us could use help and the help is widely available, so, naturally, most golfers instead keep their heads down (or not) and plod on, hoping to master the game on their own.

headline: Attorney General of N.Y. Is Said to Face Pressure on Bank Foreclosure Deal
text: Eric T. Schneiderman, the attorney general of New York, has come under increasing pressure from the Obama administration to drop his opposition to a wide-ranging state settlement with banks over dubious foreclosure practices, according to people briefed on discussions about the deal.

headline: The Kids Are Not All Right
text: Vancouver, British Columbia

headline: The Hidden Costs of Higher Ed
text: OVER the next few weeks, millions of Americans will be heading off to college, and despite the promise of need-blind admissions, more of them than ever will be struggling to pay for it. It’s not just the economy’s fault: even as they publicize lavish financial aid packages, colleges and universities are making it harder for average American families to afford higher education, while making it easier for the wealthy.

headline: How Italy Is Adjusting
text: Turin, Italy

headline: Are There Any Big Ideas Anymore?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thousands Back Antigraft Hunger Strike in New Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — Sunil and Suman Wadhwa dressed their 4-year-old son in a crisp white shirt and checkered shorts on Sunday for the blisteringly hot trip into New Delhi. They had never participated in a political rally, but after watching the anticorruption campaigner Anna Hazare on television, they wanted to do more than watch.

headline: Grieving After 9/11
text: To the Editor:

headline: Equality for Transgenders
text: To the Editor:

headline: Regulate Online Gambling
text: To the Editor:

headline: Motorola’s Identity Crisis
text: Hundreds of framed patents hang on two separate walls at the headquarters of Motorola Mobility in Libertyville, Ill. They testify to the pride in innovation at Motorola, a luminary of American business that has survived corporate crises and enormous technological change.

headline: Biggest Brewer Could Be Going, Going, Gone
text: The son of a former big leaguer, Prince Fielder has a keen appreciation for baseball’s history. For instance, to Fielder one perk of playing in Milwaukee is that Robin Yount, who spent his entire Hall of Fame career with the Brewers, sometimes stops by to visit the team.

headline: Trade Commission Challenges a Hospital Merger
text: WASHINGTON — Obama administration officials have been roaming the country, talking up their vision of a future in which doctors and hospitals team up to provide better care at lower cost. But a starkly different picture is unfolding this summer in a courtroom here, where lawyers from the Federal Trade Commission have been challenging a hospital merger in Toledo, Ohio.

headline: Would-Be Billionaires, Lost in Song
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Train Line Far From Arrival Has a Color to Be Noticed
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority may be criticized for its weekend service suspensions, broken escalators and packed L trains.

headline: Local TV Newscasts Expanding
text: ST. LOUIS — Coming soon to this city’s television screens: more news at 4 in the morning, again at 10, and at 4 in the afternoon.

headline: Federal Push for ‘Cloud’ Technology Faces Skepticism
text: WASHINGTON — Before cost-cutting became fashionable in Washington, Vivek Kundra, the White House’s chief information officer, was working to shrink the federal government’s enormous budget for information technology.

headline: In California, a Second Episode of Fan Violence
text: For the second time in less than five months, officials in California are investigating a violent event involving sports fans, after two people were shot Saturday in the parking lot of Candlestick Park in San Francisco following a professional football game.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: ConvaTec Said to Bid for Kinetic Concepts
text: ConvaTec, a company owned by two private equity firms, has made a bid for Kinetic Concepts that is higher than the wound-healing technology company’s $4.9 billion deal with another group of investors, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday.

headline: Messing With Texas
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas hasn’t lost an election in 10 tries. Among his vanquished opponents, this streak has inspired not only the usual mix of resentment and respect, but a touch of supernatural awe. “Running against Perry,” one of them told Texas Monthly, “is like running against God.”

headline: Housekeeper’s Lawyer Says He Will Seek a Special Prosecutor
text: The lawyer for the woman who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault said on Sunday that he would formally ask the judge overseeing the criminal case to disqualify the Manhattan district attorney’s office from the prosecution and appoint a special prosecutor.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Did Newark Bet on the Wrong Sport?
text: NEWARK — When the first pitch was thrown, there wasn’t much of a crowd in the ballpark to see it. Entire sections were unoccupied. The flow of people through the front gate was a trickle. The most fan-generated noise came from a children’s birthday party on a concourse in the right-field corner.

headline: Homeowners Need Help
text: Neither Congress, nor federal regulators, nor state or federal prosecutors have yet to conduct a thorough investigation into the mortgage bubble and financial bust. We welcomed the news that the Justice Department is investigating allegations that Standard & Poor’s purposely overrated toxic mortgage securities in the years before the bust. We hope the investigative circle will widen.

headline: Surveillance and Coordination With NATO Aided Rebels
text: WASHINGTON — As rebel forces in Libya converged on Tripoli on Sunday, American and NATO officials cited an intensification of American aerial surveillance in and around the capital city as a major factor in helping to tilt the balance after months of steady erosion of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s military.

headline: With the World Series Champs in a Slump, a City Suffers
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the classic rags-to-riches cautionary tale: a boy from the wrong side of the tracks moves to a new city to make it big. After years of struggle, he gets his break: a string of hits, a hot streak and all the perks that follow, including fame, adoring fans and a television show. But, of course, it comes with a price: self-doubt, questionable decisions and the relentless, almost irrational fear of being a flash in the pan.

headline: N.F.L. Crosses a Boundary in the Pryor Case
text: Terrelle Pryor is expected to become a member of the N.F.L. fraternity Monday when the league holds its supplemental draft.

headline: More Excuses and Delays From the V.A.
text: It has been more than three months since a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit accused the Department of Veterans Affairs of “unchecked incompetence” and unconscionable delays in caring for veterans with mental health problems. Instead of working with the plaintiffs to address the court’s concerns, the V.A. is appealing the ruling.

headline: Going South
text: Even after the brutal battles at Bull Run and Wilson’s Creek had made clear the depth of the conflict awaiting North and South, the people and communities along the border were still trying to decide where their true allegiances lay. Many of them — in Delaware, Maryland, Kentucky and Missouri — tried to find a middle, neutral ground.

headline: Tar Sands and the Carbon Numbers
text: This page opposes the building of a 1,700-mile pipeline called the Keystone XL, which would carry diluted bitumen — an acidic crude oil — from Canada’s Alberta tar sands to the Texas Gulf Coast. We have two main concerns: the risk of oil spills along the pipeline, which would traverse highly sensitive terrain, and the fact that the extraction of petroleum from the tar sands creates far more greenhouse emissions than conventional production does.

headline: Daylight in Yonkers
text: Not all crumbling infrastructure is bad. In Yonkers, on a narrow strip of land sloping up from the Hudson River, lie the gouged-out remains of a downtown plaza and parking lot. It is one of the most encouraging examples of urban destruction the region has seen in years.

headline: A Final Surge to Tripoli
text: Rebels took key towns outside Tripoli and then quickly overran the capital.

headline: Burress Scores for the Jets in His First Game Since ’08
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On the Jets’ opening offensive play Sunday, wide receiver Plaxico Burress was the first player to break the huddle and head toward the line of scrimmage. Burress’s hurry was understandable: It had been 33 months since his last appearance in an N.F.L. game, and he seemed determined not to wait any longer than absolutely necessary.

headline: China and U.S. Choose Safe Site for Biden Visit
text: DUJIANGYAN, China — The choice of sites for visits by foreign leaders is always the product of careful deliberations, but those calculations were particularly evident on Sunday when Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. stopped at a school here.

headline: U.S. Open Favorites Can Hear Footsteps
text: MASON, Ohio

headline: Eager for Spotlight, but Not if It Is on a Testing Scandal
text: WASHINGTON — Why won’t Michelle Rhee talk to USA Today?

headline: Egypt and Israel Move to Halt Growth of Crisis
text: CAIRO — The Egyptian and Israeli governments moved Sunday to ease tensions over fatal cross-border attacks, apparently seeking to stop the crisis from flaring up into a full-scale diplomatic rift.

headline: After Bruising Political Fights, 2 Governors Alter Their Tones
text: SAYNER, Wis. — After Gov. Scott Walker, a Republican in his first months in office, announced early this year that he wanted to cut collective bargaining rights for public workers, relations between political parties in his newly red State Capitol fell into a long, deep frost.

headline: In the Race to Succeed Weiner, a Surprising Anger at Obama
text: Of all the places to hear fulminations against President Obama, one of the least expected is the corner of 71st Avenue and Queens Boulevard, in the heart of a Congressional district that propelled Democrats like Geraldine A. Ferraro, Charles E. Schumer and Anthony D. Weiner to Washington.

headline: For Tigers, Cabrera Is Complete Package, Handled With Care
text: DETROIT — The call came to Dave Dombrowski’s home around Thanksgiving in 2007, and he knew that was unusual. Dombrowski, the president and general manager of the Detroit Tigers, does not usually hear from his boss at home.

headline: Burress Ends His Wait on the Very First Play
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On the Jets’ opening offensive play Sunday, wide receiver Plaxico Burress was the first player to break the huddle and head toward the line of scrimmage. Burress’s hurry was understandable; it had been nearly 33 months since his last appearance in an N.F.L. game, and he seemed determined not to wait any longer than absolutely necessary.

headline: Neighbor Stadiums
text: Bears and Eagles Riverfront Stadium in Newark and Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., are not far apart, but the sizes of their crowds — and perhaps their futures — are very different.

headline: Leaders of the Libyan Rebellion
text: The Libyan rebels fighting to topple Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi are led by longtime opponents of the government and officials who defected once the rebellion began.

headline: Large Zone Near Japanese Reactors to Be Off Limits
text: TOKYO — Broad areas around the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant could soon be declared uninhabitable, perhaps for decades, after a government survey found radioactive contamination that far exceeded safe levels, several major media outlets said Monday.

headline: Rebels Close In on Tripoli
text: As rebels crept to within 10 miles of the Libyan capital, they vowed to combine forces with insurgents who have waged intense battles inside Tripoli.

headline: Pryor’s Presence Adds a Dash of Spice to the Normally Sleepy Supplemental Draft
text: The N.F.L.’s supplemental draft is typically such a non-event that even some of the league’s general managers barely acknowledge it.

headline: A Ministry of Health
text: Mississippi is at the bottom of most health-related lists, and the Mississippi Delta is at the bottom of that bottom. But a church-based initiative is looking to improve the situation.

headline: Preaching a Healthy Diet in the Deep-Fried Delta
text: HERNANDO, Miss. — Not much seems out of place in the Mississippi Delta, where everything appears to be as it always has been, only more so as the years go by. But here in the fellowship hall of a little Baptist church on a country road is an astonishing sight: a plate of fresh fruit.

headline: Cycling Stars Journey to Colorado to Test the Air
text: As Australia’s newly minted Tour de France champion, Cadel Evans, sees it, this week’s inaugural running of the USA Pro Cycling Challenge is something of a high-altitude science project on wheels. Evans’s familiar rivals from Luxembourg, the brothers Andy and Frank Schleck — who finished second and third in France — seem to agree: it’s all about the rarefied air.

headline: Instead of a Bloody Struggle, a Headlong Rush Into a Cheering Capital
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — In the end, it was more of a Sunday drive than a punishing final offensive.

headline: Couples Wins, Beating Wind and a Sore Hip
text: HARRISON, N.Y. — Fred Couples never looked right Sunday.

headline: A Reluctant Sports Star Discreetly Takes His Leave
text: When Chris Drury announced his retirement from the N.H.L. on Friday, of course it was in the most low-profile way possible. There were no news conferences, no television appearances, no teary-eyed remembrances of a 12-year career. He had the players union release a statement and that was it. It did not even contain a quotation from Drury.

headline: For Georgetown, a Peaceful Win in China
text: SHANGHAI — Three days after an ugly brawl ended an exhibition basketball game between Georgetown and a Chinese professional team, the Hoyas played another game here on Sunday without incident.

headline: Jimmy Sangster, Writer for British Horror Films, Dies at 83
text: Jimmy Sangster, a prolific screenwriter best known for his classic 1950s horror movies that dipped into the cinematic delights of gore and sex and helped define the British company Hammer Films, died on Friday. He was 83.
