text: NYT: Front Page for 08/22/2011

headline: Movie Clip: Higher Ground
text: A scene from Farmiga's directorial debut, “Higher Ground,” based on the novel by Carolyn S. Briggs.

headline: Window Falls Remain a Childhood Hazard
text: Nearly 100,000 children, most of them under the age of 5, have been injured after falling from a window during the past two decades in the United States, new research shows.

headline: Word of the Day | tyranny
text: tyranny •\ˈtir-ə-ne\• noun

headline: Sports Replay: Aug. 21
text: The day in sports, including baseball, surfing, and the San Francisco Triathlon at Alcatraz.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Case Is Said to Be Set for Dismissal
text: Three months after authorizing Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s swift indictment after his arrest on sexual assault charges, the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., has decided to ask a judge to dismiss the case, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: Nunez Impresses With Bat, if Not His Glove
text: Eduardo Nunez of the Yankees has had big shoes to fill this season. He started at shortstop while Derek Jeter was on the disabled list in June and started the bulk of the games at third base after Alex Rodriguez had knee surgery in July.

headline: Rebels Enter Tripoli
text: Libyan rebels marched into the capital with relative ease.

headline: New Sponsor on W.N.B.A. Uniforms
text: The W.N.B.A. has signed a long-term deal with Boost Mobile that will put the cellphone company’s logo on most teams’ jerseys.

headline: Comfort Zones
text: One psychoanalyst photographs other psychoanalysts where they work.

headline: Qaddafi’s Son Taunts Rebels in Tripoli
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The euphoria that followed the rebels’ triumphant march in Tripoli gave way to confusion and wariness on Monday, as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi remained at large, his son Seif al-Islam made a surprise appearance at a hotel with foreign journalists, and pockets of loyalist forces stubbornly resisted rebel efforts to take control of the capital.

headline: Stocks Barely Rise After Long Losing Streak
text: Coming off four straight weeks of brutal losses, stocks ended barely higher on Monday, as investors’ attention turned to the Federal Reserve’s annual symposium later this week in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Aug. 22, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “At Stores, Making 5 for $5 a Bigger Draw Than 1 for $1.”

headline: North Korea to Auction Resort Owned by South
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Monday gave South Korean tourism officials 72 hours to leave a mountain resort, saying it would start auctioning off South Korean-owned hotels, restaurants and other remnants of what used to be a symbol of inter-Korean cooperation.

headline: News Quiz | Aug. 22, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Aug. 22, 1902 | Theodore Roosevelt Becomes First President to Ride in an Automobile
text: On Aug. 22, 1902, President Theodore Roosevelt kicked off a tour of New England with a car ride through Connecticut. His journey marked the first time a United States president made a public appearance by automobile while in office.

headline: In Ireland, Ghosts of Towns That Never Were
text: Property Listing: Three bedrooms! Two baths! Half an acre! Living room, with fireplace. Close to schools and parks. Absolutely no neighbors!

headline: Malaysian Opposition Leader Begins Defense
text: KUALA LUMPUR — The Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim began his defense in his sodomy trial on Monday, declaring the charges “a vile and despicable attempt at character assassination.”

headline: Eli Manning’s Interceptions, One by One
text: On Sunday, Jorge Castillo of The Times wrote of Eli Manning:

headline: Plaxico Burress’s Impressive Return, in His Words
text: A lot of people have shared their opinions about how well Plaxico Burress will do (or won’t do) in his first season since being released from jail. Burress spoke with his play in his preseason debut on Sunday night with the Jets, with a catch on the team’s opening offensive play and a diving touchdown catch before halftime. The message to the rest of the league seemed to be: Don’t dare cover me one-one-one. Oh, and I’m back.

headline: A Sales Tax on Wall Street Transactions
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: In Madrid, Exploring Galicia Through Photography
text: A disinterested priest takes confession from an elderly woman. A young girl walks in a Catholic procession with large votive candles clutched in her tiny hands. A woman lies in a coffin and cools herself with a fan. Each of these memorable scenes appear in “Transtempo,” an exhibition of Cristina García Rodero’s photography on view through Oct. 2 at the Círculo de Bellas Artes de Madrid (Calle Alcalá, 42; 34-91-360-5400; www.circulobellasartes.com).

headline: Americans Abroad: Goals Galore, Transfers and More
text: The soccer transfer window in Europe slams shut on Aug. 31, which means it’s a nervous time for players stuck in unfavorable situations.

headline: Another 15 Minutes of Fame for an iPad Case
text: Andy Warhol said that “In the future, everyone will be world famous for 15 minutes.” With its second line of iPhone, iPad and MacBook covers featuring Warhol artwork, the manufacturer Incase is apparently going for a half hour.

headline: Aug. 22 Updates on the Battle for Libya
text: The Lede is following the battle for the Libyan capital, Tripoli, on Monday as rebel forces seek to push Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from power after nearly 42 years. Read earlier updates from Saturday and Sunday‘s fighting.

headline: Libyan Rebels Arrive in Tripoli
text: WHO has marched into Tripoli?WHO is the leader of Libya?

headline: What Would You Do if You Were President?
text: For an Op-Ed piece, 12 Americans who don’t work in politics or the media were asked what they would do if they were president. What would you do? What issues do you think are most pressing?

headline: This Week in Small Business: Watching Armageddon From an Armchair
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Complaint Box | Generic Street Fairs
text: As our city planners attempt to convert more automotive thoroughfares into usable outdoor space for pedestrians, they might consider throwing a bone to cars by eliminating the six-month traveling commercial circus known as the “street fair.”

headline: Rick Perry’s Scientific Campaign Method
text: Sasha Issenberg, a former Boston Globe reporter who has also written for Monocle, Slate, Philadelphia and The New York Times Magazine, has been writing a book about the new science of campaigns called “The Victory Lab.” It’s scheduled for publication next year.

headline: What Drives Cities’ Runaway Growth?
text: Urban areas are growing even faster than urban populations are, and by 2030 urbanized land around the globe will expand by 590,000 square miles — an amount almost equal to the land mass of Mongolia, according to a new study.

headline: 2011 Chicago Bears Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. He kicks off the N.F.C. North with an analysis of the Bears, who will be playing the Giants tonight in a preseason game.

headline: Mass Graves Hold Thousands, Kashmir Inquiry Finds
text: NEW DELHI — Thousands of bullet-riddled bodies are buried in dozens of unmarked graves across Kashmir, a state human rights commission inquiry has concluded, many of them likely to be those of civilians who disappeared more than a decade ago in a brutal insurgency.

headline: New Fighting Tempers Rebel Euphoria From Headlong Rush Into Capital
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Fresh fighting erupted in the Libyan capital on Monday, as members of a rebel brigade trying to establish a security base near the waterfront came under fire from loyalists to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Reporters accompanying the rebel brigade were forced to duck for cover.

headline: Monday Reading: Another Look at the 15-Year Mortgage
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Ritual Draping of Politics on Sept. 11
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg says that politics must be kept out of the ceremony that will be held on the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. This understandable sentiment is being been sorely tested by New Jersey’s governor, Chris Christie, who has a habit of treating public discourse as if it were roller derby by other means.

headline: Gyrating Markets Are What You Signed Up For
text: During the last few weeks, I’ve heard a lot of chatter about volatility. I knew something was going on when I overheard people at the grocery store talking about their investments, saying things like,”This volatility is killing me.”

headline: A Good Phone With One Bad Feature
text: The myTouch 4G Slide is a well designed phone offering a spacious keyboard, a terrific camera, a fast processor and one of the most infuriating features I have ever encountered — a Wi-Fi calling app that charges you voice minutes.

headline: There’s Room for More G.O.P. Candidates
text: Rather than douse speculation about which additional Republicans might enter the presidential sweepstakes, Rick Perry’s announcement that he would seek the White House seemed only to stoke the fire. At least five prominent Republicans — Sarah Palin, Representative Paul Ryan, Gov. Chris Christie, Rudolph W. Giuliani and George Pataki — are being linked to potential bids.

headline: The S.E.C.’s Document Destruction Problem
text: The revelation that the Securities and Exchange Commission had a history of destroying documents has once again raised questions about how well the agency has exercised its enforcement authority.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Star Analysts Are Back (No Autographs, Please) | It’s official: Internet analysts, the research stars of the dot-com era, are hot again.

headline: 'Calamity Song' by the Decemberists
text: The video is directed by Michael Schur, a co-creator of NBC's "Parks and Recreation." It is based on a section of "Infinite Jest" by David Foster Wallace.

headline: 20 Years Later, Schumacher Returns to Spa
text: The Formula One world is beginning to wake up from its summer break, and the teams are sending out their press release previews as they prepare to step back into the fray for the final half of the season. The Mercedes team highlighted the phenomenal moment the coming Belgian Grand Prix at Spa Francorchamps represents for one of its drivers.

headline: 20 Years Later, Schumacher Returns to Spa
text: The Formula One world is beginning to wake up from its summer break, and the teams are sending out their press release previews as they prepare to step back into the fray for the final half of the season. The Mercedes team highlighted the phenomenal moment the coming Belgian Grand Prix at Spa Francorchamps represents for one of its drivers.

headline: The City Stirs | Brooklyn, 5:21 A.M.
text: “Lost, yesterday, somewhere between sunrise and sunset, two golden hours, each set with sixty diamond minutes. No reward is offered for they are gone forever.”   –  Horace Mann

headline: ‘Infinite Jest’ Scene, Reborn as a Rock Video
text: LOS ANGELES — While there are many details in the life of Michael Schur, the co-creator and show runner of the NBC comedy “Parks and Recreation,” that convey his obsession with the David Foster Wallace novel “Infinite Jest,” perhaps the most salient is that his wife once forbade him from discussing that 1,079-page-long work of fiction at social gatherings. “If you were at a cocktail party and you go, ‘Oh, you’re a person who’s into this?’ ” Mr. Schur said recently at his office in Studio City, “now I know what you and I are doing for the next two hours. We’re talking about this.”

headline: Has Globalization Ruined Street Style?
text: T’s fall reports on mayhem and street fashion – from London, Cairo and Tokyo – beg a question: how has globalization affected street style? The opinion department’s Room for Debate blog asked five experts to weigh in.

headline: TimesCast | Obama's Stakes in Libya
text: The seeming collapse of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's regime represents good news for President Obama after months of criticism for his Libya policy.

headline: ‘Ghost’ Musical to Materialize on Broadway in the Spring
text: There was no immediate warning about whether audience members in the first five rows might be spattered with stray bits of clay, but on Monday the producers of the musical version of “Ghost,” the supernatural romance that showed us how the living and the dead could collaborate around a pottery wheel, said it will come to Broadway in the spring.

headline: Al Jazeera Star Correspondent Rejoins NBC
text: Ayman Mohyeldin, a star Al Jazeera English correspondent, is rejoining NBC News, the news organization where he started 10 years ago.

headline: Shootings Draw Attention to Stadium Violence
text: If you look at professional sports personnel rosters, you will increasingly find someone called a Fan Ambassador or Fan Experience Manager. This person presumably works to make attending games more enjoyable and persuade people to sign over their entire bank account to the team instead of just 90 percent. In light of the weekend’s developments, however, it’s hard to imagine that more T-shirt giveaways or a punt, pass and kick contest will make people less uptight about heading to a stadium these days.

headline: Numberplay: Don’t Make a Triangle, Part 2
text: Katherine Cook of the Math for Love team continues this week with the second in our two-part triangle series. After the puzzle you’ll find Ms. Cook’s essay on the importance of making mistakes in mathematics. Mistakes! Ms. Cook has good things to say about them. We’ve seen this in the best Numberplay discussions — the most productive inquiries  come from what turn out to be initial mis-steps. So let’s go for an abundance of mistakes this week.

headline: Cerberus Kills $1.1 Billion Deal With Innkeepers
text: 5:58 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Temporary Vegetarian: Tomato, Oregano and Feta Risotto
text: The Temporary Vegetarian is retiring as of this column, only to be reborn as a book, renamed “The Occasional Vegetarian,” to be published by Hyperion ($18.99) in October.

headline: Volkswagen Up, a 3-Cylinder City Car, Is Heading to Production
text: In advance of its formal introduction next month at the Frankfurt auto show, the Up, an exercise in fuel efficiency and miniaturization, was unveiled online by Volkswagen over the weekend. The vehicle goes on sale in Europe in December, a holiday gift for the city-car set.

headline: Plant Exploration in Humid Tropical Forests
text: Paola Pedraza, assistant curator of the Institute of Systematic Botany at the New York Botanical Garden, writes about her recent expedition to catalog the flora of Las Orquídeas National Park, Colombia.

headline: The Happiest States of America: North Dakota on the Rise
text: North Dakota is not only the most employment-rich state in the country. It’s also on its way to becoming the happiest.

headline: Does Roger Maris Belong in the Hall?
text: Fans of Roger Maris were quick to respond to my column Sunday, in which I wrote that his 61 home runs looked better than ever after a half century.

headline: Creating a Community
text: A group of seniors came together to build a community for their old age.

headline: Vitamins May Lower Risk of Preterm Births
text: Taking a multivitamin around the time of conception may help women lower their risk of delivering low-birth-weight babies, new research shows. The study, one of the first to look at multivitamin use immediately before and after conception, strengthens the notion that nutritional deficiencies may increase the risk of birth complications.

headline: A Pharaoh Lords Over a Museum
text: A giant 4,000-year-old Egyptian visitor looms over the crowd of live humans milling antlike throughout the vast entry hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He is an extraordinary specimen of regal manhood. Carved from a single block of dark gray granodiorite, he sits in a form-fitting kilt on a cubic throne covered by hieroglyphics. He has the broad shoulders, narrow waist and muscular legs of a well-developed athlete. Sporting a headdress of folded striped fabric, he gazes out over the masses with imperturbable self-assurance and open eyes set in a round, youthful face. He is as thrilling as anything in the Met’s great Egyptian collection.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Winner Take All (A Rock Opera)’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festival’s close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.There isn’t much at the center of “Winner Take All (A Rock Opera),” at the Bleecker Street Theater, but there’s a lot surrounding it, all delightful. Basically, Ricky (Jared Zirilli), a singer-musician, argues with his girlfriend, Catie (Anna Ellinsfeld), dies on his motorcycle and goes to heaven. There he is recruited by angels (Jacquelyn Graham, Darren Lorenzo and Kyle Lamar Mitchell) to confront the Devil (Brian Charles Rooney) and his minions (Kat Nejat and Zakiya Young) in a face-off with “the future of music and all creation at stake.” Catie is roped in; she can sing too, you see, and someone has to restore Ricky’s life.

headline: New Names in the Dior Hat
text: I am not at all surprised that LVMH executives are talking to Marc Jacobs about moving from Louis Vuitton to Dior, as Women’s Wear Daily reported on Monday. Not to disparage Mr. Jacobs’s talents, but where else can they look? With few exceptions, the strategy of Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH, has been to load up his brands with big, bankable stars, and there are not many of them available. Shortly after John Galliano was dismissed from Dior, editors put together an imaginary list of candidates: Alber Elbaz of Lanvin, Tom Ford, Nicolas Ghesquiere of Balenciaga, among others. Yet for obvious reasons these individuals might be happy where they are, as would Sarah Burton, the creative director of Alexander McQueen, whose name surfaced soon after the royal wedding in April. According to WWD, she rebuffed overtures from LVMH.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘Chasing Heaven’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festival’s close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.You’d think Leah Maddrie had a crystal ball. The same week that Stephen Sondheim’s letter to The New York Times about Diane Paulus’s forthcoming revisionist production of “Porgy and Bess” became the talk of the town, Ms. Maddrie’s “Chasing Heaven” began its run at the New York International Fringe Festival.

headline: Low Wages in Texas
text: I guess Ross Douthat’s column requires some sort of reply. So let me address three issues.

headline: Weighing Race and Hate in a Mississippi Killing
text: JACKSON, Miss. — No one disputes that James Craig Anderson, a middle-aged black family man with a quick wit and a demanding sense of style, was robbed, beaten and then run over by a group of white teenagers in a motel parking lot early one morning in June.

headline: Qaddafi’s Whereabouts Still a Mystery as Rumors Swirl
text: He has exalted himself as the brother leader of Libya, the dean of Arab rulers and the king of kings of Africa. On Monday, though, he was the autocrat who could not be found.

headline: Spotted on the Street | Katie Fogarty
text: In this new column, the makeup artist Tina Turnbow runs into real beauty on the streets of New York City.The Girl: Katie Fogarty, a model with Next and a future culinary-school student.

headline: Early Stimulus Worries
text: Some readers have asked for cites in which I warned early on that the Obama stimulus was too small and would end up being seen as a failure. Here’s my initial math. Here’s my reaction on the ARRA’s passage. And here’s my early take on the political economy.

headline: Save the Statistical Abstract
text: I don’t usually find myself in hearty agreement with Robert Samuelson, but he’s right about this. The Statistical Abstract is a hugely important resource; experts in a particular field may not need it, but it’s invaluable to non-experts in need of basic information.

headline: Ford and Toyota to Work Together on Hybrid System for Trucks
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Ford Motor Company and Toyota Motor said on Monday that they would jointly develop a gas-electric hybrid fuel system for pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles aimed at keeping larger models affordable as the automakers work to meet stricter fuel-economy standards.

headline: Sentence of the Week, Ahoy
text: A small hand-harvested batch of sentences this week, aged for one week in the oaky cask of my Twitter feed:

headline: Getting Noticed at the Fringe: ‘Greenland’
text: ArtsBeat is taking a look at some of the most clever, mysterious and strikingly designed postcards created to draw attention among the nearly 200 productions in this year’s New York International Fringe Festival.

headline: A Fundamental Republican Science Problem
text: Many efforts to gauge why most Republicans reject or doubt the science pointing to risks from unabated emissions of greenhouse gases are issue-centric. It’s fossil fuel money. It’s disinformation campaigns that spin scientific complexity and some overheated warming rhetoric into a carbon-tax conspiracy.

headline: Under Bloomberg, a Sharp Rise in Accusations of Cheating by Educators
text: Annual allegations of test-tampering and grade-changing by educators have more than tripled since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took control of New York City’s school system, outpacing a broader increase in complaints of adult misconduct in schools during the same period, according to the special commissioner of investigation.

headline: Governing in the Gap
text: Recently I had a chance to meet the great Israeli writer David Grossman at a writer’s conference in Sun Valley, Idaho (life is good). He was mostly talking about his novel, “To the End of the Land,” but I was equally struck by his collection of essays, “Writing in the Dark.” I was struck by this passage:

headline: The dance of the flamingos, new questions about a newborn ritual and malaria in the microwave.
text: The dance of the flamingos, new questions about a newborn ritual and malaria in the microwave.

headline: TimesCast | Surveilling Libya Pays Off
text: According to military officials, an intensification of U.S. surveillance in Libya was an important factor in the collapse of the Qaddafi regime.

headline: Economic Lessons in Children’s Literature
text: An article of mine in the Sunday Review section looked at finding economic lessons in children’s books, with lots of contributions from economists and fellow parents. The list in the story was obviously just a start, and many readers had their own thoughts.

headline: Bing Considers Low-Rated ‘Glee Project’ a Success
text: Executives at the Oxygen cable channel and the Bing search engine operated by Microsoft say they are pleased with the results of the Bing sponsorship of a new reality series, despite the show’s very rocky start in the ratings.

headline: Afghan Villagers Stone a Taliban Commander to Death
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Angry villagers stoned to death a local Taliban commander and his bodyguard in southern Afghanistan Sunday after the militants killed a 60-year-old man accused of aiding the government, Afghan officials said.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q. (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Kathleen Barnes joined Kelliher Samets Volk, Burlington, Vt., in a new post, as a public relations and social media associate. She had been the annual giving coordinator in the Office of Parent and Alumni Relations at Champlain College, Burlington.

headline: Recyclebank Seeks to School Consumers on Environment
text: Certain colors have long been associated with the back-to-school season: yellow for pencils, red for apples, and black and white for the marblelike covers of composition books. Now a company is hoping to add green to that list.

headline: Original Model T’s | Mark Ohe
text: No. 5 in a series of original artworks.

headline: 34 Years Later, Supreme Court Will Revisit Eyewitness IDs
text: WASHINGTON — Every year, more than 75,000 eyewitnesses identify suspects in criminal investigations. Those identifications are wrong about a third of the time, a pile of studies suggest.

headline: Born, and Evolved, to Run
text: Among his academic peers, Daniel Lieberman, 47, is known as a “hoof and mouth” man.

headline: Sending a Child to College
text: All parenting milestones mark both beginnings and ends. First steps, and smiles, and days of school all bring our children closer to something — but also further away from us.

headline: Amy Winehouse’s Father Returns Donations for Planned Foundation
text: The father of Amy Winehouse, the British soul singer who died last month, said he has had to return donations to people who supported his plan to set up a foundation in his daughter’s name because someone else had claimed “The Amy Winehouse Foundation” as an Internet domain name, The Guardian reported Monday.

headline: Student Journalism | A Guide to Rights and Responsibilities
text: Perhaps you’re a veteran school newspaper adviser, or maybe you’re a new teacher who has just been handed the school paper as part of your program. Or you may find yourself as part of an effort to start or relaunch a school newspaper or journalism course. Or maybe you’re looking to refresh your curriculum – or integrate the Common Core Standards — in new ways this school year in your English, humanities, social studies or other courses.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Death Toll Passes 600 From Raid in South Sudan
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — The death toll from a cattle raid in an eastern region of weeks-old South Sudan rose significantly on Monday with the United Nations saying more than 600 people had been killed in what was a retaliatory attack that has raised fears of ethnic instability on the deeply impoverished country.

headline: The Scramble for Access to Libya’s Oil Wealth Begins
text: HOUSTON — The fighting is not yet over in Tripoli, but the scramble to secure access to Libya’s oil wealth has already begun.

headline: Photo Replay: Aug. 22
text: The surf was up in South Africa and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. tried his hand at archery on a visit to Mongolia.

headline: Death of Jack Layton Weakens Canada’s Political Opposition
text: OTTAWA — Canada’s political opposition was significantly weakened after the death Monday of the country’s New Democratic Party leader, Jack Layton.

headline: Dollar Store Drive By
text: Here in the photo department, we love our serendipity. A few months ago, we called the photographer Tim Davis to ask him if he was willing to photograph dollar stores for Jack’s Hitt’s article, “The Dollar Store Economy.” Not only was Davis willing, he told us, but he was already involved in shooting dollar stores. In fact, he had just wrapped a wonderful video called “Dollar Store Drive By.”

headline: Malaria Gets the Foil-in-a-Microwave Treatment
text: What wacky idea has the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation put $1 million into now?

headline: An Ad Agency Hires…Samuel Johnson?
text: The New York office of the Euro RSCG Worldwide agency is continuing to add senior managers with a new chief strategy officer, who arrives from London with a distinctive social media sideline.

headline: Housekeeper’s Lawyer Asks to Remove District Attorney From Case
text: A lawyer for the woman who accused Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexual assault filed a motion on Monday formally requesting that the Manhattan district attorney be removed from the case.

headline: TimesCast | Where is Qaddafi?
text: As he still remains at large, John F. Burns reports on the various places Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi could currently be hiding.

headline: Romney’s Home Rebuilding Plan Draws Attention
text: Mitt Romney has never claimed to be a middle-class man of the people.

headline: Parallels Between Qaddafi and Hussein Raise Anxiety for Western Leaders
text: LONDON — Nearly 20 years ago, on the eve of the Persian Gulf war, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi protested when a visiting reporter compared him to Saddam Hussein, rejecting the suggestion that Mr. Hussein’s invasion of Kuwait had caused him to supplant Colonel Qaddafi as the West’s principal nemesis in the Arab world.

headline: A Neighborhood Bar Where They Bend Elbows Over and Over
text: Lionel Mendoza, 54, a truck driver from the Bronx, flaunted his bodybuilder’s physique on Saturday and said, “You could say this body was literally built by the streets of New York City.”

headline: Retirement Plans Don’t Have to Give You a Cash Option
text: The recent wild swings of the stock market had a lot of investors seeking the safety of cash, at least temporarily. One Bucks reader wrote to lament that the retirement plan offered by his former employer, a large not-for-profit institution, lacked what he deemed suitable options for putting investments in cash.

headline: Flamingos, Up Close and Personal
text: WASHINGTON — Stranded alone in Germany over a sullen white Christmas several years back, Nira Pereg, a video artist from Tel Aviv, decided to seek distraction at the Karlsruhe zoo.

headline: Even Preseason Football Lifts TV Ratings
text: They may have only one playoff victory since the 1997 season, but the Dallas Cowboys still bill themselves as America’s Team — and they have the ratings to match. The Cowboys’ preseason game against San Diego on NBC averaged 9.6 million total viewers over the course of prime time on Sunday, handily winning the night in overall viewers and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic among the broadcast networks. (The Chargers won, 20-7.) CBS came in second for the night with a new episode of “Big Brother” (8.8 million viewers).

headline: Dissent in Syria Emerges as Front Line of Arab Uprisings
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — On the night that Libyan rebels poured into the citadel of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, inaugurating Libya’s future, his counterpart in Syria offered assurances borrowed from the past: Syria would stay steadfast, plots hatched from abroad would fail and calls for his removal were meaningless because the people supported him.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Kyle Busch Secures Position in Sprint Cup Chase
text: At last Monday’s rescheduled Sprint Cup race at Watkins Glen, Kyle Busch jockeyed in the final laps with Marcos Ambrose before a caution flag came out, robbing Busch of momentum and enabling Ambrose’s final charge to victory. On Sunday at Michigan International Speedway, as the final laps were run, Busch could not be caught.

headline: On Food Safety, a Long List but Little Money
text: This summer there has been a drumbeat of food-related illnesses. Strawberries containing E. coli killed one person in Oregon and sickened at least nine others. Ground turkey contaminated with salmonella poisoned more than 100 people nationwide, with one dead, and prompted one of the largest meat recalls ever. Imported papayas tainted with salmonella sickened at least 99. Sprouts grown in Idaho were linked to salmonella illnesses in five states.

headline: E-Book Author Signs Print Deal With Simon & Schuster
text: John Locke, the first self-published author to sell one million e-books on Amazon.com, has made a deal with Simon & Schuster for the sales and distribution of his print books. Mr. Locke said he wanted to allow readers “traditional access” to his books, which include the Donovan Creed thrillers and several westerns. Simon & Schuster, which called it “a win-win for all concerned,” said it would begin to print and distribute Mr. Locke’s books in February, making them available in bookstores and through online retailers.

headline: Shared Meals, and Lives
text: Faced with the usual options for senior housing and elder care, some older adults are inventing their own grassroots versions — do-it-yourself senior living that’s friendlier, more autonomous and less expensive. Fellows in the News21 program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism are posting video reports on four of these: a shared housing arrangement in White Plains, a senior cohousing development in Virginia, an urban village in Chicago and an R.V. community in East Texas.

headline: Rebels’ Sudden Success Sends European Backers Scrambling
text: PARIS — The apparent collapse of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s security forces is at least a partial victory for President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, who pushed the Security Council and then the NATO alliance into vital military support for the rebels.

headline: Prosecutor Asks Court to Drop Charges Against Strauss-Kahn
text: Updated, 4:48 p.m. | Prosecutors in the office of Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, have filed papers requesting that all charges be dropped against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Peanut Problems
text: Q. When I observe student teachers in a school auto shop, there is almost always an engine retrofitted to run on biofuels like used peanut oil. Is it safe for students with a severe peanut allergy to be around it or work on it?

headline: News From Libya Pushes G.O.P. Candidates to Respond
text: During remarks in New Hampshire last month, Mitt Romney accused President Obama of “mission muddle” for expanding United States operations in Libya beyond enforcing a no-fly zone to a wider goal of preventing Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from attacking his own people.

headline: Reviewing John Brown Smokehouse and Mable’s Smokehouse
text: Reviewing John Brown Smokehouse and Mable’s Smokehouse

headline: Members of Merkel's Party Emphasize Opposition to Euro Bonds
text: FRANKFURT — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has faced harsh criticism for being too passive in the face of Europe’s debt crisis. But on Monday, members of her own party and the Bundesbank made it clear just how hard it would be for her to pursue any solution that asked German taxpayers to sacrifice for the sake of European unity.

headline: Saying Goodbye to a New College Student
text: Earlier today, Pam Allyn walked us through the literal and metaphorical inventory you take before sending a child off to college. Next up, Melissa T. Shultz, who just dropped her son off at the University of Southern California, is writing about that actual moment of goodbye.

headline: Ryan Says No to 2012 — Again
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin never said he was running for president. In fact, he said again and again that he had no plans to seek the Republican nomination. Yet even with his repeated denials, several conservative leaders had stepped up their efforts in the last week and urged him to reconsider.

headline: App Smart Extra: Another Round of Wine Apps
text: Thursday’s App Smart column covered the apps that wine lovers should use when they buy a new bottle or dust one off from their wine cellars. But mobile apps can benefit oenophiles in other ways too.

headline: A Protein That Bosses Plant Cells Around
text: Plant growth can seem like a busy construction site, with a lot of activity by components called microtubules, structures that capture, store and move around plant material to help grow and shape cells.

headline: Doctors Hone Message on Kidney Disease
text: A patient with early-stage kidney disease provided a recent wake-up call for Dr. Joseph Vassalotti, a leading kidney specialist. After explaining the diagnosis in great detail, the doctor asked his patient to repeat what he had heard in his own words.

headline: Financial Analysts Coming to a Bookstore Near You
text: Michael Mayo and Richard X. Bove are two of Wall Street’s most outspoken stock analysts.

headline: Farewell to a Master of Energy, Mobility and Vibes
text: Lee Schipper, who died last week after losing a battle with pancreatic cancer, was an unsung hero in efforts to underpin energy and transportation policies with data and to foster cleaner, smarter transportation systems in fast-growing cities around the world.

headline: Reviewing John Brown Smokehouse and Mable’s Smokehouse
text: New York’s barbecue options continue to expand, as the city’s restaurateurs cut yet more notches in their Barbecue Belt explorations. Two of the city’s latest ’cue joints — John Brown Smokehouse in Long Island City, Queens, and Williamsburg’s Mable’s Smokehouse — bring the smoked meats traditions of Kansas City, Mo., and Oklahoma City, respectively, to New York. Both of them turn out some delicious food.

headline: A $19 Million Coat for Blustery Days
text: Wanted: contractor for big paint job on Staten Island. Great views, competitive compensation ($19 million). Must be comfortable working on barges. Bring along 12,000 gallons of paint.

headline: Whetherly Tees Are the Tops
text: Having learned a thing or two about thoughtful thread count at Citizens of Humanity, the breakout designer Leila Nasseri put fabric right up there with fit when planning her knits line, Whetherly. “If you want to feel good without trying too hard, that means asking yourself, ‘How good does this feel against my skin?,’ too,” Nasseri says. Using lightweight jerseys and the softest supima cottons, then applying silicone and enzyme washes to enhance the way these fabrics take color, Nasseri lets the achieved fluidity and flexibility inform her tees’ shapes and silhouettes. To keep your Whetherly tee feeling every bit as soft as the day you bought it, Nasseri says: “Hand-wash in cold water, air-dry to prevent pilling, and fold, don’t hang.” Consider it done.

headline: John Brown Smokehouse and Mable’s Smokehouse
text: NOT long ago New York was bereft of true barbecue, save for one outpost called Pearson’s in Long Island City, Queens. Since its departure, notable practitioners of the craft were largely absent from the area, until the recent opening of JOHN BROWN SMOKEHOUSE, 25-08 37th Avenue (Crescent Avenue); (718) 361-0085; johnbrownsmokehouse.org.

headline: Some Travel Problems in Need of Solutions
text: DENVER

headline: Summer Dishes With Grains and Beans
text: Every summer, I take an inventory of the dry goods in my pantry and try to use up at least some of the grains and beans that I’ve accumulated over the year. This summer the shelves are particularly well stocked, so expect a few of these clean-out columns over the next couple of weeks.

headline: Israeli Self-Defense or Tai Chi? Depends on Who’s Watching
text: BUSINESS travel has always been a part of my career. I got the idea for my latest venture, ZocDoc, when I was coming back from Seattle after working on a project when I was with McKinsey & Company. It was a late-night flight and I had a horrible sinus infection. I heard this strange popping noise and then I felt like someone was sticking a spike into my ear.

headline: U.S. Says It Won’t Bid for Games in 2020
text: The United States Olympic Committee will not submit a bid to host the 2020 Summer Games, meaning the Olympics will not be held in the United States for at least another 11 years.

headline: New York Fringe Festival Report: ‘You Only Shoot the Ones You Love’
text: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat from now to the festival’s close on Aug. 28. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

headline: Goldman’s Shares Tumble as Blankfein Hires Top Lawyer
text: 8:57 p.m. | Updated

headline: Qaddafi at Large as Forces Fight to Control Compound
text: Clashes between Libyan rebels and government troops were reported Monday morning in Tripoli even as residents celebrated the prospective end of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s rule.

headline: Circumcise or Don’t? Quandary for Parents
text: Before giving birth to her first son three years ago, Allison Manley, now 40, gave a lot of thought to childbirth (she wanted a drug-free delivery), diapers (cloth), vaccines (spaced out) and breast-feeding (absolutely).

headline: A Hopeful Future for Libya

headline: Tracking the Movement of Ice Across Antarctica
text: A new map of Antarctica illustrates for the first time how ice moves across the continent. The map’s creators believe it may be a crucial tool in helping researchers understand how a warming climate is changing the continent.

headline: Helping Out the Family, Especially in Good Times
text: Acorn woodpeckers are industrious, cooperative birds that live in family groups. Each family has several “helper” woodpeckers that do not breed. These birds devote their time to gathering acorns and other food for the young.

headline: Bill Moyers Returns to Public Television, but Not PBS
text: Bill Moyers says he is returning to public television in January, but he won’t be found on the PBS lineup.His new hourlong weekly show, called “Moyers & Company,” will focus on one-on-one interviews with people not often heard on television, “thinkers who can help us understand the chaos of this time,” Mr. Moyers said in a telephone interview. “We’re going to be concerned with the state of democracy and the state of affairs, but we will leave the daily and weekly story to others and try to do the back story.”

headline: Case Study | The White Peach Sgroppino

If I find myself drinking one, it means, in general, that something has gone terribly wrong: either I’ve elected to be hosed down as a tourist in Venice, or somehow I’ve blundered my way to brunch at the Olive Garden.

headline: Social Context as Musical Theme
text: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — “I believe that ‘pure’ and ‘purity’ are dangerous words, best reserved only for food and water,” the musicologist Byron Adams said from the stage of the Sosnoff Theater here on Friday night. Mr. Adams, a faculty member at the University of California, Riverside, and a regular at the Bard Music Festival, was delivering a lecture before a chamber music concert titled “Nordic Purity, Aryan Fantasies and Music.”

headline: Fishing Gear Is Altered to Ease Collateral Costs to Marine Life
text: BOSTON — In the world of environmental regulation, where the hope is to write rules that both industry and science can live with, few areas are as contentious as fishing. Especially on the East Coast, fishermen attack scientists as mired in bottomless ignorance about how fish are actually caught. Scientists sometimes describe fishermen as racing to catch the last fish, regardless of the harm to vanishing species.

headline: To Circumcise or Not to Circumcise?

headline: A Validation for Bisexual Men
text: A group of researchers at Northwestern University is reporting that men who identify themselves as bisexual are indeed sexually aroused by both women and men. The new report is notable, in part, because the same research group had earlier challenged the very existence of male bisexuality, reporting in 2005 that many men who said they were bisexual had arousal patterns more typical of homosexual men.

headline: Lobsters Find Utopia Where Biologists See Trouble

headline: A Long Wait Gets Longer
text: As international travel rebounds, the time it takes to get through customs is creeping up at some of America’s busiest airports — especially for passengers who are last off the plane.

headline: Judge Again Blocks Work on Landmark New York Office Tower
text: Work on a landmark office tower on Fifth Avenue will remain halted under a judge’s order filed in a lawsuit challenging renovations to the structure, the former Manufacturers Trust Company building, at 510 Fifth Avenue, at 43rd Street. New York City had filed a motion to dismiss a lawsuit by preservationists who charged that the owner of the building, Vornado Realty Trust, disregarded restrictions intended to protect the interior. But Justice Lucy A. Billings of State Supreme Court in Manhattan denied that motion last week and converted the temporary restraining order she issued last month into a preliminary injunction. It bans Vornado from doing additional work on the site until she considers the merits of the case.

headline: Mayor Praises Growth in Film and TV Jobs
text: Once upon a time in New York, the Brooklyn Navy Yard bustled with ships, and an airport called Idlewild was home to a terminal for Pan American World Airways, or Pan Am.

headline: A Mother’s Long Love Affair With Colonialism
text: Alexandra Fuller recalls in her electrifying new memoir that her mother — “Nicola Fuller of Central Africa, as she has on occasion preferred to introduce herself” — had always wanted a writer in the family, “not only because she loves books and has therefore always wanted to appear in them (the way she likes large, expensive hats, and likes to appear in them) but also because she has always wanted to live a fabulously romantic life, for which she needed a reasonably pliable witness as scribe.” When her self-dramatizing mother assessed her life, Ms. Fuller goes on, she “matched it up against the kind of biography she hoped to inspire, something along the lines of ‘West With the Night,’ ‘The Flame Trees of Thika’ or ‘Out of Africa.’ On the whole, she was satisfied.”

headline: Ferrari Testa Rossa Sells for Record $16.4 Million at Pebble Beach
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — An auction record fell here on Saturday, as had been widely expected, with the sale of a 1957 Ferrari Testa Rossa racecar by Gooding & Company at auction. The winning bid was $14.9 million, or about $16.4 million including the buyer’s premium.

headline: For Obama, a Moment to Savor, if Briefly
text: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass. — President Obama was a reluctant warrior in Libya, drawn into the rebel uprising over the warnings of his Pentagon chief and his own qualms about getting the United States entangled in yet another war in the Muslim world.

headline: It’s Not Every Cabinet Minister Who Can Also Take to the Stage
text: Politicians who promise transparency could learn something from the singer Susana Baca, who is now the Peruvian minister of culture. She is completing an extensive tour planned before her appointment in July. At City Winery on Sunday night, her music was as open as can be: a tidy, lightly propulsive mesh of largely acoustic instruments (the upright bass was electric) that never obscured her gentle but drily resolute voice. And in that show of clarity was a graceful bundle of agendas: memory and modernization, mourning and celebration. Dressed in white, Ms. Baca beamed through her set, sometimes with eyes closed as if she were entranced; now and then she let the rhythms carry her into dance steps.

headline: Medical Thriller, With a Life in the Balance
text: I was in a neurologist’s office to discuss the results of my brain scan. For the past month and a half, I’d had headaches that felt as if my skull was underwater, punctuated by frequent electric jolts through the right side of my brain. Two CT scans and an M.R.I. had revealed nothing. All the drug treatments tried by my doctor had failed to change me back into myself.

headline: A Surge of Sleepiness in China Appears to Have Been Caused by Flu
text: Cases of narcolepsy — a condition that causes sufferers to fall asleep without warning — tripled in China after the 2009 swine flu pandemic, according to a study released Monday. But the surge appeared to be an annual late spring event caused by the flu itself, not by China’s swine flu vaccination campaign.

headline: Qaddafi Leaves Little Behind to Guide Libya in His Absence
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s stranglehold on Libya appears to have ended after 42 years, even if his whereabouts remain elusive. But through countless erratic decrees and iron-handed purges, he has carved deep scars into every facet of Libyan life. The mystery and speculation swirling about him marked a fitting close to a quixotic reign.

headline: Tea Party Favorite Won’t Challenge Senate Republican
text: Representative Jason Chaffetz, Republican of Utah, announced Monday that he would not run for the Senate, removing a potentially formidable rival to Senator Orrin Hatch as he seeks a seventh term. Mr. Chaffetz, a Tea Party favorite, had signaled that he was ready to take on Mr. Hatch in the party’s nominating process, and he was given a reasonable chance of success after Utah Republicans decided in 2010 to oust Robert F. Bennett, an 18-year veteran of the Senate, in favor of a newcomer, Mike Lee. But Mr. Chaffetz said he would instead seek re-election to the House to focus on a push for fiscal discipline. “I can spend the next 15 months doing my job, or I can spend the next 15 months campaigning to do Senator Hatch’s,” he said in a statement. “Despite being tempted to compete for the privilege of serving in the U.S. Senate — and being convinced I could win — I won’t allow a fight for that seat to distract me from what I was sent to Washington to do.”

headline: U.S. Seeking Ways to Finance New Libyan Leaders

Muammar el-Qaddafi and his supporters no longer have access to the country’s financial system.

headline: Raiders’ Choice of Pryor Is Another Bet on Speed

headline: Rethinking Libya and Oil Prices
text: The endgame in Libya could herald a slump in oil prices. As with the rebel advance into Tripoli, Libyan supplies to the global market could come sooner than expected. Brent crude prices slipped by as much as $3 to almost $106 a barrel at one point on Monday, before rebounding later in the day. A resolution in Libya, coupled with concerns over global growth, means tight markets could soon look oversupplied.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Jerry Leiber, Prolific Writer of 1950s Hits, Dies at 78

headline: Hip Implant Complaints Surge, Even as the Dangers Are Studied
text: The federal government has received a surge in complaints in recent months about failed hip replacements, suggesting that serious problems persist with some types of artificial hips even as researchers scramble to evaluate the health dangers.

headline: Looking for Gas in All the Wrong Places
text: It was a big week in Andes, N.Y. Last Thursday, the New York Post devoted a full page to the small Catskill village, describing in some detail the Andes Hotel, the surrounding “rolling corn and hay fields,” the affordable housing, the Hunting Tavern Museum, the country store, the coffee shop, the tea shop, the farmer’s market, the art galleries and antique stores, the occasional celebrity resident, the extraordinary natural beauty — everything that led the Post, in an earlier article about great day-trip destinations, to dub Andes Woodstock-as-it-used-to-be.

headline: The Wild Rose of Washington
text: Washington, Aug. 23, 1861 Just before 11 a.m., Rose O’Neal Greenhow, a dark-haired, dark-eyed Washington widow in her 40s, walked toward her house on 16th Street. Greenhow circulated among the capital’s elite social circles, and her home stood within sight of the White House. Despite the sweltering heat, she stopped to talk with a neighbor. A Union guard, she learned, had been placed in front of Greenhow’s house earlier that morning.

headline: Cut Medicare, Help Patients
text: MEDICARE is going to be cut. That is inevitable. There is no way to solve the nation’s long-term debt problem without reducing the growth rate of federal health care spending. The only question is whether the cuts will be smart ones.

headline: How Democrats Hurt Jobs
text: The airplane’s aft section arrived early Monday morning. That’s what they’d been waiting for at the final assembly plant in North Charleston, S.C. They already had the wings, the nose, the tail — all the other major sections of Boeing’s new 787 Dreamliner. With the arrival of the aft, the 5,000 nonunion workers in the plant can finally begin to assemble their first aircraft — a plane three years behind schedule and critical to Boeing’s future.

headline: Qaddafi’s Final Hours
text: For more than 40 years, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has dominated and terrorized Libya — his image plastered on what seemed like every wall and his goons posted on every corner. Late Monday, with rebel fighters in substantial control of Tripoli, he was nowhere to be found, and his regime seemed to be collapsing.

headline: Tuesday: It’s a Blessing
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Michael Farabaugh just made his New York Times debut in April (Across Lite, Solution, blog), but he is back today with a list theme that shows us four different ways to think of “Bolts”.

headline: He’ll Take You Anywhere You Want to Go
text: Finding your seat at the Atlantic Theater Company’s tiny Stage 2 isn’t easy. (Hint: the numbers are on the bottoms of the seats.) So when one man is still standing, hovering over the first row, just before the lights go down for the beginning of Simon Stephens’s “Bluebird,” which opened on Monday night, you’re inclined to make allowances.

headline: Lane Venardos, Ex-CBS News Vice President, Dies at 67
text: Lane Venardos, the executive producer of the “CBS Evening News” in the 1980s and later the network’s vice president for hard news, overseeing its coverage of the protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989 and the Persian Gulf war a year later, died on Friday at his home in Maui, Hawaii. He was 67.

headline: Egypt Disavows Threat to Recall Envoy to Israel
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s foreign minister, Mohammed Amr, said Monday that the plan to recall the nation’s ambassador to Israel “was never on the table,” confirming the government’s decision to disavow a threat that generated widespread popular support at home but brought the government under intense diplomatic pressure to back off.

headline: A City Game
text: Tennis players fill public courts across New York City’s five boroughs.

headline: Courts, Characters and a Love of a Game
text: The United States Open starts on Monday, beginning two weeks of elite tennis, expensive eating and celebrity sightings. The rest of the year, though, another kind of tennis tournament unspools in New York’s public parks — a less structured, less moneyed daily draw that pulls people of all ages and skills onto all or some of the 595 public courts in the five boroughs. Earl Wilson has hit on many of those courts for more than 35 years, refining his ground strokes, running down drop shots and taking his lumps, all the while cataloging his finest moments and the most dubious of court characters. What appears below is some reminiscing, a mix of romance and regret.

headline: A Council Speaker Who Tightens the Purse Strings on Dissent

headline: It’s a Flawed Settlement
text: The Obama administration has turned up the heat on Eric Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general, to go along with a proposed settlement with the nation’s largest banks over dubious foreclosure practices. Mr. Schneiderman should stand his ground in not supporting the deal. The administration says that a settlement would quickly deliver much needed relief to hard-pressed borrowers, but it’s doubtful it would provide redress on a par with the banks’ wrongdoing or borrowers’ needs.

headline: W. B. Kannel, Who Led Historic Heart Study, Dies at 87

headline: Conservation, Beyond Boundaries
text: Over the past 25 years, the number of conservation areas set aside for the nonhuman species has grown considerably. Globally, there are now more than 100,000 protected areas, including national parks, biological reserves and marine sanctuaries. All told, they protect slightly less than 13 percent of the land on earth and slightly more than a half-percent of the oceans, though only a minute fraction are “no-take” zones that bar fishing. But can these protected areas do enough to protect biological diversity?

headline: Nora Bredes, Who Fought Long Island Nuclear Plant, Dies at 60

headline: Fantasy Focus: Mostly Lesser Known Keeper Targets
text: Over time, I’ve come to the realization that I can’t win each and every league I’m a part of, so by this point in the year, I’m focusing on 2012 in several cases. A couple of my leagues have a rule that unless a minor league prospect is drafted and held on a roster, he cannot be picked up on the waiver wire until he’s promoted to the big leagues. In many keeper leagues, there is a provision for allowing a certain number of minor leaguers to be drafted. Therefore, top prospects like Mike Trout, Julio Teheran and Eric Hosmer didn’t come up on waivers because they were already on rosters in such leagues.

headline: Daphne Rubin-Vega and Wood Harris Set for ‘Streetcar’ Revival on Broadway
text: They’ve played some of the toughest characters that New York and Baltimore had to offer, and now Daphne Rubin-Vega and Wood Harris are headed into a famously rugged depiction of New Orleans in a 2012 Broadway production of “A Streetcar Named Desire,” its producers said on Tuesday. Ms. Rubin-Vega, who originated the role of Mimi in the New York Theater Workshop and Broadway incarnations of “Rent,” will play Stella, the timid wife of Stanley and sister of Blanche DuBois. Mr. Harris, who played the drug kingpin Avon Barksdale on the HBO drama “The Wire,” will play Mitch, Stanley’s muscle-building pal who develops an attraction to Blanche. Blair Underwood and Nicole Ari Parker were previously announced to play Stanley and Blanche in this latest “Streetcar” revival, the first time that the Tennessee Williams play has been presented on Broadway since 2005. It will be directed by Emily Mann, the artistic director of the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., and presented in the spring at a theater to be determined. It is produced by Stephen Byrd and Alia M. Jones of Front Row Productions, who produced the 2008 Broadway revival of “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” that featured an African-American cast.

headline: Fewer Banks in the U.S. Considered to Be at Risk

headline: Leading Off: Raiders Strike Again
text: There is something oddly satisfying about having the Raiders in the N.F.L., setting aside for the moment their fans’ part in the violence at Candlestick Park last weekend, because staying satisfied involves not attending any actual Raiders games. But they play such a great role in poking a hole in the N.F.L.’s carefully cultivated image of order and precision, the facade of being run by civic-minded, forthright businessmen. The Raiders are like the crazy aunt the otherwise mostly respectable N.F.L. can’t uninvite to Thanksgiving dinner.

headline: Asked & Answered | Vera Farmiga
text: For Vera Farmiga, a Ukrainian-American actress whose reputably selective film career includes “Down to the Bone,” “The Departed” and 2009’s “Up in the Air,” which garnered her an Academy Award nomination, the movies are a family affair. In her directorial debut, “Higher Ground,” based on the novel by Carolyn S. Briggs and opening on Aug. 26, Farmiga handles a solid cast of actors, which includes her younger sister Taissa Farmiga and John Hawkes (“American Gangster” and the forthcoming drama “Martha Marcy May Marlene”), as she recounts the story of a woman named Corinne Walker — a mother and wife and child of God — who struggles with doubt and disbelief as she searches for her identity, her “instrument.” “I wanted to make sure that what pervaded the film was the character of music and its capacity to unite people,” says Farmiga of her hymn-heavy picture, produced by Farmiga and her rocker husband, Renn Hawkey, of the band Deadsy. Just days before the film’s opening, Farmiga spoke to The Moment about family, how she came upon “Higher Ground” and what separates the girls from the women.

headline: Lighting the Way
text: The Blind Barber in the East Village loves a good surprise. On the surface it operates as a classic barbershop, piles of shorn hair on the floor and all, but it also houses a secret speakeasy in the back room offering banquette seating, live D.J.’s and top-shelf whiskey. Now, not even their canisters of barbicide can be trusted. Teaming up with Joya, the New York company that makes all-natural fragrances for Rodarte and Opening Ceremony, the Bind Barber has crafted a signature soy wax candle that’s packaged to look just like the antiseptic used to keep combs and scissors minty fresh. Notes of lavender, smoke and leather echo the scents of an old-fashioned cut and shave. Now that’s sharp.

headline: Net-a-Porter’s Fashion at the Click of a Mouse
text: MY first encounter with luxury fashion came at age 15, when my dapper father took me past the fragrance counters of Saks Fifth Avenue, up the mirrored escalators to whichever floor was then housing the gilded designer salons (instead of the jammed racks of so-called “better dresses,” with all that ominously implies). Hitherto I had shopped at the humbler, now-defunct Gimbels on Lexington Avenue, supplementing my meager haul with the occasional vial of mascara shoplifted from the even more cut-rate Woolworth down the street. But here, in the hushed confines of Calvin Klein, we happened upon a camel-hair cape whose price tag, to my youthful astonishment, displayed four figures.

headline: Egypt Names Antiquities Chief to Replace Hawass
text: A month after Egypt’s controversial antiquities chief, Zahi Hawass, was ousted in a cabinet reshuffle, Egypt’s prime minister, Essam Sharaf, has appointed a successor. Mohamed Abdel Fattah, the head of the antiquities sector at the Supreme Council of Antiquities, will become the council’s secretary general, the position Mr. Hawass held before former President Hosni Mubarak elevated the council to a ministry. Mr. Sharaf had previously indicated that he planned to return the council to its former status.

headline: Ninja Warriors Improve NBC’s Ratings
text: With a title like “American Ninja Warrior,” one can’t help but raise an intrigued eyebrow, and that curiosity turned into solid ratings for NBC on Monday when the season finale of the obstacle course program reached nearly four million total viewers. Its audience actually grew in the second hour, averaging 4.3 million viewers and winning the 10 p.m. time slot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. It was the highest-rated program in that advertiser-coveted category for NBC in that time slot since the “Macy’s Fourth of July Fireworks Spectacular.”

headline: Fears About Bid Rock Temple-Inland’s Shares

headline: Allies of Strauss-Kahn Express Relief, but His Role in France Remains Unclear
text: PARIS — Prominent members of France’s Socialist Party expressed relief that Dominique Strauss-Kahn would soon be a free man after he was cleared Tuesday of charges of attempted rape in New York. But his political career is clearly damaged by the months of investigation and notoriety, and no one publicly urged him to run for the presidency, even though a party primary is only seven weeks away.

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company Goes Back to Work
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the ninth in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from a week off in New York City.

headline: Travel Groups Withdraw From Charity Give Back Group
text: Several major travel companies, including Westin Hotels and Resorts, Expedia.com and Hotels.com, have withdrawn their advertisements from the Charity Give Back Group, formerly the Christian Values Network, a Web site that allows consumers to give a percentage of each purchase they make from retailers advertising on the site to one of its participating charitable organizations.

headline: The MAC Is Back, but Does It Kill a Deal?

A deal-breaking move like this makes it feel like we are back in the financial crisis, when these attempts were all too common.

headline: Claes Oldenburg’s Paintbrush Erected in Philadelphia
text: “Paint Torch,” a 51-foot-long sculpture of a paintbrush by the artist Claes Oldenburg, was installed on Saturday in Lenfest Plaza at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia. Mr. Oldenburg, 82, was present for most of the installation process, which took all day and ended with the careful positioning of a giant “paint glob” near the foot of the sculpture.

headline: Fear, Empathy and Parenthood
text: A 7-year-old boy drowned on a beach in Nantucket, Mass., on Monday, The Cape Cod Times reported on Tuesday. He could have been any of our children. He could certainly have been Amber Hinds’s  little one, which she realized Monday night as she tucked her 2-year-old daughter, Nora, into bed on the same island, having just learned the reason for the sirens she had heard that afternoon.

headline: At 90, Fashion’s Latest Pop Star
text: HER spectacles, as round as soup tureens, lend Iris Apfel a startled look. If she seems surprised, she has good reason. Mrs. Apfel, the subject of a string of museum exhibitions, a coffee table book and even a fashion advertising campaign, has long been a magnet to aficionados, those devotees of fashion who dote on her style — a more-is-more mix of haute couture and hippie trimmings that appears at a glance to have been blended in a Cuisinart.

headline: Taking Stock of Campus Sustainability
text: Colleges and universities across the country have quickly taken to measuring their environmental footprint: energy efficiency, consumption levels, renewable energy targets, number of green buildings, recycling rates, water use and even the prevalence of sustainability curriculums. But in this rush to go green, two of the three sustainability pillars have remained largely in shadow.

headline: East Coast Quake Interrupts Regulators’ Day

headline: The Prodigy Burned Out. Why Not Blame Mom?
text: Few artists willingly give up their art. Remember Nureyev’s continuing to dance despite a damaged body that could no longer take him to the heights? Young artists who make a splash are even less likely to change course, typically seeking to climb higher, the faster the better.

Many of us take for granted the goods they transport, and perhaps we think about how those goods reached us only when we fly over a major port city and catch sight of maritime giants docked under the cranes in the harbor.

headline: In a Rite of Late Summer, Naumburg Concerts Finish
text: The Naumburg Orchestral Concerts had planned to present free performances by three ensembles in its four-concert series this summer, but only one — the Knights, an enterprising young chamber orchestra — made it through its programs as planned. That ensemble opened the organization’s 106th season in June, with a lineup that included a commissioned work by Lisa Bielawa and the Beethoven Fifth Symphony. And the orchestra closed this summer’s festivities on Monday evening in Central Park with a program split between works of Schubert and Liszt.

headline: The Hazards of Success in American Banking

So the crisis in America’s financial system is officially coming to an end.

headline: Some Builders Are Ready for the Wave of Seniors
text: EAST NORTHPORT, N.Y. — When the housing market collapsed in 2008, construction of retirement and assisted-living housing ground to a halt, just as it did in most commercial real estate sectors, as access to capital evaporated. But a few companies kept their development teams intact in the recession, and are now building new facilities and expanding their operations. And as lending loosens, they say, they are poised to benefit from the housing needs of America’s aging population.

headline: Gluten-Free Flour From the French Laundry
text: It started about a year ago, when customers at the French Laundry in Yountville, Calif., began requesting gluten-free versions of some of Thomas Keller’s specialties, like the flaky cornets filled with salmon tartare, or the lush little gougères. Lena Kwak, the restaurant’s culinary researcher, developed a gluten-free flour. Now she and Mr. Keller are partners in a company called Cup4Cup, so-named because its flour, C4C, can replace the regular all-purpose variety for cakes and pastries. It is a blend of flours from white and brown rice, tapioca and potatoes, with potato starch, cornstarch and milk powder.

headline: Pakistan’s Bitter, Little-Known Ethnic Rebellion
text: GENEVA — A slim figure in a dark suit, Brahumdagh Bugti, 30, could pass for a banker in the streets of this sedate Swiss city. But in truth he is a resistance leader in exile, a player in an increasingly ugly independence war within Pakistan.

headline: The Faded Voice of Sports Calls Past
text: There he sits, buckled into his wheelchair, near the table with the 17 bottles of pills. Old age often sketches people in caricature, and Dom Valentino is 82 now, his face a bit scrunched up after two strokes. His balance is wobbly, his memory porous. A pacemaker adjusts the tom-tom of his heart.

headline: Airstrikes More Difficult as War Moves to Tripoli
text: WASHINGTON — The NATO air campaign that was instrumental in helping the rebels advance into Tripoli is hamstrung in many ways now that the fighting has turned into complex house-to-house urban warfare, American military and allied officials said Tuesday.

headline: Obama, Tiger, Golf and Politics
text: Despite the carping by critics, I’m glad the president went on vacation because one of the most useful things he could do right now is play golf — a lot of golf — but not that friendly foursome thing with his aides that he usually does. No, real golf: Match play, head to head, with real money on the line. Match-play golf is a great teacher. As any good golfer will tell you, the first rule of match play is this: Never play not to lose. Do not wait and hope for your opponent to make a mistake. Always play the course, always play to win and always assume your opponent will do well — will make that long putt — so you have to do better.

headline: Dutrow Filly Is Raced 4 Times in 12 Days, Prompting Concern
text: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The story of Richard Dutrow Jr., already fighting to keep his trainer’s license in New York and Kentucky, took another controversial twist after a filly he trained, Indian Tale, was put on the steward’s list after failing to finish a race on Aug. 18, her fourth in 12 days.

What seems clear is that Mr. Vance was right to notify Mr. Strauss-Kahn’s lawyers and the court in July about troubling inconsistencies in the account of the accuser, Nafissatou Diallo, and to drop the charges this week.

headline: Libyans Rejoice in a Castle Filled With Guns and the Trappings of Power
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Its impenetrable walls breached at last, the people stripped the colonel’s home of its treasures. They sauntered on the grassy grounds as if it were a public park, and swung on his statue of a fist crushing a plane, a symbol of defiance, as if it were a jungle gym.

headline: License Access in New Mexico Is Heated Issue

headline: A’s Await Film, but Without the Ending They Wanted

headline: Cleaner Harbor Has a Downside: Pests That Plague Park Construction

text: Brown water rippled across a sludgy puddle, about 20 yards wide, along a walkway in Prospect Park. Hundreds of insects dotted the surface.

headline: Many in India See Danger in Hunger Striker’s Anticorruption Plan
text: NEW DELHI — Aruna Roy’s two cellphones were ringing before breakfast on Tuesday as she braced for another day in the media storm of the Anna Hazare anticorruption movement. Ms. Roy, a pillar of India’s civil society who has fought for greater government accountability, has been appearing on television to talk about Mr. Hazare’s populist campaign, which includes his current hunger strike. She might seem a natural ally.

headline: F.B.I. Focusing on Security Over Ordinary Crime

headline: They’re in the Back Room
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York has taken a strong stand against gerrymandering. He put forward a good bill that would create an independent commission to draw political districts and promised to veto any new maps that are “partisan.” Albany’s pols are not giving up.

headline: Oil Reserves Sidestep U.S. Vessels
text: WASHINGTON — In its hurry to transport millions of barrels of oil from federal stockpiles to stabilize world oil prices earlier this summer, the Obama administration has repeatedly bypassed federal law by allowing nearly all the oil to move on foreign-owned vessels, drawing protests from domestic maritime operators.

headline: California: 45 Are Arrested in Transit Protests
text: Police officers in San Francisco arrested 45 people Monday evening during a protest at commuter train stations organized largely online by a group of computer hackers called Anonymous. The demonstration was the latest since transit officers shot a 45-year-old man to death on July 3. Demonstrations involving more than 100 protesters began around 5 p.m., closing two stations during peak commuter hours and snarling traffic downtown for more than three hours. During an Aug. 11 protest, transit officials shut off cellphone service in transit stations in an effort to thwart protesters. The move angered online activists, who retaliated by hacking the Bay Area Transit Authority’s Web site and releasing the personal information of users.

headline: The Fierce Intimacy of Tennis Rivalries
text: Rafael Nadal was working his way into a point about tennis rivalries. It was near the end of the third day of the Wimbledon Championships in late June, and Nadal, an hour or so earlier, efficiently dispensed with his second-round opponent, the hard-hitting but chronically inconsistent American Ryan Sweeting, in straight sets. Now, freshly showered, his longish hair going its own way, his biceps stretching the sleeves of his tight-fitting polo shirt, Nadal, at that moment the No. 1 men’s tennis player in the world, was seated behind a table in a small auditorium at Wimbledon’s press center, weighing what to say. He looked down, toyed a bit with the bottle of water in front of him, brought his hands together, slowly lifted his head and tilted it, then began a smile but shut it down as he looked at me.

headline: Man Randomly Stabs Four, One Fatally, Then Slashes Himself, the Police Say
text: A naked man with a knife unleashed a torrent of violence inside the building where he lives in Upper Manhattan on Tuesday, randomly stabbing four residents, one fatally, before running outside and slashing himself, the police said.

headline: Former Manhattan Sex Crimes Chief to Join Private Security Firm
text: A career prosecutor who until recently worked as the chief of the sex crimes unit in the Manhattan district attorney’s office is leaving to join a security and investigations company.

headline: An American Songbook
text: The death of Jerry Leiber, the lyricist who brought us “Stand by Me,” “Yakety Yak” and other early rock ’n’ roll classics, gives us a moment to pause and give thanks for sugar cane. Sugar cane led to a great wave of Chinese immigration to Cuba, which, through a roundabout process of musical pollination, put an idea into the heads of Mr. Leiber and his collaborator, Mike Stoller, when they were still teenagers breaking into the business in Los Angeles.

headline: Three Quickly Discontinued Technology Products

headline: Markets Will Look for Hints in Bernanke’s Words

headline: Stocks Gain for Third Day on Late Surge

headline: Moody’s Cuts Japan’s Rating One Notch, Citing Its Giant Debt
text: TOKYO — Moody’s, the credit ratings agency, lowered Japan’s credit rating by one notch on Wednesday, warning that frequent changes in administration, weak prospects for economic growth and its recent natural and nuclear disasters made it difficult for the government to pare down its huge debt.

headline: Shay Given’s Quiet Consistency

headline: Yemen: Prime Minister Returns From Saudi Arabia
text: Prime Minister Ali Mujawar returned to Yemen on Tuesday after weeks of recuperating in Saudi Arabia from injuries sustained in a deadly attack on the presidential compound in Sana in early June, said a spokesman for Yemen’s government, Mohammed Albasha. Mr. Mujawar is the first high-ranking official to return from being treated in Saudi Arabia after the attack, which also wounded President Ali Abdullah Saleh and a handful of other high-ranking officials.

headline: Rodriguez Sits Out, and Yankees Come Up Short
text: Two days after Alex Rodriguez played his first game in six weeks, he was out of the Yankees’ lineup again Tuesday, scratched two hours before they opened a grinding stretch that includes 17 games in 16 days. His surgically repaired right knee was not the problem.

headline: Twitter Founders Back a New Start-Up

headline: Time Warner to Subsidize Subscribers’ TV Device
