headline: Hertz to Begin Renting Electric Cars in China
text: HONG KONG — In the West, electric cars appeal to a do-it-yourself environmentalist personality, one who believes in taking individual actions to help address the collective problems of air pollution and global warming.

headline: New Camry, Spruced Up but Still Free of Flash
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Toyota unveiled a revamped, lower-priced Camry on Tuesday that it hopes will retain its nearly decade-long dominance as the best-selling car in the United States and help the company regain some of the respect and momentum that has evaporated in recent years.

headline: Salvadoran Tied to Killings Faces Immigration Charge
text: A former Salvadoran military officer who has been charged in Spain with crimes against humanity for killings in El Salvador during that country’s civil war appeared in United States District Court in Boston on Tuesday after he was arrested and accused of immigration violations. The former officer, Inocente Orlando Montano, who has been living in Everett, Mass., is one of 20 people indicted in Spain for the 1989 slayings of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. Nine other men named in the Spanish indictment turned themselves in this month in El Salvador and are expected to fight extradition to Spain. Mr. Montano’s arrest clears the way for Spain to seek his extradition.

headline: The Challenge of Restoring Oil Production
text: Crude oil production in Iraq and Libya has not reached earlier highs.

headline: Lawyers Defending Suspect in Boy’s Death Are Scolded
text: The judge in the case of Levi Aron, the Brooklyn man accused of murdering an 8-year-old Borough Park boy in July, upbraided Mr. Aron’s lawyers on Tuesday for their handling of his defense and questioned whether they were experienced enough to handle such a complex case.

headline: After Stillbirth, Courts Try to Put a Price on a Mother’s Anguish
text: Eight months pregnant, suffering from abdominal pain, the woman had been sent home after three visits to Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn with a prescription for a painkiller. She lost her baby during labor at home when the head got stuck in the birth canal. A court upheld a $1 million malpractice verdict this year, ending lengthy appeals by the hospital.

headline: John Howard Davies, TV Comedy Producer, Dies at 72
text: John Howard Davies, who as a sweet-faced, trembling-lipped child actor played the title role in the 1948 David Lean film “Oliver Twist” and who went on to become a producer and director of some of British television’s most popular comedies, including “Fawlty Towers,” died on Monday at his home in Blewbury in southern England. He was 72.

headline: Ross Barbour, a Founding ‘Freshman,’ Dies at 82
text: In 1947, Ross Barbour and three other freshmen decided to take a year’s break from college to take their barbershop quartet on the road. They soon morphed into the Four Freshmen, a close-harmony, jazz-inflected vocal group that is still going strong — albeit with performers who were not even born at the inception.

headline: Samuel Menashe, New York Poet of Short Verse, Dies at 85
text: Samuel Menashe, a Greenwich Village poet whose jewel-like, gnomic short verse won him an ardent following in Britain and belated recognition in the United States when the Poetry Foundation gave him its first Neglected Masters Award in 2004, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Nonalcoholic Beer Aids Marathon Recovery
text: A new study reports that beer is an excellent recovery beverage for marathon runners. But you may not want to start a raucous celebration just yet. The beer was effective only if it was nonalcoholic.

headline: Jerome Shestack, Diplomat and Bar Association Leader, Dies at 88

headline: Looking Beyond the Literal

She graduated from Toronto’s Ryerson University in the spring. Ms. Hayeri is working on two long-term projects in Iran. Her conversation with Kerri MacDonald has been edited.

text: SEOUL, South Korea — Low turnout in South Korea’s first vote on a social policy on Wednesday left in place a program in Seoul providing free lunches for 810,000 elementary and middle school students, a victory for the liberal opposition, which had urged a boycott.

headline: Years Later, and Chumley’s Is Still Not Back on Its Feet
text: It was the storied bar whose name everybody knew, even though it had no sign: Chumley’s, in Greenwich Village. A speakeasy during Prohibition and a destination for tourists seeking a snapshot or New Yorkers seeking a nightcap, Chumley’s has been closed since a wall collapsed in April 2007.

headline: A Strategy for Learning From Mistakes
text: Eight years ago, we made a mistake that we’ve only recently stopped paying for. As mistakes go, this one was hardly disastrous, and in some ways it even helped me clarify my understanding of why mistakes happen and what we can do to avoid them. I have found that most mistakes fall into one of three categories: planning, procedures, or performance. It’s important to understand what kind of mistake has been made before you try to deal with it.

headline: Cruising for (Tennis) Partners
text: Maybe it’s because I’m a Londoner living in an overcrowded city on a tiny island where courts are in short supply, but I love seeing tennis courts: from a plane as it descends (there never seem to be any on the way up) or from speeding trains and cars. This is a purely aesthetic — i.e., pointless — pleasure, but if I am out walking or cycling, this fondness for court-spotting has obvious practical advantages. Over time, in London, I have discovered every public court within a playable distance of home.

headline: Ristretto | Los Angeles Coffee Crawl
text: The intrastate rivalry between Los Angeles and San Francisco doesn’t make much sense if you live outside of California. Or really, if you don’t live in the Bay Area. I grew up in one city and went to college a BART ride away from the other, so I feel qualified to paint a picture of the two with broad strokes: Los Angeles is crazy about San Francisco, and San Francisco wishes Los Angeles would go away.

headline: What Should We Have Known About Fiscal Stimulus?
text: I’ve noticed a number of people arguing that the original Obama stimulus was underpowered because at the time nobody realized how deep a hole the economy was in. And it’s true that revised GDP numbers have shown that the 2007-2009 recession was even deeper than we thought. But the basic line of thought here is wrong: there was plenty of information in January 2009 indicating that the economy needed a lot more help than it was about to get.

headline: Unflappable, but a Little Shaken
text: You could tell almost right away that the earthquake that rattled New York on Tuesday was not really a big deal. If it had seriously disrupted the rhythms of the city, don’t you think the mayor would have urged people to do something like take in a Broadway show?That, you surely recall, was his tin-eared recommendation in December when much of the city was brought to a standstill by the Great Blizzard of 2010 and many New Yorkers couldn’t dig their way out of their own streets, let alone make it to the theater. So the absence of any such suggestion this time was reassuring, a clear signal that we would be all right.

headline: Turning It On and Off for Politics
text: On Monday, a researcher named Lisa Diamond, who works on issues of sexuality and sexual identity, claimed that her work is being “misconstrued and distorted” by John Boehner’s legal team. Boehner’s lawyer cited Diamond’s research in a lawsuit defending the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act. (A woman named Edie Windsor has sued, claiming the law is unconstitutional.) The Boehner brief makes the case for the Defense of Marriage Act in part by quoting a study by Diamond that said, “50 percent [of respondents] had changed their identity label more than once since first relinquishing their heterosexual identity.”

headline: When Teenagers Fly Alone
text: IT was with a sense of relief that I set out to book my two teenage children’s airfares to camp last month. With Florence now 15, I knew I would no longer have to pay the $200 round-trip fee required by airlines like Delta and US Airways for children younger than 15 traveling without an adult. I also assumed that because Florence would be flying with Charles, her 14-year-old brother, from Detroit to Boston, he, too, would be exempt from the fee since she would be accompanying him.

headline: Summitt’s New Opponent
text: Just after an earthquake rolled through the world of sports on Tuesday, an earthquake rolled through the East Coast. The timing seemed fitting, suggesting perhaps even tectonic plates relied on the idea that Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, was indestructible. Having watched her will her way to so many things, lifting not only her own program and women’s basketball to a new level, but also women’s sports. Certainly she wasn’t subject to things like the law of gravity or human illnesses like Alzheimer’s, right?

headline: New ‘Paradise Lost’ Documentary, About West Memphis Three, Is Coming to New York Film Festival

headline: Where Has All the Genetic Diversity Gone?
text: Last week, I wrote about the latest meta-analysis documenting the steady march of species away from the equator and up the mountain slopes in response to a warming world. This week, a study from the Biodiversity and Climate Research Center in Germany, highlighted a new layer of complexity to consider when it comes to conservation efforts in the face of climate change — the almost invisible erosion of genetic diversity because of climate-induced range contractions. The paper, titled “Cryptic Biodiversity Loss Linked to Global Climate Change,” was published online in Nature Climate Change.

headline: So This Is the Wilderness (Forget the Stuff)
text: To come clean, this year in the woods series was all my idea. Two years ago, I said to my husband, Craig, “Let’s go live in the woods for a year, somewhere beautiful,” and he was up for it. After renting our house in the New Jersey suburbs and finding a place in Maine, here we are in an off-the-grid cabin on a gorgeous lake with our three boys and two cats.

headline: Online Shopping | Time Zones, Part 2
text: Let’s face it: Luck plays too much of a role in online discount shopping, and a lot of what we pay (or don’t pay) for clothes comes down to timing. Missing those perfect loafers on eBay by mere seconds or logging on to a Gilt sale after it’s already been ravaged by the hungriest shoppers can be a major letdown. So, T editors scoured the Internet and designed a foolproof guide to shopping the best discount sites. Happy clicking!

headline: Arguments From Personal Incredulity
text: Somewhere in his writings Richard Dawkins talks about anti-evolution types who argue from personal incredulity — they say, “I just can’t believe that chance could create something as complex as an eye”, and think that they have scored an important point. All they’ve actually done, of course, is rehash their prejudices. (Simulations show, by the way, that chance plus selection can indeed create an eye, in a relatively short time as evolutionary history goes).

headline: Owners of Nissan Trucks and S.U.V.’s Report Transmission Failures

headline: Build a 2nd Restaurant in the First’s Shadow?

Founded in 1985 by Mexican immigrants Ramón and María Cardenas, the restaurant describes its menu of moles, chile verde and enchiladas as “pre-Hispanic food, imperial Aztec cuisine and Moctezuma’s table.” Besides its sit-down restaurant business, the 130-employee company also has catering and fast-food operations.

headline: Fall for Dance Lineup Is Announced
text: A tap-dancing Steven McRae, one of the principal dancers at London’s Royal Ballet; the New York- and Sweden-based Pontus Lidberg Dance company; and the Australian Ballet are joining the mix of this season’s Fall For Dance festival at New York City Center, which will run from Oct. 27 to Nov. 6, the festival announced Wednesday. headline: Who Made That Dummy Text?
text: “Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit” is probably the most popular sentence in the world that is not meant to be read. “Lorem Ipsum” (shorthand for the entire, seemingly endless body of Latin text) is the green screen of the publishing world — placeholder copy used by designers to replicate how a block of text will look and how many words it will fit before swapping in the fully written article. This apparent gibberish, however, has been used for this purpose since the 1500s, and its foundation goes back even further. According to lipsum.com:

headline: Libya: The End and the Beginning
text: For months, almost every development out of Libya seemed to confirm my initial pessimism about our quasi-war against Muammar Qaddafi. But happily that’s changed in the last week, with the sudden collapse of his regime and the apparent victory of the rebels. As in post-Saddam Iraq and post-Taliban Afghanistan, many of the scenarios for what comes next in Libya could ultimately pose as many risks to American interests as Qaddafi himself ever did, and I agree with all the voices pointing out that the tyrant’s fall doesn’t necessarily vindicate our intervention, to say nothing of the dubiously legal means by which America was taken to war in North Africa. But I also think it’s important for critics of the war to acknowledge the significance of the last few days’ events. While few intervention skeptics “maintained that we could not possibly defeat the regime” (as Ramesh Ponnuru puts it), many of us worried that the administration’s (understandably) risk-averse approach to the conflict might create a permanent stalemate, leaving an armed-and-dangerous Qaddafi in power in Tripoli while Western warplanes circled impotently overhead. Qaddafi’s defeat doesn’t necessarily promise a happy outcome in the long run, but at the very least it guarantees that we will be spared that particular worst-case scenario, while holding out the possibility of a Libya unified and at peace — rather than a Libya partitioned and perpetually patrolled by Western forces, which is where we seemed to be headed a month ago. Declarations of victory are ridiculously premature, but for a country and a White House starved for any sort of good news, the fall of Qaddafi should be cause for (suitably restrained) celebration.

headline: Sylvia Waters, Longtime Artistic Director, to Retire From Ailey II
text: Another changing of the guard is taking place at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Sylvia Waters, the longtime artistic director of Ailey II, will retire on June 30, 2012, the company plans to announce on Thursday. Ms. Waters began her career with the company as a dancer in 1968 and Mr. Ailey chose Ms. Waters to lead the junior troupe in 1974. She went on to guide and train young dancers for nearly four decades, including Robert Battle, the company’s new artistic director. Ms. Waters has named Troy Powell, a teacher, choreographer and former dancer, as her successor. Mr. Powell has served as the associate artistic director for Ailey II since 2003.

It was more than enough to win the night for NBC, as a repeat of “NCIS” on CBS was the closest competition with 9.3 million viewers. On cable, “Teen Mom” continued to draw strong numbers for MTV with 3.7 million total viewers, while finishing second only to “America’s Got Talent” in the 18-to-49 category.

headline: Does America Need Manufacturing?
text: You can drive almost anywhere in the state of Michigan — pick a point at random and start moving — and you will soon come upon the wreckage of American industry. If you happen to be driving on the outer edge of Midland, you’ll also come upon a cavern of steel beams and ductwork, 400,000 square feet in all. When this plant, which is being constructed by Dow Kokam, a new venture partly owned by Dow Chemical, is up and running early next year, it will produce hundreds of thousands of advanced lithium-ion battery cells for hybrid and electric cars. Just as important, it will provide about 350 jobs in a state with one of the nation’s highest unemployment rates.

headline: Loud Fury and Passion, Served Up on Schedule
text: All was froth and pitch at Iceage’s sold-out show on Monday night at the Mercury Lounge, and this felt almost clinically prescribed. Elias Bender Ronnenfelt, the band’s vocalist, stalked the tight stage with sulky agitation, shoulders hunched, barking into his fist. Behind him drums and bass pumped in machinelike overdrive amid a gnarl of distorted guitar. Before him, the crowd swayed in heaves, half soaked with spilled beer. Scheduled to go on at 11:30, the band had started precisely on time.

headline: The Montelargo Banquette From Casa Midy
text: Casa Midy’s Montelargo banquette ($1,250), like many of the company’s pieces, is an amalgam of French and Mexican references reflecting the owners’ backgrounds. Anne-Marie Midy is French, and the banquette’s silhouette is inspired by park benches from that country, while Jorge Almada’s Mexican heritage is evident in the way the saddle leather is affixed to the frame, with belts and tassels. “My dad was an amateur bullfighter, and would wear leather chaps called zahones that are fastened with straps to the body,” Mr. Almada said. “The idea was to fasten the leather panel to the frame in the same manner.” Information, in Mexico: 011-52-415-15-2-04-03 or casamidy.com.

headline: Got a Good Idea? Ben Kaufman of Quirky.com Will Be the Judge of That
text: While many people have passing ideas for new household products, few make the effort to realize them. But Quirky, a self-described “social product development” company, is changing that. Founded by Ben Kaufman, a 24-year-old inventor and entrepreneur, the company solicits ideas for new products on its Web site, bringing the most popular suggestions to life with the help of in-house product designers and an online community, and then sharing the profits.

headline: In Hollywood, a Modernist’s Tag Sale

Yet it’s where Jonn Coolidge, a photographer specializing in interiors, decided to move after a decade of living in houses by Edward H. Fickett, the late Los Angeles architect known for his modernist work.

headline: Children’s Wall Decal Puzzles From Blik
text: The wall decal company Blik has introduced interactivity to its graphics with a new line of adhesive puzzles. Made from a thick low-tack film that can be stuck onto and peeled off walls without damaging paint, the puzzles function as both a game for children and decorative accents for a room. “Once you get it on your wall, it’s this beautiful thing,” said Scott Flora, one of Blik’s owners. “But at the same time, it requires some assembly, and you’re teaching your child about how things go together.”

headline: In Brooklyn, a House Rescued From the 1840s

But on one stretch of 95th Street, sandwiched between two ordinary apartment buildings, sits a home that sometimes makes passers-by do a double take: a three-story clapboard mansion from the 19th century that looks as if it were Photoshopped into the streetscape.

headline: After Strauss-Kahn, Fear of Rape Victim Silence
text: She seemed to be the perfect witness. She came forward right away, disclosing detail after damning detail of a sexual attack that, backed by forensic evidence, seemed airtight. She stuck to her story. But then her case fell apart after prosecutors questioned her credibility. The charges against the man she accused, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, were dropped.

headline: Steven P. Jobs Leaves Chief Executive Role at Apple
text: Apple said that Steven P. Jobs, its co-founder and chief executive, would step down, but wants to remain chairman. Tim Cook, the chief operating officer, will take over the position.

headline: After Player’s Death, a Question of Privacy
text: It has been a little more than a week since Winnipeg Jets forward Rick Rypien was found dead at his home in Coleman, Alberta. There was a funeral attended by 1,000 mourners. Fans paid tribute to him on the Internet and outside Rogers Arena, where Rypien, who suffered from depression, played for parts of six seasons with the Vancouver Canucks. The N.H.L., upon word of his death, said that it would review its substance-abuse and behavioral-health program, under which Rypien received treatment.

headline: Tricking Out Your iPhone Photos
text: A sample guide to photo manipulation by Brian Roberts, a master of iPhone photography.

headline: In Denmark, a Sanctuary by the Sea
text: A 5,400-square-foot house north of Copenhagen is perched on a grassy slope overlooking the tranquil Oresund strait.

headline: A ‘Sanctuary’ on the Danish Riviera
text: HUMLEBAEK, Denmark — Claus Moeller is used to uphill battles. As a biomedical researcher, and the chief executive of the Danish pharmaceutical company Azanta, he has helped create cancer-fighting drugs. But nothing prepared Dr. Moeller for the trials of constructing a home in a shoreline suburb nearly 20 miles north of Copenhagen.

headline: Romney Undeterred by Perry, or by Poll Numbers
text: LEBANON, N.H. — Mitt Romney, trying to brush off questions about Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, his Republican competitor in the 2012 presidential contest, offered a clear description of his campaign strategy during a press briefing in Claremont, N.H., on Wednesday.

headline: Strolling Artists, Bearing iPhones
text: SAN FRANCISCO — At first glance, it looked like another throng of tourists passing through San Francisco’s Chinatown. Yet one thing made this group stand out: everyone was taking pictures, but no one was using a traditional camera. No heavy D.S.L.R.’s weighed down neck straps. No point-and-shoot cameras dangled from wrists.

headline: Qaddafi Leaves Behind Little to Guide Libya in His Absence
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s stranglehold on Libya appears to have ended after 42 years, even if his whereabouts remain elusive. But through countless erratic decrees and iron-handed purges, he carved deep scars into every facet of Libyan life. The mystery and speculation swirling about him marked a fitting close to a quixotic reign.

headline: A Field Guide to Outerwear
text: The fall runway collections made a fairly convincing case for rethinking the role of outerwear in our wardrobes.

headline: Questions About Gene-Modified Foods
text: To the Editor:

headline: Colts Sign Collins and Raise a Question
text: The Indianapolis Colts made a very good move, but delivered a very bad signal Wednesday, luring the veteran quarterback Kerry Collins out of retirement to be their backup quarterback.

headline: Germany’s Capital Burns Bright, and Without Explanation
text: BERLIN — At night all over the city, cars are burning on the streets of the German capital.

headline: Starting Anew in New York, Giants Tackle Takes His Shot
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Jimmy Kennedy won the 1996 New York state football championship with Roosevelt High School in Yonkers, he was one of 20 players. One very big player.

headline: Chamber of Commerce, on Business and the Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Behind the Glittery Web Start-Ups, Investors See Other Gold
text: While the spotlight of the latest technology boom has been focused on a cluster of popular consumer applications like Facebook, Groupon and Zynga, investors are increasingly taking a shine to the start-ups building the infrastructure for those Internet powerhouses.

headline: A Rare Bustle in the Lab as Seismometers Quiver
text: New Yorkers most likely will remember Aug. 23, 2011, as the day the earth hiccupped for a matter of seconds, providing a worthy conversation piece but, ultimately, a fleeting interruption.

headline: Jobs Steps Down at Apple, Saying He Can’t Meet Duties
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Steven P. Jobs, whose insistent vision that he knew what consumers wanted made Apple one of the world’s most valuable and influential companies, is stepping down as chief executive, the company announced late Wednesday.

headline: Look Back in Envy: The ’70s Take the Runway
text: ON “The Marc and Myra Show,” on SiriusXM radio, the writer Bob Colacello recalled visiting Studio 54 in the 1970s when Yves Saint Laurent strolled into the room. Halston, on glimpsing his idol, sprang from his chair to embrace him. Taking in the scene, Truman Capote was heard to tell a companion: “You have just witnessed one of the great moments in the history of fashion. That is, if you care about the history of fashion.”

headline: Recapturing the Mood of the 1970s
text: The ’70s have been revisited time and again in more recent decades, but not with the conviction demonstrated on the runways of late.

headline: Two Old Friends, in Bronze
text: HOUSTON — Those who stand in a downtown park and stare into the eyes of a statue of James A. Baker III might wonder what has caught the former secretary of state’s gaze. Upon turning around, they squint and realize that it is his friend and former boss, George Bush, the 41st president of the United States.

headline: In Mountain Village, Cuomo Finds Respite
text: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y. — The first sighting came in March: there he was, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, forsaking his usual suit and tie for blue jeans and a pair of Oakley sunglasses, pumping gas at a Mobil station here.

headline: After Arab Revolts, Reigns of Uncertainty
text: DJERBA, Tunisia — The idealism of the revolts in Egypt and Tunisia, where the power of the street revealed the frailty of authority, revived an Arab world anticipating change. But Libya’s unfinished revolution, as inspiring as it is unsettling, illustrates how perilous that change has become as it unfolds in this phase of the Arab Spring.

headline: America’s Sweatshop Diplomacy
text: ACCORDING to the State Department, the J-1 visa Summer Work Study program, which allows foreign students to work in the United States for a few months, is meant to promote “lasting and meaningful relationships” between the students and Americans.

headline: In New Jersey, Rules Are Changed on Witness IDs
text: The New Jersey Supreme Court, acknowledging a “troubling lack of reliability in eyewitness identifications,” issued sweeping new rules on Wednesday making it easier for defendants to challenge such evidence in criminal cases.

headline: Bright Red, Yet So Hard to See
text: Scattered along the city’s sidewalks are 15,000 emergency-help boxes, though most people interviewed said they took no note of them. Including, Eddie Colon, 52, of Harlem, who was leaning his bicycle against one at the northwest corner of 125th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard/

headline: A History of Fearlessness
text: When Pat Summitt became head coach of the Tennessee Lady Vols in 1974, she drove the team van and began to shift gears on the long uphill climb for women’s sports.

headline: Over the Cliff
text: I fell into a Supreme Court time warp the other day. Preparing to teach a seminar this fall on the court under Chief Justice Warren E. Burger — the court of the 1970s to mid-’80s — I picked up for the first time in many years a decision from 1978, First National Bank of Boston v. Bellotti. The case is not well-known today, although it should be. It was the decision that really opened the door to corporate money in politics, leading 32 years later to a very well-known case: Citizens United.

headline: How to Fix Our Math Education
text: THERE is widespread alarm in the United States about the state of our math education. The anxiety can be traced to the poor performance of American students on various international tests, and it is now embodied in George W. Bush’s No Child Left Behind law, which requires public school students to pass standardized math tests by the year 2014 and punishes their schools or their teachers if they do not.

headline: Twitter Reactions to Jobs Stepping Down
text: [View the story “Tracking Jobs News” on Storify]

headline: Still City Fixture, Many Call Boxes Overstay Their Welcome
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response) {data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: '+ data +', cropType: 'blog480', appendTo: 'embeddedSlideshow', showHeadLine: 'false'}

headline: Yes, He Sold Fakes. They Are Supposed to Be Fake.
text: The items, mostly copies of luxury objects, inside the little shop in downtown Manhattan are made of thin cardboard and might not even pass muster deep in the background of a movie set.

headline: Perry Surges in Polls, Testing Romney’s Strategy
text: Primary polls can be erratic, so the rule is not to get too worked up about any one set of numbers. But now there have been five surveys conducted since Rick Perry announced his presidential campaign — one each from Gallup, Rasmussen Reports and Public Policy Polling, and two from YouGov. Each shows Mr. Perry having vaulted into a lead over Mitt Romney.

headline: China Faces Obstacles in Bid to Rebalance Its Economy
text: CHENGDU, China — A casual glance out the window is all it takes to witness the blistering growth that has become the signature feature of this provincial capital and of other cities in the vast Chinese interior. A phalanx of half-finished office and apartment towers flanked by yellow cranes rises above the brown waters of the Jinjiang River.

headline: A Jubilant Return Home
text: DAVISON, Mich. — A quarter-mile from where he used to sell apples from a roadside stand to help his family make ends meet, Tim Thomas stood on the 50-yard line at his old high school football stadium Wednesday — the Stanley Cup, the Conn Smythe Trophy and the Vezina Trophy in the foreground — facing bleachers full of fans, friends and family.

headline: Without Its Master of Design, Apple Will Face Many Challenges
text: Steven P. Jobs, one of the most successful chief executives in corporate history, once said he never thought of himself as a manager, but as a leader. And his notion of leadership revolved around choosing the best people possible, encouraging them and creating an environment in which they could do great work.

headline: When Libya Grew Wings
text: Tripoli, Libya

headline: For State Teachers’ Union, a Victory on Evaluations
text: A judge ruled Wednesday that the New York State Board of Regents overreached in its interpretation of a new law on teacher evaluations, offering a victory to the state teachers’ union.

headline: Still No Deal on Testing for H.G.H.
text: Negotiations between the N.F.L. and its players union over testing for human growth hormone continued to stall Wednesday, with the union upset that it did not receive the scientific documents it requested from the World Anti-Doping Agency regarding the test for H.G.H.

headline: Gov. Perry’s Cash Machine
text: The exchange of campaign contributions for government contracts, favors or positions is all too common in Washington and around the country. It has been developed to an especially high art — or more to the point, a low art — by Gov. Rick Perry in Texas. For a presidential contender who insists that big government is the country’s biggest problem, it is particularly cynical.

headline: Wild Ride Expected on the Slopes at the Barclays
text: EDISON, N.J. — Approach with caution, and putt with it, too.

headline: Europe Accuses Iranian Force of Aiding Syrian Crackdown
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The European Union announced on Wednesday that it was leveling sanctions against Iran’s Al Quds military force, saying it had given technical and material support to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria in his efforts to crush the five-month-old uprising against his rule.

headline: The Negative Side of Share Buybacks
text: Share buybacks are creeping back into fashion. Lowe’s and CVS Caremark divulged plans for $9 billion worth between them this week. Such repurchases become more enticing when markets are on their knees. But boards have too often sanctioned programs that destroy value. They need to resist the rising temptation.

headline: Judge Suppresses Statements in Arms Trial
text: In a rare pretrial victory for Viktor Bout, a Russian accused of conspiring to sell arms to a terrorist organization, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday that certain statements Mr. Bout made after his 2008 arrest in a sting operation in Thailand cannot be used at trial.

headline: Release Shane Bauer and Joshua Fattal
text: The American hikers Shane Bauer and Joshua Fattal have spent 755 days in Iran’s brutal Evin prison. They never should have been arrested, much less held for so long. With the Muslim world celebrating the holy month of Ramadan, Iranian officials should show compassion, and true respect for justice, and let them return home.

headline: Tomlinson Is Turning Heads, if Not Turning Back Clock
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Once and only once this summer has the Jets running backs coach Anthony Lynn thought about LaDainian Tomlinson’s age, and it happened during practice last week.

headline: Libyans Face a New Challenge: Expelling the Fear That Qaddafi Instilled in Them
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — When rebels broke through the gates of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s compound this week, Abdul Rahman Sharif was so moved that despite the gunfire he took his daughters, ages 11, 15 and 18, with him to see it for themselves. Then after dark he returned with his wife. And the next day, as more bullets flew, he visited the compound with his 90-year-old mother.

headline: N.B.A. and Union to Hold a Rare Bargaining Session
text: Lead negotiators for the N.B.A. and its players union will hold a bargaining session next week — just the second since the lockout began — with an unofficial deadline fast approaching to save the start of training camps. Four people involved in the talks said the sides planned to meet in New York, although the day and the location were still being arranged. They might not be in a conciliatory mood when they arrive.

headline: Cheney Says He Urged Bush to Bomb Syria in ’07
text: WASHINGTON — Former Vice President Dick Cheney says in a new memoir that he urged President George W. Bush to bomb a suspected Syrian nuclear reactor site in June 2007. But, he wrote, Mr. Bush opted for a diplomatic approach after other advisers — still stinging over “the bad intelligence we had received about Iraq’s stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction” — expressed misgivings.

headline: U.S. May Back Refinance Plan for Mortgages
text: The Obama administration is considering further actions to strengthen the housing market, but the bar is high: plans must help a broad swath of homeowners, stimulate the economy and cost next to nothing.

headline: Thursday: Magic 8 Ball Answer
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Any puzzle by Patrick Blindauer and Francis Heaney, either individually or as a collaboration, is O.K. by me. They are both terrific guys and two of the most creative constructors around today, in my opinion. You don’t have to fold their puzzles into the shape of a pterodactyl or spend all of your time Googling answers in order to solve them, but there is usually some visual or verbal element in each of them that makes me feel like I wish I had thought of it first.

headline: Why Is That a Secret?
text: A former top official in charge of ensuring that real secrets are kept secret has delivered a stunning repudiation of the Obama administration’s decision to use the Espionage Act against a whistle-blower attempting to expose government waste and abuse.

headline: Money Is Now at Fore of Strauss-Kahn Case
text: When Dominique Strauss-Kahn was arrested more than three months ago on sexual assault charges, the sensational accusations carried an intriguing subplot: money.

headline: U.S. Checks Conditions for Workers in Walkout
text: The Department of Labor and the State Department opened investigations this week of job conditions at a Pennsylvania packing plant for Hershey’s chocolates where several hundred international exchange students walked off their jobs last week, protesting low pay and strenuous work.

headline: Phillies’ Turf Becomes the Mets’ No-Fans Land
text: PHILADELPHIA — If the 22 ½ games separating the teams in the standings and the blowouts on Monday and Tuesday were not enough to indicate the gulf between the fading Mets and the first-place Philadelphia Phillies, then a peek into the sea of red in the stands should have done it.

headline: The Tobacco Companies Just Keep Trying
text: Tobacco companies are back in court trying to prevent the government from imposing new regulations that will require bold warning labels on cigarette packages and advertisements. They lost a similar federal lawsuit in tobacco-friendly Kentucky last year. Now they are suing in Federal District Court in Washington.

headline: Search for Answers as a 2nd Stabbing Victim Dies
text: As a second victim of a stabbing rampage at an Upper Manhattan building died on Wednesday, residents described a close-knit community and questioned what brought on the attack, which the police said was committed by a lifelong neighbor.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Official Warns About China’s Military Buildup
text: WASHINGTON — The pace and scope of China’s military buildup is “potentially destabilizing” in the Pacific, a top defense official warned Wednesday as the Pentagon released an annual report cataloging China’s cruise missiles, fighter jets and growing, modernizing army.

headline: From California, Advice for Next Time: Stay Inside
text: The earthquake on Tuesday rattled many New Yorkers enough to make them evacuate glass-encased office towers.

headline: Trinidad and Tobago Declares Emergency Over Drug Crimes
text: MEXICO CITY — The island nation of Trinidad and Tobago has imposed a nightly curfew and sent troops to cope with a rash of violent crime associated with gangs, one of the starkest signs of worry in the Caribbean region over a spike in drug trafficking.

headline: With Burnett and Colon Struggling, Yankees’ Pitching Remains Unsettled
text: The Yankees have grown weary of questions relating to their potential playoff pitching rotation, and for good reason. The team cannot even be certain who will be healthy and performing well a week from now, let alone in a month.

headline: Quake Leaves Cracks in Washington Monument, Closing It for Now
text: WASHINGTON — While the angst over whether this country’s political system is broken seems likely to go on for the foreseeable future, it gave way to some degree Wednesday to more immediate concerns about how badly the Washington Monument had been cracked.

headline: Monthly Visitors to the Washington Monument
text: The Washington Monument doesn’t average as many visitors as it once did.

headline: Rabbi Fabricated Swashbuckling Tales of Saving Holocaust Torahs, Prosecutors Say
text: He described himself as a risk-taking rabbi who had been “beaten up, thrown in jail and gone $175,000 into debt” on “expeditions” to Eastern Europe. He said his mission was to rescue and restore Torahs that had been “wrenched from their communities during the Holocaust” and place them with congregations that would look after them.

headline: Same-Sex Couples Since 1990
text: The number of same-sex couples has risen dramatically since 1990.

headline: Car Bomb in Iraq Kills 7 at a Ramadi Checkpoint
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber driving a car packed with explosives attacked a police checkpoint west of Ramadi on Wednesday night, killing seven people, including five police officers, and wounding four other officers and a civilian, according to local officials.

headline: Unsavory Culinary Elitism
text: Anthony Bourdain, the part-time chef and full-time celebrity, has a tongue on him. It’s the sharpest knife in his set. He has used it to carve up vegans, whom he called the “Hezbollah-like splinter faction” of vegetarians, and the culinary moralist Alice Waters, whose rigidity is “very Khmer Rouge.”

headline: An Original Journalism Blogger Logs Out
text: He was an aggregator before it became a dirty word. He was a blogger before there were blogs.

headline: Trying to Recapture Glory Before Season’s End
text: EDISON, N.J. — Vijay Singh was a lone figure on the far end of the three-tiered practice range at Plainfield Country Club on Wednesday, smashing shot after shot high into the afternoon sky with almost metronomic consistency.

headline: Unlikely Power From A’s Sends Yankees to Second Consecutive Loss
text: Coco Crisp is known for many things, including his talent as a center fielder, his ability to hit from both sides of the plate, and of course his name. With only 72 home runs in his 10-year career, however, he is definitely not known as a slugger.

headline: Billions in Home Loans
text: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac guarantee nearly $2.4 trillion in mortgages with interest rates above 4 percent.

headline: Geologists Sharply Cut Estimate of Shale Gas
text: WASHINGTON — Federal geologists published new estimates this week for the amount of natural gas that exists in a giant rock formation known as the Marcellus Shale, which stretches from New York to Virginia.

headline: If Texas A&M Is the SEC’s 13th Team, Who’s No. 14?
text: After a week of revelations involving Ponzi schemes, prostitutes and illicit payments, college athletic directors, presidents and television executives are now focusing on the really ugly mess facing college sports.

headline: Joey Vento, Founder of Cheese-Steak Institution, Dies at 71
text: Joey Vento, the founder of Geno’s Steaks, a stand-in-line takeout establishment that is one of the pillars of the cheese-steak mecca of South Philadelphia, died Tuesday at his home in Shamong, N.J. He was 71.

headline: Steven P. Jobs, Apple's Innovator
text: Steven P. Jobs co-founded Apple Computer 35 years ago.

headline: Former Oriole Flanagan Found Dead
text: Mike Flanagan, a former pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles and the Toronto Blue Jays, was found dead at his home in Baltimore County, Md., on Wednesday.

headline: Shares Fall as Hopes Fade for New Action by Fed and Jobless Claims Rise
text: Traders have been overwhelmed by the prospects of a global economic slowdown, a euro zone debt problem and other issues. On Thursday, there were new developments to contend with: the resignation of Steven P. Jobs as chief executive of Apple and the investment by Berkshire Hathaway, which is run by Warren E. Buffett, in Bank of America.

headline: Budd Hopkins, Abstract Expressionist and U.F.O. Author, Dies at 80
text: Budd Hopkins, a distinguished Abstract Expressionist artist who — after what he described as a chance sighting of something flat, silver, airborne and unfathomable — became the father of the alien-abduction movement, died on Aug. 21 at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Recipes: Lobster With More Than Just Melted Butter
text: A dozen ways to transform lobster into salads, bisque, chowder, sandwiches or kebabs.

headline: Lobster With More Than Just Melted Butter
text: The pleasure of eating lobster is intense, and the reward-to-work ratio is unsurpassed, all of which is fun to talk about. What’s not so fun to talk about is lobsters and pain, which is why I’m going to avoid it. All of us lobster eaters do. (If you want a full consideration of the lobster/pain issue — one that resolves absolutely nothing but grapples with it beautifully — read David Foster Wallace’s hilarious essay “Consider the Lobster.”)

headline: New Numbers, and Geography, for Gay Couples
text: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. — So much for San Francisco.

headline: Insurance Company Rebrands Itself as Kemper
text: It is not unprecedented, but it is unusual: a company that makes an acquisition sheds its own name to take the name of a product or brand it has acquired.

headline: The Most Accurate Fantasy Football Rankings
text: David Kim is the co-founder of FantasyPros, a site that aggregates and organizes advice from all the top fantasy football sources. You can follow FantasyPros on Twitter.

headline: Steve Jobs’s Patents
text: The 317 Apple patents that list Steven P. Jobs among the group of inventors offer a glimpse at his legendary say over the minute details of the company’s products.

headline: Word of the Day | pandemic
text: pandemic •\pan-ˈde-mik\• adjective and noun

headline: NYT: Front Page for 08/25/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 08/25/2011

headline: Online Enterprises Gain Foothold as Path to a College Degree
text: Harvard and Ohio State are not going to disappear any time soon. But a host of new online enterprises are making earning a college degree cheaper, faster and flexible enough to take work experience into account. As Wikipedia upended the encyclopedia industry and iTunes changed the music business, these businesses have the potential to change higher education.

headline: Weekly Prompts From a Mentor
text: Fifteen years ago, bemoaning the high cost of higher education, the governors of 19 Western states decided to start a nonprofit online institution to help meet their need for a trained work force. The result, Western Governors University, offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in education, business, the health professions and information technology. Everything is online except for student teaching and some nursing requirements.

headline: Open Courses, Nearly Free
text: After the earthquake in Haiti destroyed much of the country’s higher-education infrastructure, the University of the People decided to set up three computer centers there, inviting English-speaking students from nearby tent cities to come and work for four hours a day.

headline: A Way to Speed the Pace
text: Burck Smith, who previously started an online tutoring company, founded Straighterline in 2008 to challenge the high cost of college.

headline: Receiving Credit for Job Experience
text: Started in January, Learning Counts is a project of the Council for Adult and Experiential Learning, the American Council on Education and the College Board, in which older students take an online course that teaches them to prepare a portfolio that shows what they have learned from work and life experience. The portfolios — one for each subject area in which they are seeking credit — are then submitted to an outside evaluator, who decides whether they should get academic credit.

headline: Corrections: August 25
text: NEW YORK

headline: A Short-Lived Test, Even With Coaching
text: The first question on the screening test for an online class I signed up for was not a hard one, but my most recent exposure to math had been in high school decades before, and I didn’t remember how to solve even easy equations.

headline: Business Studies Become Environmentally Friendly
text: “Through the roof” is how Adam Zak, an executive recruiter, describes the demand for workers with sustainability-related job skills.

headline: Steven P. Jobs Leaves Chief Executive Role at Apple
text: Apple said that Steven P. Jobs, its co-founder and chief executive, would step down, but wants to remain chairman. Tim Cook, the chief operating officer, will take over the position.

headline: News Quiz | August 25, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Imagining Apple Without Steve Jobs
text: WHO is Steve Jobs?WHO will succeed him at Apple?

headline: Inside a Libyan Hospital, Proof of a Revolt’s Costs
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Word raced through Tripoli Central Hospital as fast as the bloody gurneys rushing through the entrance on Thursday carrying wounded fighters from the front: perhaps this was Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s last stand.

headline: Aug. 25, 1944 | Paris Is Liberated After 4-Year Nazi Occupation
text: On Aug. 25, 1944, Allied and French Resistance forces entered Paris and drove out the last significant Nazi opposition, liberating the city after four years of Nazi occupation. “On all sides the liberating French and Americans were greeted by hungry Parisians, mad with joy, who had fought alone against the German oppressors since they were called to arms last Saturday,” reported The Associated Press in an article printed in The New York Times.

headline: Asking Candidates Tougher Questions About Faith
text: If a candidate for president said he believed that space aliens dwell among us, would that affect your willingness to vote for him? Personally, I might not disqualify him out of hand; one out of three Americans believe we have had Visitors and, hey, who knows? But I would certainly want to ask a few questions. Like, where does he get his information? Does he talk to the aliens? Do they have an economic plan?

headline: Stephen Crowley’s Monument to Washington
text: On Tuesday afternoon, the Washington Monument — that postcard-perfect symbol of the capital — fell victim to a 5.8-magnitude earthquake that shook the East Coast.

headline: More Transparent Bank Stress Tests Are Needed
text: 1:41 p.m. | Updated Adding news of Warren Buffett’s investment in Bank of America.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 25, 2011
text: Today’s question was written by Shannon Doyne. Her question comes from the article “Worthy Rivals for the Crown in Smartphones.”

headline: Do You Like Horror Movies?
text: In the video “The Horror, The Horror,” Jason Zinoman says that people watch scary movies for the “really intense emotional experiences” and that “you never feel more ‘in the moment’ than when terrified at a horror movie.” Do you agree? Do you watch horror movies? Which are your favorites?

headline: Behind the Scenes With Andy Samberg
text: The stars were aligned for the cover-story photo shoot in this Sunday’s magazine. To accompany “The Fierce Intimacy of Tennis Rivalries,” by Gerald Marzorati, the former editor of the magazine, the current editor of the magazine, Hugo Lindgren, suggested putting a modern face on some familiar tennis icons from the not-too-distant past. So we enlisted the comedian and “Saturday Night Live” regular Andy Samberg and the photographer Walter Iooss Jr., whose work has been appearing in Sports Illustrated for decades (indeed, Iooss had shot all of our original subjects), along with an ace styling team and crew. (We also brought in a digital team to stir its magic into the images, but more about that in a later blog post.) As the magazine’s photo director, Kathy Ryan, put it, the day was “pure pleasure,” which we hope some of these behind-the-scenes photographs will reveal.

headline: A Chief Executive’s Attention to Detail, Noted in 313 Patents
text: When people in the technology industry speak of Steven P. Jobs’s knack for design, they often have Apple’s iconic products in mind: the early all-in-one Macintosh computers, the first iMacs with their brightly colored and translucent cases, and more recently, the various iPods, iPhones and iPads.

headline: The Early Word: Projections
text: In Today’s Times:The debt plan that lawmakers agreed to this month would sharply reduce budget deficits over the next decade, but the extension of the Bush-era tax rates would more than consume those savings, the Congressional Budget Office warned on Wednesday. Jackie Calmes writes that the report underlines the high stakes for the special bipartisan panel created to devise a plan by December for how to achieve up to $1.5 trillion in savings promised by the deal over 10 years.

headline: London Version of ‘Woyzeck’ Combines Puppetry and Animation
text: Best known for its award-winning production of “War Horse,” the Handspring Puppet Company will next lend its unique approach to theater with a revival of “Woyzeck on the Highveld.”

headline: India Seeks Deal to End a Hunger Strike
text: NEW DELHI — India’s Parliament met a major demand of the protest leader Anna Hazare on Thursday by agreeing to consider his proposed anticorruption legislation, but it remained unclear whether Mr. Hazare would finally end a hunger strike that has spawned a nationwide popular movement and deeply shaken India’s government.

headline: Economic Research Institute Created in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — The leader of one of the most influential business families in Hong Kong announced Thursday that the family’s foundation was setting up a nonprofit research group here to analyze economic and corporate issues from an Asian perspective.

headline: A Mirror of Greatness, Blurred
text: WASHINGTON — It is a momentous occasion. Into an honored array of presidents and soldiers — the founders and protectors of the nation — has come a minister, a man without epaulets or civilian authority, who was not a creator of laws, but someone who, for a time, was a deliberate violator of them; not a wager of war but someone who, throughout his short life, was pretty much a pacifist; not an associate of the nation’s ruling elite but someone who, in many cases, would have been prevented from joining it.

headline: If Cinderella Had a BlackBerry...
text: If Aline Brosh McKenna were to write a script about her life, it might open with McKenna, wavy-haired and underdressed, hopefully showing her work to a series of unsmiling magazine editors in New York. Discouraged but not defeated, she eventually screws up her resolve and decides to take a course in screenwriting. Cut to a classroom where student after student offers high-flown ideas for films that will never be made, until at last McKenna speaks: “I want to make a caper comedy about two girls, and one falls in love with someone she thinks is a criminal who turns out to be an F.B.I. agent.”

headline: Steve Jobs Reshaped Industries
text: When Steve Jobs resigned as the chief executive of Apple on Wednesday, his note to the public and the Apple board was short and classy. The gist was this: “I have always said if there ever came a day when I could no longer meet my duties and expectations as Apple’s C.E.O., I would be the first to let you know. Unfortunately, that day has come.”

headline: Foreign Workers Stranded Without Money or Visas
text: BAGHDAD — For months, they have sat here, half a block from the prime minister’s palace in the Green Zone, essentially captives with little food, drinking water or electricity.

headline: East Coast Battens Down for Arrival of Hurricane Irene
text: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C. — John H. Woolard, who is 79 years old, cannot remember how many hurricanes he has confronted at his home, also 79, which sits on stilts overlooking the Atlantic Ocean here. Is it 12? Or 14?

headline: Italy Cost Cutting Shines Light on Obscure Entities

headline: With a Civil Trial Pending, the Strauss-Kahn Case Is Hardly Closed
text: There may be no second acts in American lives, assuming that F. Scott Fitzgerald got it right with that oft-quoted observation, but they surely exist in American jurisprudence. So for those of you who want still more of Dominique Strauss-Kahn and his accuser, Nafissatou Diallo, another chapter may be in store. If this were a movie, it might even be called “Hot Spots! Part Deux.” While the criminal charges of sexual assault and attempted rape have been dismissed, Mr. Strauss-Kahn still faces a lawsuit brought by Ms. Diallo, seeking unspecified damages for the “violent and sadistic attack” that she says she endured in the Midtown hotel where she cleaned rooms.

headline: Aug. 25 Updates on the War in Libya

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Remembering 9/11
text: With the tenth anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks just a few weeks away, the staff at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum is preparing to open this new site for visitors in Lower Manhattan. Sean Anderson, the chief technology officer for the organization, drops in  to The New York Times’s Tech Talk podcast discuss the Explore 9/11 mobile app for those who want to understand the event more clearly. Mr. Anderson also outlines the other online educational materials the museum offers, including an interactive timeline, a virtual tour of the site with Google Earth, and the 9/11 Memorial’s Web site.

It seemed a flip from the corporate game plan Mr. Apotheker had championed only a few months earlier. H.P. is paying a high price for a business software company. And it may have undermined the value of its personal computer business by saying it was considering selling it off.

headline: Summer Cinema Worth Debating
text: FOR those of us who believe that any movie worth seeing is worth arguing about — and vice versa — summer can be a season of malaise. Screens are booked with consensus in mind, and the box office numbers are interpreted to deliver what look like unambiguous judgments. The conventional wisdom of 2011 is that everyone liked “Bridesmaids” and “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” while nobody much cared for “Friends With Benefits” or “Cowboys & Aliens.”

text: Dagmara Dominczyk, a curvy brunette bombshell who was born in Poland, appears in the movie “Higher Ground,” which opens tomorrow. She’s far from dull — she still has a crush on her husband, Patrick Wilson, adores her two sons, Kalin and Kassian, and has a great knowledge of products, potions and cosmetics, Polish and otherwise. Her passion and energy are contagious.

headline: Choosing Between Profits and Growth

So far, we have succeeded on that front, growing to more than $16 million in projected annual revenue this year — with a 103-percent yearly compounded growth rate since our inception. While this has put us on the Inc. 500 list, it hasn’t always synched with that other very important line on our profit-and-loss statement: the profit.

headline: Last Man Running

But those gathered outside were waiting for one sprinter and one sprinter only. As Usain Bolt emerged last with his green ballcap perched at a jaunty angle, he was soon back in familiar formation — at the heart of a fast-moving pack of cameras, boom microphones, security guards and officials as he flashed three fingers to his public.

headline: Farm-to-Table Meals, on European Farms

Founded in 1999, Outstanding in the Field has held sold-out, farm-based meals across the United States with cooking stars like Gabrielle Hamilton, Claudia Fleming, Charlie Parker and Evan Kleinman. A sort of cross between picnic, art happening and statement about sustainability, the meals celebrate the farmers who grow our food and literally connect diners to the land.

headline: Classical Streaming’s Fitful Baby Steps
text: FOR innumerable music lovers in America, the world changed on July 14. That was the day that Spotify, a Swedish Internet music-streaming service founded in 2008 and eagerly adopted by millions of registered users in Europe, began operating in the United States after years of arduous negotiations with the big four major recording companies: Universal Music, Sony, Warner Brothers and EMI.

headline: Let the Fun Begin
text: This Sunday, the seventh floor of the Museum of Art and Design will be transformed into a 1990s vortex of cyberpunk phosphorescence, Web 1.0 social networking and conceptual snacking (e.g., scented high-potency oxygen). Snack the Planet kicks off the museum’s Fun fellowship, which gives local night-life innovators carte blanche to create outsize party experiences at the museum. Lauren Devine and Patrik Sandberg, who masterminded the event, were inspired by the seminal Angelina Jolie film “Hackers” (1995) and its credo to “hack the planet,” but promise to collude with the present as well, with performances by the up-and-coming acts Pictureplane, Teengirl Fantasy and Mykki Blanco; an immersive multimedia “entertainment zone” designed by Thunder Horse Video; and advanced tweeting modalities engineered by DIS Magazine’s Nick Scholl, whose colleagues are supplying the souvenir branded condoms. Next up, Gag!, the long-running night at Metropolitan gay bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn hosted by Cameron Cooper and Zach Cole, will host what it is billing as a free store (in fact it will operate on a barter system) specializing in homegrown hipster esoterica during Fashion Week.Snack the Planet: Saturday, Aug. 27, 12-5 p.m. and Sunday, Aug. 28, 12-10 p.m. Bands play on Sunday only, starting at 5 p.m.

headline: The Huntsman Gambit

This prompts Jim Antle to ask the obvious question: If Huntsman actually has more right-wing street cred — on abortion, guns, taxes, you name it — than the frontrunning  Romney (or the ex-frontrunning, based on the latest polls), then why has he decided to run to Romney’s left?

The actress Anne Hathaway pairs a crochet pattern with a pink tee and conceptual cargos, while Rachel Bilson goes cozy in a nubby cable with baggier boyfriend jeans and Claudia Schiffer takes a leaner approach with leggings and over-the-knee boots.

headline: Casting Reality TV? It’s Now Difficult To Find Real People
text: IT’S going on two decades since MTV came out with “The Real World,” considered the first series to take ordinary, unknown people and focus cameras on them 24/7 until they became famous. Back in those relatively innocent times, before a bachelorette had handed out a single rose or any New Jersey housewife had flipped a table for a national audience, the concept of reality television was new enough that potential participants had no clue what to expect. Or what riches they could acquire in the process.

headline: Compass Has Closed, Will Be Reborn as Loi

headline: A Fan of Fantasy and Cartoon Squid
text: After nearly 40 years as a model of downtown cool, it’s still possible to find Debbie Harry, the longtime Blondie frontwoman, out at a tiny New York club, looking for some new momentum. “I like to go out dancing and dance around to stuff, and sometimes that will really inspire a phrase,” she said. “You can just, you know, feel it. I love it.” Ms. Harry, 66, who was wearing dresses made of double-sided razor blades decades before Lady Gaga plied a piece of beef, also has mainstream tastes. “I love a lot of the music that’s out,” she said. “I love Rihanna and I love Gaga and I love LMFAO. I’ve always been a person who pays attention to the charts as well as the counterculture and sort of the underground stuff.”

headline: Running a Restaurant Is No Joke

headline: 36 Hours in Portland, Ore.
text: WITH its celebrated bike culture and obsession with all things independent and artisan, Portland is a small-scale metropolis with an outsize cultural footprint. Spread across the twin banks of the Willamette River, this provincial hub of the Pacific Northwest has more than its share of natural beauty and an earnest, outdoorsy reputation. But in recent years, the city has emerged as the capital of West Coast urban cool, earning it a television series, IFC’s “Portlandia,” devoted to satirizing its aesthetic and progressive social bent. Indeed, Portland — whose nicknames include Beervana and Soccer City, USA — is easy to poke fun at. It’s also hard to resist.
