headline: After Decades of Brassy Civic Advocacy, Sally Goodgold Dies at 82
text: Sally Goodgold was the Ethel Merman of land use: bold, brassy and capable of sounding notes that could be heard over any orchestra. An Upper West Sider in the traditionally outspoken mold, and a civic leader of the old Progressivist school, she believed New Yorkers deserved affordable housing and accommodating public environments; that private development ought to help create these things, not eradicate them; and that it was the job of city officials to prod, not coddle, powerful builders.

headline: Japanese Island as Unlikely Arts Installation
text: ON a chilly night last November on the tiny island of Naoshima in the Seto Inland Sea of southern Japan, I found myself alone in a dark concrete gallery, a sweater pulled over my pajamas. I was staying at the Benesse House Museum, a 10-room hotel set inside a contemporary art museum, on the island’s craggy southern coast, and still battling jet lag. So instead of tossing in bed, I visited the deserted galleries of the museum — guests of the hotel are permitted to wander beyond closing time. Before long, I was transfixed by Bruce Nauman’s art installation, “100 Live and Die,” a neon billboard of flashing phrases.

headline: Letters — Traveling Along the Mediterranean
text: To the Editor: Re “Mediterranean Dream Trip Higher-Lights,” Aug. 21: I am lucky enough to live in Vienna, and I try to get down to the Croatian coast — the Istrian Peninsula, the Kavner coast and Dalmatia — at least once a year. You are right. It is breathtakingly beautiful. Istria is like Tuscany, but with beaches and gorgeous towns nearby. Southern Dalmatia is a dream and still has places where you can avoid the crowds. Edward Serotta

headline: Berlin Galleries’ Newest Home

headline: Over the Alps on a Bike With a Boost

headline: Local Data Becomes ‘Hyperlocal’

Therein lies the usefulness of data-packed Web sites like Zillow, Trulia and Streeteasy, which can be mined by the tech-savvy for the level of detail that will be most persuasive to their clients.

It’s very raw footage, but it’s worth watching just for the adorable, smiley kid with the mohawk, and for the sense of overall cheery wholesomeness that you don’t really get at American music festivals anymore (I’m looking at you, Juggalos).

headline: Scrapbooking Big-Screen Memories
text: THE Fox Venice Theater in Los Angeles — a boxy, pale-blue building topped by a jaunty red sign — opened in 1951 with a single movie screen and 1,003 seats; it was shuttered in the late 1980s and now houses an indoor swap meet. In a note posted more than 20 years after its closing on the Web site Cinema Treasures, a former patron credited the theater with a string of personal triumphs. “I went from being an uneducated warehouse worker to a therapist with a master’s degree,” the commenter wrote. “The movies at the Fox showed me that there were possibilities in life. I sat there and learned from all of it.”

headline: The Jam | Marianne Faithfull
text: The legendary English singer-songwriter Marianne Faithfull, who is also an actress, presents us with her playlist this week. “It’s heavy in the cornerstone classics of music,” says the Jam‘s curator, Sean Hanratty, of the list, which includes Leonard Cohen and the Clash. “It’s full of the timeless stuff that you never really lose, the records you own and would never part with.” Faithfull’s first hit, “As Tears Go By” (1964), which Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and the Rolling Stones manager Andrew Loog Oldham helped write, remains one of the best ballads of all time. The song, along with her highly publicized relationship with Jagger, put her on the map as one of rock’s biggest stars. “You Can’t Always Get What You Want,” on the Stones album “Let It Bleed,” released in 1969, was one of many songs written about Faithfull. “I think some people forget — certainly not me — that she also co-wrote ‘Sister Morphine,’ ” says Hanratty of the track on the Stones’s 1971 “Sticky Fingers” album. (The song is reportedly about her life and battles with drug abuse, specifically heroin.) For the past five decades, we have seen Faithfull reinvent herself as a performer and musician, in collaborations with the likes of David Bowie, Tom Waits, Emmylou Harris, Nick Cave and others, while keeping her place as one of the most influential female singer-songwriters of all time. “With the impending hurricane and Virginia’s earthquake, we are kind of in need of the classics,” Hanratty says. Faithfull will perform her classics, as well as songs from this year’s album, “Horses and High Heels,” at Manhattan’s City Winery on Dec. 18.

headline: ‘Big Brother’ Gets Boost From N.F.L.
text: Local coverage of National Football League exhibition games once again inflated early broadcast network numbers on Thursday. “Big Brother” on CBS reached new, albeit football-assisted, heights with a double-eviction episode that aired after the N.F.L. broadcast. The reality show’s ratings matching its season best in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic and the total audience was just under 8.5 million viewers – the largest viewership for the show since Sept. 2007. CBS won the night handily by filling the rest of its slate with reliable reruns of “Big Bang Theory” (7.9 million viewers) and The Mentalist (6.1 million).

headline: When an Oldie Is Only 11 Years Old
text: The Locrian Chamber Players have several quirky policies, and they usually honor them to the letter. One is a 10-year rule: the ensemble, founded 17 years ago, performs only music that is no more than a decade old — which means, at this point, pieces composed in the 21st century. Another is that the group does not provide program notes, on the theory that listeners are better off focusing on these works without preconceptions.

headline: After Taking Libya Town, Rebels Hope End Is Near

headline: This Sunday: The Dirtiest Pictures
text: There are many things to like in this week’s issue — Gerry Marzorati’s cover story on tennis rivalries, the wonderful impersonations of tennis greats by Andy Samberg, Bill Keller’s final column for the magazine and Jon Gertner’s examination of Obama’s “stealth industrial policy.” But the one that I want to especially direct your attention to is the Look feature. I hope that you’re familiar with the section. In the print magazine, it’s three pages toward the back, a single opener with a small picture and a bit of text, then a giant spread of a single image. Sometimes, on our Web site, we show more pictures that didn’t make the cut, as we do this week with the joyous, mud-drenched photographs by Peter Bohler of a Polish music festival based on Woodstock. Take some time to flip through the entire slideshow — it’s incredible fun. And then scroll down to see pictures from each of the Look features we’ve run since the section made its debut in March. It’s a great display of the talents of our photographers and the dedicated editors who work with them.

headline: Netherlands Juniors Win Gold
text: OPATIJA, Croatia — The winner of the gold medal in the Knockout Teams at the second World Youth Congress here on Friday was Netherlands Juniors. In the 56-board final against Argentina-Uruguay, the Dutch team never trailed. In the first three quarters the Europeans gained a total of 71 international match points, more than enough when the fourth quarter’s boards were very quiet. The final score was 145 imps to 68.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Photos
text: An optimistic economic forecast but no new stimulus from the Federal Reserve chairman; failed hip replacements; addressing food safety; preparing for a hurricane on the East Coast and more.

headline: App Makers Like the Sound of Googorola
text: What do app developers think of Google’s union with Motorola? Boink.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: Cities shuddered. Foreign regimes teetered. A hurricane loomed.

headline: Your Hurricane Stories
text: If you’re near the path of Hurricane Irene, we’d like to know what you’re seeing and hearing. Where are you riding out the storm? Does your neighborhood have power? Have you witnessed any damage so far? Tell us your stories using the the comments below this post. You can also send us your photos.

headline: A Jenny Jones Moment for Reality TV?
text: THE media mogul and I had swapped summer vacation stories and talked euphemistically about our own companies’ “challenges.” But then, at an off-the-record lunch last week, he suddenly changed the topic. He brought up reality television — specifically, the garish sort of reality exemplified by Bravo’s “Real Housewives” steamroller. Days earlier, one of the cast members of the Beverly Hills “Housewives” series, Russell Armstrong, had committed suicide.

headline: Fascinated by Threads and by Strings
text: IT’S hard to look at Joe Zee, the gregarious and overscheduled creative director of Elle magazine and the tough-love dispenser on the reality series “All on the Line,” and imagine him 30 years ago, growing up in Toronto as “a classic, textbook overachieving Asian kid.”

headline: Apple’s New Chief Gets a Million Shares
text: It was a good week for Timothy D. Cook.

headline: An Inner Life: The Secrecy Chronicles
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Chelsea, Determining Plans to Evacuate
text: Phyllis Gonzalez, 64, the president of the tenants association at the Elliott-Chelsea Houses, a public housing facility of 13 buildings between Ninth and 10th Avenues and 25th and 27th Streets, had been talking to residents all day, making sure they had supplies and knew what to do if the storm got worse.

headline: Looking for Leonardo, With Camera in Hand
text: FLORENCE — For decades scholars have labored to find a lost masterpiece by Leonardo da Vinci, believed by many to be hidden behind a fresco by Giorgio Vasari in the Palazzo Vecchio here. Now — thanks to an unusual marriage of art history and nuclear physics, partly arranged by an unassuming freelance photographer — the quest may soon be over.

headline: In Search of a Lost Leonardo
text: For decades some scholars have hoped to reveal a Leonardo mural hidden behind another fresco in Florence. Now the quest may soon be over.

headline: A School for Actors in Ireland
text: DUBLIN — Danielle Ryan found herself debating a question with her father several years ago when she was back home here on vacation: Why didn’t Ireland, with its rich theatrical bloodlines and population of six million people, have an acting school on a par with the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London, where she and other promising Irish artists had migrated to train in recent decades?

headline: Facing Floundering Distress With Stoicism
text: St. Vincent ended her concert at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night with an emotionally complicated plea. “Best, finest surgeon,” she sang coolly, fingers skittering along the neck of her guitar. “Come cut me open.”

headline: Keep the Webb Telescope, 32 Nobel Laureates Say
text: To the Editor:

headline: Half of America Is Using Social Networks
text: Social networks have crossed another milestone.

headline: Odysseus Is Parading Into Queens
text: Sing in me, Muse, and through me tell the story of Hermes the winged messenger, with eyes like binoculars. Of wise old Robert Moses, his head a literal globe, and of Typhoid Mary, a health threat in a skirt made of spoons.

headline: Investing in Ports, With an Eye to America’s Prosperity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Empowering Medicare
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jeanette Ingberman, a Founder of Exit Art, Dies at 59
text: Jeanette Ingberman, a founder of the New York cultural center Exit Art, which for three decades has been a hotbed of avant-garde work by artists from around the world, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: A Standard for Brokers
text: To the Editor:

text: More Photographs

headline: A Poll Tax by Another Name
text: Washington

headline: The Plastic Sandwich Bag Flunks
text: Many retailers and schools are advocating waste-free options for back-to-school shoppers this year, especially when it comes to lunch. School lists call for Tupperware instead of Ziplocs, neoprene lunch bags instead of brown paper ones, and aluminum water bottles, not the throwaway plastic versions.

headline: Unrest Builds as India Adds a Slowing Economy to Its Corruption Woes
text: MUMBAI, India — For much of the last month, India has been gripped by a raging public debate about how to tackle corruption, which is seen by many here as the country’s most important challenge. But a slowing economy may soon overtake corruption as a more pressing problem.

headline: Obama Declares State of Emergency for New York
text: President Obama declared a state of emergency for New York State about 5 p.m. on Friday in anticipation of Hurricane Irene, a Category 2 storm, making landfall on the East Coast. Philip E. Parr, a former member of the New York City Fire Department and former federal coordinator for relief efforts after Hurricane Katrina, was named the coordinating officer.

headline: Coping With 9/11, Riding on Two Wheels
text: It’s hard to remember now, but in the days after the attacks of 9/11, a back-to-basics sort of thing took hold in New York. People returned to out-of-favor practices like checking up on neighbors, talking to strangers, using courtesy and concern as their default modes rather than snark and indifference.

headline: Germans Start to Question Their Economic Resilience
George Hendry, a Young and Old Table Tennis Master, Dies at 90
text: Call George Hendry the comeback kid.

headline: Bloggingheads: Has Apple Peaked?
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Philip Elmer-DeWitt of Apple 2.0 debate Apple Inc.'s future.

headline: There’s One on Every Corner, but None Like This
text: SEATTLE — The sun is not yet up but the baristas are, a blur of busy hands wiping down counters and smoothing black aprons. Chipper and precise, they work at Starbucks, but it is probably not like the one near where you live. Among the 17,000 Starbucks that caffeinate the planet, this one is special.

headline: Stories of 9/11 and Its Aftermath
text: NEXT month’s 10th anniversary of 9/11 has inspired a dozen or more collections of heart-breaking reminiscences by New Yorkers who survived the attack and then endured a decade of denial, doubt and rebuilding. Here is a sampling:

headline: Britain Goes Nimby
text: LONDON

headline: A Teenage Killer, Now 51, Recounting His Crime
text: The 16-year-old boy had settled on a plan on how to kill his girlfriend. There was a blighted section on the north shore of Staten Island called Port Ivory, overgrown coastline facing the industrial banks of New Jersey. The land was pocked with holes leading to small underground rooms, like bunkers.

headline: Appetite for Racing, and for Winning
text: When the greatest champion of any sport comes to town, it seems like a good idea to take a look at him up close.

headline: A Dog at the Funeral Captured on Video
text: A video of a dog apparently mourning the death of his owner at a funeral has gone viral, prompting an outpouring from viewers around the world.

headline: Big City Book Club
text: From Herman Melville’s “Bartleby, the Scrivener” to Tom Wolfe’s “Bonfire of the Vanities,” New York has been a compelling character in American letters. The Big City Book Club intends to generate lively online discussion of works — classic and current, obvious and obscure, fictional and non — that centrally feature the city.

headline: Tracking the Euro Zone’s Crisis
text: The latest economic and policy developments from countries in the euro zone.

headline: Teaching Psychiatric Patients Writing, and Hope
text: Wearing her clerical collar and lugging a tote bag of supplies, the Rev. Bonnie McDougall Olson strode down the halls of Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens. She was due, moments later, to conduct a weekly writing workshop for three patients. It was the means for her mission, a way of bringing grace and mercy to the broken.

headline: As Suspensions Add Up, Luster Is Leaving a College Football Showcase
text: As an off-season of relentless scandal inundated college football, coaches and university administrators repeated the mantra that they could not wait for the season to start.

headline: Apple Ends Its TV Episode Rental Service
text: Nearly a year after Apple persuaded the television networks to try out a television episode rental service through its iTunes store, it has quietly taken the service down. Customers, it seems, did not want to rent TV episodes through an online store.

headline: Living for the Nighttime
text: Hard rocker, founding partner of the club Santos Party House in Manhattan and host of the Cartoon Network show “Destroy Build Destroy,” Andrew W. K., 32, spends most of his days doing what comes naturally: hiding from the sun. On Sundays, though, he likes venturing out from his apartment in Midtown Manhattan to nearby restaurants with his wife, Cherie Lily, a fitness instructor, dancer and singer. He also likes making music in their home studio, reading mind-blowing books and, invariably, staying up until dawn.

headline: Mr. Bernanke’s Warning
text: It’s what journalists call burying the lead. More than halfway through his speech on Friday to central bankers meeting in Jackson Hole, Ben Bernanke said the recession would not cause lasting damage to the economy “if — and I stress if — our country takes the necessary steps to secure that outcome.”

headline: Top Basketball Recruit Is Headed to UConn
text: With one Twitter message Friday night, the Connecticut men’s basketball team’s chances to repeat as national champions increased exponentially.

headline: The Sisterhood of Netball
text: ANDREA KIDD often gets puzzled looks when she tells people she spends her summer weekends playing netball.

headline: What Did They Really See?
text: In a landmark decision this week, the New Jersey Supreme Court set new guidelines for how courts and juries must assess eyewitness identification of criminal suspects. The laudable decision applies only in New Jersey but could have a national impact. It provides a thorough, science-based explanation of how eyewitness evidence can become tainted and offers a judicious template for the United States Supreme Court and other states to follow.

headline: As Qaddafi Forces Retreat, a Newly Freed Imam Encourages Forgiveness
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Like many Libyans, Sheik Abdul Ghani Aboughreis had reason to feel bitterness toward supporters of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi as he led the first Friday Prayer service since rebels flooded into the city here.

headline: Strip Club ‘Pole Tax’ Is Upheld in Texas
text: HOUSTON — The Texas Supreme Court ruled Friday that the state’s “pole tax” — a $5-per-customer fee that strip clubs that serve alcohol are required to pay the state — did not violate the clubs’ free-speech rights, overturning a lower court decision that declared the fee unconstitutional.

headline: Case of 8,000 Menacing Posts Tests Limits of Twitter Speech
text: Even the Buddha of compassion might have been distressed to be on the receiving end of the diatribes that William Lawrence Cassidy is accused of posting on Twitter.

headline: An Outdoor Exhibition of Cow-Proof Art
text: GARRISON, N.Y.

headline: Evacuation of City’s Low-Lying Areas Begins Ahead of Storm
text: As she and other customers picked the shelves bare on Friday afternoon at a supermarket in Breezy Point, Queens, Jackie Fede said she planned to abide by the official order to evacuate before Hurricane Irene hit. But she had yet to convince her mother to go.

headline: Relief for Student Debtors
text: Since the start of the recession, record numbers of Americans have enrolled in college in search of new skills that would improve their employment prospects. Unfortunately, far too many students enrolled in expensive for-profit schools end up dogged by ruinous debts, with little in the way of skills or credentials to show for their efforts.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Going to the Videotape
text: Last year, the United States Supreme Court blocked the broadcasting of the nonjury civil trial on the constitutionality of Proposition 8, California’s voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage. That August, the measure was struck down by Judge Vaughn Walker of Federal District Court, who presided at the trial. The case is pending appeal.

headline: With Williams Sisters as Model, Prospect Tries to Find Her Way
text: The scene in Flushing was familiar: a female African-American player with a loud, aggressive playing style attracting a large crowd, which included Richard Williams in the third row. She pumped her fist and let out a “Come on! Let’s go!” with each hard-fought winner.

headline: Tracing the Legacy of a Controversial Master Builder
text: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.

headline: Obama’s Non-Doctrine Doctrine
text: With the stock market gyrating, the Atlantic churning and D.S.K. walking free, it was easy to miss what some are calling a turning point in American foreign policy: the fall of Libya’s Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Thing is, no one can agree on what exactly that turning point represents.

headline: This Storm, Bloomberg Responds Differently
text: Around 8 a.m. on Friday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg received this startling piece of meteorological data: Instead of hitting New York at 3 a.m. on Sunday, as forecasters had predicted, Hurricane Irene was expected to strike six hours ahead of schedule, at 9 p.m. on Saturday.

headline: What Makes Steve Jobs Great
text: “I think I have five more great products in me,” Steve Jobs said a very long time ago.

headline: Podcast: Bernanke, the Budget and Steve Jobs
text: Ben Bernanke’s speech at Jackson Hole, Wyo., was sketchier than it might have been about monetary policy but strikingly detailed about fiscal policy.

headline: Teams Run for Cover as Irene Approaches; Jets-Giants Postponed
text: Weekends and sports are about as American as apple pie, except when extreme weather gets in the way.

headline: Out of Position in a Play Inside a Play
text: All three characters in “The Understudy” have taken jobs they normally wouldn’t. The stage manager of the play-within-a-play is an actress reduced to working backstage. The title character is an actor too good to be anybody’s standby. The action-movie star is slumming by doing a Broadway play. The question is which one we care about most.

headline: A Secret Parisian Picnic, Where Romance Reigned
text: “In about five minutes, I’ll have an even better story for you,” a man whispered to Nocturnalist on Thursday night as we stood in a sea of about 1,800 people all clad in white evening wear. They were dining al fresco on the edge of the Hudson River in Battery Park City.

headline: Failing Forward
text: Sometimes I push back on my heels, look at this country and wonder aloud: “What on earth are we doing?”

headline: As Trade Volumes Soar, Exchanges Cash In
text: The latest financial market convulsions have been tough for almost everyone, including traders caught on the wrong side of another big swing and pained everyday investors watching their dwindling holdings go down and up — and down again.

headline: Lottery Numbers
South African Goes From Never a Sip to Vineyard Fame
text: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa — When Ntsiki Biyela won a winemaking scholarship in 1998, she was certainly a curious choice. She had grown up in the undulating hills of Zululand, living in a small village of huts and shacks. People tended their patches of pumpkins and corn. The only alcohol they drank was homemade beer, a malt-fed brew that bubbled in old pots.

headline: Saturday: Like Bending Over Backward
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, that’s an interesting way to start off a crossword puzzle. I’m sure you know what I’m talking about, Ashton Anderson. I’m talking about 1 Across, which also happens to be making its debut today. And how accidental could it be that X-RATED is right there, dangling, so to speak, from that SEXCAPADE that started us off? This is The New York Times, for goodness’s sake. You should be ashamed of yourself.

headline: Populism, Technology and Interactivity
text: Make no mistake: Grounds for Sculpture, the 42-acre public sculpture park in Hamilton, aims to be populist. Its mission, according to the organization’s Web site, is to “promote an understanding of and appreciation for contemporary sculpture for all people.”

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Battle for Libya | August 26, 2011
text: Rebels investigated the Abu Salim Prison, and dozens of bodies were piled up in an abandoned hospital in Tripoli.

headline: With All Eyes on Weather, Capuano Fires Strike After Strike Past the Braves
text: The Mets did not have long to savor their 6-0 win over the Atlanta Braves on Friday, which featured a nearly flawless outing from starter Chris Capuano. Some players had to worry about where they would be sleeping this weekend.

headline: China: North Korean Leader Repeats Offer for Nuclear Talks
text: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, reiterated Friday that he would return to the so-called six-party talks on his country’s nuclear program with no preconditions, Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency, reported. Mr. Kim made his remarks in Heilongjiang Province, which borders North Korea, after meeting with the Russian president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, in Siberia on Wednesday, where he first offered to return to the talks. The United States, a leader in the talks, has expressed skepticism over the use of holding more of them. In China, Mr. Kim met with Dai Bingguo, the senior foreign policy official.

headline: A Taste of Colombia
text: You can get terrific brownies at Brownie Restaurante y Panaderia — rich and dense, with a thick coating of chocolate icing — but that’s not the best reason to visit this Colombian restaurant and bakery in White Plains.

headline: The Subtle Complexities of a Kitchen Standby
text: “THIS one comes from California and has hints of strawberry,” the server said. “This one is more floral. And this one is the most complex. It has layers of almond with an artichoke finish.”

headline: A White With Clout
text: A white made on Long Island from Finger Lakes grapes, Martha Clara Vineyards’ medium-dry 2010 riesling ($19.99), was voted the state’s best wine in the New York Wine and Food Classic this month.

headline: Unabashedly, and Exclusively, Thai
text: THE restaurant Frankly Thai in Franklin Square is aptly named, describing the kind of place it is and is not. It is not Asian fusion or Pan-Asian; General Tso’s chicken is not on the menu; and there is no sushi bar in the corner. This year-old storefront is unabashedly Thai and only Thai.

headline: New Jersey Ruling on Witnesses May Prod New York to Change
text: Although a New Jersey Supreme Court decision this week that set new rules for witness identification procedures in criminal cases does not directly affect New York City, some legal analysts and officials say it may quicken the pace of possible changes the city is now studying.

headline: Schedule Is Shifted, but Not to Yankees’ Liking
text: BALTIMORE — With Hurricane Irene bearing down and a state of emergency already declared here, the Baltimore Orioles rejected a proposal by the Yankees to play their scheduled doubleheader Friday instead of Saturday, leaving the Yankees frustrated by what they saw as the Orioles’ intransigence.

headline: The Death of Joe Hill
text: Joe Hill, a songwriter and labor activist, was executed in 1915 after being convicted of murder.

headline: Libyan War Goes a Long Way to Improve the Pentagon’s View of France as an Ally
text: WASHINGTON — Eight years ago the French were called the “cheese-eating surrender monkeys” who opposed the Iraq war. They inspired “freedom fries” and jokes meant to boost American military morale. “Have you heard about the new French tank?” a United States Marine commander asked his men in Kuwait in March 2003, only days before his unit crossed the border into Iraq. “It’s got six gears — all in reverse.”

headline: Turkey: Plot Suspects Are Charged
text: After more than five months in jail, 12 suspects, including 2 prominent journalists, were formally charged Friday with supporting a terrorist network accused of plotting a coup, the semiofficial Anatolian news agency reported. The journalists, Nedim Sener and Ahmet Sik, both vocal critics of the governing Justice and Development Party who were also known for opposing a coup, were arrested in March without charges, because of prosecutors’ fears that they might flee. Media freedom advocates have protested the detentions, which they said were aimed at silencing government opponents, an allegation the governing party denied.

headline: Sweet Treats, European-Style
text: Volta Gelateria Creperia is no run-of-the-mill ice cream shop. It is, rather, a European-style cafe, with plenty of outdoor seating, its white marble tables shaded by large striped umbrellas.

headline: The World This Week
text: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

headline: Small-Plate Italian, in a Lively Setting
text: THERE is much to like at Zaza, a restaurant and bar in downtown Stamford: great variety on the menu, an upbeat staff, moderate prices and a perfect location for business lunches, after-work drinks and tapas or a full meal in lively surroundings.

headline: France: Paris Project Is Approved
text: The government has approved plans for a $30 billion public works project dubbed “Le Grand Paris,” which President Nicolas Sarkozy hopes will prove a durable legacy of his leadership. The project, whose approval was noted in an official decree published Friday, will include the construction of more than 100 miles of automatic subway lines and 57 new stations, linking the suburbs around Paris in a massive figure 8. Mr. Sarkozy had aspired to remake the capital and solicited proposals from renowned architects, who offered extravagant visions of airborne parks, expansive greenery and futuristic towers. But his ambitions ran up against political and financial limits. The first new subways are planned to be in operation by 2018, according to the Société du Grand Paris, the state authority in charge of the project.

headline: For Wozniacki, a Win and a Kiss From McIlroy
text: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — The world’s No. 1 player, Caroline Wozniacki, may end up being one of the favorites at the United States Open after all. As some players hunkered down in New York City to stay safe from Hurricane Irene, Wozniacki was at the New Haven Open at Yale, hoping to win her first tour title since April.

headline: Call it Mexi-Cali-Jersey
text: The sign above the door reads, “10th Ave. Burrito Co. — Mexi-Cali Cuisine,” which is both misleading and informative. The restaurant is no longer on 10th Avenue in Belmar, having moved in 2009 to a larger space in Belmar Plaza, where the bright yellow dining room is decorated with works by local artists and a television showing films of lucha libre, freestyle wrestling.

headline: Classic Vietnamese, Where the Pho Reigns
text: ONE of the first things you notice at Simply Vietnamese, a bustling storefront spot in Tenafly, is the high chopstick-to-fork ratio among the diners. That’s an excellent omen. It’s a polyglot crowd — young and old, families and couples, and at least half Asian on several recent visits — and everyone seems comfortably familiar with the task at hand.

headline: Examining a Labor Hero’s Death
text: At Woodstock, Joan Baez sang a famous folk ballad celebrating Joe Hill, the itinerant miner, songwriter and union activist who was executed by a Utah firing squad in 1915. “I never died, said he” is the song’s refrain.

headline: Star Scientific Loses Bid for Patent Royalties
text: Star Scientific, a maker of tobacco products, lost a bid for a new trial in its decade-long effort to extract patent royalties from Reynolds American on a way to reduce carcinogens in cigarettes. Losing the bid set off a 40 percent decline in its share price Friday. While the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington today upheld the validity of two Star patents, the panel said there was no need to retry the infringement case against Reynolds that Star lost in 2009. Judge Randall Rader said in the 2-to-1 opinion that a new trial would not change the outcome as “there was substantial untainted evidence before the jury to support a verdict of noninfringement.” The patents cover a curing process that prevents “bacterial activity” in tobacco leaves, resulting in the lowest levels of cancer-causing nitrosamines, according to Star. Stock in the company, which is based in Glen Allen, Va., fell $1.19, or nearly 40 percent, to $1.81 a share.

headline: Stopping Trains, to Store Them Safely
text: What does it take to shut down the nation’s largest mass transit network? Hundreds of workers, dozens of exotic maintenance vehicles, and at least eight hours of preparation will be required to do all manner of tasks, including storing subway trains in underground caverns and securing the wooden gates on grade-level crossings in Long Island.

headline: One Lost Day Follows Another
text: BALTIMORE — In the wake of another disastrous outing by A. J. Burnett on Friday night, and with a compressed schedule of games coming up because of Hurricane Irene, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was asked if Burnett would still make his next scheduled start against the hard-hitting Boston Red Sox next week.

headline: Corrections: August 27
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: 30 Seconds: Kirk Herbstreit’s Heart Stays in Columbus
text: Kirk Herbstreit, a former Ohio State quarterback and captain, recently made headlines when he announced that, amid a scandal rocking the Buckeyes’ football program, he and his family would move from their longtime home in Columbus, Ohio, to Nashville.

headline: Assault Case Spurs Debate, but Sharpton Stays Silent
text: In the three months that the city and a good portion of the world buzzed about the hotel housekeeper and the French man of power, voices big and small spoke up for one side or the other, or simply urged that justice be found in a courtroom. There were news conferences, rallies, protests, cable-TV exhortations.

headline: China: U.S. Report Denounced
text: Chinese defense officials denounced Friday a Pentagon report that called China’s military buildup “potentially destabilizing,” Xinhua reported. The Pentagon report, released Wednesday, asserted that China’s military modernization could lead to regional tensions and instability. “The report does not hold water as it severely distorted the facts,” a Chinese Defense Ministry spokesman, Yang Yujun, said in a statement. He added, “China unswervingly adheres to the path of peaceful development, and its national defense policy is defensive in nature.”

headline: Conviction of Bonds on Obstruction Charge Is Upheld by Judge
text: A federal judge in San Francisco on Friday denied Barry Bonds’s request to drop his obstruction of justice conviction, upholding that jury verdict and also rejecting Bonds’s request for a new trial on that charge.

headline: Hurricane Irene – The Endgame
text: The National Hurricane Center’s final 3-day projected track for Hurricane Irene keeps the powerful storm centered on the populous metropolitan corridor from the suburbs of Washington, D.C., through New York City — showing the storm still maintaining hurricane strength as it approaches the New York coastline. The track is very similar to that of Hurricane Floyd in 1999, except that storm weakened to a tropical storm before reaching New York.

headline: Introducing ... the Bucketeers
text: Some of the members of the Red Bucket Films collective.

headline: Readers’ Photos of Hurricane Irene
text: Times readers submitted their photos of early evacuations, storm scenes and damage.

headline: Top Recruit Drummond Is Headed to Connecticut
text: Andre Drummond, considered the top big-man prospect in the country, announced Friday on Twitter that he would be playing for defending national champion Connecticut next season. Drummond had originally planned to attend prep school at Wilbraham & Monson Academy in Massachusetts next year. Drummond, a 6-foot 10-inch, 275-pound center, will head to Connecticut for what is expected to be a one-year stay. He joins Jeremy Lamb, the breakout star of last year’s N.C.A.A. tournament, and the star forward Alex Oriakhi.

headline: When Tennis Was Golden, or Was It?
text: Seen through the haze of history, the golden age of modern professional tennis emerged between 1980 and 1990, when rivalries and racket sales signaled a surge of worldwide interest and affection for the sport.

headline: New to English
text: Students learning English, labeled as English Language Learners by education officials, are among the nation’s fastest-growing group of students.

headline: The Driest Place on Earth
text: Quillagua in northern Chile is an oasis town whose population has shrunk as its water supply dwindled.

headline: For Students Learning English, a World Apart
text: At Cecil D. Hylton High School in Woodbridge, Va., which has seen a tremendous influx in immigrants, students in a program specifically tailored to non-English speakers rarely interact with other students at the school.

headline: ‘Dreamgirls’ in South Korea
text: An American producer has gone to Seoul to develop and stage a new version of the hit musical.

headline: The Art on the Library Walls
text: A foundation has built colorful new libraries in public schools, luring well-known artists and illustrators to create works for their walls.

headline: Taking the Impossible Photograph
text: David Yoder is not an art historian. Nor is he a physicist. “In fact,” Mr. Yoder said, “I’m positive I would have failed any physics course.”

headline: 2011 Baltimore Ravens Season Preview
text: Andy Benoit is previewing all 32 N.F.L. teams. Next up: The Ravens.

headline: Damage and Flooding Scar Atlantic Seaboard
text: This article was reported by   Kim Severson,  Dan Barry and  Campbell Robertson and was written by Mr. Barry.

headline: Updates on Hurricane Irene
text: On Saturday and Sunday, The Lede tracked the impact of Hurricane Irene as it swept north.

headline: A Break on Your MetroCard Because of the Storm? M.T.A. Says No
text: It may not be the first question on the minds of New Yorkers as Hurricane Irene moves into the region on Saturday. But judging from Twitter and e-mails from readers, many cannot help but wonder:

headline: Homeless World Cup: Soccer, Statistics and Social Change
text: 1:10 p.m. | Updated On Sunday, Scotland defeated Mexico, 4-3, to win the men’s title and Kenya beat Mexico by the same score to win the women’s crown in Paris.

headline: Leaving Red Hook, or Moving to Higher Ground, Vinyl and All
text: In Red Hook, Brooklyn, Saturday morning, sidewalks and parks were lined with dogs enjoying their last walks before the evacuation. Three boys finished a game of handball on King Street before returning indoors. Cars rolled slowly past a bus stop on Dwight Street, which still bore an advertisement from the spring: “Judgment Day,” it read. “May 21, 2011.”

headline: Alas, Babylon Line
text: I see that Nassau County, Long Island south of Sunrise Highway is being evacuated. That’s my homeland! In Merrick, Sunrise was the big east-west drag, with the Babylon Line of the Long Island Railroad running alongside. Our house was around a mile south of there, although it’s gone now, replaced with a McMansion. Anyway, given the canals running through that area, I can easily see how it might end up underwater.

headline: Texas A&M Close to Leaving Big 12
text: Texas A&M’s time as a member of the Big 12 is all but over. In a conference call Saturday that included the Big 12’s university presidents, R. Bowen Loftin, the president of Texas A&M, essentially said that the Aggies were leaving, and there was nothing the Big 12 could do to keep them, according to a person with first-hand knowledge of the call.

headline: Japanese Island’s Activists Resist Nuclear Industry’s Allure
text: IWAISHIMA, Japan — When the boats came to start work on a planned nuclear power plant just off this tiny island, an aging fisherwoman named Tamiko Takebayashi carried out a dramatic protest: she lashed herself to the dock.

headline: 2011 Preview: In Big Ten, Change, and One Constant

headline: Eli Manning and Giants Roll With the Storms
text: Eli Manning grew up in the South, playing high school football in Louisiana before going to college at Ole Miss, so dealing with severe weather is not new to him.

headline: Readers and Unemployment
text: As my Sunday column appears, I’ll be in transit to Libya, insha’allah. But this column grew out of my family vacation this summer back in Yamhill, Oregon, where I grew up. Like everyone in journalism, I had been focused on the debt ceiling debates, but what I saw in Yamhill was a different economic scourge: unemployment. It really puzzles me that 25 million Americans could be unemployed or under-employed, and yet the issue has never really gotten much traction. In the last month or two, it has gained more visibility and President Obama says he is pivoting to jobs — but none of the proposals on the agenda come close to matching the severity of the unemployment picture.

headline: Sunday: Pardon “E” Interruption
text: Administrivial Vacation Alert: Barring any weather complications, I will be on vacation starting Sunday, August 28 and will be back with the Monday, September 5 post. Fear not, however, because in my absence Wordplay will be written and steered by the very able and extremely brave Thomas Gaffney. Tom is a New York Times news assistant and is an excellent solver with a terrific point of view. I hope you will all welcome him. Please be gentle.

headline: Hurricanes and Climate Change
text: I have a short piece going into Sunday’s paper on the question of whether hurricanes are getting stronger because of climate change. In it, I outline the views of Kerry Emanuel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who takes the position that they are, and Thomas R. Knutson of the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory, who believes it would be premature to conclude they are getting stronger over a long stretch of time.

headline: Price Berkley, Founder and Longtime Publisher of Theatrical Index, Dies at 92
text: Price Berkley, the founder, editor and longtime publisher of Theatrical Index, the weekly trade publication that for nearly half a century has been consulted by anyone wanting to produce, finance, write about or possibly avoid a Broadway show, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Think You Own Your House? Check the Deed

But for all her financial expertise, Ms. Neely was unprepared when she learned that the name of a deceased cleric from an obscure Islamic sect was on a deed claiming he and his temple owned the Kenwood home she had lived in since 2002.

headline: Private-Sector Jobs Are a Major Factor in Employment Growth

headline: Out of Jail and Onto the Street, Alone, in the Wee Hours
text: It was 1 a.m. when Acy Williams, a slight, 53-year-old homeless man, walked out of the Harris County Jail and onto the dark, desolate streets of downtown Houston. He wore plastic flip-flops, dingy scrubs and a black fedora. He had no money and no phone, and the Houston Metro buses ran infrequently at that late hour. He decided he would just have to walk several miles across the city to the spot in South Houston where he hoped his belongings were still safely stowed.

The boys in blue tingled with nervous excitement as they slung their overstuffed knapsacks across their backs and boarded a train that would carry them from Lynnfield to Boston on the first leg of their trip to the South.

headline: Nadal Enters Open in Djokovic’s Shadow

headline: Two Big Tournaments in the Two Biggest Cities
text: The biggest tournaments in the United States are usually held in places like Philadelphia and Las Vegas, not New York and Los Angeles. The reasons are cost (rents for tournament sites are higher in New York and Los Angeles) and convenience (inland tournaments tend to be easier to get to).

Uncle Mo, last year’s 2-year-old champion, had run his heart out every step of the way for seven furlongs and was a stride away from punctuating a triumphant comeback with a victory in the King’s Bishop on Saturday. Repole was ready to hug his grandmother, Assunta; his mother, Annie; and his wife, Maria, all of whom were surrounding him in his box.

headline: Outside of Berlin, Bauhaus-Themed Fun
text: In the decade or so before the Nazis came to power in Germany, the Bauhaus school was known for its groundbreaking modern art, architecture and design — and its terrific parties. In fact, Walter Gropius, the Bauhaus founder, decreed that wild theme parties — where students and professors would dress up, recite poetry, show what they were working on, and generally have a good time — were to be part of the curriculum. These days, a version of those parties, called Farbfest, held at the Bauhaus building in Dessau, about an hour and a half outside of Berlin, are back. This year’s festivities will be on Sept. 2 and 3.

headline: Live Blog: As Irene Passes, City Exhales

headline: Recovery Is Slower in New York Suburbs
text: Tropical Storm Irene swept through the desolate streets of New York on Sunday, flooding low-lying areas and leaving millions of homes without power along the Eastern Seaboard as it continued on to New England. Most New Yorkers emerged from their makeshift bunkers to find little of the widespread devastation the authorities had feared.

headline: Could the N.B.A. Invade the U.S. Open?
text: With the N.B.A. lockout opening up the possibility that there will be no 2011-12 season, many of the world’s greatest athletes are looking at some extended unemployment. This has led to some players, like Deron Williams of the Nets, agreeing to play abroad. More interestingly, some have begun to look into other careers that suit their skill sets, with Kevin Love of the Timberwolves choosing beach volleyball.

headline: Boston Symphony Orchestra Performance Is Canceled
text: The Boston Symphony Orchestra has canceled its performance of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony scheduled for Sunday afternoon at the Tanglewood Festival in Lenox, Mass., because of the approach of Hurricane Irene. The performance of the Ninth Symphony, which traditionally ends the orchestra’s season at the festival, was to have been conducted by Lorin Maazel. All other Tanglewood events scheduled for Sunday have also been canceled, but the Tanglewood Jazz Festival is still scheduled to run from Thursday to next Sunday. The orchestra says that this is the first time it has canceled a concert in its 75-year residence at Tanglewood, despite occasionally heavy weather in the surrounding Berkshire Hills. Refunds will be available. Information can be found online or, as of Monday, at (617) 638-9395.

headline: Life in a Storm Shelter in Brooklyn

headline: New Movies Struggle Amid Hurricane Irene
text: Three new releases with dim box-office prospects going into the weekend were additionally pummeled by Hurricane Irene, which shuttered theaters in the all-important East Coast movie market. “The Help” (DreamWorks Studios) repeated as No. 1 for a third weekend, taking in an estimated $14.3 million for a new domestic total of $96.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.“Colombiana” (TriStar) performed the best of the three newcomers, placing second with about $10 million in ticket sales, a total that its distributor positioned as “better than expected.” Third place went to “Don’t Be Afraid of the Dark,” which took in about $8.7 million; Film District notably marketed this thriller on the back of Guillermo del Toro, one of its writers and producers (and a type of fanboy pied piper for his “Hellboy” series.)

headline: Doubles Standouts Talk About Culture and Collaboration
text: Vania King, Sania Mirza and Aisam-ul-Haq Qureshi, three of the best doubles players in the world, participated in a roundtable discussion about tennis and culture on Friday in front of more than 50 New York Times staffers. King, 22, a Taiwanese-American from Monterey Park, Calif., and Boynton Beach, Fla., is the defending doubles champion at the United States Open and winner of the Wimbledon doubles title in 2010. Qureshi, 31, of Lahore, Pakistan, reached the doubles finals of the U.S. Open last year, where he and Rohan Bopanna, of India, lost to Bob and Mike Bryan in two tiebreakers. Mirza, 24, who was born in Mumbai, India, and currently lives in Dubai, was a doubles finalist at the French Open this year.

headline: When is a Road Not a Road?
text: Answer: After a torrential deluge from a deteriorating hurricane.

headline: The Meaning of Utopia
text: The modern world was inaugurated by two books with opposing perspectives, published at the same time in the early years of the 16th century: Machiavelli’s “The Prince” and Thomas More’s “Utopia.” Modernity came to a close with the collapse of all those attempts, both collective and liberal, that had been made to bring utopia about in history. Here I should like to reflect on that beginning and that end, insofar as they involve the status of utopia.

headline: Irene Forces Mostly Mozart’s End, and Unfinished Works Are the Focus
text: You would not have guessed that it was the eve of Hurricane Irene weekend from the placid scene at Lincoln Center on Friday night. The weather was humid but mild; there were people buying gelato, tourists taking photos of the plaza and music lovers heading into Avery Fisher Hall for what was supposed to have been the next-to-last performance of this summer’s Mostly Mozart Festival, with Louis Langrée, the festival’s music director, conducting the festival orchestra in works by Stravinsky, Schubert and Mozart.

headline: Vettel Returns to Victory, at Belgian Grand Prix
text: SPA-FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium – Sebastian Vettel returned to the highest step of the podium for the first time in four races, as the German driver for the Red Bull team won the Belgian Grand Prix, driving from pole position to victory.

headline: A Young Scientist, Waiting for the Baboons to Do Something
text: On one side of the glass, an 11-year-old male hamadryas baboon sits on a miniature hillside. He sits some more. He sucks on his right hand, then cleans the toes on his right foot, which rests on an artificial rock.

headline: Turkish Leader Says He Has Lost Confidence in Assad

headline: Problems Building for Chinese Banks
text: China’s five biggest banks raised their combined earnings by 37 percent during the first half of 2011. Lending margins and fees rose, while bad debts fell. In a sign of flush times, some big banks are now even offering their best customers private jet services. Yet there is still plenty to worry about, and that explains why their shares have fallen roughly a quarter from this year’s peak.

headline: Gumshoe on Capital Asphalt

headline: How the Serve Went Over the Top
text: Imagine, in your mind’s eye, Serena Williams serving, facing break point. She toes the line, bounces the ball and takes a deep breath. She draws the racket back almost languidly, coils her body and vaults skyward, her legs driving the racket head at blinding speed as she clobbers an ace up the T at 120 miles an hour. The best server in the history of women’s tennis pumps her left fist and yells, “Come on!”

headline: Islamic Group Says It Was Behind Fatal Nigeria Attack

headline: Collegiate Chorale Announces Season
text: The Collegiate Chorale has announced its 2011-12 season, highlighted by a new production of Gilbert and Sullivan’s comic opera “The Mikado,” featuring the three-time Tony nominee Kelli O’Hara (“South Pacific,” “The Pajama Game,” “The Light in the Piazza”). Set to open in April, the operetta represents another direction for Ms. O’Hara, right; it will follow her already announced role as Regan in the Public Theater’s production of “King Lear.” The Chorale’s 70th anniversary season is also scheduled to include Rossini’s “Moïse et Pharaon” (Nov. 30) and “A Child of Our Time” by Michael Tippett paired with Bruckner’s “Te Deum” (Feb. 3). All three productions are to be performed at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Condé Nast Deepens Its Social Connections
text: Readers of the online versions of Condé Nast publications will have to look no further than the bottom of their screens to see what content other readers have deemed worthy of a “Tweet” on Twitter or a “like” on Facebook. And right below that social media will be a hefty dose of advertising.

headline: Tom Jones Cancels Concert
text: Tom Jones was recovering in a hospital in Monaco on Sunday and said that “severe dehydration” had forced him to cancel a concert, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Jones, below, apologized to his fans on his Web site and denied British press reports that a heart scare had forced the cancellation. “There are no heart problems, as has been reported in the press,” said a statement on the Web site. Mr. Jones, 71, blamed a long tour in which “many of the shows were in locations that were in the throes of high summer heat.” The Web site statement indicated that doctors had ordered him to cancel the show, which was to have been the end of his three-month “Praise & Blame” tour. A spokesman for the Princess Grace Hospital in Monaco told The A.P. that Mr. Jones was admitted on Saturday night and was doing well.

headline: Staying Focused
text: On Par columnist Bill Pennington gets a little too distracted while on the golf course.

headline: Mel Gibson Settles With Former Girlfriend
text: Whatever the peace settlement contains, the fight is over. At an unusually late hour — after 8 p.m. on Friday — Los Angeles County Superior Court disclosed in a statement that Mel Gibson and his ex-girlfriend Oksana Grigorieva had reached an agreement resolving the many issues between them. They had been engaged in an epic court battle over custody of their young daughter, and related financial matters. The fight involved claims of abuse by Mr. Gibson and of extortion by Ms. Grigorieva. But the court said there is a deal between the two, the terms of which will be reviewed at a hearing scheduled for 8:30 a.m. Wednesday in the courtroom of Judge Peter D. Lichtman. The court hears custody issues behind closed doors. But issues concerning the financial agreement between Mr. Gibson and Ms. Grigorieva will be reviewed in an open hearing, the court’s statement said.

headline: On Court 4, Intense Lessons in Competition
text: I returned to Flushing Meadows Friday planning to watch the later stages of the qualies, only to be informed that, avant le deluge, those scheduled to play second-round matches faced, should they win, a third match that same evening, and with it the possibility of playing as many as six hard-fought sets, split between two opponents, in one very long day. Then again, as one of the better tennis-playing literary men, Randall Jarrell (team captain at Vanderbilt in the 1930s) once observed, “the really damned not only like Hell, they feel loyal to it.”

headline: Anchor to Leave PBS’s ‘Need to Know’
text: PBS’s Friday newsmagazine “Need to Know” is losing Alison Stewart, the second of its original co-anchors to depart, when it switches to a half-hour format on Sept. 16.

headline: Sampras vs. Agassi, 2001: An Open Classic Endures
text: Ten years ago, nobody knew that American tennis was close to being broken. To make the case that the sport here was alive and kicking, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi played a quarterfinal match at the United States Open in which neither broke serve.

headline: Norwegian Team Squeaks Past American Players in Croatia
text: OPATIJA, Croatia — The Board-a-Match Teams at the second World Youth Congress ended here on Saturday evening. It came down to the final board, which was played simultaneously at all tables.

headline: Irene Adds to a Bad Year for Insurance Industry
text: The total damage inflicted by Hurricane Irene may reach $7 billion by the time the storm dissipates in the coming days, making one of the insurance industry’s worst years even tougher, according to an early estimate by the Kinetic Analysis Corporation in Silver Spring, Md.

headline: Keeping Score: Giving Foes the Runaround
text: In 2009, Ivo Karlovic served 78 aces against Radek Stepanek in a five-set Davis Cup semifinal to set a record for the most aces in a match. Karlovic lost.

headline: Photos of Hurricane Irene
text: Irene, now downgraded to a tropical storm, pushed into the New York area on Sunday, unleashing rain and wind on a city girded for the worst.

headline: Victorious Hunger Striker Shakes a Political Status Quo
text: NEW DELHI — For the nearly two weeks that Anna Hazare staged his hunger strike, the question hanging over India had been, “When would it end?” After Mr. Hazare triumphantly broke his fast on Sunday, a different question arose: “What now?”

headline: Masked Protesters Aid Time Warner’s Bottom Line
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Anonymous, the hacker group, has jostled with the Iranian government and the Church of Scientology and has briefly shut down the Web sites of Visa, MasterCard and other global corporations.

headline: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament
text: The Times’s tennis experts debated, and the results are in: readers chose Roger Federer and Steffi Graf as the greatest Open champions from the past 30 years.

headline: A Subtle Emotional Appeal to Luxury Travelers
text: DESPITE an unsettled economic climate, the Luxury Collection, an upscale brand of Starwood Hotels and Resorts, is updating its advertising to attract new guests.

headline: Serve and Return: Feeding the Masses at the Open
text: When you’re feeding 700,000 people in two weeks, you’re running a sizable food-service operation. When many of those people spend 10 or more hours on your premises, you’re feeding them a lot. When half of them are New Yorkers and much of the remaining half are people well-heeled enough to spend days at a time visiting and paying for not-cheap tickets, you have to try to feed them at least decently.

headline: A Map of Readers' Photos of Hurricane Irene
text: Times readers submitted their photos of early evacuations, storm scenes and damage.

headline: Public Relations a Concern as N.B.A. Millionaires Spar
text: N.B.A. players make a lot of money, but they spend a lot of money, and when times are tough, they might sell their luxury cars.

headline: In Unsettled Times, Media Can Be a Call to Action, or a Distraction
text: THE mass media, including interactive social-networking tools, make you passive, can sap your initiative, leave you content to watch the spectacle of life from your couch or smartphone.

headline: Product Placement Rises in Networks’ Telenovelas
text: Viewers who tuned in to watch the Telemundo telenovela “Mi Corazón Insiste” last week may have seen a new type of cliffhanger, one that directed them to a Web site with exclusive content sponsored by JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Airports Resume Service in Northeast, but Backups Could Persist for Days
text: Airlines haltingly began to resume some flights on Sunday in the northeastern United States after the destruction left by Hurricane Irene, but travelers still faced widespread cancellations into Monday and backups well into next week.

headline: Nepal Elects a Maoist as Prime Minister
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — The deeply fractured Parliament of Nepal elected a Maoist as the country’s new prime minister on Sunday, after weeks of efforts to form a national unity coalition proved fruitless.

headline: Not Just a Sport, but a Window to the Soul
text: It has been said a million times. You have probably heard it, too:

headline: Turkish Government to Return Seized Property to Religious Minorities
text: ANKARA, Turkey — The Turkish government said it would return hundreds of properties that were confiscated from religious minorities by the state or other parties over the years since 1936, and would pay compensation for properties that were seized and later sold.

headline: Teachers Get Little Say in a Book About Them
text: Can an education reform movement that demeans and trivializes teachers succeed? It’s hard to imagine, but that is what is going on in parts of America today.

headline: Profits Falling, Banks Confront a Leaner Future
text: Battered by a weak economy, the nation’s biggest banks are cutting jobs, consolidating businesses and scrambling for new sources of income in anticipation of a fundamentally altered financial landscape requiring leaner operations.

headline: In Pakistan, Court Moves to Punish Ex-President
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani court has ordered that former President Pervez Musharraf’s property be seized and his bank accounts frozen in connection with the legal case concerning the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.

headline: 28 Are Killed in Bombing at a Mosque in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber mounted a devastating attack in one of the largest Sunni mosques in Baghdad on Sunday, killing at least 28 people, including a member of Parliament, and wounding dozens more, according to security officials.

headline: A Fine Line on Foot Faults
text: In tennis, the thin white line runs underneath the server, out of sight but never out of mind. If the rubber toe of the server’s shoe so much as glances that line, the rest of the motion, the toss, the body contortions, the follow-through, no longer matter.

headline: When Roommates Were Random
text: EAGER to throw off my nerdy past and reinvent myself at college, I wrote “party animal” on my roommate application form where it asked incoming freshmen whether they wanted to bunk with a smoker or a non-smoker. When I told my mother about this later, she laughed and bought me a T-shirt that sported the image of Spuds MacKenzie, the 1980s Budweiser beer mascot, under the words “the original party animal.”

headline: Dangerous White Stereotypes
text: Davis, Calif.

headline: The Nation’s Cruelest Immigration Law
text: The Alabama Legislature opened its session on March 1 on a note of humility and compassion. In the Senate, a Christian pastor asked God to grant members “wisdom and discernment” to do what is right. “Not what’s right in their own eyes,” he said, “but what’s right according to your word.” Soon after, both houses passed, and the governor signed, the country’s cruelest, most unforgiving immigration law.

headline: Tripping Over Their Tongues at the Open
text: Lleyton Hewitt

headline: There Has to Be a Better Way to Grade Tests
text: A task force appointed by the New York State education commissioner, John King Jr., is to report next month on ways to improve the integrity of the state’s educational testing system. New York has thus far escaped cheating scandals like the one that exploded in Atlanta. But troubling new developments have shown weaknesses in New York’s testing system that need to be fixed.

headline: Didn’t They Learn Anything From Whitey Bulger?
text: Cutting deals with criminal informants may, at times, be a necessary if unsavory part of law enforcement. But the benefits must outweigh the costs, and it is not clear the F.B.I.’s Boston office has mastered that balance.

headline: ‘Independents’ Candidates Really Love
text: There was no little dog Toto to pull back the curtain, but the fiction was clear when the presidential candidate Mitt Romney dropped by an event run by a political “Super PAC” with the Oz-like name of Restore Our Future.

headline: Where Missing a Signal Can Result in a Trip to an Imaginary Morgue
text: Nick Feldaverd stood in the middle of a large parking lot the other day and, all of a sudden, threw his arms in the air. The motorcyclist who was headed in his direction, a trainee just learning to operate his bike, rolled past Mr. Feldaverd, a veteran instructor.

headline: American Theocracy Revisited
text: During George W. Bush’s presidency, many liberal and secular Americans came to regard religious conservatives not merely as their political opponents, but as a kind of existential threat. The religious right, they decided, wasn’t a normal political movement. Rather, it was an essentially illiberal force, bent on gradually replacing our secular republic with what Kevin Phillips’s 2006 best seller dubbed an “American Theocracy.”

headline: Republicans Against Science
text: Jon Huntsman Jr., a former Utah governor and ambassador to China, isn’t a serious contender for the Republican presidential nomination. And that’s too bad, because Mr. Hunstman has been willing to say the unsayable about the G.O.P. — namely, that it is becoming the “anti-science party.” This is an enormously important development. And it should terrify us.

headline: Jeter Scratched From Second Game of Doubleheader
text: BALTIMORE — Derek Jeter was scratched from the second game of Sunday’s doubleheader with a contusion of his right knee.

headline: Trying to Make Red Zone Sanchez’s Comfort Zone
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The best red-zone quarterback Trent Dilfer said he ever played with was Matt Hasselbeck, who on a weekly basis would conquer that chaotic, compressed and critical area inside the opposition’s 20 by flashing what Dilfer called the “brass of a burglar and the discretion of a doctor.” Hasselbeck would handle every snap believing that no defense could stop a perfect throw, Dilfer said, and if the coverage was tight, he felt no shame dumping a pass to his running back or tight end or tossing away the ball to avoid disaster.

headline: Enigmatic in Power, Qaddafi Is Elusive at Large
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — It was perhaps only fitting that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi would be as unpredictable on the lam as he was in power for 42 eccentric years.

headline: Heads Held High on a Team Laid Low
text: Divide this latest lost Mets season into three parts. The beginning, mercifully, was brief, a 5-13 start. Then, for more than half the season, the Mets went 50-38. That stretch took them through July 29, the day after they traded Carlos Beltran. Since then, they are 10 games under .500.

headline: A Warning for Some, Entertainment for Others
text: NAGS HEAD, N.C. — Standing where he warned others not to tread, the beach on the Outer Banks during Hurricane Irene’s landfall, Mike Seidel had sand in his teeth, his pockets and his ears. He was soaking wet, barely able to hear — and he was beaming.

headline: For Some Medical Evacuees, Safety Brought Its Own Difficulties
text: David Clark sat in an ambulance for hours late Saturday night in front of the Park Slope Armory in Brooklyn. Mr. Clark, who is 48 and relies on a wheelchair because of diabetes and a leg injury, was late to receive his medicines. But he still had not even been admitted to the armory, which was a designated shelter for patients with special medical needs who had been displaced because of the storm.

headline: U.S. Tactics in Libya May Be a Model for Other Efforts
text: WASHINGTON — It would be premature to call the war in Libya a complete success for United States interests. But the arrival of victorious rebels on the shores of Tripoli last week gave President Obama’s senior advisers a chance to claim a key victory for an Obama doctrine for the Middle East that had been roundly criticized in recent months as leading from behind.

headline: In Nevada, Apathy Is a Front-Runner
text: RENO, Nev. — Do not come here expecting to find optimism. Unemployment in the state is at 13 percent, and foreclosure rates remain among the highest in the country. Ask people about the future, and they speak of fear and dread. They may have come to the state with big dreams, but these days they are just trying to get by.

headline: This Time, Mostly Praise for Mayor on Storm Response
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was a ubiquitous scold, appearing on camera four times in 24 hours to tell grizzled urban dwellers that, yes, they had to take the threat of dangerous weather seriously.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Silicon Valley Scion Tackles Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES — Annapurna, a Hindu goddess of nourishment, has her name on a section of the Himalayas. Annapurna Pictures operates from a cluster of three multimillion-dollar homes in the Hollywood Hills.

headline: School Gym Shelters Evacuees From Irene
text: They took a corner in the school’s gymnasium, finding forest green city-issued cots for themselves and their four children. They unfolded their blue city-issued fleece blankets, stamped with the city’s official seal, opened their paper cartons of water and settled in for the night.

headline: From Coastline to Mountains, Water Fast and Lethal
text: In southern New Jersey, a 20-year-old woman called her boyfriend early Sunday to tell him that she was trapped in her car with water that was up to her neck. Then she called the police. Her body was found about eight hours later, still inside her car, which had been swept away during a flash flood on Route 40 in Salem County.

headline: The Union Finally Lands a Victory
text: The North Carolina Coast, Aug. 28, 1861 As 318 seasick soldiers staggered through the booming surf near Forts Hatteras and Clark, the Union’s invasion of the coastal South seemed to be literally stuck in the sandy spits of North Carolina’s Outer Banks. The soldiers who made it to shore were thirsty and nearly defenseless, their ammunition spoiled by the crashing waves. Out at sea, more than 500 potential reinforcements were stranded on two troop transports, unable to brave the swells.

headline: Players to Watch at This Year’s Open
text: Three women and three men who may make a run at this year’s United States Open.

headline: At a Marina, Enduring the Rain, Wind and Tedium
text: COINJOCK, N.C. — When the eye finally came and the torrent turned off like a faucet and it became so quiet that a lone bullfrog could be heard, the dock here turned into something of a social club. Captains emerged from their boats, standing barefoot on the wet planks and chatting with the crew at the marina. Ice chests were restocked, and legs were stretched.

headline: Playing in Pinstripes
text: Derek Jeter became the Yankees’ career leader in games played on Sunday.*

text: The United States Open will begin as scheduled, at 11 a.m. on Monday, on a majority of the courts. The biggest change is at Arthur Ashe Stadium, where the first match will begin at 1 p.m. instead of 11 a.m.

headline: Hurricane Lost Steam as Experts Misjudged Structure and Next Move
text: It began as something far off and dangerous — a monster storm, a Category 3 hurricane that packed winds of 115 miles an hour as it buzz-sawed through the Caribbean last week, causing more than a billion dollars of destruction in the Bahamas alone.

headline: Changing the Way Witnesses Look at Suspects

text: Sally Goodgold was the Ethel Merman of land use: bold, brassy and capable of sounding notes that could be heard over any orchestra.

headline: Double Faults That Turned the Tide
text: The most memorable serving is often the worst — the heart-breaking double faults, the serves at crucial moments that land a few inches long or wide. New York Times reporters recall some of the most notable double faults at the United States Open.

headline: ‘Some Hurricane,’ New Yorkers Grumble as Danger Passes

headline: Spreading Diplomacy on Two Wheels While Weathering Traffic and Shouts
text: Few professions conjure up glamorous images like that of ambassadors. They are often social savants with the looks and accents to pass for characters in a James Bond film. They are frequent guests at black-tie dinners who arrive and leave in chauffeured cars.

headline: 5 Suggested Techniques to Aid in Identifying Suspects
text: It is no surprise that eyewitness identification — these days usually conducted with photo arrays — can be impaired by factors like stress, poor lighting and difficulty recognizing people of other races. Less known are issues having to do with how memory itself is shaped and tainted. Researchers and law enforcement officials say several techniques can increase the accuracy of identification.

headline: Police Lineups Start to Face Fact: Eyes Can Lie
text: The decision by New Jersey’s Supreme Court last week to overhaul the state’s rules for how judges and jurors treat evidence from police lineups could help transform the way officers conduct a central technique of police work, criminal justice experts say.

text: A look at the day in sports, from a champion in South Williamsport to a surprising disqualification in South Korea.

headline: Mayor Making It No Secret: He’ll Endorse Quinn in 2013
text: It is the worst-kept secret in City Hall. Michael R. Bloomberg has told almost everyone who asks — but only privately, so far — that he hopes the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, will succeed him as mayor in 2013.

headline: As a States’ Rights Stalwart, Perry Draws Doubts
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — As Gov. Rick Perry of Texas begins his presidential campaign, he is working hard to position himself as the leading Republican champion of states’ rights, using his high-profile battles with Washington and his book on the dangers of federal power to build an ideological and constitutional rationale for his fierce anti-Obama message.

headline: At OTB Parlors, Ghosts of Wagers Past Linger
text: It took OTB a long time to be born. And it is taking a long time to die.

headline: Dr. Charles C. Edwards, Influential F.D.A. Commissioner, Dies at 87
text: By the early 1970s, public alarm over health threats had prompted Congress to pass a barrage of laws requiring the government to ride closer herd on the multibillion-dollar food and drug industries. Dr. Charles C. Edwards, as head of the Food and Drug Administration, led the regulatory charge.

headline: Battle for Libya | August 28, 2011
text: Libyans continued to search the Bab al-Aziziya complex and rebel fighters continued their slow push toward Surt.

headline: Fishing for Salmon That Like a Crowd
text: BALLINA, Ireland — Rotating my two-handed rod and snapping it forward, I unfurled a long cast across the Ridge Pool on the River Moy, the most desirable stretch of water on Ireland’s most plentiful Atlantic salmon river. As my fly, a No. 12 Cascade with double hooks, swung across the current, salmon rolled in the river before me, at once beguiling and maddening. I took two steps downstream and prepared to cast again, but my concentration was broken by a series of staccato beeps from a procession of cars passing over Upper Bridge downstream.

headline: After Hurricane Irene: What You Need to Know in New York
text: Most of New York City’s agencies shut down service in anticipation of Hurricane Irene. Now that the tropical storm has passed through the five boroughs, here’s what you need to know.

headline: A Soaked Vermont Awaits Even More Flooding
text: BRATTLEBORO, Vt. — Much of Vermont was paralyzed Sunday by treacherous flooding in the wake of Tropical Storm Irene, with scores of state and local roads closed, homes underwater, bridges wiped out and at least one person dead after being swept into a rushing river.

headline: Jeter and Rodriguez, After Sunday’s Injuries, May Miss Monday’s Game

text: HONG KONG — A study sponsored by the solar power industry has concluded that the United States ran a trade surplus of $1.88 billion in solar technologies last year, as exports of raw material and factory equipment for the solar sector outpaced imports of finished solar panels.

headline: Aug. 29, 1991 | Soviet Parliament Suspends Activities of Communist Party

headline: Have You Experienced a Severe Weather Event?

headline: Qaddafi’s Wife and 3 of His Children Flee to Algeria
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Algeria said Monday that it had allowed a two-vehicle caravan of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s relatives, including his second wife and three of his children, into the country. The flight of his relatives provided powerful new evidence of surrender by the Qaddafi clan as rebels consolidated their hold on Tripoli, the capital.

headline: Mustang Boss 302 TracKey Package: A Skunkworks Effort From Ford
text: ROMEO, Mich. — Sitting behind the wheel of a gently rumbling 2012 Ford Mustang Boss 302 here on the tarmac apron at Ford’s proving grounds, I put my foot on the brake, pushed the speed control’s Set button and watched the tachometer needle sweep through its range. With Jeff Seaman, the Mustang program manager, providing instruction from the passenger’s seat — a brave man, he — I released the Set button, then used the plus and minus controls to set the tach to 4,200 r.p.m. When the needle returned to idle, I pressed the speed control’s On button to lock in the r.p.m. setting.
