headline: Alan Krueger Chosen as Obama’s Top Economic Adviser
text: President Obama will nominate Alan B. Krueger, a Princeton University labor economist, to be his top economic adviser, a White House official said Monday.

headline: Exit Stage Left
text: Lizzie Owens knows how to dress performers. From psychedelic woodsmen to hip-hop street kids, Owens, a Utah native, has costumed an array of bands, like MGMT, the Cool Kids and Brandon Flowers from the Killers. Her third and most fully conceived collection for Highland, which she started with partners and childhood friends Cramer Tolboe (above left) and Mike Franks (right), features rugged, wearable clothes for the everyday man. Highland showcases mixed prints, unconventional details (like detachable pockets) and classic outerwear in surprising materials (like a teddy-bear car coat) that combine the theatricality of her past with what appears to be a practical future.

headline: Storm’s Push North Leaves Punishing Inland Floods
text: CHESTER, Vt. — While most eyes warily watched the shoreline during Hurricane Irene’s grinding ride up the East Coast, it was inland — sometimes hundreds of miles inland — where the most serious damage actually occurred. And the major culprit was not wind, but water.

headline: Monday Reading: Rules Vary When Teens Fly Alone
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: For Suburban Commuters, Train Service Slowly Returns
text: With no commuter rail trains running to New York City from Connecticut, New Jersey and Westchester County on Monday morning, many residents of the suburbs faced a day stranded at home, tens of thousands of them without electricity. Those who ventured out encountered snaillike traffic conditions on clogged parkways and country roads blocked by fallen trees and standing water, part of the damage left by Tropical Storm Irene.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Sino-Forest’s Ratings Are Cut Sharply
text: Two ratings agencies on Monday slashed their ratings on Sino-Forest, the Chinese forestry company that Canadian securities regulators have accused of fraud.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Markets to Open as Usual, After Storm | The New York Stock Exchange and other equity markets plan to be up and running on Monday, following Hurricane Irene, The New York Times reports. Wall Street banks said they, too, would be open for business as usual, and the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association said bond markets were on schedule as well.

headline: For Zvonareva, a Tropical Storm Is No Obstacle
text: Vera Zvonareva, the No. 2 seed in the women’s draw at the United States Open, will be talking with Straight Sets about her experiences throughout the tournament. On Sunday, Zvonareva, who is 26 and was born in Moscow, spoke about what she does to prepare to play; she will face Stephanie Foretz Gacon on Monday at Louis Armstrong Stadium.

text: 6:58 p.m. | Updated

headline: I Me Mine: The Beatles and Their Pronouns
text: James W. Pennebaker’s new book “The Secret Life of Pronouns,” which I reviewed in The Times Book Review on Sunday, makes it hard to stop thinking about pronouns and the other little “function words” that Mr. Pennebaker, a social psychologist at the University of Texas at Austin, sees as “the keys to the soul.” Mr. Pennebaker is admirably omnivorous when it comes to looking for material that will show how these stealthy words — which include articles, prepositions, conjunctions and auxiliary verbs — reflect our social psyche. One of his more unexpected sources is the lyrical canon of the Beatles.

headline: Back on the A-List: New ‘Absolutely Fabulous’ Episodes Are Coming
text: They’re coming back, sweeties: Patsy Stone and Edina Monsoon, the foul-mouthed, fashionably wasted ladies portrayed by Joanna Lumley and Jennifer Saunders in the comedy series “Absolutely Fabulous,” will return to television in a series of anniversary specials, the BBC said on Monday.

headline: Sex Change
text: The name is synonymous with glamorous, exotic-skinned heels (thanks to one too many “Sex and the City” puns), but Jimmy Choo’s debut collection for men is thoroughly, surprisingly, masculine. The line ranges from Alfie-worthy Chelsea boots and crocodile monk-strap shoes to modern street-wear classics like the leopard-print high-top featured here on Tamara Mellon, Choo’s founder. “Men started going in and buying the big sizes of the women’s sneakers,” Mellon says. “It was like an aha moment — it made sense.”

headline: Russia Parliamentary Elections to Be Held Dec. 4
text: MOSCOW — President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Monday set a Dec. 4 date for a parliamentary election that will almost certainly be dominated by the governing United Russia party and will set the stage for a presidential election early next year.

headline: Palestinian Man Injures 8 at Israeli Club, Police Say
text: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man from the occupied West Bank wounded eight Israelis early Monday when he hijacked a taxi in Tel Aviv, drove it to a packed nightclub and ran over police officers at a security checkpoint before emerging to stab several bystanders.

headline: Post Your Hurricane-Related Insurance Questions

Cars crushed by trees are generally covered under the comprehensive portion of your auto insurance policy, according to this video from the Insurance Information Institute. The institute also has published a list of toll-free numbers for contacting insurance companies.

headline: Stuffed Vegetables for Late Summer
text: Travel anywhere in the Mediterranean region, and you will find stuffed vegetables. In Provence, they tend to be filled with meat (a way to stretch leftover stews), but in the Middle East and Greece rice and grain fillings prevail. Regional cooks make abundant use of fresh herbs like parsley, dill and mint, and sweet spices like cinnamon and allspice.

headline: Welcoming Monks and Wild Horses, in North Dakota

headline: Being and Weather
text: Two nights ago, Hurricane Irene was taking her sweet time, making her painfully slow path up the East Coast towards New York. And everyone, but everyone, was talking about the weather. New Yorkers, many of whom ordinarily exhibit a strong aversion to small talk, had given themselves carte blanche to do so until after the storm weakened and passed on to irrelevant Canada.

headline: Preseason Football Lifts NBC on Sunday
text: Although coverage of Hurricane Irene dramatically affected the early numbers for the broadcast networks, an overall ratings picture for Sunday is clear. NBC easily emerged as the victor with its presentation of a preseason football game between the New Orleans Saints and the Oakland Raiders, pulling in an estimated average of 7.3 million total viewers during the night. (The Saints won the game, 40-20.) Second place belongs to ABC, with “20/20: The Sixth Sense,” up 23 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic category when compared with last week. The show averaged just under 6 million total viewers during a two-hour period.

headline: At the End of the Road
text: Faced with the usual options for senior housing and elder care, some older adults are inventing their own grass-roots versions — do-it-yourself senior living that’s friendlier, more autonomous and less expensive. Fellows in the News21 program at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism are posting video reports on four of these: a shared housing arrangement in White Plains, a senior cohousing development in Virginia, an urban village in Chicago and an R.V. community in East Texas.

headline: Events in Libya: A Chronology
text: Aug. 24 Buoyed by their seizure of Col. Qaddafi’s compound, rebels sought to strengthen their control of Tripoli, placing a nearly $2 million bounty on the Libyan leader’s head and dispatching fighters toward one of his last bastions of support, his tribal hometown of Surt.

headline: Lehman Legal Problems Appear to Be Fading
text: Two settlements of investor securities fraud claims against former officers and directors of Lehman Brothers provide another sign that the federal government is unlikely to pursue criminal or civil charges stemming from the firm’s collapse in 2008.

headline: The Tenor Jonas Kaufmann Keeps Plans Despite Surgery
text: Jonas Kaufmann, a major international tenor who has become an increasingly important presence at the Metropolitan Opera, plans to go ahead with an Oct. 30 recital at the house just two months after undergoing chest surgery, the Met said on Monday. He also remains committed to a run as the title character in a new production of Gounod’s “Faust,” which opens on Nov. 29, and to appearances in the “Ring” cycle in the spring, the Met said. “Jonas Kaufmann has assured the Met through his management that he plans to sing all of his scheduled performances here this season,” according to a company statement. Mr. Kaufmann said on his Web site that he needed to have an operation to remove a node from his chest. “I do not wish anyone to become alarmed reading this, but my physicians have ordered me to have the surgery done as soon as possible, and it will take place after my appearance in Stockholm on Sept. 2,” he said. He is scheduled to sing in the Jussi Björling gala that day at the Royal Opera. Mr. Kaufmann’s Web site lists five other performances in October, starting on Oct. 10.

headline: The Height Equation
text: Q. Is there an upper limit to human growth? Why does one generation grow taller than the last?

headline: With HX1, Peugeot Adds a Plug-In to Its Diesel-Hybrid Program
text: Sleek and sensuous, the Peugeot HX1 concept, which is expected to have its debut at the Frankfurt auto show next month, is a six-seat, plug-in diesel hybrid that attempts to meld design elements of sedan and wagon. It follows the 508 RXH, the brand’s first mass-produced diesel hybrid, which is expected to go on sale in Europe next spring.

headline: Should Parents Ban Fraternities?

It is not coincidence, many of you said, that all the incidents I described in my Sunday Styles article, about why young women have moved past stereotypes in the classroom but not in relationships, involved Greek life.

headline: The New Yorker and Francis Schaeffer

headline: Fresh and Direct From the Garden an Ocean Away
text: Charles C. Mann has faced up to the locavore’s dilemma. At his home in the Berkshires, he likes to eat food that has traveled directly from his own garden: heirloom tomatoes, eggplant, bell peppers, kale, chard, lettuce and other foods for his table. He and his family belong to a farm-share program in which they advance money each year to a farmer a few miles away in return for the farm’s crops. He loves local food, but he knows too much about it to be a truly devout locavore.

headline: Fish Dominates in Opening Round
text: Shrugging off nerves in the opening minutes, Mardy Fish of the United States cruised to victory over Tobias Kamke of Germany, 6-2, 6-2, 6-1, on Monday to move into the second round of the 2011 United States Open.

headline: Arizona’s New Post-Partisan: Charles Barkleyism

headline: Teaching 9/11 | Why? How?
text: Both the start of the new school year and the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, are upon us. Many teachers address 9/11 as part of United States history, while others want to commemorate the anniversary with their students. And there are teachers out there who are hesitating, wondering how to teach about 9/11 in an appropriate and meaningful way, or whether to mention it at all.

headline: Bronx Boater, 68, Is City’s First Irene-Related Death
text: The authorities linked the drowning of a man in the waters off City Island to Tropical Storm Irene, in what they are describing as the first Irene-related death discovered in New York City.

headline: Smart Choices to Ensure Safety at Lunch
text: If you, like me, distrust school cafeterias, you pack homemade lunches for your children, as I did until my sons finished high school. But in the rush to get youngsters up, dressed, fed and off to school on time, the safety of that packed lunch easily can be overlooked.

headline: TimesCast | August 29, 2011
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's wife and three of his children have fled to Algeria; inside the homes the Qaddafis left behind; and in Vermont, flooding damages roads and iconic covered bridges.

headline: It Was a Dark and Sort of Stormy Night
text: Friday was too balmy to trust. We brought all our plants inside and made cardboard blockades so my 9-month-old son Zev couldn’t munch all the dirt. Bought some batteries and candles. A special treat for my 2-year-old, Sonya. Our snack drawer was full and we’d just splurged for our first month of HBO. Our Brooklyn apartment is in a converted Catholic school nowhere near water and we’re on the first floor in a courtyard so quiet we often wake to wind chimes.

headline: In an Upset, Kvitova Loses to Dulgheru

headline: Introducing Fech
text: Ten years ago, the Federal Election Commission introduced electronic filing for political committees that raise and spend money to influence elections to the House and the White House. The filings contain aggregate information about a committee’s work (what it has spent, what it owes) and more detailed listings of its interactions with the public (who has donated to it, who it has paid for services).

headline: A Peaceful Penthouse That Turmoil Calls Home
text: The western penthouse at 37 Riverside Drive soars above the park and the Hudson River, offering sweeping sunset views across the Palisades and past the George Washington Bridge, conjuring a feeling of country in the city and respite from the hubbub of Manhattan far below.

headline: Congress Returns for Another Round on Jobs, Spending

headline: The Appraisal: Is Co-op Living Worth the Hassle?

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘In a Lonely Place’

Gloria Grahame also stars as Laurel Gray, the actress who provides Dixon an alibi, and with whom he quickly begins a romance.

headline: As Expected, Hurricane Fallout Puts a Damper on Broadway Box Office
text: Broadway musicals and plays grossed only $11.6 million last week, a sharp drop from overall tickets sales of $20.1 million during the previous week — the result of New York City’s shutdown over Hurricane Irene, which led to the cancellation of typically profitable performances on Saturday and Sunday. Nearly 131,000 people saw Broadway shows before theaters went dark for the storm, compared to about 218,000 the week before.

headline: Ideals Are Easy; Living Up to Them Isn’t
text: STRATFORD, Ontario — Heroism is not a career to be undertaken lightly, as the two musical revivals at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival here this season make clear. King Arthur, the legendary English leader of knights and founder of the Round Table, finds the task of shaping a chivalric code to be easier than living up to its ideals in the 1960 musical “Camelot.” And his burden is a mere feather compared to that of Jesus himself, the martyred founder of a worldwide faith in “Jesus Christ Superstar,” first staged on Broadway in 1971.

headline: A Writer Deals With Success as Not the End of the World
text: BELMONT, Mass. — The Rapture came at a good time for Tom Perrotta.

headline: Testing Water Along the Path of Irene
text: Beyond flooding and destruction, Hurricane Irene is likely to have caused less visible environmental damage by dumping sewage, pesticides and other contaminants into waterways along the East Coast, federal officials said.

headline: In Southampton, Irene Blew In the First Hints of Fall
text: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — It was fall on Monday in this seaside resort village, temperature in the 70s, not a drop of humidity, the wind virtually silent. Ideal conditions to rake the leaves.

headline: Doctors With Plenty of Time for Patients
text: Standard outpatient medical care affronts all logical time management. You wait for an appointment, you wait to be seen, and then comes the hectic series of milliseconds that constitutes the medical encounter itself. Before you remember half your agenda, you are firmly ushered on your way, down the exit chute to start the process all over again.

headline: Sharapova Struggles but Prevails
text: Troubled by a faltering focus that produced 58 unforced errors, Maria Sharapova of Russia nearly squandered a 4-1 lead in the final set but moved into the second round of the U.S. Open Monday with a 3-6, 7-5, 6-3 victory over unseeded Heather Watson of Great Britain.

headline: TimesCast | Vermont Flooding
text: August 29, 2011 - In Vermont, flood waters have largely receded, but roads are damaged and some of the state's iconic covered bridges have washed away.

headline: Zvonareva Sweeps Through the First Round
text: While other top seeds on the women’s side struggled, No. 2 Vera Zvonareva swept through her first match at the 2011 U.S. Open, winning the final eight games of the match to cruise to a 6-3, 6-0 win over French qualifier Stephanie Foretz Gacon. The win improves Zvonareva’s career record in the first round of the tournament to 9-0.

text: Q.

headline: A Bacteria-Busting Oil Behind a Popular Spice
text: Coriander (cilantro, when the leaves of the plant are used fresh) is a popular spice widely used in Asian, Latin American and Mediterranean cooking.

headline: Eustace Tilley vs. Waxy Derek Jeter
text: We liked Kevin O’Callahan’s  design of a Derek Jeter birthday candle for our cover story so much, we made a softball jersey out of it. Tomorrow we play our annual game against The New Yorker in Central Park, provided Irene hasn’t rendered the field unplayable. It’s our only game of the year, so it’s kind of a big deal. At least for some of us. What we lack in batting and fielding skills, we will make up for in sartorial flair. And beer consumption.

headline: If You Build It, Then the Real Work Starts
text: That’s the thing about ideas: They’re so cheap that anyone can have them. They’re ubiquitous sparks. They’re democratic.

headline: Tenor Seriously Injured In Sicily Road Accident
text: The tenor Salvatore Licitra, who made a splash with a last-minute substitution for Luciano Pavarotti at the Metropolitan Opera in 2002, was severely injured in a motor-scooter accident in Sicily on Saturday night and was in serious condition with severe head injuries, according to news reports and his Web site.

headline: Popularity and Pedigree Matter in the B.C.S.
text: If you were in all-Irene, all-the-time mode for the last week, you might have missed Nate’s article looking at off-field influences on college football’s B.C.S. ranking system. Read more.

headline: Poets’ Visions of America From the Inside and Out
text: American writers eventually come face to face with the barnacle-encrusted myths that we use to invent ourselves: Manifest Destiny, the Greatest Generation — and let’s not forget Honest Abe and plucky little Betsy Ross stitching together the first Stars and Stripes. Each poet in these collections wrestles with our American myths: Kathleen Ossip waves her red-white-and-blue cape at the mad bull of the cold war; in a country that prefers truth in black and white, Jane Hirshfield drapes herself in grays; Tracy K. Smith vanishes into outer space as last frontier; Dilruba Ahmed ponders her roots in Ohio and Bangladesh; and William Carlos Williams is himself myth incarnate.

headline: Cholera: Climate Change Isn’t a Culprit in Increasing Outbreaks, Study Finds
text: Cholera outbreaks seem to be on the increase, but a new study has found they cannot be explained by global warming.

headline: Bachmann Takes Her Tea Party to Florida
text: MIAMI — In her nearly five years in Congress, and just over two months as a declared presidential candidate, Representative Michele Bachmann has demonstrated time and again that she knows how to fire up the base. Her four-day, six-city swing through Florida has been no exception, as Mrs. Bachman, a Minnesota Republican, addressed stalwart Republican groups of retirees, Cuban-Americans and Tea Party members, who repeatedly answered her speeches with lusty cheers.

headline: Risks: Infections Follow Rise in Cardiac Implants
text: The number of implantable cardiac devices in use has doubled since 1993, and the number of infections associated with them has more than tripled, a new study has found.

headline: Trailer: 'One Day on Earth'
text: Two fledgling filmmakers have involved more than 7,000 people in documenting one day all over the world.

headline: Prevention: Evidence of Heart Benefits From Chocolate
text: An analysis of studies including more than 100,000 subjects has found that high levels of chocolate consumption are associated with a significant reduction in the risk of certain cardiovascular disorders.

headline: Nutrition: Breast-Feeding Does Not Prevent Eczema
text: Prolonged breast-feeding is widely believed to protect infants against developing eczema and other allergic diseases. But a new study has found no evidence for the belief.

headline: Tallying the Benefits of Chocolate
text: Chocaholics may have more reason to indulge in a chocolate truffle or two today. New research from scientists at the University of Cambridge suggests that the heart-healthy benefits chalked up to regularly indulging in chocolate treats may not be all hype. The research involved more than 100,000 subjects and included data from a half dozen studies.

headline: Hurricane News, Mostly Uninterrupted by Ads
text: THE effects of Irene — as hurricane, tropical storm or wet and wild troublemaker — had marketers, agencies, media companies and retailers scrambling all weekend and into the new workweek.

headline: No Evidence That Breast-Feeding Prevents Eczema
text: Many parents who breast-feed believe it can boost a child’s immunity, protecting against a number of allergies. But that widely held belief has not always been borne out in studies. Now, researchers in Britain have found that breast-feeding may not protect infants against developing eczema and other allergic diseases.

headline: Sybil Jason, Cherubic Child Actress, Dies at 83
text: Sybil Jason, a cherubic child actress signed by Warner Brothers to compete with Shirley Temple in the 1930s, died on Aug. 23 at her home in Northridge, Calif. She was 83.

headline: Against Craybas,  Madison Keys Plays Like a Veteran
text: Sixteen-year-old Madison Keys, playing in her first main draw at Flushing Meadows, defeated tour veteran Jill Craybas in straight sets, 6-2, 6-4. Keys raced to a 4-1 lead in the second set, hurting Craybas by playing with a near perfect blend of patience and aggression.

headline: After Panhandler Says Police Harassed Her, a Judge Tells Them to Stop
text: On Fifth Avenue, somewhere between the University Club and Tiffany, Sojourner Hardeman sat before an empty storefront recently, displaying a cardboard sign that detailed her abilities as a typist and her familiarity with computer software.

headline: Harrison Can’t Control His Serve, or His Temper
text: American hopeful Ryan Harrison, who upset No. 15 seed Ivan Ljubicic in the first round of the 2010 tournament, was unable to repeat the effort Monday on Louis Armstrong Stadium, falling in straight sets to Marin Cilic despite having opportunities to serve for both the second and third sets. Cilic, the No. 27 seed, won 6-2, 7-5, 7-6(6).

headline: For the Mets, a Long Day’s Journey Ends Promisingly
text: The Mets hosted the Florida Marlins on Monday for a twi-night doubleheader that essentially functioned as a showcase of inconsequential baseball. Still, although the games may have been an afterthought, the Mets managed to have a promising evening.

headline: Storm’s Worst Deluge Swamped the Mountains in the Northeast
text: In the end, the storm made more waves in the mountains than it did along the shore.

headline: Yankees Will Head to Boston Short-Handed
text: BALTIMORE — It will be a short-handed Yankees club that begins a three-game series with the Boston Red Sox on Tuesday night at Fenway Park.

headline: Statistics, Beloved by Mayor, Show a Slump in City Services
text: “In God we trust,” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is fond of saying, before invariably adding a caveat: “Everyone else, bring data.”

headline: At Open, Petzschner Is a Marathoner Again
text: With every minute that went by in his first-round match Monday at the United States Open — and those were a lot of minutes, 264 of them, to be exact — Germany’s Philipp Petzschner tried to evaluate the body language of his opponent, Albert Ramos of Spain.

headline: Holden Set for Return
text: The American midfielder Stuart Holden, who has missed six months because of a knee injury, is set to play for the first time since last season, suiting up Tuesday for Bolton’s reserves in a game against Fulham’s reserves. Michael Bradley, another American midfielder, is expected to sign with Chievo of Italy.

headline: Madden NFL 12 Adds Depth to the Franchise
text: The very best video games are those that permit gamers to dwell inside a world in which they would never otherwise be allowed. In particular, sports games give those of us born without superhuman speed or strength the chance to dominate when we would normally be asked to pay a stunning sum just for the privilege of sitting up close.

headline: Fantasy U.S. Open: Steffi Graf

headline: Australian Arrives With a Game That’s Growing

headline: He’s Not an Immortal Time-Traveler, but He Plays One on TV
text: I’M a bad flier. But the aircraft itself is fascinating to me and I have actually read a lot about planes. But as far as being a passenger, I’m never totally relaxed.

headline: Alabama: Judge Delays Tough Immigration Law
text: A federal judge in Birmingham has temporarily halted a tough state immigration law from taking effect on Sept. 1, saying she needed more time to consider challenges to it. The judge, Sharon L. Blackburn, ordered a stay until Sept. 29, saying she would rule by then on a longer suspension that opponents of the law are seeking. Alabama’s law to crack down on illegal immigrants has been described by supporters and opponents alike as the toughest in the nation. Among others, the Obama administration and four Alabama bishops have brought lawsuits to stop it.

headline: Fantasy U.S. Open: Venus Williams
text: William C. Rhoden explains why Venus Williams is a great Open champion and how she could defeat Steffi Graf in a hypothetical Open match.

headline: For Egypt, a Symbol of Boldness Is Disputed
text: CAIRO — As a modern Egyptian legend, it lasted just under a week.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,733 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Plenty of Good Seats Unavailable
text: The run began on May 15, 2003, when Pedro Martinez beat the Texas Rangers, 12-3. It continues this week as the Yankees visit Boston for a three-game series that begins Tuesday. And appropriately, Fenway Park’s sellout streak is scheduled to hit 700 games on Friday night when the Rangers will again be Boston’s opponent.

headline: The Annals of Extreme Surgery
text: THE heat is on again in the world of cancer treatment, both literally and figuratively.

headline: A Stigma Lifts for Luxury Hotels
text: Two years ago, corporations clamped down on employee travel and canceled meetings in droves. The chilling effect was most pronounced at luxury hotels, which were eschewed entirely by many companies in the wake of the disclosures about a lavish retreat held by the American International Group right after it accepted a government bailout.

headline: Knicks, as Part of Effort to Boost Defense, Add Ex-Hawks Coach as Assistant
text: When the Knicks set out to hire another assistant, preferably one with a head for defense, Coach Mike D’Antoni concentrated on one name: Lawrence Frank. With local ties, a solid reputation and success with the Nets, Frank had the right profile.

headline: New Mexico Governor Rushes to Undo the Agenda of Her Predecessor
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — When Gov. Susana Martinez of New Mexico handed over the keys of a state-owned jet to a wealthy businessman and his wife for $2.5 million last week, she was eliminating one more remnant of her predecessor, Bill Richardson.

headline: Unlike Banks, This Wall St. Group Embraces Dodd-Frank
text: While the United States military has Defcon, the tiered alert system used during times of national crisis, Wall Street has fashioned a critical event of its own, Sefcon.

headline: WikiLeaks Leaves Names of Diplomatic Sources in Cables
text: WASHINGTON — In a shift of tactics that has alarmed American officials, the antisecrecy organization WikiLeaks has published on the Web nearly 134,000 leaked diplomatic cables in recent days, more than six times the total disclosed publicly since the posting of the leaked State Department documents began last November.

headline: Five Years of Successes and Strife
text: In Oakland, Terrelle Pryor prepares to begin a five-game suspension for violating N.C.A.A. rules. In Tampa and Nashville, Aqib Talib and Kenny Britt just learned that they will not join Pryor on the sideline for violating the N.F.L.’s personal conduct policy during the lockout. And in New York on Thursday, a week before the league kicks off a wildly anticipated season, Commissioner Roger Goodell will mark his fifth anniversary in the job.

headline: Manufacturing a Recovery
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: The First Emancipation Proclamation
text: On Aug. 30, 1861, Maj. Gen. John C. Frémont, commander of the Union Western Department in St. Louis, issued a proclamation of martial law. “All persons who shall be taken with arms in their hands,” he announced, “shall be tried by court-martial, and if found guilty will be shot.” This was harsh, but perhaps to be expected in the strife-torn region. But Frémont went further. “The property, real and personal, of all persons in the State of Missouri, who shall take up arms against the United States, or who shall be directly proven to have taken an active part with their enemies in the field, is declared to be confiscated to their public use, and their slaves, if any they have, are hereby declared freemen.”

headline: ‘Smart Collar’ in the Works to Manage Wildlife Better
text: FORT COLLINS, Colo. — The collar of the wild is coming.

headline: Open Rookie Has Queens Roots
text: Anna Tatishvili was a 7-year-old from Tbilisi, Georgia, when she visited her aunt in New York with her father in 1997. They went to Juniper Valley Park in Middle Village, Queens, so she could hit some tennis balls, the way she had done since she was 4 and her sister had given her a racket.

headline: Labor Board’s Exiting Leader Responds to Critics
text: WASHINGTON — Rarely has a federal agency been attacked with as much vitriol as the National Labor Relations Board now faces.

headline: Increasing Drug Violence in Brazil
text: The number of murders in Bahia state grew 430 percent to 4,709 between 1999 and 2008.

headline: Defense Tack in Family Killings Promises More Harrowing Jolts
text: For weeks last fall, until Steven J. Hayes was sentenced to death, Connecticut was riveted by testimony describing the nightmarish fate of the Petit family in Cheshire. The mother was strangled in 2007 after an ordeal that began when two men burst into the home, and her two girls, 11 and 17, died after being tied to their beds and the house was set ablaze.

headline: The Mystery of Steve Jobs’s Public Giving
text: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg NewsSteve Jobs, a founder of Apple, has focused on his work to improve the lives of millions of people through technology.

headline: 2 in Florida Are Charged In $22 Million Ponzi Scheme
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued two Florida men, claiming that they had defrauded teachers and retirees in a $22 million Ponzi scheme by posing as a private equity fund while enriching themselves.

headline: As Prosperity Rises in Brazil’s Northeast, So Does Drug Violence
text: SALVADOR, Brazil — Jenilson Dos Santos Conceição, 20, lay face down on the rough concrete, his body twisted, sandals still on his feet, as the blood from his 14 bullet wounds stained the sloped alleyway.

headline: Edgar M. Cullman Sr., Who Helped Turn Cigars Into Objects of Desire, Is Dead at 93
text: Edgar M. Cullman Sr., a cigar maker who worked to broaden the appeal of his product in the late 20th century, helping transform its public image from an unwieldy mobster’s appendage to a cool and slim object of desire, died on Sunday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 93.

headline: I.R.S. Loses Tax Case Against Lay of Enron
text: The United States Tax Court rejected a bid by the Internal Revenue Service to collect $3.9 million from the estate of the former Enron chief Kenneth L. Lay and his wife.

headline: Casinos Find Latin Niche
text: Primm Valley Casino Resorts is betting that aggressively courting Latinos in Southern California will help lead them to success.

headline: Casino Town Puts Its Money on Hispanic Market
text: PRIMM, Nev. — For decades, a patch of casinos on the western edge of Nevada has relied on geography to lure California gamblers reluctant to drive the extra 45 miles for the glamour and glitz of Las Vegas.

headline: The Haimish Line
text: Recently I did a little reporting from Kenya and Tanzania before taking a safari with my family. We stayed in seven camps. Some were relatively simple, without electricity or running water. Some were relatively luxurious, with regular showers and even pools.

headline: Falser Words Were Never Spoken
text: Bronxville, N.Y.

headline: In Catskill Communities, Survivors Are Left With Little but Their Lives
text: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y. — It chewed up Moore’s Trailer Park, sweeping up homes and discarding them in devastating piles of wood, plastic, orphaned automobile wheels and broken children’s toys. It tore apart painstakingly maintained Victorians, their pastel-colored and gingerbread-style exteriors cracked and caved-in, their front lawns, porches and sidewalks replaced by muddy lagoons.

headline: A Cheering Section, and a Support Team
text: Novak Djokovic scanned his guest box at the 2010 United States Open and was struck by the same feeling many couples experience when they glance at their wedding guest list. He wondered who some of the people were and why they were sharing his stage.

headline: NATO’s Teachable Moment
text: The hunt for Muammar el-Qaddafi goes on, but his tyrannical 42-year rule over Libya is finished. The Libyan people bore the brunt of the fighting and dying that brought him down. But NATO air power played an important role. Airstrikes in March stopped Colonel Qaddafi’s forces from storming Benghazi and slaughtering its inhabitants. Continued pounding degraded the regime’s firepower, giving the rebels time to organize and train. NATO’s refusal to back away — and its decision to bring the fight to the skies over Tripoli — helped push Qaddafi cronies to switch sides.

headline: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Steffi Graf vs. Venus Williams
text: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? It’s up to you to decide, with a little help from The Times’s tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section.

headline: China Takes Aim at Rural Influx
text: BEIJING — Xie Zhenqing spent 12 years transforming a collection of ramshackle houses into Red Star, a privately run, low-cost school for 1,400 children of migrants from poor rural areas. It took just a few hours this month for a government-dispatched demolition crew to turn the place into a jagged pile of bricks.

headline: Tuesday: Ain’t She Sweet?
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Ladies and gentlemen, you are witnessing history.

headline: Targeting Women
text: A lawsuit filed in Kansas this month has opened a new front in the legal war over women’s reproductive rights. Since last year, 13 states, including Kansas, have enacted laws banning insurance coverage of abortion in the health insurance exchanges created by the federal health care reform law. Some states have gone even further, aggressively restricting abortion coverage even in private insurance plans sold outside the exchanges.

headline: At the Open, Two Players from Ireland Make History
text: When Novak Djokovic steps onto the court for his first round match at this year’s Open, it’ll be his New York debut as world number one, but it will be the unfamiliar player on the other side of the net who will be making history. That man is Conor Niland, a 29-year-old Irishman, who, together with countryman Louk Sorensen, will be the first Irish players ever to compete in the main draw of the U.S. Open.

headline: A Couple’s Big Break That’s Not So Lucky
text: What’s the No. 1 thing couples fight about? Money. And a hard-luck pair is doing so with bedraggled elegance in “Temporal Powers,” another fine revival of a Teresa Deevy play by the Mint Theater Company.

headline: The Cost of Business Lost and Property Damaged
text: A day after Tropical Storm Irene blew through, New York City wrung itself out on Monday under a blue sky and started getting back to business.

headline: White House Issues Guides on Sept. 11 Observances
text: WASHINGTON — The White House has issued detailed guidelines to government officials on how to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, with instructions to honor the memory of those who died on American soil but also to recall that Al Qaeda and other extremist groups have since carried out attacks elsewhere in the world, from Mumbai to Manila.

headline: Pulling Out of a Debate, Over a Storm Long Gone
text: The politicians had carefully prepared. The organizers had booked the room. The audience was lined up.

headline: Down and Out at the Post Office
text: Neither rain nor snow may stop the United States Postal Service, but will the abysmally divided Congress? The service is reeling toward default and urgently needs the Capitol’s help to modernize and pay its bills.

headline: David Honeyboy Edwards, Delta Bluesman, Dies at 96
text: David Honeyboy Edwards, believed to have been the oldest surviving member of the first generation of Delta blues singers, died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 96.

headline: End the Slush
text: All members of the New York City Council have long enjoyed a slush fund, an annual allowance that is supposed to go to a soup kitchen or senior center or other nonprofit social program in the district. The amount of money for each district seldom depends on need; it comes courtesy of the Council speaker, who holds the purse.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Subsidiary of News Corp. Loses Deal With State
text: The New York State comptroller’s office has rejected a $27 million contract with a News Corporation subsidiary to build a data system for tracking student performance, as fallout widens against the international media conglomerate due to a phone hacking scandal in Britain.

headline: Uneven Night for Quarterbacks and Their Teams
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — At various points during the past month, Eli Manning and Mark Sanchez have drawn attention for things they have said. First, Sanchez revealed (in a GQ interview) that he once wanted to fight Coach Rex Ryan last season, then Manning opined (in a radio interview) that he believed he was one of the five best quarterbacks in the N.F.L.

headline: Arsenal’s Embarrassment Leads to Free Ticket Offer
text: Arsenal Manager Arsène Wenger began Sunday’s late-afternoon disaster in Manchester wearing his familiar full-length down parka. By the end of the game, the coat was gone as Manchester United turned Old Trafford, often called the Theater of Dreams, into Wenger’s unabashed house of horrors.

headline: Venus Williams Returns With a Victory
text: Stepping back into tournament competition after an extended absence since the Wimbledon Championships in June, Venus Williams of the United States powered her way to victory over Vesna Dolonts of Russia, 6-4, 6-3, to gain the second round of the U.S. Open at Flushing Meadow on Monday night.

headline: Bloggingheads: Libya's Non-Lessons
text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com debate whether there are lessons to be learned from Libya.

headline: ABC Unveils ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Cast
text: The prosecutor-turned-cable-TV-shouter Nancy Grace was the most noteworthy of the 12 contestants announced Monday for the 13th season of ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars.”

headline: From a Few Iraqis, a Word to Libyans on Liberation
text: BAGHDAD — The men sat around a small plastic table at an outdoor cafe here on Friday evening, playing chess, smoking cigarettes and reminiscing about when Saddam Hussein’s regime fell and they felt free for the first time in their lives.

headline: Yankees Salvage a Split but Lose Some Strength
text: BALTIMORE — A long, wet and almost costly weekend came to a satisfactory conclusion for the Yankees, who beat the Baltimore Orioles, 3-2, Monday night behind a masterly performance by Freddy Garcia, then headed to Boston for a three-game series against the division-leading Red Sox.

headline: Corrections: August 30

headline: Nuclear Panel Expanding Team to Check for Quake Damage
text: WASHINGTON — The earthquake last Tuesday in Virginia may have produced stronger shaking at the North Anna nuclear plant than the reactors were designed to withstand, and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has sent additional inspectors to determine what steps are needed to determine if there is damage. No significant damage has been identified so far.

headline: Texas A&M Closer to Withdrawing From Big 12
text: Texas A&M’s departure from the Big 12 Conference drew closer to reality on Monday when the university’s president, R. Bowen Loftin, called the Big 12 board chairman, the Missouri chancellor Brady Deaton, notifying the league that the Aggies would formally withdraw — very likely on Tuesday — according to two college officials with direct knowledge of the decision.

headline: Qaddafi ‘Gave Us Dignity,’ a Captured Loyalist Says
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Faraj Mohamed cast his eyes across the hospital room with the furtive anxiety Tripoli residents used to display when they spoke ill of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Al Qaeda Affiliates Growing Independent
text: WASHINGTON — At some point in coming days, a shadowy group of Al Qaeda operatives in Pakistan who make up the network’s “General Command” is likely to announce a replacement for Atiyah abd al-Rahman, the Libyan chief of operations who was killed last week in a drone strike launched by the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: McHale Gets Off to a Rousing Start
text: Christina McHale’s hardcourt season has included an upset of the women’s world No. 1, Caroline Wozniacki. But without a victory Monday night in her opening match at the United States Open, all the good vibrations of the summer would have evaporated in the night air.

headline: Germany's Non-Nuclear Future
text: The Times's Elisabeth Rosenthal looks at how Germany has transitioned away from nuclear power in the wake of the Fukushima accident.

headline: Germany Dims Nuclear Plants, but Hopes to Keep Lights On
text: BIBLIS, Germany — Not since the grim period after World War II has Germany had significant blackouts, but it is now bracing for that possibility after shutting down half its nuclear reactors practically overnight.

headline: Monfils Mixes in Some Drama
text: While thrilling, watching Gael Monfils can be a decidedly exhausting experience.

headline: U.S. Open Fantasy Tournamet
text: Naila-Jean Meyers on why Pete Sampras was a great Open champion and how he would defeat Ivan Lendl on the hardcourts of the Open.

headline: Stetson Kennedy, Who Infiltrated and Exposed the Klan, Dies at 94
text: Stetson Kennedy, a folklorist and social crusader who infiltrated the Ku Klux Klan in the 1940s and wrote a lurid exposé of its activities, “I Rode With the Ku Klux Klan,” died on Saturday in St. Augustine, Fla. He was 94.

headline: New Road Signs Will Now Wait
text: It is a sign of the times: The Obama administration is planning to yield to strapped states and local governments who urged them to slow or be prepared to stop federal safety requirements that they replace thousands of road signs with bigger, brighter, more legible signs by 2018, arguing it would be the wrong way to make them to spend their limited money.

headline: NYT: Front Page for 08/30/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 08/30/2011

headline: Flooding in Irene’s Wake
text: Up and down the East Coast, Irene’s impact was felt in rising waters and submerged homes.

headline: Vietnam: Warning on Bird Flu
text: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations on Monday warned of “a possible major resurgence” of the H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus in the coming months. The virus had been fading since 2006, but migratory birds now seem to be carrying it to infect poultry in more countries, while a variant of the virus has emerged in Vietnam and China that is not easily stopped by vaccines, the F.A.O. said. The resurgence of the virus poses “unpredictable risks to human health,” the agency said.

headline: Iraq: Turks Report Kurdish Deaths
text: The Turkish military said Monday that it had killed more than 150 Kurdish separatists this month with artillery fire and airstrikes in northern Iraq that were carried out in retaliation for increased cross-border violence. The rebels, who are fighting for autonomy in southeast Turkey, often operate out of bases in northern Iraq, where the Iraqi Kurds have achieved a level of autonomy of their own. The rebels — from the P.K.K., or Kurdistan Workers Party — have refused to stop fighting unless demands like the release of a jailed leader and public education in the Kurdish language are met by the Turkish government.

headline: Russia: Space Mission Delayed
text: Russia’s space agency has delayed the launching of the next rocket and crew to the International Space Station until October or November. The delay will give engineers more time to study why an unmanned Russian rocket of the same type tumbled into a Siberian forest after launching last week. A representative of a small, indigenous tribe that lives in the region where the spaceship fell said she intended to sue the Russian space agency for spilling fuel in the forest, though officials said most of what was in the cargo spaceship’s tanks probably burned up on the way down.

headline: Federer Defeats Giraldo in Straight Sets
text: Roger Federer beat Santiago Giraldo in straight sets, in a briskly played match that looked more like a relaxed practice match than an opening round of a Grand Slam.

headline: Ecuador: Journalist Flees to U.S.
text: Emilio Palacio, a senior journalist at the newspaper El Universo, has disclosed that he has fled to the United States after he and three of the newspaper’s board members were sentenced to three years in prison in a dispute over coverage of President Rafael Correa. A judge also ordered the four men to pay Mr. Correa $30 million in damages and imposed a $10 million fine on El Universo over a column questioning Mr. Correa’s handling of a police uprising last year. Mr. Palacio, El Universo’s op-ed editor, and the board members were appealing the ruling. “One would have to be blind not to understand that they want me behind bars,” Mr. Palacio, who is in Miami, wrote in a public letter.

headline: Close Calls and Controversy at the Track and Field World Championships
text: A disqualification in the men’s hurdles led to an appeal, and a mere two inches separated the first and second place hammer toss.

headline: Photo Replay: U.S. Open Day 1
text: The first day of match play at the U.S. Open saw former U.S. Open champions advance and the reigning Wimbledon champion fall.

headline: Gunman Shoots 3 People, Including 2 Children, in the Bronx
text: A gunman fired wildly into a small group of people in the Bronx on Monday evening, wounding three people, including two small children, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Battle for Libya | August 29, 2011
text: Residents returned to assess damage in Tripoli.

headline: Japanese Parliament Backs Noda as Prime Minister
text: TOKYO — Yoshihiko Noda, a down-to-earth fiscal conservative, was elected prime minister by the Japanese Parliament on Tuesday in the sixth change of leaders in five years, a period of mounting economic and social challenges to the world’s third-largest economy.

headline: News Quiz | Aug. 30, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Aug. 30, 1963 | Communications ‘Hot Line’ Connects Soviet and U.S. Heads of State
text: On Aug. 30, 1963, a direct line of communication between Washington and Moscow, dubbed the “Hot Line,” became operational. The Hot Line was established after previous methods of communication were found to be dangerously cumbersome.

text: Photographs by Joao Silva are on exhibit at the Visa Pour l’Image photojournalism festival in Perpignan, France. Mr. Silva spoke at the Bronx Documentary Center on Aug. 2, during his first visit to New York since he was injured in Afghanistan. The following week, he went into surgery. He is doing well.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Aug. 30, 2011
text: Today’s question was written by Susan Behrens, who is a professor at Marymount Manhattan College and the author of “Grammar: A Pocket Guide.” Her question comes from the article “Politicians and Protesters Assail British Police.”

headline: Syrian Security Forces Fire on Worshipers as Ramadan Ends
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of Syrians took to the streets on Tuesday after prayers that signaled the end of the holy month of Ramadan, defying a broad deployment of security forces across Syria that has made August one of the bloodiest months of the uprising.

headline: Who Has the Power in School Social Life?
text: In the Motherlode blog column “After Class, Skimpy Equality,” Lisa Belkin observes that in the classroom, female students are often confident, but socially, “equality, respect and self-worth” often go out the window. Is the gender dynamic at your school or college like this?

headline: South Africans Protest Over Hearing for Zuma Rival
text: The police in South Africa on Tuesday confronted crowds of angry demonstrators supporting Julius Malema, the firebrand leader of the governing party’s influential youth league, as he attended a disciplinary hearing that could sway both his own political career and that of President Jacob Zuma before party elections next year.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Season Awards
text: As this will be my last post in the fantasy baseball series for 2011, let’s give out some season-long awards.

headline: Ahead of Baltimore Grand Prix, Pit Row Is Filling With Lawsuits
text: BALTIMORE — As reported by The Times on Aug. 18, potholes and other undesirable obstacles are being paved over for the Baltimore Grand Prix, which will be held on city streets here over Labor Day weekend. Yet two recent lawsuits have called into question whether the promoters that persuaded IndyCar and the American Le Mans Series to stage races here can actually foot the bill.

headline: What to Watch on Tuesday
text: At 5-foot-9, and without a single dominant stroke, David Ferrer is hardly the prototypical top-five player. Yet, here he is again, ranked fifth in the world and seeded fifth here.

headline: Visiting a Historic, and Hidden, Area of Mumbai
text: Khotachiwadi, a historic area of Mumbai, is like Platform 9 3/4 in the Harry Potter series: invisible to all but those who know exactly where it is or are determined to find it. The narrow lane leading into the wadi, or hamlet, does nothing to inspire confidence and, like Harry and his friends, you need to take a leap of faith and enter.

headline: The Case Against a Payroll Tax Cut
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul.

headline: On Day 2, Commuter Trains Limp Back
text: On the second day back to work after Tropical Storm Irene, things are looking better, though still problematic, for people heading in from the suburbs and beyond. There will be limited commuter train service and some difficult road conditions, but PATH trains, as well as subways and buses, are up and running again.

headline: Macarons and Ice Cream, Direct from Paris to the Upper East Side
text: Before you say “Not another macaron shop!” consider that this newcomer to the Upper East Side from Paris brings almond meringue cakes with a pedigree like none other. Ladurée, which first established a tea room just steps from the Place de la Concorde in 1862, is said to have originated French macarons as we know them: not the little round cakes, but the idea of sandwiching a pair of them with a creamy filling.

headline: Why Red Iguana Built Red Iguana 2 Right Next Door
text: Last week, we published a case study that looked at a choice facing Red Iguana, a Salt Lake City Mexican restaurant that was deciding where, and how, to expand. Founded in 1985 by Ramón and María Cardenas, the 130-employee company offers sit-down restaurant service as well as catering and fast-food operations.

headline: Building a Model New York, Only to Burn It
text: On Thursday, New York City will burn to the ground.

headline: In Men’s Doubles, Looking Beyond the Bryan Brothers
text: Even sports fans who don’t follow doubles know all about the Bob and Mike Bryan, the twins have become synonymous with the game. Their level of fame is well deserved: after all, they’re favored to win their fourth United States Open which would also give them a record 12th Grand Slam title.

headline: Qaddafi Forces Given Deadline to Surrender
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Saying that they had a “good idea” where Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was hiding, the Libyan rebels on Tuesday gave the colonel’s recalcitrant loyalists four days to surrender or face military action against holdout towns.

headline: Italy’s Cost of Borrowing Falls in Latest Bond Sale; Central Bank Action Is Credited
text: Despite a backdrop of weakening growth in the euro zone, Italy on Tuesday was able to sell a slice of debt at a lower interest rate than at its previous auction.

headline: Heroic Past Erodes in Present
text: “The Debt,” John Madden’s remake of a 2007 Israeli thriller, shuttles back and forth between a dim, creaky East Berlin apartment in 1965 and the sunshine of elite Tel Aviv a little more than 30 years later. The film, written by Matthew Vaughn, Jane Goldman and Peter Straughan, is interested in the ways that the truth of the past can be shaded and illuminated by the imperatives of the present, and it probes, with perhaps more energy than clarity, the ethical and psychological complications that can lie hidden beneath a story of simple heroism.

headline: 2012 Campaign: What to Watch For in September
text: With summer over and Labor Day approaching, the 2012 campaign is set to enter its most important phase yet: the fall primary season.

headline: Tuesday Reading: How To Ensure Lunchbox Food Safety

headline: Sara Lee Names Chief for Beverages Spinoff

headline: In National Politics, Not Exactly an Empire State
text: Since you were surely distracted by the former hurricane known as Irene, you may not have noticed one of the weekend’s major nonevents. George E. Pataki, once New York’s governor, announced that after indulging in his quadrennial routine of dropping flirtatious hints of a presidential run, he would once again not seek the Republican nomination.

headline: Hurricane Cost Seen as Ranking Among Top Ten
text: Hurricane Irene will most likely prove to be one of the 10 costliest catastrophes in the nation’s history, and analysts said that much of the damage might not be covered by insurance because it was caused not by winds but by flooding, which is excluded from many standard policies.

headline: NBC Taps ‘Today’ Producer for 2012 Olympics
text: NBC is to announce on Tuesday morning that it has given the top production job for its coverage of the 2012 Olympics to Jim Bell, executive producer of the network’s most important news program, the “Today” show.

headline: Behind Google’s $500 Million Settlement With U.S.
text: The Justice Department’s settlement of a criminal investigation of Google for allowing Canadian pharmacies to advertise drugs for distribution in the United States reflected an effort by prosecutors to extend the reach of federal drug laws. This may present future challenges to Internet search companies over their advertisements.

headline: Shares Edge Higher on a Mixed Bag of Economic Reports

headline: The TV Watch: Sharpton Brings His Pulpit to MSNBC
text: The Rev. Al Sharpton began his new career as an official MSNBC talk show host on Monday by telling viewers not to expect James Brown.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Ziyoou-vachi
text: A little punk, a little glam, and with more than a touch of Gaga and Patricia Fields, Ziyoou-vachi (“Queen Bee”) is not the type of act you’d expect to find on a major record label, but Sony Music Japan snapped up the gender-bending teenage quartet this past year. Celebrating the impending release of their new album at New Japan in the seedy neighborhood of Shinjuku, Tokyo, the band sashayed down a stripper-ish catwalk in the center of the club — not one of them in any less than five-inch heels — and threw themselves into a heavy, energetic set. The drummer and lead singer, Luli-chan and Avu-chan (17 and 19 respectively), are siblings of African-American and Japanese descent. Avu, 6-foot-3 in heels and weighing no more than 110 pounds, is a natural performer. Wearing a dress of her own creation, she captivated the crowd of masked fans with songs sung in Japanese in both “male voice” and “female voice” as she dangled from a spinning handle in the ceiling and coyly hid behind a fan.

headline: Former ‘SpongeBob’ Artist Sues His Art Dealer After She Sues Him
text: A former lead artist on the cartoon series “SpongeBob SquarePants,” who faces a lawsuit from his art dealer concerning what she says was his hiring of accomplices to burglarize her gallery, has fired back with his own suit, accusing her of fraud.

headline: Stamp Act
text: Harris Tweed, the flecked hand-woven wool from Scotland, is celebrating the centennial of its trademark stamp: a Maltese cross atop an orb. An ancestor to the counterfeit wars raging today, the stamp was implemented in 1911 to distinguish the genuine cloth from machine-milled knockoffs. This fall, designers are offering special-edition pieces in tweed as a tribute to those original weavers, our fashion brave hearts.

headline: Drawing Dance: The Merce Cunningham Company in Mexico City
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting their two-year Legacy Tour through a series of drawings and paintings. After 58 years, the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 10th in a series of graphite drawings he plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Mexico City.

headline: Ground Zero Now
text: New office towers are rising on the site, which also serves as a memorial and a transportation hub.

headline: ‘Sweet Bird’ Won’t Fly on Broadway This Fall; Franco No Longer Involved in Revival
text: The movie star James Franco (“Rise of the Planet of the Apes”) is no longer linked to a planned Broadway revival of the Tennessee Williams drama “Sweet Bird of Youth,” Mr. Franco’s publicist said on Monday, and the production itself will not happen this fall as previously reported, according to the director attached to the project.

headline: Wheelies: The Halo Caddy Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Lens: Joao Silva on Loss, Perseverance and Being the Human Behind the Camera
text: If you read one thing today, make it Joao Silva’s post over at the Lens blog. Mr. Silva is a New York Times photographer who was severely wounded in October 2010 when he stepped on a mine while on patrol with American soldiers in southern Afghanistan. Reading his sometimes wry words now, you might be surprised by how seriously he was injured. Legs gone, still taking pictures, Mr. Silva remembers, “I knew it wasn’t good, but I felt alive.”

headline: Honor Guard Scripts for Veterans' Funerals
text: Traditional scripts used by some Veterans of Foreign Affairs groups in funerals.

headline: Defining the Newest Generation of Parents
text: Every group of parents rediscovers the role. Like brides and widowers, the unemployed and college students, newly fledged parents plunge into a universal experience with a vague sense of disbelief that anyone has experienced exactly this before.

headline: G.O.P. Staff Member Picked to Run Deficit Panel
text: Leaders of the new Congressional deficit-reduction committee have chosen a veteran Senate Republican staff member to take over the challenging job of running the panel.

headline: Pairings: Spaghetti With Crab Meat, Cherry Tomatoes and Arugula
text: There was plenty of warm sunshine in the dry rieslings from Alsace. These were not the first rieslings that suggested crab meat to me, or the first time that mellow crab meat suggested riesling. Several weeks ago, before the ballet at Lincoln Center, I cleaned my plate of spaghetti tossed with crab meat, tart-sweet cherry tomatoes, arugula and bread crumbs at Nick & Toni’s Cafe. About a week later, the recipe in hand, I served it at home with Alsatian riesling for an elegant pas de deux.

headline: Alsatian Rieslings Return to Form
text: FEW things have made me as happy recently as the wine panel’s tasting of dry rieslings from Alsace. Not only did we absolutely love many of the wines, but also the rieslings actually tasted pretty dry.

headline: Final Resting Place, and Battleground
text: Every week, thousands of veterans are buried at national cemeteries, often to the sorrowful sound of a bugle. Yet even for families that quietly mourn their dead, these can be the most public of private affairs, taking on deep meaning — about politics, war and religion — to others, particularly other veterans.

headline: All Eyes on Spain as EuroBasket Tips Off
text: Every two years the best national basketball teams in Europe battle it out for continental supremacy at EuroBasket. This year’s edition should be typically intense and, given the current lockout, there will be no shortage of N.B.A. players. Part N.B.A., part Euroleague, mixed in with some soccer-style fan fervor; here’s what to look for at when EuroBasket 2011 tips off Wednesday in Lithuania:

headline: Thinking Cap: When Foul Language Brings Fouls
text: “May I Curse a Referee? Swear Words and Consequences,” by Andrea Praschinger and Christine Pomikal, freelance scientists, and Stefan Stieger, who teaches psychology at the University of Vienna. This article appeared in the June issue of the Journal of Sports Science and Medicine.

headline: Seoul Brothers
text: Emerging from the shadow of that other stylish, innovative Asian city (ahem, Tokyo), Korea’s capital has become an epicenter for trends — particularly for men. The evidence is in popular street style blogs like Your Boyhood, Street Peeper and even The Sartorialist (which has featured the model Bae Jung Nam, who, à la Kate Moss, has turned into a style sensation and is the basis of “Bae Jung Nam-style”). Korean men, in fact, have started to outshine the women in terms of experimentation and overall expression, wearing everything from Opening Ceremony’s kookiness to the elegant homegrown designer Wooyoungmi.

headline: India’s Identity Project
text: India is undertaking an ambitious project: collecting the biometric information of 1.2 billion people and assigning each of them a unique 12-digit ID number. Here’s are the thoughts of a few of those who will be assigned.

Well 12.4 million people were watching on Sunday night, the biggest viewership for any show in the 30-year history of the cable channel and continuing the upward ratings trend for the annual awards. Last year’s VMAs drew 11.4 million viewers.

headline: At This Match, It’s Spectators Who Make Too Much Noise
text: The noise Tuesday morning during Victoria Azarenka’s 6-1, 6-3 victory against Johanna Larsson at the United States Open was off-putting. Azarenka’s grunts, which can be louder than a car horn, weren’t the problem.

headline: Good Soles
text: Steven Tiller, a co-founder of the retro SoCal sneaker brand SeaVees, was driving to work recently when he heard on NPR that the 50th anniversary of the Peace Corps was coming up. Initiated by an executive order issued by President John F. Kennedy, the Peace Corps Act was passed in 1961, instituting an “army” of volunteers to aid those in developing countries. Sensing an opportunity right in line with SeaVees’s revisionist design philosophy and midcentury aesthetic, Tiller and his business partner, Derek Galkin, began sifting through old photos of Peace Corps volunteers. On their feet? Narrow plimsolls, a common canvas and rubber sneaker for that era. “The idea was to go back in time, reimagine these shoes and hopefully make them cooler,” Tiller said. The resulting slim-lined sneaker in salt-washed canvas has a contrast suede stripe around its rims and a distinct vintage look. Donations to the National Peace Corps Association will be made for each pair sold exclusively at seavees.com and jcrew.com.

headline: Film Series in Washington Square Park to Feature New York Musicals
text: To celebrate the opening of the renovated Washington Square Park, the IFC Center and the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation are presenting three free outdoor screenings of New York-centric musicals there in September.

headline: Can Clearer Language Clear Up Climate Disputes?
text: Earlier this summer I taped a series of discussions on climate, energy and other topics with Piya Chattopadhyay of The Agenda, the excellent Canadian public affairs program on TVO. The pieces are running all this week along with the network’s coverage of options for the world’s energy menu through 2030, built around a summit that took place at the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics in June. (The show ran an in-depth series on climate science last year that I covered here.)

headline: Smithsonian Plans Exhibition on Jefferson and Slavery

headline: Preparing for the Next Disaster
text: The gods must be crazy, or at the very least they seem extremely perturbed this year. Each season of 2011 has been one for the record books as far as weather events. Here in the state of Arkansas we had record cold and snowfall this winter, followed by historic flooding and tornado damage in the spring. In states throughout the south central United States, the Mississippi river went on a flooding rampage the likes of which had not been seen since the 1930s. A tornado outbreak ripped across several states, with Alabama bearing the brunt. Texas and Oklahoma are still being oppressed by relentlessly hot temperatures, and now Irene has come barreling up the eastern seaboard. Dare I ask what’s next?
