headline: Israeli Columnist Is Fired for Writing That Palestinian Terrorism Is ‘Justified’
text: In a brief “Note to Readers” published Tuesday on the front page of The Jerusalem Post, the newspaper announced that it had parted ways with a columnist who wrote last week on his blog that terrorist attacks on Israelis were “justified” because Palestinians living under Israeli occupation since 1967 “have a right to resist.”

headline: Controversial Airport Is Planned for Costa Rica
text: In a region of Costa Rica that harbors 3 percent of the world’s known biodiversity, a proposed international airport is eliciting concern about ecological consequences and potential damage to an existing and exemplary network of ecotourism lodges.

headline: S.E.C. Recoups Bonus of Former Beazer Executive
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that it had reached a settlement with the former chief financial officer of Beazer Homes USA to recover $1.4 million in bonus and stock profits.

headline: Israel Intensifies Training of Settler Security Teams
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military has stepped up training for more than 100 settler security teams in the West Bank in anticipation of Palestinian popular protests and possible mass disturbances accompanying any Palestinian bid for United Nations recognition in September, settler leaders said on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Day 2
text: The second day at the U.S. Open saw most top players hold seed, although defending French Open champion Li Na was upset by Simona Halep.

headline: Film Festival | Documentaries About 9/11
text: Watch more free documentaries

headline: Wozniacki Wins in Straight Sets
text: W.T.A. No. 1 Caroline Wozniacki turned in an impeccable first round performance in her opening round match at the 2011 U.S. Open, charging to a 6-3, 6-1 victory over Spanish doubles specialist Nuria Llagostera Vives in 80 minutes.

headline: The U.S. Open in Photos: Day 2
text: View photos from the early matches at the U.S. Open on Tuesday.

headline: No Hurricane Worries as Viewers Flock to ‘Jersey Shore’
text: While the MTV Video Music Awards did set an audience record for largest viewership in the cable channel’s 30-year history, the once-a-year event can’t quite compare to the steady ratings dominance coming out of New Jersey (by way of Italy these days).

headline: At Winston’s Champagne Bar, 100 Ways to Fill Flutes
text: Luxurious is the word for Winston’s Champagne Bar, which opens next Tuesday with as elite a list of high-end bubbly as you are likely to see, more than 100 choices from 20 houses.

headline: Zabar’s New Non-Lobster Z-Food
text: Gadzookz. Would Zhakezpeare wonder, What’z in a name, anyway?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Bangladesh, New York, New Jersey and Libya.

headline: Day-Tripping in Segovia (and Counting Euro Pennies)
text: If you’ve never peered into 12th-century churches, meandered down cobblestone streets or pretended to dump boiling oil over ancient city walls onto barbarians below, a day in Segovia is a piece of frugal cake. Figure 20 euros for the 27-minute train from Madrid, 10 euros for lunch and another 4.50 to enter the celebrated castle. Voilà: you’ve got a day trip for around 35 euros per person (or about $50 at $1.42 to the euro).

headline: On Dams, Gutters, Floods and Climate Resilience
text: New York City and the communities downstream of one of the city’s reservoirs in the Catskills may have dodged a disaster as the swirling remains of Hurricane Irene dumped between 9 and 13 inches of rain across the valleys feeding that part of the city’s water supply. At the Gilboa dam on the Schoharie River over the weekend, evacuation sirens sounded after the reservoir exceeded the highest levels recorded there. But inspections of the aging dam, which had seen stopgap repairs recently and is poised for a $350 million rebuild, found no structural problems. (The image above was shot as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo toured the region on Sunday.)

headline: Hurricane Insurance Claims: All About Falling Trees
text: Now that Hurricane Irene has passed, the thoughts of homeowners turn to filing claims for damage caused by the storm. Several Bucks readers had questions about damage caused by trees, so we spoke with representatives of the Insurance Information Institute for some answers.

headline: World Athletics Championships: Day 4
text: Photos from Day 4 of the International Association of Athletics Federations world athletics championships in Daegu, South Korea.

headline: Weather Channel’s Ratings Surge With Irene
text: By television ratings standards, Hurricane Irene was the biggest storm system in the Weather Channel’s 29-year history.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bangladesh and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Bangladesh, New York, New Jersey and Libya.

headline: TimesCast | August 30, 2011
text: Libyan rebels set a deadline for forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to surrender Surt; uncovering Qaddafi's family pictures; and WikiLeaks releases documents without redacting names.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Apologizes to I.M.F. Staff
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn returned to the International Monetary Fund in Washington on Monday to say farewell, a week after the Manhattan district attorney dropped sexual assault charges against him. In a 15-minute speech delivered without notes, Mr. Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the organization, said repeatedly that he wanted to “apologize” for what he said was “a mistake on my part,” according to news reports. Read the full story here.

headline: Yemen, Amid Political Turmoil, Is Embracing a Holiday
text: SANA, Yemen — The dusty streets of this ancient capital were jammed with cars as Yemenis ran last-minute errands before the start of Id al-Fitr, the joyous holiday that began Tuesday with the end of the holy month of Ramadan. Men stood in lines outside tiny barber shops, waiting patiently for their holiday trim, and, for a moment at least, the city tried to focus on something other than a lingering political and economic crisis.

headline: Djokovic Wins–in 44 Minutes
text: In a dream season in which Novak Djokovic has beaten 57 of the 59 opponents he’s faced, just about the only thing he hasn’t done is beat a player from Ireland. Now he’s done that too, taking just 44 minutes to demolish 29-year-old Conor Niland, who had to retire down 0-6, 1-5 due to illness.

headline: Zabar’s No-Lobster Salad Has a New Name
text: After being called out by a reporter for The Times-Picayune of New Orleans earlier this month for selling lobster salad that contains no lobster, Zabar’s has renamed it “zabster zalad,”  City Room reports. The main ingredient remains the same: wild freshwater crayfish.

headline: ‘Jagger’
text: The T.A.M.I. Show was all about showcasing the new.

headline: Tax Me More, Europe’s Wealthy Say
text: LONDON — Echoing a call by Warren E. Buffett, members of the European wealthy elite are urging their governments to raise their taxes or enact special levies to help reduce growing budget deficits.

headline: Icahn Finally Ends His Battle With Lions Gate
text: 7:57 p.m. | Updated

headline: Republican Hopefuls Sound Anything But
text: Looking for a bit of optimism about the future? Hoping for a quick psychological pick-me-up amid the economic downturn?

headline: Disaster Relief Economics
text: In a way, I may be wasting my time doing any kind of rational analysis of Eric Cantor’s demand that any disaster aid in the wake of Irene be offset by spending cuts elsewhere. Cantor is, of course, being totally hypocritical; where were the demands for offsets to the cost of invading Iraq?

headline: Settling a Score, and Matters of Manhood, on Behalf of Rock Royalty
text: The Rolling Stones’ “Bigger Bang” album included a song called “Oh No, Not You Again.” A lot of readers may join in on that refrain at the news that the Stones are back on the bookshelves with “Jagger,” another rehashing of grievances between a certain snake-hipped singer and a louche guitar man. Next year these two will hit their golden anniversary and be able to celebrate 50 years at each other’s throat.

headline: Wikileaks Releases New Cache of Files
text: WikiLeaks,the antisecrecy organization, releases documents, including many that name confidential sources.

headline: Your Reflections on 9/11
text: The New York Times and YouTube invite you to submit a video discussing your perspective on the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11. Go to youtube.com/september11 for details and to upload your video.

headline: Court Grants Citadel Restraining Order Against Employee
text: An Illinois circuit court has granted a request by the hedge fund Citadel for a temporary restraining order against an employee accused by the firm of sneaking highly sensitive information off its computer servers.

headline: A Series of Second Acts Prepares to Open on a Harlem Street
text: The Victoria Theater on 125th Street in Harlem has been home to vaudeville shows, Off Broadway productions and Hollywood movies. But its terra cotta facade has been mostly dark since 1989 when, after failing as a five-screen multiplex, it shut its doors.

headline: CNN Acquires Zite, an iPad App Company
text: Putting an emphasis on personalization tools for the Web, CNN on Tuesday said it had acquired Zite, a company that markets an iPad app that learns what its users want to read and view.

headline: ‘Je T’Aime,’ He Sang, to His Women and Himself
text: Singer and writer of songs, lover of women, prodigious smoker of cigarettes — Serge Gainsbourg was an indelible, unavoidable figure in French culture in the postwar years until his death in 1991. Equal parts icon and iconoclast, he shocked respectable opinion even as he seemed to embody the contradictory moods of his era. He could, sometimes within a single song, appear suave and profane, cynical and romantic, a personification of existential ennui and an avatar of down-and-dirty passion.

headline: Double Vision
text: In order to come up with a full audience for Andy Samberg’s impersonations of tennis players, we asked the digital wizards at Picturehouse to blend our studio photographs by Walter Iooss Jr. with his own photographs from the 1970s and 1980s, when he covered tennis for Sports Illustrated. In the sequence below, you can see the original picture of John McEnroe lying on Center Court at Wimbledon, from the final he lost to Bjorn Borg in 1980, followed by Samberg on the green screen and then the composite of the first two shots. Doing it this way meant we didn’t have to ask Samberg to play all those blurry folks in the stands. And that left him more time to personify tennis greatness, as seen in the outtake at bottom.

headline: Preaching Gospel, Not Singing It
text: The Rev. Al Sharpton began his new career as an official MSNBC talk show host on Monday by telling viewers not to expect James Brown.

headline: Edible Selby | Chez Panisse Turns 40
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#737", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: 456 Shanghai Cuisine
text: ROUGHLY 200 years ago, in the 1970s, there was a nice little restaurant on Chatham Square in Chinatown called 456, which served mild, salty-sweet southern Chinese specialties accompanied by gallons of hot tea: cold sesame noodles, dim sum, pork in brown sauce, stir-fried greens with garlic.

headline: Reviewing 456 Shanghai Cuisine
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response) {data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: '+ data +', cropType: 'blog480', appendTo: 'embeddedSlideshow', showHeadLine: 'false'}

headline: After 9/11, Grappling With Grief and Rage
text: The next two weeks will bring lots of stories updating the lives of 9/11 survivors or of those who lost loved ones in the attacks, but few are likely to exhibit the care and persistence of “Rebirth,” a documentary by Jim Whitaker that stands as both a tribute and a study in healing.

headline: Who You Gonna Bet On, Yet Again (Somewhat Wonkish)
text: Today’s FT has a piece on famous financial managers having a bad year; among them are John Paulson and Bill Gross. Regular readers may recall that back in 2010 Business Week ran an article contrasting my views with Paulson’s, with the tone of the article clearly conveying the message that we should trust the billionaire, not the silly academic. You might also recall that I was highly critical of Pimco’s assertions that the end of quantitative easing would lead to a spike in interest rates.

headline: Mad Scientists, Real and Fictional, Giving Birth to Troubling Theories
text: Normally, “Dark Matters: Twisted but True,” a cornball documentary series starting on Wednesday on the Science Channel that tells unsavory stories of scientific research, wouldn’t merit much attention. It’s a standard show of its kind, relating urban legends, conspiracy theories and sensational more-or-less-true stories with the help of cheap special effects and hilariously cheesy re-creations.

headline: Heroes Take Flight, Again
text: When the latest issue of Justice League is released on Wednesday by DC Comics, it will be scrutinized like no other installment in the 76-year history of that publisher of superhero adventures.

headline: Honduras: Coach Suárez, Najar, Klinsmann and Brazil 2014
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Luis Fernando Suárez took the helm of the Honduras national soccer team last March, and will try to steer the Central American nation to a return trip to the World Cup in 2014. It will face Cuba and the winners of Groups C and D in the semifinal round of the Concacaf region qualifying.

headline: Nevada Says Bank Broke Mortgage Settlement
text: The attorney general of Nevada is accusing Bank of America of repeatedly violating a broad loan modification agreement it struck with state officials in October 2008 and is seeking to rip up the deal so that the state can proceed with a suit against the bank over allegations of deceptive lending, marketing and loan servicing practices.

headline: TimesCast | Libyan Rebels Set Deadline
text: August 30, 2011 - Libya's rebels set a Saturday deadline for forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to leave Surt.

headline: H.P. Plans to Make a Few More TouchPads
text: 6:48 p.m. | Updated  Adding pricing information.

headline: Facebook’s New (New) Privacy Controls
text: Over the weekend, Facebook began rolling out a new interface that gives members much more direct control over who can see what they post, as well as when they’re tagged by others. Some of the options were already available, but you had to click through multiple pages and pop-ups to use them. There are also two new important options.

headline: Rapper Returns, With Punch Lines but Little Soul
text: There goes Lil Wayne, wearing bleached leopard-print skinny pants — women’s pants, as it happens — and stalking the stage of the MTV Video Music Awards with Iggy Pop attitude. There goes Lil Wayne, riding a skateboard and falling off. There goes Lil Wayne, who can’t sing worth a lick, taking a ballad, “How to Love,” into the Top 10 of the Billboard pop chart.

headline: A Ramapo River Spill is Being Addressed
text: As hurricane cleanup continues, many residents of hard-hit areas are worrying about ancillary damage, like toxic runoff from businesses that were hit by Irene.

headline: Cuomo Asks Obama to Declare Disaster in New York State
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, warning that several emergency shelters had been rendered unreachable by flooding and that dams were at risk of failing, asked President Obama on Tuesday to declare a major federal disaster in New York State.

headline: Another Upset: Li Loses to Halep in Straight Sets
text: Following on the heels of Wimbledon champion and No. 5 seed Petra Kvitova’s upset loss yesterday, French Open champion and No. 6 seed Li Na crashed out of the 2011 U.S. Open in the first round, falling 6-2, 7-5 to 53rd-ranked Romanian teenager Simona Halep.

headline: A Tribute to Jackson Riles Fans and Family
text: It seems that nothing involving Michael Jackson or his fractious family is ever free of controversy, even two years after his death.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Portraitist’s Eye Gazes on Fashion
text: DAVID ARMSTRONG and his cat were splayed on a chaise. Mr. Armstrong wore black Levi’s, a denim cowboy shirt and Ray-Ban Wayfarers with prescription lenses. The outfit, appropriate for a hipster 40 years his junior, completely suited him, although he might not think so.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: How to Deflate a Gold Bubble (That Might Not Even Exist)
text: Gold is caught in a frenzy.

headline: Livonia, a Detroit Suburb, Tops List of Worst Cities for Speed Traps
text: Drivers with heavy right feet might want to steer clear of Livonia, Mich., according to a list of American and Canadian cities with the highest number of reported speed trap locations over the last two years.

headline: Charities Struggle With Smaller Wall Street Donations
text: Operation Hope built a nonprofit powerhouse over the last decade, spinning a stockpile of donations from Wall Street firms into 27 financial education centers across the country.

headline: Long Braids Take Center Court at U.S. Open
text: THERE were high-pitched grunts and moans during this year’s Wimbledon three-set semifinal match between Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic and Victoria Azarenka of Belarus, but the hair remained under control. Both players, in white headbands and long dramatic braids, seemed to have torn a page out of the bohemian-chic playbook.

headline: Around Bee Rescue, Honey and Rancor
text: Tropical Storm Irene moved through New York City on Sunday knocking out power, causing flooding in some neighborhoods and knocking over many trees.

headline: N.B.A. and Union Will Talk on Wednesday
text: The first critical bargaining session of the N.B.A. lockout will take place on Wednesday in Manhattan, with negotiators facing an ever-shrinking window to make a deal. It is unclear if either side will make a new proposal.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,737 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Protests in Iran Over Disappearing Lake
text: The raw YouTube clips, of Iranian protesters filling the streets and clashing violently with members of the security forces on motorcycles, might seem familiar to readers who followed the wave of unrest over Iran’s disputed presidential election in 2009, but the anger in the city of Tabriz this time has a more local cause: the government’s failure to halt the gradual disappearance of a vast salt lake that is crucial to the region’s economy.

headline: NBC Picks Executive Producer of ‘Today’ to Run London Olympics Coverage
text: Nearly three months ago, Comcast agreed to pay $4.38 billion for its NBC Universal subsidiary to carry the four Olympics from 2014 to 2020. On Tuesday, NBC made a critical hire, naming Jim Bell, the executive producer of the “Today” show, as its top Olympic producer for the 2012 London Games.

headline: The Ballet of Movement in Grand Central
text: Every hour brings a juxtaposition of energy and stillness to the cavernous terminal.

headline: Water Still Rises in New Jersey and Connecticut
text: As many people in the path of Tropical Storm Irene struggled to recover, floodwaters continued to rise on Tuesday in New Jersey and Connecticut, forcing thousands of evacuations, even two days after the storm swept through the region.

headline: Rodriguez Is Likely to Miss Boston Series
text: BOSTON — Alex Rodriguez received a cortisone shot Monday for his sprained left thumb and said he did not expect to play in any of the three games here against the Red Sox. But he held out hope that he could play Friday against the Toronto Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Paella Compromise

headline: Ladurée Brings Its Macarons to New York
text: Before you say, “Not another macaron shop!” consider that this newcomer to New York from Paris brings almond meringue cakes with a pedigree like no other. Ladurée, which first established a tea room near the Place de la Concorde in 1862, is said to have originated the French macaron as we know it: not the little round cakes, but the idea of sandwiching a pair with a filling. That happened some 60 or so years ago.

headline: Jersey Tomatoes? Jersey Ketchup!
text: This Labor Day, you can let loose those locavore instincts and slather your burgers with new seasonal ketchup made from New Jersey tomatoes. First Field, a company in Princeton, makes the ketchup from sustainably grown tomatoes seasoned with onions, cider vinegar, organic sugar, soybean oil, salt and spices. It is not quite as silky as the supermarket icon, and its flavor is a bit more robust. And after September, it will be gone until next year.

headline: Mediterranean Supplies, Downtown
text: For years, diners at Il Buco, a rustic Italian restaurant just off the Bowery on Bond Street, have been able to buy the olive oils, vinegars and salt that Donna Lennard, an owner, imports from Italy for the restaurant. Now she is formally going into the retail business, with a market set to open on Friday.

headline: Former Territory Inciting Violence at Border, Sudan Tells the U.N.
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — The Sudanese government has filed a complaint with the Security Council that South Sudan, its newly independent neighbor and former territory, is inciting violence and instability in the Nuba Mountains region of Sudan, a volatile border area where United Nations officials warn that war crimes may have been committed in recent months.

headline: On the Court, Bubka Looks for His Own Fame
text: It used to bother Sergei Bubka, the tennis player and son of the legendary Ukrainian pole vaulter with the same name, when reporters would ask him about his father.

headline: Admiral Defends Use of Elite Unit in Calamitous Raid
text: TAMPA, Fla. — The new commander of American Special Operations forces has defended the use of commandos in a Navy Seals unit to back up a raid in Afghanistan earlier this month that ended in tragedy when a Chinook helicopter was shot down, rejecting criticism that planning for the operation was different from other missions that had been carried out successfully, as many as a dozen on a typical night.

headline: Unfamiliar Path Unfolds at Tennessee
text: Mickie DeMoss had been away from the Tennessee women’s basketball program for seven years, working as a head coach and an assistant elsewhere, when she gave in to Pat Summitt’s entreaties to come back last year as an assistant. It was a chance to go home, to return to the place she had worked for 18 years for her beloved mentor. But when DeMoss started work, she was immediately struck by changes she saw in Summitt.

headline: Panel Hears Grim Details of Venereal Disease Tests
text: Gruesome details of American-run venereal disease experiments on Guatemalan prisoners, soldiers and mental patients in the years after World War II were revealed this week during hearings before a White House bioethics panel investigating the study’s sordid history.

headline: Latest Trial Set to Begin in Insider Trading Inquiry
text: A former salesman at a Silicon Valley research company is set to go on trial Wednesday on insider trading charges, the latest in the federal government’s sprawling investigation.

headline: On a Postindustrial Potomac, an Old Plant Gives Way
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — For much of the history of this city on the Potomac, industry has dominated its waterfront, from its postcolonial role as a port for the nation’s capital, to the World War I era when torpedoes were made here, to more recent years when a Ford plant handled parts distribution and warehouses stored newsprint delivered by boat.

headline: Zone for 9/11 Compensation in Lower Manhattan Is Expanded
text: The special master of a fund created to compensate people who became sick after being exposed to the toxic cloud from ground zero has announced that the fund will enlarge the zone considered part of the 9/11 crash site to cover all of Lower Manhattan south of Canal Street.

headline: Casting a Long Shadow
text: John Isner appreciates, but does not celebrate, or elevate, the marathon tennis match that continues to define him. He views it as a feat of endurance, a historical quirk, but not much more.

headline: The Advantages of Breaking Up
Chinese Telecom Executive Sentenced to Death for Bribery
text: SHANGHAI — A former executive at China Mobile, one of this country’s biggest state-owned telecommunications companies, was sentenced to death with a two-year reprieve Tuesday for accepting bribes, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency.

headline: Coming Up at the ‘21’ Club, Beer on Tap in a Swivel Stool
text: TRADITION relinquishes its grasp but slowly in the power-dining precincts of that 81-year-old former speakeasy, the “21” Club. Still disputed is the reconfiguration of its 32-foot-long mahogany bar in 1997. In 2006, there was the much-debated banishment of the brass spittoons (only one holdout has survived, by the lobby stairs). There was the controversial revocation of the dinnertime necktie rule in 2009.

headline: One-Hour Texas Chili
text: Adapted from “The Homesick Texan Cookbook” by Lisa Fain (Hyperion)

headline: A Great Big Texas Helping of Home
text: AN unexpected highlight of my summer reading was a book featuring a hot and juicy threesome: jalapeño, cilantro and lime. Lisa Fain calls these the Tex-Mex trinity, which is a recurrent combination in her “Homesick Texan Cookbook” (Hyperion, $29.99), to be published on Sept. 13.

headline: Fantasy U.S. Open: Stefan Edberg
text: Jeffrey Marcus explains why Ivan Lendl was a great Open champion and how he could defeat Pete Sampras in a hypothetical Open match.

headline: At N.L.R.B., Flurry of Acts for Unions as Chief Exits
text: The National Labor Relations Board on Tuesday released a decision that would make it easier to unionize nursing home workers.

headline: Nights and Weekends
text: 1 Bedford Avenue (Manhattan Avenue), Greenpoint, Brooklyn; (718) 383-5349; nightsandweekendsny.com.

headline: Covering 2012, Youths on the Bus
text: WASHINGTON — A group of five fresh-faced reporters from National Journal and CBS News clicked away on their MacBooks one recent afternoon, dutifully taking notes as seasoned journalists from the campaign trail shared their rules of the road.

headline: Gulbis Forgoes Partying Well for Playing Well
text: Tuesday was Ernests Gulbis’s 23rd birthday, an occasion he commemorated with a commanding 6-2, 6-4, 6-4 upset of Mikhail Youzhny, the 16th seed at this year’s United States Open and a singles semifinalist a year ago. It was the first Grand Slam match victory in more than two years for Gulbis, a first-rate moneyed player from Latvia frequently undone by a second-rate everyday work ethic.

headline: Bi Lokma
text: 212 East 45th Street (between Second and Third Avenues); (212) 687-3842; bi-lokma.com.

headline: Republican Staff Member, Steeped in Tax Law, Is Chosen to Lead Deficit Panel Staff
text: WASHINGTON — Even in the silence of the August recess, the special Congressional committee focused on deficit reduction has begun to hum to life. On Tuesday, the panel announced it had chosen a veteran Senate Republican staff member to take over the challenging job of running the bipartisan panel and its staff.

headline: New Claims Against Man Accused of Framing His Ex-Girlfriend for Robberies
text: Last December, a Queens woman was released from prison after prosecutors said her former boyfriend, Jerry Ramrattan, had framed her for a series of brazen armed robberies that never took place.

headline: The Value of an Ace Like Sabathia
text: BOSTON

headline: Avastin Injections Are Reported to Cause Blindness
text: At least 16 people in two states have gotten severe eye infections, and some have been blinded, from injections of the drug Avastin, according to health authorities and to lawyers representing the patients.

headline: High Above the Hog
text: Asheville, N.C.

headline: On the Move, Athletically, Against Arthritis
text: THE Arthritis Foundation is taking a new tack with its public service advertising, introducing a hard-hitting campaign that urges people to take up exercise as a weapon against pain.

headline: Players Question New Tests for H.G.H.
text: Negotiations toward establishing a testing program for human growth hormone are at a standstill, the players union said Tuesday, and expectations are dimming that a program can be put in place to start testing by the start of the regular season next week.

headline: Tight Budget? Look to the ‘Cloud’
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Tripoli Divided as Rebels Jostle to Fill Power Vacuum
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Fighters from the western mountain city of Zintan control the airport. The fighters from Misurata guard the central bank, the port and the prime minister’s office, where their graffiti has relabeled the historic plaza “Misurata Square.” Berbers from the mountain town Yafran took charge of the city’s central square, where they spray-painted “Yafran Revolutionaries.”

headline: Surge in Global Migration Expands Scale of an Aid Group’s Influence
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — As global migration has rapidly expanded, so has the influence of a little-known group whose eclectic work shapes migrants’ lives across six continents.

headline: David Ferrer Makes Up for Height Disadvantage With Speed
text: After winning his first-round match at the United States Open on Tuesday, the Spaniard David Ferrer flung his soaked white headband onto the court and jogged to greet his opponent, his longtime friend Igor Andreev.

headline: Trouble at a Bar, a Suspected Break-In, Then a Fatal Standoff With the Nassau Police
text: There was trouble at the Buoy Bar, a dockside hangout in Point Lookout, N.Y., and Kurt Doerbecker was the apparent cause.

headline: What Price Life?
text: So the big, bad storm huffed and puffed and didn’t blow all the houses in.

headline: In Latest Breach, Hackers Impersonate Google to Snoop on Users in Iran
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Hackers passed themselves off as the Internet giant Google with the apparent goal of snooping on people using Google services in Iran, the company said.

headline: U.S. Open Point/Counterpoint: Pete Sampras vs. Ivan Lendl
text: Fantasy U.S. Open Tournament: Who are the two greatest U.S. Open champions from the past 30 years? It’s up to you to decide, with a little help from The Times’s tennis experts. Watch our video debates, vote on the winner and then explain your position in the comments section.

headline: The New Resentment of the Poor
text: In a decade of frenzied tax-cutting for the rich, the Republican Party just happened to lower tax rates for the poor, as well. Now several of the party’s most prominent presidential candidates and lawmakers want to correct that oversight and raise taxes on the poor and the working class, while protecting the rich, of course.

headline: Federal Austerity Changes Disaster Relief
text: WASHINGTON — As Senator Bernard Sanders toured Vermont by helicopter on Tuesday to assess the damage from what he said could be his state’s worst-ever natural disaster, the idea of cutting other federal programs to aid towns pummeled by Hurricane Irene was stoking his outrage.

headline: Christine Lagarde’s Tough Message
text: Less than two months after being chosen to lead the International Monetary Fund, Christine Lagarde shook up last weekend’s conference of central bankers in Jackson Hole, Wyo., with an urgent, much needed plea for bolder economic policies in the United States and Europe to head off a looming double-dip recession.

headline: Wednesday: Sting Like a ‘B’
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s creation from Peter A. Collins floats like a butterfly and stings like a B, in a puzzle that incorporates boxing, bullfighting and the Beach Boys.

headline: Safety Report on Vaccines
text: A comprehensive evaluation of eight common childhood vaccines has found that any adverse effects from vaccines are very rare or very minor. The report, issued last week by a panel of experts assembled by the Institute of Medicine, said there is no evidence that childhood vaccines cause autism, diabetes, facial palsy or episodes of asthma, as some people fear.

headline: For Congress in New York’s Ninth District
text: When Representative Anthony Weiner resigned in disgrace in June, he left his diverse district without a voice in the House of Representatives. On Sept. 13, voters in that Queens and Brooklyn district can choose his replacement.

headline: Bullying Law Puts New Jersey Schools on Spot
text: Under a new state law in New Jersey, lunch-line bullies in the East Hanover schools can be reported to the police by their classmates this fall through anonymous tips to the Crimestoppers hot line.

headline: Despite Risks, Romney Presses Grim Picture of Obama
text: Mitt Romney warned on Tuesday that America was on the brink of “profound economic misery,” the latest effort by the Republican presidential candidate to paint an unrelentingly grim picture of the country under President Obama’s leadership.

headline: With Help Online, French Farmers Now Playing the Field
text: LASSAY-LES-CHATEAUX, France — Patrick Maignan, a robust gray-haired farmer, lives alone on his farm, surrounded only by the freshly plowed wheat fields of this lonely corner of northern France.

headline: Mismanagement Blamed for Bay Area Gas Disaster
text: WASHINGTON — The main cause of the natural gas pipeline rupture in San Bruno, Calif., that killed eight people and burned three dozen houses last September was 54 years of bad management by the Pacific Gas & Electric Company, and state and federal regulators who did not notice the problem, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.

headline: Old Hand at Hurricanes, Cuomo Leads Response

headline: Brave, Foolhardy and Just Unlucky: The Lives Lost in a Storm’s Watery Fury
text: In the Bronx, Jose Sierra ignored his sister’s warning not to check on the boat his wife had gotten him as a gift. In Bristol, Conn., Shane Seaver and a friend could not resist the impulse to view the storm’s destruction from a canoe. In Princeton, N.J., Michael Kenwood waded into angry waters to try to save someone who might have been trapped in a car.

headline: Park’s Rules on Scarves Are Cited in a Melee
text: A scuffle broke out at an amusement park in Westchester County on Tuesday when a group of Muslims there to celebrate the end of Ramadan were told that women could not wear their head coverings on certain rides, park officials and witnesses said. Fifteen people were arrested.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Profits Before Environment
text: I wasn’t surprised when the administration of George W. Bush sacrificed the environment for corporate profits. But when the same thing happens under a Democratic administration, it’s depressing. With little or no public input, policies that benefit corporations regardless of the consequences continue to be enacted.

headline: Cursing and Consequences
text: The ArtsBeat blog has a post on the consequences of swearing in soccer. The rules say it should produce an automatic red card from the referee, but a study found that’s not always the case. Read the entire post here, and share your comments.

headline: Upstate Farmers Find That a Fertile Flood Plain Is a Two-Edged Sword

Should Harry and Luka make up at Tottenham? Is Owen’s career in low-budget Internet films over? Can Arsène buy true love, or at least a midfielder who won’t stomp on his heart or opponents’ calves? headline: Western Officials Seek Softer Approach to Militants in Nigeria

headline: Kansas City School District Loses Leader Who Began Turnaround Effort
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — John Covington arrived here two years ago with the promise of transforming a district that had become synonymous with the failures of urban education. He even managed to win support for his drastic recommendation to shut down nearly half its schools, saying it was a necessary step to achieve desperately needed stability.

headline: Town Draws Together in the Midst of Losses
text: WILLIAMSVILLE, Vt. — The gas lamp and candles that Melvin and Norma Shakun had prepared for Hurricane Irene are still sitting on the kitchen table in their 200-year-old home here.

headline: Kenya: Officials’ Cases to Go Forward
text: Kenya’s government has lost its bid to block the prosecution of senior politicians before the International Criminal Court in The Hague. On Tuesday, appeals judges ruled that they had found insufficient evidence that Kenya’s government was investigating the cases, as it had long claimed. The prosecutor has accused six Kenyans, including the deputy prime minister, two former ministers and a former police chief, of orchestrating large-scale violence after the 2007 elections. More than 1,200 people died and several hundred thousand fled their homes. The decision means that the next stage of the criminal proceedings, confirmation of charges, can go ahead in The Hague this week.

headline: Rivalry Heats Up as Yankees Draw Closer in the Division Race
text: BOSTON — Another spark was thrown into the combustible rivalry between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox Tuesday, when players fumed, benches emptied and coaches were ejected.

headline: China: Sentence in Monk’s Suicide
text: A Chinese court sentenced a Tibetan monk to 11 years in prison on Monday for his role in the death of a fellow monk who set himself on fire in March to protest government policies, according to Xinhua, China’s official news agency. The Chinese court found the 46-year-old monk, Drongdru, guilty of “intentional homicide” in the death of his nephew, a 16-year-old monk, in Sichuan Province. Prosecutors say that after the teenager immolated himself, Drongdru and two other monks hid him and delayed emergency treatment.

headline: AT&T Plans to Bring Back Jobs Sent Abroad
text: AT&T, its $39 billion deal to buy T-Mobile USA under pressure from multiple fronts, is now seeking to promote one benefit of the blockbuster deal: jobs.

headline: As Refugees From Haiti Linger, Dominicans’ Good Will Fades

headline: Prescribing Exercise to Treat Depression
text: Can a stroll help ease depression? That question preoccupied Dr. Madhukar H. Trivedi, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, after several of his patients, all suffering from serious depression, mentioned that they felt happier if they went for a walk. The patients in question were taking the widely prescribed antidepressants known as S.S.R.I.’s, for selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, but not responding fully. They remained, by clinical standards, depressed. Dr. Trivedi and his colleagues began to wonder if adding a formal “dose” of exercise would increase their chances of getting better.

headline: Where Pay for Chiefs Outstrips U.S. Taxes
text: At least 25 top United States companies paid more to their chief executives in 2010 than they did to the federal government in taxes, according to a study released on Wednesday.

headline: Poking Fun at the Mayor, El Leadero in el Stormo
text: Rachel Figueroa-Levin has a dog, three cats, five fish, a snake, a turtle, a parakeet, a gecko (“like the Geico lizard,” she explained) and two sugar gliders (picture little flying opossums). The gliders’ cage sits beside a screen that streams “Sesame Street” videos for her 9-month-old daughter, Adiella, whose playpen and bouncer are strategically arranged by the living room’s centerpiece: a Macintosh computer where Ms. Figueroa-Levin blogs, posts messages on Twitter, and writes about, well, anything.

headline: Susan Fromberg Schaeffer, Inventive Novelist, Dies at 71
text: Susan Fromberg Schaeffer, a novelist with a gift for evoking complex characters in the grip of extreme psychological stress and physical suffering, notably in “The Madness of a Seduced Woman” and the Vietnam War novel “Buffalo Afternoon,” died on Friday in Chicago. She was 71.

headline: Patrick C. Fischer, Early Unabomber Target, Is Dead at 75
text: Patrick C. Fischer, a computer scientist whose theoretical work helped make Internet searches possible, but who was most widely known as an early target of the so-called Unabomber, died on Friday in Montgomery County, Md. He was 75.

Getting around New York City is far less problematic than it was before with PATH trains, buses and subways all running. Amtrak is running again between Washington and Boston. Even some suburban lines are springing back to life.

headline: Syria’s Sons of No One
text: It was past 11 a.m., and Abdullah was finally waking up. The night before had gone late, he and his friends challenging and daring and fleeing from the feared mukhabarat, Syria’s secret police, who for the past five months have been bent on crushing dissent here in Homs. With a few hours of sleep behind him, Abdullah rolled off his mattress and began tapping out details of their exploits on his laptop. The clashes had been fierce and lasted hours, past the muezzin’s call to prayer at dawn. “We won’t bow to anyone but God,” the protesters declared. The mukhabarat replied with tear gas, buckshot and bullets. “Hot” was how Abdullah described it as he typed.

headline: How Sassy Is Tavi Gevinson?
text: When the teenage fashion blogger Tavi Gevinson announced last November that she was joining forces with the editor Jane Pratt to start a magazine modeled after Pratt’s much-mourned Sassy, the blogosphere lit up with excitement. For a generation of women, Sassy — with its indie ethos and straight talk about weighty topics like feminism and sex — was a seminal magazine: it not only changed their expectations of media, but it also changed how they saw themselves. Gevinson seemed the perfect choice to lend the old-media Pratt some new-media fame. Her precocious blog, Style Rookie, has, in a mere three and a half years, made her a darling of the fashion establishment — she has written for Harper’s Bazaar, served as muse for Rodarte’s Target line, sat front row at the Marc Jacobs runway show and been the subject of a profile in The New Yorker. Even so, a few carped that she intended to edit a publication inspired by one that folded in 1996, the year she was born.

headline: The Fluid Human Dance That Is Grand Central
text: Every city has its own choreography, formal or informal. The composer John Cage loved to point out how any street corner is theater of a kind; the dance critic and poet Edwin Denby wrote ardently of how daily life was full of things to see; and when one of Merce Cunningham’s dancers asked what a piece was about, he took her to the window, showed her the view of the sidewalk and said, “That.”

So consider some of the ways in which we in the five boroughs have focused on what we consider the truly important stuff.

headline: Bus Driver Files Assault Charge Against ‘Lost’ Star Matthew Fox
text: Here’s another outcome that “Lost” fans aren’t going to be happy with: Matthew Fox, a star of that twisty-turny, probably made-up-as-it-went-along ABC drama, has been charged with assault by a bus driver who says he punched her outside a Cleveland nightclub, CNN reported. The bus driver, Heather Bormann, said that Mr. Fox tried to board the charter vehicle she was driving early Sunday morning for a bachelor party he was not invited to, and that he became physical when she barred him from entering. “I told him, ‘Sorry, buddy, this is a private party,’ ” Ms. Bormann told Cleveland.com. ” ‘You get off my vehicle.’ I told him three times.” Mr. Fox, who is in Cleveland shooting the film “I, Alex Cross,” was allowed to take a taxi back to his hotel.

headline: The Role of Values in Driving Climate Disputes
text: Reacting to yesterday’s piece on how better definitions of terms could help clarify climate disputes, Oran Switzer of Phoenix, Ariz., posted a comment reminding folks how values, more than data, largely shape positions on the level of risk posed by greenhouse gases. This is a theme stressed by Dan Kahan and other researchers studying cultural cognition.

headline: Documenting a Collapsing Ice Shelf
text: One of the more dramatic events in the Arctic in recent years was the detachment, in 2010, of a large section of the ice shelf attached to Petermann Glacier, in northwest Greenland. The possible connection of this event to global warming drew immediate interest, including a hearing in Congress.

headline: Six Actors No Longer in Search of a Play
text: LIKE a clumsy kid in the schoolyard Shakespeare’s late play “Cymbeline” has suffered plenty of bullying. George Bernard Shaw called it “exasperating beyond all tolerance.” Henry James named it “a florid fairy tale.” And Samuel Johnson, its chief tormenter, said that to discuss the play “were to waste criticism upon unresisting imbecility, upon faults too evident for detection, and too gross for aggravation.”

headline: The Social Scene Spa-Francorchamps
text: The Spa-Francorchamps circuit where the Belgian Grand Prix took place last weekend is considered one of the best on the Formula One calendar. But the track is in the Ardennes Forest, far from any major city, and bad weather is almost a given during race weekend, so Spa is rarely a very big place in terms of visits from stars or dignitaries, or any other kind of party-like atmosphere.

headline: Broadway Cast for ‘Chinglish’ Is Announced
text: The “Gatz” star Gary Wilmes, who played Tom Buchanan in that nearly seven-hour-long Elevator Repair Service adaptation of “The Great Gatsby,” will be getting less stage time in his next project, though it’s hardly a demotion. Mr. Wilmes is set to start in the coming Broadway transfer of “Chinglish,” the David Henry Hwang comedy about an American businessman who encounters linguistic and cultural difficulties on a trip to China, its press representatives said Wednesday. Jennifer Lim, who played a strong-willed Chinese official in the play’s Chicago production at the Goodman Theater, will reprise her role on Broadway, as will the cast members Angela Lin, Christine Lin, Stephen Pucci, Johnny Wu and Larry Zhang. Leigh Silverman, who directed “Chinglish” in Chicago, will also stay on for the Broadway run, which will be presented at the Longacre Theater. It is scheduled to begin previews Oct. 11 and open Oct. 27.

headline: Iran Concerned West Will Benefit From Arab Uprisings

headline: Program Hopes to Make Broadway Friendlier to Those With Autism
text: Earlier this month the Theater Development Fund, the nonprofit organization that runs the city’s TKTS discount ticket booths, announced that it was starting the Autism Theater Initiative, which aims to make theatergoing accessible to children and adults living on the autism spectrum. The program kicks off on Oct. 2 with a sold-out matinee of “The Lion King” for what T.D.F., in a news release, calls “the first ever autism-friendly performance in Broadway history.”

headline: Stanford’s New Coach Fulfills 2 Dreams
text: Soon after he graduated from Stanford, David Shaw met Kori Bevans. They saw “Apollo 13” on their first date, then went to Jack in the Box and ordered two tacos and two fries.

headline: Obama Reschedules Economy Speech at Boehner’s Request
text: 9:40 p.m. | Updated President Obama acquiesced to a request from Speaker John A. Boehner on Wednesday to move the date of his proposed address to a joint session of Congress to Thursday Sept. 8, after Mr. Boehner all but rejected Mr. Obama’s request to speak next Wednesday.

headline: G.O.P. Congressman Might Leave Black Caucus Over Remarks
text: Well, it was interesting while it lasted.

headline: A Redesigned Brand Hopes to Avoid Tropicana Storm
text: As an up-and-coming beverage brand gets a new look, executives are hoping to avoid a redesign debacle like the one that roiled Tropicana orange juice.

headline: Lipitor, Available to Anyone
text: Reading through Twitter recently, I came upon a dramatic tweet from the normally mild-mannered Dr. Ken Covinsky, a geriatrician at the University of California, San Francisco and the San Francisco VA Medical Center. He was reacting to news reports that Pfizer wants to turn its cholesterol drug Lipitor into an over-the-counter medication.

headline: Land Rover DC100: a Return to Rugged?
text: The Land Rover Defender, the blocky British off-roader that helped set the table for the modern  S.U.V., will re-emerge, if only in spirit, at the Frankfurt auto show next month.

headline: The Role of Buildings and Cities in Cutting Energy Waste
text: The Canadian public affairs program The Agenda is running segments all this week on ways to enable human prosperity with less energy. The pieces were recorded at a summit on energy options through 2030, held at the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics earlier this year (which I’m thrilled to see has been working on the practical end of physics, too, by hosting this and previous events). Here’s today’s installment and a summary of the themes:

headline: For Nadal, It’s All About Finding ‘Solutions’
text: The second question of Rafael Nadal’s post-match press conference Tuesday night pointed out that he had lost his serve six times in his match with Andreiy Golubev, while last year he was only broken five times in the whole tournament. He drew laughter from reporters when he replied, “Is impossible to win this year. No, I am joking.”

headline: Famed Guitar Maker Raided by Federal Agents
text: Tracing what they say is an illegal shipment of Indian hardwood, federal agents raided offices and factories belonging to Gibson Guitar Corporation last week for the second time in two years, seizing documents, computer hard drives, pallets of wood, guitars and tools.

headline: Essential Summer Dishes: Submit Your Photos and Recipes
text: Food writers for The Times shared recipes and memories of their essential foods of summer this week. Use this form to share the best dishes you’ve made since Memorial Day, whether they were grilled or iced, old standbys or fresh triumphs. A selection of the best photos and recipes will be displayed at nytimes.com/dining.

headline: A 14-Year-Old Boy Is Killed in Bahrain as Security Forces Break Up a Protest
text: A 14-year-old boy was killed Wednesday as security forces in Sitra, Bahrain, broke up a small protest. Witnesses said the boy was struck in the head by a tear gas canister that the security forces fired directly into the crowd at close range, and died shortly afterward at a hospital.

headline: Delay Worth the Wait as Game Tops Album Chart
text: After almost two years of delays for Game’s newest release, “The R.E.D. Album” (DGC/Interscope) — and a promotional campaign that included the West Coast rapper sporting a red-dyed mohawk — it opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with 98,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Game narrowly beat Jay-Z and Kanye West’s “Watch the Throne” (Roc-a-Fella/Def Jam/Roc Nation), which had 94,000 sales in its third week out.

headline: Job Insecurity Remains High
text: For the last couple of years, the problem plaguing the job market was that companies have been in a holding pattern: Companies weren’t laying off workers in high numbers. But if you were already laid off, finding a company willing to expand was impossible.

headline: Giants Trim Roster; Jets Stick With Folk
text: GIANTS TRIM ROSTER TO 85 The Giants placed wide receiver Ramses Barden and center Adam Koets on the physically unable to perform list, meaning neither player will be eligible until at least Week 7 of the season.

headline: S.E.C. Examines Mutual Funds’ Use of Derivatives
text: Securities regulators are weighing new rules for mutual funds that invest in derivatives, the complex securities that wreaked havoc on the financial industry during the credit crisis.

headline: Karma by the Cup
text: Anyone who has ever been desperate for a cup of coffee will appreciate a new trend cropping up in Berlin.

headline: Fantasy Football: Preseason Week 3 Recap
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football draft. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Mel Gibson and Former Girlfriend Reach Custody Accord
text: LOS ANGELES — After more than a year in court, Mel Gibson and his ex-girlfriend Oksana Grigorieva ended a custody battle over their 2-year-old child, Lucia, with an omnibus settlement much of which was described by a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge at a hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Texas A&M Sets a Date to Leave the Big 12
text: Texas A&M’s break from the Big 12 arrived Wednesday morning, the next mile marker in its quest to join the Southeastern Conference.

headline: Reacting to Justice’s Suit Against AT&T
text: As the biggest telecom deal in years, one that could reshape the American wireless landscape, AT&T‘s $39 billion purchase of T-Mobile USA drew scores of supporters and critics alike.

headline: The Fine Print: No Bricklin, Excalibur or DeLorean Rentals for Chase Cardholders
text: A few weeks ago, I received a new credit card I’d signed up for — Chase’s Continental Airlines Presidential Plus card. (Just getting the card was a whole other story.) The card comes with a number of perks, including the ability to waive additional insurance when renting a car.

headline: Lucasfilm Confirms Change to Blu-ray Release of ‘Return of the Jedi’
text: It’s an event that seems to happen in the “Star Wars” world about as often as Wookiees celebrate Life Day, and which fans await with just as much dread. New versions of George Lucas’s space-fantasy films are released, and with them come changes to the movies – alterations to audio and video, characters’ actions and even dialogue that is very different from what fans remember seeing in theaters a long time ago and far, far away.

headline: Back to the Desert
text: With “Tassili,” the band Tinariwen has sought to return to its beginnings.

headline: The Caucus | Jobs Plans Aplenty
text: A look ahead as President Obama and Republican candidates are set to release their plans for jobs. Also, a report from Capitol Hill as the committee charged with taming the deficit begins work.

headline: Myanmar Soccer Fans Given Freedom of Raucous Speech
text: YANGON, Myanmar — The hardships and oppression of living in an authoritarian country like Myanmar all but vanish at the gates of its soccer stadiums. Or so say the fans, who swarm into the grandstands for a carnival of drunken revelry that would never be tolerated outside the stadium walls.

headline: U.S. Moves to Block Merger Between AT&T and T-Mobile
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Wednesday sued to block the proposed $39 billion merger between the cellphone giants AT&T and T-Mobile USA, arguing that keeping them separate would preserve competition in the wireless industry and even help save jobs of American workers.

headline: Courtside: Roddick Creeping Out of the Spotlight
text: Andy Roddick has played in many prime time matches before, but this year he is not the focus of the American men. Lynn Zinser reports.

headline: Even in Defeat, Keys Is Impressive
text: The September issue of GQ magazine features a story that is highly critical of U.S. tennis but anyone who saw 16-year-old American Madison Keys nearly upset Lucie Safarova, the tournament’s 27th seed Wednesday, would have to conclude that the future of American tennis may not be quite so bleak. Keys’ upset bid faltered, 3-6, 7-5, 6-4, but she looked very much like a contender despite losing a dramatic, 2 hour and 24 minute contest to an older and more experienced player.

headline: Roddick Is Able to Forge Ahead as Younger Americans Start to Rise
text: Andy Roddick arrived at this United States Open without, really, any serious expectations. His hardcourt season was an odd mix of injury and combustion. His status as a Grand Slam contender was slipping, if not already gone.

headline: Courtside: Roddick Out of the Spotlight
text: Andy Roddick has played in many prime time matches before, but this year he is not the focus of the American men.

headline: The Cavalier
text: Like Coco Chanel, Pierre-Henri Mattout was born in Saumur, the medieval French town in the Loire Valley famous among wine snobs for its superb cabernet franc appellation, Saumur-Champigny. The town also happens to be an equestrian center of France, home to the Cadre Noir, one of the world’s most prestigious riding schools. “It’s very uptight, very bourgeois and very elegant,” says Mattout, who, as a p’tit garçon, dreamed not of mounting a Lusitano but of being the academy’s head tailor. Accordingly, Mattout’s latest men’s collection — all jodhpur-style chinos, leather elbow patches and whipcord wool blazers in dragoon red — is a paean to his horse-loving hometown. But rather than reboot some bygone vision of aristo chic, Mattout drew on his design experience at Dior Homme, Dunhill and Victorinox. The result is a modern sportswear collection of uncommon elegance, detail-obsessed yet refreshingly remote from the work-wear-inspired stuff that’s glutting American runways.

headline: ‘Real Housewives of Beverly Hills’ to Air With Suicide-Prevention Announcements
text: LOS ANGELES — When the second season of “The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” has its debut on Sept. 5 it will be accompanied by public service announcements about suicide prevention, the Bravo Media president Frances Berwick said in a statement Wednesday.

headline: Caucus Video: Job Plans Aplenty From 2012 Candidates; the Debt Committee Begins Work
text: Jeff Zeleny and Michael D. Shear look ahead as President Obama and Republican candidates are set to release their plans for jobs. Also, Jennifer Steinhauer reports from Capitol Hill as the committee charged with taming the deficit begins work.

headline: Evaluation of World Bank Gives Mixed Picture
text: LONDON — The World Bank is doing better at helping poor countries fight corruption and strengthen their institutions, but it has a long way to go toward matching its own ambitions in the area, according to a report released Wednesday.

headline: Earliest Signs of Advanced Tools Found
text: One hallmark of Homo erectus, a forerunner of modern humans, was his stone tools, an advanced technology reflecting a good deal of forethought and dexterity. Up to now, however, scientists have been unable to pin a firm date on the earliest known evidence of his stone tool-making.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, China, Libya and Slovenia.

headline: NBC Wins Ratings Race on Tuesday
text: NBC was the No. 1 broadcast network on Tuesday, partly because it was the only network that showed a full night of original programming. It averaged just under 8.8 million total viewers. With no real competition, “America’s Got Talent” was the most-watched show with 10.9 million total viewers, although it was still down when compared with last week, according to Nielsen data. CBS was second in total viewers (8.2 million) with three hours of repeats from its “NCIS” franchise. The Spanish-language Univision finished second for the night in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic.

headline: Q&A: Separating Messages in Gmail
text: Q.

headline: A Minimalist Take on a Cambodian Country Home
text: Built on stilts and surrounded by water and lush greenery, a house in Siem Reap merges tradition with modernity.

headline: In Cambodia, a Contemporary Home in a Pastoral Setting
text: SIEM REAP, Cambodia — As a young Cambodian architect in the 1960s, Borath Ros never imagined it would take nearly half a century before he would see his tropical dream house come to fruition. Nor could he have predicted that his son and daughter would help him design it.

headline: Kelli O’Hara Will Star Opposite Matthew Broderick in ‘Nice Work If You Can Get It’
text: Kelli O’Hara will be the leading lady in the new Broadway musical “Nice Work If You Can Get It,” the producers announced on Wednesday. She will star opposite Matthew Broderick in the show, which includes songs from the George and Ira Gershwin catalog and a book by Joe DiPietro (“Memphis”). Kathleen Marshall (“Anything Goes”) will be the director and choreographer.

headline: Zvonareva Raises Her Voice, Wins a Round
text: The on-court tantrums and meltdowns that once were the hallmark of her game seemed to have been eliminated when Vera Zvonareva reached her first Grand Slam final at Wimbledon in 2010.

headline: ‘Red’
text: Photos from the Broadway play about the painter Mark Rothko.

headline: For Graduates, a Shrinking Payoff
text: Attention recent college graduates — as well as parents who covered those big tuition bills. You may not want to hear this, but a study released on Wednesday found that entry-level wages for students who graduated from college in 2010 was lower than a decade earlier, after adjusting for inflation.

headline: Scientology Strikes Back at The New Yorker
text: The Church of Scientology is certainly no shrinking violet when it comes to defending itself.

headline: Hold Everything
text: The actress Anne Hathaway has been living la vita Tod’s ever since she got her saddle-colored D Bag. Now, Hathaway, who’s also the face of the brand, can expect still more baggage as Tod’s introduces its Signature collection, built around the iconic pebble. There are eight styles to choose from, including envelope clutches and shoulder bags. The Shopper ($2,165), an oversize bag with a drawstring closure, would appear to be the perfect choice for Hathaway, but she seems preoccupied with her “new envelope clutch and iPad case in black,” she says. “They’re just so sleek.”

headline: Storm’s Cost May Reach $1 Billion, Cuomo Says
text: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday that he expected damage in the state from Tropical Storm Irene to reach “close to $1 billion,” though he assured residents that there would be sufficient state and federal financial assistance for the recovery effort.

headline: Buffett Investment Could Erode Confidence in Big Banks
text: Last week, our financial Superman, the mild-mannered Midwesterner Warren E. Buffett, swooped in again to save another bank, the financial markets, the American economy and just maybe our precious way of life.

headline: Teaching 9/11 | Ideas and Projects From Teachers
text: Sept. 8, 2011 | Updated

headline: Imagining the Rolling Stones Without Keith Richards
text: Today in The New York Times Janet Maslin reviews Marc Spitz’s new book, “Jagger: Rebel, Rock Star, Rambler, Rogue.” She liked the book, and so do I. It argues against the prevailing and increasingly boring theory that Keith Richards is the Stones’ main claim to authenticity, the soul of the band, the principal force of their sound and songcraft, and that Mick Jagger is a shallow socialite poseur. If you were persuaded by Keith Richards’ strong attitudes in his memoir, “Life” — which has sold a million copies worldwide in under a year, according to a recent statement by its American publisher — you may believe in this theory yourself.

headline: App Smart Extra: 70 Catalogs on One App
text: Last week’s App Smart column, on big-box shopping apps, pointed out the strengths and, more frequently, the weaknesses of the category.

headline: Warnings and the Cost of Storms and Climate Change
text: Casey B. Mulligan, an economics professor at the University of Chicago, has a post on the Economix blog that looks at the Northeast’s recent weather-related disaster and the long-term trajectory for climate change and expresses confidence that the costs attending environmental threats are lower when they can be anticipated.

headline: If You Ain’t Bleedin’, You Ain’t Leadin’
text: Catfish hunters compete in the 12th annual Okie Noodling Tournament that climaxes with a weigh-in of the still-living catfish.

headline: Rating the No. 1’s: ‘Justice League’
text: Times staffers and comic-book fans George Gene Gustines and Adam W. Kepler will review all of the 52 DC Comics titles that have been rebooted as part of a company-wide effort to resuscitate the brand. In the first of five weekly installments they discuss Justice League, which came out on Wednesday. Next week they’ll look at 13 other first issues, including Action Comics.

headline: A Chance to Peek Inside Yaddo
text: For more than a century, Yaddo, the private artists’ colony on 400 acres of woods in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has been a haven for writers, painters and composers. In cozy studios there, Patricia Highsmith wrote “Strangers on a Train,” Aaron Copland created his “Piano Variations,” and authors like Eudora Welty, Truman Capote and Langston Hughes spent productive time.

headline: Justice Department’s Complaint in AT&T and T-Mobile Case
text: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit to block the proposed $39 billion merger between AT&T and T-Mobile USA on antitrust grounds.

headline: In Yet Another Upset, McHale Defeats Bartoli
text: Christina McHale, an American teenager, toppled eighth-seeded Marion Bartoli of France, smashing an ace up the middle of the court on match point, for a 7-6 (2), 6-2 victory at the U.S. Open.

headline: Tea Party Groups to Protest Romney in N.H.
text: Many Tea Party supporters have been less than enthusiastic about the prospect of Mitt Romney becoming the Republican nominee for president in 2012, but now that antipathy is becoming louder.

headline: TimesCast | August 31, 2011
text: Floodwaters from Hurricane Irene cover New Jersey's suburbs; the Justice Department moves to block AT&T’s merger; and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof reports from the road  to Tripoli.

headline: For Murray, a Convincing Victory
text: Andy Murray of Great Britain rolled into the second round of the U.S. Open on Wednesday with a convincing 7-6 (5), 6-2, 6-3 victory over Somdev Devvarman of India.

headline: Unfinished Beach Boys Album Is Set for Release, 44 Years Later
text: One of the most famous unfinished recordings in the history of popular music –The Beach Boys’ “Smile” sessions — will be released in November, 44 years after it was scheduled to come out, Capitol/EMI records has announced.

text: Allan J. Lichtman, a presidential historian at American University, has issued a prediction that, given an economy still teetering on the brink of recession and President Obama’s 40 percent approval ratings, looks awfully bold.

headline: If Deal Is Killed, Wall Street Will Lose Out
text: Some $150 million in advisory fees is at risk if AT&T is thwarted in its bid to buy T-Mobile USA from Deutsche Telekom, Thomson Reuters calculates.

headline: Are You as Fertile as You Look?
text: FORTY may be the new 30, but try telling that to your ovaries.

headline: A Bungalow Frozen in Time, Till the Storm Washed It Away
text: On Saturday, there were eight wood-frame, century-old bungalows perched above Jamaica Bay on the eastern edge of Broad Channel, the small island community squeezed between the Rockaways and the Howard Beach section of Queens.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: ARGAN MADNESS Argan oil, purportedly rich in vitamins and antioxidants, continues to pop up in products, like the Zinn Beauty Collection (zinnbeauty.com), including a facial cleansing milk, anti-aging cream, body milk and a conditioning treatment for hair and skin (about $25 to $30), now at all Ricky’s New York stores. Olie Biologique is offering three new essential oils: rose hip, evening primrose and argan ($39 each at oliebiologique.com). And Sally Hershberger (sallyhershberger.com) just introduced Hyper Hydration Super Argan Serum, also infused with amla (Indian gooseberry) and rice bran oils ($15 at Duane Reade, Ulta and other locations).

headline: Bus Driver in Bronx Crash That Killed 15 Is Said to Be Indicted for Manslaughter
text: The driver of a bus that crashed and killed 15 people on a return trip to New York from a Connecticut casino in March has been indicted on multiple counts of manslaughter, a law enforcement official said Wednesday.

headline: John Paulson Gets a Brief Reprieve
text: The hedge fund magnate John A. Paulson has endured a long, hot summer, with two of his largest funds seemingly in free fall.

text: The reigning Wimbledon champions and the world’s top ranked doubles team, Mike and Bob Bryan of the United States, suffered a first-round upset at the hands of Ivo Karlovic of Croatia and Frank Moser of Germany, 6-4, 2-6, 6-2, on Wednesday at the U.S. Open.

headline: The Evolution of Binghamton, Block by Block
text: For years the evolutionary biologist David Sloan Wilson paid little attention to Binghamton, N.Y., where he lived and taught. “I hadn’t joined the PTA,” he writes, “attended council meetings, given blood, or served turkey to the homeless on Thanksgiving.” It was enough, he modestly believed, “to raise two healthy kids and work at changing the way the planet thinks about evolution.”

headline: Share Your Thoughts: A 9/11 State of Mind
text: Do you associate the events of 9/11 with a particular song, book, movie or turn of phrase?

headline: J Mays: Evos Styling Will Distinguish Ford Product ‘in Four Months’
text: The Ford Evos concept car, which is scheduled to have its debut at the Frankfurt auto show next month, represents a near-term design strategy, said J Mays, the company’s design chief, in a telephone interview on Wednesday.

headline: What Is That? Let Your Smartphone Have a Look
text: I never carry a point-and-shoot camera. Chances are you don’t either. In the last few years, cellphone optics have improved substantially. That means more megapixels, better image sensors and stronger flashes and zooms on the one device most of us carry all the time.

headline: TimesCast | U.S. Challenges Telecom Deal
