headline: Designers Start to See in Triplicate
text: WITH something like 250 runway shows and parties crammed into the New York Fashion Week that begins Sept. 8, a lot of designers are saying that there must be a better way to show clothes, or at least some way to grab people’s attention for more than a second or two.

headline: U.S. Open Replay: Day 3
text: The third day of match play saw Venus Williams withdraw from the tournament and No. 8 seed Marion Bartoli upset in straight sets.

headline: Keystone XL Is Self-Destructive. Does the Obama Administration Need to Be Also?
text: So many thoughts after today’s column, in which I wrote about the Keystone XL pipeline. If it’s approved by President Obama, it would carry diluted bitumen — acidic crude oil — 1,700 miles from the tar sands in Alberta to refineries on the Texas Gulf Coast. The Times has already come out against the pipeline, citing the risk of spills, spikes in greenhouse gas emissions and massive destruction of Canada’s boreal forest. Proponents cite job creation and “oil security.”

headline: Tribute Concert Promoters Fail to Sway Jackson Fan Clubs
text: The promoters of a Michael Jackson tribute concert tried to dispel the concerns of fan clubs Monday during a series of international conference calls on Wednesday, but leaders of some large groups said afterwards they were still opposed to the event.

headline: Obama to Visit Paterson on Sunday and the Overflowing Passaic River
text: President Obama will travel to Paterson, N.J., on Sunday to survey the damage from Tropical Storm Irene, White House officials said Wednesday.

headline: A Harlow for the New Era
text: Emily Bergl, an incandescent kewpie doll with a bright Betty Boop-inflected chirp, a defiant flounce and a sharp comedic edge, took the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel by storm on Tuesday evening. Her sensational show, “Kidding on the Square” may have played elsewhere, but arriving at the staid Oak Room it felt like a gust of fresh air that could knock you off your feet.

headline: Iraq War Marks First Month With No U.S. Military Deaths
text: BAGHDAD — Under increased pressure from the United States, an Iraqi crackdown on Iranian-backed Shiite militias has helped produce a previously elusive goal: For the first time since the American invasion of Iraq, an entire month has passed without a single United States service member dying.

headline: He’s Always Around, Showing Off His Muscles
text: The Hindi-language film “Bodyguard” has nothing to do with the   Whitney Houston and Kevin Costner love story from 1992, though it does concern an attractive woman and a man hired to protect her, and is a towering geyser of sentiment. But it’s a bit closer to Jason Statham’s “Transporter” movies, with plenty of over-the-top fight choreography. Except that the male lead isn’t tearing across the countryside in a black Audi. And there’s frustrated ardor. And music-video-style production numbers.

headline: French and Dutch Players Face Off in Croatia
text: OPATIJA, Croatia — The last event of the second World Youth Congress ended here on Tuesday. With three boards to play in the Pairs Championship, the first two pairs were playing against each other. Berend van den Bos and Joris van Lankveld from the Netherlands were leading Aymeric Lebatteux and Simon Poulat from France by 20.28 matchpoints, with 18 available on each board.

headline: New headphones from SOL Republic, digital audio in Ubuntu Linux; tech news.
text: Kevin Lee of SOL Republic introduces his company’s new line of headphones. Cristian Parrino of Canonical discusses digital audio options in the Ubuntu Linux operating system, including the Ubuntu One cloud service. This week’s tech news includes a look back at the career of Apple’s Steve Jobs and a new survey on social-media use.

headline: Jamaican Kingpin Pleads Guilty in New York
text: Christopher Coke, a Jamaican drug trafficker whose arrest last summer came after a monthlong manhunt that left scores dead in Kingston, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to racketeering conspiracy charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Petraeus Retires, With a Warning
text: WASHINGTON — An era in the American military came to an end on Wednesday when David H. Petraeus, the most influential general of his generation, retired with a 17-gun salute and a warning that coming budget cuts should not lead to the “hollow Army” that occurred after the Vietnam War.

headline: Flooding in New Jersey
text: The Times’s Sam Dolnick reports on flooding in Paterson, N.J.

headline: Happiness, Philosophy and Science
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: As One Qaddafi Promises Peace, Another Calls for War
text: Two Arab satellite channels broadcast starkly different audio messages on Wednesday from men who both claimed to be sons of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

headline: After 9,382 Performances, Actor to Leave ‘Phantom’
text: As the Guinness World Record holder for the most performances in the same Broadway show, George Lee Andrews thought he had seen it all during his 23 years in “The Phantom of the Opera,” including 12 different actors in the title role and the stunning metamorphosis of a once-seedy Times Square. Yet he was shocked in May when the powers that be at “Phantom” revealed that they were not extending his six-month contract, which had been renewed more than 40 times before.

headline: Gallery Owner Stirs Hamptons Art Crowd
text: THE guests at the recent Ross School benefit at the Gallery Valentine in East Hampton, N.Y., were not necessarily recognizable types. The art on the walls was another matter. With a Hans Hoffman here and a Fernando Botero there, not to mention Sam Francis, George Condo and Damien Hirst, the star power was as bright as the dollar-sign silk screen by Andy Warhol in the back.

headline: Fashion Week Is Pruning Its Diesel Generators
text: Fashion Week is back, minus two diesel-powered generators.The event’s producers said they had plugged into Fordham University and the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center to help power their tents and get rid of two of nine portable generators that drew complaints about noise and fumes from Upper West Side neighbors last winter.

headline: OnStar for All Who Have the Wherewithal
text: Most people probably don’t think of General Motors as, ahem, the living definition of a technologically nimble company. But deep in the G.M. archipelago of cars, parts and wholly owned subsidiaries there sits a technological gem: OnStar.

headline: Saint Vitus, Greenpoint, Brooklyn
text: FEARFUL naïfs may assume that heavy-metal bars are cradles of malevolence where depraved longhairs slake their thirst with bats’ blood. But Saint Vitus, a gothic-themed bar in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, named after a Black Sabbath song, is actually a welcoming spot for downing cheap beers and listening to Pantera.

headline: Let’s Help Michele Bachmann
text: It ought to surprise no one that Representative Michele Bachmann is writing a memoir. We received the news yesterday in the form of a press release from Sentinel, an imprint of Penguin Group (USA). It read, “The book, currently untitled, will go on sale nationwide on November 21.”

headline: Reference Resources for the Budding Know-It-All
text: You could once gauge a family’s intellectual vitality by its living room bookshelves. If your family scored the trifecta of Encyclopedia Britannica, the Oxford English Dictionary and the World Almanac, you were ahead of the pack.

headline: For del Potro, a Return to Form
text: Before Wednesday, the last time Juan Martin del Potro of Argentina won a match at the United States Open, he beat Roger Federer in the men’s singles final in 2009.

headline: Now Playing | The World Premiere of When Saints Go Machine’s New Video
text: Historically, the D.J. culture of Germany has dominated its little neighbor Denmark, but that’s all changing. Pioneering a new and distinctive Copenhagen sound is the band When Saints Go Machine, whose hypnotic electro-pop is held together by the lead singer Nikolaj Manuel Vonsild’s soaring falsetto vocals, which have earned him comparisons to Arthur Russell and Antony Hegarty. As the band prepares to embark on a big tour of Britain, Vonsild talked to The Moment about the new video for the hit single “Kelly” off their latest album, “Konkylie.”

headline: Federal Hurricane Forecasters Did Their Job
text: It seems inevitable to have finger-pointing whenever a hurricane makes landfall. If the storm weakens, there are charges of alarmism and fear-mongering. If it veers or strengthens, hammered communities cry out. With Hurricane Irene, it was mostly the former, as various factions with axes to grind piled on the National Hurricane Center. (A case in point was Patrick Michaels, a climate scientist at the anti-regulatory Cato Institute who last Friday said the storm should be renamed “Hurricane Hype,” adding that he doubted it would “cough up even eight bodies.” With the death count far higher, he apologized through the Watts Up With That blog.)

headline: Bonds Avoids New Trial on Three Perjury Charges
text: Barry Bonds will not face a new trial on charges of lying to a federal grand jury about his use of steroids and human growth hormone, according to papers filed Wednesday in federal court.

headline: The Debt Non-Explosion
text: A conversation I had earlier today suggested that it might be worth pointing out a fact that isn’t as widely known as it should be: namely, that there has not been an explosion in debt over the past few years. There has been a big rise in federal debt, but this has gone along with a collapse in private borrowing, so that overall debt growth has been lower than it was in the pre-crisis years:

headline: Traveling Across Libya
text: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof finds signs of hope on the road to Tripoli.

headline: How AT&T Got to a Standoff With the Government
text: The Justice Department’s lawsuit to block AT&T‘s $39 billion takeover of T-Mobile USA took the company by surprise. But depending on whom you ask, it shouldn’t have.

headline: Watching That Home From Afar
text: WE’RE in the high season for the second home. Everywhere you look, as the Labor Day weekend approaches, someone is packing up for the Hamptons, the Vineyard, Nantucket or Tahoe. I’m told that there are unbounded thrills to be had on these sojourns, but I’ve never experienced them. Not only do I not own a second home, I don’t even own a first.

headline: Hip-Hop Finds an Artist to Believe In
text: HIP-HOP has long given shout-outs to alcoholic beverages, foreign cars and jewelry. But recently, an artist has been added to that list.

headline: Tough Talk Leads to Difficult Conversations
text: BOSTON — When David Ortiz comes home each night, his 7-year-old son, D’Angelo, often asks him questions about what went on during that night’s game. Ortiz, the Red Sox’ designated hitter, enjoys telling D’Angelo about a great pitch or a powerful home run, but sometimes — as was the case after Tuesday’s game between the Yankees and the Red Sox — Ortiz is forced to answer questions about a scuffle. And he does not like it.

headline: George Jensen’s Liquid Collection
text: A single sheet of stainless steel molded into a seemingly random, asymmetrical form: that’s the minimalist look that defines Liquid, a new collection from Georg Jensen.

headline: Music for the End of August
text: And hoping that next month is better.

headline: 19 Have Died of Heat This Summer, City Says
text: The heat wave that gripped the city in late July is turning out to have been a fairly deadly one. Fourteen people are now certified to have died of weather-related hyperthermia, combined with other medical conditions, from July 22 to July 25, the city medical examiner’s office said Wednesday. Five more died of the heat in August, bringing the total for the summer to 19.

headline: Nursing Bras That Show Mothers in More Than ‘Work Mode’
text: MATERNITY and nursing bras have long been the ugly stepsisters to gorgeously constructed lingerie. If you became pregnant or nursed your child, scratchy, unadorned, matronly bras — probably colored inconspicuously “nude” or white — were your lot. Elisabeth Dale, the founder of the Web site The Breast Life, which has bra reviews and health information, says she thinks this was because functionality and sex appeal can seem incompatible.

headline: An Airstream Dressed Up for Burning Man
text: A designer and her husband renovated a 1969 trailer to take to the annual festival, creating a Moorish-inspired home for the road.

headline: For Burning Man, an Airstream Done Up in Moorish Splendor
text: About 50,000 Burners, as attendees of the annual Burning Man festival are called, were expected to journey to the Black Rock Desert in Nevada this week for days of revelry in a makeshift city where art is everywhere but showers can be hard to come by. The festival, which began on Monday and runs through Monday, sold out in advance for the first time in its 25-year history.

headline: A Hero’s Legend and a Stolen Skull Rustle Up a DNA Drama
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Even with the best scientific techniques, you can’t always get what you want. But if you try, as the Rolling Stones put it, sometimes you get what you need.

headline: Shopping for Back-to-School Accessories With Jerry Helling
text: The president of Bernhardt Design, a North Carolina furniture company, set out in search of back-to-school accessories worthy of a well-designed desk.

headline: Back-to-School Accessories
text: AS president of the North Carolina furniture company Bernhardt Design, Jerry Helling has collaborated with a number of high-profile designers. But in recent years, he’s become increasingly invested in working with students.

headline: A Glass-Top Desk From Gallotti & Radice
text: Like many of the pieces made by the Italian furniture manufacturer Gallotti & Radice, the Lui desk has a streamlined design that fluidly mixes glass with a variety of other materials.

headline: In Maine, Gifts From the Sea, and the Landfill
text: PHIPPSBURG, Me.

headline: Since You Can’t Stay in Fallingwater ...
text: In 1910, when Frank Lloyd Wright designed the Park Inn and City National Bank building in downtown Mason City, Iowa, he most likely didn’t anticipate that one day it would be a boutique hotel. But the restored building recently reopened with 27 rooms, offering architecture enthusiasts the opportunity to spend the night in a Wright building.

headline: You’re Not a Stranger When You Leave
text: DANIEL RUF and Patrick Palme, budget-minded students from Hanover, Germany, drove across the United States this spring without paying for nearly any of their accommodations. During the trip, they stayed overnight in 20 cities with people they met through CouchSurfing, a social networking Web site whose members make their homes available to travelers free of charge.

headline: Sales at Calypso Home and Others
text: Furniture is 15 percent off and rugs are 20 percent off at Calypso Home, through Monday (a Lima 9-by-12-foot rug, originally $1,900, is $1,520; a silver woven stool, usually $350, is $297); 407 Broome Street (Lafayette Street), (212) 925-6200.

headline: Striped Wallpapers From Osborne & Little
text: “There’s something innately pleasing about a stripe,” noted Peter Osborne, the chief executive and head of design at Osborne & Little, the British wallpaper and fabric company.

headline: An Elegantly Frugal Rental in Maine
text: Using found and handmade furnishings, thrift and ingenuity, a talented couple furnished a home stylishly on a budget.

headline: Safely Above the New Orleans Parade
text: I AM writing this in an 1832 brick house on Julia Street in New Orleans, a place with all the mildew, mortar dust and karma you’d imagine a New Orleans building would have. I write, but don’t live, here — if living means more than a MacBook, a tomato sandwich and a passable amount of upkeep for my two rooms and myself. For part of each week, I leave my two daughters and my home in Jackson, Miss., 192 miles away, to coop myself up in a place famous for its live-music venues and restaurants.

headline: Homes for $599,000
text: A contemporary outside Charleston, S.C.; a bungalow in Los Angeles; and a house in New Orleans.

headline: What You Get for ... $599,000

headline: Speed and Spin: Nadal’s Lethal Forehand
text: Rafael Nadal’s forehand is a rare combination of speed and tremendous topspin. Here is a look at how he generates the stroke and how he uses it against his opponents.

headline: Activists Aim to Revitalize Israeli Protests
text: TEL AVIV — For many Israelis, the size of Saturday night’s protests against the high cost of living and for social justice will serve as a barometer of whether the popular movement that began in this Mediterranean city and swept the country this summer is thriving or fading.

headline: Vandeweghe Is Stopped in the Second Round
text: Coco Vandeweghe, the promising 19-year-old American who chose tennis over basketball, said she prefers to progress in a consistent rather than streaky manner. After losing in her second-round match against the steadier and more experienced Samantha Stosur, she will have to wait another year to try to reach the third round.

headline: Mother’s Long Vigil for Seattle Woman Jailed in Murder
text: PERUGIA, Italy — In the sweltering days of summer, the sun-scorched streets of this storied hilltop town echo with the indistinguishable conversations of world travelers here to explore its medieval and Renaissance palazzos or climb its steep alleys to catch a glimpse of the verdant Umbrian countryside.

headline: Obama Moves Jobs Speech After Skirmish With Boehner
text: WASHINGTON — Any hopes that a kinder, gentler bipartisan Washington would surface once Congress returns after Labor Day were summarily dashed on Wednesday when President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner clashed over, of all things, the date and time of the president’s much-awaited speech to the nation about his proposal to increase jobs and fix the economy.
